title: Dr. Laurel Blair Salton Clark: After Sea and Sky Moving on to Space
description: Laurel Blair Salton Clark had conquered the sea, diving with the Navy Seals and conducting medical evacuations from submarines off Scotland. She had penetrated the air as a flight surgeon aboard the Marine Attack Squadron of the Year.

Family will be sitting shiva Sunday at 158 Sagamore Drive, at the Hamlet at Old Oyster Bay, Plainview. Monday through Thursday services will be held at 3 Magnolia Lane, Woodbury.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHRECK, LAUREL
description: SCHRECK-Laurel. The staff of The Alan Guttmacher Institute mourns the loss of Laurel Schreck, our friend and former colleague, and extend their deepest sympathy to her husband, Josh Katz, and daughter, Anya.

title: McGreevey Proposes a $200 Million Increase in Aid to New Jersey's Schools
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey has decided to propose increased aid to schools in next year's budget, administration officials said today, but only if the Legislature agrees to eliminate property tax rebates for taxpayers making more than $100,000 a year.

title: New Jersey Doctors Find Unity in Fight to Limit Malpractice Awards
description: If New Jersey doctors make good on their vow to stage a partial work stoppage on Monday, they will not be the first to walk out over the high costs of medical liability and malpractice insurance.

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: CLINTON RECORDS ARE COMING QUICKLY Former President Bill Clinton has waived his right to restrict access to most records of confidential advice during his administration, opening the path for historians to study more quickly key decisions in the Clinton White House. But Mr. Clinton will not waive attorney-client privilege over issues like Whitewater and the Monica Lewinsky-Paula Jones investigations. Under the Presidential Records Act, former presidents can withhold the release of records for at least 5 years and up to 12 years under certain criteria. Mr. Clinton and the National Archives have agreed to release most of the records as soon as they are processed, said Bruce Lindsey, Mr. Clinton's lawyer. President Bush retains veto power over the release of any Clinton records, but Mr. Lindsey said he did not expect Mr. Bush to object. (AP)

title: Indian Point Battle Lines Are Redrawn
description: The state's decision this week not to approve the emergency plan for the area around the Indian Point nuclear complex has set in motion what is likely to be a long and complicated legal battle over the plant's future.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: A PROFIT AT HONDA The Honda Motor Company earned 115 billion yen ($958 million) in the October-December period, a 40 percent surge from the period a year earlier, thanks to strong sales in the United States and Europe. Honda, the No. 2 carmaker in Japan, also produced the best-selling car in Japan. Its Fit compact car unseated the Toyota Corolla, which had ranked No. 1 for three decades. Honda's motorcycle sales rose 40 percent in the period.

title: Trade Center Leaseholder Says Officials Are Ignoring His Right to Rebuild as He Wants
description: Days before city and state officials are scheduled to narrow the design competition for the World Trade Center site to two architecture teams, Larry A. Silverstein, the developer who holds the lease to the property, charged yesterday that rebuilding officials were ignoring his right to rebuild the site as he sees fit.

title: Gunman Surrenders in Mail Truck Hijacking
description: A man holding a gun to the throat of a postal worker forced her to drive her delivery truck around the city for hours today before releasing her unharmed and surrendering peacefully.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, ELIZABETH. LIZZIE
description: LEVIN-Elizabeth. Lizzie, you went too soon too fast. A wonderful friend, a marvelous person. Costco will never be the same. Our love to Gil, Alex and Ayissa, Michael and especially Roz and Kira. Harvey and Merrill

title: LeBron James Is Ruled Ineligible After Taking Gifts
description: LeBron James, the country's most visible high school basketball star, was stripped of his remaining eligibility yesterday because he accepted two sports jerseys from a Cleveland clothing store.

title: A Musical Love Fest for Two
description: The calendar may say that tomorrow is Groundhog Day, but at the Beacon Theater, without a doubt, Valentine's Day -- big heart, big beat and bright color -- is already here.

title: Freed Ayatollah Again Makes Voice Heard
description: The invisible man of Qum has returned to the battlefield of Islamic politics.

title: U.S. Incomes And Spending Both Gained In December
description: Americans made and spent more money in December, reports released today showed, helping the economy cling to a fifth consecutive quarter of growth. Midwest manufacturing expanded in January, the latest sign that demand may be picking up.

title: India, Out of Cheetahs, Seeks to Clone
description: Indian scientists have asked Iranian officials to lend them a pair of Asian cheetahs, which have been extinct in India for about half a century, for cloning. A team of scientists from the Center for Cellular and Molecular Biology in in the southern Indian city of Hyderabad are working on a project to copy the animal within five years. The request was made during the visit of Iran's president, Mohammad Khatami, to Hyderabad early this week.

title: Ex-Prosecutor Pleads Guilty In the Death Of His Mother
description: A former Westchester County prosecutor has pleaded guilty to manslaughter in the death of his mother, who had Alzheimer's disease and died of an infection after he neglected her, the authorities said today.

title: Suit Expected Against Star Of First Boston
description: Securities regulators have notified Frank P. Quattrone, a top investment banker at Credit Suisse First Boston, that they plan to file a civil suit against him, according to two people briefed on the matter.

title: An International School Lunch Tour
description: Congress has vowed to take up the highly polarized issue of school lunches this spring with the reauthorization of the law that helps states pay for school lunches. The attention comes not a moment too soon. While school lunches have never approached haute cuisine, some of us can recall a time when trays of mystery meat and creamed corn offered a sort of bonding experience, something we suffered through together, like showers after phys. ed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEEGER, BEVERLY
description: SEEGER-Beverly. Of Kings Point, NY, passed away on Thursday, January 30, 2003. She was born in New York City on September 22, 1930. She is survived by her husband, Hal Seeger of Kings Point; three daughters, Susan Seeger and Mindy Seeger of Los Angeles, CA., and Charlene Seeger of Kings Point; two sons, David Seeger of Palisades, NY and Efrem Seeger of Los Angeles, CA; ten grandchildren and two sisters, Evelyn Fisher of Teaneck, NJ and Dorothy Cooper of Jericho, NY. Services Sunday, February 2, 2003, 11:30AM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. Burial immediately following at the Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, ROBERT P.
description: JOHNSON-Robert P. Died January 26th, 2003; retired United States Army Colonel, member of the West Point Class of 1955, President of the Lee-Grant Chapter of the West Point Alumni Association, survived by his wife, Mary Alice, his daughter, Dr. Valerie Tyson and son Major Stephen Johnson, his grandchildren Justin and Claire Tyson, his sister Helen T. Lowe, his son-in-law Dr. Daryl Tyson and daughter-in-law Sabina Johnson. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to the Robert P. Johnson Scholarship Fund at All Hallows High School, 111 East 164th St, Bronx, NY 10452

title: F.A.O. SCHWARZ PARENT REACHES AGREEMENT WITH LENDERS
description: FAO Inc., parent of the F. A. O. Schwarz toy chain, reached a deal to continue using the cash collateral of its secured lenders to finance operations and pay its employees. A key to the agreement with the lenders, Wells Fargo Retail Finance and KBB Retail Assets, was a provision that calls for professional fees and expenses to be capped at $750,000. The deal also includes a provision that FAO emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection as a going concern or sell its assets before April 4. If that deadline is not met, FAO can be liquidated.

title: Afghan Women and Children Among 16 Dead in Bus Blast
description: At least 16 people, including women and children, were killed today when their minibus exploded on a bridge just outside the southern city of Kandahar. Local police officials blamed Taliban or other rebel forces for the explosion.

title: Cause of Fiery Fall Is Unknown; Ship Was Fleet's Oldest
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1  The space shuttle Columbia broke up this morning on re-entry into the earth's atmosphere, killing all seven astronauts aboard and sending fiery debris over Texas in the second loss of a space shuttle in 17 years.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: VATICAN: A BAN ON TRANSSEXUALS A Catholic news agency published what it said was a confidential Vatican document banning transsexuals from religious orders and forcing any clergy members who undergo a sex change to be expelled. Vatican officials were not available for comment and the document was not mentioned in the daily press release. According to the Rome-based Adista agency, the document is signed by Cardinal Eduardo Martinez Somalo, the head of religious orders for the Holy See. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Former Oil Chief Turns Himself In
description: The former president of the old state-owned oil company, Elf Aquitaine, turned himself in to the authorities after an appeals court in Paris upheld his conviction and a 30-month jail sentence for corruption. An arrest warrant had been issued for Lok Le Floch-Prigent, 59, who was in hiding when he was convicted last year on charges rising out of a vast scandal at Elf, which was privatized in 1994 and now forms part of the TotalFinaElf oil group. The court overturned the conviction of a former French foreign minister, Roland Dumas. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: From a Women's Jail, Anthology of Lives
description: Nineteen women listened closely in a classroom at the York Correctional Institution in Niantic, Conn., on a recent afternoon as Wally Lamb read aloud, not from one of his best-selling novels, but from a terse account that one of the women had written about her first day in prison. Her bare-bones sentences recorded lockups after meals, a bathroom with no privacy and a room crowded with warring roommates.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: New Job For Lieutenant Governor
description: Trustees at Florida Atlantic University selected the state's lieutenant governor, Frank Brogan, left, as the university's next president. Mr. Brogan, 49, who is expected to leave state government on March 1, earned a master's degree at Florida Atlantic and was state's education commissioner before being elected twice as lieutenant governor. Gov. Jeb Bush has not said whom he wants to replace Mr. Brogan. Terry Aguayo (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: GOVERNMENT APPEALS REACTOR RULING In an attempt to salvage a disputed nuclear energy project, the government appealed a court ruling that could prevent the resumption of operations at an accident-prone experimental nuclear reactor that uses so-called fast-breeder technology. On Monday, the Nagoya High Court in central Japan handed down what antinuclear campaigners described as an "epoch making" ruling that would effectively block use of a prototype reactor. The fast-breeder reactor, designed to produce more nuclear fuel than it consumes, has been shut since December 1995 after a huge leak of a liquid sodium coolant. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: Bush Meets Blair Amid Signs of Split on U.N. War Role
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain stood with President Bush today in warning Saddam Hussein that time is running out for Iraq to avoid war, but Mr. Bush and Mr. Blair appeared divided over how hard to press the United Nations Security Council for a new resolution supporting military action.

title: BUSH MEETS BLAIR AMID SIGNS OF SPLIT ON U.N. WAR ROLE
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain stood with President Bush today in warning Saddam Hussein that time is running out for Iraq to avoid war, but Mr. Bush and Mr. Blair appeared divided over how hard to press the United Nations Security Council for a new resolution supporting military action.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAGGER, ROBERT
description: JAGGER-Robert. The Kibel Companies regrets the passing of our dear friend and colleague. We will always remember your talent, dedication and good humor.

title: Briefly Noted
description: 2 GERMANS AIDED IRAQ A German court convicted two men of violating arms export laws by shipping drills to Iraq for the purpose of producing long-range artillery. The main defendant, Bernd Schompeter, 59, was sentenced to five years, three months in prison. His accomplice, Willi Heinz Ribbeck, 53, received two years' probation. Prosecutors said the drills, made by a German company, could be used to make artillery capable of launching chemical, biological or nuclear weapons. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: Ashcroft's Push For Execution Voids Plea Deal
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft has ordered federal prosecutors to seek the death penalty for a murder suspect, even though he had agreed to testify against others tied to a deadly Colombian drug ring in exchange for a life sentence.

title: Israelis Kill a Hamas Militant; Sharon's Party Gains 38th Seat
description: Israeli forces shot and killed a Hamas militant in the West Bank city of Jenin today in a gun battle outside a fire station in which a bystander was also killed.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day on Thursday with an article about regulators' concerns about the collision dangers posed both by sport utility vehicles and by pickup trucks referred incorrectly to the accident shown. The larger vehicle was a pickup, not an S.U.V. And it was the car that struck the pickup.

title: Critic's Notebook; Bravos at Opera Are Expected, But Booing?
description: Opera buffs tend to be passionate sorts with strong reactions. In some ways, a great performance of a favorite aria isn't over until the audience erupts in bravos.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CZUKOR, ALICE C.
description: CZUKOR-Alice C. 9/18/15-2/01/01. We remember you every day. John and Lester

title: A Friendship Sundered by Muslim Code of Honor
description: IT is 3 a.m. and the loneliness has become too much for Norma Khouri. Risking discovery, she dials the number of an aunt in Jordan, the homeland she fled three years ago in fear and anger and secrecy.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Airline's Loss Narrows
description: The privatized Spanish airline Iberia said its loss narrowed to 15.6 million euros ($17 million) in the fourth quarter from 88.7 million euros a year earlier as sales increased 4.4 percent. For the full year, profit tripled to 157 million euros despite a slight decline in revenue as a result of cost-cutting. The company forecast a difficult year in 2003 even without a war in Iraq. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: Sather May Be Looking to Deal During Weekend
description: The day after coaching his first game in the National Hockey League since 1994, Glen Sather, the Rangers' president, general manager and now head coach, flew to South Florida for this weekend's All-Star Game, where he will focus on his executive duties.

title: IRANIAN CLERIC REBUKES BUSH
description: Ayatollah Muhammad Yazdi, a member of Iran's conservative Guardian Council, lashed out at statements in President Bush's State of the Union address that said Iran was violating human rights and trying to develop weapons of mass destruction. Ayatollah Yazdi rejected the president's claims and responded with his own: that White House policies after the Sept. 11 terror attacks violated the rights of Muslim immigrants. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: Antiwar Sentiment Appears In County Seats and City Halls
description: Spurred by local antiwar sentiment, dozens of cities and counties around the country have passed resolutions imploring President Bush to slow down his confrontation with Iraq.

title: Poison Gas in Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: MEDICAID PROPOSAL WOULD GIVE STATES MORE SAY ON COSTS
description: The Bush administration proposed fundamental changes in Medicaid today that would give states vast new power to reduce, eliminate or increase benefits for millions of low-income people, including many who are elderly or disabled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARPER, MURIEL A. (NEE DRUMGOOLE)
description: HARPER-Muriel A. (nee Drumgoole), 85. Of Middletown, NJ, on January 30, 2003 at home. Beloved wife of the late Eugene W. Much loved mother of Eugene W, Jr, James D, Robert F, Gerard E, Thomas P, Daniel J, Mary T, and the late Lawrence J. and William M. She tenaciously clung to and revered life in all its forms. A funeral liturgy will be held Monday, February 3, at 10:30 A.M., at St. Mary's RC Church, New Monmouth, NJ. Reposing at the John F. Pfleger Funeral Home, 115 Tindall Rd, Middletown, NJ, Saturday, February 1, 7-9 PM and Sunday, February 2, 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Memorial donations may be made to the Rosary Hill Home, Hawthorne, NY 10532.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRADLEY, ANGELA
description: BRADLEY-Angela. Of Sayville, on January 31, 2003. Mother of Mark J. Bradley, James Chappel and Michelle Chappel-Valerio. Sister of Mary C. Carlucci, Francis J. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2 to 6 PM, Sunday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Monday, February 3, at 10 AM.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Mozambique: Convictions In Reporter's Killing
description: Six men accused of killing a prominent journalist, Carlos Cardoso, were convicted and sentenced to terms ranging from 23 to 28 years in prison. Mr. Cardoso was killed in November 2000 after he wrote articles exposing bank embezzlement and other wrongdoing by members of the country's elite. Several of the convicted men accused President Joaquim Chissano's son, Nyimpine, of ordering the killing, and Judge Augusto Paulino has vowed a thorough investigation. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUHAUS, ROBERT HARRY
description: NEUHAUS-Robert Harry. Of Fort Lee, NJ. Beloved husband of Donna. Cherished son of Esther and the late Jerome. Devoted father of Jonathan and Todd. Dear brother of Susan Cohen, and Linda Levy. Services Sunday 10:45 am at The Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, Paramus, NJ. For information call ''Gutterman-Musicant'', 800-522-0588.

title: NBC Executive Is Named Network President
description: NBC realigned its top management structure this week, adding significantly to the duties of a longtime executive, Randy Falco, and elevating him to a new position, group president of the NBC network.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Utility Acquisition Advances
description: The German utility E.ON won permission to take control of the gas company Ruhrgas after all nine opponents of the deal dropped their legal cases. The out-of-court settlement opened the way for E.ON to proceed with the acquisition of a majority stake in Ruhrgas, Europe's largest gas importer. With two opponents, the utilities EnBW and Fortum, E.ON said it essentially agreed on an exchange of shareholdings. The settlement with the other opponents consisted of supply contracts and financial payments of about 90 million euros ($97 million). Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Snow Paralyzes Country
description: Much of Britain ground to a halt because of blizzards and freezing weather, with many airports closed, flights delayed and some drivers stranded in their cars overnight on major highways blocked by snow drifts and crashed or abandoned vehicles. Transport Secretary Alistair Darling demanded to know why so much of the road and rail network had become paralyzed. ''Snowfall in January is hardly unexpected,'' he said. Londoners seeking to escape the street congestion by traveling underground found large sections of the city's subway lines shut down. The Freight Transport Association complained that despite forecasts of severe weather, highway crews failed to salt and sand major arteries. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DESROSIERS, DENISE
description: DESROSIERS - Denise. Of West 76 Street, passed away on January 29. An extraordinary artist, Denise was an avid equestrian and lover of animals, but she'll be remembered most for her inexhaustible spirit and for being the most loyal, dependable and loving of sister, aunt and friend. We will miss her.

title: National Briefing: South
description: FLORIDA: NEW JOB FOR LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR Trustees at Florida Atlantic University selected the state's lieutenant governor, Frank Brogan, left, as the university's next president. Mr. Brogan, 49, who is expected to leave state government on March 1, earned a master's degree at Florida Atlantic and was state's education commissioner before being elected twice as lieutenant governor. Gov. Jeb Bush has not said whom he wants to replace Mr. Brogan. Terry Aguayo (NYT)

title: More Digits to Dial
description: Remember when making a long-distance call was an event? You'd self-importantly insist on a little quiet around you, dial an operator and prepare abridged versions of what you were going to say.

title: Japan Posts Gloomy Numbers, And Fears of Recession Return
description: Japan's jobless rate matched a record high in December, one of several indicators that show that the economy stalled in the last quarter of 2002.

title: Cause of Fiery Fall Is Unknown; Ship Was Fleet's Oldest
description: The space shuttle Columbia, streaking across a bright blue Texas sky at about 3.5 miles a second, broke up as it re-entered the Earth's atmosphere this morning, barely 15 minutes before it was to have landed at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida.

title: Details Given On New Plans To Aid Saving
description: The Bush administration today unveiled its plan to create two new types of savings accounts that would allow a couple to save as much as $30,000 a year in funds that could be withdrawn, with any investment gains, free of taxes.

title: Triumphant Return of Israeli Space Hero Turns Into Nightmare
description: MODIIN, Israel, Feb. 1  He was the newest hero of a country yearning for one, and in towns like this one across Israel today people gathered in front of their television sets, happy and expectant, to watch the homecoming of Col. Ilan Ramon, Israel's first astronaut.

title: The Pataki Plan For the Mentally Ill
description: To the Editor:

title: ITALY DETAINS 28 PAKISTANIS
description: The Italian police said they had arrested 28 Pakistanis on charges of terrorist activity after discovering explosives and maps in a Naples apartment during a routine search for illegal immigrants and prostitutes. The police said they found about 750 grams of explosives, false documents, maps of the southern city and long fuses during a sweep early Thursday. The arrests echoed a similar incident in the northern city of Rovigo last week, when the police arrested five Moroccans found with explosives and maps of London. More than 100 people have been arrested in Italy for suspected links to international terrorist groups since the Sept. 11 attacks, although most have gone free for lack of evidence. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | South Africa: South Africa: Trade Surplus
description: South Africa posted its biggest trade surplus in 18 months in December, reversing a deficit in November, after imports of oil and machinery slumped, the Revenue Service reported. The larger-than-expected surplus of 6.1 billion rand ($707 million) was in contrast to a deficit of 605 million rand in November and the average analysts' forecast of a 2.1 billion rand surplus.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Ending Diplomatic Crisis With Morocco
description: Spain and Morocco have agreed to exchange ambassadors in a move ending the diplomatic dispute that peaked in July in a military clash over the uninhabited Parsley Island, claimed by both countries. The two Mediterranean nations have clashed recently over fishing rights, immigration and the future of the Western Sahara, but King Mohammed VI of Morocco said he was working for ''the normalization of relations of friendship and cooperation between the two peoples.'' Emma Daly (NYT)

title: A Wanderer for Peace Has Run Out of Road
description: It appears that Reza K. Baluchi made a string of serious miscalculations.

title: Victory Stands For Seton Hall
description: An extra man in pro football draws a 5-yard penalty. An extra man in hockey draws a 2-minute penalty. An extra man in college basketball draws a technical foul and two free throws, but only if the game officials detect it.

title: Teachers' Chief Is Outsider in Schools Shake-Up
description: At the end of the whirlwind day last month when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced his plan to restructure the New York City school system, Chancellor Joel I. Klein stopped by a packed meeting of teachers' union delegates.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Higher Spending On Schools
description: Despite a budget crisis, state lawmakers approved an 8 percent increase in state spending on public schools, community colleges and universities. Gov. Ronnie Musgrove, who called on legislators to finance school budgets fully before tackling other state spending, is expected to sign the measures next week. The spending includes the third year of a five-year plan to raise teacher salaries to the average of the Southeast region.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TILSON, PHYLLIS WIEGAND
description: TILSON-Phyllis Wiegand, 93. Of Old Chatham, NY, died January 29, 2003, after a brief illness. She was the daughter of American landscape artist, Gustave Wiegand. She was predeceased by husband Paul in 1986 and is survived by two daughters, Phyllis Piotrow and Ann Burnham, and six grandchildren and twelve great-grandchildren.

title: Giuliani Firm Confirms It Hired L.I. Priest Barred From Ministry
description: A prominent Long Island priest who was barred from the ministry last year after an allegation of sexual abuse has been quietly working for the consulting business of Rudolph W. Giuliani, a Giuliani spokeswoman confirmed yesterday.

title: Kovalev Has N.H.L. Ready to Talk Trade
description: When Aleksei Kovalev of the Pittsburgh Penguins walked across the lobby of a fancy hotel here, a team executive in town for the National Hockey League All-Star Game saw Kovalev, the talented right wing from Russia, and alluded to all the trade rumors involving him. ''I wish they would hurry up and trade him,'' the executive said. ''Because until they do, they're clogging up all the other deals.''

title: Taking a Perverse Pride In a Double Disaster
description: In team competition, players sometimes take a twisted pleasure in announcing, after comparing scores, ''We lost that board in both rooms.'' If both pairs have had a disaster on the same board, the net result is usually less unpleasant than having disasters on different boards. They are saying, in effect, ''It might have been worse.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STILES, NED B.
description: STILES-Ned B., 70. Of Greenwich, CT, died January 29, after a brief illness. Husband of Deborah Fiedler Stiles; father of Jessica, Michael, Andrew and Peter. Brother of Andrew. Service Monday, February 3, at 11:30 AM, at Christ Church, 254 E. Putnam Ave, Greenwich, CT. In lieu f flowers the family requests that contributions be made to Memorial Sloan - Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Ave, NYC 10021.

title: G.O.P. Makes It Official: New York Is Site of Its 2004 Convention
description: New York City officially became the site of the 2004 Republican National Convention today, with planners announcing that they had already lined up choice spots for various events.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, JOHN G.
description: SULLIVAN-John G. The officers, employees and agents of Brown Harris Stevens are deeply saddened by the death of our colleague John G. Sullivan, a talented agent, musician, sculptor and collector. Our sincere condolences to his two brothers, Dale Sullivan, Robert Sullivan and their families. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to Memorial Sloan - Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Avenue, NY, NY 10021.

title: The Qaeda Vipers In Europe's Bosom
description: Make no mistake: the United States is still Al Qaeda's main enemy. But it's become morbidly obvious in the last few months, with terrorist attacks in Indonesia and Kenya, that Al Qaeda has expanded its ''fields of jihad.'' That development should be a particular cause of concern for Europe, where much of the planning of the Sept. 11 attacks was done and where perhaps thousands of Al Qaeda affiliates live. Just this week, the Italian police arrested 28 Pakistanis suspected of links to Al Qaeda.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ORBITAL SCIENCES, Dulles, Va., a maker of rockets and satellites, won two 10-year contracts valued at $475 million from the United States Air Force to make rockets for use as missile-defense-system test targets.

title: APPLIED MATERIALS SAYS FIRST-QUARTER ORDERS FELL 35%
description: Applied Materials, the world's biggest maker of computer-chip production equipment, said yesterday that first-quarter orders fell more than forecast. Orders sank 35 percent in the quarter, which ended Sunday, compared with those in the fourth quarter. In November, Applied predicted a 20 percent drop. The slump in new bookings is the steepest in at least seven quarters, a sign that demand for chip equipment may not recover as soon as investors expected. Shares of Applied Materials fell 98 cents, or 7.6 percent, to $11.97.

title: Trial Linked to Sept. 11 Attacks Stalls in Clash Over Secret Data
description: A judge unexpectedly delayed the conclusion of the first criminal trial connected to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks today, protesting the government's refusal to disclose classified information about a potential witness who might help exonerate the defendant.

title: AIDS, Africa and Our Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, EUGENIE
description: KAUFMAN - Eugenie. On January 30, 2003. Loving sister of Helaine Banner. Dear sister-in-law of Jerry. Devoted aunt and great aunt. Graveside service Sunday, 11:30AM, at King David Cemetery, Putnam Valley, N.Y.

title: Corrections
description: A note in Weekend yesterday about the Metropolitan Museum of Art, with an article about bird-watching among the paintings there, referred incompletely to admission prices. Admission is free for children under 12 accompanied by an adult, as well as for members.

title: Qaeda Member Pleads Guilty To 1990's Conspiracy Charge
description: One of the last remaining Al Qaeda operatives being held in Manhattan on criminal charges pleaded guilty yesterday to a charge that carries a maximum prison sentence of 10 years.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Government Appeals Reactor Ruling
description: In an attempt to salvage a disputed nuclear energy project, the government appealed a court ruling that could prevent the resumption of operations at an accident-prone experimental nuclear reactor that uses so-called fast-breeder technology. On Monday, the Nagoya High Court in central Japan handed down what antinuclear campaigners described as an ''epoch making'' ruling that would effectively block use of a prototype reactor. The fast-breeder reactor, designed to produce more nuclear fuel than it consumes, has been shut since December 1995 after a huge leak of a liquid sodium coolant. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: The Brains Behind Bush's War Policy
description: Any history of the Bush administration's march toward war with Iraq will have to take account of long years of determined advocacy by a circle of defense policy intellectuals whose view that Saddam Hussein can no longer be tolerated or contained is now ascendant.

title: Mexican Energy Giant Lumbers Into Hazy Future
description: The view from the 44th-floor offices of Ral Muoz Leos is both breathtaking and dismal. All the city lies beneath him, steeped in an ocean of smog.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEEDS, LAURENCE C. III.
description: LEEDS-Laurence C. III. Our wonderful Cary, devoted son, beloved brother, uncle, grandson and nephew. We admired and respected you so much. Strong, kind, sensitive, caring, generous, proud, brave, independent, beautiful soul. Gallant, chivalrous, charismatic. Handsome, graceful, marvelous athlete. Brilliant, world ranked tennis star. Wimbledon semi-finalist. Graduate of Collegiate School and Yale University, class of 1979, attended the Wharton Graduate School of Business. Inquisitive, thoughtful, successful entrepreneur. Always the sought after, kind and loyal friend. You made an indelible impression everywhere you went and on everyone you met. You brightened our days, made us laugh, cry, and then laugh more. We wanted to be where you were. You changed our lives. Cary, you are the shining star in the eyes of Samuel, Michael, Benjamin, Nicholas and Olivia. You will always be their hero and ours. You were so brave always, overcoming great adversity, rebuilding your world, finding happiness. You inspired us with your courage and we will always take great pride in your achievements. You left us at the prime of your life and we will miss you with all our heart everyday. A beautiful soul. Dalia, Larry, Tracy, Evan, Ashley, Christopher. A service will be held on Sunday, February 2, at 11:30 AM, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, NYC. 212-288-3500. In lieu of flowers, donations in Cary's memory may be sent to The New York Junior Tennis League, 24-16 Queens Plaza South, Long Island City, NY 11101, an organization that provides free tennis programs in NYC's public elementary and middle schools.

title: NASA Press Conference
description: Following is text of NASA's midafternoon press conference from the Johnson Space Center in Houston regarding the Columbia Space Shuttle, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: World Briefing | Asia: Turkmenistan: Adding To Convictions List
description: Ten more people were convicted this week for what President Saparmurat Niyazov has said was a plot to assassinate him, bringing the total convicted to 56, according to the government-controlled news media. In trials that human rights organizations have said are reminiscent of Stalin's 1930's show trials, the accused, many of them political opponents of Mr. Niyazov, have been given sentences of between five years and life in prison. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: City College Senior Seeks Yet Another Record
description: Lauren Cargill's 2,000th point came in the dimly lighted gym at the City College of New York late at night on Jan. 16. Most in the sparse crowd had already drifted away, leaving a scattering of people spread across the rows of bleachers. City College was beating Medgar Evers College by more than 30 points, and there was only one thing left to see.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Petrochemical Profit Rises
description: India's largest petrochemicals company, Reliance Industries, said profit for the quarter ended in December doubled from a year earlier. The company said profit increased to 10.83 billion rupees ($225.62 million) from 5.15 billion rupees ($107.29 million). Reliance Industries is part of the Reliance Group, India's largest industrial conglomerate with holdings in oil, telecommunications and power. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Honeywell Posts a $1.4 Billion 4th-Quarter Loss
description: Honeywell International, the maker of cockpit electronics, said today that it had a $1.47 billion fourth-quarter loss as it settled asbestos claims and profit from airplane parts and automated controls declined.

title: National Briefing | West: California: $13 Million Payment In Power Case
description: Reliant Resources, one of the companies involved in the California energy crisis of 2000-2001, agreed to pay the state $13.8 million for withholding electricity for two days in June 2000. The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, which negotiated the settlement, said Reliant traders withheld electricity from the California grid to drive up prices. Reliant Resources, based in Houston, called it an ''isolated situation'' that stemmed from unauthorized actions by some traders. The settlement does not address the issue of whether Reliant and other companies deliberately withheld electricity from California, leading to huge price increases, power shortages and blackouts. John M. Broder (NYT)

title: Ending the 212 Clique
description: Beginning today, New Yorkers must dial 1, plus the area code, plus the seven-digit telephone number, to complete any local telephone call made within or between New York City boroughs. That's 11 digits in total, whether the call is from Manhattan to Manhattan or Brooklyn to Queens. The Federal Communications Commission says this change will eliminate the hurdle faced by phone companies that can't offer new customers the beloved 212 area code -- thus fostering local telephone service competition. Regardless, Manhattanites are sure to complain. But for longtime residents of the outer boroughs like me, this is sweet justice.

title: Capt. David M. Brown: A Circus Performer and a Top Aviator
description: Trapeze artist. Stilt walker. Test pilot. Doctor. David M. Brown had a special blend of the right stuff.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: UAL Has Big Quarterly Loss And Ends Year Deep in Red

title: A New Name For Comiskey Park
description: The Chicago White Sox yesterday announced a $68 million deal that will change the name of Comiskey Park, ending a 93-year association with the Comiskey name.

title: Martha Graham's Eerie Visions of War
description: The Martha Graham Dance Company has been impressive throughout its winter season, which concludes tomorrow night at the Joyce Theater in Chelsea (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street). On Thursday night it offered a superlative performance that featured debuts in several major roles. Its highlight was an emotionally shattering account of sketches from ''Chronicle,'' a suite of dances concerning war and unrest that Graham choreographed in 1936, which look eerily timely.

title: New Zealanders Explain Why They Left to Sail for Swiss
description: The question has haunted many New Zealanders for two years: why did the famed skipper Russell Coutts and his tactician, Brad Butterworth, leave their country's sailing team to join the Swiss billionaire Ernesto Bertarelli's Alinghi team?

title: Political Memo; These Men Don't Brawl Or Bicker; How Odd
description: Plainly put, Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg are not behaving the way New Yorkers expect them to.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: A Profit At Honda
description: The Honda Motor Company earned 115 billion yen ($958 million) in the October-December period, a 40 percent surge from the period a year earlier, thanks to strong sales in the United States and Europe. Honda, the No. 2 carmaker in Japan, also produced the best-selling car in Japan. Its Fit compact car unseated the Toyota Corolla, which had ranked No. 1 for three decades. Honda's motorcycle sales rose 40 percent in the period. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: A Sign That U.S. Military May Use Turkey as a Base
description: Senior Turkish officials signaled their willingness late today to let the American military use Turkey as a base to attack Iraq, publicly calling on their Parliament to prepare the country for a possible war.

title: Cmdr. William C. McCool: Carrying a Memento of Home
description: When Cmdr. William C. McCool of the Navy, the pilot of the space shuttle Columbia, took off on Jan. 16, he carried a piece of his hometown with him: a spirit towel for the Coronado Mustangs, his high school football team in Lubbock, Tex.

title: President Bush's Remarks
description: The following is a transcript of remarks by the President on the loss of Space Shuttle Columbia:

title: World Briefing | Africa: Algeria: Chirac To Make State Visit
description: President Jacques Chirac of France will make a state visit to Algeria from March 2 to 4 as part of French efforts to improve relations. On Feb. 5, the Algerian president, Abdelaziz Bouteflika, will visit Paris. It will be Mr. Chirac's second visit to Algeria -- but his first official state visit -- and the fourth by a French president since Algeria obtained its independence from France in 1962. Relations between France and Algeria have been difficult and complicated since Algeria won its independence after a bitter eight-year war that caused the death of hundreds of thousands and the expulsion of large numbers of French settlers. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURRAN, DR. JOHN P., (M.D.)
description: CURRAN-Dr. John P., (M.D.) Devoted husband of Juanita. Beloved father of Maureen Kleinman, Kathryn, Michael, John Patrick and Michele Cali. Loving grandfather of eight grandchildren. Reposing at Pitta Funeral Home, 300 McDonald Avenue, Brooklyn until Monday, 10AM. Mass of Christian Burial at Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, Fort Hamilton Parkway and East 4th Street at 10:30 A.M. Interment Greenwood Cemetery. Visiting 2 to 5 and 7 to 9:30PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, RUTHVEN W.
description: ROBERTS-Ruthven W. Died Sunday, January 26, 2003. Husband of Beverly JosephsRoberts, father of Fitzroy, Lyndon and Ellana Roberts. Viewing will be held on Sunday, February 2, 2003 from 4-6 PM. Funeral service at 6PM at The Christian Fellowship S.D.A. Church, 779 Schenectady Ave, Brooklyn, NY. Interment Cypress Hills Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY on Monday, February 3, 2003 at 9:30AM.

title: Kidd Sits, but the Nets Have Plenty in Reserve
description: It was the sort of image that floats through Byron Scott's most horrific nightmares. The Nets took the floor tonight with Jason Kidd watching from the bench in street clothes, sidelined with a strained groin muscle. On the nightmare scale, that ranks right behind the image of Kidd in another team's uniform.

title: Corrections
description: The Floyd Norris column in Business Day yesterday, about economic policies in Europe, misstated the name of the firm that employs Robert Barbera, a chief economist who said the United States had achieved nearly twice the growth of France and almost three times that of Germany over the last decade. It is ITG/Hoenig, not ING.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a vote by the Senate Judiciary Committee to approve the nomination of Miguel Estrada to a federal appeals court misstated the position taken by the Hispanic advocacy group La Raza on his nomination. While La Raza expressed concern about Mr. Estrada, it did not oppose him.

title: In Freestyle, a Finn Halts The Americans' Daring Streak
description: The Americans made a statement in the men's moguls competition at the freestyle skiing world championships, but it was Mikko Ronkainen of Finland who delivered a near-flawless run late in the competition to take the gold today at Deer Valley Resort.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in Escapes yesterday with a capsule report in the Quick Escapes column about Scottsdale, Ariz., was published in error. It showed Taliesin, the Frank Lloyd Wright house in Spring Green, Wis., not his Taliesin West house in Scottsdale.

title: All the Way Back From Near Amputation
description: Hermann Maier looked shocked at the crush of photographers and reporters as he blew into town today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   DONOFRIO, MICHAEL T.
description: DONOFRIO-Michael T. Dear Dad, never a dull moment, right? We all wish you were here! Missing you always. Love, Mom, Michael, Bob and Gay

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Spare Times for Children column of Weekend yesterday for the Special Needs Camp Fair today at the Church of St. Paul the Apostle in Manhattan misstated the church's address. It is at Columbus Avenue and 60th Street, not 50th Street.

title: Ryanair Orders 100 Planes; Agrees to Buy an Ailing Rival
description: Ryanair, the discount Irish airline, has committed itself to buying 100 more 737-800 aircraft from Boeing, less than a year after ordering 150 of the planes, the companies said today.

title: Admiral Seeks Deterrent Force In Korea Crisis
description: The commander of American forces in the Pacific, Adm. Thomas B. Fargo, has requested additional air and naval forces as a deterrent against North Korea, in the first military response to the escalating crisis over the country's nuclear program, Pentagon officials said tonight.

title: Accounts Chock-Full, Or a Plan Half Empty?
description: The White House's proposal to simplify and expand tax-preferred savings accounts has just one problem: it may not increase saving.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Officers Suspended For Chase
description: The Detroit Police Department suspended 10 officers for defying an order to cease a high-speed chase that ended in death. The chase began with two officers trailing a stolen car. A convoy of five cruisers joined for backup. Minutes later, a supervisor radioed for the chase to be halted. One cruiser pulled off, but 10 ''young, aggressive officers'' continued the pursuit for 17 miles at speeds exceeding 60 miles an hour, Deputy Chief Harold Cureton said. One of the police cruisers slammed into an oncoming vehicle, killing a man. Anand Giridharadas (NYT)

title: Mary Ellis, London Star of Stage and Screen, Is Dead at 105
description: Mary Ellis, the young opera singer for whom Rudolf Friml wrote ''Rose-Marie'' in 1924 and who later became the queen of musicals in London, died there on Thursday at her home on Eaton Square. She was 105, including the three years that Hollywood publicists subtracted in the 1930's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEAHEY, MICHAEL I.
description: LEAHEY-Michael I., 46. Of Irvington, NY, formerly of Nyack, NY, suddenly on January 30, 2003. Founder and Director of Clinical Trials at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, past Director of the Office of Cardiac Research at Columbia Presbyterian. Beloved husband of Lynn (nee Davey), loving father of James Patrick and Katherine Michaela. Beloved son of Edward B. Leahey Sr., MD and Mary (nee Carlin) Leahey. Beloved brother of Mimi Leahey Nangle, Anne Leahey, Frances Leahey, Patricia Meriam, the late Joseph Leahey and the late Edward B. Leahey Jr., MD. Cherished uncle of 15 nieces and nephews. Funeral services Monday 10 am, Church of St. Barnabas, N. Broadway, Irvington, NY. Visiting Saturday 7-9 PM & Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Edwards - Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue, (Exit 17 Saw Mill) Dobbs Ferry, NY. Memorials to the Edward B. Leahey, Jr. Foundation, 156 Strawtown Road, West Nyack, New York 10994.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBURG, ETHEL
description: GREENBURG-Ethel. January 31, 2003. Beloved wife of the late William Greenburg. Loving nother of Jonnie Greene and her husband Roger and Susan Wood Richardson and her husband Randolph. Cherished grandmother of Tracey Riese and her husband Phillip and Seth Greene and his wife Marina. Proud great grandmother of Sophie and Lillian Riese. Loving aunt of numerous nieces and nephews. We will all miss her. The family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St., Sunday 5-7PM with a service on Monday, February 3, 11:30 at Frank E. Campbell.

title: British Child Sex Charges
description: Two Cambridgeshire police officers who helped search for two missing girls last August were arraigned today in a Suffolk crown court on unrelated child sex charges.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Wednesday about the Modern Art Museum of Fort Worth misspelled the given name of an artist with work in the collection. He is Clyfford Still, not Clifford.

title: Grand Jury To Convene In Jets Case
description: A Nassau County grand jury will convene on or about Feb. 10 to examine allegations that a Jets player pushed a 60-year-old limousine driver to the ground in December, the lawyer for the driver said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SELVERNE, MARTIN M.
description: SELVERNE-Martin M. Who can ever forget such a fine man! Forever missed. Your Famil

title: Corrections
description: A picture yesterday with the obituary of the Broadway producer Lester Osterman was published in error. The subject was not identified. A picture of Mr. Osterman appears today, on Page B8.

title: Facing 'Common Enemy,' Terrorism and Weapons of Mass Destruction
description: Following is the transcript of a White House news conference yesterday by President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, as recorded by Federal News Service Inc. The transcript is also online at nytimes.com/international.

title: Venezuela Pumps More Oil, Adding Pressure on Strikers
description: Though hammered by a 61-day strike, Venezuela's oil industry is now pumping three times the crude it was in December and will soon meet contractual commitments that were scrapped when the walkout began, the president of the state-run petroleum company said today.

title: Col. Ilan Ramon: Pilot Embraced Role as a Symbol for Jews
description: Col. Ilan Ramon, the Israeli astronaut who died today aboard the space shuttle Columbia, was a soft-spoken combat pilot conscious of the importance of symbols and history, and the role he played in both.

title: Col. Rick D. Husband: A Lifelong Dream of Being an Astronaut
description: It took Rick D. Husband four tries to convince NASA to let him become an astronaut. The 45-year-old Air Force colonel from Amarillo, Tex., had yearned to fly in outer space since he was a child.

title: ORASURE WINS APPROVAL FOR EXPANDED USE OF H.I.V. TEST
description: OraSure Technologies said yesterday that it had received federal approval for expanded use of its rapid H.I.V. test. OraSure's test, which can diagnose H.I.V. in 20 minutes rather than the week that previous tests required, was approved in November for use in laboratories at about 38,000 doctors' offices and hospitals. Health officials now want the product used in settings like outreach clinics and by community organizations so more people can be tested for H.I.V. Stock in Orasure rose $1.65, or 27 percent, to $7.85 a share.

title: MORE CZECH TROOPS TO KUWAIT
description: The Czech Republic sent another 70 troops to join its chemical warfare protection unit in Kuwait; 360 Czech troops are already stationed there. The Czech Parliament last week agreed to send the reinforcements at the request of the United States. Military analysts say the Czech unit will probably be used to protect Kuwaitis in the event of a chemical or biological weapons attack by Iraq. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about an Iraqi invitation to the two top United Nations weapons inspectors to return to Baghdad before their next report to the Security Council in mid-February reversed their functions in some copies. Hans Blix heads the United Nations Monitoring, Verification and Inspections Commission, known as Unmovic; Mohammed ElBaradei heads the International Atomic Energy Agency.

title: Study Confirms What Drivers Long Suspected: Bumpy Roads
description: Buckle up, and hold on tight.

title: Duke Crazies Ready for Women's No. 1 vs. 2
description: The first tent at ''G-ville'' was pitched Thursday night. The inhabitants, students at Duke, were planning to camp out for two days to be at the head of the line and get the best seats for Saturday night's women's basketball game against Connecticut at Cameron Indoor Stadium.

title: In China, Quick Rise And Death Of a Tycoon
description: Li Haicang and Feng Yinliang were old friends, schoolmates and fellow villagers, and their transaction sounded common enough: Mr. Feng wanted to sell a patch of land to Mr. Li, who wanted to expand his steel factory.

title: Jonesville Journal; Pitching In As Town Hits Hard Times
description: This town of 236 souls is stone-broke. Founded about 1865, Jonesville now has $359 in the bank. It owes the trash company $5,966.25.

title: Critics Say Albany Is Wasting Insurance Windfall
description: When Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield first announced that it might go public in 1996, the company's press release cheerfully promised that the change would mean an additional $7 million a year in taxes for New York State.

title: Unflappable Eisley Energizes the Knicks
description: Howard Eisley stepped back and faded a bit, off balance but still confident that his 21-foot jumper would hit the spot. And why not?

title: Pentagon and Companies In Agreement on Spectrum
description: Technology companies and the Pentagon have reached an agreement to unlock a swath of spectrum for the next generation of wireless devices, officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUTHERLAND, NORMAN
description: SUTHERLAND-Norman. Of Ridgewood, NJ, on January 29, 2003. Retired from New York City Housing Authority and Sandcastle Inc. Husband and best friend of Elizabeth Cameron. Father of Scott, Pat Harper, Kenny and Teresa Rao. Grandpa of 10. Poppy of 1 great-grandson. Visiting Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9PM at C.C. Van Emburgh Funeral Home, Ridgewood, NJ (201445-0344).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAD, MORTON
description: GRAD-Morton. Passed away Wednesday. He was 98. Born in Debrecen, Hungary, May 24, 1904, he was editor of the Hungarian weekly newspaper Magyar Szo for 51 years and wrote several books over that span including ''How the Hungarians Saved Western Civilization,'' released in 1996, under the pen name of Zoltan Deak. In 1984 he received, along with co-honoree Nobel Laureate Dr. Albert SzentGyorgyi (discoverer of Vitamin C), the Medal of Honor from the Hungarian government for contributions to the arts, culture, and science. He will be remembered as a loving and gentle husband and father, and for his passionate advocacy of world peace. He leaves a wife, Fay, and two sons, Robert and Peter. Services will be Sunday, 10 AM, at the Davis/Garlick Funeral Home, 14 Lecount Place, New Rochelle, New York.

title: Face That Stirred Cambodian Riots
description: Her nickname is Kob. A sweet-faced young actress, she is almost as popular on Cambodian television as she is here in her homeland.

title: Editors' Note; Parking Rules
description: Because of the Asian Lunar New Year, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: J.D.L. Member In Plea Accord On Bomb Plot
description: A longtime member of the Jewish Defense League agreed to plead guilty to civil rights and explosives-related charges today in connection with a plot to blow up a mosque and a congressman's field office.

title: Michael Jackson Is Sued by Sotheby's
description: Sotheby's auction house filed suit yesterday against Michael Jackson's production company, saying the entertainer had refused to pay for two paintings worth more than $1.3 million that he had successfully bid for in October.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican: A Ban On Transsexuals
description: A Catholic news agency published what it said was a confidential Vatican document banning transsexuals from religious orders and forcing any clergy members who undergo a sex change to be expelled. Vatican officials were not available for comment and the document was not mentioned in the daily press release. According to the Rome-based Adista agency, the document is signed by Cardinal Eduardo Martnez Somalo, the head of religious orders for the Holy See. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Indian Leader Cites Poverty and Pleads for Aid
description: The president of the National Congress of American Indians, which represents more than 250 tribes, called on Congress and President Bush today to ''make good on its word'' to provide financial aid for education, housing and health care while respecting the tribes' right to self-governance.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: J. P. Morgan Trader Quits
description: J. P. Morgan Chase's head of Nasdaq trading, James Tarantino, will leave the bank after 14 years with the company and its predecessors, Morgan said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LESCHER, MARY CANTWELL
description: LESCHER-Mary Cantwell. May 10, 1930 to February 1, 2000. Mom, we love you and miss you. Margaret, Jon & Anna

title: Charles Schwab To Give Up Title At Brokerage Firm
description: The Charles Schwab Corporation said yesterday that its founder and chairman, Charles R. Schwab, would give up the title of co-chief executive in May, though Mr. Schwab intends to continue piloting the company's strategy.

title: Political Memo; Environment Fits in Political Strategy
description: President Bush's prominent mentions of clean air, healthy forests and pollution-free cars in his State of the Union speech reflect what Republican strategists say is an effort to repair his image on environmental issues.

title: The Granddaddy Of Blabbermouths
description: On Feb. 8, 1668, after writing about the political perversities of the House of Commons in his now-famous diary, Samuel Pepys described a more private scandal. That day, he confessed, he bought ''an idle, roguish French book, 'L'Escholle des Filles,' which I have bought in plain binding (avoiding the buying of it better bound), because I resolve, as soon as I have read it, to burn it, that it may not stand in the list of books, nor among them, to disgrace them, if it should be found.''

title: Calling 911
description: To the Editor:

title: Beliefs; 'Pacem in Terris,' and debate on it, echo anew.
description: The 40th anniversary of Pope John XXIII's encyclical ''Pacem in Terris'' (''Peace on Earth'') is not until April, but the commemoration has already begun -- understandably enough.

title: Editorial Observer; Pondering Condoleezza Rice's Affirmative Action Problem -- and Mine
description: With African-Americans spread throughout the government, President Bush has assembled what may be the blackest administration in American history. But black voters have been waiting warily to see what impact, if any, this will have on policy. The pessimists predicted that nothing of substance would change, except that Republicans would try to legitimize anti-black positions by lining up the black faces for photo opportunities at the White House.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWNING, JOHN
description: BROWNING - John. The House of Steinway & Sons notes with profound sorrow the untimely passing of its beloved friend, the eminent American pianist John Browning, on January 26, 2003 at the age of 69. A Steinway Artist for more than 46 years, Mr. Browning was an articulate master of the piano who captivated audiences wherever he played. He leaves a legacy rich with historic performances and award-winning recordings. John Browning earned the wide respect of his colleagues and a special place in the hearts of Steinway employees and dealer representatives everywhere. To his family we extend our heartfelt condolences. He will be deeply missed. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, V.P. Worldwide Concert and Artist Activities

title: In Automated Subways, Who'll Open the Door?
description: To the Editor:

title: Co-op Where 2 Were Slain Had Been Audited for Bias
description: A Brooklyn co-op complex where an Asian-American couple were found murdered on Tuesday was the subject of an official audit in 2001 into complaints about how the much-coveted apartments in the complex were awarded to applicants.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Chechen Faces Extradition
description: The government authorized extradition proceedings against Akhmed Zakayev, a 43-year-old Chechen separatist leader accused by Russia of mass murder and ''levying war.'' Preliminary court hearings will be held on Feb. 14, the Crown Prosecution Service said. Mr. Zakayev was arrested in December on his arrival in London from Denmark; the actress Vanessa Redgrave then posted bail for him. His supporters say he is a peace negotiator and an official in the elected Chechen government. Extradition hearings can last months, or even years. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Winners Know Nothing Beats a Great Defense
description: The Tampa Bay defense that routed Oakland in Super Bowl XXXVII will be copied so often in the years to come that you might start looking for a paperback edition. Other teams will place a greater emphasis on finding speed pass rushers like Simeon Rice, swift linebackers like Derrick Brooks and aggressive and versatile cornerbacks like Ronde Barber.

title: Veteran Umpire Is Suspended For an Anti-Semitic Remark
description: Bruce Froemming, a veteran umpire, acknowledged yesterday that he had been suspended for 10 days without pay for making a crude anti-Semitic remark to describe a Major League Baseball administrator in a recorded telephone message. The suspension relieved Froemming of an opening day assignment in Tokyo in two months.

title: Disaster Stirs Already Unsettled Feelings Across the Country
description: WASHINGTON, Feb.1  To sleeping Texans who heard the "boom-boom," it was the sound of the sky falling. To the clinical-voiced controller at NASA's Mission Control, it was a "contingency." To Americans already grappling with a confluence of threatening events, the instinctive reaction was, "What next?"

title: Natalya Dudinskaya, 90, A Leading Kirov Ballerina
description: Natalya Dudinskaya, who wielded major influence over the Kirov Ballet in Leningrad as its leading ballerina in the 1940's and 50's and as a revered teacher and the wife of its onetime artistic director, Konstantin Sergeyev, died on Wednesday in St. Petersburg. She was 90.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Economic Expansion
description: India said its gross domestic product grew 5.6 percent last year, up from 4.4 percent in 2001. The government's Central Statistical Organization said the farm sector grew 5.7 percent in contrast to a contraction in 2001. Finance, insurance and other business services grew at a rate of 4.5 percent, up from 3.5 percent. Manufacturing, however, fell to 3.4 percent from the previous year's growth of 7.3 percent. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Inspectors Set Terms for Talks With Baghdad
description: The chief United Nations weapons inspectors, Hans Blix and Dr. Mohamed ElBaradei, declined today to accept outright an invitation from Iraq to return there for talks by Feb. 10, insisting instead that they would go only if real progress could be made.

title: If June Cleaver Joined 'Sex and the City'; Tupperware Parties for the Cosmo Set
description: ''I've got cosmopolitans,'' Cindy Pitteway calls from her sprawling kitchen, as she gives a silver martini shaker a final swish. There is caviar in the living room, the Irish rock group the Corrs on the stereo and a stream of smartly dressed women coming through the front door.

description: BAMBRICK-Mary A. Of Rosedale, NY on January 30, 2003. Loving wife of Eugene P., beloved mother of Eugene P., Jr., Mary Ellen, Peter J., Julianne, Alicia and Gerard B., cherished grandmother of seven. Fond sister of the late Peter W. Thompson, Jr. Friends may call on Sunday at the O'Reilly Funeral Home. 137-40 Brookville Blvd, Rosedale from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Clare RC Church Monday at 9:30 AM. title: Dr. Kalpana Chawla: Quiet and Modest, but Also Determined
description: Nearly everyone who walks into Don Seath's classroom has at least toyed with the thought of becoming an astronaut. Mr. Seath, who has taught aerodynamics at the University of Texas at Arlington since 1965, would be hard pressed to think of a student who on first meeting seemed less likely to go into space than Kalpana Chawla.

title: 2 GERMANS AIDED IRAQ
description: A German court convicted two men of violating arms export laws by shipping drills to Iraq for the purpose of producing long-range artillery. The main defendant, Bernd Schompeter, 59, was sentenced to five years, three months in prison. His accomplice, Willi Heinz Ribbeck, 53, received two years' probation. Prosecutors said the drills, made by a German company, could be used to make artillery capable of launching chemical, biological or nuclear weapons. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank's Capital Declines
description: Mizuho Holdings Inc. said that it expected its capital adequacy rate to slip to 9 percent by the end of the fiscal year in March as it writes off more nonperforming loans and writes down the value of its sagging stock portfolio. The rate, an indicator of the bank's health, stood at 10.4 percent on Sept. 30. International banks in Japan must maintain a minimum rate of 8 percent to continue operating overseas. Mizuho, Japan's largest bank by assets, said the amount of nonperforming loans it held rose 3.5 percent in the October-December period. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Action by 8 countries reveals deep breach : Iraq letter splits Europe
description: PARIS:  The Greek government, which currently holds the presidency of the European Union, sought Friday to mend the deep breach that has opened up within the EU over going to war with Iraq.

title: Iraq to Be the Leader Of Disarmament Body
description: In an embarrassing coincidence for the United Nations, Iraq is to take over as chairman of the disarmament conference in Geneva for four workweeks, officials here announced today.

title: Broad Study Finds Lower Level of Old Chemicals, but New Trends Are Called Worrying
description: The broadest study yet of toxic chemicals that Americans absorb in their bodies showed a continuing decline in the clearest threats, like lead, pesticides and tobacco residues, but turned up numerous other findings that federal scientists and other experts called troublesome yesterday.

title: Lt. Col. Michael P. Anderson: A Source of Hope for Children
description: Whenever Happy Watkins wanted to inspire black children in Spokane, an overwhelmingly white city in eastern Washington, he would reach into his wallet and pull out an autographed picture of Lt. Col. Michael P. Anderson of the Air Force, the black astronaut who grew up in their town and died on the space shuttle Columbia today.

title: Bush Leads Nation's Grieving
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1  President Bush said today that the country would never forget the seven lost astronauts, but that the tragedy would not deter the exploration of "the darkness beyond our world."

title: Sports of The Times; Tillman Set For What Lies Ahead
description: PAT TILLMAN's story has always been a compelling tale of selflessness and personal challenge. He left the Arizona Cardinals and the security of a $3.6 million contract to join the elite Army Rangers Special Operations unit. A friend of Tillman's said he traded in his shoulder pads for fatigues last year because he was bored with professional football. I always thought you read a good book when tedium set in.

title: Mandela Rebukes Bush Over Crisis With Iraq
description: Former President Nelson Mandela sharply assailed President Bush this week for pushing the United States to the brink of war with Iraq, calling him ''a president who has no foresight, who cannot think properly.''

title: Cmdr. William C. McCool: Carrying a Memento of Home
description: When Cmdr. William C. McCool of the Navy, the pilot of the space shuttle Columbia, took off on Jan. 16, he carried a piece of his hometown with him: a spirit towel for the Coronado Mustangs, his high school football team in Lubbock, Tex.

title: Once the Source of a Dispute, New Fire Radios Hit the Field

title: A California Cultivator of Medical Marijuana Is Convicted on Federal Charges
description: A federal jury today found the author of marijuana books and advice columns, Ed Rosenthal, guilty of marijuana cultivation and conspiracy. Under mandatory sentencing laws, Mr. Rosenthal faces a minimum of five years in prison.

description: After news that the space shuttle Columbia apparently disintegrated in flames over Texas, NYTimes.com readers reacted to the events.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If I was not willing to do this, how could I expect my son or anybody else's son to answer our country's call?''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Sentence In Phone Dispute
description: A Turkish businessman, Kemal Uzan, was sentenced to 15 months in prison after failing to appear at a London court to disclose assets in connection with charges in New York that he and his family owe Motorola and Nokia almost $3 billion. Mr. Uzan's son, Hakan, was also sentenced to 15 months in prison for failing to attend court. The two men, who are living in Turkey, were expected to appear in court on Jan. 20. Nokia and Motorola say they are owed money they lent the Uzans to build a cellular network in Turkey. They want shares in the family's Telsim Mobil Telekomunikasyon Hizmetleri, Turkey's No. 2 mobile phone company, as compensation. The Uzans deny wrongdoing.

title: America Mourns, Again
description: At a time when there seemed to be more than enough bad news to go around, we woke up on Saturday morning to TV bulletins about a missing space shuttle, and then pictures of a disintegrating, burning spacecraft streaking across the sky.

title: Conseco to Stick to Insurance In Plan to Leave Bankruptcy
description: Conseco Inc., the insurance and finance company, filed a reorganization plan late tonight that details its plans to emerge from bankruptcy and maintain its insurance business while selling its consumer finance operations.

title: The Evolution of Flamenco and a 20-Year-Old Star
description: Style is a question of taste, but in the hot ticket this weekend that is the third Flamenco Festival New York, Farruquito, Spain's 20-year-old flamenco superstar, is an obvious draw among other artists.

title: A Serious Response to AIDS
description: President Bush's decision to triple spending to fight AIDS overseas, announced in the State of the Union address, finally provides a response from Washington commensurate with the disease's catastrophic scale. Mr. Bush proposed committing $10 billion in new money over the next five years to an emergency plan for AIDS relief that would finance AIDS prevention, treatment and orphan care in some of the most hard-hit countries in Africa and the Caribbean.

title: Facing 'Common Enemy,' Terrorism and Weapons of Mass Destruction
description: Following is the transcript of a White House news conference yesterday by President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, as recorded by Federal News Service Inc. The transcript is also online at nytimes.com/international.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Arrests In Downing Of Helicopter
description: The deputy prosecutor general, Sergei N. Fridinsky, said the authorities had detained four suspects in the downing of a military transport helicopter in Chechnya in August that killed 121 of 147 people on board. Mr. Fridinsky also suggested that the type of portable surface-to-air missile used in the attack, a Soviet-era Igla, had been supplied to military units in southern Russia, raising the possibility that Russian soldiers sold it to Chechen rebels. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Protesters Storm Abidjan Airport as French Citizens Leave
description: Several hundred young Ivoirians stormed the international airport here early this morning as groups of French citizens were seeking to leave the country, hurling stones at the French soldiers charged with protecting them.

title: Citizen Soldiers Are Leaving Big Gaps on the Home Front
description: The printout of names on Sheriff Darren P. White's desk is his official worry list. Eleven have big red letters after them: Deployed.

description: As hundreds of scholars get ready to gather in Harlem on Thursday night for a conference on the state of black studies, many find that suddenly their attention is turning to another topic: Hispanics.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Venture Talks End
description: The drug makers Bayer and Aventis ended talks to create a joint venture for treatments of blood conditions. The venture was expected to have potential sales of more than $2 billion a year. Bayer plans to continue its blood products business alone, a spokeswoman said. Aventis may sell its Aventis Behring blood protein unit, a company spokeswoman said.

title: Cause of Fiery Disintegration Isn't Immediately Known
description: The space shuttle Columbia, streaking across a bright blue Texas sky at about 3.5 miles a second, broke up as it re-entered the Earth's atmosphere this morning barely 15 minutes before it was to have landed at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida.

title: ADVANCED MICRO DELAYS RELEASE OF 64-BIT CHIP FOR PC'S
description: Advanced Micro Devices, a leading maker of microprocessors, said yesterday that it had postponed the release of its new line of faster chips for desktop PC's until September. The delay is at least the second for the chip, once scheduled to go on sale by the end of 2002. The chip, code-named Hammer, processes data in 64-bit portions, twice the size of the Pentium processors made by Advanced Micro's rival, Intel. From now to September, Advanced Micro will release two faster Athlon processors that run at 32 bits. Opteron, the company's 64-bit chip for server computers, will still go on sale April 22.

title: Iraqi Slum Vows to Fight U.S. But It Couldn't Be Friendlier

title: Assemblyman Pressing Case For Tracing Calls to 911

description: Dynegy, the energy provider whose trading business drove the company close to bankruptcy, restated four years of earnings yesterday and said that it could be in violation of loan agreements. The shares fell 21 percent.

description: The UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, reported a much larger fourth-quarter loss yesterday that underscored the problems that forced it to seek bankruptcy protection in December.

description: Russia's biggest oil producer, Lukoil, reported a 7.2 percent rise in net income in the third quarter of 2002. The earnings, however, fell short of analysts' expectations, and the company's shares fell in trading in Moscow. Third-quarter profit rose to $507 million from $473 million in the third quarter of 2001. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

description: Only a decade ago, Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield would have been an unlikely honey pot for any state government to use to solve a cash crisis.

It calls into question the government's authority to shut down meat plants for repeatedly violating sanitary standards designed to combat bacterial contamination and outbreaks of food-borne illness.

description: Correction: Lester Osterman, Broadway Producer

description: Ned Berry Stiles, a former managing partner of the international Wall Street law firm of Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton, died Wednesday in Greenwich, Conn. He was 70 and lived in Greenwich and Quogue, N.Y.

description: Fueled by increased sales of its digital cameras, the Fuji Photo Film Company said profits rose 2.4 percent in the October-December quarter. The world's second-largest maker of film earned 25.9 billion yen ($216 million) in the period as sales rose 2 percent. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEEDS, CARY
description: LEEDS-Cary. A warm, loving, talented friend. Your drive, determination, charm and charisma on and off the tennis court was admired by all. You will be sorely missed. The Kiams

title: Celebrating Composers From Soviet Underground
description: This week the pianist Vladimir Feltsman is offering his own take on the concept of notes from the underground. The notes here are musical, the work of 14 Soviet composers who largely worked out of official favor after World War II but who for Mr. Feltsman and other musicians who grew up in the Soviet Union represented an important element of artistic life. Feeling that they remained too little known in the West, Mr. Feltsman came to the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center with the idea of a miniature festival devoted to the Russian underground with poetry readings, lectures, films, a photography show and three concerts.

title: Rapes in 2 Boroughs Linked to 1 Attacker
description: The police are looking for a man who has attacked up to three women at a time in three incidents in the Bronx and in Chelsea. In each case, the man got onto an elevator in an apartment building with his victims, then attacked them in the elevator or a stairwell, a police spokesman said.

title: Collapse Halts Metro-North
description: A brick wall collapsed near the Metro-North commuter train lines in East Harlem yesterday, disrupting all train service in and out of Grand Central Terminal for about an hour just as the evening rush began, the authorities said. No one was injured in the accident.

title: F.D.A. Approves Biotechnology Drug for Psoriasis
description: The Food and Drug Administration has approved Amevive, the first drug from the biotechnology industry to treat psoriasis, opening what doctors say will be a new era in treating the disease, a sometimes debilitating skin ailment.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: ALGERIA: CHIRAC TO MAKE STATE VISIT President Jacques Chirac of France will make a state visit to Algeria from March 2 to 4 as part of French efforts to improve relations. On Feb. 5, the Algerian president, Abdelaziz Bouteflika, will visit Paris. It will be Mr. Chirac's second visit to Algeria  but his first official state visit  and the fourth by a French president since Algeria obtained its independence from France in 1962. Relations between France and Algeria have been difficult and complicated since Algeria won its independence after a bitter eight-year war that caused the death of hundreds of thousands and the expulsion of large numbers of French settlers. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: In Maazel's Philharmonic, A Study in Hard and Soft
description: Lorin Maazel may not be the warmest conductor in the world. His Mozart is not playful or childlike or poignant. But there's a diamond glitter to his conducting, a precision and polish that allows music to emit flashes of brilliant light. This can be extremely exciting in its own way, and at the New York Philharmonic's concert on Thursday night, it often was.

title: U.N. WARNS OF ATTACKS ON FOOD
description: The World Health Organization warned of a serious threat to global public health from potentially ''malicious contamination of food for terrorist purposes.'' Its report noted that already as many as 1.5 million people die each year from noncriminally contaminated food. The United Nations agency urged governments to improve their national food safety programs and recommended strengthened ties between food industries and law enforcement.

description: A mysterious white substance found floating in bags of donated blood here led the American Red Cross today to quarantine nearly its entire blood supply for Georgia and parts of South Carolina.
