description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Feb. 2  An explosion ripped through a dense city block in Lagos, Nigeria, this morning, killing roughly 30 people, injuring many more and setting off scenes of chaotic looting that impeded rescue efforts.

title: 'Soft' Adventure in Alaska
description: I KNEW from studying the Web site that the Wilderness Adventurer was a dwarf as cruise ships go -- only 160 feet, with room for 72 passengers -- and that was exactly what appealed to me. Small size, low key, lots of bobbing and weaving through the great Alaskan outdoors. And no shopping or gambling. The Seattle-based Glacier Bay Cruiseline termed the six-night package of cruising, hiking and kayaking amid the fjords and mountain-rimmed bays of the Inside Passage a ''soft'' adventure -- which struck me as a slightly pudgy version of what I was looking for.

description: MILWAUKEE, Feb. 1  Howard Eisley's terrific performance in Friday's victory over Memphis notwithstanding, the Knicks are still lacking a top-flight point guard. But obtaining one would be only second on the Knicks' list of priorities behind finding a solid big man. That's because, when put together, Eisley and his backup, Charlie Ward, have handled the playmaking duties very well this season.

title: Crime Scene Photographer: New York
description: THE bodies lie slack, sometimes in tender repose, belying the way their lives were wrenched away. But mostly they are twisted and left to cure in a pool of blood, conveying the ugly nature of their ends. They are the images of murder victims in a show of 20th-century crime photography entitled ''Shots in the Dark: True Crime Pictures,'' at the Chelsea Art Museum on West 22nd Street, through March 15. Although the curator, Gail Buckland, the author of an accompanying book, culled the images from crime scenes around the country, the most fertile source for these nightmare stills appears to be New York, with its abundance of street shootings, parlor stabbings and gaudy gangland rub-outs.

title: Lawmakers to Take a Closer Look at the Space Program
description: Today's breakup of the space shuttle Columbia has revived a long-simmering debate in Congress about the future of the nation's space program. The disaster, which is certain to lead to new hearings, also renewed questions about whether cost-cutting and management problems at NASA may be compromising astronauts' safety.

description: The destruction of the space shuttle Columbia came just as NASA and its 15 international partners were preparing for a major expansion of the International Space Station, and it has dealt a heavy blow to that effort, experts and agency officials said yesterday.

title: Enticing Thai Cuisine in Babylon
description: EVER wonder what happened to all those Chinese buffets that blanketed the Island a few years ago? Many have been transformed into other ethnic restaurants ranging from Japanese to Polish. In Babylon village, one of those large Chinese spots has been divided into three separate storefronts. A third of the trio is now Nattee Thai Cuisine, which has enlivened the Babylon dining scene.

Did Valentine cause the weak concession sales? How about the mail that was misplaced? Did the owner, Fred Wilpon, ever find the umbrella he lost?

title: Dear Leader
description: 'Leadership Both Great and Dear'' was the headline over a Newsday column by Murray Kempton in 1986. ''Kim Il Sung is president of North Korea. He is never introduced in press releases except as 'the Great Leader of Our Party and Our People.' His son is Kim Jong Il, who is the Dear Leader.'' The late columnist helped readers unfamiliar with Asian names by differentiating between them as Great Kim and Dear Kim.

title: Uneasy Lies the Head That Runs the Web Site
description: Wanted: Thick-skinned Webmaster willing to endure verbal abuse from politically obsessed residents, in exchange for no salary, no title and a soupon of power. Dictators need not apply.

He said that the exclusivity period for Mark Hamister's group to negotiate to buy the Sabres would expire on Monday and that he was not sure about extending it again.

title: Forget Diversity
description: 'Diversity'' must be a very, very good thing; President Bush used the word, or a variant of it, 10 times in his speech last month announcing that the administration would seek to have the Supreme Court declare the undergraduate admissions policies at the University of Michigan unconstitutional. ''I strongly support diversity of all kinds,'' said the president, with his flair for hijacking the key words of his opponents, ''including racial diversity in higher education.'' As the president knows very well, ''diversity'' is precisely what the University of Michigan says its admissions program is designed to ensure. The two sides disagree only about the acceptable means of attaining this supreme good.

title: 'On Top of the World'

Marcus, the president of Scholastic Book Publishing and Distribution, earns more than most of the men she works with.

title: Editors' Note
description: The Age of Dissonance column last Sunday, about cozying up to celebrities, mentioned a report in The Daily News that guests at the Sundance film festival "had their shoes spattered" when the actor Tobey Maguire was taken ill. But the day the Times column appeared, The News quoted the actor's publicist as saying that although Mr. Maguire doubled over at one point, it was not he who vomited.

title: Southampton Hospital Explores Merger

title: Corrections

They were four counts of fraud, in May 1996. In April 1999 she was acquitted of obstruction of justice, and a jury did not reach a verdict on two charges of criminal contempt.

title: Departing Security Official Issues Warning

Clarke, the blunt, sometimes abrasive White House adviser who raised the alarm about unconventional national security threats ranging from failed states to biological and computer terrorism for more than a decade, quietly resigned as President Bush's special adviser for cyberspace security on Friday.

Intrawest agreed to cancel plans for condos and a golf course there and will instead develop a tourist village at the mountain's base. How many times have we heard that we ''made'' Saddam (because he was Iran's enemy) and bin Laden (because he was the Soviets' enemy)? And the shah and Batista and Pinochet, and how dare we try to start a war with someone we armed in the first place yada yada?

title: No. 1 Duke Is No. 59 in UConn's Streak

title: Who Holds The Deeds To the Land
description: JOHN D. ROCKEFELLER began buying property in Pocantico Hills in 1893. He bought all the land he could see from the top of Kykuit hill and removeding barns, relocated railroad tracks and demolished houses. His son, John D. Rockefeller Jr., expanded the Rockefellers landholdings to include more than 3,600 acres. But the cost of maintaining all of the land was exorbitant even by Rockefeller standards, so in the 1970s, John D. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLACK, RUTH BRILL
description: POLLACK-Ruth Brill. Age 96, died peacefully in New York City on January 30. Born February 14, 1907 in New York City, she attended Parsons School of Design and freelanced until her marriage to industrialist Jacob (Jack) Kugelman. A resident of Miami Beach and Abington, Pennsylvania. Volunteered for Red Cross as a Gray Lady during WW II. She returned to NYC in 1942, when she was widowed. In 1945 married the late Herbert Pollack, M.D., renowned specialist in nutrition and diabetes, author and consultant to NASA, IDA and the State Department. They traveled widely internationally, often on official business as guests of foreign dignitaries and heads of state. Lived in Leesburg and Upperville Virginia and the District of Columbia for over 40 years. She was a member of the Women's Board of George Washington University Hospital and the Cosmos, Metropolitan, Chevy Chase and Dacor clubs. She was a lifelong bridge and tennis enthusiast, raconteur and ballroom dance maven. Survived by daughters Jane K. Sobol, Escondido, CA, and Connie P. Cohen, New York, NY and Scottsdale, AZ, a sister, Molly Bronstein, four grandchildren: Wendy Glenn, Valerie Jorgensen, Keith Frankl and John Glenn and several great-grandchildren.

title: '20:21 Vision'

The challenge of trying to sort out the wood from the trees, the important from the unimportant, the honest from the dishonest, the reasonable from the hyperbolic. The independence of mind and of spirit, the accompanying sense of the ridiculous, that are available to an outsider, an observer of rather than participant in events, processes and organizations. The fact that so many people read or hear what you have to say, and that some of them even pay heed to it. The privilege of being able to, and actually being paid to, write or broadcast what can fairly be described as a sort of first draft of history, albeit with all the foibles and frailties that performing that task typically implies.

Still, the general outlines seem clear enough. By virtually all accounts, the president wants to offer drug coverage only through private health plans, not through the traditional Medicare fee-for-service system, which insures an overwhelming majority of the elderly. The notion is that drug coverage can be used as a sweetener to entice the elderly toward market-oriented reform of the Medicare system.

Though concentrations of PCB's and pesticides have decreased in the last decade, the new guidelines take a more protective approach to human health and cancer prevention, officials said. The restrictions apply to american eel, bluefish and striped bass taken anywhere in the state and to crabs and other fish taken in specific waterways. The advisories, including ranges of risks, are available at www.state.nj.us/dep/dsr/njmainfish.

But they have not allowed shareholders in the west wing to use their apartments. Meanwhile, it is costing all the shareholders extra money for electricity, water, sewage and garbage collection. description: Seven astronauts, six Americans and an Israeli, died aboard the shuttle Columbia yesterday. Of the crew of five men and two women, four had never flown in space before.

title: Understanding a Publisher's Passion (A Hint: It's All in the Translation)
description: ROBERT WECHSLER, who lives in North Haven, may be better known in Prague than he is in his home state. That is entirely because of his one-man mission -- some might say obsession -- to bring Czech literature in English translation to American readers.

title: Cruise Sites That Are Data Ports
description: FEW people reflect the changing nature of travel consumers in general, and cruise aficionados in particular, as much as Rebecca Fix. Ms. Fix, a stay-at-home mom in Lyndhurst, N.J., last month arranged to go on her second cruise, and the first for which she did the booking. She invested all of an hour researching trips and prices online, then spent $1,500 for a four-day Caribbean cruise for herself, her husband, Glen, and their 8-year-old son, Eric, without so much as calling a customer service agent.

title: Rutgers Sweeps Titles
description: Rutgers swept the team titles in the Metropolitan Intercollegiate Championships yesterday at the Armory Track and Field Center in Upper Manhattan. The men won with 150 points and the women with 172.

title: The Odd Girl In: Zooey Deschanel, Actress
description: She is a fine-boned, wide-cheeked young actress with huge, intent blue eyes, and her appearance in a movie provokes a blink of delayed recognition. Wait, who was that? Wasn't she the big sister in ''Almost Famous''? And didn't I see her on an episode of something once? Was it ''Frasier''? What's her name again?

title: Space Flight's Dangers Are Raised by Speed
description: Even though its payload is not a satellite or a weapon, but precious human life, the space shuttle will always face about the same witheringly high chances of catastrophe as any other launching system.

title: Dealing With Aging Executives Who Just Won't Quit
description: WHEN CBS News pushed Don Hewitt, the legendary executive producer of ''60 Minutes,'' out of his job last week at the age of 80, the incident seemed so extraordinary that it made headlines. On first glance, it was. Mr. Hewitt invented the news magazine and embodied the format at its best. Even at his age, he wangled an additional 18 months as head of ''60 Minutes'' out of CBS as well as a contract that will pay him until he is 90.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OBSTBAUM, EVELYN
description: OBSTBAUM - Evelyn. On January 31, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Cantor Irving Obstbaum. Loving mother of Dr. Abigail Brenner and Raymond, and Dr. Stephen Obstbaum and Merilee. Cherished grandmother of Jesse, Lauren, David, Jamie and Robbie. Great-grandmother of Bronwen. Services Sunday, 9:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Reservists Watch News and Wait for the Call
description: I CHECK the news on the Web often lately. At least once an hour. Or more. It is a new pattern for me, and the rate has increased steadily over recent months, in direct relation to the threat of war. I feel vaguely the way I do when my children are feverish; if I don't keep taking the emotional temperature of the world, I fear it will shoot up to critical when I'm not looking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAESS, MICHAEL R.
description: NAESS-Michael R. 63, died at his home in Bermuda, on February 1, after a long, courageous battle with cancer. He was the beloved husband of Eleanor Bonbright Naess and the devoted father of Stephanie Kennedy, Michele Burke, Michael T. Naess, and the late Jeremy M. Naess, and stepfather of Hilary B. Mullarkey and Libby B. Moulton, eight cherished grandchildren also survive him. Michael Naess was the dear brother of Janecke Madsen, Jennifer Moe, Karen Budd, Astrid Gifford and Fredrik Naess. A memorial service will be held in Bermuda on Tuesday, February 4. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to The Bermuda Biological Station for Research, St. George's GE 01, Bermuda.

description: AT public universities in California and Texas, the end of affirmative action in admissions has benefited one minority: Asian-Americans.

description: Growing numbers of employers are offering full-service brokerage accounts in their 401(k) plans, giving participants a much broader array of investment choices.

description: An article last Sunday about the Dollywood theme park and the devotion of Dolly Parton's fans misspelled the surname of an artist who created an installation based on Ms. Parton's song ''Coat of Many Colors,'' and misspelled the name of a New York gallery where it was exhibited. He is Larry Krone, not Crone; the gallery is the Whitney at Philip Morris, not Phillip.

description: Georgia Mitilineos and Abdelhak Hamdaoui, the St. Regis hotel, New York, Jan. 14, 2003

title: Questions for Arianna Huffington
description: I have a question for Arianna Huffington: since when is my life any business of hers (The Way We Live Now, Robert Mackey, Jan. 19)? What has become of our fellow Americans these days that they seem to spend more time telling others what they should be doing than perhaps examining their own little corner of the universe. Get your own life, Arianna, and stay out of mine!

On 2 february 1421, China dwarfed every nation on earth. On that Chinese New Year's Day, kings and envoys from the length and breadth of Asia, Arabia, Africa and the Indian Ocean assembled amid the splendours of Beijing to pay homage to the Emperor Zhu Di, the Son of Heaven. A fleet of leviathan ships, navigating the oceans with pinpoint accuracy, had brought the rulers and their envoys to pay tribute to the emperor and bear witness to the inauguration of his majestic and mysterious walled capital, the Forbidden City. No fewer than twenty-eight heads of state were present, but the Holy Roman Emperor, the Emperor of Byzantium, the Doge of Venice and the kings of England, France, Spain and Portugal were not among them. They had not been invited, for such backward states, lacking trade goods or any worthwhile scientific knowledge, ranked low on the Chinese emperor's scale of priorities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BACHNER, ARNOLD H.
description: BACHNER-Arnold H. Of New York, NY, died January 27, 2003 after long and painful illnesses. Born June 14, 1919 in Newark, NJ, Mr. Bachner had a distinguished career as the CEO of Kmart Apparel and was on the Board of Directors of the Kmart Corporation until his retirement. He was honored as man of the year by the Jack Martin Fund. He served in the armed forces in W.W. II as a member ''this is the army''. He was the beloved father of Walter and Debra. He is also survived by his former spouse, Patricia. He was an exceptional human being and will be in our hearts forever.

title: BackTalk; Twilight Tales, Upbeat and Otherwise
description: No scriptwriters are required when it comes to sports. The true stories are routinely dramatic and sensationalist enough. There is no need to jazz them up for wider consumption -- from figure skating's Russian mafia connections, to Lance Armstrong's comeback from cancer, to Andre Agassi's and Steffi Graf's beyond-the-baseline romance to a laundry list of other fiction-defeating plots and subplots.

description: The following is the text of Sean OKeefe, NASA administrator, as released by NASA.

title: First the Air Shook With Sound, And Then Debris Rained Down
description: It sounded like a freight train, like a tornado, like rolling thunder -- and then a gigantic boom.

title: A Hero of the Indies Gets Minimal Again
description: One of the best jokes in ''Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back'' (2001), Kevin Smith's hilariously rude send-up of the movie business, is when the film's stoner protagonists visit the set of ''Good Will Hunting 2,'' the supposed sequel to Gus Van Sant's 1997 blockbuster hit. Case, told investors he hoped AOL Time Warner would become the most valuable company in the world, surpassing even Microsoft and General Electric. Instead, the next year will determine just how much smaller AOL Time Warner will end up.

description: IN the end, if this really is the end, LeBron James's senior season should be remembered as just another excess of reality TV. It was a bad game show, the purpose of which was to determine how many delusions of scholastic grandeur could be achieved before someone stepped in to send the hero home in his Hummer, leaving the court without King James.

description: As the chief executive of Dassault Aviation, Serge Dassault blocked his share of mergers while resisting consolidation in Europe's aerospace and military industry. Notably, he stopped a 1996 effort to combine his company with Aerospatiale, the French government-run enterprise that is part of the consortium that makes Airbus commercial airliners.

title: Corrections

description: For the second time in 17 years, tragedy has cast a shadow over the American space program, and its future has been put on hold.

description: FOR all of the talk about class warfare, one difference in the Republican and Democratic positions on taxes has actually received too little attention. That difference may be one reason that President Bush and the Republicans seem to have won the recent tax wars.

title: Winter Palette
description: Colors in cotton candy pastels were a welcome thaw after the recent frigid cold spell. Those powdery hues are a uniform on children and on a few adults not caught up in the somber blacks and browns of winter clothes. The lighter colors are a luxury, of course, requiring more expensive cleaning bills. But the wearers enjoy cheerful, soft shades that brighten gray winter days.

When she goes for the latter, she serves something like a rib roast with a cheese souffl for the main course and individual chocolate souffls for dessert. ''I mean, you're mixing those egg whites, you might as well go on.''

The good intention is welcome. But this restaurant, only seven months old, hasn't decided what it wants to be when it grows up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AGNELLI, GIOVANNI
description: AGNELLI - Giovanni. Con summate businessman and industrialist, Philanthropist, world leader, automobile magnate and enthusiast, art collector, bon vivant, connoisseur of all the arts from publishing to fashion, sportsman, patriot and soldier-Giovanni Agnelli lived life fully in all its dimensions and possibilities. He was a builder and a doer. Architecture, not surprisingly, was one of the art forms that he greatly admired. His deep interest led him to become an important patron in the field and led him to serve many years on the Jury of the distinguished Pritzker Architecture Prize, a position he held at the time of his death. A generation of Pritzker Prize laureates honors and mourns the loss of his intellect and connoisseurship to the field. They are joined in their grief by members of the Pritzker family of Chicago in expressing their deep sadness to his wife Marella and his family. Architecture, Italy and the world will miss the forceful and wise presence of this great man.

The goal is to assess the feasibility of creating an 8,400-acre park that would piece together wetlands in Secaucus, Kearny, North Bergen and Carlstadt, among other communities. Jeremy Pearce

Though the Gap suffered in the last two years, Mr. Drexler, 58, is still the man who basically invented ''vertical retailing'' -- creating one's own brand, like the Gap, and selling nothing else. His challenge now is to make J. Crew fashionable, and to differentiate its clothes from its competitors -- including the Gap, whose sales figures improved over the holidays. Tracie Rozhon

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: WHEN you see IN THE BEDROOM (2001), it doesn't matter if you already know that Frank Fowler (Nick Stahl) is going to be killed about half an hour into the film. Todd Field, the director, somehow makes it abrupt and surprising, even the second time around. Frank is the golden, college-bound son of one of those educated, sophisticated couples who adopt the small-town life but always feel a little superior. Matt (Tom Wilkinson) is the local doctor; Ruth (Sissy Spacek) teaches Balkan folk music. When Frank is fatally shot by his girlfriend's ex-husband, the couple seem to age 15 years in a day. This is a painfully accurate portrait of the workings of grief and the relative value of revenge. Everyone turns in a grand performance -- everyone (so I take back everything I've ever thought about Marisa Tomei) -- Saturday at 8 p.m. and Saturday/Early Sunday at 3:15 a.m. on Starz.

title: Nassau and Suffolk Gained 6,200 Jobs in December
description: Employment in Nassau and Suffolk rose slightly in December from November's figures, according to the State Labor Department. The Island gained 6,200 nonagricultural jobs, for an increase of 0.5 percent. The largest number of new jobs were in the services sector; retailing alone added 4,400 jobs. The unemployment rate remained flat at 3.9 percent.

title: Jan. 26-Feb. 1: NATIONAL; MORE TIME WARNER DISARRAY
description: AOL Time Warner said it would be another year before it emerges from the rubble created by AOL's acquisition of Time Warner two years ago. It reported the largest annual loss in corporate history, mainly because of a $45 billion accounting charge to reflect the declining value of its AOL and cable divisions. Though the charge does not affect operations, it underscored the magnitude of its problems. Its vice chairman, Ted Turner, resigned, partly to devote time to his philanthropy, but partly to gain more freedom to sell his company stock. David D. Kirkpatrick

title: Politics, Reading and Writing
description: Look out, Oprah. Governor McGreevey has a book club, too, called -- what else? -- Governor McGreevey's Book Club. It is for children from kindergarten to third grade. Each month the club offers new selections for each grade plus a newsletter and a colorful Web site (www.nj.gov/bookclub) where participants can download book summaries, puzzles, games, coloring books, book marks and badges. There are also messages from the governor: ''Hi kids: Welcome to my book club.'' Children join on line or with their classes at school. To date, Mr. McGreevey's office says, 58,000 children and more than 1,500 teachers have signed up. The governor hopes the club will help children develop a love of reading. ''We cannot expect our teachers to do this job alone,'' he said. ''The book club provides an opportunity for parents and grandparents, librarians and community members to become involved in our goal of having children read at or above grade level by the third grade.'' The governor picks the books from those that the State Department of Education culls from Scholastic Book catalogs. Companies including Scholastic Book Clubs, PSE&G, Horizon Blue Cross Blue Shield, New Jersey Natural Gas, Pfizer, Washington Mutual and the CIT Corporation are helping to finance distribution of the books to participating schools. The project was Governor McGreevey's idea, his office said, and both Scholastic and the governor's office said they knew of no other state that had such a governor's book club. When James McGreevey himself was a lad, he says, his favorites were ''Huckleberry Finn'' and ''The Adventures of Tom Sawyer.'' He says the book that he and his 1-year-old daughter, Jacqueline, like to read together the most is ''Guess How Much I Love You,'' by Sam McBratney. (Candlewick Press, 2003) Margo Nash

title: Jodie Magid, Peter Oriol
description: Jodie Robyn Magid, the daughter of Bonnie and Joel Magid of Jericho, N.Y., and Peter Alexander Oriol, son of Esther and Bill Oriol of New York, were married last evening. Rabbi Harvey Abramowitz officiated at Carlyle on the Green, a caterer in Bethpage, N.Y.

title: An Expected Triumphant Return Becomes a Nightmare for Israelis
description: He was a hero for a country in need of one, and in towns like this one across Israel, people gathered in front of their television sets today, happy and expectant, to watch the homecoming of Col. Ilan Ramon, Israel's first astronaut.

title: Nassau Taxes May Be Fairer, but Protests Abound
description: MICHAEL EISENBERG knows that the real estate market in his Massapequa neighborhood is going strong. It seems each day brings news of another sale well above $500,000, sometimes even into the low $600,000's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIED, ANDREW
description: FRIED-Andrew. Beloved son of the late Hyman and Frances Fried entered into rest January 31. He is survived by his sisters Dorothy and Elinor, brother-in-law Bernard, numerous nieces and nephews, great-nieces and greatnephews. A graveside service will be held on Sunday, February 2, at 11 AM, at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont.

title: At Sundance, Documentaries As Scrapbooks
description: YOU can see the family resemblance between the Friedman sons, David and Jesse, and their father, in the documentary ''Capturing the Friedmans,'' which just won the Grand Jury Prize at the Sundance Film Festival. David and Jesse both have identical receding hairlines. David shares his father's goofy, ingratiating sense of humor. (David is now a top New York kiddie clown, according to the film's end credits.) And, like his father, he has a compulsion to film family events. Most important, though, just like his dad, Jesse is arrested and charged with molesting boys in the computer class he and his dad taught at the family home. Andrew Jarecki's film is about, among other things, information -- how the withholding of information eats away at trust.

title: Where AIDS Stalks, Everyone Lives in Fear
description: THESE may be the faces of the rescued. Virtually no one in Africa admits being H.I.V.-positive. But everyone knows someone who has died young. Very few even ask for tests, because the result, as President Bush noted in his State of the Union address last week, is so often a death sentence: Yes, you have AIDS. We have no drugs. We're sorry. Go home and die.

Their departure from the capital was so sudden that the royal servants at the party's first stopping-place, Hampton Court Palace, two hours or so away by barge down the River Thames, had no time to prepare for their arrival - we are told that it was so cold in the closed-up royal apartments that on their first night the King and Queen and their children were obliged to sleep together in one bed for warmth. The Palace at Whitehall, summarily abandoned by its royal owner and left vacant and unsecured, swiftly became a tourist attraction - curious Londoners wandered around its twenty acres of opulent grounds and buildings, staring at the King's picture collection, and even, apparently, trying out the throne for comfort!

title: This Dream Is Not for Sleeping
description: Described as the '' 'funny house' of tomorrow,'' Salvador Dal's pavilion for the 1939 New York World's Fair was commissioned largely as a diversion from the Depression and news of imminent war overseas. In exhibits including a boudoir (or mausoleum) of flowers, mirrors and fuchsia satin in which a topless sleeping beauty lay ensconced; an aquatic diorama of nymphs swimming past a body-painted wax nude; and an ivy-encrusted taxi with Columbus in its back seat and cheesecake sirens recumbent on its hood and roof, the ''Dream of Venus,'' which opened mere days after Franco's victory in Spain, Dal's homeland, offered an opulent visual alternative to the nightmare of modern alienation and war. SALVADOR DAL'S DREAM OF VENUS: The Surrealist Funhouse From the 1939 World's Fair (Princeton Architectural, $60), presents a trove of photographs, recently unearthed from the estate of the photographer Eric Schaal, of the pavilion and its creation. The individual images, many in color, of the tableaux vivants and the scenes ''backstage'' are often striking and reassert the work's strangeness -- Surrealism for the masses. Yet their presentation is stilted in book form, accompanied by Irene Schaffner's essay detailing the exhibit's preparation, financing and reception. The tension between the curatorial impulse to contextualize, and the immediate, inarticulable response the ''Dream of Venus '' sought to evoke, tends to undermine both. Christina Cho

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEELER, ROBERT TEMPLE
description: KEELER - Robert Temple, noted Ohio lawyer, philanthropist, corporate director and World War II Navy veteran, died on December 19, 2002 of complications from a stroke suffered at his country home in Dorset, Vermont. He was 88. Keeler was born in Cleveland on August 3, 1914, the day Germany declared war on France, invaded Russia, and ignited the First World War. A man of wry humor and acerbic wit, he sometimes described his birth as ''the second calamity of the day.'' Keeler graduated Magna cum Laude and Phi Beta Kappa from Dartmouth in 1936, and earned his LL.B from Yale in 1939. He soon joined the Cincinnati law firm of Taft, Stettinius & Hollister, founded by Robert Alphonso Taft, eldest son of William Howard Taft, 27th President and 10th Chief Justice of the United States. Later a U.S. senator, conservative Republican icon, and contender for the presidency, Robert Taft became a mentor and friend to his brilliant young associate. In 1942, Keeler enlisted in the Navy as an ensign and after 2-1/2 years in the Pacific and the Aleutians was discharged as a lieutenant (j.g.). He was made a partner at T.S.& H. in 1953, and gained renown as a trial and an appellate court lawyer during his 43 years with the firm. A scion of the Temple family of east Texas, Keeler also worked with his first cousin, Arthur Temple, Jr., to build the timber business developed to 7,000 acres by their grandfather, Thomas Louis Latane Temple, into the halfmillion-acre East Texas Pulp & Paper Company, which became a principal supplier to Time Inc. When the media conglomerate merged with Eastex in 1973, Keeler and his cousin joined Time Inc.'s board of directors, resigning ten years later in vehement protest of Time's merger with Warner Brothers. Keeler was married twice, first to Florence Field Mithoefer of Cincinnati in 1940, with whom he had five children. After his divorce in 1975, he wed Margaret Palmer Mithoefer of Dorset, Vermont. In addition to his widow, Keeler is survived by his sister Virginia of Green Lake, WI, his cousin Arthur Temple Jr. of Diboll. TX, and by four children, all of California-David, of Slovang; Tanny Keeler-Hodgetts of Santa Barbara; Alison Keeler Carrillo of Santa Cruz; and Melissa Keeler Morris of Santa Barbara. In 1982 Keeler retired from the Taft firm and concentrated on his interest in travel and the arts. He was elected to the Board of Directors of the Cincinnati Art Museum, and with his wife Margaret, endowed part of the renovation of Cincinnati's historic waterfront, as well as the Mary R. Drury Chair of History at the Seven Hills School; he gave the John Whitman Keeler Memorial Theater to the Cincinnati Country Day School in honor of his younger son who had predeceased him in 1993; and he renovated and endowed the golf course at Dartmouth College. Although he and his wife maintained a river-view condominium in Cincinnati, his ''box seat on the Ohio'', they spent most of his later years at their home in Vermont, where Keeler continued his avid enthusiasm for golf well into his 86th year. A memorial service will be on March 7th at 3PM at the Christ Church in Cincinnati, Ohio. Gifts may be made to the Seven Hills School of Cincinnati and the Cincinnati Art Museum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FROMME, ALLAN, PH.D.
description: FROMME-Allan, Ph.D. Of Sarasota, FL, died on January 30th. Survived by Babette Brandt Fromme, his loving wife for over 59 years, father of Pamela Fromme Formato of Sarasota, FL, Steven Fromme and his wife, Lynn, of Chapel Hill, NC; very special grandfather to Brian Formato and his wife, Brita, Oliver Formato, Alison Fromme and Christopher Fromme; adoring great-grandfather to Olivia Kristin Formato. Dr. Fromme was a clinical psychologist practicing in New York City from 1945 until 1976, when he moved to Sarasota, where he continued to practice while maintaining a partial practice in New York City. Dr. Fromme was graduated from the City College of New York cum laude with special honors in psychology. He was a member of Phi Beta Kappa and Sigma Xi, and received his Ph.D. From Columbia University. He served in the army during World War II. Dr. Fromme taught for many years at C.C.N.Y., Sarah Lawrence College and Columbia University. He became chief psychologist at the Child Guidance Clinic of St. Luke's Hospital, and later director of the Mental Hygiene Clinic of the University Settlement House. He was asked by radio WMCA to develop the weekly program, ''Adventure into the Mind,'' which he wrote and participated in as the psychologist. He also served as the expert on the celebrity panel of the weekly radio show ''Make up Your Mind.'' In addition to his many appearances on television, Dr. Fromme gave a popular lecture series at the 92nd Street Y. His eight books include ''The Ability to Love,'' ''Sex and Marriage,'' and ''The ABC of Child Care.'' Dr. Fromme was a member of the Board of Directors of the Trans-Lux Corp. for many years. There will be no funeral or memorial service held either in Sarasota or New York City. Donations in his memory may be made to Eckerd College, 4200 54th Ave So, St. Petersburg, FL 33711; or to the Literacy Council of Sarasota, 1750 17th St, Sarasota, FL 34234.

title: 'Making Things Better'
description: Herz had a dream which, when he awoke into a night that was still black, left him excited and impressed. He dreamed that he had received a call from his cousin, Fanny Bauer, the love of his life. He was to take her to the cinema, she ordained. Eager to conform to her wishes, as he always had been, he shrugged on his coat, and within seconds was elsewhere, as was the norm in dreams of wish-fulfilment. Although it was a weekday afternoon the cinema was so crowded that they had to stand at the back of the auditorium. Fanny was as he had always known her and still remembered her: petulant, with the petulance of a spoilt pretty woman, demanding and discontented. Shortly after the beginning of the film she had clutched his arm and declared that she felt unwell. Again, without transition, they found themselves in the vast cafe that was part of the cinema complex. Fanny had recovered somewhat but looked uncharacteristically dishevelled, with a large camel-hair coat slung over her shoulders. He was conscious of retaining his eager smile, but felt discomfited. This feeling had something to do with the coat, which he recognized as his own, the coat he should have been wearing. He had no memory of having offered it to her. The coat, and Fanny's malaise, remained closely associated in his mind. It was only when he understood that it was he who had been taken ill that the dream attained its peak of significance. Ailing, smiling, he had offered her his remaining health and strength, and she, not in the least grateful, had carelessly dispossessed him, not noticing that she had done so. This was so akin to their real life association that, if anything, his newly awakened self was conscious of its reality. Brought back to himself he was aware of the smile-of complicity, of acquiescence-directed to the corners of the dark bedroom. Only the relentless ticking of his clock informed him that he had woken up, that this would soon be a new day, all too closely resembling the others, the normal days of his present existence, in which nothing happened nor could be expected to happen.

title: Surgical Strike
description: Two dozen surgeons walked off the job in West Virginia on New Year's Day to protest the costs of medical malpractice insurance and reduced reimbursement rates. After effectively paralyzing emergency rooms at Wheeling Hospital, Ohio Valley Medical Center and Weirton Medical Center for almost two weeks, most of the surgeons returned to work on Jan. 13, after legislation was introduced to amend malpractice liability language and lower the cap on damage awards for pain and suffering. That bill, which has passed the House of Delegates, is now under review in the West Virginia Senate. Many surgeons have said that if it fails, they'll walk out again -- or simply look for jobs in other states. Their protest has already inspired some of their peers: surgeons in coastal Mississippi have just walked out, and doctors in New Jersey are planning a slow-down this month. Loch Adamson

The organization was celebrating the city's decision to save from demolition the 1 1/2-mile abandoned elevated rail line on Manhattan's West Side. Plans for the site include a public park. About 400 guests raised $40,000 toward the High Line's transformation.

title: Personal Business; Solving the Cellphone Maze One Twist at a Time
description: WHEN Ilissa Best, a mother of two young children from San Carlos, Calif., signed up for cellphone service two years ago, she received 300 minutes of talk time for $40 a month, plus 200 bonus minutes. She figures she uses all those minutes each month talking with friends during the day as she shuttles her children around town. So when the bonus period ended recently because her contract had expired, her monthly bill nearly tripled.

title: Pilot Embraced Role as a Symbol for Jews
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1  Col. Ilan Ramon, the Israeli astronaut who died today aboard the space shuttle Columbia, was a soft-spoken combat pilot conscious of the importance of symbols and history, and the role he played in both.

title: The Real World
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Towns, Another Hit, But This One They'll Fight
description: BIT by bit, Mayor John DeStefano of New Haven has watched as state money promised to his city was chipped away in Gov. John G. Rowland's attempt to address a $650 million budget deficit. But when the state failed to pay $68 million in tax reimbursements owed New Haven and other cities and towns, the municipalities decided to sue.

title: A Painterly Look for Camera Images

Since 1982, the Perkins Center for the Arts here has held an annual juried exhibition each winter that continues to maintain a reputation for presenting quality work. It has remained true to its regional mission, attracting some of the leading photographers in the greater Delaware Valley. With purchase awards offered by the Smithsonian American Art Museum, the Philadelphia Museum of Art, and the Johnson & Johnson World Headquarters, the competitive stakes are high.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

Typically set during the final throes of an adulterous affair or its immediate aftermath, these tales have less to do with sins than with low-grade personality disorders as they track the self-absorption, vague yearnings and befuddled fortunes of cheaters and the cheated-upon. Last year in these pages, Colson Whitehead admired the author's ''strengths as a scientist of locale'' and said, ''Dick Clark would sooner have a hair out of place than Richard Ford put a word where it shouldn't be.''

Mr. Blix challenged many of the Bush administration's allegations of illicit activity, as did Mohamed ElBaradei, chief nuclear inspector, who said he had found no evidence that Iraq had resumed its nuclear arms program. Dr. ElBaradei gave a less critical assessment of the first two months of inspections, and appealed for more time.

title: Is a Demon Humanized No Longer A Demon?
description: THE Hitler industry has marched effortlessly into the 21st century, with a new round of movies, documentaries and books. But this isn't your father's Hitler. The previous generation was fixated on military strategy, the corruption of power, the nature of evil. Now there's a new emphasis on psychology and aesthetics, youthful disappointments and artistic frustration. Was Hitler gay, or simply misunderstood? Or maybe it was something in his childhood.

title: The Mother of an Era: August Wilson's
description: ON a stifling July night in 1982, an aspiring playwright named August Wilson sat in the airless barn that served as the main stage for the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center in Waterford, Conn. Nearing 40, he had lately been earning his living as the staff cook for a social service agency in Minnesota. Beside him perched his mother, who had never seen any of his efforts at drama performed. This one was called ''Ma Rainey's Black Bottom.''

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2003 Honda Accord; Further Dividends From Honda's Midsize Investments

Near the end of each model year, automakers mounted last-ditch efforts to win the crown that went to the nation's best-selling car.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOBELSKI, DOROTHY T.
description: KOBELSKI-Dorothy T., 78. Devoted widow of John J. Kobelski, Jr. Died Monday, January 20th, 2003 in her home. Funeral mass will be held at 10 A.M., on Monday, February 3rd, 2003 at The Church of our Saviours (38th Street and Park Avenue, Manhattan). She is survived by her sister Helen.

title: Jan. 26-Feb. 1: INTERNATIONAL; A DIVIDED EUROPE
description: As Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain met President Bush in Washington, Europe's divisions over war in Iraq deepened. Mr. Blair was one of nine European leaders who offered support for Washington in a letter published in several newspapers to scold France and Germany, whose leaders say the case for war is unproven. The letter split Europe into relative hawks and doves, reducing the chances of consensus if United Nations weapons inspections fail to disarm Baghdad. Alan Cowell

title: The Outsider
description: Gary Hart is standing in the kitchen of his cabin in the Denver foothills, where, for a week about 15 years ago, he and his family hid from the news media by pinning sheets over the windows. ''You couldn't know what kind of nightmare that was if you haven't lived through it,'' he says. Now the former senator and two-time presidential candidate is leaning against the oven in a black turtleneck sweater, holding a glass of white wine in one hand and a fistful of assorted nuts in the other. A decade in the political wilderness will do things to a man, and Hart looks considerably more weathered than the young candidate in old photos.

title: A New Draw for the Delicatessan Crowd
description: MURRAY, the central character in the play ''A Thousand Clowns,'' says, ''People fall into two distinct categories, Miss Markowitz; people who like delicatessen and people who don't like delicatessen.'' The pro-deli crowd is on a roll these days. After a long period of decline, Jewish delis are surging back on Long Island. A few years ago, Ben's opened a big one in Woodbury. More recently, Pickles started up in Port Washington, then Pastrami on Park in Rockville Centre, the City Deli in Huntington and two months ago the Pastrami King, a legendary Queens deli, struck a nostalgic chord by opening a 200-seat spot at 196 Merrick Road in Merrick (516-377-4300).

title: FIRING UPHELD
description: A Superior Court judge has awarded severance pay of $79,675 but upheld the firing of a chief executive of the Miss America pageant. The judge, M. Allen Vogelson, further ruled that a jury should decide on claims by the executive, Robert L. Beck, to a bonus, further severance and lawyers' fees. Mr. Beck said in his suit against the pageant's board that he was dismissed illegally after a dispute over whether divorced or pregnant women could compete in the 1999 pageant. Mr. Beck contended that not allowing them to participate could open the organization to discrimination lawsuits, but the board did not agree. Judge Vogelson ruled that the board had the right to fire him and did not infringe on his rights to free speech.

title: On the Streets Where We Live

The woman was homeless, and she was walking down Main Street in Peekskill, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARKE, JOSEPH P.
description: CLARKE-Joseph P. 86, died at home on January 31, 2003. Beloved husband of the late Eileen Williams Clarke, devoted father of Eileen Guiney, Mary Anne Korsiak, Joseph M., Peter and Kevin. He is survived by three brothers, Rev. Thomas Clarke, S.J., Charles Clarke and Raymond Clarke. A veteran of World War II, Mr. Clarke was an active leader in the building and construction industry for over 60 years. He was President of the New York Roofing Co., and past President of the Building Trades Employers Association. He was chairman of Local 8 Board of Trustees. Mr. Clarke's long career was marked by volunteer service to many organizations. He served on the Board of Directors of Calvary Hospital, The Catholic Medical Center of Brooklyn and Queens, and St. Johns Medical Center. An active member of Sacred Heart Parish, Mr. Clarke was also a longtime advisor to the Archdiocese of New York and the Diocese of Brooklyn and Queens. He was an honoree of the Cardinal's Committee of the Laity. Family will receive friends at Francis X. Hatton Funeral Home, 36-46 Bell Blvd, Bayside, NY, on Sunday and Monday from 2-5 PM, and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers donations to Hospice of Naples, 1095 Whippoorwill Ln, Naples, FL 34105; American Cancer Society, 20 Mercer St, Hackensack, NJ 07601; Make a Wish Foundation, 1034 Salem Rd, Union, NJ 07083, would be appreciated.

title: 'A Box of Matches'
description: Good morning, it's January and it's 4:17 a.m., and I'm going to sit here in the dark. I'm in the living room in my blue bathrobe, with an armchair pulled up to the fireplace. There isn't much in the way of open flame at the moment because the underlayer of balled-up newspaper and paper-towel tubes has burned down and the wood hasn't fully caught yet. So what I'm looking at is an orangey ember-cavern that resembles a monster's sloppy mouth, filled with half-chewed, glowing bits of fire-meat. When it's very dark like this you lose your sense of scale. Sometimes I think I'm steering a space-plane into a gigantic fissure in a dark and remote planet. The planet's crust is beginning to break up, allowing an underground sea of lava to ooze out. Continents are tipping and foundering like melting icebergs, and I must fly in on my highly maneuverable rocket and save the colonists who are trapped there.

title: Double-Timing the King
description: Perhaps the final verdict on Wallis Warfield Spencer Simpson, better known as the Duchess of Windsor, should be William Manchester's. In the second volume of his biography of Winston Churchill, he writes, simply and pungently, ''If the man existed with whom Wallis had enjoyed a platonic friendship, his name is lost to history.'' Mr. Manchester also quotes H. L. Mencken on the subject of Mrs. Simpson's affair with Edward VIII, which led to his abdication in 1936 and his becoming the Duke of Windsor. Mencken was a Baltimore man, and Mrs. Simpson was ''the Baltimore woman.'' He called it ''the greatest story since the resurrection.''

title: The Other Face of Fanaticism
description: On the evening of Jan. 30, 1948, five months after the independence and partition of India, Mohandas Gandhi was walking to a prayer meeting on the grounds of his temporary home in New Delhi when he was shot three times in the chest and abdomen. Gandhi was then 78 and a forlorn figure. He had been unable to prevent the bloody creation of Pakistan as a separate homeland for Indian Muslims. The violent uprooting of millions of Hindus and Muslims across the hastily drawn borders of India and Pakistan had tainted the freedom from colonial rule that he had so arduously worked toward. The fasts he had undertaken in order to stop Hindus and Muslims from killing one another had weakened him, and when the bullets from an automatic pistol hit his frail body at point-blank range, he collapsed and died instantly. His assassin made no attempt to escape and, as he himself would later admit, even shouted for the police.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEEDS, LAURENCE C. III.
description: LEEDS-Laurence C. III. Our wonderful Cary, devoted son, beloved brother, uncle, grandson and nephew. We admired and respected you so much. Strong, kind, sensitive, caring, generous, proud, brave, independent, beautiful soul. Gallant, chivalrous, charismatic. Handsome, graceful, marvelous athlete. Brilliant, world ranked tennis star. Wimbledon semi-finalist. Graduate of Collegiate School and Yale University, class of 1979, attended the Wharton Graduate School of Business. Inquisitive, thoughtful, successful entrepreneur. Always the sought after, kind and loyal friend. You made an indelible impression everywhere you went and on everyone you met. You brightened our days, made us laugh, cry, and then laugh more. We wanted to be where you were. You changed our lives. Cary, you are the shining star in the eyes of Samuel, Michael, Benjamin, Nicholas and Olivia. You will always be their hero and ours. You were so brave always, overcoming great adversity, rebuilding your world, finding happiness. You inspired us with your courage and we will always take great pride in your achievements. You left us at the prime of your life and we will miss you with all our heart everyday. A beautiful soul. Dalia, Larry, Tracy, Evan, Ashley, Christopher. A service will be held on Sunday, February 2, at 11:30 AM, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, NYC. 212-288-3500. In lieu of flowers, donations in Cary's memory may be sent to The New York Junior Tennis League, 24-16 Queens Plaza South, Long Island City, NY 11101, an organization that provides free tennis programs in NYC's public elementary and middle schools.

With the agility of gymnasts and the strength of bodybuilders, they stacked themselves into a human pyramid, then formed baskets with their outstretched arms and blasted teammates known as fliers like toy rockets on a spring 25 feet in the air to twist, flip and strike ballet poses. Like dancers in a Broadway production, they shimmied their hips in synchronized chorus lines, stepping in time to the thumping music.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, CHARLES C., ''BUZZ''
description: WILLIAMS - Charles C., ''Buzz''. Age 75, of Lake Worth, FL, passed away on January 24, 2003, after a long battle with cancer. Born in Irvington, NJ, he entered the US Navy upon graduation from high school. After active duty he worked at Adler Electronics as office manager and after that began work with I.T.T. based at Griffith Air Force Base, Rome, NY. In the mid 60's he spent many years with Litton Industries. He moved to Boynton Beach, FL, in the early 70's to begin work at Rel-Reeves, an electronics and communciations firm, upon leaving RelReeves in mid 70's he started his own company with partner Ed Pastorino, Acme Products, Inc, an injection molding operation, which later specialized in products for the railroad industry. He worked up until five days of his passing, refusing to retire. Buzz is survived by his wife, Sally R. Williams, children, Charles (Judy) Williams, Wendy Williams, Marisa Nastasi (Richard) Englin, Tanya (Michael) Nastasi, and grandchildren, Chaz, Justin, Carly, Hunter, Alex, and Robin.

title: Patents; The patent office gains ground in its quest to keep more of what it receives in fees from customers.
description: AS the battle over the 2004 federal budget begins this week, many government agencies will argue that their piece of the fiscal pie should increase so they can reverse the nation's economic doldrums with increased productivity and new jobs. The Patent and Trademark Office is not shy about promoting itself as the source of many ideas for products and services. As such, it has argued for years that it should keep all the money it earns from customer fees, rather than watch as Congress diverts substantial chunks to other parts of government.

title: Investigation of a Tragedy
description: Even as we grieve the loss of the space shuttle Columbia and its crew of seven, the nation must gird itself for a searching inquiry into just what happened, and why. It is not enough to accept NASA's assurances that the space agency will find the problem, fix it and move on, carrying the nation's banner back into space. Rather this tragedy, like that which befell the Challenger in 1986, requires an aggressive, no-holds-barred inquiry by a presidential commission charged to evaluate not only the technical roots of this failure but also whether any management mistakes, budget cuts, loss of engineering talent or deep-seated cultural traditions at NASA may have contributed.

title: Vaclav Havel Takes His Leave
description: The phrase ''end of a political era'' usually refers to the eclipse of a movement, a collective approach animated by an idea. But when Vaclav Havel left Prague Castle on Sunday after 13 years as president, he took with him something quite different -- an exceptional individual moral authority. Mr. Havel leaves no clearly defined political legacy. What he leaves is the sense that in the life of a nation the character of its leaders matters. He showed us that speaking honestly and deeply when you are expected merely to express platitudes brings its own political authority. Czechs and the rest of us are better off because of him.

title: At Dawn, the Columbia
description: In the dark before dawn Friday morning, 24 hours prior to Columbia's re-entering the earth's atmosphere, I went outside to see if I could catch sight of it. Fog hung over the bay, obscuring all but a few stars. I had almost given up when the shuttle suddenly appeared, gliding across a black lagoon of clear sky between two cloudbanks. It didn't look like much -- a yellowish dot of light, wavering in the turbid air like a lantern on the stern of a receding square-rigger, bustling eastward with appointments to keep. But as I watched it vanish behind the clouds, I found myself thinking about the seven astronauts aboard.

title: Fear and Flying
description: Every tragedy in space gives rise to a handful of usual questions, and a big one is, Are astronauts ever scared? The answer, of course, is that every mission is different, every program is different, every person is different. For me, there is no question that space travel gave rise to an anxiety, a heightened sense of alertness. But I think most of my colleagues would agree that this has less to do with concern for your safety than with anxiety that your performance will not measure up to expectations. The big worry is that you are on the verge of messing up, and that might lead to a problem, endangering the mission and the crew.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMAS, ALEXANDER, M.D.
description: THOMAS-Alexander, M.D., Professor of Psychiatry. The NYU School of Medicine and the Department of Psychiatry wish to express our profound sympathy to the family of Dr. Alexander Thomas, on his untimely death. Dr. Thomas was a devoted, highly prized member of the Department of Psychiatry and made significant contributions as a scientist and administrator. With his wife, Dr. Stella Chess, he was in the forefront of studies in temperament. He wrote extensively and was internationally recognized. He served for more than ten years as Director of Psychiatry at Bellevue Hospital Center. Dr. Thomas graduated from NYU School of Medicine as the youngest member of his class in 1936, and was elected to Alpha Omega Alpha. After World War II, he returned as a resident in psychiatry and joined the faculty in 1948. He is responsible, with Dr. Chess, for the training of child psychiatrists on an international basis. We are deeply saddened by the loss of his future contributions to us all. He will be sorely missed. Robert M. Glickman, M.D., Dean, NYU School of Medicine Robert Cancro, M.D., Chairman, Department of Psychiatry, NYU School of Medicine

''This is a large and dynamic region where we currently don't provide any retail banking services,'' he said. ''It's also adjacent to the Clearwater area, where we already have a presence.'' Charter Banking is the holding company for Southern Exchange Bank, based in Tampa, Fla., which has 18 branches in the region, FNB said.

The prisoner, Jorge Paneto, 27, had been charged with burglary and he escaped as he was being led from Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn Saturday evening. Gregory Michaels, the detective escorting him, was suspended, the police said on Sunday. Mr. Paneto was arrested at his girlfriend's house on West 133rd Street in Manhattan around 11:30 p.m. last night. He was charged last night with first degree escape, said Detective Robert Price. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Flat Biotech Results
description: Europe's largest biotechnology company, Serono, reported $320.8 million in 2002 profit, an increase of 1.3 percent from 2001, in part because of costs of phasing out the company's first big success, a line of fertility treatments made from purified urine, which have been eclipsed by newer products. The company had hoped for 10 percent growth for the year. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: Election Defeat May Move Schrder to Reform Economy
description: A day after Chancellor Gerhard Schrder suffered a humiliating rebuke in state elections, politicians and economists here said today that the defeat might liberate his government, at long last, to undertake a wholesale reform of Germany's hidebound economy.

title: Plans to Reform House of Lords Are Plunged Into Confusion
description: LONDON, Feb. 4  Government plans for reforming the House of Lords were plunged into confusion and uncertainty tonight when the House of Commons dealt Prime Minister Tony Blair a rare parliamentary setback by rejecting his preferred choice of an all-appointed upper chamber.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALY, DANIEL
description: DALY-Daniel, formerly of Fairfield, CT, died at Pine Plains, NY on February 1, 2003. He was Founder and President of the Mashomack Club and the Mashomack Foundation. He was a veteran of the U.S. Army and attended Columbia University where he was President of St. Anthony Hall, Georgetown University School of Foreign Service, the Sorbonne in Paris. He is survived by his sisters, Mrs. Bevin Patterson and Mrs. Alison Gerard, his brother, Michael, his 28 nieces and nephews, and his longtime friend and Manager of the Mashomack Club, David Thieringer. He was predeceased by his sister, Mrs. Madeleine Potter, and his brothers, T.F. Gilroy and Dermot. A wake will be held at the Mashomack Club, 7435 Route 82, Pine Plains, NY, on Friday, February 7, from 4pm to 9pm and Saturday, February 8, from 9:30am to 1pm. A funeral mass will be held at 11am, Monday, February 10, at St. Joseph Parish, Routes 25 and 133, Brookfield, CT. Interment to follow at Oaklawn Cemetery, Fairfield, CT. A memorial service will be held at the Mashomack Club in June. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Mashomack Foundation, PO Box 308, Pine Plains, NY 12567. The Foundation supports scholarships for area students.

title: Robbing a Bank the Hard Way: Through Wall, Not Teller Window

Jennifer Granholm, a Democrat, announced $4 million in across-the-board cuts for state agencies. The cuts include an annual savings of $3 million by dropping 1,000 leased vehicles from the state's fleet; eliminating color copying and reducing cellphone use by state employees were expected to save a combined $500,000. The cuts were in addition to more than $100 million in reductions lawmakers were negotiating. David Enders (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: WHITE PLAINS: HOME PRICES RISE IN WESTCHESTER Despite a troubled economy, prices for existing homes rose sharply last year in Westchester and Putnam Counties. In Westchester, the average cost of a single-family home rose to $525,000, up about 17 percent from the previous year, according to the Westchester-Putnam Multiple Listing Service, a realty group. In Putnam, homes sold for an average of $305,000, up about 21 percent. P. Gilbert Mercurio, the chief executive officer of the Westchester County Board of Realtors, said that demand remained high because of a limited stock and because the houses were less than one hour's commuting distance from Manhattan. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Wine Executive Dismissed
description: Southcorp, Australia's biggest winemaker, fired its chief executive, Keith Lambert, ending a 19-month tenure in which the shares fell 42 percent and the company had to cut its profit forecasts. Mr. Lambert, 48, is married to the daughter of Bob Oatley, Southcorp's biggest shareholder and the founder of Rosemount Wines. Mr. Lambert joined Southcorp when it acquired Rosemount.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: WAGES DECLINE Total pay packets shrank at a record pace in 2002 as companies slashed wages and replaced full-time workers with more part-time employees. title: 60's Radicals Reunited, This Time As Ensemble
description: A beckoning warmth radiates from the revival of Lanford Wilson's ''Fifth of July,'' which opened last night at the Peter Norton Space of the Signature Theater Company. And it's not just the midsummer imagery of buttery lighting and people in featherweight clothes. What really gives this production, which features the high-profile presences of Robert Sean Leonard and Parker Posey, a solar center is something less easily come by, especially in the ego-driven world of New York theater. If this ''Fifth of July'' glows in ways to melt even ice-bound cynicism, it's because it has that rare feeling of performers who seem to respect and -- get this -- actually like one another as much as they do their own juicy parts.

description: Auto sales dropped 2 percent in January from a year earlier, carmakers reported today, signaling what many analysts say will be a tough year for the industry. Consumers are expected to benefit, though, from a wave of new products, particularly from foreign automakers like Nissan Motor, and cheaper prices because of the competition.

description: For weeks now, the students of Russ Patane's sixth-grade science class at Lodi's Thomas Jefferson Middle School had been preparing for their visit today to the Buehler Challenger and Science Center.

title: Met Orchestra's Principals, Out of the Pit
description: Concertos were the order of the day at the Met Orchestra's Sunday afternoon performance at Carnegie Hall, and if there was a secondary agenda, it was putting some of the orchestra's principal players in the spotlight, at least during the first half of the concert. Both of the Met Orchestra's concertmasters, as well as its principal violist and one of its principal cellists were soloists on the first half of the program. The concerto-fest continued after the intermission, but with a rising star from outside the Met, the 30-year old Russian pianist Arcadi Volodos.

description: NEW YORK CITY'S chief supplicant went to Albany yesterday to ask the powers there if they would, pretty please, do something to keep his city, the avowed Capital of the World, from sliding down the tubes.

title: Assembly Approves Rent Bill Without a Crucial Loophole
description: True to his pledge, the State Assembly speaker today led his chamber to pass a bill that would extend rent regulation laws -- but without a key provision that has let landlords remove thousands of apartments from rent regulation.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Bosnia's Lawsuit To Proceed
description: The World Court confirmed that it would hear the lawsuit against Yugoslavia brought by Bosnia, which is seeking damages for genocide during the 1992-95 war. It was the second time the court rejected an appeal from Yugoslavia, trying to block the case, which was first filed in 1993. This time the Belgrade government argued that the suit was not admissible because Yugoslavia joined the United Nations as a new state in 2000 and could not account for actions before that. In a new complication, this week Yugoslavia is renaming itself Serbia and Montenegro. The role of the Hague-based World Court, also known as the International Court of Justice, is to settle disputes between nations, unlike the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia, which tries individuals. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Blair, Despite a Dubious Public, Sticks to Firm Stance on Iraq
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair, facing a public largely opposed to war in Iraq and critical legislators in the House of Commons, said today that Britain and the United States would not back down on their insistence that the time has come for Saddam Hussein to disarm or be disarmed by force.

title: Rose's Bid For Return To Game Hits Snag
description: If it seemed only a few weeks ago that Pete Rose was hustling back into baseball's good graces, he now appears to be running in place. A baseball official said yesterday that recent revelations about tax and gambling matters involving Rose had slowed the process by which Commissioner Bud Selig would determine whether to remove Rose from the permanently ineligible list.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Worldcom Will Cut 5,000 More Jobs
description: WorldCom Inc., the long-distance telephone company, said yesterday that it would cut 5,000 more jobs, or 8.3 percent of its work force, as part of a plan to emerge from bankruptcy protection by the third quarter. To help save $2.5 billion a year, WorldCom will also close offices and reduce line costs, or fees paid for network use, by 12.5 percent, the company said. The chief executive, Michael D. Capellas, has vowed to keep WorldCom mostly intact. He said last month that cost reductions would be part of preparations for a reorganization plan to be filed by April 15. The company, which cut 17,000 jobs last year, filed for bankruptcy protection in July after disclosing accounting errors that may total more than $9 billion. The 5,000 jobs to be eliminated are mainly corporate and administrative, WorldCom said. The company, which has 60,000 workers, also said it would pare sales, general and administrative expenses by 13 percent. Line-cost savings of $1.5 billion will come from network integration, improved technology and the renegotiation of more than 2,600 contracts with suppliers, WorldCom said. It did not say which offices would be closed or name the locations that would have employee reductions.

title: Reviving Romance With Space, Even as 'Space Age' Fades

Ballard published ''Which Way to Inner Space?,'' a manifesto railing against his field's preoccupation with exotic space travel and calling on popular imagination to focus instead on Earth, human consciousness and biology.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Court Stays Ruling On Java Technology
description: Microsoft won a round in its private antitrust fight with Sun Microsystems yesterday. A federal appeals court agreed to shelve temporarily a lower court order requiring Microsoft to carry Sun's Java technology in the Windows operating system. On Dec. 23, Judge J. Frederick Motz of Federal District Court in Baltimore issued the ''must carry'' order, ruling that Microsoft had to include the Java programming language and related technology for its anticompetitive behavior. In an appeal on Jan. 22, Microsoft called Judge Motz's order ''extreme and unprecedented.'' The federal appeals court agreed to stay the must-carry order pending appeal, which could take weeks or months. Microsoft said it was pleased with yesterday's ruling, while Sun expressed regret. Steve Lohr (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARZ, DIANE
description: SCHWARZ-Diane. Born May 13, 1942, in Newark, died February 1, 2003, at home in South Orange, NJ, with her family and loved ones. Diane attended Weequahic High School in Newark and the University of Chicago and went on to teach fourth grade in Westfield. She was a founder of South Orange Neighbors, a community stabilizing organization. Diane worked with the JCC of Union County, NJ, and United Jewish Federation of MetroWest, where she and her husband James have been longtime active volunteers. She leaves her husband James, mother Chuddy Polk, three daughters, Amy, Rachel and Rebecca and one grandson, Eli Joel Hollen, all bereft of an inspiring, articulate and devoted presence. Contributions in her memory may be made to Solomon Schechter Day School, or The Greater Newark Conservancy, or the charity of your choice.
