description: When all the proposals are tallied in the budget President Bush submitted today, they amount to the most ambitious changes in government operations that any president has put forward in decades.

title: A Team Player, Despite Little Acts of Sabotage
description: To know a period, look not to its greatest but its most typical. For the last half of the 18th century, Muzio Clementi will do nicely: not Haydn (sublimely eccentric), nor Mozart (atypically ambiguous, harmonically arcane). Clementi (1752-1832) sailed over the bright, ordered surfaces of the rococo and out of our memories, unless, that is, you are a 12-year-old piano student flailing away at his ''Gradus ad Parnassum.''

title: Bush's $2.2 Trillion Budget Proposes Record Deficits
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3  President Bush sent Congress a $2.23 trillion budget today  with record deficits  that would speed up billions of dollars in income tax cuts, provide huge increases for the Pentagon and offer a modest jump in spending for NASA.

title: Bits of Bugs Glow, to Delight a Queen
description: At the invitation of most unlikely patrons, the king and queen of Belgium, an artist has produced his latest and perhaps most extravagant venture in the Royal Palace here, decorating the principal hall with the wing cases of almost a million Asian jewel beetles.

title: For Republicans, Praise for President's Budget Is Selective
description: The Democrats had stockpiled red ink to dramatize the record deficits in President Bush's 2004 budget, and within hours of its release the printers on Capitol Hill were churning out crimson charts and the incendiary statements.

title: An Ode to Joy at Third and 61st
description: Michel Willaume, a pastry chef who was on the American team that won the pastry World Cup in Lyon, France, in 2001, has opened Mondrian, a shop and cafe at 1026 Third Avenue (61st Street). It's a branch of his shop in Great Neck, N.Y. Done in white and charcoal, it's brightened by his finely crafted confections, most named for painters and composers. Monet is layered with praline and chocolate on a butter cookie base, Gauguin is a golden dessert with bananas and other tropical flavors, and Beethoven is a seriously dark chocolate pastry. They are $4 to $6 each. He also makes macaroons in assorted flavors, including passion fruit, and sells sandwiches and salads.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCARLETT, BERNELL H.
description: SCARLETT-Bernell H. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family acknowleges with sadness the passing of Bernell H. Scarlett, beloved mother of our dear friend and devoted colleague, June Scarlett, Administrator for the Department of Medicine. To June, her brothers and sisters, the entire Scarlett family and to all of her mother's loved ones, we extend heartfelt condolences. Thomas Killip, MD Interim President and CEO Ruth Hennessey Senior VP for Administration Stephen G. Baum, MD Chairman of Medicine

title: Projection of Economy Takes a Cautious View
description: Compared with President Bush's nearly euphoric budget two years ago, the one the president put forward today was a splash of cold water.

title: California Monks Wage Fight on Developers
description: From a hillside perch fronting the Ramakrishna Monastery, Wil Devine, a jean-clad monk, pointed east toward a long verdant foothill and ridgeline.

title: Judith Miller
description: Judith Miller, who has had a distinguished career in journalism, is a senior writer at The New York Times and currently writes about national security issues.

title: ASARCO SETTLES WITH JUSTICE DEPT. ON SALE AND POLLUTION
description: Asarco, the United States subsidiary of Grupo Mexico, the copper mining company, has reached an agreement with the Department of Justice to sell its 54.2 percent stake in Southern Peru Copper to another unit of Grupo Mexico. The sale price of $765 million permits Asarco to pay off debts of $550 million that fell due this week and last week. The deal also sets up a $100 million trust fund for cleaning polluted Asarco sites. The agreement ends a lawsuit filed by the United States government seeking to stop the sale on the ground that Asarco would sell assets, declare bankruptcy and walk away from the environmental cleanup. Wall Street analysts say the final cleanup costs could reach as much as $700 million. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

title: 2 Teams of Architects to Compete for Ground Zero Design
description: Two teams of architects, one that sees the foundations of democracy in the concrete walls surrounding ground zero and another that imagines New York's rebirth in soaring towers of culture, have been selected as finalists in the competition to create the design for the World Trade Center site, rebuilding officials said yesterday.

title: Unions Object To Elements Of Proposal By United Air
description: Leaders of unions at United Airlines offered pre-emptive objections yesterday to a recovery plan that airline executives are expected to present to them today.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Setting Out With a Dream And a Lot Of Sausages
description: THE MASTER BUTCHERS SINGING CLUB

title: Businesses Overcome a Burden on the Fingers
description: Dave Schneider needed only an hour yesterday to save a 70-person office from New York's newest inconvenience, dialing a 1 and an area code on every call -- even to the takeout place down the street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAUB, MILTON M.
description: TAUB-Milton M., 88. Of Mount Vernon, NY. On February 2, 2003. Beloved husband of Edna. Devoted father of Laura and her husband David, Janet and her husband David, Victor and his wife Esty, Bernardo and his wife Lidia. Loving grandfather of eight grandchildren. Services will be 10AM Wednesday at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: NIGERIA: CURFEW AFTER UNREST A dawn-to-dusk curfew was imposed in the southern oil city of Warri after a third night of ethnic violence that brought the number of deaths to more than 20, including members of the security forces. Youths went on the rampage overnight in Warri, in the oil-rich Niger Delta, killing police officers and setting dozens of homes and offices ablaze, witnesses said. The latest violence has pitted ethnic Urhobos against Itsekiris in a long-standing dispute over the location of government offices and amenities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEBEL, RUTH (NEE KIRSTEIN)
description: ZEBEL-Ruth (nee Kirstein). Beloved wife of the late Sydney. Loving sister of the late Ann Rothenberg, Ida Kirstein & Myron Kirstein. Dear aunt of Neil Rothenberg, David Kirstein and Emily Kirstein. For information, call Jewish Memorial Chapel, Yonkers, New York, 914-965-0660.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: President Lacks Majority
description: Lacking a majority in the new Congress sworn in over the weekend, President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva, left, will have to rely on support from opposition parties to push through reforms he promised voters. In the lower house, Mr. da Silva has the support of 254 deputies from 10 parties, shy of the 308 he would need to vote through pension, tax and other reforms. In the 81-seat upper house, Mr. da Silva has formal backing from just 31 senators. Jos Sarney, a former president who has backed Mr. da Silva, was elected head of the Senate, while Joo Paulo Cunha of the president's Workers' Party was elected head of the Chamber of Deputies. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: Misguided Marijuana War
description: Administration officials annoyed at California's support of the medical use of marijuana have found someone on whom to vent their frustration. Last week, at the urging of federal prosecutors, a judge convicted Ed Rosenthal of charges that carry a five-year minimum sentence. Mr. Rosenthal is a medical-marijuana advocate who grows the drug for use by the seriously ill. His harsh punishment shows that the misguided federal war on medical marijuana has now escalated out of control.

title: Cancer Surgery to Sideline UConn Coach Calhoun
description: Jim Calhoun, the highly successful men's basketball coach at Connecticut, said yesterday that he had an early stage of prostate cancer. He will have surgery Thursday to remove the prostate and said his doctors expected he would return to coaching in three to four weeks.

title: New Jersey Doctors Hold Back Services In Insurance Protest
description: The doctor was out for patients all across New Jersey today as thousands of physicians stayed away from their offices and hospitals to protest what they consider to be ruinous increases in malpractice insurance rates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITTLE, ELIZABETH STELLA
description: LITTLE-Elizabeth Stella, 87. Died peacefully in her home in Palo Alto, CA on January 26th. Born in New York in 1915 to Itala and Joseph Stella. She is survived by a sister, Ethel Stella, a son Andrew Little, daughters Anne Broderick Kavanau, Katy Derezinski and Amy Mayer, nine grandchildren and four greatgrandsons. She has been cremated and a memorial service will be held on March 14th, in Palo Alto, CA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, MICHAEL
description: KLEIN-Michael, 65. Of White Plains, NY on February 2, 2003. Devoted husband of Jill, beloved father of Marcie and Anthony and his wife Lynn. Cherished grandfather to Blake Michael. Services will be 12 noon, Wednesday, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: Ankara Parliament Expected to Take Up U.S. Troop Issue
description: Prime Minister Abdullah Gul said today that he would ask Parliament this week to consider measures that could clear the way for American combat troops to use the country as a base for an invasion of Iraq.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the formal announcement that the 2004 Republican National Convention would be held in New York City referred incorrectly to Mark Racicot, the national party chairman. He is the former governor of Montana, not the current one.

title: BIOGEN TO PAY $55 MILLION TO SETTLE PATENT DISPUTE
description: Biogen said yesterday that it would pay $55 million to Berlex Laboratories, an affiliate of Schering, as part of a settlement that ends patent infringement claims related to the two companies' drugs for treating multiple sclerosis, a neurological disease. Last month, the parties reached a settlement that called for Biogen to pay Berlex $20 million and receive a license under patents held by Berlex. On Friday, the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit upheld most of a lower court ruling that Biogen did not violate patents. Had the ruling been reversed entirely, Biogen would have faced a $230 million payment. Biogen said the payment, to be made immediately, ends the litigation between the companies.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Death Toll Rises In Blast
description: Rescue workers continued to dig for bodies crushed by an explosion in a crowded city block in Lagos, as investigators, including bomb experts, plowed through the debris for clues to the cause of the Sunday morning blast. A Lagos state government spokesman said the death toll was at least 30, while later reports by The Associated Press put the toll at 44. Somini Sengupta (NYT)

title: Editorial Observer; The Exotic but Fallible Spy Machines Behind America's Case for War
description: Secretary of State Colin Powell will be laboring under the burden of a generation's worth of spy novels and movies when he comes before the United Nations Security Council tomorrow to unveil some of America's intelligence secrets about Iraq. In the popular imagination, spy satellites can tell the president of the United States anything he wants to know at any time about America's foreign enemies. Turn on TV almost any night and you'll see Bondian agents ferreting out the bad guys with the help of satellites that follow their every move like security cameras in a bank. It's an appealing concept, but it isn't true.

title: Suit Is Filed to Block Layoffs Of Connecticut State Workers
description: Relations between Gov. John G. Rowland and state-employee labor unions went from bad to worse today as labor leaders filed a federal lawsuit seeking to rescind thousands of layoffs that they say illegally single out their members.

title: Vatican Book Is Offering Reflections On 'New Age'
description: The Vatican turned its attention to the New Age movement today, years after unicorns and dolphins started gliding together in Venice Beach landscapes and Shirley MacLaine began waxing spiritual about the healing powers of crystals.

title: Even the Up Escalator Is Down, and It's Not Likely to Be Fixed Soon
description: In 1931, the construction of the Empire State Building, then the tallest skyscraper in the world at 1,250 feet, was completed after 14 months.

title: Finding Happiness: Cajole Your Brain to Lean to the Left
description: All too many years ago, while I was still a psychology graduate student, I ran an experiment to assess how well meditation might work as an antidote to stress. My professors were skeptical, my measures were weak, and my subjects were mainly college sophomores. Not surprisingly, my results were inconclusive.

title: OIL PRODUCER MAKES $333 MILLION ACQUISITION
description: The Plains Exploration and Production Company, an oil and natural gas producer, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the 3TEC Energy Corporation for $333 million in cash and stock to expand its holdings of drilling properties. 3TEC stockholders will receive $8.50 and 0.85 share of Plains Exploration common stock for each of their shares, Plains said. Plains said it would also assume $99 million in 3TEC debt. Plains Exploration, based in Houston, produces oil and gas in California, Indiana and Florida. 3TEC Energy, also based in Houston, has oil and gas exploration operations in Texas, Louisiana and Oklahoma.

title: New Burden for a Cash-Poor Russian Space Program
description: The disintegration of the shuttle Columbia throws the mantle of space exploration for the immediate future onto a venerable Russian program that is experienced in manned flight but, by most accounts, hard-pressed to shoulder such a heavy burden.

title: Back to Earth: Two Stories of Return
description: Like Jim Pawelczyk, I was a payload specialist aboard the space shuttle Columbia. Our mission, like that of the Columbia crew who perished, was devoted to biomedical research. On May 3, after 16 days of weightlessness, it was time for us to come home.

title: DaimlerChrysler Returns to Profit, but Investors Want More
description: FRANKFURT, Feb. 4  Reaping the benefits of a deep cost-cutting regime at its troubled Chrysler division, DaimlerChrysler of Germany said today that it swung from a net loss to a profit in the fourth quarter and for all of 2002.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Brewer Expects Costs
description: The British brewer and pub operator Scottish and Newcastle said additional revamping costs at its British beer division would crimp profit for 2003. The division, known as Scottish Courage, is expected to incur an additional 15 million ($24.6 million) in costs as it consolidates its distribution centers. As a result, the company expects no significant growth in operating profit in its British beer division. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Activision Account Is in Review
description: In the continuing fallout from the closing of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles by its parent, the Publicis Groupe, Activision, the video game maker, is conducting an informal review for its account, which has been handled by the D'Arcy Los Angeles office since 2000.

title: Debris at Liftoff a Leading Suspect in the Shuttle Loss
description: NASA investigators said today that a piece of insulation that broke off the shuttle's external fuel tank about 80 seconds after liftoff was now a prime suspect in the cascading series of failures that destroyed the shuttle Columbia 16 days later.

title: Bush Leads Memorial in Houston for Seven Columbia Astronauts
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 4 - President Bush hailed the astronauts of the space shuttle Columbia today as seven lost explorers of great daring and purpose, then declared that America's only course in the face of the tragedy was to push forward in the conquest of space.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL FALLS. Prices fell after OPEC warned of a possible second-quarter glut and as exports from Venezuela began to recover from a strike. In New York, oil for March delivery fell 75 cents, or 2.2 percent, to $32.76 a barrel.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Retail Sales Decline
description: German retail sales declined 2.3 percent last year compared with the year earlier, falling for the first time since 1997, the government said. Sales in the month of December fell short of most forecasts, falling by 3.2 percent from December a year earlier. The government said food sales were nearly steady, falling only 0.2 percent, while the nonfood sector was hurt by overall weakness in consumer spending. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: A New Show Blessed for What It Isn't
description: ''A.U.S.A.,'' a new NBC sitcom set in the United States attorney's office in Manhattan, seems startlingly old-fashioned: it is a three-camera taped show with a laugh track, a cast of likable oddballs and dialogue sprinkled with references that seem taken from an old Bob Newhart episode, like Bob Dole and the Tuskegee airmen of World War II.

description: Barry Krause, a top executive at Publicis Worldwide, is returning to Chicago to fill the vacant post of president at the Chicago office of J. Walter Thompson.

description: Even among people who do not have diabetes, poor glucose tolerance appears to be linked to weaker memory, according to a study released yesterday.

description: In the aftermath of the Columbia disaster, questions are being raised about the future of the space shuttle program, but there can be no satisfactory answers without considering what is to become of the International Space Station.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Holocaust Site Vandalized
description: Vandals in the northern town of Cernobbio damaged a monument to an Italian who saved thousands of Jews from the Holocaust, the Italian police said. The memorial was dedicated to Giorgio Perlasca, who prevented the deportation of at least 3,000 Hungarian Jews to concentration camps by issuing protective passes under the guise of the Spanish consul to Budapest. The police said they suspected that the defacement took place over the weekend and that it was random rather than anti-Semitic. The incident, however, came on the heels of Italy's Holocaust Memorial Day, which included a widely publicized television movie about Mr. Perlasca. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Budget Committees' Leaders
description: SENATOR DON NICKLES Oklahoma. Republican, chairman. Age 54. Elected 1980. Assistant Republican leader 1997 to 2003. Member of the Budget Committee since 1987. Named chairman in 2003. Worked for a family owned business that made equipment for the oil and gas industry; eventually became vice president and general manager. Forcefully advocates a reduced role for the government. Strong supporter of President Bush's economic proposals, including more tax cuts.

title: The Imbalanced Budget
description: The $2.23 trillion budget unveiled by the Bush administration yesterday is the furthest thing from a fiscally conservative document. It shifts taxes from today's citizens to those of the future. Rather than truly giving state governments the power to be flexible, it sticks them with the responsibility for delivering the bad news to poor people who will be denied a health care safety net. The gargantuan defense budget is bloated with money for old-style weaponry needed only by defense contractors and military empire builders.

description: Department of Justice

title: Even Before Disaster, the Plan Was to Increase NASA Spending
description: In his proposed budget for 2004, written well before the space shuttle Columbia disintegrated, President Bush said the shuttle program suffered ''from inadequate planning and poor cost management.'' He asked Congress to increase spending for the shuttle to $3.97 billion, up from $3.2 billion this year.

title: Medical Errors, for Outpatients
description: Studies of medical errors generally focus on those in hospitals. But a new study suggests that injuries stemming from mistakes made when patients are discharged from hospitals or in their follow-up care may be more common, though not as serious.

title: South Korea Calls Off Inquiry Into Payments to North Korea
description: Worried about aggravating tense relations between the two Koreas during the nuclear crisis, South Korean prosecutors called off an investigation today into whether South Korea secretly paid North Korea to agree to their summit meeting two and a half years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOOVER, GEORGE
description: HOOVER-George. 69, on January 31, in NYC. Cherished companion of Marian Porges. Beloved father of Geoffrey and Robby. Doting grandfather of four. Adored son of Rose Hoover. Memorial service to be held Tuesday, February 4, 3 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Asmterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The Porges Family Fund at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 633 3rd Ave, 28th flr, NYC 10017.

title: Swiss Court Approves Hearing in Gypsy Suit Against I.B.M.
description: PRAGUE, Feb. 4  A Swiss court has cleared the way for hearings in a $12 billion lawsuit against the computer giant I.B.M. by a group of Gypsy organizations, which are arguing that the company helped the Nazis automate the Holocaust.

title: Now, the Space Station: Grieving, Imperiled
description: The grounding of the three remaining space shuttles after the destruction of Columbia poses enormous, and potentially calamitous, challenges for the International Space Station and the 16 countries trying to maintain it as a permanent foothold in space.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASCHE, MARJORIE E.
description: ASCHE-Marjorie E. On February 1. Beloved wife of the late Abraham (Jack) Asche. Loving mother of Richard and Barbara Asche and Judith and Stephen Stoll. Adoring and proud grandmother of Michael, Rachel, Corey and Katia. Dear sister of Leonard Ernst and sister-inlaw of Esther Asche. title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: GLOBAL CHIP INDUSTRY RECOVERED IN 2002 The microprocessor industry recovered in 2002 and will see sales grow 20 percent in 2003, according to a report issued yesterday by an industry trade group. The Semiconductor Industry Association said global chip sales, buoyed by a strong fourth quarter, hit $140.7 billion, a 1.3 percent rise from 2001. The organization projected that sales would hit $169.3 billion in 2003, with growth coming in particular from sales to makers of wireless devices, like cellphones, and consumer electronics, like DVD players and digital cameras. The report found that the fastest growing market is the Asia-Pacific region, where chip sales rose 29 percent over the previous year.    Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: BREWER EXPECTS COSTS The British brewer and pub operator Scottish and Newcastle said additional revamping costs at its British beer division would crimp profit for 2003. The division, known as Scottish Courage, is expected to incur an additional 15 million ($24.6 million) in costs as it consolidates its distribution centers. As a result, the company expects no significant growth in operating profit in its British beer division. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: WENDY'S CUTS ITS PROFIT FORECAST FOR 2003
description: Wendy's International cut its 2003 profit forecast yesterday because of falling prices, rising costs and less spending by customers, the company said. Per-share profit will rise 7 percent to 10 percent, to $2.02 to $2.08, from $1.89 last year, the chief executive, Jack Schuessler, told investors in New York. That was less than his previous forecast for annual profit growth of 12 percent to 15 percent. Sales at company-owned restaurants open at least a year in the United States declined 3.5 percent in January as cold weather kept customers away and Wendy's promoted its 99-cent menu, the company said. Higher costs for labor, insurance and beef will also hamper results.

title: CNN's Anchor Was Caught At Golf Event
description: Aaron Brown, who has anchored much of the CNN coverage of major breaking news events for 18 months, did not appear until 10 p.m. on Sunday, more than 36 hours after the news of the shuttle catastrophe broke.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HELD, JAMIE
description: HELD-Jamie. You are missed. Love, Shooter

title: Mattel's Profit Is Up by 35%, Led by Sales Of Barbies
description: Mattel Inc., the world's largest toymaker, said today that its fourth-quarter profit rose 35 percent after the company reduced costs and increased sales of Barbie dolls in the United States for the first time in at least two years.

title: Revamped MetroStars Return to the Field
description: It does not exactly rank up there with the day pitchers and catchers report, but the MetroStars opened training camp yesterday talking about new traditions and new beginnings -- again. This time, it looks as if they mean it. Really.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Governor Announces Budget Cuts
description: Facing a $292 million deficit for this fiscal year, Gov. Jennifer Granholm, a Democrat, announced $4 million in across-the-board cuts for state agencies. The cuts include an annual savings of $3 million by dropping 1,000 leased vehicles from the state's fleet; eliminating color copying and reducing cellphone use by state employees were expected to save a combined $500,000. The cuts were in addition to more than $100 million in reductions lawmakers were negotiating. David Enders (NYT)

title: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- In Miami; Where a Working Trip Can Seem Like Pleasure for Those in Winter's Grip
description: Being sent to Miami on business is usually a lot more like pleasure, especially when the rest of the country is enduring the big chill.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 24 about a possible link between a type of leukemia and exposure to high levels of Agent Orange, the defoliant widely used in the Vietnam War, referred imprecisely to the progression of the disease, chronic lymphocytic leukemia. It is gradual, not fast-moving, with the average life expectancy about eight years after the onset of the disease.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Chvez Rejects Early Election
description: President Hugo Chvez's government has rejected a proposal by the opposition movement for a constitutional amendment that would shorten the president's term and lead to new elections in this oil-rich nation. The announcement, made by Vice President Jos Vicente Rangel, came a day after the opposition held a petition drive on several antigovernment demands and collected what they said were more than four million signatures in support. The government has instead proposed a recall referendum for later this year. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Two Killed By Trains In Apparent Suicides
description: Two people died under trains last evening in what appeared to be suicides, the authorities said. As a result, thousands of commuters were delayed on subways running near 34th Street and 6th Avenue and on the New Haven line of the Metro-North Railroad. Around 5 p.m., a 48-year-old woman was struck by a northbound F train as it entered the 34th Street station, the police said. She was pronounced dead at the scene. While her death is still under investigation, witnesses said they saw her jump, the authorities said. Trains were rerouted, and normal service was restored about an hour later. On the New Haven line, an unidentified woman was struck and killed on the outbound tracks at the Mamaroneck station around 7:30 p.m. All four tracks there were shut down until 9 p.m., when one outbound track was opened. Inbound service was partly restored at 9:45 p.m., said Dan Brucker, a spokesman for the railroad. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: With Substance Unexplained, Red Cross Shelves a Blood Bag
description: The Red Cross shelved a once widely used type of blood collection bag yesterday as the investigation continued into a mysterious white substance discovered in its supply of donated blood in Georgia and Tennessee.

title: Richard Lyng, 84, Agriculture Secretary in Reagan Administration
description: Richard Edmund Lyng, a California businessman who became the secretary of agriculture in the Reagan administration, died on Saturday at his home in Modesto, Calif. He was 84.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. The yen fell against the dollar after a Japanese official said the government might consider ''massive'' sales to help stem the currency's rise. In New York, the dollar settled at 120.33 yen, up from 119.89 on Friday.

title: Stretch of Bronx Street Renamed to Honor Amadou Diallo
description: Ablock of the Bronx street where Amadou Diallo was killed in a hail of police gunfire was renamed today to honor the 22-year-old West African immigrant on the fourth anniversary of his death.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Americans Closing Guest Ranch
description: The American owners of a popular guest ranch in the southern state of Chiapas said they were closing it to tourists because of violent intimidation by Zapatista members of a neighboring community. The owners, Ellen Jones, 55, and Glen Wersch, 49, are former Peace Corps workers who have operated their Rancho Esmeralda for eight years. They said that staff members had been assaulted and were the focus of death threats from the neighboring Zapatistas, who have told the Americans that the ranch rightfully belongs to them. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Global Chip Industry Recovered In 2002
description: The microprocessor industry recovered in 2002 and will see sales grow 20 percent in 2003, according to a report issued yesterday by an industry trade group. The Semiconductor Industry Association said global chip sales, buoyed by a strong fourth quarter, hit $140.7 billion, a 1.3 percent rise from 2001. The organization projected that sales would hit $169.3 billion in 2003, with growth coming in particular from sales to makers of wireless devices, like cellphones, and consumer electronics, like DVD players and digital cameras. The report found that the fastest growing market is the Asia-Pacific region, where chip sales rose 29 percent over the previous year. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Hearing Will Focus On Bellsouth Executive
description: A court hearing will discuss BellSouth's effort to thwart the defection of its No. 2 executive, Gary D. Forsee, to the Sprint Corporation. The hearing, scheduled for tomorrow afternoon at the Superior Court of Fulton County in Atlanta, was requested by BellSouth after its lawyers obtained a restraining order over the weekend preventing Mr. Forsee from taking the job of chief executive at Sprint. BellSouth has said Mr. Forsee's employment contract prevents him from working for a competitor for 18 months after he leaves the company. A Sprint spokesman said yesterday that the company still expected Mr. Forsee to take its chief executive job after its legal differences with BellSouth were resolved. Sprint shares rose 36 cents, or 3 percent, to $12.50. BellSouth shares rose $1.02, or 4.5 percent, to $23.80. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKAY, SR. RAYMUNDE
description: McKaY - Sr. Raymunde, RSHM. In mourning her passing and celebrating her life, we at Marymount Manhattan College join the Religious of the Sacred Heart of Mary in expressing tribute to Sr. Raymunde. As a former dean and president, Sr. Raymunde made an extraordinary contribution to our founding and our independence, to our survival and our success. Those who knew her well remember a committed and gifted leader. In her later years, she never failed to convey her interest in our students and faculty and her enthusiasm for the mission of the College to which she had devoted so much of her life. Anna Hayes Levin, Chair of the Board Judson R. Shaver, Ph.D., President Marymount Manhattan Coll.

Old buildings need new uses, Ms. Jacobs once observed in her classic ''Death and Life of Great American Cities.'' The sentiment has a certain aptness as the creaking global house of fashion prepares this Friday to begin a monthlong open-house during fashion weeks in New York, London, Paris and Milan.

title: We May Conquer Space; It Will Never Be Easy
description: When I was a boy hiking in the mountains of the Northwest, one of the persistent fantasies that my friends and I had whenever we went someplace remote was that while we were gone, World War III would happen and we'd come back to find that the world had ended. Something like that happened to me Saturday, although what ended this time was not any world that ever existed, but a world that I had always presumed would one day exist, and had hoped to glimpse in my lifetime.

title: NESTL BUYS BOTTLED WATER UNIT OF HUTCHISON WHAMPOA
description: Nestl, the bottler of Perrier mineral water, said yesterday that it had bought the Powwow bottled water division of Hutchison Whampoa for 560 million euros ($604 million) in cash and debt to become Europe's largest seller of bottled water for home and office delivery. Powwow has sales of 120 million euros annually and about 1,500 employees in seven European countries, Nestl said. Hubert Genieys, a spokesman for Nestl's water unit, said the portion of the price that was debt was not immediately available. The purchase is Nestl's 11th acquisition in a year and reflects increasing competition for bottled water businesses.

description: Medical records were released yesterday for a woman who accused St. John's forward Grady Reynolds of assault, Reynolds's lawyer said.

title: A.I.G. ADDS $2.8 BILLION TO RESERVES
description: The American International Group, the commercial insurer, said late yesterday that it was setting aside an additional $2.8 billion because of unexpected increases in liability claims. The company had already set aside $30 billion for liability and other claims. The increase in reserves was one of the largest by any commercial insurer in recent years. That A.I.G., respected for its careful management, could be caught by surprise by a surge in claims suggested that other insurers will be increasing their reserves, a move that will reduce their earnings. The chief executive, Maurice R. Greenberg, attributed the jump in claims ''to the rampant rise in jury awards and a tort system in urgent need of reform.'' Joseph B. Treaster (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMITIN, ERNEST JONAS
description: AMITIN-Ernest Jonas. Died Sunday, February 2, age 90. Son of the late MenachemMendel (Max) and Sophie (Garfinkle). Brother of Alex, Rita, Isadore, Eva, Harry and Ethel. Born in Manhattan. Former resident of Fort Lee, Westwood, Saddle Brook and Elmwood Park (NJ), New York City and Waterville (NY). Husband of 64 years to the late Gladys (Epstein). Survived by his children, MerleJoy Cenicola (Philip) and Mark Hall Amitin, three grandchildren, eight great grandchildren and one greatgreat granddaughter. Recipient of the Red Cross Clara Barton Award for four years of service teaching first aid, life saving, swimming. Founding member of SBRP Jewish Center, boat model designer exhibiting in libraries and museums. Worked with Hackensack YMHA, Tenafly Jewish Center, Teaneck Yeshiva, Supreme Pants and Formflex Foundations. Services today, February 4, 12:15 PM at Plaza Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave, at 91st Street followed by funeral at Riverside Cemetery, Saddle Brook, NJ at 2:15 PM.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Bank Posts Profit
description: Brazil's largest bank in the private sector, Bradesco, made a profit of 2.02 billion reais ($573 million) in 2002, a decline of 6.8 percent from the previous year, because of a slowing credit market and increased provisions for bad debt and a depreciating real. Bad-debt provisions totaled 333 million reais ($93 million) last year, compared with 156 million reais ($44 million) in 2001, while provisions to deal with the volatile exchange rate totaled 504 million reais ($143 million), the bank said. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Leader To Run For Parliament
description: Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the leader of Turkey's governing Justice and Development Party, is planning to run for Parliament in March, a move that could lead to his becoming prime minister, a Turkish official said. The party captured a majority in the Turkish National Assembly in elections last November, but Mr. Erdogan could not run for Parliament, and so could not become prime minister, because of a prior conviction for reading aloud a poem that was said to be inciting religious hatred. Over the past several weeks, members of Mr. Erdogan's party amended Turkey's Constitution to enable their leader to run for office. Dexter Filkins (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Security Guard Charged With Sodomy
description: An armed security guard employed by Sea Gate, a gated community west of Coney Island, was arrested yesterday and charged with sodomizing a 14-year-old boy, the police said. The officer, Wilfredo Torres, 39, of Creston Avenue in the Bronx, was also charged with unlawful imprisonment. Around 10 p.m. on Sunday, the police said, Mr. Torres picked up the victim in his marked car and attacked him. The boy was treated at Coney Island Hospital, and Mr. Torres was arrested yesterday afternoon, the police said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPODHEIM, RENEE
description: SPODHEIM - Renee. Died January 31, 2003 at her residence in New York; daughter of Frederic and Regina Spodheim. She was born in Bacau, Romania and became a U.S. citizen in 1947. During WWII she was a translator for the Office of War Information. She studied at the Sorbonne and Columbia University; she taught at Columbia, The University of Havana, Cuba, and Fieldston School, holding the last post until she retired. She was also a literary agent and translator. She is survived by her sister Hilda DeBacker of Charleston, S.C. The burial will be private.
