title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Home Prices Rise In Westchester
description: Despite a troubled economy, prices for existing homes rose sharply last year in Westchester and Putnam Counties. In Westchester, the average cost of a single-family home rose to $525,000, up about 17 percent from the previous year, according to the Westchester-Putnam Multiple Listing Service, a realty group. In Putnam, homes sold for an average of $305,000, up about 21 percent. P. Gilbert Mercurio, the chief executive officer of the Westchester County Board of Realtors, said that demand remained high because of a limited stock and because the houses were less than one hour's commuting distance from Manhattan. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Briefly Noted
description: U.S. PLANE ATTACKED Five war protesters overpowered a policeman guarding a hangar at Shannon Airport in southwest Ireland and attacked a United States Navy plane with hammers, as well as vandalizing the site with human blood and spray-paint, the police said. The protesters were arrested at the scene and later appeared in court. The airport is a refueling stop for American military planes en route to the Persian Gulf. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Mitsubishi Electric Profit
description: One of Japan's five largest chip makers, the Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, earned 1.1 billion yen ($9 million) in the October-to- December quarter, helped by cost-cutting measures and increased sales of industrial machinery. The small profit was in contrast to the 38.4 billion yen loss the company posted a year earlier. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Technically Speaking
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Bush Mourns Astronauts
description: President Bush hailed the astronauts of the space shuttle Columbia as seven lost lives of great daring and purpose.

title: Full Transcript of NASA News Conference
description: Following is the full transcript from a news conference on Wednesday in Houston by Ron C. Dittemore, the manager of NASA's space shuttle program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYMAN, ROBERT
description: LYMAN-Robert. The members, Board of Governors, and staff of Pine Hollow Country Club mourn the passing of our long time member and good friend. We extend our sympathies to his wife, Sally, and the entire family. The Board of Governors Pine Hollow Country Club

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Kearny: Trooper Shoots Man After Chase
description: A New Jersey state trooper fatally shot a man who had led officers on a chase from East Orange last night, the authorities said. About 7:30 p.m., officers with the East Orange narcotics unit approached a suspected drug dealer near Clinton Street and Central Avenue, said John R. Hagerty, a spokesman for the Division of Criminal Justice, which is investigating the shooting. The suspect, who police believe was armed, fled on Route 280 eastbound in a 1992 Honda Acura. His car collided with several vehicles, though no one was injured, and he fled into a marshy area, Mr. Hagerty said. A state trooper followed the man and shot him, and he was pronounced dead at 9:40 p.m. at University Hospital in Newark. The names of the victim and the trooper were not released. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Hitachi Reverses Loss
description: Hitachi said that it earned 1.3 billion yen ($10.8 million) in the last three months of 2002 as sales grew 5 percent. The company lost 116 billion yen ($968 million) in the same period a year ago. Hitachi said the revamping of its semiconductor and telecommunications equipment businesses improved profitability. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Ethiopia: Trying To Stop Genital Cutting
description: Delegates from across Africa arrived in Addis Ababa for a three-day conference whose goal is to stop the traditional practice of cutting women's genitals as a rite of passage. ''An intolerable number of women are mutilated, abused, abducted, battered, maimed, bruised and forced into early marriage in the name of tradition,'' Berhane Ras-Work, president of the Inter-African Committee on Traditional Practices Affecting the Health of Women and Children, said at the opening of the conference, which is titled Zero Tolerance to Female Genital Mutilation. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Europe Debates Whether to Admit God to Union
description: In the colorless conference rooms of the European Union's headquarters here, where discussions often center on farm subsidies and budget deficits, a small group of politicians will meet on Wednesday to discuss God.

title: Scientists Suspect a Wider Field of Debris, With the Breakup Starting Over California
description: Pieces of wreckage that investigators here hope will tell them the cause of the destruction of the Columbia are now believed to be spread across more than half the continent, covering thousands of square miles from California to Louisiana.

title: Iraq Has No Banned Arms, Hussein Says in Interview
description: In a rare televised interview that was broadcast here tonight, Saddam Hussein denied that Iraq possessed any weapons of mass destruction or had any links to the terror network Al Qaeda.

title: Moscow Journal; Capitalism Spawns a New Leisure Class: Mall Rats
description: They come on free shuttle buses and flock together in the food court. They play video games for hours in the Soyuz computer store. They are Moscow mall rats.

title: Interpublic is making some headway with its financial problems as a deadline approaches.
description: AS a deadline nears for renegotiating loan agreements with banks, the Interpublic Group of Companies in New York seems to be making some progress in addressing its financial problems. The troubled agency company has received bids in the sale of a large division and is cutting costs through a merger of two of its agencies.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Science Times yesterday with an article about the science experiments aboard the space shuttle Columbia reversed two images in some copies. A diagram by NASA should have appeared with text describing the shuttle's observations of the ozone layer; a photograph of Earth from Columbia should have appeared with a description of research on dust storms and climate change.

title: House Raises Questions on Dividend Taxes and Deficit
description: House Republicans, President Bush's strongest base of loyalty in Congress, were skeptical today about his plans for eliminating most taxes on dividends and for running large deficits in the foreseeable future.

title: Woman Crushed in Israeli Demolition of Gaza Home
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 5  While demolishing the home of a Palestinian militant's family in the Central Gaza Strip today, Israeli forces crushed to death his 65-year-old stepmother, who apparently did not hear their warnings to leave, the woman's family said.

title: Powell's Speech Seen as Unlikely to Change European Opinion
description: BERLIN, Feb. 5  The presentation by Secretary of State Colin L. Powell at the United Nations was termed persuasive and forceful by foreign policy experts and political figures in Europe, but few seemed to believe that European public opinion would be measurably swayed one way or the other.

title: With Stream of Intelligence, Powell Makes Case to U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 5 - Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, pressing the American case for a possible war to disarm Iraq, today presented photographs, intercepts of conversations between Iraqi military officers and information from defectors aimed at proving that Saddam Hussein poses an imminent danger to the world.

title: Not to Copy Choreography but to Reveal It With New Clarity
description: Taking stock of the Martha Graham Dance Company season, which ended on Sunday at the Joyce Theater, one might arrive at two conclusions. The first is that the commitment of the dancers and the new artistic directors, Terese Capucilli and Christine Dakin, is not in doubt. The second is that these same directors need to crack the whip and have the Graham technique executed properly and to the hilt. Often it was not.

title: Turkey Declares Intention to Back U.S. War Plans
description: ISTANBUL, Feb. 5  Turkey's prime minister said today that his government would ask parliament later this month to allow American troops to use the country in event of a war with Iraq, marking the first time the government has publicly declared its intentions to back American war plans.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: HACKENSACK: 4 CHARGED IN ATTACK ON OFFICER An off-duty police officer was hospitalized Sunday after four people attacked him and one bit off most of his nose and right ear. The officer, Richard Levis, was recovering at home yesterday after emergency reconstructive surgery. Chief Charles Zisa of the Hackensack police said that as Officer Levis left work on Sunday, he noticed a vehicle blocking traffic and spoke to the driver. As the officer tried to return to his car to call for police assistance, the driver, Carlos Diaz, 23, jumped him, Chief Zisa said. Mr. Diaz then bit him, Chief Zisa said, while three others  Jose Felix, 43, Franklin Guerra, 27, and Shemara Nunez, 27  joined the attack. The four were charged with attempted murder.

title: NASA Now Doubts Tank Foam Debris Doomed Columbia
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 5 - NASA officials expressed doubt today that a piece of foam from the external fuel tank that struck the shuttle Columbia during its liftoff could have led to the destruction of the ship.

title: Debris Search Is Expanded To California and Arizona
description: NASA dispatched teams to Arizona and California today to determine if any of the Columbia's heat-resistant tiles or material from its wings had fallen early in the shuttle's descent on Saturday morning, a senior NASA official said.

title: Who Is Being Judged, We or McDonald's?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, EUGENIE. ''GENIE''
description: KAUFMAN-Eugenie. ''Genie''. Passed away January 30, 2003. Represented J. Arthur Rank in America. Heaven will be filled with her laughter. We will love and miss her. Katie, Elizabeth, Joyce Rosenberg and Family

title: Judge to Hear New Evidence In '86 Murder
description: Reopening an all-but-dormant case that has been a lightning rod for Asian-Americans, a judge in upstate New York has agreed to hear fresh evidence in the case of an illegal Chinese immigrant who was convicted of killing a fellow inmate more than 15 years ago.

title: U.S. INVESTMENT FUND IN TALKS FOR JAPANESE PHONE UNIT
description: Ripplewood Holdings, a $3 billion United States investment fund, is in talks to buy the fixed-line phone business of Vodafone Group in Japan, the president of the phone unit said. ''We are in discussions with parties including Ripplewood to sell our fixed-line business in Japan,'' said William Morrow, the president of the Japan Telecom Holdings Company, the nation's third-largest fixed-line operator. ''We can't comment on the value as we have had no firm offer.'' A Ripplewood spokesman, Jeffrey Taufield, declined to comment. Japan Telecom hired UBS Warburg to advise on the sale, Mr. Morrow said.

title: S.E.C. Nominee Vows to Revive Investors' Confidence
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 — President Bush's nominee to head the badly bruised Securities and Exchange Commission pledged today to restore the agency's stature as part of a campaign to revive investors' confidence in Wall Street, confidence that he said had been deeply undermined in recent months.

title: On a Mission To Shine A Spotlight On Genocide; Samantha Power's Mind Leaps From Bosnia to Iraq
description: By her own definition Samantha Power is a child of Bosnia. Not literally: born in Ireland in 1970, she came to the United States when she was 9. With her billowy red hair and long-legged stride, she exudes a purposeful all-American energy that is far from the bleakness of the Balkans.

title: Will the Neighbors Approve?
description: In talking with Bush administration officials of late I am struck by an incredible contrast. It is the contrast between the breathtaking audacity of what they intend to do in Iraq -- an audacity that, I must say, has an appeal for me -- and the incredibly narrow base of support that exists in America today for this audacious project. They are gearing up for the rebuilding of Iraq, along the lines of the rebuilding of Germany and Japan after World War II, and the nation is geared up, at best, for the quick and dirty invasion of Grenada.

title: WARNACO GROUP EMERGES FROM BANKRUPTCY
description: The Warnaco Group, the maker of Calvin Klein jeans, emerged from bankruptcy after repaying creditors with new shares and eliminating more than $2 billion in debt. Warnaco sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in June 2001, unable to pay debt from acquisitions and licensing agreements. Warnaco, which is based in New York, renegotiated licensing deals, sold assets and closed retail stores during its reorganization. A federal judge approved the company's plan to come out of Chapter 11 on Jan. 16. Creditors, who were owed more than $2.45 billion, were repaid with new shares, notes and cash. The company reorganized around its sportswear, intimate apparel and swimwear product groups. Warnaco says it has arranged a $275 million loan to help finance its current operations.

title: Remembering the Columbia Crew
description: ''That melody is lost.'' Those words were quoted by Rabbi Harold Robinson as he stood in the spring-like sunshine of southern Texas yesterday. The melody he meant was that of the seven lives that ended when the shuttle Columbia disintegrated on re-entry, lives that were honored in a simple memorial service outside the Johnson Space Center in Houston. The past few days have witnessed a tragic succession of images, from the bright streak in the Saturday morning sky to the pieces of wreckage that lay scattered halfway across the country.

title: A New Face in the Trattoria Crowd
description: THE branzino, or sea bass, is a mainstay all over northern Italy. Firm fleshed, with a mild flavor, it seems to thrive on almost any preparation. Nearly every trattoria along the Ligurian coast serves branzino baked in the fruity, light-bodied local olive oil with a handful of Gaeta olives, a little garlic and a scattering of herbs. Branzino baked in a salt crust, another popular version, traps the moisture in the fish. And wherever artichokes thrive, they end up sharing the plate with one of Italy's most beloved fishes.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the search for debris from the space shuttle Columbia misstated the craft's mission. It was primarily for scientific experiments; Columbia did not travel to the International Space Station.

title: The Iraqis' Use of Poison Gas
description: To the Editor:

title: Mariucci Signs With the Lions For $25 Million
description: Steve Mariucci might have felt like an outsider as the coach of the San Francisco 49ers, but he has been embraced by the Detroit Lions, who signed him yesterday to a five-year deal worth a reported $25 million.

title: A Power Struggle Without End
description: If Congress needed any further proof that the United States Olympic Committee has ceased to function as a governing body and has become nothing more than a laughingstock, it came last night.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: 350,000 Subscribers For Virgin Mobile
description: Virgin Mobile U.S.A., the wireless carrier venture between Sprint PCS and the Virgin Group of Britain, is expected to announce today that it signed up 350,000 subscribers in its first six months of operation in the United States. The company, which focuses on providing prepaid cellular service from Sprint's network to young consumers, had 245,000 new subscribers in the fourth quarter of 2002, representing about 6 percent of total net subscriber additions in the period. Virgin Mobile succeeded in attracting subscribers at a time when other carriers, including Sprint and Cingular Wireless, a joint venture of BellSouth and SBC Communications, suffered from customer defections. Daniel H. Schulman, above, Virgin Mobile's chief executive, said in an interview that he expected the company to become profitable within two and a half years. Shares of Sprint PCS fell 8 cents, to $3.69. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article and a chart in Business Day on Monday about a decline in the number of dial-up subscribers to Internet services misstated the percentage change for two services from 2001 to 2002. The combined total of dial-up and high-speed subscribers for Earthlink rose by 3 percent, to 4.8 million; it was not unchanged. The number of dial-up customers for SBC-Prodigy declined by 22 percent, to 1.4 million, not by 61 percent.

title: Bagels in Paradise, Kona Nova With a Schmear
description: ''SHALOHA!''

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a damaged mosque in Afghanistan that was rebuilt with money raised by Episcopalians and Muslims in the United States misstated the date of the smaller of two pictures. It showed the mosque after it had been damaged, not before.

title: Showdown Over Orchestra Size Looms on Broadway
description: In what is shaping up to be one of the most bitter showdowns in Broadway history, theater producers and musicians have begun negotiations on a new contract that will hinge on the size of orchestras.

title: Indonesia Officer Says Soldier Killed Independence Leader
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 5  An Indonesian Army officer told a court-martial today that a soldier killed Theys Eluay, the popular leader of a nonviolent campaign for an independent Irian Jaya, an eastern province also known as Papua.

title: Governor's Cutbacks Anger Advocates for the Arts and Health Care
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey offered some sympathy today as he doled out the bad news, saying his budget would hurt programs he supported and bring pain to constituents he would like to help. But cuts in spending on the arts and health care left advocates for those programs feeling singled out and abandoned.

title: London Imam Is Removed As Leader Of Mosque
description: The government today removed Britain's most outspoken Muslim cleric from his post as imam at the Finsbury Park mosque, which it contends is a recruitment center for violent Islamic militants.

title: Who Is Being Judged, We or McDonald's?
description: To the Editor:

title: AID TO POOR FACES TIGHTER SCRUTINY
description: President Bush's budget proposes new eligibility requirements that would make it more difficult for low-income families to obtain a range of government benefits, from tax credits to school lunches.

title: Russia Halts Tourist Trips Into Space In Emergency
description: Thrust by the Columbia shuttle disaster into a new role as sole supplier of the International Space Station, Russia said today that its lucrative space tourism program had been suspended until the station's future was assured and seats in its Soyuz space capsules were again available.

title: INSIDE
description: Finalists in Design Contest

title: Florida Is Making Its Mark During the Recruiting Period
description: February is considered by some to be a down time on the sports calendar, but nothing could be further from the truth for college football fans.

title: Court Agrees to Hear Appeal, Delaying Trial for Ex-Nets Star
description: ANew Jersey appellate court agreed yesterday to hear arguments by lawyers for the former basketball star Jayson Williams seeking a dismissal of an indictment in the shooting death of his limousine driver last year.

title: Trenton Seeks a Compromise for Doctors
description: As thousands of New Jersey doctors rallied against rising malpractice insurance costs today outside the State House, lawmakers inside said they had sketched the broad outlines of a compromise that might end the doctors' two-day work slowdown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABELES, LILLIAN WEINER
description: ABELES-Lillian Weiner, 86. Formerly of New York City, died Monday, February 3, 2003. Graveside services will be held on Thursday at 11:00 in Wellwood Cemetery, Farmingdale. Contributions may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: Make It 60 In a Row: UConn Routs St. John's
description: For one glorious moment at Alumni Hall last night, after the first basket of the game, St. John's held the lead over the best women's basketball team in the nation.

title: Gunman Robs Guards Filling Cash Machine at L.I.U.
description: In a daring morning robbery in Brooklyn yesterday, an armed man escaped with $74,000 and the weapons of two security guards as they tried to fill an automated teller machine machine at Long Island University, the authorities said.

title: Give Us a Chance to Build a Democratic Iraq
description: When Colin Powell appears at the United Nations today, he is expected to talk about Iraq's efforts to build weapons of mass destruction and its ties with terrorist organizations.

title: North Korea Opens a Route Across Its Frontier
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 5  A convoy of buses carrying 100 South Koreans crossed the North Korean frontier today, opening the first road for normal traffic between the two Koreas since the Korean War.

title: NASA Colleagues, by the Thousands, Get Their Chance to Mourn
description: The crowd of thousands stretched over a large lawn, and included presidents, senators and dignitaries. Yet for many NASA employees, it felt like an intimate gathering.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Dividend Plan Drops Penalty For Borrowers Who Buy Stock
description: The Bush administration has reversed course and decided not to penalize individual investors who borrow money to buy dividend-paying stock.

title: Budget Gives I.R.S. More Money to Investigate Tax Cheats
description: President Bush's budget would increase by a third or more the number of audits of taxpayers suspected of hiding income received from their businesses, partnerships, investments and offshore accounts.

title: National Briefing | West: Hawaii: Illnesses Cut Short Cruise
description: Princess Cruises has canceled the final five days of a Hawaii voyage after 265 passengers, or 13 percent of the 2,029 on board, came down with a Norwalk-like gastrointestinal virus. The Sun Princess had made all of its scheduled port calls, but a company spokeswoman said the remaining five days of the return trip to Los Angeles were called off to prevent further illness. Passengers began disembarking in Honolulu and were to be flown back to the mainland by Wednesday, the spokeswoman said. Michele Kayal (NYT)

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  YACCARINO, JOSEPH J.
description: YACCARINO-Joseph J. Seventh birthday away, but never out of mind. Happy Birthday dear friend, Ton

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Bush Budget Increases Push to Find Tax Cheats

title: Off With Her Crown! Miss Brazil Hid a Vital Statistic (Marriage)
description: It was one thing when the last Miss Brazil admitted she had shaped her perfect figure under the plastic surgeon's knife, but this year's incumbent lost her crown and sash today after confessing that she was, in fact, Mrs. Brazil.

title: Yazoo Boondoggle
description: Every so often something comes along to remind us of Congress's immense capacity for self-indulgence at the expense of sound public policy. This time it's the Yazoo Pump, a senseless (and expensive) project buried in the Senate version of a huge appropriations bill now headed to a House-Senate conference. Our hope is that fiscal conservatives among the House conferees will kill it. Failing that, it will be up to Christie Whitman, head of the Environmental Protection Agency, to do so. This project is yet another instance of the destructive relationship between the Army Corps of Engineers and its pork-loving paymasters in Congress that, over the years, has produced one environmental disaster after another.

title: Some Trades in S.&P. Futures Are Canceled After Odd Surge
description: More than $170 million in futures trades in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index were canceled late yesterday after the Chicago Mercantile Exchange concluded that a sudden spike that sent prices up almost 12 percent within seconds had occurred for no good reason.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GOLD RISES. Gold rose as the United States stepped up efforts to win support for a war on Iraq, increasing demand for the metal as a haven. In New York, gold for April delivery rose $8.30, or 2.2 percent, to $379.90 an ounce.

title: A Space Big Enough for Sandwiches, and Not Much Else
description: LET me say it straight out: La Sandwicherie is not for everybody. In fact, it's hardly for anybody. This narrow slice of a place, carved out of a storeroom in the rear of the Moroccan restaurant Zitoune, comfortably seats six, providing the weather is good and puffy jackets don't take up too much room. It is quite possibly the smallest restaurant in the city.

title: Nets Need a Break, and They're Getting One
description: Richard Jefferson was sweating out the lingering effects of the stomach flu today, amazed that he was able to play a team-high 47 minutes Monday night in the Nets' 109-108 overtime victory against the Seattle SuperSonics.

title: Reebok Ad Tackles Nike Commercial
description: The longtime rivals Nike and Reebok International are at it again as Reebok introduces a commercial tonight that parodies a new Nike spot.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Decision Delays Ex-Basketball Star's Trial
description: A New Jersey appellate court agreed yesterday to hear arguments by lawyers for the former basketball star Jayson Williams, who is seeking a dismissal of an indictment in the shooting death of his limousine driver last year. The decision, by the Appellate Division of the Superior Court, delays the long-scheduled Feb. 18 start of Mr. Williams's trial on charges of aggravated manslaughter. The appeals panel scheduled arguments for March 12. Mr. Williams, 34, a retired star of the New Jersey Nets, has pleaded not guilty to charges that he recklessly shot the limousine driver, Costas Christofi, 55, during an impromptu tour of his Hunterdon County estate with friends on Feb. 14, 2002. His lawyers say the shooting was accidental. Mr. Williams is also charged with witness tampering and obstruction of justice. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: Mining for Riches on the Farm
description: This was not his destiny. Jos Contreras did not know there was gold in his right arm. His father was a tobacco farmer in Pinar del Rio, a town in the Cuban countryside near the western end of the island. The youngest of nine children, Contreras was working with the oxen by the time he was 7, helping his father in the fields.

title: A Tribute To a Pioneer Just Before His Death
description: Lou Harrison was not able to attend the six-day festival of chamber music and orchestral works presented at the Juilliard School last week, titled ''Beyond the Rockies: A Tribute to Lou Harrison at 85.'' Though he had long been struggling with health problems, the given reason for his absence was a previous commitment to another Harrison festival.

title: Where Banks Pay Borrowers to Borrow Money
description: People often think of zero interest the way physicists do the speed of light, as an absolute limit. After all, who would agree to lend money at negative interest and be certain of a loss, when it could simply be left in a safe and remain whole?

title: Rumsfeld Defends General Investigated by Pentagon
description: The Pentagon confirmed today that Gen. Tommy R. Franks is under investigation for possible abuse of his office. But Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld expressed full confidence in the general, who commands the American forces preparing for possible war with Iraq.

title: Toyota Says Profits Nearly Doubled in Last Quarter of 2002
description: TOKYO, Feb. 5  Toyota Motor Corp. said profits nearly doubled in the last quarter of 2002 as Japan's largest automaker continues to solidify its share of the global car market.

title: Long Island Priest Admits Sodomizing a Teenage Boy
description: A Long Island priest pleaded guilty yesterday to sodomizing a teenage boy, wrapping up a case that first came to light before allegations about abusive priests began making headlines across the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALDSTON, MORTON, MD
description: GALDSTON-Morton, MD, 90, February 3rd, after a long battle with Parkinson's Disease. Beloved husband of Irene; father of Elsa, Kenneth and Philip; father-in-law of Janet Saglio and Nancy Tarshis; grandfather of Jesse, Molly and Daniel. Loving brother of 12 (including Naomi Rosenberg and Vera Simms, who survive); uncle, great and great-great uncle of over 100. Esteemed physician, researcher, teacher, friend and colleague. Affiliated with NYU Med School for 70 years, from student to Assoc. Prof. of Medicine. Fellow in Medicine, The Johns Hopkins Hospital. Member Alpha Omega Alpha, NY Academy of Medicine, among many professional societies. His thirst for knowledge, sensitivity, perserverance and love will inspire us always. Donations to Friends of the Library, NYU Med School, C/O Ehrman Medical Library, 550 1st Ave., NY, NY 10016. Service Sunday, February 9, 12:45PM, ''The Riverside'', 76th and Amsterdam Avenue

title: For Do-It-Yourselfers Who Specialize in Sweets
description: Those who light the oven for special occasions like Valentine's Day, instead of merely shopping, can find supplies galore at Choc-Oh-Lot-Plus, 7911 Fifth Avenue in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. The shelves overflow with candy and pastry molds; sugars and chocolates in assorted colors for dipping, molding and decorating; even pleated paper cups, doilies, boxes and ribbon for wrapping homemade confections. The shop also sells instruction books and candy made on the premises.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORSHIN, CAROLYN R. (NEE RELIS)
description: KORSHIN-Carolyn R. (nee Relis) died peacefully at her home in Whitestone, NY on February 4, 2003, after a short illness in which she was attended by close friends and her granddaughter Farra Korshin. She was born in New York City on November 25, 1910, and grew up near Liberty, NY. She graduated from Hunter College in 1931 and began her teaching career the same year in a one-room schoolhouse in Bushville, NY at a salary of ten dollars a week. After the birth of her children, she resumed her teaching career in New York City, earned two M.A. degrees from Queens College and, after many years of teaching at Thomas Edison High School in Queens, retired in 1975. She had an active retirement, enjoying travel, gardening, and her piano, and will be greatly missed by her friends and family. Her husband Nathan Korshin, whom she married in 1937, predeceased her. She is survived by her sons, Jonathan of Prestonburg, KY., Oliver of Anchorage, Alaska, and Paul of Wyncote, PA., six grandchildren, and two greatgrandchildren. Funeral arrangements will be private. Donations in her name may be made to the Korshin Family Fund, St. John's College, Annapolis, MD 21404.

title: An Environmentalist With No Time for Houseplants
description: HOLED up in the 400-square-foot East Village cubbyhole that passes for his urban retreat, Alex Matthiessen, the gaunt, tousled executive director of the environmentalist group Riverkeeper, is making urgent notations on a computer as he barks instructions meant for Robert F. Kennedy Jr., a member of Riverkeeper's board and its chief counsel, into a cellphone.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Bloomberg Says Disagreements With Pataki Will Stay Private
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that any private complaints he had with Gov. George E. Pataki about the budget would stay private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERRY, EDWARD HARRIMAN
description: GERRY-Edward Harriman. The Boards, Faculty, and Staff of NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital extend their deepest sympathy to Martha B. Farish Gerry, Hospital Life Trustee, and her family for the loss of her beloved husband, Edward Harriman Gerry. We also extend our heartfelt condolences to his daughters, Libbie F. Merovich, Martha R. Townley, and Cornelia Harriman Corbett. Herbert Pardes, M.D. President and CEO NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital

title: Students' Mental Health
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: LOSS AT TELECOM CONCERN The maker of tele-communications equipment Alcatel posted a loss of 1.12 billion euros ($1.2 billion) for the fourth quarter and predicted that sales would decline 25 to 30 percent in the current quarter compared with a year ago. The chief executive, Serge Tchuruk, said that the industrywide slump would continue this year and warned that sales would be hurt by the strengthening of the euro against the dollar, as well as soft demand from telecom operators. The fourth quarter results were, however, better than expected, and Mr. Tchuruk said he remained confident that Alcatel would reach its goal of breaking even in operating results in 2003. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: A Ticking Clock on North Korea
description: North Korea's rapidly advancing nuclear weapons program is the most urgent threat facing America today. Yet the administration, intent on dealing with Iraq first, has been reluctant to give diplomacy with North Korea the priority it warrants. Yesterday's reaffirmation by Washington that it recognizes the need for direct talks with North Korea is fine, but not good enough. Those talks will probably never take place unless the administration drops its preconditions.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Racial Bias Case
description: A federal lawsuit has accused DaimlerChrysler of routinely denying African-American car buyers low-interest loans based on their race. The lawsuit on behalf of six black car owners accuses the company of unfairly rerouting credit applications from black consumers to its regional headquarters rather than processing them in an automated, colorblind computer program. Those customers were denied loans, the suit said. It also said that black customers who were in good standing had their vehicles repossessed without warning. A company spokesman denied the accusations, calling them outrageous. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: TOMMY HILFIGER CHIEF ADDS THE TITLE OF CHAIRMAN
description: The clothing manufacturer Tommy Hilfiger named its chief executive, Joel J. Horowitz, as chairman yesterday, replacing Tommy Hilfiger, the designer who started the company. Mr. Hilfiger will remain principal designer and will resume the role of honorary chairman, which he gave up in October after being named chairman. The company said it was still looking for someone to succeed Mr. Horowitz as chief executive since he has said he will retire next year. The apparel company reorganized its board last year to meet a New York Stock Exchange rule requiring a majority of members to be independent.

title: Barolos Become a Little Friendlier, Faster
description: BAROLO is a big, muscular red wine capable of living forever thanks to its tarry, impenetrable tannins. Any Barolo worthy of the name is, or should be, undrinkable until it is at least 10 years old. Right?

title: Bush's Speech at the Houston Memorial Service for Shuttle's Crew
description: Following is a transcript of President Bush's remarks yesterday at a memorial service in Houston for the crew of the space shuttle Columbia, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO GAINS. The dollar fell against the euro as some investors grew concerned that a war with Iraq would erode consumer confidence and slow growth. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0877, from $1.0768 on Monday.

title: A.I.G. Adds $3.5 Billion To Reserves
description: Facing an upsurge in potential liability claims, the American International Group increased its reserves by $3.5 billion yesterday in a move that could have reverberations across the insurance industry and in Washington, where Republican lawmakers are eager to restrain liability lawsuits.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: AZERBAIJAN: INDICT GORBACHEV, OFFICIALS SAY Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the last leader of the Soviet Union, should be indicted for "crimes against humanity" for his role in crushing an uprising in Azerbaijan in 1990, Azerbaijani officials said. They blame Mr. Gorbachev, a winner of the Nobel Peace Prize, for the deaths of about 170 people killed when troops and tanks were sent into the capital, Baku. Mr. Gorbachev defended his actions this week, saying the troops were sent in to stop pogroms against ethnic Armenians. (Agence France-Presse)

title: Blair, Out to Change Lords, Trips Up in House of Commons
description: Government plans for reforming the House of Lords were plunged into confusion and uncertainty tonight when the House of Commons dealt Prime Minister Tony Blair a rare parliamentary setback by rejecting his preferred choice of an all-appointed upper chamber.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: ILLINOIS: RACIAL BIAS CASE A federal lawsuit has accused DaimlerChrysler of routinely denying African-American car buyers low-interest loans based on their race. The lawsuit on behalf of six black car owners accuses the company of unfairly rerouting credit applications from black consumers to its regional headquarters rather than processing them in an automated, colorblind computer program. Those customers were denied loans, the suit said. It also said that black customers who were in good standing had their vehicles repossessed without warning. A company spokesman denied the accusations, calling them outrageous. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Viewers Flocked to Coverage by NBC and CNN
description: NBC commanded the largest broadcast viewership during live coverage of the shuttle crash on Saturday, according to preliminary figures from Nielsen Media Research, while CNN's coverage ranked first among cable networks.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about exhibits that Secretary of State Colin L. Powell was preparing for the United Nations about Iraq's concealment of weapons misstated the source of 1962 photographs showing Soviet missiles in Cuba that Adlai E. Stevenson displayed to the United Nations in an episode that Bush administration officials called more dramatic than the current one. The pictures were from U-2 spy planes, not satellites.

title: The Doctor Is Out in New Jersey
description: The spectacle of thousands of physicians hitting the bricks this week in New Jersey is a sobering measure of doctors' fury at the rising costs of malpractice insurance. But their proposed solution of a $250,000 cap on pain-and-suffering litigation is far too simplistic a prescription as the doctors attempt to pressure the state government for a quick fix.

title: Great Britain's Remarks to the U.N.
description: The following is the text of an address by British Foreign Secretary of State Jack Straw at the United Nations:

title: Special Courts Will Handle Felons' Probation Violations
description: The city and state will create new courts in all five boroughs to issue stricter and speedier sentences to felons who violate their probation, officials said yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: A Telecom Profit
description: South Korea's largest phone company, the KT Corporation, posted a 31 percent increase in fourth-quarter net income, chiefly on gains from selling shares in the SK Telecom Company. Profit rose to 654 billion won ($557 million) from 499 billion won a year earlier. Without the 670 billion won of share-sale gains, the company had a loss of 16 billion won.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: CAR SALES RISE South Korea's five motor vehicle manufacturers  Hyundai and Kia, in the Hyundai Automotive Group; GM Daewoo; Renault Samsung; and Ssangyong  reported total sales of 298,000 vehicles last month, an increase of 7 percent from January 2002. Hyundai, the country's dominant vehicle manufacturer, reported sales of 156,222 vehicles, up 3 percent, while Kia sold 86,712 vehicles, up 23 percent. Hyundai Automotive claimed 4.2 percent of the United States market in January; with Hyundai Motor selling 27,179 vehicles, up 0.2 percent; and Kia selling 18,524 vehicles, up 11.8 percent. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLOWNEY, EDWARD F.
description: MULLOWNEY-Edward F., 59. Formerly of Ridgewood, NJ, died suddenly at his home in Palo Alto, CA on January 31, 2003. He was the beloved husband of 36 years of Carole May of Bayonne, NJ and the father of Laura Mullowney of Palo Alto and Alison Cole and her husband Michael of Fremont, CA. He is survived by sisters Anne Petchel, Mary Lee, Denise Bickford and brothers William Mullowney and Thomas Mullowney. Ed, a renowned patent attorney, was the senior intellectual property lawyer in the Menlo Park, CA. office of the New York based law firm of Shearman & Sterling. He was a member of the recently established Patent Arbitration Committee of the Center for Public Resources, which has been at the cutting edge of alternative resolution in the United States. He was also director of the Law Foundation of Silicon Valley, a leading public interest group in Northern California, and was recently named by his peers in the publication ''Best Lawyers in America.'' Previously a partner in the firm of Fish & Neave from 1971 to 2001, he was a lead partner in the trial team for Polaroid in its landmark $925 million victory over Eastman Kodak. Edward received both his undergraduate and Master's degrees in engineering from Stevens Institute in Hoboken, NJ and proudly served as a trustee for the college. He received his law degree from Columbia University in New York City. In lieu of flowers, a contribution would be gratefully accepted to establish an endowment for The Edward F. Mullowney Scholarship at Stevens Institute of Technology, C/O Mr. James N. Snyder, Office of Development, Castle Point on Hudson, Hoboken, NJ 07030. Memorial mass, St. Thomas Aquinas, Palo Alto, February 6, 2PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALY, DANIEL
description: DALY-Daniel. A good and appreciated friend. He loved Mashomack and the young people who helped him make it a club for all to enjoy. We will miss him greatly and regret not spending more time with him. He is now with the God he loved. Dora and Ted

title: Corrections
description: The Eating Well column last Wednesday, about a provision in the farm bill last May to offer irradiated beef for school lunches, misstated the purpose of a pilot program in Minneapolis. It is to provide education about irradiation; irradiated beef is not being served at any school in Minnesota.

title: Tyco to Hold Its Meeting For Holders In Bermuda
description: Despite repeatedly proclaiming its commitment to become a leader in corporate governance, Tyco International plans to hold its annual meeting in Bermuda, where few of its shareholders will be able to attend.

title: Powell Without Picasso
description: When Colin Powell goes to the United Nations today to make his case for war with Saddam, the U.N. plans to throw a blue cover over Picasso's antiwar masterpiece, ''Guernica.''

title: Talk in Schools of Risk and Rewards in Space
description: With her 20 kindergarten pupils sitting cross-legged before her on a rug at the Murch Elementary School here, Melanie ElLaissi, their teacher, helped them understand what happened to the shuttle Columbia.

title: Speech Seen as Strong but Unlikely to Sway Skeptics
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  Secretary of State Colin L. Powell's presentation on Iraq to the Security Council today produced no smoking gun, but considerable and compelling smoke, in the view of some analysts and others who follow Iraq and arms issues.

title: Filmmakers Seek Protection From U.S. Dominance
description: During the countdown to the last global free trade accord in 1994, an outspoken group of French movie producers, directors and actors scored an impressive victory over Hollywood when cinema and other forms of audiovisual entertainment were excluded from the agreement. The compromise became known as the ''cultural exception,'' a term that, in France at least, quickly assumed the patriotic resonance of the opening line of ''The Marseillaise.''

title: 19 Charged in Identity Theft That Netted $7 Million in Tax Refunds
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have charged 19 people with being part of an identity theft ring in the Bronx that obtained at least $7 million in federal tax refunds by filing thousands of fraudulent income tax returns.

title: The Iraqis' Use of Poison Gas
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, DANIEL
description: FRIEDMAN - Daniel. We mourn the loss of Danny, our dear friend, and remember him as a source of strength, wisdom, humor and integrity. The memories will live on. Our deepest condolences to his entire family. Danny had a loving partner, his wife Lynn, to help him through the last few years. Jerry Stern, Allan Armour and Paul Christian

title: Cost-Cutting Lets Daimler Post Profit
description: Reaping the benefits of a stringent cost-cutting at its troubled Chrysler division, DaimlerChrysler of Germany said today that it had swung from a net loss to a profit in the fourth quarter and for all of 2002.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANDIER, FRANCES
description: BANDIER-Frances. Beloved wife of the late Otto Bandier and mother of Martin and Robert. Passed away peacefully, aged 92, at her home in Hallandale, FL on February 4. Loving and proud grandmother of Allison, Jennifer, Max, Mark, and David. Great grandmother of Cameron, Julia, Ashley, Daniel, Haley, and Emily. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The TJ Martell Foundation, 555 Madison Ave, 3rd Floor, New York, New York 10022.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: No Refund Sought Of Extra 9/11 Aid
description: The city's Human Resources Administration said yesterday that it would not seek the return of extra financial aid given to families of the victims of the Sept. 11, 2001, terror attack. Typically, the city recovers aid if recipients receive help for the same event from another agency, like the federal Victim Compensation Fund. The city does not have an estimate of the number of recipients or of how much money was given to those who also received federal aid. But the city said the number of New Yorkers receiving public assistance jumped by about 5,500 in the two months after the attack. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Great Britain's Remarks to the U.N.
description: The following is the text of an address by British Foreign Secretary of State Jack Straw at the United Nations:

title: Suspect in Slaying of Hong Kong Businessman Arrested in China
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 5 — The police in mainland China's Hunan Province said today that they had arrested the suspected gunman in the slaying of a prominent Hong Kong businessman, in a case that has fed crime fears in Hong Kong as border controls are relaxed.

title: Jurors Who Convicted Marijuana Grower Seek New Trial
description: In an unusual show of solidarity with the man they convicted last week, five jurors in the trial of a medicinal marijuana advocate issued a public apology to him today and demanded that the judge grant him a new trial.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Guilty Plea On Bomb Plot
description: Earl L. Krugel, 60, a former high-ranking member of the Jewish Defense League in Los Angeles, pleaded guilty to two federal charges related to a conspiracy to bomb a local mosque and the field office of a congressman, Darrell Issa, a Lebanese-American. Prosecutors said Mr. Krugel conspired with the J.D.L. leader Irving David Rubin, who died in November in what federal officials called a jailhouse suicide. Mr. Krugel faces 10 to 20 years in prison. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Loss At Telecom Concern
description: The maker of tele-communications equipment Alcatel posted a loss of 1.12 billion euros ($1.2 billion) for the fourth quarter and predicted that sales would decline 25 to 30 percent in the current quarter compared with a year ago. The chief executive, Serge Tchuruk, said that the industrywide slump would continue this year and warned that sales would be hurt by the strengthening of the euro against the dollar, as well as soft demand from telecom operators. The fourth quarter results were, however, better than expected, and Mr. Tchuruk said he remained confident that Alcatel would reach its goal of breaking even in operating results in 2003. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Liquor Outlook Is Flat
description: The liquor maker Allied Domecq said profit growth would stall this year because of declines in Spain, pension shortfalls and the weakening dollar. The chief executive, Philip Bowman, told shareholders that profit this year would be about the same as the 480 million earned last year. Shares in the company, which ranks behind Diageo among liquor makers, fell 10 percent.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Chemical Profit Rises
description: Ciba Specialty Chemicals posted a 6 percent rise in net income, to 406 million Swiss francs, but the strong Swiss currency last year caused a 4 percent decline in sales, to 7.08 million francs ($5.2 million). In local currencies, sales climbed 3 percent, the company said. Operating income was up 25 percent, to 788 million francs, and Ciba reduced its debt by one-third. Still, analysts say they are concerned because Ciba's profits have not recovered to its level in 2000, when it earned 452 million francs. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: No Assertion Of Irish Roots, Kerry Says
description: One might forgive people for assuming that Senator John F. Kerry of Massachusetts, a fast-rising Democratic candidate for president, is another in a long line of Irish-American politicians who have made it big in urban ethnic centers like Boston.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about exhibits that Secretary of State Colin L. Powell was preparing for the United Nations about Iraq's concealment of weapons misstated the source of 1962 photographs showing Soviet missiles in Cuba that Adlai E. title: James Asks Ohio Court To Block Suspension
description: The high school basketball star LeBron James has asked a court to block his suspension by the Ohio High School Athletic Association after he jeopardized his amateur standing by accepting two vintage jerseys valued at $845 from a clothing store in Cleveland.

title: U.S. Economy in Worst Hiring Slump in 20 Years
description: The American economy has fallen into its worst hiring slump in almost 20 years, and many business executives say they remain unsure when it will end.

title: Russia and Pakistan End 30-Year Estrangement
description: MOSCOW, February 5  Ending a 30-year diplomatic estrangement, the presidents of Pakistan and Russia met in the Kremlin today and pledged a fresh start to relations after decades of alliances with each other's sworn enemies.

title: President Bush's Address
description: Following is the text of President George Bush's address today at the memorial for Columbia's crew as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Nothing Like Big Deficits To Hearten Bond Traders
description: Only two years ago, the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, voiced his fears that the government was in danger of building up such big budget surpluses that the Treasury market could dry up. Washington might have no choice, he warned, but to put its extra money into buying up corporate stocks and bonds.

title: Ex-G.O.P. Boss on Trial Says He Funneled Bribes Reluctantly
description: A former Republican Party boss is portraying himself in trial testimony as the reluctant conduit for kickbacks to Nassau's chief deputy county executive in a multimillion-dollar health insurance scandal.

title: In Piedmont, a New Landscape for Barolo
description: WINTER in Piedmont is an unchanging tableau of mists rising over rolling hills faded to pale shades of green, brown and straw. Switchback roads climb past ancient farmhouses, toward hilltop towns crowned by castles. Everywhere, crisscrossing the bowl-shaped valleys, are vineyards. Though they seem bare in January, no more than masses of gnarled wood in various stages of pruning, it's easy to see the regional hierarchy of vines. The cooler areas, where the snow lingers the longest, are planted with lesser grapes, like dolcetto and barbera. The choice areas, where the snow has melted in the warmth of the sunshine, are reserved for nebbiolo, the great grape of Barolo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, HELEN GERSON
description: LEVIN-Helen Gerson. Of Lauderhill, FL on February 3, 2003. Loving wife of Norman L. Levin. Services at 10 A.M. on February 6 at I.J. Morris, Dix Hills, New York. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 8333 W. McNab Road, Tamarac, FL. 33321.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Key3Media Allowed To Tap Financing
description: The Key3Media Group, which produces the Comdex trade show, received approval yesterday from a federal bankruptcy judge to tap into a $30 million loan from Thomas Weisel Capital Partners. Key3Media filed for bankruptcy protection on Monday and said it would reduce debt by 87 percent, to $50 million, and transfer ownership to Thomas Weisel. The judge, Jerry Venters of Federal Bankruptcy Court in Delaware, gave Key3Media permission to use as much as $12.5 million, turning aside objections from secured lenders Wells Fargo & Company and the Fleet National Bank unit of FleetBoston Financial.

title: U.S. Delays Suing Europe Over Ban on Modified Food
description: With war looming in Iraq, the Bush administration has decided against antagonizing its European allies and has postponed filing a case against the European Union for its ban on genetically modified food, according to a senior administration official.

description: BAROLO is a big, muscular red wine capable of living forever thanks to its tarry, impenetrable tannins. Any Barolo worthy of the name is, or should be, undrinkable until it is at least 10 years old. Right?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPITALNICK, RUTH (NEE STRUMWASSER)
description: SPITALNICK - Ruth (nee Strumwasser). On February 4, 2003. Devoted wife of Morris, loving mother of Dennis and Andrea Spitalnick and June and Larry Aversano, adoring and proud grandmother of Ross, Jared, Adam and Jonathan. An independent woman with a zest for life. We will remember her warmth, generosity and love for family.

title: Smallpox Researchers Seek Help From Millions of Computer Users
description: Responding to worries that smallpox could become a weapon of bioterrorism, a group of research universities and corporations and the Defense Department are announcing today a networked computer project intended to accelerate the search for a cure for smallpox.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, GEORGE
description: KAPLAN-George. Husband of the late Selma, loving father of Barbara and Harvey Kramer, Paul and Joy Kaplan, and Nancy and Alan Einstein. Dear brother of Rita and the late Lionel Kaplan. Loving grandfather and great-grandfather, longtime loving companion of Bernice Gold. Services today, 1:30 PM at ''Parkside,'' Queens Blvd. and 66th Ave., Forest Hills.

title: Street Where He Lived and Died Now Amadou Diallo Place
description: On the fourth anniversary of Amadou Diallo's death, city officials and community leaders gathered in the Bronx last night to rename the street where he died in a hail of police gunfire as Amadou Diallo Place.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEITCH, AUDREY
description: DEITCH-Audrey. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York are saddened by the passing of Audrey Deitch, beloved sister of Morton P. Hyman, a cherished friend of UJA-Federation. Mr. Hyman is a former UJA-Federation Board member and Chairman of the Board, Beth Israel Medical Center. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to the entire Deitch and Hyman families. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: HAILING CREW, BUSH VOWS TO CONTINUE CONQUEST OF SPACE
description: President Bush hailed the astronauts of the space shuttle Columbia today as seven lost explorers of great daring and purpose, then declared that America's only course in the face of the tragedy was to push forward in the conquest of space.

title: New Jersey Governor Seeks Extensive Cuts
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey presented a budget for next year that cuts deeply into state programs and calls for tax and fee increases that have already drawn protests. Mr. McGreevey's $23.7 billion plan closes a deficit he projected at $5 billion for the year starting July 1.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Witness Tells Of Assassination Plot
description: The star witness in the treason trial of the opposition leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, testified that Mr. Tsvangirai had paid to arrange the assassination of President Robert Mugabe. Ari Ben Menashe, who runs a Canadian consulting firm, said Mr. Tsvangirai had asked him to set up the hit. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Excerpts From News Conference by a NASA Space Shuttle Administrator
description: Following are excerpts from a news conference yesterday by Maj. Gen. Michael C. Kostelnik, NASA's deputy associate administrator for the space shuttle program, as recorded by The New York Times. Fuller excerpts are online at nytimes.com/columbia.

title: Blair Tries to Sell a Military Solution for Iraq, but Chirac Won't Buy It
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, Washington's staunchest ally and the greatest European champion of an eventual war with Iraq, failed today to persuade President Jacques Chirac of France to endorse military action through the United Nations Security Council.

title: New Name, Similar Struggles For Group of African Nations
description: The new African Union struggled this week at its first summit meeting to distinguish itself from the body it replaced, the Organization of African Unity, long criticized for being too bureaucratic and toothless to right the continent's many wrongs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESSLER, LAWRENCE
description: KESSLER-Lawrence. Larry stood for the best to all who knew him. He always will. With love from his wife Ruth, daughters Jane, Theodora, and Amy; sister Adrienne, and three grandchildren. Following private funeral services, a memorial service will be announced. Donations to Teaneck Ambulance Corps would be appreciated. For information call GuttermanMusicant: 1-800-522-0588.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROSS, STEWARD R. JR. (''STEVE'')
description: BROSS - Steward R. Jr. (''Steve''). On January 31, 2003. Loving husband of Isabel, his wife of almost 60 years. Caring father of Donna Campagna, grandfather of Christina Kapp and Brian Cunneff, and great grandfather of Emily Kapp. Retired partner of the law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore; Church Warden Emeritus of Trinity Church, New York City; Trustee Emeritus of The Cathedral Church of Saint John the Divine. A service will be held at Trinity Church, Broadway and Wall Street, New York City, at 10 A.M. on Thursday, February 6, 2003. Following the service a reception will be held in the Church parlor. Entombment will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the New York Presbyterian Hospital, New York, N.Y. 10032, or to The Church of the Good Shepherd, 2140 Main St., Wailuku, HI 96793.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Car Sales Rise
description: South Korea's five motor vehicle manufacturers -- Hyundai and Kia, in the Hyundai Automotive Group; GM Daewoo; Renault Samsung; and Ssangyong -- reported total sales of 298,000 vehicles last month, an increase of 7 percent from January 2002. Hyundai, the country's dominant vehicle manufacturer, reported sales of 156,222 vehicles, up 3 percent, while Kia sold 86,712 vehicles, up 23 percent. Hyundai Automotive claimed 4.2 percent of the United States market in January; with Hyundai Motor selling 27,179 vehicles, up 0.2 percent; and Kia selling 18,524 vehicles, up 11.8 percent. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONNELL, JOHN R.
description: McDONNELL-John R., 86. Of Allenhurst, New Jersey died on February 3. Born in NYC. He was a Wall St. Account Exec. for 54 years. Survived by wife Dorothy, children: John, Peter, Jane Steele, Paul & Richard, 13 grandchildren. Visitation will be from 7-9 Thursday and 2-4 & 7-9 Friday at John E. Day Funeral Home, 85 Riverside Ave., Red Bank, NJ. Funeral Mass will be held at 9 AM Saturday at St. Mary's Church, Deal, NJ. Interment in Gate of Heaven, Hawthorne, New York.

title: Genzyme Outlook Clouded
description: The Genzyme Corporation, a biotechnology company based here, said today that profit for 2003 would probably be below analysts' expectations because of higher costs, setting off an 8 percent decline in its share price.

title: Jerome Hines Is Dead at 81; Sang at the Met for 41 Years
description: Jerome Hines, a bass whose performing career spanned six decades -- including 41 years as a mainstay of the Metropolitan Opera, where he had the longest career of any principal singer in the company's history -- died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 81 and lived in Scotch Plains, N.J.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Soldiers To Vote On Chechnya
description: The government announced that it would allow 38,000 soldiers permanently based in Chechnya to vote in next month's constitutional referendum there. The Kremlin's human rights commissioner for Chechnya, Abdul-Khakim Sultygov, said the troops would represent 7 percent of the more than 500,000 eligible voters but suggested their participation would not skew the results of what is supposed to be a vote by Chechens on their republic's place in Russia. ''The military's position echoes the views voiced by Chechen society,'' he said, contradicting the view of many Chechen representatives. Foreign Minister Igor S. Ivanov also announced that the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe would be allowed to send observers to monitor the referendum, scheduled for March 23. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: New Products Aid Colgate Net
description: Colgate-Palmolive, the consumer products company, said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit rose 15 percent after new products like its teeth-whitening gel led to the biggest sales gain in five years.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Boldface Names column yesterday about a party after the screening of the film ''How to Lose a Guy in 10 Days'' listed three guests erroneously. Donna Hanover, her daughter, Caroline, and the lawyer Ed Oster attended the screening, but not the party.

title: Trapped in Kenya
description: To the Editor:

title: White House Report Stings Drug Agency on Abilities
description: In an unusually harsh critique of an agency with a strong global reputation, the White House has questioned the ability of the Drug Enforcement Administration to stem the flow of narcotics and is threatening to give the agency its smallest budget increase in 15 years.

title: For French Art Thief, It Was Love at First Sight
description: A 31-year-old Frenchman on trial in a Swiss town called Bulle for stealing some 70 works of art from museums, galleries and antique fairs told the court today that he could not resist the eyes on the woman in the first painting he stole.

title: An Ode to Joy at Third and 61st
description: Michel Willaume, a pastry chef who was on the American team that won the pastry World Cup in Lyon, France, in 2001, has opened Mondrian, a shop and cafe at 1026 Third Avenue (61st Street). It's a branch of his shop in Great Neck, N.Y. Done in white and charcoal, it's brightened by his finely crafted confections, most named for painters and composers. Monet is layered with praline and chocolate on a butter cookie base, Gauguin is a golden dessert with bananas and other tropical flavors, and Beethoven is a seriously dark chocolate pastry. They are $4 to $6 each. He also makes macaroons in assorted flavors, including passion fruit, and sells sandwiches and salads.

title: Powell to Charge Iraq Is Shifting Its Illegal Arms to Foil Inspectors
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell will show the United Nations evidence on Wednesday that Iraq has worked to conceal illegal arms from international inspectors, American officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLUCKIN, EDWIN W.
description: GLUCKIN-Edwin W. Beloved husband of Lucille, loving father of Harvey and Pam and Marjorie and Stewart Zimmerman, wonderful grandfather and great-grandfather passed away on February 3. Rest in peace, my dearest. We love you.

title: Rivera Eager to Pitch Again
description: Like all great closers, Mariano Rivera is accustomed to bouncing back from a rough outing. This season, Rivera will have to come back from tendinitis in his shoulder that put him on the Yankees' disabled list three times last season and limited him to one appearance in the postseason.

title: Ex-Manager of Helmsley Hotel Wins $11.2 Million in Bias Case
description: The former general manager of Leona Helmsley's five-star Park Lane Hotel was awarded nearly $11.2 million in damages yesterday by a jury that found that she had fired him because he is gay.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The cause of exploration and discovery is not an option we chose. It is a desire written in the human heart.''
