description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: COLLEGE STUDENTS PLAN PROTEST College students in New York plan a protest in Albany against proposed tuition increases. Students from the State University of New York, the City University of New York and other campuses plan a "relay march" of more than 500 miles to protest proposals by Gov. George E. Pataki to cut state support for education and raise tuition. Late this month, one group of students will start out from Stony Brook on Long Island and another from Buffalo, and they will converge in Albany for a rally in mid-March. "We're willing to walk through snowstorms and blizzards to say no to tuition increases," said Charlene Piper, a Brooklyn College student and an organizer of the march. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Hackensack: 4 Charged In Attack On Officer
description: An off-duty police officer was hospitalized Sunday after four people attacked him and one bit off most of his nose and right ear. The officer, Richard Levis, was recovering at home yesterday after emergency reconstructive surgery. Chief Charles Zisa of the Hackensack police said that as Officer Levis left work on Sunday, he noticed a vehicle blocking traffic and spoke to the driver. As the officer tried to return to his car to call for police assistance, the driver, Carlos Diaz, 23, jumped him, Chief Zisa said. Mr. Diaz then bit him, Chief Zisa said, while three others -- Jose Felix, 43, Franklin Guerra, 27, and Shemara Nunez, 27 -- joined the attack. The four were charged with attempted murder. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Top Politician Indicates Turkey May Join U.S. Effort Against Iraq
description: American officials stepped up their diplomatic campaign for permission to use Turkish military bases today, as the country's leading politician hinted that his country might be preparing to grant the American request.

title: Hamilton, on the Mend, Plans a Giants Return
description: Doctors told Giants defensive tackle Keith Hamilton that surgery last October on his torn Achilles' tendon was successful, but he thought about retiring anyway. The pain in his right leg was excruciating, and at 31 years old, he was already staring into the twilight of his career.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Reward Offered In Shooting Of G.I.
description: The police offered a $4,600 reward for clues in the shooting of an American soldier who was wounded after he pulled his car off the road to clean ice from the windshield. The soldier, from the First Infantry Division, was in civilian clothes on his way to the barracks in Schweinfurt, 60 miles east of Frankfurt, when he was shot in the left hand and leg. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: States' Budget Gaps Widen Nearly 50% in Two Months
description: Estimates of state budget deficits for the current fiscal year have grown by nearly 50 percent in two months, creating the worst fiscal outlook for states since World War II and prompting nearly half of them to consider raising taxes, a new survey by the National Conference of State Legislatures shows.

title: Iraq's Remarks to the U.N.
description: The following is the text of an address by Iraqi Permanent Representative to the United Nations Muhammad Abdallah Ahmad Shati Duri:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHMUTTER, MURRAY
description: SCHMUTTER-Murray. The Shelter Rock Jewish Center, Roslyn, NY, sadly records the loss of its past President and friend. We extend heartfelt condolences to Fran and the family. May they be comforted with all who mourn. Martin S. Cohen, Rabbi Harold Rabinowitz, President

title: Shuttle Program: Fly or Shut Down?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOWNSEND, MARJORIE BRADLEY
description: TOWNSEND-Marjorie Bradley. January 31, 2003. In New York City at age 93. Daughter of the late Alden Shirley Bradley, and Martha Jane Paulette. Devoted wife of the late Barnard Townsend, beloved mother of Diana Townsend-Butterworth, mother-inlaw of Duke Butterworth and loving grandmother of James and Diana. Longtime member of the Colony Club and Junior League of NYC. Descendant of Anneke Jans and Peter Stuyvesant. Family matriarch, spirited, talented, loyal and gracious. Known for her beautiful smile, keen intuition and extraordinary devotion to her family. Always there to listen and care, Marjorie will live forever in our hearts. Viewing at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., February 9th, 3-5 PM. Service, Church of the Heavenly Rest, 90th St. at 5th Ave., February 10th, 11 AM. Donations may be made to Church of the Heavenly Rest.

title: Cablevision Unimpressed By YES Offer
description: The testy relationship between the YES Network and Cablevision flared anew yesterday over the details of the most recent offer the cable home of the Yankees and the Nets made to the region's largest cable operator.

title: Isles' Early Hopes Thwarted By the Hard-Checking Flyers
description: Six defensemen dressed for the Islanders tonight, and for the first time in two weeks, Coach Peter Laviolette planned to give them all plenty of playing time. Then the game started.

title: Gas Explosion Rocks Building In Stuyvesant Town Complex
description: A gas explosion ripped through a top-floor apartment in Stuyvesant Town yesterday, injuring a 51-year-old man and forcing the evacuation of more than 100 other residents of the complex on the East Side.

title: Footlights
description: The Footlights column, expanded and renamed Arts Briefing, will be found on Page 2 of this section and will appear there Mondays through Thursdays.

title: Critics Seek a Broader Shuttle Panel
description: Some members of Congress want NASA to expand the membership of the outside panel created by the space agency to investigate the Columbia disaster, saying it is dominated by government and military officials.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Suspected Guerrilla Leader Arrested
description: The police arrested a suspected leader of an urban guerrilla group responsible for more than 100 bomb attacks over 30 years, including one against American business targets. Officials said Christos Tsigaridas, 64, was the fourth member of the Popular Revolutionary Struggle to be arrested since a crackdown on the group began last weekend. Anthee Carassava (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMANN, MIKLOS
description: FRIEDMANN-Miklos. Congregation Beth Sholom records the passing of our esteemed member Miklos Friedmann. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Kenneth N. Hain Dr. Gilbert Klaperman, Rabbi Emeritus Danny Hiller, President Gary Miller, Chairman of the Board

title: News Service President Retiring After 18 Years
description: Louis D. Boccardi, the president and chief executive of The Associated Press, is retiring after 18 years as the top executive of the news cooperative, a time when it expanded geographically and technologically to become the world's most pervasive purveyor of breaking news in all media, The A.P.'s governing board announced yesterday.

title: Rolling the Dice On a Family Dream
description: THE dream of Albano Ballerini and Ellen Fishman to own a restaurant will come true on Friday. Aliseo will open in the storefront of the building they own and live in at 665 Vanderbilt Avenue (Park Place) in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn. The last four years of planning and construction may have been difficult, but simply by opening their doors, the 40-something couple have cheated long odds: many amateur food enthusiasts harbor restaurant fantasies but only a few act them out.

title: New Jersey Gets a Budget No One Likes
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey, in an angry and frustrated address to legislators, today presented a budget for next year that cuts deeply into state programs and calls for tax and fee increases that have already drawn protests.

title: Trade Center Developer Is Portrayed in Court Papers as Calculating and Rapacious
description: Larry A. Silverstein, the developer who controls the World Trade Center lease, has fought for the past 17 months with his insurance companies, arguing that there were two terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, 2001, requiring a double payment, nearly $7 billion, for the rebuilding effort.

title: G.E. Buying British Consumer Loan Operation
description: Abbey National, a big British bank, said today that it had agreed to sell most of its consumer lending division to General Electric of the United States for $1.4 billion in cash, to focus on providing consumers with checking and saving accounts, credit cards and mortgages.

title: China's Remarks to the U.N.
description: The following is the text of an address by Chinese Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan at the United Nations:

title: It's a Fact of Life: Prime-Time Shows Are Getting Sexier
description: What Evan and Sarah were doing deep in the French woods that balmy, moonlit night was not audible, so on last week's episode of ''Joe Millionaire,'' Fox added subtitles (''aaah,'' ''slurp'' and ''gulp'') that suggested that the couple were engaged in more than conversation.

title: The Iraqis' Use of Poison Gas
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; The Mets, and Plenty of Detractors, Remain on Bobby V's Menu
description: AT Bobby V's, the restaurant on Main Street in Stamford, Conn., you can order -- this is true -- Piazza Pasta, Pete ''Roast'' Beef, Billy Martin ''Tossed'' Salad, ''Ty'' Cobb Salad and a Benitez Burrito, among other, pardon the expression, gourmet grand slams.

title: Mosley Wants to Be King of the Hill
description: In his penthouse suite, Shane Mosley watched snowboarders career down his 45-inch television screen. ''I love doing that when I'm up in camp,'' Mosley, a once-celebrated boxer whose career has gone downhill over the last year or so, said of snowboarding. ''I went down two times, two and a half weeks ago.''

title: Turner Confirms Doubt About CNN-ABC Link
description: Ted Turner, the founder of the Cable News Network, told CBS News yesterday that he opposed a merger of CNN and ABC News, the network said. But executives on both sides of the negotiations said his opposition would make little difference because the merger proposal is dormant if not moribund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUINLAN, AMY
description: QUINLAN-Amy. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of former member, Amy Quinlan, daughter of members, Thomas and Carolyn Kohlberg, and extend sincere condolences to her family. Alex C. Solowey, President

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Record In Personal Bankruptcies
description: A record 214,634 Japanese people filed for bankruptcy last year as the sluggish economy pushed more people into debt. The number of personal bankruptcies increased 34 percent compared with 2001 and have quadrupled in the last eight years. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: New Head of Public Service Commission Is Quickly Confirmed
description: William M. Flynn, a politically well-connected former prosecutor, sailed through the Senate confirmation process today to become the chairman of the Public Service Commission, after Republicans cut off questions about his record during his confirmation hearing.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Carriage House Returns

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Sharp's Profit Triples
description: The electronics maker Sharp said that profits tripled in the October-to-December period as demand for its liquid crystal screens and flat-screen televisions rose. The company, which is based in Osaka, earned 14 billion yen ($117 million) in the quarter, with sales up 23 percent. Sharp is Japan's largest maker of L.C.D. screens. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: 3 Sentenced In $2 Million Fraud
description: Three men were sentenced to prison in a scheme that cost a federal housing agency more than $2 million in bad home loans. Two mortgage underwriters, Robert Jordan and Peter Tortorelli, were each sentenced to 18 months in federal prison. Federal prosecutors said the underwriters had created false tax returns for loan applicants who sought mortgages guaranteed by the Department of Housing and Urban Development. The third man, a real estate broker, Raul Torres, sold the homes at inflated prices, prosecutors said. Mr. Torres was sentenced to 24 months in prison. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: For Those Aboard, Final Minutes Held Hint of Catastrophe
description: They probably knew something was wrong. Maybe for only seconds, but possibly for several long minutes, they almost certainly knew that things were not going according to plan.

title: Gregg Rice -- Biology Professor, 59
description: Gregg Rice, a former professor of biology at Mercy College in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., died Jan. 19 in Mount Vernon, N.Y. He was 59 and a longtime resident of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS, JOHN C.
description: PHILLIPS-John C. Artist, died at home in Cos Cob, CT. on February 1st, 2003, age 94. A family ceremony was held February 2nd.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKULE, LLOYD IRA
description: BERKULE-Lloyd Ira. February 2, 2003. Survived by loving wife Andrea, son Erik, daughter Samantha and daughter-in-law Stephanie.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, JOEL BAIRD
description: MILLER-Joel Baird. On February 3, 2003, died peacefully at home after a long and courageous battle with cancer. He is survived by his beloved family, wife, Lee Miller (Tarlow), daughter and son-in-law Stephanie and Ken Landau of Oradell, NJ, grandsons Jordan, Avery and Brett Landau and son, Corey Miller and his partner Jon Connett of San Francisco, CA. Funeral service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, NYC, today at 1:30PM. Interment will follow at Beth El Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. In lieu of flowers the family wishes that contributions be made to a charity of your choice.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Bardot Is Latest Mugabe Critic
description: Arguing that the president of Zimbabwe, Robert Mugabe, has trampled the rights of animals as well as of human beings, Brigitte Bardot urged France to withdraw an invitation for him to attend an African summit meeting in Paris on Feb. 21. France's decision to invite Mr. Mugabe opened differences within the European Union, which agreed last year to bar him from traveling to its 15 member countries because of human rights violations. But Ms. Bardot said animals suffered, too. Calling Mr. Mugabe a ''destroyer of nature,'' she wrote in an open letter to Le Figaro that ''white rhinoceroses, cheetahs, leopards, and so forth, are ensnared, elephants massacred, the forests set on fire, to allow poaching.'' John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: A Diverse Band of Volunteers Sends a Warning to America
description: There were only a few spectators in the stands today for the huge military parade on a hilltop here. It did not matter, though. The real audience was not in this northern city, near the border with the nominally independent Kurdish zone, but elsewhere.

title: Cisco Sees No Upturn Soon for Technology Spending
description: Cisco Systems Inc., the largest maker of Internet network equipment, reported today that its sales held steady last quarter amid a continued technology downturn. But, in remarks that suggest an upturn is not imminent, Cisco's chief executive said customers had grown even more cautious about spending.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KENNY, PATRICK J.
description: KENNY-Patrick J., who died on Nov. 22, 2002. A Mass of Thanksgiving will be offered to express our gratitude to all those who comforted us, on Wednesday, February 26, 2003, 6:45 A.M. at St. Margaret of Cortona Church, in Riverdale, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, HENRY, M.D.
description: GREEN-Henry, M.D. On February 2, 2003. Beloved father, father-in-law, grandfather, colleague.

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: 350,000 SUBSCRIBERS FOR VIRGIN MOBILE Virgin Mobile U.S.A., the wireless carrier venture between Sprint PCS and the Virgin Group of Britain, is expected to announce today that it signed up 350,000 subscribers in its first six months of operation in the United States. The company, which focuses on providing prepaid cellular service from Sprint's network to young consumers, had 245,000 new subscribers in the fourth quarter of 2002, representing about 6 percent of total net subscriber additions in the period. Virgin Mobile succeeded in attracting subscribers at a time when other carriers, including Sprint and Cingular Wireless, a joint venture of BellSouth and SBC Communications , suffered from customer defections. Daniel H. Schulman, above, Virgin Mobile's chief executive, said in an interview that he expected the company to become profitable within two and a half years. Shares of Sprint PCS fell 8 cents, to $3.69.    Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Upper Crust or Inner City, It's Squash
description: The first few times Tyquan Jones took the B train from his school in Harlem for a squash lesson at the Harvard Club on 44th Street, he was not impressed.

title: Law Firms Merge Or Close, Caught In Economy's Vise
description: Law firms, commonly seen as islands of security and stability to their employees, are proving vulnerable to the turbulence in the economy.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Indiana: Lawyer's Punishment Softened
description: The State Supreme Court reduced the punishment it imposed in October on a lawyer who had criticized a lower court's decision in a footnote to a brief. The Supreme Court replaced its earlier 30-day suspension of the lawyer, Michael A. Wilkins, with a reprimand. A justice in the majority in the earlier ruling, Robert D. Rucker, did not participate in decision. The justice had served on the appeals court panel that Mr. Wilkins criticized. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Quiogue: Deaths Termed Murder-Suicide
description: The Suffolk County medical examiner said yesterday that the deaths of a couple who were found dead in their Hamptons home last weekend had been deemed a murder and suicide. The police said it appeared that Giulio Romano, 66, had stabbed his companion of 10 years, Julie-Ann Low, 61, at least six times in or around her neck before plunging the knife into his own neck. The police declined to comment on a possible motive. The bodies were found on the dining room floor on Saturday after Mr. Romano's brother, unable to contact him, flew in from Italy. The couple died about a month ago, the authorities said, but neighbors did not notice their absence, as the two usually spent part of the year in Florida. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Wagner Star Forward Takes Flight
description: Wagner Coach Dereck Whittenburg was scouting the current Manhattan star Luis Flores years ago at an A.A.U. game but instead came away with Jermaine Hall. It was not a bad bargain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRISON, LOU
description: HARRISON-Lou. The American Music Center's Boards of Directors, staff, and membership mourn the death and celebrate the life of one of America's truly great and original artists, our beloved composer Lou Harrison. A student of Henry Cowell and Arnold Schoenberg; colleague of John Cage, Virgil Thomson, Charles Ives, Mark Morris, and many, many others; builder of instruments; builder of musical bridges to non-Western cultures; gay man of great pride; and mentor to generations of composers and performers, Lou was a man of courage and beauty. Lou Harrison will be sorely missed, but his legacy, his wonderful and beautiful music, will forever inspire us.

title: REGAL ENTERTAINMENT TO BUY THEATERS FROM HOYTS
description: The Regal Entertainment Group, the movie theater chain, plans to buy 52 theaters from the Hoyts Cinemas Group for $200 million in cash and stock to add properties in the Northeast. The acquisition will give Regal theaters in Boston and other areas of Massachusetts where it does not have any, a Regal spokesman, Don De Laria, said. Regal Entertainment operates 5,663 screens in 36 states. Regal is based in Knoxville, Tenn.

title: President Pledges U.S. Will Continue to Explore Space
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 4  President Bush hailed the astronauts of the space shuttle Columbia today as seven lost explorers of great daring and purpose, then declared that America's only course in the face of the tragedy was to push forward in the conquest of space.

title: U.S. Official Says North Korea Could Sell Bomb Material
description: A senior Bush administration official warned today that North Korea, if allowed to reprocess spent nuclear fuel rods, could sell some of that fissile material to terrorists and other enemies of the United States who are seeking to build nuclear weapons.

title: With Audio Tapes and Images, Powell Makes Case to U.N.
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell took Washington's case for military action against Iraq to the United Nations today, presenting audiotape recordings and satellite photographs to support what he described as ``irrefutable and undeniable'' evidence of Baghdad's attempt to ignore and evade international demands that it rid itself of weapons of mass destruction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYER, BERNARD
description: MAYER-Bernard. Of Hartsdale, NY. Beloved husband of Beverly Jordan, devoted father of Valerie Mayer and Lori Rubabshi, adored grandfather. Services on Thursday, 1 PM, at Weinstein Memorial Chapel Inc, 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers, New York.

title: In Coney Island, Neptune Rising; Ornate and Fabled Restaurant Becomes a Landmark
description: On the ground floor, shelves of books fill the space. One flight up, the guts of a candy manufacturing business lie about.

title: Second Enron Energy Trader Pleads Guilty
description: A former senior trader with the Enron Corporation pleaded guilty yesterday to manipulating the California power market illegally during the state's energy crisis and then lying about his actions to federal law enforcement officials.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COMMUNITY, WIDE MEMORIAL TO THE SEVEN ASTRONAUTS OF THE COLUMBIA SHUTTLE
description: COMMUNITY-WIDE MEMORIAL TO THE SEVEN ASTRONAUTS of the Columbia Shuttle, Wednesday, Feb. 5, 11:45AM, Park East Synagogue, 163 East 67 Street.

title: Two Finalists Are Selected For the Void at Ground Zero
description: Two teams of architects, one that sees the foundations of democracy in the concrete walls surrounding ground zero and another that imagines New York's rebirth in soaring towers of culture, have been selected as finalists in the competition to create the design for the World Trade Center site, rebuilding officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERT, SONDRA R.
description: ALBERT-Sondra R. Beloved daughter of the late Bernard and Lily Albert. Sister of Sigmund and Edward Albert (Brenda Krepol). Cherished friend of Joan Srager and Sally Dorst. Passed away peacefully January 31 after a long illness. Services will be held Thursday, February 6, 10 AM, at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made in her memory to the Jerome Robbins Foundation, 18 West 21st Street, NY, NY 10010.

title: Devils' Nieuwendyk Contributes to Sabres' Woes
description: Devils center Joe Nieuwendyk said before tonight's game against Buffalo that he felt badly for the Sabres. Their former owner has been arrested, the team is under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, and on Monday, a prospective new owner suspended his bid to purchase the team.

title: Turning a Kitchen Into Child's Play
description: LIFE, to paraphrase Dr. Johnson on the nature of second marriages, is largely the triumph of hope over experience. Anyone who has to cook regularly for small children will wince at the truthfulness of this maxim. Every mealtime brings with it the soft-focus dream of a cozy family gathering, but even the smallest investment of hope can be disastrous. The provision of any food is in some sense an offering of love, and the food we cook for our children is particularly loaded. The gulf between our tremulous expectations and their rejection can be a bitter one.

title: President Is Quitting U.S. Olympic Panel In Dispute on Ethics
description: Marty Mankamyer resigned as the president of the embattled United States Olympic Committee last night, saying that she has ''neither the resources nor the energy to continue to battle against the onslaughts of my detractors.''

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: IDENTIX INC., Minnetonka, Minn., a security technology company, said the Defense Department had decided to license the company's BioEngine fingerprint-recognition technology to upgrade fingerprint record files of all military and civilian personnel. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Layoffs Create Glut of Space in Boston Area
description: The pressures weakening the commercial property market here were illustrated by the largest lease negotiated last year.

title: The Prune Pit Has Its Day: An Oil for Accent
description: What is that hint of bitter almond in the salad dressing? The distinctively nutty scent on that ripe pear or those sauted chanterelles?

title: Texas Searchers Map and Bag a Trove of Items
description: When the sun came up, they set off, walking six abreast through scratchy fields marked with anthills, cow pies and little red flags.

title: Seller of Fake ID's to Hijackers Accepts Plea Deal in New Jersey
description: A man who sold fake identification cards to two of the 9/11 hijackers pleaded guilty today to a single count of selling simulated documents and was released from jail on $50,000 bail.

title: Corn Kernels, Savory Stew
description: POZOLE is dried corn treated with limestone. In its ground form, it is the main ingredient in tortillas, but for some reason the whole kernels are largely ignored outside the Southwest. Hominy, basically the same thing, has a bit of a following in the South, but again mostly in ground form: grits.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Jan. 26 about Edward Farhat, an early professional wrestling villain known as the Sheik, misstated the place of his death. It was Williamston, Mich., not Williamstown.

title: Promoting Tolerance, Not Paying Heed
description: THE civil rights division of the West Virginia attorney general's office has prosecuted many cases involving schools where bullying got out of hand. Usually the cases involved race, but sometimes the victim was a slow child, a poor child, an odd child, a gay child.

title: Council Speaker Says State And U.S. Owe City Billions
description: Even as Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg stuck to his nonconfrontational budget negotiating tactics, Council Speaker Gifford Miller took a decidedly tougher approach yesterday, accusing both Gov. George E. Pataki and President Bush of cheating New York City out of billions of dollars.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Tomorrow: Transit Worker Safety
description: The City Council has scheduled a public hearing on job safety for transit workers. Council Chambers, City Hall, Manhattan, 10 a.m. Information: (718) 888-8747.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWEENEY, REV. EDWARD JOHN, S.J.
description: SWEENEY - Rev. Edward John, S.J. Beloved brother of William, John and Elinor Connors. Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel at Loyola Hall, Fordham University Wednesday from 3-5 & 7-9. Mass of Christian Burial Thurs. 11 AM at The Loyola Hall Chapel. For information Farenga Bros. Inc., Directors.

title: Onward and Outward
description: On Saturday, numbed by what NASA persisted calling, with depressing caution, the space shuttle's ''contingency'' and ''mishap,'' I wistfully logged onto a little-known portion of the agency's Web site that's devoted to a project that ponders the possibilities of interstellar travel.

title: Afghans No. 1 in Opium
description: Afghanistan was the world's largest source of illicit opium in 2002, according to a United Nations report released on Monday, which estimates that opium revenues amounted to $1.2 billion in that country while the average daily wage was only $2 per day.

title: Nominee Had Been Investigated for Intervening in Iraq Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4  The Senate Judiciary Committee is scheduled on Wednesday to interview a federal appeals court nominee who was once questioned by officials about whether he improperly intervened in a federal investigation of loans to Saddam Hussein.

title: Who Is Being Judged, We or McDonald's?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, RABBI JOSHUA
description: EPSTEIN-Rabbi Joshua. The S/A/R Academy extends condolences to Tamar Bar-David, wife of Trustee Dr. Tzvi Bar-David on the loss of her beloved father. May the entire family find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Killing Puzzles the Police And Spector's Friends Too
description: As detectives searched for a motive in the fatal shooting of a B-movie actress, friends and colleagues of both her and the rock producer Phil Spector, charged by the police with murdering her at his mansion, puzzled today over what might have brought them together in the first place.

title: Critics Say Money for Schools Falls Short of Promises
description: In an aside as they presented the 2004 education budget, federal officials barely concealed their pleasure on Monday in announcing that, for the first time, all 50 states had submitted plans to monitor student performance by a federal deadline last week.

title: Giving Voice to an Awkward Silence in Germany
description: ON THE NATURAL HISTORY OF DESTRUCTION

title: Hometown Service for Astronaut
description: Here in the birthplace of the space shuttle Columbia's payload commander, Lt. Col. Michael P. Anderson, a crowd of more than 300 filled the third-floor rotunda of City Hall tonight for a candlelight memorial service.

title: Rebuilding Effort Could Help Space Industry in Long Run
description: Analysts who follow the business of building and launching rockets and satellites anticipate that the loss of the space shuttle could eventually help rather than hurt the industry.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Palm Lowers Price To Lift Sales
description: The world's largest maker of hand-held computers, Palm Inc., yesterday lowered the price of its most expensive devices as much as 20 percent, seeking to reverse a slump in sales. Palm cut the price of the m130 by 20 percent, to $199; the m515 by 14 percent, to $299; and the Tungsten T by 20 percent, to $399. The Tungsten is Palm's highest-priced electronic organizer. Palm is trying to increase demand for its products after recording $731.4 million in losses in the last two years. Sales of the hand-held computers dropped last year because businesses cut spending on new equipment as their own profits slipped. Palm shares fell 41 cents, to $14.81.

title: Our Towns; A Whisper Of Terrorism, And Its Echo
description: The raid last July on the offices of All Services Plus here was a lot less than advertised. The owner of the company that sold official-looking documents to illegal immigrants, including two Sept. 11 hijackers, was nowhere to be found, having left for vacation in Egypt two weeks before.

title: Oxford Health Profit Falls After Charge
description: Fourth-quarter earnings at Oxford Health Plans dropped 22 percent, the company said today, reflecting a charge related to securities lawsuits brought in 1997.

title: Ivorian President Caught Between 2 Leaders He Groomed
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Feb. 5  "Gbagbo Between Two Fires," a morning tabloid roared here this week, describing the predicament of the Ivorian president, Laurent Gbagbo, a man caught between the guns of rebel forces and the rage of his supporters.

title: Sprewell Sinks 9 of 9 3-Pointers, A Record
description: With trade rumors encircling him like a halo, Latrell Sprewell taught the young, brash and underachieving Los Angeles Clippers the art of shooting the basketball last night at Madison Square Garden. While the Clippers were talking trash and making cocky gestures, Sprewell was putting on a shooting display that would make Allan Houston envious.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: College Students Plan Protest
description: College students in New York plan a protest in Albany against proposed tuition increases. Students from the State University of New York, the City University of New York and other campuses plan a ''relay march'' of more than 500 miles to protest proposals by Gov. George E. Pataki to cut state support for education and raise tuition. Late this month, one group of students will start out from Stony Brook on Long Island and another from Buffalo, and they will converge in Albany for a rally in mid-March. ''We're willing to walk through snowstorms and blizzards to say no to tuition increases,'' said Charlene Piper, a Brooklyn College student and an organizer of the march. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Forum Will Focus On Unsolicited E-Mail
description: The Federal Trade Commission said yesterday that it would hold a forum to address the proliferation of unsolicited commercial e-mail and to explore the technical, legal and financial issues related to such mailings, known as spam. The forum, in Washington from April 30 to May 2, will involve law enforcement officials, Internet service providers and other technology professionals. The agency said it was ''seeking to explore the impact that spam has on consumers' use of e-mail, e-mail marketing and the Internet industry.'' Officials said the commission intended to focus on issues related to spam, including security problems and viruses; possible structural changes to e-mail systems; e-mail address-harvesting technology; deceptive routing and subject information; the cost of technology to eliminate or negate spam; and effects on wireless devices, text messaging and wireless e-mail.

title: Profit Up 50% at Irish Discount Airline
description: While other airlines struggle with high costs and weak traffic, Ryanair, the Irish discount airline, is enjoying ''a virtuous cycle of lower costs, lower fares, faster growth and increasing profits,'' the chief executive, Michael O'Leary, said today. That is why Ryanair's net income for the quarter ended Dec. 31 rose 50 percent from the year-earlier period, he said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, ARNOLD ''ARNIE'' J.
description: KAYE-Arnold ''Arnie'' J. Longtime resident of Westport, CT. Passed away on Tuesday in Norwalk Hospital. Family will receive friends today from 5-9 PM at the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 31 Arch St., Greenwich, CT. Services will be held Thursday in Temple Sholom, 300 East Putnam Avenue, Greenwich, CT. Interment Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory to the American Cancer Society would be appreciated.

title: NASA Was Told in 1990 About Vulnerable Tiles
description: The space agency was warned in 1990 that the protective tiles around the shuttle's wheel wells were particularly vulnerable to damage and failure, inviting catastrophe because those tiles protect both fuel tanks and the shuttle's hydraulic system.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Apologies From Cambodia Accepted
description: Moving quickly to try to ease frictions after anti-Thai riots in Cambodia, King Bhumibol Adulyadej of Thailand accepted a letter of apology from King Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia, and Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra accepted a letter of apology from Hun Sen, the prime minister of Cambodia. But anger in Thailand was still high over the burning last week of its embassy and a number of businesses by rioters in the Cambodian capital, Phnom Penh, who had been spurred by false reports of insulting remarks about their homeland made by a popular Thai actress. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Yugoslavia Is Again Reinvented, in Name and Structure
description: Lawmakers in Belgrade's federal Parliament consigned the troubled name Yugoslavia to the history books today, endorsing the Constitution of a new, less binding union between the republics of Serbia and Montenegro.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILLMAN, PEARL
description: GILLMAN - Pearl. Beloved wife of Seymour. Loving mother of Joan and Larry. Proud grandmother of Rachel and Jason. Service 12:30PM Thursday, Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W. 150 Route 4 (East), Paramus, N.J.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: WOODBRIDGE: STUDY OF STUDENTS WITH CANCER A State Department of Public Health study has concluded that there is no link between cancer cases and buildings in the Amity Regional School District. The findings, released on Monday, came four months after 31 cases of cancer among students and faculty were reviewed. The report found that "Hodgkins disease could be considered a possible cluster," but also said, "Tthis is the most common cancer in young adults." The report was compiled by Dr. Mary Lou Fleissner, a state health official. The Amity district includes Bethany, Orange and Woodbridge. (AP)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOUGLAS, PERCY S.
description: DOUGLAS-Percy S. The Board of Overseers and Overseers Emeriti of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center note with great sorrow the sudden passing of our friend and colleague Percy S. Douglas. Always conveying his strong interest in our programs, we will miss his enthusiastic support of our mission. We extend our most sincere condolences to his family. Laurance S. Varmus President Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Sumitomo Profit Rises
description: The Sumitomo Corporation, the trading company, said that its profit grew 67 percent in the October-to-December quarter, helped by a brisk turnover of machinery and pharmaceuticals. Sumitomo earned 15.2 billion yen ($127 million) in the quarter. Still, sales overall during the quarter fell 10 percent. The company also said it took a 19.9 percent stake in Nissho Electronics, a trader of communications and informations systems equipment, to improve its technology telecommunications operations. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, ALEXANDER I.
description: ROSS-Alexander I. Loving and beloved father of Catherine Ross (Jon Rieder), grandfather of Daniel Ross-Rieder, brother of Henry Rosovsky (Nitza). Advertising executive at Al Paul Lefton, Director of Public Relations for American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science, former Chair of the Social Action Commission of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, past Board Member of Congregation Ansche Chesed and Stephen Wise Free Synagogue. Died February 4, age 80, after an extended illness. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam, Thursday, February 6, at 11:15 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Ansche Chesed or UAHC Religious Action Center.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Democracy Advocate On Trial Again
description: A nine-judge panel led by the head of the country's highest appeals court opened the third trial of an Egyptian-American social scientist and democracy advocate, Saad Eddin Ibrahim. The appeals court has twice thrown out convictions of Mr. Ibrahim on charges of defaming Egypt, accepting money from overseas without authorization and others stemming from his research on sensitive topics like voter rights and the treatment of the Coptic Christian minority. A verdict is due on March 18 and can be overturned only by presidential decree. Samar Aboul-Fotouh (NYT)

title: Patent Lawsuit Set to Begin Today Could Be Crucial for Generic Drugs
description: An important drug patent trial is expected to begin in Chicago today when GlaxoSmithKline, one of the world's largest pharmaceutical manufacturers, squares off in federal court against Apotex, a Canadian maker of generic drugs, over an essential patent covering GlaxoSmithKline's top-selling drug, Paxil.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Saturday about a concert by the New York Philharmonic misstated the title of the Mendelssohn symphony performed on Thursday. It was the ''Reformation.'' (The ''Resurrection'' is by Mahler.)

title: Hydrogen Cars Remain Decades In the Future Under New Budget
description: The Bush administration plan to spur development of hydrogen cars does not envision mass production until 2020. The plan also says there will not be enough research and installations like fueling stations to decide whether the technology is commercially viable until 2015.

title: Yet Another Celebrity Behind Bars
description: As one half of the 1990's comedy duo ''The Jerky Boys,'' Kamal Ahmed once made his living placing crank phone calls to unsuspecting victims and releasing the results on CD's. He has now graduated to independent filmmaking, and his first fiction film as a director, ''God Has a Rap Sheet,'' opens today at the Pioneer Theater in the East Village, where it will play every Wednesday and Thursday this month at 9:20 p.m.

title: 16 Westchester Teenagers Charged at Drinking Party
description: Sixteen teenagers were charged with possessing alcohol after the police broke up a weekend party here in Westchester County, where officials and parents have been struggling to fight under-age drinking, the authorities said today.

description: Demand for manufacturers' products increased in December, the Commerce Department said yesterday, with factory orders rising 0.4 percent over November, when orders fell 0.8 percent.

title: Fragile Ceramic Tiles Long a Source of Concern
description: Experts have known since the early 1990's that foam insulation on the space shuttle's fuel tank sometimes tore off and damaged the fragile ceramic tiles that make up its heat shield. The tiles' general fragility has kept them busy devising protective countermeasures since the start of the shuttle program.

title: An Englishman and an Irishman, Companionable as Fish and Chips
description: Queens Boulevard in Sunnyside has its share of Irish pubs -- Bloom's, Courtyard and Maggie Mae's, among others. To serve the hungry overflow from them, Andrew Morrison, at left in photo, who is from Cheshire, England, and Paul Gallen, a Dubliner, have opened the Chipper, offering fish and chips until 5 a.m. Friday and Saturday nights, till 11 other nights. The shop, at 41-28 Queens Boulevard, has an open kitchen and counters with stools. The fish and chips are made with sweet, flaky cod or haddock ($7.95), though a smoked cod version throws a deeply flavorful curve ($7.95 without chips, $9.95 with). Batter-dipped sausage and burgers, fried chicken, coleslaw and the inevitable mushy peas are also on the menu.

title: Toyota Says Profits Nearly Doubled in Last Quarter of 2002
description: TOKYO, Feb. 5  Toyota Motor Corp. said profits nearly doubled in the last quarter of 2002 as Japan's largest automaker continues to solidify its share of the global car market.

title: New York Seeks Cooperation On Indian Pt. Emergency Plan
description: In an attempt to resolve an impasse over certifying the emergency plan for the Indian Point nuclear power plant in Westchester County, New York State last night suggested a meeting of federal and local officials to discuss their differences.

title: Amended Lawsuit Accuses Some Stewart Executives
description: Senior executives at Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia knew Ms. Stewart was under investigation for her sale of shares in ImClone Systems before the inquiry was disclosed to the public and discussed how that might affect the stock price of their company, an amended class- action lawsuit contends.

title: BLACKBIRD CHIEF TO OVERSEE FANNIE MAE AND FREDDIE MAC
description: President Bush intends to nominate Mark C. Brickell, director and chief executive of a derivatives trading firm, Blackbird Holdings, to succeed Armando Falcon Jr. as chief regulator of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the White House announced. Mr. Brickell, a former managing director of J. P. Morgan, would succeed Mr. Falcon as director of the Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight, the White House statement said. The term of the appointment is five years, it said. Mr. Brickell declined to comment. Mr. Falcon resigned yesterday.

title: COMCAST WILL SELL SOME OF ITS CABLE SYSTEMS TO BRESNAN
description: The Comcast Corporation, a leading operator of cable networks, said yesterday that it would sell systems in four Western states to Bresnan Communications for $525 million in cash and stock. Bresnan, a closely held company, will acquire 317,000 subscribers in Montana, Wyoming, Colorado and Utah, the companies said. The cable operations belonged to AT&T Broadband before Comcast acquired the company for $59 billion in November. AT&T Broadband agreed to sell the systems to Bresnan in April for $735 million in cash. The companies changed the terms as pressure on the cable industry for borrowing billions and for questionable accounting made raising money through stock and bond offerings difficult. Bresnan, based in White Plains, has not operated a cable system since its chief executive, William Bresnan, sold his last cable company to Charter Communications Inc. in 2000.

description: POWERS-Joseph P., 62, of New York City, and husband of Jo Ann Langer Powers, died Wednesday, January 29 at his home. description: Six years ago, in flusher economic times, Gov. George E. Pataki signed off on an ambitious plan to offer prekindergarten to all of New York State's 4-year-olds by 2002.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Cutchogue: Plan For Boutique Winery Fails
description: An ambitious plan to establish a boutique winery for red wines on the North Fork of Long Island has foundered. Leslie Alexander, owner of the Houston Rockets basketball team, began plantings on his properties in the region in 2000, and last year the equivalent of 750 cases of wine was made for him at a local winery. But Mr. Alexander, who lives in Boca Raton, Fla., has concluded that he cannot make reds that meet his standards. He shut down vineyard operations yesterday and said he would sell all 177 acres eventually. Howard G. Goldberg (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Doctor Accused Of Deadly Surgery
description: A surgeon in the wealthy northern town of Como has been arrested on charges of killing at least eight patients, the police said. Dr. Angelo Rumi is accused of operating excessively and at a lethal frequency on elderly patients, and his arrest on Monday followed an 18-month investigation. The police said none of the suspicious deaths, which took place between 1999 and 2001, occurred after the investigation was opened. The doctor, 56, was convicted of manslaughter when he worked at a hospital outside of Milan in 1994. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURRAY, RALPH COUGHLAN
description: MURRAY-Ralph Coughlan. Died on February 1, 2003, in Rye, New York, of complications following a stroke. An attorney and retired partner for the Wall Street law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley and McCloy, Mr. Murray graduated from The College of the Holy Cross in Worcester, MA, in 1941. After serving in World War II, Mr. Murray completed his education at Columbia School of Law, where he was on the Law Review. Mr. Murray was an active parishioner of Resurrection Church in Rye and served there as a lector for many years. Friends may call on Friday from 5:30-8PM at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, New York. A funeral mass will be offered at Resurrection Church in Rye on Saturday at 10 AM.

title: World Briefing | Asia: East Timor: U.N. Charges 32 In Attacks
description: The United Nations indicted 32 people, including 15 Indonesian soldiers, on charges they tortured and killed East Timorese civilians during the bloodshed at the time of a referendum in 1999 on independence for the province. A prosecutor with the United Nations Crimes Unit, Eric MacDonald, said it would be difficult to bring those charged to trial. They are all believed to be in Indonesia, which has refused to honor arrest warrants. An Indonesian court set up to prosecute Indonesian military and police officers has acquitted 10 former army and police officers on charges connected with the violence.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Loss At Bank
description: South Korea's largest commercial bank, Kookmin Bank, reported a worse-than-expected net loss of 202.6 billion won ($173 million) in the fourth quarter, largely as a result of defaults on consumer loans. The loss widened from a loss of 140.7 billion won in the fourth quarter of 2001. Kookmin reported a profit in 2002 of 1.31 trillion won compared with 1.49 trillion won in 2001. The bank said it set aside 1.6 trillion won to cover bad loans, while over all, loans were up 22.9 percent from the year before. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Sungard Data Buys HTE For $121 Million
description: SunGard Data Systems Inc. said that it would buy HTE Inc. for about $121 million, or $7 a share, in cash. HTE, which provides software to local government agencies, had 2002 revenue of about $70 million, SunGard said. SunGard makes a wide variety of corporate software, including systems for financial services. It had 2001 revenue of $1.9 billion. SunGard said that HTE would operate as a unit of its public sector and nonprofit systems division and that the president and chief executive of HTE, Joseph Loughry, would continue to lead the business. Shares of HTE rose $2.19, to $6.93. HTE shareholders controlling about 49.6 percent of the company have agreed to tender their shares. SunGard shares dropped 33 cents, to $18.78. The deal, which was approved by both boards, is expected to close in the first quarter.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Bosnia: Postwar High In Refugee Returns
description: More than 100,000 Bosnian refugees returned to their prewar homes in 2002, the highest number since the year after the war among Serbs, Muslims and Croats ended in 1995. Close to one million have returned, but more than 1.2 million others who were driven from their homes during the war are still living elsewhere and many will probably never go back. Daniel Simpson (NYT)

title: Economic Scene; Military manpower and leadership are pluses, but battles are hard to predict.
description: DONALD H. RUMSFELD, the defense secretary, and his top generals are vigorously debating the number of troops to deploy in the event of a second Persian Gulf war. Coalition forces numbered 795,000 in the 1991 war. Mr. Rumsfeld has argued that far fewer American troops -- no more than 100,000 -- are needed to defeat Saddam Hussein's armies this time around because of the revolution in military technology and Iraq's weakened state, while the military brass is not so sure, and prefers at least 250,000.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hotels.com Posts Big Profit; Shares Soar
description: The discount lodging Web site Hotels.com reported that fourth-quarter profit rose on sharply higher revenue as more travelers reserved online. It also said room rates, a crucial indicator, were running slightly ahead of its 2003 goals. Hotels.com, controlled by USA Interactive, posted a profit of $17.7 million, or 30 cents a share, up from $4.8 million, or 8 cents, in the quarter a year earlier. Hotels.com stock rose 11 percent and was one of the biggest point gainers on Nasdaq. Analysts cited its positive comments on room rates and the shares' being oversold in recent weeks. Excluding one-time items, Hotels.com posted profit of 37 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had expected 38 cents. Revenue rose 92 percent, to $272.6 million. Last month, the Dallas-based company warned that fourth-quarter revenue would be $270 million to $271 million, rather than its previous forecast of $283 million to $289 million. At the time, Wall Street expected about $293 million. Shares rose $4.42, to $43.02.

title: Growth and Employment in Services Rose Modestly Last Month
description: The service sector grew at a slightly stronger pace in January than in December, a private industry group said yesterday, amid the first increase in services hiring in nearly two years.

title: PERELMAN PLEDGES TO INCREASE FINANCING AT REVLON
description: The financier Ronald O. Perelman gained breathing room from banks for Revlon, the cosmetics maker he controls, after he agreed to provide as much as $215 million to the company. Mr. Perelman increased his financing from the $150 million proposed in December, according to Revlon. Banks led by Citigroup and J. P. Morgan Chase waived some financial performance conditions of a $250 million loan through January 2004, Revlon said. Loans of $165 million by Mr. Perelman and stock purchases of as much as $50 million will give the company cash it needs to raise marketing spending and cut prices. Revlon has $2 billion in debt, mostly as a result of Mr. Perelman's 1985 takeover. (Bloomberg News)

description: In releasing the Bush administration's 2004 budget this week, the White House budget director, Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., was adamant that the government needed to cap any growth in federal spending next year at 4 percent.

description: The commission charged with redrawing City Council districts is set to vote today on a new set of lines that gives more power to the city's Hispanic and Asian voters, but still largely protects City Council incumbents, according to people involved in the redistricting process.

description: Serbia's prime minister, Zoran Djindjic, appealed today for international negotiations on the future of Kosovo to be started in June, challenging Western assertions that the subject is not up for discussion yet.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Arrest In Visa Case
description: American officials announced a fourth arrest in an investigation into the illegal sale of visas at the American Consulate in Nuevo Laredo, on the Texas border. The four men arrested, one a naturalized American citizen, the other three Mexicans, worked at the consulate. The investigation began last summer, and the accused are alleged to have conspired in a ring of ''persons buying visas without required interviews and without determinations that a person was qualified for a visa,'' United States Justice Department officials said. Tim Weiner (NYT)

description: Does poetry matter? Few but other poets may read it. Auden wrote that ''poetry makes nothing happen.'' Except perhaps when violent events are upon us. Then it can cut through the darkness, console, summon. War and poetry, for instance, have always been connected, and now, at the what seems the moment before war, America's poets are suddenly again playing a traditional, if at times quixotic role of poets as spokesmen for dissent.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Jobless Rate Rises
description: Unemployment in Germany rose to 11 percent last month, up from 10.1 percent in December and its highest level in five years. The number of jobless people rose nearly 400,000, to 4.62 million, an unexpectedly large increase, even taking into account the seasonal loss of outdoor jobs. The statistics suggest that German companies remain pessimistic about an economic rebound. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPRAGUE, LUCY RUFFIN
description: SPRAGUE-Lucy Ruffin. Of Tenafly, NJ, passed away on January 14, 2003. A memorial service will be held at St. Paul's Church, Englewood, NJ at 12 noon, on February 8, 2003 (phone: 201-568-3276). In lieu of flowers gifts in her memory may be made to St. Paul's Church, 113 Engle Street, Englewood, NJ 07631.

title: Pursuing Leads, NASA Officials Look to Western States for Pieces of the Shuttle Puzzle
description: With NASA issuing renewed pleas for residents of Arizona, California and New Mexico to look for possible pieces of the space shuttle Columbia, the sheriff's department here has locked away a small piece of blackened foam in its evidence room.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about the Comcast Corporation's sale of some cable systems to Bresnan Communications misstated the terms. Bresnan agreed to pay $525 million in cash plus an undisclosed amount of common and preferred stock -- not a total of $525 million in cash and stock.

title: Amid Much Anticipation, A Rap Artist Makes a Debut
description: After poking fun at a break-dancing troupe and pronouncing the employees of a local sneaker store ''savages,'' Star, the cantankerous shock jock on the New York radio station Hot 97, posed a simple question Monday morning. ''Other than 50 Cent,'' he asked his merry band of studio buddies, ''what's going on in hip-hop right now?'' The lengthy silence said it all.

title: Brooklyn Hit-and-Run Kills 2 Young Women and Infant
description: A hit-and-run driver speeding on a major thoroughfare in Brooklyn yesterday struck and killed a baby and two young mothers before smashing his Jeep into a tractor-trailer 10 blocks away, the authorities said. He and a second child who was struck were in critical condition last night.

title: Job Action By Doctors Winds Down
description: In its third day of rallies and canceled appointments, the work slowdown by New Jersey doctors appeared to be winding down today, as many doctors made plans to resume their normal schedules and organizers of the job action began softening their tone.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Beautiful and Edible

title: Delta to Alter Check-In, Using More Machines
description: Seeking to eliminate at least one of the lines passengers have to endure at the airport, Delta Air Lines announced a plan yesterday to modify its procedures at 81 airports in hopes of ensuring that most customers do not have to wait more than two minutes to check in, even at peak times.

title: No Legal Precedent Is Seen Should Columbia Families Choose to Sue
description: The families of the astronauts who perished in the Challenger disaster in 1986 received millions of dollars in settlements from the government and Morton Thiokol, the company that manufactured the faulty rocket boosters blamed for that accident.

title: Injury to Martin Doesn't Rattle Kittles or the Nets
description: The Nets figured they would slip quietly into the All-Star Game break to nurse their injuries after tonight's game against the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: Weapons Inspector Warns Iraq to Disarm or Face Grave Problems
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  A top United Nations weapons inspector exhorted Iraq today to "show drastic change" in cooperating to disarm or be prepared for grave problems. But several important countries continued to hold out for further United Nations inspections, and not war.

title: BAYER SAYS IT FACES 400 MORE BAYCOL LAWSUITS
description: Bayer, the German pharmaceutical maker, said the number of lawsuits it faced after the recall of its anticholesterol drug Baycol had risen to 7,800 from 7,400 last month. About 420 cases have been settled, the company said. Baycol was withdrawn in August 2001 after it was linked to more than 50 deaths worldwide. The number of deaths linked to the drug has since risen to more than 100. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARLAN, DR. HAROLD, D.D.S.
description: HARLAN-Dr. Harold, D.D.S., 97, of Jamesburg, NJ, died Tuesday at his home. Services will be today in Temple B'nai Jeshurun, South Orange Ave, Short Hills, NJ. Dr. Harlan was a self-employed dentist in Newark, NJ, for 51 years. He received a Bachelor's degree from New York University, Master's degree in Public Health from Columbia University and his doctorate in dental science from the University of Pennsylvania. Dr. Harlan served in the Army Dental Corps Active Reserves for 38 years. He was a member of the Unity Club, Maplewood, the Rotary Club and B'nai B'rith and was a 32nd degree Mason at the Salaam Temple, Livingston, NJ. Dr. Harlan was a board member of the American Cancer Society, a director of the Dental Board for the City of Newark, president of the Essex County Dental Society, treasurer of the Newark Dental Club, adjunct professor at the Columbia School of Nursing and an elected member of the International College of Dentistry. He was also a member of the first class of dental interns at Newark Beth Israel Medical Center, Newark. He served as president of the New Jersey Public Health Association. Born in Newark, NJ, he lived in Maplewood and East Orange before moving to Jamesburg 15 years ago. Surviving are his wife, Doris; sons Leonard of New York City and Bruce; brothers Martin and Sheldon and two grandchildren. For further information please contact Menorah Chapels at Millburn, Union, NJ.

title: CALIFORNIA MAY BAR WELLS FARGO FROM HOME LOANS
description: Wells Fargo & Company, the largest mortgage lender in the nation, was threatened by California authorities with the loss of its license to make home loans in the state amid allegations that the bank overcharged borrowers. The warning, made by the California Department of Corporations, is an escalation of the dispute. The bank sued the state last week, saying that federal rules should apply to its mortgage practices. The California agency said the bank refused to make refunds after an examination by the department of loans made in 2000 and 2001 showed improper interest charges and inadequate disclosure on consumer bill statements.

title: Bush Says 'Game Is Over' for Iraq and Urges U.N. to Act
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 - President Bush, in some of his strongest words on Iraq, warned the Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein this afternoon that he ``will be stopped,'' and the president cautioned the United Nations Security Council that it must not back down when its demands for disarmament were ``defied and mocked by a dictator.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Must Release Rescue Tapes
description: A state judge ruled yesterday that the city must release hundreds of tape recordings and other documents relating to the Fire Department's rescue operations on Sept. 11, 2001. Judge Richard F. Braun of State Supreme Court rejected the city's argument that releasing the records would interfere with the trial of Zacarias Moussaoui, a terror suspect. Ruling in a lawsuit brought by The New York Times, he said the city must release the Fire Department's internal radio transmissions and the factual portions of its oral histories of Sept. 11. But the city can withhold intra-agency advice from the records, he wrote. He also ruled that the tapes of 911 telephone calls made on that day must remain largely confidential because of the callers' privacy interests. The judge, however, ordered the release of those portions of the tapes involving relatives of nine families who moved to join the suit, and those portions consisting of the words of the 911 operators. The city is expected to appeal the decision, but a call to city lawyers was not immediately returned last night. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: Ashcroft Pushes Executions In More Cases in New York
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft has ordered United States attorneys in New York and Connecticut to seek the death penalty for a dozen defendants in cases in which prosecutors had recommended against or did not ask for capital punishment, according to lawyers who follow the issue. Those are nearly half of all the cases nationwide in which Mr. Ashcroft has rejected prosecutors' recommendations in a death penalty case.

title: With Woods Sidelined, The Field Is More Open
description: A month into the PGA Tour season, Tiger Woods has not played, no American player has won, but there has been plenty to discuss.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Sotheby's Will Discontinue Auctions On Its Web Site
description: The auction house Sotheby's Holdings said that it would stop holding online auctions on its Web site, sothebys.ebay.com, which was built by and linked to eBay. The alliance between Sotheby's and eBay will end in May, officials said. ''As our online auctions offered by our dealer associates and Sotheby's have not generated a profit for Sotheby's, we are discontinuing separate online auctions,'' said William F. Ruprecht, president and chief executive of Sotheby's Holdings Inc. The company plans to continue operating a Web site, officials said, to provide details on its live auctions and for other company information. The auction house said that it had lost about $100 million on Internet operations in about three years. In June, Sotheby's started selling its fine art, antiques and other collectibles on the Web. But online sales did not meet company expectations; Sotheby's said it made about $135 million through its eBay-affiliated site.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: 3 Companies To Make Games For Nokia
description: Nokia, the No. 1 mobile phone maker, said that Eidos P.L.C., Activision Inc. and THQ Inc. would develop games for its hand-held video game player as it tries to increase revenue by taking market share from Nintendo. Nokia will start selling the N-Gage player, which also doubles as a mobile phone, in the fourth quarter, Pekka Rantala, a vice president at Nokia's handset unit, said in an interview. Sega and Taito have previously said they would cooperate with Nokia. The games by established developers will help Nokia challenge Nintendo, whose Game Boy Advance dominates the hand-held player market, analysts have said. Nokia is expanding outside traditional cellphones after its revenue slid in 2002, for the first time in a decade. The N-Gage phone will allow users to play video games on their own or against others within a range of 33 feet, connected by wireless Bluetooth technology.

title: From Baubles To Gems For the Home
description: Herv Van der Straeten (above) made his name in jewelry design working with Christian Lacroix, Yves Saint Laurent and Jean Paul Gaultier. Now decorators like Muriel Brandolini, Robert Couturier and Alberto Pinto are among the customers at his gallery in the Marais in Paris.

title: The $100 Posy Race
description: IN the spirit of Valentine's Day, I sent six bouquets of flowers to a complete stranger, along with notes that I was thinking of her, that I loved her, that I hoped she was thinking of me, and, well, that I was thinking of her still more.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROOKS, SHELDON VON HAGEN
description: BROOKS-Sheldon von Hagen, 82. Of Key Largo, Florida, formerly of Wayzata, Minnesota died Saturday, February 1, 2003 at his home in Key Largo from complications of prostate cancer. Born in Minneapolis January 10, 1921, son of Paul Andros and Hazel von Hagen Brooks, he attended the Blake School, Hotchkiss and graduated from The Thacher School in 1939. A member of the Yale Class of '43, during World War II, Mr. Brooks served in the Navy Air Corps first as an instructor at Pensacola and later in the Pacific Theater flying for the Naval Air Transport Service. After the war, he was for 35 years the owner of the Minnetonka Boat Works, retiring in 1985. He was preceded in death by his parents, his sisters Polly Brooks Hollern, Barbara Brooks Kroos and his brother Anson Brooks. He is survived by Carroll, his wife of twentyone years, three children of a previous marriage to the late Frances Atkinson Hewitt, Paul Andros (Pam) Brooks, Sky Atkinson Brooks, Molly Moyer Brooks his sister, Stanley Brooks Gregory and four grandchildren. Mr. Brooks was a member of the Key Largo Anglers Club, the Ocean Reef Club, Woodhill Country Club, Shikar Safari Club International, The Bohemian Club, Quiet Birdmen and numerous conservation organizations. Contributions in his memory to the Ocean Reef Medical Center Foundation, Ocean Reef Drive, Key Largo, Florida 33037 or the Ridgeview Medical Center Foundation in C/O of Robert Stevens, 500 South Maple Street, Waconia, Minnesota, 55387 would be greatly appreciated. There will be a memorial service at a later date.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Many questions remain about energy trading practices, despite the lessons of Enron's collapse.
description: THERE is no question that the scandal that began with Enron and has yet to entirely die away has decimated the energy marketing and trading industry. But some experts question whether the bruising has prompted energy companies to change the business practices that got them into trouble in the first place.

title: Turkey Backs United States Plans for Iraq
description: The prime minister of Turkey declared his government's support today for America's plans for military action in Iraq, saying he would ask Parliament later this month to open the country's bases to thousands of American combat troops, Turkish reporters said.

title: Senate Presses Powell on North Korea
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 — Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that the United States would continue to talk with North Korea through many channels and to send the message that diplomacy is the best way to ease tensions on the Korean Peninsula.

title: Powell's Address, Presenting 'Deeply Troubling' Evidence on Iraq
description: Following is a transcript of an address given yesterday by Secretary of State Colin L. Powell to the United Nations Security Council, as recorded by Federal News Service Inc.

title: Technology Briefing: E-Commerce
description: COMPUTER ASSOCIATES ACQUIRES NETREON Computer Associates International Inc. has acquired Netreon Inc. to increase sales of computer programs that make storing vast amounts of electronic data more efficient and affordable. A Computer Associates spokesman, Robert Gordon, declined to disclose the price of the acquisition, which was completed Monday. Most of Netreon's 22 employees, who are based in Mountain View, Calif., will join Computer Associates, he said. Computer Associates competes with EM, the Veritas Software Corporation and other companies in sales of storage networks. Netreon's products will be sold under the BrightStor brand of Computer Associates. Shares of Computer Associates fell 23 cents, to $13.22.   (Bloomberg News)

title: Higher Rates Ordered For Lawyers for Poor
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan ruled yesterday that the system of compensating private lawyers assigned to represent the poor in city courts is unconstitutional. The justice ordered the city and the state to more than double the hourly rates, which have been in place since 1985.

title: A Reprise of 1962, With Less Electricity
description: A Stevenson moment?

title: Steamrolling Judicial Nominees
description: The new Senate Republican majority is ushering in an era of conveyor-belt confirmations of Bush administration judicial nominations. No matter which party holds the gavel, the federal courts are too important for the Senate to give short shrift to its constitutional role of advice and consent.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Skyscraper Crash Not a Suicide
description: The crash of a small plane into a Milan skyscraper last year, which initially raised the specter of terrorism, was most likely a result of the pilot's inability to control the aircraft as it suffered technical problems, and not a suicide, investigators concluded. The National Agency of Air Security also faulted the control tower at Linate airport for sending contradictory and confusing messages to the pilot, which may have resulted in his death along with those of two people inside the landmark Pirelli tower. Scores of the airport's air traffic controllers are already accused of abandoning their posts to play soccer and take long cappuccino breaks; prosecutors blame airport officials for an October 2001 runway crash that killed 118 people.

title: Venezuela Imposes Currency Controls to Shore Up Economy
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 6  In an effort to shore up an economy that was devastated by an antigovernment strike, President Hugo Chavez announced today a series of currency controls intended to bolster Venezuela's diminishing foreign reserves and price cuts on essential goods.

title: Whose Vision for Ground Zero?
description: To the Editor:

title: Islanders' Jonsson Cleared to Play
description: Two days after he had what the Islanders carefully labeled a post-traumatic migraine headache, defenseman Kenny Jonsson practiced with the team yesterday and has been cleared to return.

title: POWELL, IN U.N. SPEECH, PRESENTS CASE TO SHOW IRAQ HAS NOT DISARMED
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, pressing the American case for a possible war to disarm Iraq, today presented photographs, intercepts of conversations between Iraqi military officers and information from defectors aimed at proving that Saddam Hussein poses an imminent danger to the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CATANZARO, ROSE (NEE MISTRETTA)
description: CATANZARO - Rose (nee Mistretta), 72. Of Woodcliff Lake, NJ died February 4, 2003. Born in New York City, she lived in New Bern, NC before moving to Woodcliff Lake, NJ. Mrs. Catanzaro was a homemaker. Beloved wife of Rosario Catanzaro of Woodcliff Lake, NJ. Devoted mother of Marisa McDonnell of Woodcliff Lake, NJ and Leonard Catanzaro of Little River, SC. Loving grandmother of Russell James and Patrick Catanzaro. Dear sister of Dr. Charles Mistretta of Flushing, NY. Funeral service at 11:00 A.M. on Saturday at Vander Plaat Memorial Home, S113 Farview Avenue, Paramus, NJ. Entombment George Washington Memorial Park, Paramus, NJ. Family will receive their friends on Friday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M.

title: Extortion Victim Is Accused Of Being Mob Co-Conspirator
description: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn asserted yesterday that Carmine Ragucci, the chairman of the influential Conservative Party in Staten Island, was a co-conspirator in making payoffs to the Mafia while running a Staten Island waterfront company. They had previously described him as an extortion victim only.

title: Intelligence Break Led U.S. to Tie Envoy Killing to Iraq Qaeda Cell
description: An intelligence breakthrough in the last several weeks made it possible for Secretary of State Colin L. Powell to set forth the first evidence of what he said was a well developed cell of Al Qaeda operating out of Baghdad that was responsible for the assassination of the American diplomat Laurence Foley last October.

title: U.S.-Russia Atomic Arms Pact Wins Senate Panel's Backing
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee unanimously endorsed a treaty today that obliges the United States and Russia to cut their strategic nuclear arsenals by two-thirds over the next 10 years, granting President Bush a long-delayed foreign policy victory.

title: CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER RESIGNS POSITION AT SPIEGEL
description: Spiegel Inc., the clothing and home-furnishings retailer, said its chief financial officer, James R. Cannataro, is leaving to become executive vice president of the United States unit of the Nintendo Company. Mr. Cannataro joined Spiegel in 1984 and was promoted to chief financial officer in 2001. His last day is Feb. 12, the company said. Spiegel, the owner of the Spiegel and Newport News catalogs and the Eddie Bauer clothing chain, said it was searching for a successor. Spiegel is based in Downers Grove, Ill. News of Mr. Cannataro's resignation came a day after its auditor, KPMG, said there was substantial doubt about the company's future after it failed to comply with some of its debt agreements. Nintendo, which is based in Kyoto, Japan, said Mr. Cannataro would join the company next month.
