title: U.N. Begins Choosing The Judges For New Court
description: As the Bush administration sought to muster backing for a strike against Iraq in the Security Council, the United Nations moved forward this week toward creating an International Criminal Court -- a project that America's allies hope the United States will support over time.

title: Powell Answers Questions on North Korea
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that the United States will continue to talk with North Korea through many channels and to send the message that diplomacy is the best way to ease tensions on the Korean Peninsula.

title: Westchester Faces Cuts in Standoff Over a Higher Sales Tax
description: Westchester County will have to increase property taxes, lay off police officers and cut spending to close its budget gap after members of the county's delegation to the State Legislature said they could not reach an agreement to support a one percentage point increase in the sales tax, county officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sunday with an obituary of the pioneer aviator Evelyn Trout misidentified the plane shown with her. It was a Curtiss Pusher, not a Curtiss Robin.

title: A 60-Gigabyte Guardian Averts Hard-Drive Disasters
description: Backing up a computer is a chore that is often neglected until disaster strikes, and by then it may be too late to do much more than hand over your credit card to a data-recovery service or PC repair shop. A new external hard drive from Iomega could help head off such a situation. The 60-gigabyte version of the Iomega HDD portable drive not only makes it possible to store big things in small packages but also helps automate backup sessions, saving both time and space.

title: Korean Border Opens to Traffic As Bus Tour Leaves for the North
description: Buses carrying 100 South Koreans crossed the North Korean frontier today, opening the first road for normal traffic between the Koreas since the Korean War.

title: Sprint's Shares Rise, but Its Woes Are Rising Faster
description: Management tumult at the telecommunications company Sprint reached a new level yesterday as the chief executive, William T. Esrey, acknowledged that he was the subject of an Internal Revenue Service audit, while the executive whom the company has chosen to succeed Mr. Esrey became the target of a second lawsuit meant to keep him from joining Sprint.

title: After Successfully Reducing Debt, Primedia Explores Sale of Seventeen
description: Primedia Inc. announced yesterday that it would explore a sale of Seventeen magazine, the largest teenage magazine.

title: U.S. question:with us, or against us?: Issue in sharp focus
description: PARIS:  The United States' effort at documenting Iraq as a seething threat to humanity went so far in its presentation of damning evidence and intention that, whatever the world's reaction, it leaves American leadership in a place from which it is difficult to return.

title: Act Now on 911 System
description: To the Editor:

title: The Next Step
description: Today the prospect for the World Trade Center site in Lower Manhattan looks much clearer than it did two days ago, in a design sense at least. After a number of false starts and false premises, a team of officials from the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, the Port Authority, the state and the city has selected two designs from among the nine that were presented at the Winter Garden in mid-December. The Studio Daniel Libeskind proposal and the World Cultural Center plan offered by the Think team of architects both boldly recast the skyline and cityscape of Lower Manhattan, and both place remembrance at the heart of their vision.

title: Speedskier Barrels Down Snowy Expressway
description: In the summers when Tracie Sachs is back home on Long Island, there will always be an occasion when someone asks her what she does for a living. If she needs a good laugh, she will answer, ''I'm a speedskier.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOWMAN, ANNA
description: BOWMAN-Anna. Formerly of Scarsdale, died February 2, 2003. Services at the Hawthorne Funeral Home, 21 Stevens Ave., Hawthorne, on Sunday, February 9th, 10AM. For further information, please call 914-769-4404

description: This article was reported by James Glanz, David E. Sanger and John Schwartz and was written by Mr. Glanz.

title: A.G. Edwards Opens Review to 5 Agencies
description: A. G. Edwards & Sons, the brokerage firm, has begun a review for its account, which has been handled internally.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Former Police Official Slain
description: An unidentified assassin shot and killed Guillermo Gonzlez Calderoni, a former senior federal police official, in the border town of McAllen, Tex. Mr. Gonzlez fled Mexico 10 years ago, pursued by accusations of corruption and torture. He gave American and Mexican officials information about corruption at the highest levels of the government of Carlos Salinas de Gortari, president of Mexico from 1988 to 1994, including evidence against Mr. Salinas's brother Ral, now in prison. Tim Weiner (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, ADELE B. (NEE GAUDET)
description: CLARK-Adele B. (nee Gaudet). Died on January 30, 2003. Devoted mother and grandmother, friend and neighbor. Teacher, volunteer and community activist. She is survived and remembered by her family: her son, Dr. Christopher Osgood, professor at Old Dominion University in Norfolk, VA; her daughter-inlaw, Eileen Osgood, CSW; and her grandson, Nicholas Osgood. She joins her late husband, George Clark.

title: INSIDE
description: Turkey Backs War on Iraq

title: EXPEDIA SALES SOAR; CHIEF ANNOUNCES RESIGNATION
description: Richard N. Barton, the chief executive of Expedia, the online travel agency, said yesterday that he would resign as of March 31. His plan, perhaps to no one's surprise, is to travel, spending a year in Tuscany and Paris with his wife, Sarah, and three young children. Erik C. Blachford, the president of Expedia North America, will become chief executive and Mr. Barton will join the board of USA Interactive, which controls a majority of Expedia's shares. Mr. Barton, who started the company as a unit of Microsoft, is leaving on a high note. Expedia said yesterday that its sales in the fourth quarter of 2002 nearly doubled to $1.38 billion and its profit quadrupled to $21.4 million. Saul Hansell (NYT)

title: 'Irrefutable And Undeniable'
description: It isn't the crime that gets you it's the cover-up.

title: Hussein Aide Denounces Powell's Case as Full of Baseless 'Stunts'
description: Iraq tonight denounced as ''manufactured'' and ''baseless'' the arguments made to the United Nations Security Council by Secretary of State Colin L. Powell.

title: El Paso Cuts Dividend; Asset Sales Planned
description: The El Paso Corporation, the nation's largest energy pipeline company, said yesterday that it would conserve cash by cutting its dividend 82 percent and selling more assets, including a refinery in New Jersey.

title: HIRING IN NATION HITS WORST SLUMP IN NEARLY 20 YEARS
description: The economy has fallen into its worst hiring slump in almost 20 years, and many business executives say they remain unsure when it will end.

description: International Herald Tribune

description: Marcus Hatten left the Conte Forum floor tonight without shaking hands. He showered quickly and left without talking to reporters.

title: French Bank Says It Will Seek Acquisitions in Western U.S.
description: The chairman of BNP Paribas, Michel Pbereau, said today that the bank would seek to make acquisitions in the Western United States as he ruled out a possible merger with a rival French bank, Socit Gnrale.

title: MYSTERY DEEPENS
description: NASA investigators said yesterday that the disintegration of the space shuttle Columbia had turned into a scientific mystery.

title: Priest Convicted of Molesting Girl, 12, at Her Home in 1999
description: In the first case brought in New York City based on old files turned over by the Roman Catholic church, a priest was convicted yesterday in Brooklyn of molesting a 12-year-old girl at her home in 1999.

title: Rumsfeld Warns He Will Ask Congress for More Billions
description: Days after the administration asked Congress for the biggest military budget since the Reagan-era buildup, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld told a Congressional panel today that the administration would soon request additional billions to fight terrorism and for any conflict with Iraq.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Cellular Takeover Advances
description: The Malaysian cellular operator Celcom won regulatory approval for its planned takeover of Telekom Malaysia's cellular unit TM Touch. The merger of the two cellular operators is part of a plan by Telekom Malaysia to take over Celcom. Telekom Malaysia bought a controlling stake in Celcom early last year, ousting a Malaysian tycoon, Tajudin Ramli. But the merger, which must still win shareholder approval, is said to face opposition from a minority shareholder, Deutsche Telekom. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Cutting to the Chase: Kitchen-Only Tours
description: MICHELE JACOBS of Wayne, N.J., recently redid her kitchen. But that didn't stop her from plunking down $45 to see 10 more on a kitchen tour in nearby Glen Ridge. Her stove-filled itinerary was a version of the old house tour, where people tromp through your rooms, oohing, aahing and quietly criticizing your taste, but with a sharper focus.

title: House and Senate Panels Will Hold Joint Hearing on Shuttle
description: House and Senate committees with oversight of the space program will convene a joint hearing next Wednesday to begin their inquiries into what caused the breakup of the shuttle Columbia.

title: Demolishing Gaza Home, Israelis Kill Militant's Stepmother
description: While demolishing the home of a Palestinian militant in the Gaza Strip today, Israeli forces crushed to death his 65-year-old stepmother, who apparently did not hear their warnings to leave, the woman's family said.

title: Coliseum Books Finds a New Home on 42nd Street
description: Coliseum Books, the bookstore near Columbus Circle that closed in January, 2002, after nearly three decades, will reopen in April in a new location, opposite the New York City Public Library's main branch, its real estate broker said yesterday.

title: Teenager Invited To L.P.G.A. Event
description: Michelle Wie, a 13-year-old, received an invitation from the Kraft Nabisco Championship yesterday to play in the L.P.G.A. Tour's first major after she impressed PGA Tour pros in a men's event with her fluid swing and 300-yard drives.

title: Kurds Puzzled by Report of Terror Camp
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell's assertion today that Islamic extremists were operating a poisons training camp and factory in northern Iraq appeared to surprise Kurdish officials, who greeted the claim with a mix of satisfaction and confusion.

title: Who Says Sculpture Can't Be Functional?
description: Augustin Granet (below) grew up watching his mother sculpture in bronze. Today he is the director and designer of a family business, Objet Insolite, which creates bronze lamps, curtain rods, doorknobs and furniture handles.

title: Object, Caught in a Tree, Prompts Thoughts of God
description: Sitting in her backyard swing with her Bible in her lap, Nancy Youngs squinted at the white fabric 30 feet up in the branches of the oak tree.

title: NASA Officials Look to Western States for Pieces of Shuttle Puzzle
description: REDWOOD CITY, Calif., Feb. 5  With NASA issuing renewed pleas for residents of Arizona, California and New Mexico to look for possible pieces of the space shuttle Columbia, the sheriff's department here has locked away a small piece of blackened foam in its evidence room.

title: Map Becomes Clearer In Trade Center Choices
description: EVER since nine competing architectural visions for the World Trade Center site were unveiled in December, it has been irresistible to talk about their place on the skyline and in the civic heart. The winnowing announced Tuesday permits closer scrutiny of a more basic building block: their place on the streets of Lower Manhattan.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Bank Acquisition
description: The Dutch financial services company, ING Groep, agreed to buy Entrium Direct Bankers of Germany for 300 million euros ($324 million) to strengthen its position as Germany's largest Internet bank. ING, which is based in Amsterdam, will make the purchase from Capitalia of Italy through ING's German unit, Allgemeine Deutsche Direktbank, or DiBa. The purchase will give ING 965,000 new clients, with 7.1 billion euros in assets, compared with 1.9 million customers at DiBa, with 21 billion euros in assets.

title: Toyota to Build Assembly Plant in Texas
description: Toyota Motor said today that its profits nearly doubled in the last quarter of 2002 and announced that it would build a new assembly plant in Texas to challenge the Big Three automakers in areas where they traditionally dominate.

title: Too Many Security Patches
description: To the Editor:

title: Seeing the Pen Not as Mightier, but as More Honest
description: CHRISTIAN BAUMAN says that when he has time, he watches the commercials, the ones that got him into war in the first place. He remembers what it was like, his daughter born before he graduated from high school, the series of dead-end jobs as a cook and a house painter, the bills from collection agencies he could not pay and the struggle to get by without health insurance. And he remembers the Army recruiter, with the promise of travel and another life, of adventure and a decent paycheck.

title: Phone Dialing Simplified
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraq's Response: 'Incorrect Allegations'
description: Following are excerpts from the response given yesterday by Mohammed Aldouri, Iraq's United Nations ambassador, to Secretary of State Colin L. Powell's address to the United Nations Security Council, as recorded by Federal News Service Inc. A full transcript is online: nytimes.com/international.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CONOCOPHILLIPS, Houston, bought a 1.5 percent stake in the Trans-Alaska Pipeline System from Amerada Hess Corp., New York, the oil compa ny, to increase its interest to 28.2 percent. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A Neverland World Of Michael Jackson
description: Martin Bashir, the British television journalist who followed Michael Jackson for eight months, should have introduced his interview floating face down in a swimming pool and speaking in a voice-over, like William Holden in ''Sunset Boulevard.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, JACK
description: YOUNG-Jack. Website designer and computer genius. Died Tuesday, January 28, 2003. Dearly loved and missed by his wife Gaylin, family and friends. Survived by his daughter Michele and son Christian.

title: Watching a Cold Front Advance Across Your Palmtop Screen
description: Weather reports on television have long been accompanied by a swirl of computer-animated images and photographs.

title: Trenton Lawmakers Seek Alternatives to McGreevey's Austere Budget Plan
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey insisted today that he would not consider any increase in the state's three major taxes, but many state legislators, responding grimly to the stripped-down budget he presented on Tuesday, said they would listen to any proposals to alleviate the pain in it.

title: Suspect Is Arrested in the Killing of a Hong Kong Businessman
description: The police in mainland China said today that they had arrested the suspected gunman in the slaying of a prominent Hong Kong businessman, a case that has fed fears of crime in Hong Kong as border controls are relaxed.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: LOSS AT BANK South Korea's largest commercial bank, Kookmin Bank , reported a worse-than-expected net loss of 202.6 billion won ($173 million) in the fourth quarter, largely as a result of defaults on consumer loans. The loss widened from a loss of 140.7 billion won in the fourth quarter of 2001. Kookmin reported a profit in 2002 of 1.31 trillion won compared with 1.49 trillion won in 2001. The bank said it set aside 1.6 trillion won to cover bad loans, while over all, loans were up 22.9 percent from the year before. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Army Says It Downed Pakistani Robot
description: Army officials said India had shot down a robot Pakistani spy plane flying over Indian airspace in Kashmir. They said wreckage from the plane fell 400 yards inside the part of the region controlled by India. There was no immediate response from Pakistan. Last week, Pakistan said it had shot down an unpiloted Indian spy plane, an assertion India denied. Pakistan says it provides moral and political support to Kashmiris fighting for independence; India accuses Pakistan of sponsoring terrorism in the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir.

title: Personal 555 Number Is Still Mostly Fiction
description: IN the movie ''Last Action Hero,'' a boy who has been sucked into an action movie tries to convince the skeptical adults around him that they are fictitious. To prove it, he asks for the phone number of the store he is in.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 23 about the renovation of the landmark Ferry Building in San Francisco misidentified a nearby coffee shop where cultural figures like the poet Lawrence Ferlinghetti sometimes have breakfast. It is the Cafe de Stijl, not the Cafe Bastille.

title: National Briefing | West: Illinois: Rallying Doctors Against Insurance Costs
description: A doctor is trying to organize a one-day halt to nonemergency procedures by doctors across the state to bring attention to the high cost of malpractice insurance. Dr. Thomas Pliura of LeRoy, a small town 60 miles northeast of Springfield, said he hoped 2,000 doctors would join him in the capital on Feb. 26 to ask legislators to enact measures to control insurance costs. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Australia/New Zealand: New Zealand: Retailer's Sales Are Weak
description: Cool summer weather and a weak rural economy helped sap sales growth at the Warehouse Group, New Zealand's answer to Wal-Mart. Sales in the three months ended in January, which coincide with summer in the Southern Hemisphere, grew 5.3 percent, to 657 million New Zealand dollars ($360 million), lower than expected. The results prompted the company to warn that first-half profit would fall short of earlier estimates as it lays off workers and writes off assets at its Australian operations. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEISER, STEVEN R.
description: WEISER-Steven R. February 6, 1993. Ten years and the light and the love never dim. Robin, Jessica, Lauren, Jil

title: Arthur Olsen, 82, Reporter and Envoy, Dies
description: Arthur J. Olsen, a retired Foreign Service officer and former foreign correspondent for The New York Times, died on Friday at his home in Washington. He was 82.

title: Shuttle Inquiry Transferred to an Independent Board
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 6 - Under sharp prodding from Congress, NASA formally transferred authority for the investigation of the shuttle Columbia disaster to an independent review board today and agreed to add new members to the panel with no ties to the space agency.

title: Struggling With Memory Cards
description: Achief beauty of the digital camera is that its film is reusable. You can fill up your memory card, dump the photos off to a computer or printer, erase the card and start filling it up again.

title: CALENDAR
description: Paper Dreams

title: The Industrial Aesthetic Charm of Jean Prouv
description: Over the last decade, the furniture of Jean Prouv (inset above), the French architect, engineer and designer, has attracted collectors like Marc Jacobs, Brad Pitt and Azzedine Alaa. A hero as well to designers and architects like Jean Nouvel and Norman Foster, Prouv, who died in 1984, was a Modernist who produced his own industrial aesthetic. If he is appreciated more today than in his lifetime, it is partly thanks to Patrick Seguin (above left), a Parisian dealer who began collecting and exhibiting the designer's work in the 1980's.

title: Powell's Trademark: Overwhelm Them
description: To convince allied nations that Saddam Hussein is trying to deceive United Nations weapon inspectors, the Bush administration today applied a tried- and-true strategy: it invoked the Powell doctrine.

title: In Their Words: The Security Council
description: Following are excerpts from a meeting of the United Nations Security Council yesterday after the address by Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, as recorded by Federal News Service Inc. A full transcript is online: nytimes.com/international.

title: Queen, Captured by Mouse; More Chess Players Use Computers for Edge
description: Garry Kasparov, the world's leading chess player, is tied with a powerful computer program in a six-game match at the New York Athletic Club that will conclude tomorrow. But whoever wins this latest man-versus-machine showdown, chess players say computers have already scored a profound victory by changing the way humans play against one another.

title: 7 Detained in British Anti-Terror Raids
description: LONDON, Feb. 6 — Anti-terrorism police detained seven people in coordinated early morning raids in four cities in England and Scotland today in an operation that officials linked to recent arrests in Britain of North Africans charged with plotting attacks with the deadly toxin ricin.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We must not shrink from whatever is ahead of us. We must not fail in our duty and our responsibility for the citizens of the countries that are represented by this body.''

title: Whose Vision for Ground Zero?
description: To the Editor:

title: Speech Praised by Europe's Politicians, but Public Is Still Unpersuaded
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell's presentation at the United Nations was called persuasive and forceful by foreign policy experts and political figures in Europe, but few seemed to believe that European public opinion would be measurably swayed by it.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Computer Associates Acquires Netreon
description: Computer Associates International Inc. has acquired Netreon Inc. to increase sales of computer programs that make storing vast amounts of electronic data more efficient and affordable. A Computer Associates spokesman, Robert Gordon, declined to disclose the price of the acquisition, which was completed Monday. Most of Netreon's 22 employees, who are based in Mountain View, Calif., will join Computer Associates, he said. Computer Associates competes with EM, the Veritas Software Corporation and other companies in sales of storage networks. Netreon's products will be sold under the BrightStor brand of Computer Associates. Shares of Computer Associates fell 23 cents, to $13.22.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROSS, STEWARD R. JR. (''STEVE'')
description: BROSS - Steward R. Jr. (''Steve''). On January 31, 2003. Loving husband of Isabel, his wife of almost 60 years. Caring father of Donna Campagna, grandfather of Christina Kapp and Brian Cunneff, and great grandfather of Emily Kapp. Retired partner of the law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore; Church Warden Emeritus of Trinity Church, New York City; Trustee Emeritus of The Cathedral Church of Saint John the Divine. A service will be held at Trinity Church, Broadway and Wall Street, New York City, at 10 A.M. on Thursday, February 6, 2003. Following the service a reception will be held in the Church parlor. Entombment will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the New York Presbyterian Hospital, New York, N.Y. 10032, or to The Church of the Good Shepherd, 2140 Main St., Wailuku, HI 96793.

title: New Allies Back U.S. Iraq Policy
description: Ten Eastern European countries all aspirants to NATO membership -- have united behind a strongly worded statement of support for the United States in a further sign of the increasingly polarized positions in Europe toward a possible war in Iraq.

title: Doctors Find Treatment to Reduce Risk of Premature Birth
description: Doctors reported today that they had found the first treatment ever proved to reduce the risk of premature birth in women with a high risk of having their babies too early.

title: Star Wars
description: Highlights from this week's forum discussions, including thoughts about the shuttle program's viability and questions on high-definition television.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 9/11 Aid For Nonprofit Groups
description: Two groups announced yesterday that they would provide emergency loans of as much as $25,000 and other financial aid for nonprofit organizations hurt by the September 2001 terror attack. The groups, the United Way of New York City and Seedco, a community development organization, said they would provide $9.5 million in loans and technical assistance to nonprofit groups in Lower Manhattan and other neighborhoods financially hobbled by the attack. The groups said the aid, including longer-term loans of up to $500,000, would be provided at below-market interest rates over the next three years. Information is available at (212) 473-0255. David W. Chen (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BABUSHKIN, WALTER, DDS.
description: BABUSHKIN-Walter, DDS. On February 5, 2003. Beloved husband of Janet Marder. Cherished father of Joyce, Mark, Robert and Stephen. Loving grandfather and great grandfather. A W.W.II veteran. Funeral services on Friday, February 7, at 12 noon at The Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: Official Hears Teenagers' Views on Drinking
description: One shaggy-haired teenager urged an emphasis on ethics and values, not laws, to get his peers to stop binge drinking. Another said a zero-tolerance crackdown was the only way to prevent under-age tippling. Others said it was pointless even to try to stop the suburban drinking parties at which teenagers become falling-down drunk, parties that seem to happen every week.

title: From Paris, for a Home That's Ready to Wear It
description: DESIGNS shown at Maison & Objet, the home design fair held Jan. 24 to 28 just outside Paris, reflected the exuberance of the previous week's haute couture shows. Products gleamed with bright colors. Upholstery and bedcovers in buttery leather and plush furs were adorned with dressmaker details like embroidery and feathers. Many of the designers began their careers in fashion. Some also offered accessories like necklaces and handbags.

title: Who's Sneakier? Spy Toys Differ for Girls and Boys
description: The toy manufacturer Wild Planet takes make-believe spying seriously. So seriously, in fact, that the company has made it its business to nail down the differences between boys and girls when it comes to the subject.

title: Allstate Reports 69% Increase in Quarterly Profit
description: The Allstate Corporation, the auto and home insurer, said today that fourth-quarter profit rose 69 percent after it raised premiums and contained losses from homeowners filing claims for mold damage to houses.

title: F.D.A. Says Food Supply May Contain Altered Pigs
description: The Food and Drug Administration said yesterday that it was investigating the possibility that genetically engineered pigs might have been illegally sold for use as food.

title: Spacey Puts Down New Roots At Old Vic
description: British comedy writers who want to signal an audience that a character is a loser have only to call him Kevin.

title: Confidential Advisory Warns Officials of Rise in Possible Terror Threats
description: American authorities have spotted a recent upsurge in possible terrorist threats and are warning law enforcement officials to be alert to the prospect of attacks by Al Qaeda in the United States and abroad as early as within several weeks, officials said today.

title: Europe Cites Interference By 3 States
description: The European Commission began legal proceedings today against three of its members -- Italy, the Netherlands and Denmark -- in an effort to force those countries to give up a common technique they use to block foreign ownership of formerly state-owned companies.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Delay In Price Rules Is Urged
description: Connecticut has asked federal regulators to delay new federal pricing rules for electrical transmission because they may raise utility prices in Connecticut. In a Feb. 3 letter to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, Attorney General Richard Blumenthal said that under the new rules, which will take effect March 1, Connecticut utility companies can be charged a new unspecified fee based on the difficulty of carrying power to them. Under the current rule, such an increase would be spread over companies throughout New England. Mr. Blumenthal said the rule change penalizes Connecticut businesses and consumers for problems in the utilities' infrastrasture. A spokeswoman for the commission said it was reviewing Mr. Blumenthal's request. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHINE, LILLIE
description: SHINE-Lillie. On February 4, 2003. Beloved daughter of the late Ida and Joseph Shine, loving sister of Jack Shine, Edith Picker and the late Saul Shine and Esther Shine. For more information contact Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Blvd, Flushing, New York.

title: In Tiny Spaces, Expansive Living
description: THE decorator Alejandro Aguilar is a fool for shoes -- hand-stitched loafers, Prada slip-ons, Gucci boots -- but there are never more than six pairs in his closet. As soon as he gets a new pair, an old pair must go. Six is the exact number that can fit in his specially designed closet.

title: Getting Game Boy to Play Their Tune
description: WHEN Ronald L. Jones, an engineer and inventor, traveled from his home in Los Angeles to the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas three years ago to seek backers for his product ideas, he was down to his last $800, and determined to make the trip fruitful.

title: Excerpts From NASA News Conference on the Loss of the Shuttle Columbia
description: Following are excerpts from a news conference yesterday in Houston by Ron D. Dittemore, the manager of NASA's space shuttle program, as recorded by Federal Document Clearing House Inc. A full transcript is online at nytimes.com/columbia.

title: Guarding the Back Door To Your XP Computer
description: Q. I have the Norton AntiVirus program installed on my Windows XP machine, and I keep it updated with the latest security patches. My dial-up connection used to hang up when it was inactive, but recently I have noticed that it will stay on for hours if I do not manually disconnect. I worry that my machine is being monitored or used maliciously. My antivirus program has not found anything amiss, but should I be concerned?

title: Mobilizing a Theater of Protest. Again.; Artists Try to Recapture Their Role as Catalysts for Debate and Dissent
description: When Sam Hamill, a poet and founder of Copper Canyon Press in Port Townsend, Wash., was invited to a poetry symposium by Laura Bush last month, his response was to send e-mail messages to 50 friends and colleagues asking them for antiwar poems to send to Mrs. Bush. In four days he received 1,500 responses.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Less Red Tape
description: A Russian research organization, in an extensive survey of hundreds of small businesses, announced today that legislation enacted in 2001 and 2002 has begun to reduce Russia's red tape. In a study conducted with the World Bank, the Moscow-based Center for Economic and Financial Research interviewed 2,000 companies in 20 regions and found that new laws limiting government inspections of businesses and the number of licenses a business must obtain have begun to reduce corporate paperwork. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONNELL, JOHN R.
description: McDONNELL-John R., 86. Of Allenhurst, New Jersey died on February 3. Born in NYC. He was a Wall St. Account Exec. for 54 years. Survived by wife Dorothy, children: John, Peter, Jane Steele, Paul & Richard, 13 grandchildren. Visitation will be from 7-9 Thursday and 2-4 & 7-9 Friday at John E. Day Funeral Home, 85 Riverside Ave., Red Bank, NJ. Funeral Mass will be held at 9 AM Saturday at St. Mary's Church, Deal, NJ. Interment in Gate of Heaven, Hawthorne, New York.

title: Prison Company Faces Fine On Gaps in Lobbying Records
description: New York's lobbying commission has determined from an initial review of a private prison company's records that company officials failed to disclose meals and other items used to cultivate ties to state lawmakers, officials said yesterday. As a result, the company is expected to face a sizable fine.

title: Drug Maker In Ireland Posts Heavy Losses
description: The Elan Corporation, the Irish drug maker, raised hopes for its prospects last week when it raised $1.5 billion to pay off debts a year ahead of schedule. Today, the full scale of the challenges the company faces became clear when Elan reported a net loss of $639 million in the fourth quarter of 2002 and a loss of $2.4 billion for the year.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ACKERMAN, KENNETH
description: ACKERMAN-Kenneth. 60 years ago you lighted my life, darkened now by your absence. Russ

title: France, Backed by Germany, Calls for Stronger Inspections, but the U.S. Is Unmoved
description: In a move that seemed intended to blunt the United States' drive toward war to disarm the Iraqi government, France, with the support of Germany, proposed today to strengthen United Nations weapons inspections.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINMAN, VIRGINIA (GINNY)
description: KLEINMAN-Virginia (Ginny) on February 5, 2002 of Roslyn, NY. Having never given up, Ginny lost her brief yet valiant battle against the effects of liver cancer. Always giving of herself selflessly towards others, she had a way about her that made everyone she came in contact with happy to be with her. Her smile and personality would light up any room she was in. Her inner strength and determination throughout her ordeal was to be admired. She loved people, especially her boys, Jared and Evan, her family and friends. We are all grateful for the time we were able to have with this wonderful person, we just wanted a little bit more. All who knew Ginny should only have wonderful memories of a person whose natural beauty was matched by her inner goodness. Loving wife of Richard. Cherished mother of Jared and Evan. Daughter of Caesar and Carolyn Bonis. Sister to Cathy Pearson, Margie Anderson, Carolyn Levitan and Chuck Bonis. Also survived by 7 nieces and nephews. Funeral Mass Thursday 1:00 PM at St. Marys RC Church Manhasset. Interment private. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Crohn's and Colitis Foundation of America, Inc, 585 Stewart Ave, Suite 414, Garden City, NY 11530, or Tourette Syndrome Association, Inc., 42-40 Bell Blvd, Bayside, NY 11361.

title: Treasury to Add Auctions To Meet U.S. Budget Needs
description: The Treasury Department said yesterday that it was reviving the three-year note, increasing quarterly sales of five-year notes and considering shifting to monthly five-year note auctions to cover rising budget deficits, which are projected to reach record levels this year and next year.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Officers Blamed In Dog Attack
description: Witnesses in a racially charged trial testified that two white police officers deliberately ordered their dogs to attack three black illegal aliens from Mozambique in 1998 as part of a dog-training exercise. The attack, which was videotaped, shocked the nation when it was broadcast on national television three years ago. Four police officers have pleaded guilty in the case and are serving prison sentences. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: CROATIA: GENERAL TOO SICK FOR TRIAL Doctors appointed by the United Nations war crimes tribunal ruled that a Croatian general charged with authorizing atrocities against Serbian civilians is too sick to stand trial. Gen. Janko Bobetko, 84, denies the charges against him and vows he will never surrender. The indictment against him remains in place and tribunal prosecutors plan to monitor his health unless judges in The Hague decide to drop the case.    Daniel Simpson (NYT)

title: World Court Tells U.S. to Delay Executing 3
description: The International Court of Justice at The Hague ordered the United States today to postpone the executions of three Mexicans until the court has had a chance to rule on a complaint filed by Mexico.

title: Ex-Nets Star Settles Lawsuit With Dead Driver's Siblings
description: Jayson Williams, the former basketball star, has settled a civil lawsuit brought against him by the brother and sister of the limousine driver he is accused of fatally shooting a year ago.

title: For Seminoles' Bowden, Signing Day Is a Success
description: Florida State turned what had been a disappointing recruiting year into a huge success yesterday when two highly coveted high school players formally agreed to play for the Seminoles.

title: Powell Gets Good Reviews, But Few Stands Are Changed
description: Political leaders from both parties said today that they were impressed with the breadth of the evidence against Iraq Secretary of State Colin L. Powell presented, but few budged significantly from positions they had already taken.

title: Cendant Reports a Profit in 4th Quarter
description: Cendant, the provider of travel and real estate services, said yesterday that it had a profit in the fourth quarter, helped by acquisitions of residential brokerage operations and the Budget Group car rental company.

title: U.S. Charges 2 in Shuttle Debris Theft, Citing Need to 'Make an Example'
description: Federal agents arrested two people in East Texas today and accused them of stealing debris from the space shuttle Columbia.

title: Lawmaker Says Interning U.S. Japanese Was Proper
description: The chairman of a House subcommittee on domestic security said today that it had been appropriate to intern Japanese-Americans during World War II, a step he said had been taken mainly for their own safety, to protect them from a hostile citizenry.

title: Olympic Committee Ponders What's Next . . . Or Who's Next?
description: Marty Mankamyer's resignation as the president of the United States Olympic Committee on Tuesday night raised this immediate question: Can Lloyd Ward continue to survive as the organization's chief executive?

title: African Women Gather to Denounce Genital Cutting
description: Some of the activists who gathered here in the Ethiopian capital today to combat the traditional practice of genital cutting had had the procedure performed on them when they were girls. Others, before learning of the serious health risks, had allowed their daughters to undergo the painful rite, which is steeped in tradition and myth.

title: Bank of England Cuts Key Interest Rate in Surprise Move
description: International Herald Tribune

title: Jerry Mayer, Actor In One-Man Shows
description: Jerry Mayer, who won an Obie award for one of his own long-running one-man shows, was found dead in his apartment in Manhattan on Feb. 3. He was believed to be about 60.

title: Kiwis Give Their Side Of Messy Breakup
description: The beginning of the America's Cup between Team New Zealand and the Swiss team Alinghi is nine days away, but the biggest sailing story in New Zealand is not about the coming Cup. It is about the last one.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: INDIA: ARMY SAYS IT DOWNED PAKISTANI ROBOT Army officials said India had shot down a robot Pakistani spy plane flying over Indian airspace in Kashmir. They said wreckage from the plane fell 400 yards inside the part of the region controlled by India. There was no immediate response from Pakistan. Last week, Pakistan said it had shot down an unpiloted Indian spy plane, an assertion India denied. Pakistan says it provides moral and political support to Kashmiris fighting for independence; India accuses Pakistan of sponsoring terrorism in the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir.

title: Sports of The Times; Colts Finding Motivation In New Way
description: MY new favorite National Football League team is the Indianapolis Colts. You've got to admire a team whose kicker has the guts to call the quarterback wimpy, if for no other reason than this: When the local newspaper conducted an informal poll, Indianapolis fans supported the kicker -- Mike (Don't Call Me An Idiot) Vanderjagt -- by a 2-to-1 margin.

title: Wi-Fi as Savior? France's Farm Dwellers Hope So
description: NEAR Sill-le-Guillaume, a rural patch of western France, Ginette Sybille moves some 8,000 fowls, 150 swine and 120 head of cattle on and off her 395-acre farm each year. She conducts most of her business with slaughterhouses in the region, but each time an animal changes hands, Mrs. Sybille has to register the transaction online with the government.''We are managing with our dial-up Internet connection,'' she said, ''but a faster one would make a big difference.''

title: AVENTIS LOWERS ITS TARGETS FOR SALES AND EARNINGS
description: France's largest drug maker, Aventis, lowered sales and profit targets for 2003 and 2004 as a result of slower sales growth of its top seller, the Allegra allergy pill, and the delay of a new antibiotic in the United States. Sales will increase 7 percent to 9 percent this year after rising 12 percent last year, Aventis's chief financial officer, Patrick Langlois, said. The company expects earnings per share to rise 14 percent to 18 percent, less than the previous forecast of as much as 30 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIEDLER, LESLIE
description: FIEDLER-Leslie. The members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters note with sorrow the death of their esteemed colleague whose passing will be mourned by the world of literature.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Officer Blames Soldier In Killing
description: An Indonesian Army officer said a soldier had killed the popular leader of a nonviolent campaign for an independent Irian Jaya, also known as Papua. Theys Eluay, 64, was killed in November 2001 after a party with officers from an elite army unit. Under pressure from the United States and Australia, the Indonesian government conducted an investigation and a court-martial of seven officers and soldiers began last month. Lt. Col Hartomo, a defendant, told the court that one of his soldiers had strangled Mr. Eluay. Raymond Bonner (NYT)

title: New Method Aids Evaluation of Alzheimer's Drugs
description: Scientists have developed a technique that allows them to watch the destruction by Alzheimer's disease travel through the brains of living patients ''like a flow of lava,'' as one researcher put it.

title: Full Penalty Box Is Bad for the Rangers
description: It only seemed as if someone were in the Rangers' penalty box all game last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Young, Jobless, Hopeless
description: You see them in many parts of the city, hanging out on frigid street corners, skylarking at the malls or bowling alleys, hustling for money wherever they can, drifting in some cases into the devastating clutches of drug-selling, gang membership, prostitution and worse.

title: Mr. Love Finds an Island, If Not Entirely to Himself
description: A WINDBLOWN island 80 minutes by ferry from Maine's rocky coast might not be everyone's idea of paradise in frigid winter. But the artist Robert Indiana, who moved here from Manhattan 25 years ago, prefers his chilly exile on Main Street.

title: Tax Shelter Is Worrying Sprint's Chief
description: The chief executive of the Sprint Corporation, William T. Esrey, said last night that he could lose his entire fortune if the Internal Revenue Service decided that a tax shelter that he and the company's No. 2 executive bought from the company's auditors was improper.

title: Trading Places; In an $800 Palm-Based Model, The Aroma of Power and Luxury
description: EVEN as the prices and sizes of Pocket PC's have begun dipping to Palm-esque levels, Palm organizers have been creeping up to Pocket PC-ish features and power. A case in point is Sony's new Cli PEG-NZ90, a weighty, jet black high-tech machine that would look right at home in Darth Vader's home office.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day yesterday about the Bush administration's plan to eliminate taxes on dividends -- and a change that would remove the penalty for investors who borrow to buy stock -- misstated the surname of the deputy assistant treasury secretary for tax policy, who confirmed the change. He is Greg Jenner, not Jensen.

title: Judge Orders Rates Doubled For Lawyers for the Poor
description: A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that the system of compensating private lawyers assigned to represent the poor in New York City courts is unconstitutional, and he ordered that the city and the state more than double the hourly rate the lawyers are paid.

title: Vodafone Is Wanting to Shed Part of Its Japanese Venture
description: The Vodafone Group, the British mobile phone giant, confirmed today what many had long suspected: It wants to sell its fixed-line telephone business in Japan. But with cellular phones, Internet telephony and broadband connections fast replacing plain old local phone service, the question is, Who will want to buy the business?

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Union Drive At Uniform Maker
description: A textile workers' union said yesterday that it hoped to unionize the Cintas Corporation, the leading maker of uniforms for hotels, airlines and other businesses. The Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees said the drive was one of its largest, an effort to organize 17,000 Cintas workers. At a City Hall news conference, Bruce Raynor, the union's president, said the union hoped to organize 300 Cintas sites in the United States and Canada. The union filed charges yesterday accusing Cintas, based in Cincinnati, of violating federal labor laws at 36 plants in New York, Newark, Hartford and 14 other cities. Cintas officials said they comply with the law. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLADSTON, MORTON, M.D.
description: GLADSTON-Morton, M.D. The Department of Medicine of New York University School of Medicine is saddened by the passing of our longtime colleague, Dr. Morton Gladston. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his wife Irene and family. Martin J. Blaser, MD Chairman

title: Millar May Not Have to Play in Japan
description: Kevin Millar was on the verge yesterday of ending his status as a player without a country and becoming a player free to sign with anyone, most likely the Boston Red Sox.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRONENGOLD, MARJORIE
description: KRONENGOLD - Marjorie. On February 4, 2003. Beloved wife of Toby. Loving daughter of Harold and the late Hilda Franks. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: New Consumer Protection Chief
description: Teresa A. Santiago was sworn in yesterday as the new head of the state's Consumer Protection Board. She replaces May M. Chao, who resigned. Ms. Santiago, 42, most recently led the Institute for the Puerto Rican/Hispanic Elderly, a nonprofit advocacy organization, and also headed Amigos de Pataki, a campaign group in the November election. Gov. George E. Pataki swore in Ms. Santiago at her alma mater, St. Pius V High School in the South Bronx. The board conducts investigations, reviews consumer complaints and recommends comsumer protection legislation.

description: EURO DROPS. The euro fell after traders bought dollars on speculation that the Security Council would help the United States gain support for an attack on Iraq. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0803, from $1.0877 on Tuesday.

Under her stewardship, the Division developed into a major fundraising arm of the medical school and one of the premier women's philanthropic organizations in the nation. To her sister, Bernice Levine, and all the members of her family, we offer our heartfelt sympathy. Dr. Dominick P. Purpura The Marilyn and Stanley M. title: Can I Borrow Your Lipstick? Sure, Check Out the First Song

Continuing the trend toward ever smaller digital products, Philips Electronics is introducing Key Rings, a range of audio and photo products the size and shape of a lipstick. Available in black or white cases (with more colors to come), the units connect directly to a computer's U.S.B. port for transferring songs from the PC to an audio Key Ring or exporting pictures from a photo Key Ring to the PC for printing or e-mailing.

description: Students and teachers at many public schools here staged a 15-minute walkout today in support of the district's embattled superintendent, who has been recommended for replacement by a local advisory board.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Croatia: General Too Sick For Trial
description: Doctors appointed by the United Nations war crimes tribunal ruled that a Croatian general charged with authorizing atrocities against Serbian civilians is too sick to stand trial. Gen. Janko Bobetko, 84, denies the charges against him and vows he will never surrender. The indictment against him remains in place and tribunal prosecutors plan to monitor his health unless judges in The Hague decide to drop the case. Daniel Simpson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: March Organizers Sue City
description: A group opposed to United States policy in Iraq sued the city and the Police Department in federal court yesterday after organizers were denied city permits to march past the United Nations on Feb. 15, an event expected to attract at least 50,000 marchers. The march organizers, United for Peace and Justice, said in court papers that the denial infringed on the group's free-speech rights and that the city routinely issued permits for marches of comparable size, like the annual St. Patrick's Day parade. The city contends that the planned march would strain police manpower and might jeopardize public safety. Judge Barbara S. Jones of United States District Court scheduled a hearing on the suit tomorrow. Susan Saulny (NYT)

description: Germany's fourth-largest lender, Commerzbank, said today that it lost 298 million euros ($322 million) in 2002, one of the worst losses in its 130-year history. The bank's results reflected $1.4 billion in provisions it took to offset bad loans. Commerzbank plans to cut 425 jobs in its investment banking division, having already eliminated 4,300 jobs. The chairman, Klaus-Peter Mller, predicted the bank would return to a profit this year. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Americas

Mr. González fled Mexico 10 years ago, pursued by accusations of corruption and torture. He gave American and Mexican officials information about corruption at the highest levels of the government of Carlos Salinas de Gortari, president of Mexico from 1988 to 1994, including evidence against Mr. Salinas's brother Raúl, now in prison.    Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: JOBLESS RATE RISES Unemployment in Germany rose to 11 percent last month, up from 10.1 percent in December and its highest level in five years. The number of jobless people rose nearly 400,000, to 4.62 million, an unexpectedly large increase, even taking into account the seasonal loss of outdoor jobs. The statistics suggest that German companies remain pessimistic about an economic rebound. Mark Landler (NYT)

Analysts said the loss was considerably higher than anticipated, attributing their incorrect forecasts to year-end bonus payments of 150 billion won and a loss of 130 billion won on a liquid crystal display unit that the company owns with Royal Philips Electronics of the Netherlands. title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Jersey City: Three Killed In Fire
description: Three people were killed in a house fire last night, the authorities said. The Jersey City Fire Department released no details about the victims, but neighbors said that a mother and her son and daughter had been killed. The three-alarm fire, which broke out about 10 p.m. in a six-unit apartment house on Wilkinson Street also injured four other people, said Firefighter Anthony Johnson, a spokesman. The police took one resident of the building into custody, but an officer at the scene would not say why. Nicole Parker, 20, who used to live on the third floor, said the fire escape had often been locked. About 80 firefighters fought the fire, which was shooting 20 feet in the air from the top floors, Firefighter Johnson said. Rescuers could not make it past the second floor, and the bodies were later found on the third floor, he said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: S.E.C. Choice Says He's No Harvey Pitt
description: William H. Donaldson, President Bush's latest choice to head the Securities and Exchange Commission, won broad bipartisan support today at a confirmation hearing after repeatedly assuring lawmakers that he would be significantly different from his predecessor.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Speak Russian and Don't Swear
description: The lower house of Parliament approved a much-debated language law that enshrines Russian as the national language and prohibits the use of foreign words where Russian alternatives exist. The government has sought to crack down on provinces that have sought to ban the Cyrillic alphabet or adopt other languages as alternatives to Russian. The law also prohibits the use of obscenities, a prohibition unlikely to be rigidly observed in Russia, where blue outbursts on the Parliament floor are not uncommon. There are no penalties for violating the new code. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: The Case Against Iraq
description: Secretary of State Colin Powell presented the United Nations and a global television audience yesterday with the most powerful case to date that Saddam Hussein stands in defiance of Security Council resolutions and has no intention of revealing or surrendering whatever unconventional weapons he may have. In doing so, with the help of spy satellite photos and communications intercepts, Mr. Powell placed squarely before the Security Council the fateful question of how it should respond. As American military forces in the region build toward full strength, President Bush should continue to let diplomacy work. The manner in which the United States wields its great power, and the regard it gives to the views of other nations, are vital matters as a showdown with Iraq draws near. The character of America is at issue as much as its military might.

title: Vive l'Histoire
description: The French-American alliance -- whose birth was celebrated 225 years ago this month, with Champagne on one side of the Atlantic and later with rum on the other -- has always been an uneasy one. ''I cannot deny that the Americans are somewhat difficult to handle, especially for a Frenchman,'' was the quiet verdict of one of our best friends, the Marquis de Lafayette. As late as the close of the Revolution, an American officer warned his superior: ''The people do not like Frenchmen; every person they can't understand they take for a Frenchman.'' And that was during the honeymoon period. No one accused the French then of getting the vapors or of being weak-kneed, as the United States has done now during the Security Council debates over Iraq. But the colonists did believe Voltaire's nation to be one of frivolous, immoral, consumptive pygmy barbers.

description: NORTH CAROLINA: 50-50 (OR 60-60) FOR SPEAKER The Statehouse will have its first co-speakers after lawmakers in the evenly divided chamber chose a Democrat and a Republican to lead it. The vote followed a week in which the House, which has 60 Republicans and 60 Democrats, was unable to elect a speaker. The House voted, 89 to 31, for the power sharing by James B. Synthes, based in Oberdorf, Switzerland, said the acquisition price included a $175 million payment at closing and an additional $175 million once regulators in the United States approved Spine Solutions' cervical and lumbar disc products. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Airline Grounded
description: France's secondlargest airline, Air Lib, lost its operating license and was forced to ground all its planes after a Dutch investment company, IMCA, declined to invest in the airline. Gilles de Robien, the transport minister, said that the French government would try to find jobs for the carrier's 3,200 employees, but left the company's fate in the hands of the commercial court, which could place the airline in liquidation or receivership. The owner of Air Lib, Jean-Charles Corbet, above, said bankruptcy was not automatic. He also said that IMCA might yet invest in the company.

''And nice bracelet,'' she replied. It took only a minute for us to discover that we shared the same couturier, the Salvation Army Thrift Shop on Fourth Avenue at 12th Street in the East Village.

description: FARKAS-Pearl. Widow of Meyer Farkas. Dear sister of Ruth Shenkman. Beloved mother of Robert (Diana) Farkas and Howard (Geneva) Farkas. Adored grandmother of Michael (Marcy) Farkas and Jane (Ken) Guarino, Jonathan and Zachary Farkas. Proud great-grandmother of Gabriel and Harold Guarino. Graveside services, Today, 11 AM Old Montefiore Cemetery, St. Albans, NY.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  The Bush administration raised the country's alert status from "elevated risk" to "high risk" today, saying that there was now an increased risk of terrorist attacks and that apartment buildings, hotels and other places where security is relatively light may be targets.

title: Presents for the Viewer, Not All of Them Kindly

What's missing is focus, the sharpness of vision that produces a think-piece show that actually prompts some thinking.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Lagging Phone Sales
description: NTT DoCoMo said it might not reach its full-year sales target for its high-speed third-generation phones. The cellular phone company expected to sign up 320,000 customers by the end of March this year, but the president, Keiji Tachikawa, said delays in the rollout of new handsets might have kept consumers away. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Mayor Is More Modest on Charter Reform
description: When he seeks to reform the City Charter this year, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will not try to change the way a successor is chosen if a mayor becomes unable to serve, city officials said yesterday. Instead, he will contemplate structural issues in government like the merger of city agencies and changes in the way the city purchases goods.

description: Several space shuttle flights, including the Columbia's returns to earth in 1989 and 1995, have experienced the same kind of higher-than-normal heating on one side, and similar abnormal drag on one wing, that NASA says the Columbia went through just before its disintegration on Saturday morning.

It was President Jean-Bertrand Aristide who said: ''Haiti is not guilty of these charges. We are a poor country and we feel victimized by these actions.'' It was not David Lee, the chief of the special mission of the Organization of American States to Haiti.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH AMERICAN NATIONS PURSUE CLOSER TIES Concluding a meeting in Uruguay at which they agreed to negotiate as a bloc in trade talks with the United States, the foreign ministers of Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay called for the creation of a new regional parliament. The move comes after the four countries agreed in December to begin phasing out immigration and residency restrictions within the group and considering a common passport.    Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Hearing On Building-Code Reform
description: The city plans a public forum next Friday on how to reform its building code. Last year, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said the city's building code was ''often an impediment to new construction and drives up the cost of building.'' He ordered a review of whether New York should adopt a model building code, looking at the International Building Code and the National Fire Protection Association 5000 Building Construction and Safety Code. The Buildings Department has scheduled the forum for 9 a.m., in the former United States Custom House on Bowling Green in Lower Manhattan. Those wishing to comment must apply by 5 p.m. Monday, either by e-mail at codecommission@buildings.nyc.gov or by fax to (212) 566-3813. David W. Dunlap (NYT)

title: Bryant Takes Star Turn On the Garden Stage
description: Late in the first half, the Lakers were already one foot into the relaxation of the All-Star Game break. Kobe Bryant was trying out his assortment of playground shots even though the lead was just barely tipping double figures, and then Bryant tossed a soft pass into the post for Shaquille O'Neal and backed away, leaving O'Neal alone with an anxious Michael Doleac.

title: How Powell's Evidence Compares to Findings From Prior Intelligence
description: The main purpose of the presentation that Secretary of State Colin L. Powell made to the United Nations Security Council was to demonstrate that Iraq was not complying with United Nations demands that it abandon its programs to develop weapons of mass destruction.

title: PepsiCo's Quarterly Profit Increases 21%
description: PepsiCo posted a 21 percent increase in its fourth-quarter earnings yesterday and attributed its growth to continued savings from the acquisition of Quaker Oats and strong sales at its Frito-Lay division.

description: BANK OF AMERICA, Charlotte, N.C., said it had acquired Framework Inc., Tarrytown, N.Y., and will use its technology to speed the processing of home mortgages.

description: With its core local phone business in decline, SBC Communications has entered serious negotiations to acquire General Motors' DirecTV satellite-television operation in a deal that could be worth more than $10 billion, people close to the talks said today.

title: Dreaming Up a Riddle for a Know-It-All
description: Evangeline Dandridge (Gabrielle Union), the formidable title character of Gary Hardwick's romantic comedy ''Deliver Us From Eva,'' is a self-righteous, sharp-tongued know-it-all who works as a health inspector in Los Angeles. Eva, as she is called, relishes the opportunity to ambush a restaurant and reduce its manager to jelly by smugly ticking off health-code violations on her checklist.

title: Knick Rally Can't Erase Lakers' Reel of Highlights
description: Kobe Bryant and Shaquille O'Neal had made a mockery of the Knicks' 7-3 record over their previous 10 games, taking over Madison Square Garden last night with a flurry of spectacular dunks that had supposed Knicks fans cheering wildly for the Lakers. Bryant had 40 points, O'Neal had 28, Los Angeles was ahead by 30 points, and the fourth quarter had yet to begin.

description: Devils center Sergei Brylin had surgery yesterday on his broken right wrist and will be out for two to three months, the team said. He is expected to miss the rest of the regular season and the first month of the playoffs.

description: Somewhere beneath the murky surface of the Toledo Bend Reservoir may be the answers NASA needs.

About 60 minutes before landing, when the shuttle is upside down and traveling backward, it fires its rockets and flips forward again by turning nose over tail, not nose under tail.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Korean Air Earnings
description: Korean Air said it earned 111.9 billion won ($101 million) last year, reversing a loss of 590 billion won in 2001, as sales rose 10 percent, to 6.25 trillion won. The airline said results were helped by an increase in passenger traffic and cargo. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: NIGERIA: ARRESTS AND EVIDENCE IN DEADLY BLAST The police said that they had arrested eight people and that bomb disposal experts had found detonators in the rubble of buildings destroyed last weekend in an explosion in central Lagos that killed 35 people. They increasingly suspect that criminals or people involved in illegal stockpiling or manufacture of explosives were responsible for the explosion, although they have not ruled out an accident.    (Reuters)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAUSER, HARRY R.
description: HAUSER-Harry R. Of Newton, MA and Wolfeboro, NH, died at home in Wolfeboro on February 6, 2003. Beloved husband of Deborah. Cherished father of Mark, Joshua, Bradford and Matthew and their wives. Devoted grandfather of ten grandchildren. Dear brother of Richard Hauser and brother-in-law of Brian Marlowe. Services in Boston, MA. Remembrances to the North Bennet Street School, 39 N. Bennet St., Boston, MA. 02113; Hospice of Southern Carroll County, PO Box 1620, Wolfeboro, N.H. 02894 or to the Thoracic Oncology Research Fund, Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, 330 Brookline Ave., Boston, MA. 02115.

description: Some wealthy Americans who paid millions in fees to two of the Big Four accounting firms to set up tax shelters are suing the firms after the Internal Revenue Service denied the tax savings that they had been promised.

description: Freeport-McMoRan Copper and Gold sold $500 million in convertible bonds yesterday, and its stock fell $1.32, or 7.3 percent, to $16.84 a share.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Bridgeport: Ex-Mayor Faces New Abuse Charges
description: The former mayor of Waterbury, already facing 14 federal counts involving child sex abuse, was accused of four more counts. The former mayor, Philip A. Giordano, pleaded not guilty yesterday to the new counts in United States District Court; he had pleaded not guilty previously to the other counts. Few details were immediately available about the new charges, but Mr. Giordano is on trial relating to accusations that he had sex with two girls, then aged 9 and 11. The new charges relate to his using a cellphone, which helped establish federal jurisdiction, while arranging to have sex. Jury selection begins March 5 and the trial is scheduled for March 12.

title: Newark Boy's Death Reveals Failed Promise to Fix System
description: If ever there was a moment for New Jersey to have tackled the problems of its long-troubled child welfare agency, February 1998 seemed to be it.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Opinion On Golden Shares
description: The chief adviser to the European Union's highest court returned a split recommendation in lawsuits against Britain and Spain regarding government control of privately held companies. The adviser, Dmaso Ruiz-Jarabo Colomer, the advocate general of the European Court of Justice, said the system used in Spain was acceptable but the system used in Britain was not. Mr. Colomer's opinion will be considered when the court makes a final ruling later this year. Complaints against the so-called golden share provisions in Britain and Spain were made in a lawsuit filed by the European Commission. The commission filed new complaints against Italy, the Netherlands and Denmark on Wednesday as part of its attempt to create a level playing field for investors straddling the borders of the European Union's member countries. Paul Meller (NYT)

description: A year ago, at the Salt Lake City Winter Olympics, the United States Alpine Ski Team readied a challenge -- an ambush on their own turf -- for the mighty Austrians. In the end, the Americans not only failed to sneak up on the Austrians, who doubted their rival's depth of talent all along, but the Americans were outclassed.

description: Gov. James E. McGreevey took his new $23.7 billion austerity budget on the road today, listening to the concerns of hand-picked citizens and deflecting complaints by saying that dire economic times left no room for generosity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HONIG, ROSALIND (PENNY)
description: HONIG-Rosalind (Penny). In her 92 year peacefully. Beloved mother of Sheila Levin and Elliot Honig. Grandmother of Alison, Ethan and Eric (Anne) Woods. Great grandmother of Samantha, Mackie, Josie and Olivia Woods. Funeral will be on Sunday. You will be missed.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Tech Data Says 2004 Earnings May Drop 25%
description: The Tech Data Corporation, the world's second-largest computer distributor, said yesterday that its fiscal 2004 earnings could decline as much as 25 percent from the previous year because of competition and lagging demand. The forecast excludes the effects of a proposed acquisition. The company's shares fell as much as 16 percent. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had expected earnings to rise to $2.50 a share in fiscal 2004. They had forecast profit of $2.33 for fiscal 2003, which ended Jan. 31. The company said fourth-quarter sales were at or above the high end of its forecast of $3.80 billion to $3.95 billion. Analysts had expected sales of $3.87 billion, First Call said.

title: Jesse Ventura Reaches Deal for Talk Show at MSNBC
description: Cable news in the new millennium has often been described as an arena where brass-knuckle politics are presented with the showmanship of professional wrestling.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Garden City: Sentence In Fatal Accident
description: Robert Mikols, whose car struck and killed the wife of Angel Cordero Jr., the jockey, in 2001, was sentenced yesterday in Nassau County Court to six months in jail for leaving the scene of the accident. The victim, Marjorie Clayton Cordero, was herself a jockey and a trainer. She was walking in Greenvale near her home when she was struck. Later, the driver, Mr. Mikols, surrendered to the police and pleaded guilty to leaving the scene. Mr. Cordero, who retired in 1992 after more than 7,000 victories as a jockey, objected that Mr. Mikols, 63, of Glen Cove, had gotten away with murder. But prosecutors said they had insufficient evidence that he had caused the accident. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

description: President Bush's plan to vaccinate 500,000 health care workers against smallpox is getting off to an unexpectedly slow start as hundreds of hospitals and thousands of nurses across the country say that they will not participate.

description: With the wireless industry's largest carriers in an all-out struggle to increase subscribers and sales, it is no wonder BellSouth reacted so fiercely to the announcement last week by its vice chairman, Gary D. Forsee, that he planned to become chief executive of the rival Sprint Corporation.

title: A Man, Like His Music, of Quicksilver
description: Hector Berlioz, who gave musical Romanticism a distinctively French spin as well as his own distinctive twist, was born in La Cte St.-Andr, near Grenoble, in 1803. He studied music and began to compose in his teens. Expected to become a doctor, like his father, he abhorred gore and fled further into the embrace of music.

title: Commuter Tax Gets a Nay; Tolls, a Maybe
description: The majority leader of the State Senate, Joseph L. Bruno, said yesterday that he might allow New York City to raise the income tax on its residents and put tolls on the East River bridges, but that he remained opposed to taxing commuters who work in the city.

title: Beyond Stilettos, Bringing a Harsher Reality to Life
description: YOGA prowess aside, there is not much common ground between the glossy life experience enjoyed by Kristin Davis, instantly recognizable as Charlotte York, the ingenuous component of that gals-on-the-prowl quartet in HBO's ''Sex and the City,'' and the egregious life experience endured by Sunny Jacobs, the death-row inmate Ms. Davis now portrays nightly downtown in the play ''The Exonerated.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Cleric Denies Pro-Terrorist Comment
description: An influential Muslim cleric, who coordinated the state's Islamic prison program for two decades, denied yesterday that he had made comments to The Wall Street Journal in support of the Sept. 11 hijackers. A front-page article on Wednesday said that the cleric, Warith Deen Umar, 58, said in an interview that they should be honored as martyrs. It said he had written in an unpublished memoir that ''even Muslims who say they are against terrorism secretly admire and applaud'' them. Mr. Umar said yesterday that his comments were taken out of context, but a spokesman for The Journal told The Associated Press that the newspaper believed the article was accurate and fair. Mr. Umar retired in 2000 from his job recruiting and training Muslim prison chaplains, but continued to make prison visits. State officials barred him from making the visits after the article was published, and the remarks attributed to him were denounced by Gov. George E. Pataki and Senator Charles E. Schumer. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New Hiring Freeze At CUNY
description: A hiring freeze was announced yesterday at the City University of New York. The freeze, effective immediately, applies to all positions except teachers. Matthew Goldstein, the chancellor, said the freeze was the first of several steps the university was taking in response to Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed education cuts. The freeze comes just weeks after 530 CUNY employees said they were taking early retirement. Barbara Bowen, chairwoman of CUNY's faculty and staff union, said the university was already understaffed. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

description: Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, said today that he could not guarantee that President Bush's Medicare proposal would include prescription drug benefits for elderly people who remain in the traditional fee-for-service Medicare program.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Wireless Investment Plans
description: SK Telecom is sticking with its plan to pump 2.5 trillion won ($2.1 billion) into new equipment for wireless networks despite a big sell-off of its stock. Pyo Moon Soo, the chief executive, said the investment was needed for long-term growth even though the market value of the company's stock has fallen by 4 trillion won (3.5 billion), since the plan was announced two weeks ago. description: Conceived to show how the impact of Modernism on the art of African-Americans differed from its perception and use by white practitioners, ''Challenge of the Modern: African-American Artists 1925-1945'' at the Studio Museum in Harlem is one of the most ambitious shows this museum has produced.

title: Jonsson Cleared To Play
description: Defenseman Kenny Jonsson practiced with the Islanders yesterday and has been cleared to play, two days after he had what the team called a post-traumatic migraine headache.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: The Trailer Park Lounge and Grill is not so much a restaurant as a walk-in diorama: it has an actual trailer, a chubby turquoise and white 1959 Spartanette, with a fake coconut tree and some genuine lawn chairs. There's other stuff, too. A small metal frame on the wall encloses a can of Spam. In one corner there is a tribute to Tonya Harding, with newspaper clippings and photographs. Against the back wall, Elvis (fat, out-of-control Elvis, not young, sexy Elvis) holds court in another montage. Up front, a glass case celebrates great American celebrities of a certain kind, like Mary Kay, Tammy Faye Bakker and New York's own Amy Fisher.

title: Study Looks At New Ideas For Deficit
description: If libraries charged $1 to lend videotapes, the income would net the city $6 million a year. Charging households for garbage collection would bring in $171 million a year. Sending city workers home two hours early once a week would save $144 million.

description: Pundits and officials in Washington have dubbed Secretary of State Colin Powell's attempt to make a case for war against Iraq in the United Nations Security Council an ''Adlai Stevenson moment.''

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Industrial Output Rises
description: Brazilian industrial production recorded its seventh consecutive month of growth in December, helped by growing exports of steel, motor vehicles and food, but held back by a depressed local economy and continuing high interest rates. The national statistics institute said production was up 5.5 percent in December compared with a year earlier. Manufacturing output rose by an annualized 2.4 percent, compared with 1.5 percent in 2001, it said. Exports are being helped by the weak real, which lost 35 percent of its value against the dollar last year. But the highest interest rates in four years are depressing local consumer demand and forcing companies to cut spending.

title: Jets Promote Assistant Coach
description: The Jets named the senior offensive assistant, Jimmy Raye, an assistant head coach yesterday as they awaited plans on the future of another assistant head coach, Ted Cottrell, the defensive coordinator, who is a finalist for the head coaching job in San Francisco. Cottrell wrapped up an interview with the 49ers owner, John York, yesterday.

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: SENATOR HIRES COAL LOBBYIST Senator James M. Inhofe, the Oklahoma Republican who is chairman of the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee, has hired a mining lobbyist to oversee clean air legislation. The lobbyist, John Shanahan, is director of air quality issues at the National Mining Association. The president of the association, Jack Gerard, said he was pleased that a person who "intimately understands the industry" would be in a position "to educate the administration and Congress on the importance of coal in meeting our nation's future energy needs." Frank O'Donnell of the Clean Air Trust called the hiring "a sign that Inhofe's top priority is to protect the coal industry." Katharine Q. Seelye (NYT)

The firm earned 26.2 billion yen ($218 million), 151 percent more than in the period a year earlier.
