title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEAN, RUTH JOSEPHINE
description: DEAN-Ruth Josephine, 100. Of 165 West 66th Street, passed away on February 3. A native of Manhattan, she was born March 10, 1902. Internationally recognized as an Anglo-Norman scholar, Dean taught at Mount Holyoke College for 33 years. Since retirement in 1967, she has worked primarily in England and France on the publication of her 30 year's worth of study. In November 2001, Dean's book was awarded the Prix Honore Chavee by the Academie des Inscriptions et Belles-Lettres. She is survived by her sister, Blanche Dean DuBois of Bradenton, FL, nephew Dean DuBois, niece Judith Osterholt., and good friend Hya Bassier. Services will be held at 12:00 PM, Friday, February 7, at the First Presbyterian Church of Bradenton, Florida. For information Shannon Funeral Home. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be made in her name to Mount Holyoke College, South Hadley, MA 01075.

title: Mets Could Offer Cone A Chance to Pitch Again
description: David Cone attended John Franco's charity bowling tournament last week to support his friend and former teammate. But after Cone threw strikes with a bowling ball, Fred Wilpon, the owner of the Mets, asked the 40-year-old Cone if he was going to toss strikes with a baseball this year.

title: Endgame
description: The Iraq crisis has entered a period of intensely coercive diplomacy. It is unclear how long this phase will last -- our guess is a few weeks -- but the pressure is rapidly building on Saddam Hussein to give up his evasions or even his office. He may well do neither, inviting an American attack, but we are glad to see the Bush administration turning up the heat before it turns to war.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Cities Lose Jobs
description: Chicago led the nation in lost jobs last year, the Bureau of Labor Statistics says. The city lost 57,400 jobs, more than half of them in manufacturing, the bureau said. New York City was second, with 45,100, and Detroit was third, with 39,000. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: 'Insider' Witness At Milosevic Trial
description: The trial of Slobodan Milosevic heard evidence from a Serbian witness considered crucial by the prosecution, Gen. Aleksander Vasiljevic, the former chief of the counter-intelligence for the Yugoslav Army. Prosecutors hope to use his testimony to show the power Mr. Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president, had over the military during the war against Croatia between 1991 and 1995. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Muscovites' Love for a Classic Ends at the Park
description: Russians love their writers, not least because they were the keepers and chroniclers of history when times got tough. So when the Moscow city government unveiled plans for a monument to Mikhail Bulgakov, one of this country's most adored authors, it should have been a happy occasion.

title: Orbitz Moves Work To Young & Rubicam
description: The online travel service Orbitz in Chicago has awarded the creative part of its account, with billings estimated at $20 million, to the Chicago office of Young & Rubicam Advertising, part of the Young & Rubicam division of the WPP Group. The incumbent agency of less than a year, Fusion Idea Lab in Chicago, decided not to take part in a review.

title: Keeping Brother a Bachelor Becomes a Family Project
description: ''Zus and Zo,'' a Dutch comedy that opens today in the New York metropolitan area, weds 21st-century sexual mores to the rather Victorian narrative premise of a contested inheritance. Three sisters, Michelle (Sylvia Poorta), Wanda (Anneke Blok) and Sonja (Monic Hendrickx) -- a human rights activist, a conceptual artist and a magazine journalist, respectively -- are dismayed to learn that their brother, Nino (Jacob Derwig), who is gay, is about to marry a young woman named Bo (Halina Reijn). The marriage means that, in accordance with their late father's will, Nino will become the sole owner of the family's lovely tile-roofed waterfront hotel in Portugal.

title: Shortchanging the Environment
description: His State of the Union oratory to the contrary, President Bush wants to spend less money on the environment and clean energy programs than Congress gave him two years ago. In a way, that's not surprising. Domestic programs generally took their lumps in a budget weighted toward tax cuts and military spending. Even so, some of the president's proposals -- including a reduction in the Environmental Protection Agency budget from $8.1 billion in 2002 to $7.6 billion this year -- seemed downright peculiar, coming as they did on the heels of Mr. Bush's ringing pledges for a cleaner environment and reduced dependence on foreign oil.

title: Across Iraq's Border, A Land Haunted by War
description: The feeling of death lingers on this parched desert plain two miles from the Iraqi border, many years after the fighting ended.

title: Ever-So-Clever Games of Love That End as Expected
description: I'll say this much for ''How to Lose a Guy in 10 Days'': it is a little better than the two other recent high-concept romantic comedies based in New York, ''Two Weeks Notice'' and ''Maid in Manhattan.'' This is largely because the writing is a bit sharper and the two stars, Matthew McConaughey and Kate Hudson, have a prickly, hot-and-cold chemistry. The screenplay is by Kristen Buckley and Brian Regan, who wrote ''102 Dalmations,'' and Burr Steers, who wrote and directed ''Igby Goes Down.''

title: SBC Dismisses Goodby, Silverstein
description: SBC Communications said yesterday that it had dismissed Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco, which handled product advertising for the company since 1997. Though billings were not disclosed, SBC spent $52 million to advertise in major media during the first 11 months of 2002, according to CMR, part of Taylor Nelson Sofres.

description: President Bush and Colin Powell have adroitly shown that Iraq is hiding weapons, that Saddam Hussein is a lying scoundrel and that Iraqi officials should be less chatty on the telephone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOWNSEND, MARJORIE BRADLEY
description: TOWNSEND-Marjorie Bradley. January 31, 2003. In New York City at age 93. Daughter of the late Alden Shirley Bradley, and Martha Jane Paulette. Devoted wife of the late Barnard Townsend, beloved mother of Diana Townsend-Butterworth, mother-inlaw of Duke Butterworth and loving grandmother of James and Diana. Longtime member of the Colony Club and Junior League of NYC. Descendant of Anneke Jans and Peter Stuyvesant. Family matriarch, spirited, talented, loyal and gracious. Known for her beautiful smile, keen intuition and extraordinary devotion to her family. Always there to listen and care, Marjorie will live forever in our hearts. Viewing at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., February 9th, 3-5 PM. Service, Church of the Heavenly Rest, 90th St. at 5th Ave., February 10th, 11 AM. Donations may be made to Church of the Heavenly Rest.

description: Serbia's acting president, Natasa Micic, announced that voters would not have a chance to elect a successor for up to six months, drawing criticism from a popular candidate, Vojislav Kostunica. Ms. Micic is a close ally of the Serbian prime minister, Zoran Djindjic, who has had a long power struggle with Mr. Kostunica, the former president of the former Yugoslavia. Daniel Simpson (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Effort To Avert Clash With Rebels
description: An American couple whose guest ranch in the southern state of Chiapas has been blockaded by Zapatista rebels said the state government was weighing whether to buy them out to avert a violent confrontation. The Americans, Glen Wersch and Ellen Jones, have operated Rancho Esmeralda as an eco-tourism resort for eight years. Neighboring rebels have said the land rightfully belongs to local peasants, not foreigners, and have been trying to seize it since December. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Napkin Note Grounds Plane
description: An airliner aborted takeoff from Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport, and a passenger was questioned after handing a flight attendant a note on a napkin that read, ''Fast, neat average.'' The passenger, who was not identified, was on ATA Flight 295 to Chicago. He told investigators that he was a cadet at the Air Force Academy and that the pilot would have understood the message if had he been in the Air Force. The Web site of the Air Force Academy class of 1982, www.usafa.net/1982/, says, ''Cadets and graduates on commercial flights have been known to write on a napkin, 'fast-neat-average' then ask a flight attendant to give it to the cockpit crew for the proper response,'' which is ''friendly-good-good.'' The sequence was the standard response to a form about the quality of food and service at the academy in Colorado Springs.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: LAOS: 10 SHOT TO DEATH ON BUS At least 10 people, including 3 foreigners, were killed yesterday when gunmen attacked a bus in Laos, officials said. A group of about 20 men sprayed the bus with automatic weapons fire on the road to Vangviang, about 75 miles north of the capital, Vientiane, an official in Vangviang said. A senior government official said seven Laotians on the bus were killed, along with a Chinese person and two foreign cyclists, one male and one female.   (Reuters)

A charge of a hate crime could effectively double the penalty if the crime is based on sexual orientation. The amendment, approved 7 to 2, includes crimes based on sex, age or physical or mental disability. The law already covered race, color, religion and national origin. (AP)

Terra is eliminating 147 jobs, including 101 in its office in Waltham, Mass., a spokesman said. It also trimmed jobs in New York and San Francisco. This is the second time in five months that Terra has cut its American work force as it scales back its operations after spending $6.5 billion to buy Lycos in 2000.   (Bloomberg News)

description: Larry LeSueur, the CBS correspondent who reported from the rooftops of London during the blitz of World War II, went ashore in the first waves of the D-Day invasion and made the first radio broadcast to America telling of the Allied liberation of Paris, died on Wednesday at his home in Washington. He was 93.

description: Albert L. Hotchkin Jr., a wine merchant specializing in Burgundy whose Manhattan shop, restaurants and classes became meeting places for wine enthusiasts of all levels of expertise, died Tuesday at Bellevue Hospital in Manhattan. He was 59.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Judge Wants Sniper Experts Made Public
description: A judge sitting in the case of Lee Malvo, the 17-year-old charged in the sniper shootings in the Washington area, denied defense requests to hire expert witnesses in secret. Judge Jane M. Rousch of Fairfax County Circuit Court ruled that Mr. Malvo's lawyers had to present publicly a list of experts they would like to hire, a move that the defense contends would tip off prosecutors to its strategy. Because Mr. Malvo is indigent, his lawyers have to have a judge's permission to hire and pay experts. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Briefly Noted
description: 3 CHARGED IN MICHIGAN Three more men have been charged with racketeering in connection with a ring of cigarette smugglers accused of fund-raising for an Islamic militant group. Two Detroit-area brothers were convicted last year of smuggling cigarettes from North Carolina to Michigan, manipulating state tax differences to raise hundreds of thousands of dollars for the militant group Hezbollah. Eleven new indictments in that case were made public this week, including charges against Elias Akhdar, 30; Hassan Makki, 41; and Salim Awde, 45. All had listed residences in southeastern Michigan, and were of Lebanese descent. The United States Attorney's office for the Eastern District of Michigan said Mr. Akhdar and Mr. Makki have taken part in military exercises with Hezbollah. A judge ruled that Mr. Akhdar and Mr. Makki were to be detained until trial. Mr. Awde was awaiting extradition to Michigan from New York. David Enders (NYT)

title: 36 Hours | Lake Placid, N.Y.
description: IN any trip to Lake Placid, there will be a moment when you catch yourself thinking: Do you believe this little place was the host of two Olympic Games? Not because something so symbolic and global does not fit in a tiny upstate New York village of 3,000, but, more striking, because it will dawn on you that it is the perfect place. While the Olympics have become outsized, intimate Lake Placid retains ties to simpler times, be it 1932, when the Winter Games first came to visit, or 1980, a time remembered fondly by Americans for the Miracle-on-Ice United States hockey team. Still, a visit is less about the Olympics as they were than about life as it was. Lake Placid has the rhythm of a small town, albeit one with the sophistication to have played host to the world, and its pace is spiked by active people who embrace the mountain and lake setting that has attracted visitors for centuries. In the end, at least occasionally, you have to buy into the Olympic motto -- Swifter, Higher, Stronger -- and just go with it. Oh, and hold on for dear life. BILL PENNINGTON

description: The government moved today to put an end to its long battle with two elderly sisters, Western Shoshone Indians who for 30 years have defied federal complaints that they are illegally grazing their animals on public land.

It also ordered the 101st Airborne Division to the Persian Gulf, where more than 100,000 American troops are massed, a total that could double by the end of the month.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Police Union Dispute Leads To Court
description: A dispute within the police union led to state Supreme Court yesterday. Six police officers sought a court order to force the police union and its president to release the union's mailing list so they could use it to distribute campaign literature. The officers, who call themselves the True Rank and File, are hoping to replace the leadership of the union, the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association. They filed a complaint stating that the union's president, Patrick J. Lynch, was trying to weaken their campaign by refusing to immediately release the list. Michael Murray, a P.B.A. lawyer, said Mr. Lynch's decision was reasonable because the group's by-laws limit the release of names and addresses of police officers and because the P.B.A. does not recognize candidates for office until May. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: EDO, A MILITARY CONTRACTOR, IS BUYING A RIVAL
description: The EDO Corporation, a maker of military and aerospace electronics, said yesterday that it was acquiring Advanced Engineering and Research Associates for about $38 million. EDO's products include undersea sonar systems and equipment used to fire missiles from aircraft. Advanced Engineering, which is closely held and based in Alexandria, Va., provides consulting and computer services to government and commercial clients. It has contracts with the Defense Department and had revenue of about $50 million in 2002. Shares of EDO, which is based in New York, rose 22 cents, to $17.38.

title: Lost Weekend: F. Scott and Budd Go to Dartmouth
description: STEPPING into the Hanover Inn in Hanover, N.H., is like entering a Dartmouth-themed time capsule. The inn is directly across Wheelock Street from Dartmouth College's main lawn and its guest room floors are covered in ''Dartmouth green'' carpeting. An 1853 front page from The Dartmouth Advertiser and The Literary Gazette hangs behind the registration desk, and a plaque proudly salutes the class of 1945.

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: U.S. SETTLES ANTITRUST CASE AGAINST GEMSTAR The Justice Department said yesterday that it had settled antitrust charges against Gemstar-TV Guide International Inc. after the company agreed to pay a fine of $5.67 million. The department said it had reached a consent decree settling accusations that Gemstar, the publisher of TV Guide magazine and the maker of software to run onscreen TV program guides, had illegally coordinated operations with TV Guide before the companies merged in July 2000. Under federal antitrust laws, merger partners must continue to operate independently until their deal is consummated and cleared by federal regulators. The investigation began shortly after the Justice Department approved the $14 billion merger of Gemstar and TV Guide. Shares of Gemstar rose 10 cents, or 3.4 percent, to $3.04.  (Reuters)

title: Fiery Romantic, Burning Alone
description: TO say that the French composer Hector Berlioz was an artist ahead of his time is hackneyed. In fact, he was very much a man of his time: in some ways the quintessential Romantic, scaling new heights of fancy, passion and grandeur.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Loss At Cruise Line
description: P&O Princess Cruises reported a loss for the fourth quarter, mainly a result of fees incurred during a battle for control of the company last year. P&O Princess eventually agreed to be acquired by the Carnival Corporation, breaking off an earlier agreement to merge with Royal Caribbean Cruises. P&O Princess paid Royal Caribbean $62.5 million in penalties for ending their agreement and it spent a further $54.5 million in general advisory fees. As a result, the company lost $85.8 million in the fourth quarter, in contrast to a profit of $16.3 million a year earlier. P&O Princess said bookings in North America, its biggest market, had increased, but were not at the level normally seen this time of year.

title: War-Weary Immigrants Facing Another War

''Kedma,'' the newest film by this acerbic social critic, is as inflammatory in its way as ''Kadosh,'' his harsh portrayal of an ultra-Orthdox sect in Jerusalem and its treatment of women. But ''Kedma,'' which opens today in Manhattan, has larger issues on its mind than marital customs. In imagining the events of early May 1948, when unauthorized groups of Jewish settlers were arriving from Europe on the shores of Palestine, it questions the very foundations of the Israeli state.

description: The struggle for the control of history continues in Mexico. The biggest battleground today is what happened on the night of Oct. 2, 1968.

title: Finally, Kiawah Becomes Trendy (But Don't Touch Those Trees)
description: IF homeowners on Kiawah Island ever need a reminder of how different things might have been, all they have to do is look at their neighbors up and down the South Carolina coastline, from the crowded, commercialized beachfront of Myrtle Beach to the rows of condominiums on Hilton Head. And even on nearby Seabrook Island, just one mile to the south -- a place that for the most part has resisted some of the worst impulses of overdevelopment -- are a cluster of condos crowding a beachfront with a history of erosion problems.

title: Injury to Nets' Martin Not Serious
description: Forward Kenyon Martin of the Nets had a magnetic resonance imaging exam yesterday morning on his injured left knee, and the results showed nothing more than a sprain.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Mine Strike Ends
description: About 1,300 copper miners at the Cananea mine returned to work after reaching an agreement over productivity bonuses with Grupo Mexico, the copper mining company. The agreement ends a 16-day strike during which the company had threatened to shut down the mine. The workers will receive bonuses based on output as part of the agreement. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

description: Marion Goodman

title: NASA RELINQUISHES AUTHORITY TO LEAD COLUMBIA INQUIRY
description: Under sharp prodding from Congress, NASA formally transferred authority for the investigation of the shuttle Columbia disaster to an independent review board today and agreed to add members to the panel with no ties to the space agency.

description: Dr. Jacques Rogge finished his previous career on July 7, 2001.

title: How Venezuelan Outlasted His Foes
description: When Venezuela's opposition movement started a national strike on Dec. 2, the objective seemed easily within reach. Its leaders portrayed President Hugo Chvez as rash and weak and predicted he would soon resign or call early elections under the pressure of a punishing walkout.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Senator Hires Coal Lobbyist
description: Senator James M. Inhofe, the Oklahoma Republican who is chairman of the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee, has hired a mining lobbyist to oversee clean air legislation. The lobbyist, John Shanahan, is director of air quality issues at the National Mining Association. The president of the association, Jack Gerard, said he was pleased that a person who ''intimately understands the industry'' would be in a position ''to educate the administration and Congress on the importance of coal in meeting our nation's future energy needs.'' Frank O'Donnell of the Clean Air Trust called the hiring ''a sign that Inhofe's top priority is to protect the coal industry.'' Katharine Q. Seelye (NYT)

title: Works That Helped Invent the Image of an English Elite
description: If you hear the name Gainsborough and your first and last thought is ''Blue Boy,'' you might think again. This most fluent of 18th-century British painters was hardly a one-shot phenomenon. He produced hundreds upon hundreds of portraits, many of a visionary, fantastical chic, along with landscapes, genre scenes and drawings galore.

title: After Sweeping Clemency Order, Ex-Gov. Ryan Is a Celebrity, but a Solitary One
description: George Ryan has never been in more demand, with interview and speech requests flooding in from earth's far corners. Yet in a way, he has never been so alone, shunned by friends from 30 years in politics and hometown neighbors and left to unpack untold boxes of memorabilia in his century-old house.

title: Battery Rescue
description: One staple of driver preparedness, especially in winter, is a pair of jumper cables. But a traditional jump start requires another car and a good Samaritan. What if the battery goes dead somewhere remote, or in the middle of the night?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, NATHAN
description: STEINBERG - Nathan. Of White Plains, NY, on February 5, 2003. Born May 3, 1918 in the Bronx, son of Isidore and Fannie. Capt. US Army Air Corp in WW II and graduate of NYU. Formerly a pharmacist, before a career in NYC real estate. Member Greenburgh Hebrew Center and avid bowler and golfer. Survived by wife Ruth, daughter Cheryl, son Leonard, White Plains, NY. Sister Sylvia Schwartz and brother Murray, in FL. Funeral 10 am today Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave., Dobbs Ferry Saw Mill exit 17,

title: 3 CHARGED IN MICHIGAN
description: Three more men have been charged with racketeering in connection with a ring of cigarette smugglers accused of fund-raising for an Islamic militant group. Two Detroit-area brothers were convicted last year of smuggling cigarettes from North Carolina to Michigan, manipulating state tax differences to raise hundreds of thousands of dollars for the militant group Hezbollah. Eleven new indictments in that case were made public this week, including charges against Elias Akhdar, 30; Hassan Makki, 41; and Salim Awde, 45. All had listed residences in southeastern Michigan, and were of Lebanese descent. The United States Attorney's office for the Eastern District of Michigan said Mr. Akhdar and Mr. Makki have taken part in military exercises with Hezbollah. A judge ruled that Mr. Akhdar and Mr. Makki were to be detained until trial. Mr. Awde was awaiting extradition to Michigan from New York. David Enders (NYT)

title: Arrests Reported in Britain and Germany
description: The antiterrorism police detained seven people in coordinated early morning raids in four cities in England and Scotland today, and officials linked the operation to recent arrests in Britain of North Africans charged with plotting attacks with the deadly toxin ricin.

title: Hong Kong Shipments Rejected Under New Anti-Terrorism Rules
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 7  New anti-terrorism rules that the United States began enforcing last Sunday prompted shipping lines to reject 310 of 11,000 freight containers that Hong Kong exporters tried to ship to American ports from Sunday through Tuesday, officials said here today.

title: U.N. Envoys Said to Differ Sharply in Reaction to Powell Speech
description: Although the Bush administration is not yet assured of the nine votes necessary to win another resolution authorizing war against Iraq, officials see tremendous advantages to having an endorsement from the Security Council, even if it passes with abstentions from France, Russia and China, veto-bearing permanent powers.

description: L.A.P. Happy Birthday. February 4, 1944-May 5, 1991.

description: International Center of Photography

title: National Briefing | Washington: Judge Tells Lawyers To Pay Opponents' Fees
description: A judge ordered government lawyers to pay personally the fees of plaintiffs' lawyers in a class-action suit filed by a group of Indians who say the Interior Department lost or stole billions of dollars in oil, gas and timber royalties from Indian land. The judge, Royce C. Lamberth of Federal District Court, said Justice Department lawyers had tried to cover up misrepresentations they made in a hearing in December. He called the lawyers' behavior repugnant. The government has never said how much money has been raised from leases on Indian land. Those proceeds go into a trust fund.

title: Cancer Drug to Be Provided To Limited Number of Patients
description: ImClone Systems and Bristol-Myers Squibb said yesterday that they would begin to provide their cancer drug, Erbitux, to a limited number of colorectal cancer patients who have exhausted other treatment options.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEROLA, LOUIS J.
description: MEROLA-Louis J., 82, on 4 February, peacefully, at the V.A. Hospital in Albany, NY. Born in Brooklyn NY to John and Martha (nee Guglielmo) Merola. Served in the US Army during WWII, as Master Sergeant. A sister, three daughters, a son and two grandchildren survive him.

title: Yankees Welcome Contreras to the Mix
description: Orlando Hernndez arrived with a nickname, and so does Jos Contreras. In Cuba, Contreras was called Titan Bronce, the Bronze Titan -- a reference to a 19th century machete-wielding warrior from the Cuban countryside.

title: Gannett Quarter Profit Up 40%
description: Gannett, the largest American newspaper publisher and owner of 22 television stations, said here today that its fourth-quarter profit rose 40 percent, helped by higher TV advertising sales.

title: Woods Will Play Buick Invitational
description: Tiger Woods has confirmed on his Web site that he will play next week in the Buick Invitational, his first tournament since knee surgery in December.

title: Corrections
description: The State of the Art column in Circuits yesterday, about three new Pocket PC palmtops, included an outdated price for a competing product from Palm, the Tungsten T. It was reduced this week to $399 from $500.

title: Shopping List | Chalet Cookery
description: YOU and yours are stranded in a ski house -- or wish you were stranded in a ski house, preferably one where the wine in the cellar has aged to must-drink perfection. Like Heidi, you have a loaf of bread and access to some very good cheese.

title: MERCK DISCONTINUES TRIALS ON ANXIETY TREATMENT
description: Merck, the drug maker, said yesterday that it was discontinuing clinical trials on an experimental treatment for anxiety. The drug, known as a GABA-A a2/a3 agonist, was in the second of three stages of testing generally required for federal approval, the company said. Merck had not provided sales forecasts for the drug, a spokesman said. Merck, based in Whitehouse Station, N.J., has been trying to add new medicines to ease the effect of generic competition and a new rival for its painkiller Vioxx.

title: Moussaoui Case May Have to Shift From U.S. Court to Tribunal, Administration Says
description: The Justice Department is trying to salvage the civilian prosecution of Zacarias Moussaoui after a court order issued secretly last week that could compel the government to place him before a military tribunal instead, administration officials say.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: NEW HIRING FREEZE AT CUNY A hiring freeze was announced yesterday at the City University of New York. The freeze, effective immediately, applies to all positions except teachers. Matthew Goldstein, the chancellor, said the freeze was the first of several steps the university was taking in response to Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed education cuts. The freeze comes just weeks after 530 CUNY employees said they were taking early retirement. Barbara Bowen, chairwoman of CUNY's faculty and staff union, said the university was already understaffed. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEVY, SENATOR NORMAN J.
description: LEVY, Senator Norman J. 02/07/98. Fifth anniversary in Heaven. To my beloved Norman: on the anniversary of your departure, you are always remembered and forever in my thoughts, and in my heart. Your legacy is being fulfilled and preserved through all who loved and respected you. I miss you and will love you forever. Love, Joy

title: Protecting A Gun Law, Or a Family
description: IN all likelihood, most New Yorkers would find it hard not to sympathize with Ronald Dixon. No, that's too soft. In all likelihood, most New Yorkers would find it close to impossible not to sympathize with Mr. Dixon, or question his right to do what he did.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the World Briefing column on Wednesday about a reward offered by the German police for information on the shooting of an American soldier misstated the amount. It is about $5,400, not $4,600.

title: Productivity Fell in Quarter But Rose Sharply in 2002
description: Companies stopped becoming more efficient in the final three months of last year as a slowing economy caught many by surprise, according to government figures released yesterday. The productivity gain for all of 2002 was still the best in more than 50 years, however.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: CYPRUS: GREECE AND TURKEY AGREE TO TALKS Without setting a date, Greece and Turkey agreed yesterday to hold talks on the security of Cyprus. The decision comes after the United Nations set a Feb. 28 deadline for a deal to reunite the island's Greek and Turkish halves.

title: TOYOTA PLANS HYBRID VERSION OF SPORT UTILITY
description: Toyota is likely to produce a hybrid version of its Highlander sport utility, making it the third hybrid vehicle in the company's lineup, a company executive said yesterday. Hybrids use fuel more efficiently than traditional cars because they supplement the internal combustion engine with electric power and trap energy used in braking. Toyota now sells the Prius, a subcompact hybrid that gets 45 to 50 miles a gallon. The technology, also used by Honda, is expected to start appearing in sport utilities from Ford and Toyota next year. Toyota has said it will sell a hybrid version of a Lexus sport utility, the RX 330, next year. Danny Hakim (NYT)

title: Injured Vindication to Miss The Triple Crown Series
description: Vindication, considered the early favorite for the Kentucky Derby after his convincing victory in last year's Breeders' Cup Juvenile, will miss the entire Triple Crown series with what is being described as a possible strain of a suspensory ligament in his left front leg.

description: Deitch Projects

title: U.S. Issues Warning On Terrorist Threats
description: Increasingly jittery about the heightened threat of terrorist attacks, the United States warned Americans overseas today to ''remain vigilant'' and avoid attending public demonstrations that could be the site of attacks.

description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Buchanan: Congress To Examine Indian Point
description: The House of Representatives will hold a hearing on the Indian Point nuclear power plant. The hearing will examine the federal government's response to a report last month that called evacuation plans unworkable. An aide to State Representative Sue Kelly, a Westchester Republican whose district includes the plant, said the hearing would be held this month or next in Washington before a House transportation subcommittee. Ms. Kelly said she had requested the hearing because the Federal Emergency Management Agency had not adequately responded to the evacuation report. FEMA officials say they are reviewing it. Randal C. Archibold (NYT)

title: Weekender | Essex, Conn.
description: EAGLES like Essex, and so do people. Ten years ago, the book ''The 100 Best Small Towns in America'' by Norman Crampton (Hungry Minds, 1993) named Essex, with its lovely villages and sweeping vistas of the Connecticut River, the No. 1 small town in the country, and its residents say it's as good now as it was then. The eagles -- bald eagles, now increasing in numbers from their most endangered days -- vote with their wings, flying in by the scores from northern New England to fish in the tidal open water of the Connecticut River.

title: U.S. in Talks on Allowing Turkey To Occupy a Kurdish Area in Iraq
description: American diplomats are engaged in delicate negotiations here that could allow tens of thousands of Turkish soldiers to occupy part of northern Iraq behind an advancing American army, Turkish and Kurdish officials said today.

title: America, Iraq and the Court of Public Opinion
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing: Americas
description: BRAZIL: INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT RISES Brazilian industrial production recorded its seventh consecutive month of growth in December, helped by growing exports of steel, motor vehicles and food, but held back by a depressed local economy and continuing high interest rates. The national statistics institute said production was up 5.5 percent in December compared with a year earlier. Manufacturing output rose by an annualized 2.4 percent, compared with 1.5 percent in 2001, it said. Exports are being helped by the weak real, which lost 35 percent of its value against the dollar last year. But the highest interest rates in four years are depressing local consumer demand and forcing companies to cut spending.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: New Antipolio Campaign
description: Health officials will start a widespread vaccination program on Sunday to combat a recent rise in polio cases. Last year more than 1,500 new cases, 85 percent of all new cases worldwide, were detected in India, mostly in the Muslim population of the northern state of Uttar Pradesh. Hari Kumar (NYT)

title: A Killer of Millions Lets One Slide; Plague Left a Man on the Brink, and a City on Edge
description: John Tull raised his right arm the other day. Nurses cheered. It was a big deal.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Volcano Refugees Return Home
description: Residents of the tiny volcanic island Stromboli will be permitted to return to their homes on Friday, more than a month after an eruption and ensuing giant wave flooded houses and forced 400 of the island's 450 people to flee. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Progress Seen in Border Tests of ID System
description: Immigration officials say they are moving rapidly to meet a congressionally mandated deadline for a sophisticated new identification system to be in use at its 100 most porous entry points over the next year.

title: 'Significant' Piece of Wing of Shuttle Is Found
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 - The space agency today found what investigators called a ``significant'' section of one of the space shuttle's wings, including the hardened leading-edge material and heat-resistant tiles that are among the leading suspects in the accident that killed the crew of the Columbia six days ago.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: AIRLINE GROUNDED France's second- largest airline, Air Lib, lost its operating license and was forced to ground all its planes after a Dutch investment company, IMCA, declined to invest in the airline. Gilles de Robien, the transport minister, said that the French government would try to find jobs for the carrier's 3,200 employees, but left the company's fate in the hands of the commercial court, which could place the airline in liquidation or receivership. The owner of Air Lib, Jean-Charles Corbet, above, said bankruptcy was not automatic. He also said that IMCA might yet invest in the company.

title: GOODYEAR SAYS IT IS RENEGOTIATING LOAN AGREEMENTS
description: Goodyear Tire and Rubber said yesterday that it was renegotiating loan agreements with banks, including $1.1 billion in two credit lines, to try to avoid breaching terms of the borrowings. The banks, which Goodyear did not identify, already waived until March 7 loan provisions that would have required Goodyear to contribute about $500 million above federal requirements to its pension plans, a company spokesman said. The two credit lines and the $600 million in cash that Goodyear said it had at the end of January are enough to cover contractual payments in 2003, said Scott Lee, an analyst at Fitch Ratings, which reduced its credit rating on the company in November. Shares of Goodyear fell 10 cents, to $3.57.

title: Citing Financial Pressures, Fairfield Drops Football
description: Fairfield University, following in the footsteps of Canisius and St. John's, yesterday became the third college in the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference to drop football since last fall.

title: U.S. Seeks 54 Exemptions on Pesticide Ban
description: The Bush administration is requesting exemptions for 54 companies and trade groups that want to continue using a pesticide scheduled to be phased out by 2005 under a treaty to protect the ozone layer, officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROOKS, SHELDON VON HAGEN
description: BROOKS-Sheldon von Hagen, 82. Of Key Largo, Florida, formerly of Wayzata, Minnesota died Saturday, February 1, 2003 at his home in Key Largo from complications of prostate cancer. Born in Minneapolis January 10, 1921, son of Paul Andros and Hazel von Hagen Brooks, he attended the Blake School, Hotchkiss and graduated from The Thacher School in 1939. A member of the Yale Class of '43, during World War II, Mr. Brooks served in the Navy Air Corps first as an instructor at Pensacola and later in the Pacific Theater flying for the Naval Air Transport Service. After the war, he was for 35 years the owner of the Minnetonka Boat Works, retiring in 1985. He was preceded in death by his parents, his sisters Polly Brooks Hollern, Barbara Brooks Kroos and his brother Anson Brooks. He is survived by Carroll, his wife of twentyone years, three children of a previous marriage to the late Frances Atkinson Hewitt, Paul Andros (Pam) Brooks, Sky Atkinson Brooks, Molly Moyer Brooks his sister, Stanley Brooks Gregory and four grandchildren. Mr. Brooks was a member of the Key Largo Anglers Club, the Ocean Reef Club, Woodhill Country Club, Shikar Safari Club International, The Bohemian Club, Quiet Birdmen and numerous conservation organizations. Contributions in his memory to the Ocean Reef Medical Center Foundation, Ocean Reef Drive, Key Largo, Florida 33037 or the Ridgeview Medical Center Foundation in C/O of Robert Stevens, 500 South Maple Street, Waconia, Minnesota, 55387 would be greatly appreciated. There will be a memorial service at a later date.

description: Mary Boone Gallery

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Mixed Trading Results
description: Japan's largest general trading firm, the Mitsubishi Corporation, said profit more than doubled in the three months to December driven by its metals and food businesses. The firm earned 26.2 billion yen ($218 million), 151 percent more than in the period a year earlier. The country's second-largest trader, Mitsui & Company, said profits slid 21 percent, to 12 billion yen, because of losses in its chemical trading operations. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show. + means discounted tickets were at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth for performances last Friday and Saturday nights. ++ means tickets were at the booth for last Friday night only.

title: World Briefing | Americas: South American Nations Pursue Closer Ties
description: Concluding a meeting in Uruguay at which they agreed to negotiate as a bloc in trade talks with the United States, the foreign ministers of Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay called for the creation of a new regional parliament. The move comes after the four countries agreed in December to begin phasing out immigration and residency restrictions within the group and considering a common passport. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEMYSS, COURTNEY
description: WEMYSS-Courtney, age 80. Of Huntington. Professor Emeritus of Biology, Hofstra University. Husband of Joy. Memorial service Saturday, 11AM, Connell Funeral Home, 934 New York Avenue, Huntington, N.Y. Donations to Calvary Hospital, Bronx, New York 10461.

title: Seconds
description: New York offers a dizzying variety of thrift shops, from the high-toned to the basic. Here are three Manhattan favorites of a veteran thrift-shopper.

title: Chief Ousted at Vivendi TV Unit; Plans for Reshuffle Are Stressed
description: Jean-Ren Fourtou, the chief executive of Vivendi Universal, announced a management shake-up today at the Canal Plus Group, the company's pay television division, and said an overhaul of the division, which continues to lose money, remained a priority.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPEYER, RONALD JEFFREY
description: SPEYER - Ronald Jeffrey, Ph.D., 57, of Newport Beach, CA, died on February 3, 2003. He is survived by his loving wife Ellen Vigman Speyer, his beloved children Joshua, Gabriel and Alexandra, all of Newport Beach, CA, and loving brother Franklin of New York City. A gentleman of character, integrity and style, his warmth, humor and charismatic presence will be sadly missed but fondly remembered by all those who shared the pleasure of his company. A devoted husband and father, a standout athlete, scholar and businessman, he spent a lifetime giving selflessly to others, and made the world a better place while he lived. A funeral service will be held on February 7th at 1:30 P.M. at Temple Bat Yahm, 1011 Camelback Road, Newport Beach, CA. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in memory of Ronald Speyer to the Seattle Cancer Care Alliance, P.O. Box 19023, Seattle, WA. 98109-1023.

title: Unemployment Rate Falls to 5.7% as Job Growth Surges
description: The job market showed unexpected signs of improvement in January, relieving worries that the country could be slipping into a new recession, but economists and investors remained unconvinced that the economy was recovering strongly.

title: NASA Seeks Answers From Simulators, Amid Some Doubting
description: Besides sifting debris and data, investigators seeking to understand what destroyed the space shuttle Columbia are using powerful computers and wind-tunnel models to simulate the doomed craft and the forces at play as it hurtled toward earth.

title: For Crash Victims, Parallel Lives and the Same End
description: The familiar foursome were strollering around Brooklyn together on Wednesday afternoon, as they so often did: Nery Lissette Mejia, 17, and her baby son, Ricky; Yaritza Santos, 19, and her son, Manuel Villot Jr.

title: City Is Fined $5.7 Million For Muddying Catskills Creek
description: A federal judge fined New York City $5.7 million yesterday for violating the Clean Water Act by discharging muddy brown water into a storied Catskills trout-fishing stream.

title: Confederate Flag Boycott Tests Candidates' Resolve
description: The Democratic candidates for president are struggling these days to work their way through a bit of a headache: How to campaign in South Carolina, a state with a pivotal primary, without running afoul of an economic boycott intended to force the removal of a Confederate flag from the State House grounds.

title: Teamsters Reach Tentative Pact That Provides Raises for Drivers
description: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters yesterday reached a tentative master freight agreement that covers 65,000 drivers and warehouse workers and provides raises of 11.3 percent over five years.

title: John Ashcroft's Death-Penalty Edicts
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft has directed federal prosecutors in New York and Connecticut to seek the death penalty in a dozen cases in which they had recommended lesser sentences. Mr. Ashcroft's orders are a triumph of ideology over good prosecutorial practice. The Bush administration should reconsider them.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Arrest In Stuyvesant Town Blast
description: A 51-year-old man was arrested and charged with reckless endangerment and arson yesterday in connection with an explosion in Stuyvesant Town on Tuesday that forced the evacuation of more than 100 residents, the police said. Arson investigators believe Larry Feingold, who lives in the East Side apartment complex, caused the explosion that blasted through a cinder-block and concrete wall on the 12th floor, sent him to the hospital, and injured seven others, including three firefighters. The force of the blast also blew a window air-conditioner and 12 windows from their frames. Investigators said that all the stove's gas jets had been turned on in the apartment where the explosion occurred, and they considered that evidence of a suicide attempt. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Scientist Gives Inspectors First Private Talk
description: Under closer threat of war, Iraq bent today to a central demand of the United Nations weapons inspectors by saying one of its scientists agreed to be interviewed in private, without a government witness at his side.

title: F.B.I. Recruits Chinese Students in U.S.
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is recruiting Chinese students at American universities to gain insight into what it says is an intensified effort by the Chinese government to obtain militarily useful technologies in the United States, according to law enforcement officials.

title: INSIDE
description: Warning to North Korea

title: A Wagon Like Dad's, But Now I'm in Front
description: FOR Steve Barnes, the search for the Brady-Bunch-mobile of his dreams became an all-consuming passion. After months of surfing the Web and culling through car magazines and newspaper advertisements, he decided to take the ultimate step and hire a private detective to find the elusive 1971 Dodge Monaco station wagon he was looking for.

title: Hartmarx Delays 2002 Earnings Report
description: The Hartmarx Corporation, the country's top maker of men's suits, said today that it would delay the release of its results for the fiscal year ended Nov. 30 until its auditors completed a review of the books for its women's wholesale unit.

title: New Plans to Aid Savings May Harm Financial Firms
description: For seven years, Bill Ferrigno has run a profit-sharing program for the half-dozen employees in his construction company in Connecticut. But now, he says, he is probably going to shut it down, along with another employee retirement program, because of the savings plans that President Bush is proposing.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Terra Networks Dismisses 22% Of U.S. Work Force
description: Terra Networks, Spain's largest Internet company, cut 22 percent of its United States work force yesterday to reduce costs, fueling speculation that the company may sell its Lycos unit, analysts said. Terra is eliminating 147 jobs, including 101 in its office in Waltham, Mass., a spokesman said. It also trimmed jobs in New York and San Francisco. This is the second time in five months that Terra has cut its American work force as it scales back its operations after spending $6.5 billion to buy Lycos in 2000.

title: Calhoun's Surgery Is Successful
description: Jim Calhoun, the coach of the University of Connecticut men's basketball team, had successful surgery for the removal of his cancerous prostate yesterday, and his surgeon said he did not think the cancer had spread.

description: Free medicine offers the poor a chance to live.
