description: Apartments are for rent again at 45 Wall Street.

title: GENESCO REVISES OUTLOOK, CITING SLUGGISH SHOE SALES
description: Genesco Inc., a shoe company, cut its earnings estimates for the latest quarter, citing sluggish sales, setting off a 21 percent decline in its share price yesterday. Genesco, which is based in Nashville, Tenn., sells shoes mainly for men and boys to department, discount and specialty stores, as well as through about 900 company-owned stores under names like Journeys, Jarman, Johnston & Murphy and Underground Station. Genesco said that excluding a restructuring charge, it expected earnings for its fiscal fourth quarter, ended in January, of 60 cents to 63 cents a share, down from a forecast of 68 cents to 71 cents a share that it made in July, and less than the 70 cents expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Genesco's stock fell $3.32, to $13.05 a share.

title: Organizers Call for an End To Doctors' Work Slowdown
description: After nearly a week of rallies, rancor and crowded emergency rooms, organizers of the work slowdown by New Jersey doctors have called for an end to their five-day job action.

title: The Desperate Refugees of North Korea
description: More than 200,000 North Koreans have fled into northeastern China in recent years trying to save themselves and their families from famine. Now they are trapped there, hunted down by Chinese police and blocked from traveling to South Korea, which says it would willingly receive them. Though less threatening than nuclear weapons programs, this is a dimension of the Korean crisis Washington cannot afford to ignore.

title: Bus to Casinos Skids Off Parkway; 2 Die and 28 Are Injured
description: A white charter bus carrying 30 casino gamblers from Manhattan's Chinatown to Atlantic City spun off the Garden State Parkway in South Jersey yesterday and flipped on its side on a snowy embankment. Two were killed and 28 were injured as passengers were hurled about and one was ejected through a shattered window.

title: Religion Journal; Yoga in Aspen Public Schools Draws Opposition
description: Yoga has become as trendy as this glamorous ski hamlet, so it would not seem surprising that some local schools have added it to the students' day. But some parents and religious leaders here are objecting, saying that teaching yoga in school violates the separation of church and state.

title: Filipino Immigrants
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPATZ, WERNER
description: SPATZ-Werner. Born March 26th, 1925, died February 6th, 2003 from Parkinson's disease. Married for fifty-two wonderful years to Ilse. Adored father of David and Linda and Sherrill and Rob. Cherished grandpa (and baba) of Hana, Emma, Alex and ZoeLoving uncle. Son of Dr. Albert and Sitta Spatz. Brother of Edgar. He was a kind and generous man of faith who taught us all how to be happy & live life to its fullest. He will be missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPITZER, SUZANNE ELIN
description: SPITZER-Suzanne Elin (daughter of the late Sol and Sylvia Cohen, Newport Nitwear), of New York City, residing in Boynton Beach, FL, died on February 2, 2003. Survived by her daughters: Arlene and Caren Elin, Diane and Ross Browarnik, and grandson Seth. Funeral at 1:00PM, February 9th, 2003, Beth Israel Memorial Chapel, Delray Beach, Florida, phone 561-499-8000.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Unemployment Rate Falls, But Analysts Are Cautious

title: Phenom's School Tries to Avoid Getting Caught Up in the Game
description: As students poured out of St. Vincent-St. Mary High School on Wednesday, freshly aware that the suspended basketball star LeBron James could again play for the top-ranked team in the country, a sense of excitement and satisfaction seemed to swirl like snowflakes.

title: Gallery's Tip Helps Police Arrest 2 in Theft of Stamps
description: For four years, the greatest theft in the world of stamp collecting has gone unsolved.

title: Iranian Calls U.S. Presence Worse Than Rival's Weapons
description: Former President Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani said today that while Iraq should be disarmed, the presence of American forces in the Persian Gulf was worse than Iraq's access to weapons of mass destruction.

title: Suddenly Onscreen, It's All About Wonder
description: A female nude stands in the middle of a 1929 collage by Magritte. She is framed, literally, by the faces of 16 men, each with his eyes closed. Written above and beneath her shapely body are the words: ''I do not see the woman hidden in the forest.''

title: Four Officials Are Ousted In One Town's Drama
description: Talk about going down swinging.

title: Still Here, Still Cool in a Hot Genre
description: What does Chrissie Hynde, rock star, have in common with the late Ted Williams, baseball player and cryonics enthusiast? Both of them know that if you want to stick around for a long time, you had better keep cool.

title: Witness Describes How Mayor Used Powers to Get Kickbacks
description: Joseph P. Ganim, the Bridgeport mayor on trial for 24 federal corruption-related charges, used his official powers to pry tens of thousands of dollars in kickbacks from contractors eager to win city business, the government's key witness testified today.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Cuban Coast Guard Defection
description: Four Cuban Coast Guard members defected, docking their patrol boat at a Key West hotel marina and flagging down a police officer. The men, wearing military uniforms, arrived about 4 a.m., armed with a handgun and two AK-47 assault rifles. They told the police they were on patrol when they decided to defect. The men were to be turned over to the Immigration and Naturalization Service. Terry Aguayo (NYT)

title: Robert St. John, 100, Globe-Trotting Reporter and Author
description: Robert St. John, a journalist and prolific author who was beaten by Al Capone's thugs, wounded by Nazis in the Balkans and competed against Edward R. Murrow in London, died on Thursday at his home in suburban Maryland. He was 100.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALDSTON, MORTON, M.D.
description: GALDSTON-Morton, M.D. The Friends of the Library of New York University School of Medicine wishes to remember Dr. Morton Galdston with gratitude and fondness for his support and leadership as president for many years. He was a beloved colleague and teacher, and a historian of medical practice in New York City and at Bellevue Hospital. He will be missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOSS, REBECCA H.
description: FOSS-Rebecca H., 101. On February 7, 2003. Beloved wife for 65 years of the late Mortimer M. Foss. Cherished mother of Natalie Stein (Robert) and Beejay Brown (Donald). Adored Nana of grandsons Edward Stein (Katie Connolly) and Kerry Stein (Jean Marie), Mark Brown (Roxanne), Douglas Brown (Laura), and Charles Brown. Proud great-grandmother of Morgan and Jackson Stein and David, Richard and Sarah Brown. A lady to her fingertips, gracious, generous and caring. Fiercely independent, feisty and courageous in the face of encroaching blindness. Devoted to a host of friends. In lieu of flowers donations to Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83 St, NY 10024 or Macular Degeneration Research will be most appreciated. Visiting Saturday, 7-9 PM. Service Sunday, 1PM, at ''The Riverside'' 76 St & Amsterdam Ave

title: Fewer Strings but All Mozart
description: For the second of its four concerts at Carnegie Hall on Monday evening, the Cleveland Orchestra played an all-Mozart program. For the occasion the ensemble shed a bit of 19th-century string weight and gave its music director, Franz Welser-Mst, the evening off. In his place, the pianist Mitsuko Uchida conducted two concertos from the keyboard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOFSHEVER, BERNARD
description: BOFSHEVER-Bernard. Of Tamarac, FL, died on February 7, 2003, after a valiant struggle with cancer. Born on August 25, 1919, in Brooklyn, NY, Mr. Bofshever served as a captain in the US Army during W.W. II. Upon his return he founded the Metroplitan Lamp Co, retiring in 1988, after 35 years serving as its president. He is survived by his loving wife Caroline, his daughter Marilyn, his son Michael, his grandchildren Jessica, Katie, James and Elizabeth, and his brother Ralph. Services will be held on Sunday, February 9, 2:15 PM, at the Star of David Chapel, North Lauderdale, FL.

title: Carter Defends Choice To Keep Starting Slot
description: Vince Carter was ready and willing to answer all the questions about why, after the fans voted him as an All-Star, he was still going to start Sunday night's game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAAS, MARTHA KOHN
description: HAAS-Martha Kohn, 102. Died on February 6, 2003. Devoted wife of Adolf. Loving Mother of Martin, Liese, Ann and Fred. Grandmother of Joanne, Michael, Arlene and Orlando. Great-grandmother of Scott, Cara, and Alexandra. Special friend to Wanda. In our hearts forever.

title: Rumsfeld visits Europe with more frank words
description: PARIS:  Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld brought his dispute with France and Germany to Europe on Friday, ruffling feathers further by saying that France is a country that always seems to disagree with everyone else.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: In Any Test of Human Limits, Death Is Among the Judges
description: Too much money, too much risk, too much death. In the week since the shuttle disaster, these have been some of the judgments offered as the space program has come under scrutiny. But when have such verdicts not been plausible for journeys of exploration?

title: Corrections
description: A report in the National Briefing column on Thursday about an assessment by Jerry McEntee, chairman of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s political committee, on Democrats' chances in the 2004 presidential campaign referred incorrectly to his comments about Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts. He said Mr. Kerry had the best chance to break support for President Bush on foreign policy. He did not say Mr. Kerry had the best chance of defeating Mr. Bush, and he did not endorse Mr. Kerry.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: YANKEE CANDLE CO., South Deerfield, Mass., a maker of scented candles, said its founder, Michael Kittredge, had resigned as chairman and as a member of the board. The chief executive, Craig Rydin, will succeed Mr. Kittredge as chairman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILENSKY, ADA
description: WILENSKY-Ada. The entire Dunewood community mourns the loss of Ada Wilensky. She was a summer resident in Dunewood for several decades. Her friendly smile and manner will be missed by all. We send condolences to her sons and her entire family.

title: Missing on Broadway
description: To the Editor:

title: White House Floats Idea Of Dropping Income Tax
description: President Bush, having already set off a firestorm over his proposals to cut taxes and revamp retirement accounts, suggested today that the time might be near to drop the income tax as a whole and replace it with some form of consumption tax.

title: Furyk Uses Positive Energy To Lead Pebble Pro-Am
description: Jim Furyk was having a blast at the AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-Am even before he took the lead. Furyk, a huge Pittsburgh Steelers fan, asked Lynn Swann to be his partner in the pro-am this year. Swann, a former Steelers wide receiver and a member of the Pro Football Hall of Fame, readily accepted.

title: SHAREHOLDER MAKES A COMPETING BID FOR HOOVER'S
description: Hoover's Inc., a publisher of corporate data, said a shareholder, Marathon Partners, together with an investment firm, Austin Ventures, had offered to buy the company for about $131 million in cash. Marathon's offer of $8 a share for Hoover's outstanding stock is higher than the $7 a share, or $117 million, that D&B, the business information provider, agreed to pay for the company. Hoover's, which is based in Austin, Tex., said it was considering Marathon's offer. Marathon sued Hoover's and its directors last month in a Texas court, saying the company was worth more than what D&B had agreed to pay.

title: Free AIDS Drugs in Africa Offer Dose of Life
description: Every Monday morning, patients infected with the AIDS virus come to the red-brick clinic in this impoverished community of dilapidated shacks.

title: A Cup Without Winston
description: Perhaps no brand name has been more closely associated with a sport than Winston cigarettes and Nascar. But tobacco's last major billboard is about to be torn down.

title: Leiter Says Mets Have Nothing to Lose by Signing Cone
description: Al Leiter implored David Cone to attempt a comeback with the Mets when they spoke at John Franco's charity bowling tournament last week. He cornered Cone, 40, in a back room, challenging him and predicting a gaudy 2003 for him. Leiter continued expressing a passion for seeing Cone pitch for the Mets again during a conversation yesterday.

title: INSIDE
description: DeLay Disavows Letter

title: Dept. of Consumption
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Heightens U.S. Terror Alert; No Solid Evidence of Specific Plot
description: The Bush administration today put the nation on a ''high'' terror alert for only the second time since the Sept. 11 attacks, warning Americans that Al Qaeda may be planning attacks on hotels, apartment buildings and other vulnerable targets in the United States.

title: Britain Admits That Much of Its Report on Iraq Came From Magazines
description: The British government admitted today that large sections of its most recent report on Iraq, praised by Secretary of State Colin L. Powell as ''a fine paper'' in his speech to the United Nations on Wednesday, had been lifted from magazines and academic journals.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Telecom Loss
description: South Korea's second-largest long-distance phone carrier, the Dacom Corporation, posted a loss for the fourth quarter, hurt by two affiliates that provide Internet content. The 3.7 billion won ($3 million) net loss was in contrast to net income of 3.6 billion won the previous year. Sales were little changed at 277 billion won. The company had a profit for all of 2002, its first in three years.

title: A Gun Lawsuit's Smoking Gun
description: Cities suing the gun industry for its role in promoting violence got a powerful new weapon of their own this week. A onetime industry leader has come forward to say that his former colleagues have long been aware that some of the dealers they supply turn around and sell guns to criminals. The new testimony provides an important link between gun makers and criminal activity, and should make courts more willing to find the industry liable for damages.

title: Sprint Is Sued by BellSouth and Cingular
description: BellSouth and its affiliated mobile-phone company, Cingular Wireless, said today that they were suing Sprint over its effort to hire BellSouth's vice chairman, Gary D. Forsee.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: BANK TO RAISE CAPITAL A leading Japanese bank, the Mitsubishi Tokyo Financial Group , plans to sell common stock in hopes of raising as much as 300 billion yen ($2.5 billion). The bank, the largest in Japan by market value, will issue 454,000 new shares and sell another 155,027 shares held by its subsidiaries. Mitsubishi Tokyo and other large bank groups are trying to raise capital to help offset the write-off of nonperforming loans. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Hardcover Business Best Sellers
description: This

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, LEONARD
description: JACOBS-Leonard. Temple Beth-El of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of its member. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Franklin S. Abrams, Pres. Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Truck Maker Posts Profit
description: Volvo A.B., the world's second-largest maker of heavy trucks, returned to profit in the fourth quarter after closing a factory in the United States and eliminating 7,100 jobs last year. But the company gave a cautious outlook and its shares fell 4 percent. Net income was 638 million kronor ($75 million), or 1.5 kronor a share, in contrast to a loss of 487 million kronor, or 1.2 kronor, a year earlier. Sales fell 5.7 percent, to 45.9 billion kronor.

title: Cryptic Clues and New Questions Face NASA in Columbia Inquiry
description: A blurry silhouette of the space shuttle Columbia in its last moments and a complex, cryptic series of sensor readings that were released yesterday brought renewed focus to the theory that damage to the orbiter's left wing led to its destruction when it re-entered Earth's atmosphere. But even if that theory is correct, NASA officials said, it does not fully explain what went wrong with the shuttle.

title: Sather's Attention to Detail Sparks the Rangers
description: The most noticeable difference behind the Rangers' bench since Glen Sather replaced Bryan Trottier as coach has been the sheer force of personality.

title: Another Republican to Leave Post Amid Party Turmoil
description: The upheaval among Suffolk County's top Republicans is claiming another casualty. This time it is the party's chairman, Anthony F. Apollaro, who will resign his party post soon and take a new job at the county's Off-Track Betting Corporation, political leaders say.

title: STOCK OF SCIOS RISES ON NEWS OF TAKEOVER BID
description: Scios Inc., the maker of the heart medicine Natrecor, said yesterday that it was considering a bid to be taken over, setting off a 21.7 percent gain in its share price. Scios, an unprofitable biotechnology company based in Sunnyvale, Calif., said in a statement that it was discussing a possible merger or a partnership for an experimental rheumatoid arthritis drug. Companies may be interested in the Scios arthritis pill, which would offer an easy-to-take alternative to Johnson & Johnson's intravenous Remicade, investors said. Scios said last month that it was talking with several companies about developing the drug. The Wall Street Journal, quoting sources it did not identify, reported yesterday that the bid was made by Johnson & Johnson and was valued at about $2 billion. Shares of Scios rose $7.51, to $42.20.

title: Rumsfeld Faces Tense Greeting and Antiwar Rallies in Munich
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld arrived tonight in the heart of what he has dismissed as ''old Europe,'' facing antiwar street rallies and a tense reception from his hosts even as he declared that debate among allies is healthy.

title: ABC Tops the Ratings With Michael Jackson
description: ABC's special on Michael Jackson was one of the most-watched programs of the current television season with more than 27 million viewers, leading ABC to its first ratings victory on a Thursday night in more than eight years.

title: A Song of Themselves
description: Last week a group of American poets showed once again that artists can be the worst enemies of the arts. Laura Bush, as part of her efforts to encourage reading by honoring literature, had invited several poets to the White House for a symposium. One of the invitees -- perhaps channeling Eartha Kitt, who lambasted Lady Bird Johnson about the Vietnam War at a White House luncheon in 1968 -- decided to use the occasion to protest the administration's Iraq policy. He solicited antiwar poems to present to Mrs. Bush at the White House and posted them on a Web site.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Central Bank's Bond Risk
description: The governor of the Bank of Japan, Masaru Hayami, said a one-percentage-point rise in long-term bond yields would shave a trillion yen ($8.4 billion) off the central bank's portfolio. The bank has been buying 1.2 trillion yen a month in government bond markets and politicians have been calling for more purchases. But with yields on the 10-year bond near historic lows, some investors say the market is overheating. At the end of 2002, the central bank held 84.5 trillion yen in Japanese government securities. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Korea Gas Ownership Shift
description: The Korea Gas Corporation announced today that it was doubling the percentage of ownership that could be held by foreign investors. As of today, foreign investors can own 30 percent of the company rather than 15 percent, the previous limit. The state-controlled company has said that it will raise the limit on foreign ownership to 49 percent by the end of 2003 as part of its overall plan to make the company private.

title: France and China Rebuff Bush On Support for Early Iraq War
description: The leaders of France and China rebuffed efforts by President Bush today to line up support for the use of force against Iraq within the next month or two. Their continuing resistance made clear the difficulty the White House faces in its attempt to win explicit new authorization from the United Nations Security Council for military action.

title: Performing a Free Trade Juggling Act, Offstage
description: Over the next few months, Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, will play the central role in deciding whether people in sub-Saharan Africa have access to inexpensive drugs to fight a host of diseases.

title: Fliers Frequent A Stopover In Brooklyn
description: Prospect Park ''is an oasis in the middle of a concrete desert,'' said Peter Dorosh, president of the Brooklyn Bird Club.

title: Sports of The Times; Hingis Jumps Forward Into New Life
description: SHE started off as the youngest tennis player on the Tour. Now she is the youngest student in her English class. Martina Hingis always was precocious.

title: Isles' Strategy Against Jagr Backfires
description: The Islanders thought Sven Butenschon would make a perfect shadow for Jaromir Jagr. Butenschon is a 6-foot-4 defenseman with a fearsome blond goatee and the desire not to be sent back to Bridgeport for the fourth time this season.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about embezzlement charges against Jacquelyn Allen-MacGregor, a former officer of the United Way in Lansing, Mich., referred incorrectly to a recommendation made in letters from the organization's auditor and in some copies, because of an editing error, misstated a comment by David Brower, a financial adviser, about the advice. The auditor advised that someone review Ms. Allen-MacGregor's reconciliation of bank statements -- not that someone other than she reconcile them. Mr. Brower said the recommendation had not been followed; he did not say it had been.

title: Greek Monks Guard Faith and Sacred Ground
description: The rebel forces occupying a rugged cove on the Aegean here number more than 100, and they will not budge.

title: In New York, a New Array Of Safeguards Take Effect
description: In New York, museums, transportation terminals, hotels and the subway system were put on high alert yesterday as officials across the country responded to reports that terrorists might be planning to attack American targets.

title: The I-Can't-Believe-I'm-a-Hawk Club
description: If the United States storms into Iraq, as now seems almost inevitable, it will have been airlifted to war with a tailwind from some unlikely sources.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: SRI LANKA: REBEL SUICIDE ATTACK Three Tamil Tiger rebels blew up their boat, killing themselves, after they were found trying to smuggle an antiaircraft gun and hundreds of rounds of ammunition into Sri Lanka, defense officials said. Two European peace monitors who had boarded the boat to inspect it were unharmed. Before killing themselves, the rebels asked the monitors to jump overboard, Brig. Sanath Karunaratne, a military spokesman, said in a statement. The monitors had found an antiaircraft gun, spare parts for the gun, ammunition, three hand grenades and a radio set, he said. (AP)

title: Another Executive Quits Merrill's Research Unit
description: Now, even the executives who were staying at Merrill Lynch & Company are leaving.

title: PATAKI PRESENTS TRANSIT HUB PLAN
description: Gov. George E. Pataki outlined a long-awaited plan yesterday to spend up to $5 billion to restore and upgrade transportation in Lower Manhattan, including new above-ground hubs at the World Trade Center site and at the Fulton Street subway stations, as well as a rebuilt subway terminal at South Ferry.

title: Who's Best at Chess? For Now, It's Neither Man Nor Machine
description: A battle-weary Garry Kasparov and a stolid Deep Junior agreed to a 28-move draw yesterday in the last game of their man-vs.-machine chess competition at the New York Athletic Club. The six-game match ended in a tie, with each side winning a game and drawing the other four.

title: Uneasy Accord By Investigators In Banker Case
description: A legal quarrel almost boiled over this week between rival prosecutors vying to lead the criminal investigation of Frank P. Quattrone, Credit Suisse First Boston's embattled technology banker.

title: U.S. Team Faces Argentina At Start of Busy Schedule
description: For Pablo Mastroeni, nothing would be better than sliding on the captain's armband this afternoon for the United States when it plays Argentina in an international match at the Orange Bowl in Miami.

title: Auditor Role In Working For Executives Is Questioned
description: Accounting firms' close ties to companies have been criticized for more than a year, but regulators and lawyers are now examining the work that accountants do for executives.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Seeking Extradition
description: Officials said they had asked the mainland Chinese police to hand over a mainland citizen arrested in Hunan Province and accused of fatally shooting a Hong Kong businessman in a teahouse on Nov. 30. Hong Kong and China do not have an agreement on the return of suspects because of concerns in Hong Kong, which does not have the death penalty, about sending suspects to the mainland, which does. China has previously returned suspects who are Hong Kong citizens but has held its own trials for mainland citizens. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: SWITZERLAND: INSIDER TRADING A Swiss billionaire, Thomas Schmidheiny, who controls the cement maker Holcim Ltd. quit as chairman after being fined in Spain to settle charges of insider trading. Mr. Schmidheiny, 57, will remain on Holcim's board, according to the company, which is based in Jona, Switzerland. Willy Kissling will stay on as interim chairman until June 4, when the company holds its annual shareholders' meeting. Mr. Schmidheiny stepped down after paying a fine of 1.46 million euros ($1.57 million) to settle the case, a spokesman, Joerg Denzler, said. The fine ends an investigation into Mr. Schmidheiny's December 2000 acquisition of a minority stake in a Spanish zinc producer, Asturiana de Zinc, after learning of a pending takeover bid by Xstrata, a mining company where he was a board member. (Bloomberg News)

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Son Of President Is Jailed
description: Kim Hong Up, left, the second of President Kim Dae Jung's three sons, was sentenced to two years in prison, fined $333,000 and ordered to return $217,000 that he accepted in return for promising businessmen favors in their dealings with government officials. Mr. Kim's lawyer said he would appeal to the Supreme Court. Kim Hong Gul, the president's youngest son, was convicted earlier of bribery but freed with a two-year suspended sentence. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Hamas Leader Tells Muslims To Retaliate If U.S. Attacks
description: The spiritual leader of the Palestinian group Hamas instructed Muslims worldwide today to retaliate against ''Western interests'' if the United States made war on Iraq.

title: Minus Brylin, Devils Appear Lost on Ice
description: The loss of Sergei Brylin for about three months will surely hurt the Devils. It won't be easy to replace Brylin, their versatile Russian right wing, unless they acquire someone of his caliber or another of the Devils' players lifts his game and fills his role on the team's invaluable checking line.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Feb. 3 about financial challenges confronting the Women's National Basketball Association and the Women's United Soccer Association misstated the average attendance for the W.N.B.A. last season. It was 9,228, not 8,500.

title: Logistics and Criticism in Panel's First Week
description: The board that NASA named to head the investigation into the Columbia disaster devoted much of its first week to arguments over its mission and membership. Then its members went home today for the weekend, even as some lawmakers in Washington continued to press for changes they said were needed to bring about a more independent and credible inquiry.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Cable Executive Named
description: Net, the cable arm of the television giant Globo, named Francisco Tosta Valim Filho as its chief executive in the latest effort to shore up the debt-laden company. Mr. Valim, the former finance director at the telephone company Tele Norte Leste Participaes, or Telemar, replaces Luiz Antonio Viana who held the office only 15 months before resigning last month. After defaulting in December, Net is struggling to reschedule its dollar debt, bloated by a 35 percent devaluation in the real last year. The company has also been hurt by the moribund Brazilian economy. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: A Champion of Women, and a Defender of Girls
description: WITH her crisp greeting, Kim Kang Ja whisks a visitor through a narrow side office, where her four male assistants work, and into a comfortable chair in her own roomy private sanctum.

title: The Tiresome Tuition Game at SUNY
description: January proved to be a painful month for the State University of New York. First, its trustees called for an increase of $1,400 in undergraduate tuition, the first in seven years. Then, Gov. George E. Pataki called for huge cuts in higher education spending in his budget plan. Taken together, the developments are a sad admission that the budget process for New York's public higher education system remains seriously flawed.

title: Is War With Iraq Inevitable?
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: G.I. Shot Himself
description: An American soldier who had said he was wounded by gunfire this week on his way to a barracks in Schweinfurt, 60 miles east of Frankfurt, has admitted that he shot himself in the left hand and leg, the German police said. The soldier, a 32-year-old private first class from the First Infantry Division, initially told the police an attacker had fired at him four or five times. The soldier has a history of depression, the police said. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Agrilink Foods to Close 6 Processing Plants
description: Agrilink Foods Inc., the maker of Birds Eye vegetables, said yesterday that it would close six frozen-vegetable processing plants and lay off about 260 employees to cut costs.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Front Row column of the Fashion page on Tuesday about preparations for New York Fashion Week referred incorrectly to the twins who design the Palmer Jones line. Only one, Kathryn Jones, was formerly an assistant to Ralph Lauren; her sister, Lindy Jones, was not.

title: Bush and the Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: In New York, a New Array of Safeguards Take Effect
description: In New York, museums, transportation terminals, hotels and the subway system were put on high alert yesterday as officials across the country responded to reports that terrorists might be planning to attack American targets.

title: Price of Oil Hits 26-Month High After Bush's Comments on Iraq
description: Crude oil rose to a 26-month high yesterday after President Bush said that the United Nations Security Council must enforce its resolution on disarming Iraq.

title: U.N. Warns of Mideast Conflict's Harm to the Environment
description: The conflict in the Middle East is having grave effects on the environment of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, delegates at a United Nations environmental conference here agreed today. They urged the Israelis and Palestinians to work jointly to reduce the damage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCKSTEIN, ROCHELLE J.
description: BUCKSTEIN-Rochelle J., 61. Of Boca Raton, formerly of New York, passed away Thursday, February 6, 2003. Loving daughter and daughter-in-law. Beloved wife of Mark, devoted mother of Michael and Robin (Michael) Stier. Joyous grandmother of Jason, Jared and Talia. Loved by her extended family of brothers, sisters-in -law, nephews and nieces. As the wind beneath the wings of all who knew her she will always be remembered and cherished as a loving and caring friend. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Hospice By The Sea, Boca Raton, where she spent many days caring for the infirm and where she spent her last peaceful days with us, will be appreciated. Funeral services will be tomorrow, February 9, 2003, at Levitt Weinstein Memorial Chapel, Coconut Creek, Fl. at 9:30AM. Interment to follow at Eternal Light Memorial Gardens, Boynton Beach.

title: Bad Seed or Bad Science?
description: For more than a century, the Jukes clan has been presented as America's most despised family. Social science researchers long believed they were a case study of dysfunction, a bunch of genetically linked paupers, criminals, harlots, epileptics and mental defectives, whose care had placed a huge financial burden on taxpayers. The family's pedigree was used for decades as a textbook example of how heredity shaped human behavior and helped lead to calls for compulsory sterilization, segregation, lobotomies and even euthanasia against the ''unfit.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Wind Power Increases
description: Wind power in Europe increased by 33 percent in 2002 to reach a total capacity of 23,000 megawatts, or the equivalent of several large nuclear energy plants, the European Wind Energy Association reported. The group said Europe was the world's fastest-growing region for wind energy. Wind power last year represented a $6 billion market. Germany, Spain and Denmark accounted for almost 90 percent of it. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: A Tumult From the Piano
description: The pianist Jacky Terrasson seemed abristle with nervous energy on Tuesday night at the Village Vanguard, and his early set rose up out of silence, his slow left-hand ideas offsetting a fast right hand that made strips of melody flutter and then fall. He and his trio played in this vein continuously -- with pauses but without properly stopping for applause -- until the end, 75 minutes later.

title: Is War With Iraq Inevitable?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Areport in the World Briefing column on Jan. 23 about the nomination of Goh Kun for prime minister in South Korea misstated his political affiliation. He is independent, not a member of the opposition Grand National Party.

title: SBC Said to Be in Talks to Buy DirecTV
description: With its core local phone business in decline, SBC Communications has entered serious negotiations to acquire the DirecTV satellite television operation of General Motors in a deal that could be worth more than $10 billion, people close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Is War With Iraq Inevitable?
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHERING-PLOUGH WILL LICENSE PATENT TO THREE RIVERS
description: The Schering-Plough Corporation said yesterday that it would license patents on its ribavirin hepatitis C treatment to Three Rivers Pharmaceuticals to settle patent litigation between the companies. The closely held Three Rivers will pay an undisclosed amount in royalties on its ribavirin sales, Schering-Plough said. Schering-Plough and ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc. together hold patents that cover the hepatitis treatment. Schering-Plough had sued to block Three Rivers from introducing its version of the medicine. Three Rivers is based in the Pittsburgh suburb of Cranberry Township, Pa., and Schering-Plough is based in Kenilworth, N.J.

title: For Salt Mine, Snowy Weather Leads to a Financial Bonanza
description: At least one place in New York State has more business than it can handle and balmy weather all the time.

title: Polish Town Still Tries To Forget Its Dark Past
description: This is a small rural town in denial, although the facts are now clear.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Insider Trading
description: A Swiss billionaire, Thomas Schmidheiny, who controls the cement maker Holcim Ltd. quit as chairman after being fined in Spain to settle charges of insider trading. Mr. Schmidheiny, 57, will remain on Holcim's board, according to the company, which is based in Jona, Switzerland. Willy Kissling will stay on as interim chairman until June 4, when the company holds its annual shareholders' meeting. Mr. Schmidheiny stepped down after paying a fine of 1.46 million euros ($1.57 million) to settle the case, a spokesman, Joerg Denzler, said. The fine ends an investigation into Mr. Schmidheiny's December 2000 acquisition of a minority stake in a Spanish zinc producer, Asturiana de Zinc, after learning of a pending takeover bid by Xstrata, a mining company where he was a board member.

title: Lord Aberconway, 89, Met With Gring Secretly in '39
description: Lord Aberconway, once a major British industrialist who built the Queen Elizabeth 2 ocean liner and who in 1939 took part in a secret meeting with Hitler's close aide Hermann Gring, died on Tuesday in London. He was 89.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOCKNOFF, ALAN R.
description: STOCKNOFF-Alan R. On February 2, 2003. Beloved husband of Linda. Loving father of Michele and Michael. Devoted brother of Rhoda Friedland, brother-in-law of Stuart Friedland, uncle of Michael, Laurie, Lisa and Edward, grand-uncle of William, Matthew, Adam, Peter and Andy. May his entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Services will be held Sunday, 10 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Five Inches of Snow Seems More of a Burden Beyond the City Line
description: His fenders were filled with it, his brakes covered in it: snow. But Franois Bureau just kept going. Not at the wheel of a four-wheel-drive monster that could bulldoze its way through any kind of weather. Mr. Bureau was whizzing down Varick Street toward the Holland Tunnel on a 21-speed racing bike.

title: Court Is Told Tyco Deals Had Backing of Auditors
description: The criminal cases against Tyco International's former top executives took an unusual turn yesterday when prosecutors acknowledged in court that the company's auditors, PricewaterhouseCoopers, had approved many of the transactions that are now in question.

title: Landing Site Is Setting For Tribute
description: The Columbia's seven astronauts were honored here this morning in a memorial service on the runway where the shuttle should have landed last Saturday.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: G.I. SHOT HIMSELF An American soldier who had said he was wounded by gunfire this week on his way to a barracks in Schweinfurt, 60 miles east of Frankfurt, has admitted that he shot himself in the left hand and leg, the German police said. The soldier, a 32-year-old private first class from the First Infantry Division, initially told the police an attacker had fired at him four or five times. The soldier has a history of depression, the police said. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Cold and Foam Are Called a Dangerous Mix
description: The large chunk of foam insulation that flew off the shuttle Columbia's 15-story external fuel tank and hit its left wing during blastoff may have been stronger and more dangerous than NASA realized, an expert on synthetic materials has warned the federal board investigating the disaster.

title: For Yao, Lights, Cameras and an All-Star Frenzy
description: The boom mikes bounced just above his head, and the white-hot camera lights blinded his eyes as television crews and photographers rushed backward in a cavalcade to capture his entrance.

title: P. Diddy Signs 3-Year Deal With Universal Records
description: The hip-hop executive Sean (P. Diddy) Combs, signed a basic three-year distribution deal with Universal Records yesterday. The deal is a far cry from the $100 million agreement that he was seeking eight months ago to sell his label outright, signaling that Mr. Combs has to prove himself to come near that sum, people close to the negotiations said.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the World Briefing column on Jan. 23 about the nomination of Goh Kun for prime minister in South Korea misstated his political affiliation. He is independent, not a member of the opposition Grand National Party.

title: Sports of The Times; The U.S.O.C. Should Simply Start Over
description: TODAY in Chicago, the United States Olympic Committee's executive committee will attempt to pick up the pieces of the organization's shattered credibility.

title: German Bank Is Showing Mixed Results
description: Nine months after he took the helm of Deutsche Bank, the Swiss chief executive, Josef Ackermann, said today that he had transformed the bloated, vulnerable German giant into a leaner, healthier outfit -- one poised to catch the next wave of growth.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank To Raise Capital
description: A leading Japanese bank, the Mitsubishi Tokyo Financial Group, plans to sell common stock in hopes of raising as much as 300 billion yen ($2.5 billion). The bank, the largest in Japan by market value, will issue 454,000 new shares and sell another 155,027 shares held by its subsidiaries. Mitsubishi Tokyo and other large bank groups are trying to raise capital to help offset the write-off of nonperforming loans. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about a tax shelter used by top executives of the Sprint Corporation misstated the name of a law firm of a tax partner who predicted that the Internal Revenue Service would question the design of the shelter. It is Morrison & Foerster, not Foerster & Morrison.

title: Pension Costs May Widen Budget Gap In New York
description: Because of sharply rising pension costs, next year's state budget gap could be $700 million larger than the Pataki administration had expected, according to figures released today by the state comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi.

title: Arrest in Holdup at College
description: The police arrested a 25-year-old Brooklyn man yesterday, charging him with stealing $74,000 and two guns from security guards trying to refill a cash machine on Tuesday at Long Island University.

title: JOB MARKET SHOWS A RISE IN JANUARY
description: The job market showed unexpected signs of improvement last month, relieving worries that the country could be slipping into a new recession. The unemployment rate fell to 5.7 percent in January, from 6 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LENARD, FRANCES
description: LENARD-Frances. On February 5, 2003, peacefully at home in Highland Park, NJ. Beloved wife of the late George, devoted mother of John and Thomas, cherished grandmother of Eric, Keith, Karen, Steven, Julie and Michael, great-grandmother of Ruby Frances. She will be missed.

title: 'SIGNIFICANT' PIECE OF SHUTTLE'S WING IS FOUND IN TEXAS
description: The space agency today found what investigators called a ''significant'' section of one of the space shuttle's wings, including the hardened leading-edge material and heat-resistant tiles that are among the leading suspects in the accident that killed the crew of the Columbia six days ago.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: Bribery Charges
description: Three members of Congress, stripped of parliamentary immunity last month in connection with a widening corruption scandal that has shaken the Socialist government of President Ricardo Lagos, have been arrested on charges of demanding bribes in return for awarding government contracts. Their imprisonment comes a month after a former minister of public works and two others were detained on fraud charges in a separate scandal in the country that prides itself on being the most honest in Latin America. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Bush Orders Increased Alert for Terrorist Attacks in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  The Bush administration today put the nation on a "high" terror alert for only the second time since the Sept. 11 attacks, warning Americans that Al Qaeda may be planning attacks on hotels, apartment buildings and other vulnerable targets in the United States.

title: Some Agencies' Increased Efforts
description: With the national alert level raised to orange, indicating a high risk of terrorist attacks, many of the federal agencies that will become part of the new Department of Homeland Security on March 1 are taking additional protective steps. Some representative examples are these:

title: Pentagon Forms 2 Panels To Allay Fears on Spying
description: The Defense Department established two new advisory committees today as it sought to curb fears about domestic spying by its Total Information Awareness program and to keep Congress from supervising the program closely.

title: Ivoirian Leader Urges Supporters To Give Peace Accord a Chance
description: While his supporters rampaged through the streets here in defiance of a French-brokered peace deal, the Ivoirian president, Laurent Gbagbo, tonight broke nearly two weeks of silence and beseeched his people to accept the accord.

title: DeLay Denies Role in Letter Riling Unions
description: Representative Tom DeLay, the House majority leader, yesterday disavowed an anti-union fund-raising letter that bears his signature after several union leaders condemned the letter because it accuses ''big labor bosses'' of seeking to expand their power at the expense of national security.

description: A storm of liberal criticism erupted today over a Justice Department draft of legislation to increase the law enforcement powers it won in 2001 in the U.S.A. Patriot Act.

title: Wife Testifies She Was 'in a Fog' Just Before Her Car Struck Husband
description: A former beauty queen on trial for murder in the death of her husband testified today that she was ''in a fog'' when she drove toward him in her car, and that she had no intention of running over him and killing him.

title: As Vaccination Rates Decline in Ireland, Cases of Measles Soar
description: When a British scientist published research five years ago suggesting a link between autism and a common childhood measles vaccine, the news caused a wave of fear among parents and a steep decline in vaccination rates.

description: HEALY-Eleanor B. (nee Berg). Age 90, of Sag Harbor, Long Island, NY. Formerly of New York City, on February 2, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Martin E. title: Justice Department Will Appeal Ruling in Trial Linked to 9/11
description: The Justice Department has asked a federal court to suspend preparations for the trial of Zacarias Moussaoui and will appeal a secret court ruling that would allow Mr. Moussaoui's lawyers to interrogate a captured leader of Al Qaeda, according to court papers filed today and people who have access to classified information about the case.

title: The Rural Life; Under the Glacier
description: ''An old-fashioned winter,'' you hear people saying, as though the snow were falling or the mercury dropping to the sound of sleigh bells. On a bright blowing day, the air fills almost invisibly with particles of snow that catch the sunlight. They look like the stars you see when you stand up too quickly. At night the moon coasts through the sky like the source of cold, shedding its beams on a frozen world that the sun is powerless to warm when it finally rises.

title: Barge Strikes Railroad Bridge, Forcing Amtrak to Detour Trains
description: A barge carrying gravel up the Harlem River struck the Spuyten Duyvil railroad bridge yesterday, disrupting Amtrak service to upstate New York and closing the Harlem River to all boat traffic, the authorities said.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the National Briefing column yesterday about the decision of a circuit court in Fairfax County, Va., that lawyers for Lee Malvo, a defendant in the Washington area sniper shootings, must make public a list of potential expert witnesses misspelled the surname of the judge. She is Jane Marum Roush, not Rousch.

Officials at Floral Park Memorial High School in Nassau County say no one named Kevin Dunn attends the school.

title: When Normalcy's a Goal, Not Just How Things Are
description: When Ricardo Thornton was a little boy, a woman in social services asked him if he knew what a city was or what a country was. Then she asked him to name three cities. When he didn't answer, she sent him off to Forest Haven, an institution for the developmentally disabled, to his shame.

title: Blake Helps U.S. Salvage First Day of Davis Cup
description: Ivan Ljubicic made a good point after he dispatched Mardy Fish, 7-5, 6-3, 6-4, to give Croatia an early advantage over the United States in their Davis Cup first-round match today.

title: Among California's S.U.V. Owners, Only a Bit of Guilt in a New 'Anti' Effort
description: Encased in a massive black Toyota Land Cruiser, Shirley Collenette admits feeling a little guilty about her gas-guzzling, smog-inducing, planet-warming, road-hogging ''armor,'' as she calls her sport utility vehicle.

title: Government Report Says Wood Playsets Pose a Cancer Risk
description: Scientists at the Consumer Products Safety Commission said today that children playing on millions of outdoor wood playground sets nationwide face an increased risk of bladder and lung cancer from arsenic exposure.

title: Similar Colleges Play Same Game So Differently
description: It is a short drive from Manhattan College to Fordham University, about three miles. In some ways, the two colleges are even closer than that. They have relatively small campuses in the Bronx, their emphasis is on a quality Catholic education, and their students scurry to buildings that seem untouched since they were built in the mid-1800's.

title: Official Urges Delay in Choice Of Developer for Arena Site
description: The Republican co-president of the State Senate called on the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority today to put off its selection, scheduled for next week, of a redevelopment plan and developer for the Continental Arena site in the Meadowlands and hold a series of public hearings on the three finalists' plans.

title: Bush Urges Chinese President To Press North Korea on Arms
description: President Bush urged President Jiang Zemin of China today to help resolve the crisis with North Korea, telling him in a phone conversation that Beijing had a responsibility to prevent the North from developing nuclear weapons that could threaten much of Asia.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Job Market Turns Flat
description: After a year of buoyant growth, Canada's job market turned flat in January, with 34,400 new full-time jobs offset by the loss of 36,500 part-time positions, Statistics Canada said. The unemployment rate fell to 7.4 percent from 7.5 percent in December. Less dependent on technology industries, Canda's economy has been more robust than that of the United States recently. But with the United States accounting for 85 percent of Canada's exports, recent data has pointed to a slowdown in Canada. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Education Reform Left Behind
description: George W. Bush's promise to end ''the soft bigotry of low expectations'' that allows poor children to fall permanently behind at school was one of his most popular campaign themes. Americans who view education as the country's top priority were further encouraged when Congress passed President Bush's ''No Child Left Behind'' act one year ago, promising to erase the achievement gap between rich and poor students. But the presidential budget unveiled last week drops the ball. The money earmarked for aid to the country's poorest students is about 30 percent, or $6 billion, less than Congress called for last year.

description: Cardinal Bernard F. Law, who resigned as archbishop of Boston in December because of his mishandling of accusations of sexual abuse by members of the clergy, said he would leave Boston, at least temporarily, to live with an order of nuns in suburban Maryland. The nuns, the Sisters of Mercy of Alma, are a conservative religious order. ''It is my hope to be of assistance to the sisters as a chaplain,'' Cardinal Law said. Pam Belluck (NYT)

description: The spiritual leader of the Palestinian group Hamas, Sheik Ahmed Yassin, has instructed Muslims worldwide to retaliate against ''Western interests'' if the United States makes war on Iraq. Hamas leaders had previously said they would not widen their conflict with Israel to focus on Americans and other Westerners.

title: Higher Profit for Asiana
description: Asiana Airlines, the second-largest Korean airline behind Korean Air, said today that it had net income for 2002 of 194 billion won ($164.4 million) and an operating profit of 177 billion won, four times higher than the year before. Asiana had a net income of 132.2 billion won ($112 million) in the fourth quarter after losing 193.6 billion won in the 2001 period. The higher profits were due to expanded service on routes to China and Japan and the rising value of the won, which meant lower fuel prices.

title: Side by Side, Anguished Challenges to Convention
description: Edward Albee turns 75 next month, an occasion that the Alley Theater here has chosen to celebrate with an unusual pairing of plays. Or maybe it just wanted to do the plays and named the birthday as an appropriate occasion. In any case, its concurrent productions -- both excellent -- of Mr. Albee's most famous work, ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?,'' and his most recent, ''The Goat, or Who Is Sylvia?,'' provide a unique perspective on the career of one of our most accomplished playwrights.

title: Incoming Port Chairman Is Named in Lawsuit
description: A former employee says in a federal lawsuit that the developer who is in line to become chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey doctored the books and misappropriated funds at the real estate partnerships he controls.

title: World Business Briefing: Americas
description: CANADA: HEARING ON BANK MERGERS The chief executives of three of Canada's biggest banks told a parliamentary committee in Ottawa that merger and takeover curbs should be eased to enable their institutions to expand more aggressively in the United States. The Canadian government has thwarted several merger attempts among the banks in recent years amid concerns that further consolidation would give them too much power and lead to huge job losses. Peter Godsoe, chairman of the Bank of Nova Scotia , told the committee that banks merge to increase scale, to diversify and grow outside Canada.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROOKS, SHELDON VON HAGEN
description: BROOKS-Sheldon von Hagen, 82. Of Key Largo, Florida, formerly of Wayzata, Minnesota died Saturday, February 1, 2003 at his home in Key Largo from complications of prostate cancer. Born in Minneapolis January 10, 1921, son of Paul Andros and Hazel von Hagen Brooks, he attended the Blake School, Hotchkiss and graduated from The Thacher School in 1939. A member of the Yale Class of '43, during World War II, Mr. Brooks served in the Navy Air Corps first as an instructor at Pensacola and later in the Pacific Theater flying for the Naval Air Transport Service. After the war, he was for 35 years the owner of the Minnetonka Boat Works, retiring in 1985. He was preceded in death by his parents, his sisters Polly Brooks Hollern, Barbara Brooks Kroos and his brother Anson Brooks. He is survived by Carroll, his wife of twentyone years, three children of a previous marriage to the late Frances Atkinson Hewitt, Paul Andros (Pam) Brooks, Sky Atkinson Brooks, Molly Moyer Brooks his sister, Stanley Brooks Gregory and four grandchildren. Mr. Brooks was a member of the Key Largo Anglers Club, the Ocean Reef Club, Woodhill Country Club, Shikar Safari Club International, The Bohemian Club, Quiet Birdmen and numerous conservation organizations. Contributions in his memory to the Ocean Reef Medical Center Foundation, Ocean Reef Drive, Key Largo, Florida 33037 or the Ridgeview Medical Center Foundation in C/O of Robert Stevens, 500 South Maple Street, Waconia, Minnesota, 55387 would be greatly appreciated. There will be a memorial service at a later date.

Ms. Fantham, 69, is National Public Radio's mischievous, fruity-voiced classics commentator on ''Weekend Edition,'' and her specialty is drawing parallels between the ancient world and us.

title: To Serve and Persuade
description: BRISTOL, facing a reduced city budget that could prevent it from purchasing new police cars, is about to vote on a proposal that would let it get the cars without spending a dime of taxpayers' money. But as with many breathless offers that sound too good to be true, there is indeed a catch: the cars would have to carry advertisements. The city would receive the cars through Government Acquisitions Inc., a Charlotte, N.C., company that offers the program. John DiVenere, the city police chief, has proposed the idea because he has received only four of the 11 new cars he needs. He said police cars, which cost around $28,000 each and average 80,000 to 100,00 miles per year, must be replaced every year.

The songs, like the man himself, are witty, acerbic, sometimes touching, often poetic and always great rock 'n' roll. Classically trained, with a literary sensibility and a prankster's sense of humor, he is truly a unique individual in rock's short history. His recent Letterman appearance and his efforts to turn out one more album are much appreciated by his fans.

Whenever the date rolls around, it also brings the joy and angst of New Year's -- the anticipation of thrills in counterpoint to the dread of not having a date or a place to go, or of a festivity at your place. And then, if it's at your place, what to serve?

Sometimes you want a good bowl of tom kha kai, the soul-soothing chicken soup smoothed by coconut milk and fired with galanga, kaffir lime leaves, lime juice, fresh chilies, fish sauce and cilantro. Sometimes you want stir-fried watercress, its leaves barely wilted, its stems tenderly crunchy, its bite mellowed by a bit of garlic and oyster sauce.

title: Destined For Failure
description: On weekday mornings, after a hurried breakfast of frozen waffles and scrambled eggs and a two-block dash through the neighborhood crush of strollers and briefcases, my 6-year-old son slips his backpack over his shoulders, grants me a desultory hug and passes through the double doors of the school bus into the care of the New York City public school system. He is the apple of my eye, my hostage to fortune, every sentimental paternal clich you can think of and also, like every other child on the bus, a pawn in an endless political chess game. Along with the peanut butter and jelly sandwich and last night's homework, that blue nylon school bag is weighted down with a century's worth of ideological baggage. And my own parochial parental anxieties -- Is he happy? Is he learning? Is he making friends? -- are, whether I like it or not, shrill notes in a cacophony of political contention, along with the thundering of officeholders, the rumbling of bureaucrats and the horn bleats of think-tank intellectuals.

title: The Interior Designer
description: Alexandra Champalimaud adores rich colors and luxe fabrics -- witness the lobby of the Algonquin Hotel in New York, which she refurbished in 1998. Since then, Ms. Champalimaud, an interior designer and the president of Alexandra Champalimaud & Associates in New York (the business also includes architecture) has left her mark on the Marriott Financial Center and the Embassy Suites in Lower Manhattan, as well as at the Hilton Times Square. She is now renovating the swanky Berkeley Hotel in London. Ms. Champalimaud, who was born in Lisbon and studied in Montreal, views getting dressed and transforming a space similarly. ''I love layering textures and bringing different designers and cultures together in an eclectic but sophisticated way,'' she said. As a result, her everyday outfits tend to be an elegant hodgepodge of patterns and hues. Here, she wears a Marni blouse under a nubby Lanvin coat with silver pailettes dangling from the sleeves; a Missoni scarf; a khaki-colored denim skirt from Christian Dior; brown fishnet stockings from Wolford; and green suede Prada pumps. She bought her red gloves in London; the crocodile Kelly bag from Herms is 15 years old. And while Ms. Champalimaud prefers, she said, not to think in seasons, she did concede that she will most likely veto wearing miniskirts come spring. ''Other women,'' she said, ''would look a lot better in them than I would.'' JENNIFER TUNG

title: 3BR w/Vu, Small Kitchen
description: Daniel Boulud says his classic-six apartment on 65th Street and Park Avenue, above his restaurant Daniel, lacks one essential ingredient: a good kitchen. His is so small and boxy that he rarely uses it for anything other than making coffee. ''My dream was to extend the kitchen onto the terrace and build a glass roof over it,'' he says. ''But the building wouldn't let me.'' Boulud, who also owns DB Bistro Moderne and Caf Boulud, has lived in his three-bedroom home for the last five years. And while he appreciates his two-story commute to work, which keeps him close to his wife and 13-year-old daughter, it's in his nature to tinker. His list of projects includes painting the white walls a warmer color, converting the guest bedroom into an office to store his cookbooks and Cognacs and replacing the old zebra-print couch in the den. ''That couch, how do you say it? It's trashed.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, JILL WARREN (MARY AUDREY ROCHLEN)
description: GREENBERG-Jill Warren (Mary Audrey Rochlen). Beloved mother of Peter Greenberg and Dr. Karen Greenberg Rudman. Wife of the late Dr. Sidney Greenberg. Sister of Kendis, David, Hartwell, Gail and the late Donald Rochlen and a longtime devoted friend of Lucille Fore, died on February 7, 2003, at her home in Manhattan. The daughter of journalist and aviation industry pioneer A.M. Rochlen, she was born July 4, 1915 in Los Angeles. She was an actress, singer, a magazine and newspaper journalist, and for many years a real estate broker in Manhattan and Fire Island, NY. She had boundless energy and an extraordinary spirit that touched and enriched countless lives. A selfless woman devoted to her siblings and her children, her legacy is a life eternally distinguished by not merely being interesting. For she was a great story teller and philosopher-but of being interested in the stories and philosophies of everyone she ever met. She is survived by her son, daughter, and son-in-law Richard Rudman. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, February 15, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. We will love her always.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOVEY, FRANK ALDEN
description: BOVEY-Frank Alden. Died January 19 at Warner, NH. Born in Minneapolis, the son of John and Margaret (Jackson) Bovey, he graduated from the Blake School, Harvard University and received a doctorate from the University of Minnesota. He was a research chemist and the head of the Polymer and Chemistry Research Department at Bell Laboratories in Murray Hill, NJ. He also worked at 3M where his team invented scotch guard. During W.W. II, he originated the formula for manufacturing artificial rubber. He was a candidate for the Nobel Prize in chemistry and a member of the National Academy of Sciences. He was the author of six books and 100 articles dealing with nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy and the structure of polymers. He also lectured at MIT and throughout the world. Survivors include two daughters Margaret Bovy Glassman of Amherst, MA., and Victoria Bovey of Bernardsville, NJ; a son, Peter Bovey of Oak Park, IL; seven grandchildren and two great grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

By week's end, it seemed increasingly clear that whatever went wrong to cause the death of seven asronauts, it happened on the left side, and that by 8:59 a.m. Feb. 1 parts of the wing were shearing off the Columbia and falling on central Texas. description: KURRELMEYER - Nancy Snow. Of Whiting, Vermont, died unexpectedly at home Saturday, February 1, 2003 at the age of 40. She attended The Brearley School in NYC and was a graduate of the University of Vermont, BS in Mathematics, and The Ohio State University, MS in Mathematics. She worked as a Scientist, Mathematician, Economist, Technical and Business Analyst for the Central intelligence Agency and a variety of Fortune 100 corporations including Exxon, ADP and Schering-Plough. Why do we care about that? The memory of a person's name is all we need to get our basic question going: Is there room for an ethics of memory?

But this 58-year-old former truck driver from Fredericksburg, Ohio, and other investors like him, have become one big nightmare for Wall Street. Mr. Wolfe sued Merrill Lynch last year over $172,000 in stock market losses in his 401(k) plan, and last month, arbitrators awarded him $310,000, including legal expenses.

title: In the Gray Zone
description: THE latest biographer of Otto Frank, Anne Frank's father, says she has identified the man who betrayed him, as well as Anne, her mother, her sister and the four others who hid from the Nazis for 25 months in the tiny warehouse annex in Amsterdam. The culprit was Anton Ahlers, a Dutch thug turned Nazi who knew Otto Frank because he had once blackmailed him. The biographer also speculates that Ahlers blackmailed Frank again after he came back from Auschwitz in 1945. This time the blackmail may have gone on for decades, and Frank may have protected his tormentor from Nazi hunters and Dutch police.

title: All Spent
description: When Sheila Wessenberg's breast cancer was diagnosed and she needed a lumpectomy and then a mastectomy, her husband Bob's insurance covered her care. Then Bob lost his job in December 2001, and they and their two children went from living comfortably on his $102,000-a-year salary to facing bankruptcy. They managed to pay for health insurance out of pocket for six months, until the premiums jumped to $832 a month. After being rejected for Medicaid because they had too many assets, the Wessenbergs joined the ranks of the 41 million uninsured Americans. Sheila, who was forced to quit chemotherapy midtreatment, is tempting the odds.

Loved forever.

title: Full Disclosure
description: Your article opens with a sidebar quoting my book ''The Intimate Hour.'' Although we may agree on the problem, I do not endorse Slater's solution. She suggests that to stymie a small minority of clinicians from seducing a patient and to prevent a larger minority from burdening patients with personal information, we should video- or audiotape all sessions. The solution is worse than the problem, as it would disable one of therapy's active ingredients -- confession.

Mr. Barton said last week that he would soon step down as chief executive of Expedia, the biggest online travel agency, so he could spend a year in Europe with his family.

description: The United States Olympic Committee today stripped Lloyd Ward, its chief executive, of the $184,800 bonus he earned in 2002 because he violated the organization's ethics code. The money will be spent on programs for athletes.

title: February 2-8: NATIONAL; PREGNANCY ADVANCES
description: Doctors conducting a nationwide study announced that they had devised the first treatment that has ever succeeded in preventing premature births. They found that weekly shots of a form of the hormone progesterone lowered the rate of premature births by more than a third. Nearly half a million babies are born too early in the United States every year. Prematurity is a leading cause of newborn death, cerebral palsy, mental retardation, hearing loss and blindness. Denise Grady

Restrained and a little stiff, he speaks in the dry tones and jargon-filled language of a technocrat on such obscure topics as 1958 American oil regulations or 1930's energy policies in Venezuela.

title: In (Self-)Defense Of the Fanatical Sports Parent

There were times when I resisted him, when I wanted to get a life instead of going to my second workout of the day. Now I am 33 and in good shape, and pick up activities and new tasks easily and with little self-doubt. My father expected me to work hard, with no excuses. The goal was always to do your personal best.

title: Facing Off for the America's Cup
description: Team New Zealand's defense of the America's Cup begins Saturday against Switzerland's Alinghi team. At stake is the Auld Mug, which was awarded to the New York Yacht Club in 1851, when the yacht America defeated England in what was then called the 100 Guineas Cup. The New York Yacht Club held the Cup for 132 years, until Australia II defeated Dennis Conner's Stars & Stripes in 1983. New Zealand is the only nation other than the United States to successfully defend the Cup. A look at the race and its competitors. Warren St. John

title: Images of Celebrities From a Raucous Era
description: THIS is, emphatically, the age of personality'' wrote the poet Samuel Taylor Coleridge. He was referring to the Regency period in Great Britain, those rowdy decades from about 1790 to the accession of Queen Victoria in 1837, when abundant cleavage was in, powdered wigs were out, and almost every sphere of life was turned on its head by scientific discovery, political reform, artistic experimentation, rebellion and war. It was also the era of popular celebrity, when commoners rose on their own efforts to the renown of kings.

Hill II, also gave the school 5,000 Commerce shares from his personal trust fund.

Ms. Vega reached into a feed bag and tossed out handfuls of grain. Her menagerie nibbled and pecked, then ambled after her across the frozen, rocky dirt backyard that doubles as pasture, bordered with corrals, pigpens and dog sheds.

title: Full Disclosure
description: Lauren Slater (The Way We Live Now, Jan. 26) proposes that psychiatrists and clinical psychologists offer tape recordings, videotapes and case files for peer review. The notion that you can't trust your own doctor but you can trust the entire profession is a dangerous leap of faith. Did the Catholic priesthood as a whole crack down on individual priests who abused their positions of power? Hardly. Why believe that mental-health professionals would not similarly protect their own, rather than those they supposedly serve? At the very least, confidentiality of the doctor-patient relationship would be shredded. Who wants to reveal his darkest thoughts with the office door open?

title: WILLIAMS TRIAL DELAYED
description: A state appellate court agreed last week to hear a motion by Jayson Williams, a former New Jersey Nets star, to dismiss manslaughter charges against him in the fatal shooting of a limousine driver at Mr. Williams's mansion in Hunterdon County. As a result, a trial that was to begin on Feb. 18 has been postponed. Arguments on the motion are scheduled for March 12. Mr. Williams says the prosecutors misled the grand jury about the accidental nature of the shooting. Lawyers for Mr. Williams also said on Wednesday that he had settled a civil lawsuit brought against him by the brother and sister of the driver, Costas Christofi, 55. Terms were not disclosed. The lawyers released a letter to Anthony Christofi, the brother, and Andrea Adams, the sister, in which Mr. Williams said he prayed each day for forgiveness for the shooting and begged for theirs. George James

title: Warehouse Is an Emblem Of Newest Waterfront Battles
description: Last year, debate over whether to put a Fairway supermarket in Red Hook landed a Brooklyn councilman in jail for attempted bribery. The Fairway is moving in, but Red Hook, like other parts of Brooklyn on the waterfront, is still the scene of skirmishes involving developers who envision lucrative lofts with river views, residents who worry about losing housing they can afford, and manufacturers who want to keep their industrial zones industrial.

title: Editors' Note; EDITORS' NOTE
description: An article on the Executive Life page last Sunday discussed the growing willingness of companies to fill board seats with younger executives who have little or no board experience. The article gave as one example Nicole W. Piasecki, 40, a vice president of Boeing Commercial Airlines, appointed in June to the board of Weyerhaeuser, the forest products company.

title: 2 Die in Brooklyn Blaze
description: Two people were killed yesterday afternoon in a fire the broke out shortly after 4 p.m. in their apartment at 519 Kings Highway in Brooklyn, the authorities said.

title: North Hempstead Vote On a District System
description: North Hempstead officials announced last week that a special election would be held on April 29 to ask voters whether town board members should be elected under a district system instead of the current at-large system.

title: In (Self-)Defense Of the Fanatical Sports Parent
description: Marino is right about one thing: no one ever achieves greatness without aspiring to it, and every high achiever has a megalomaniac either inside or behind him. Our culture is too comfortable in its leisure and mediocrity to readily accept that greatness demands sacrifice. And while no one generally enjoys being driven or disciplined, few who mount the pedestal would claim they were sorry that they went through what it took to get them there. It's worth wondering, however, in whose service and for whose glory the sacrifices are being made before appointing ourselves masters of our children's dreams.

title: Reagan's Son
description: With the perspective of history, those who so choose can now, with some credibility, see Ronald Reagan as a master communicator and politician who revitalized our nation's spirit and its economy. We can also realistically choose to credit him with boldly exposing the frailty of the Soviet Union and accelerating its demise.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LISKIN, LOUIS D.
description: LISKIN-Louis D., 87, of Englewood, NJ. Born on April 10, 1915 and passed away on February 5, 2003. Loving and beloved husband for 53 years of Anita. Father of David and Max and of Alisa Clausen and Diana Chapman and of his late daughter Dr. Barbara Ann Liskin. Grandfather of Elizabeth and Rebecca Bonagura and Helene Clausen. Devoted son of the late Ida Tobacznik Liskin and Joseph Liskin. Brother of the late beloved Max and Elliot. A founder and president of Standard Corrugated Case Corporation, Ridgefield, NJ; decorated veteran of World War II; longtime member of the Salmagundi Club. Private burial. Family will be receiving visitors Sunday through Thursday between 2PM & 7PM. No flowers or donations, please.

title: INVESTIGATION SOUGHT
description: A Camden activist, Frank Fulbrook, has asked federal prosecutors to investigate a possible conflict of interest in the state aid plan for the city. He argues that a provision of the $175 million plan would unfairly benefit CAMcare, a health-care corporation run by a brother of state Senator Wayne R. Bryant, a Democrat. Mark Bryant, president of CAMcare, has denied that argument. The corporation operates five health-care centers that serve about 24,000 patients a year. A spokesman for the United States attorney said the request was under review. Jeremy Pearce

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUNTOON, ANN DEAR
description: HUNTOON-Ann Dear. Quietly at home in Chappaqua, NY, on February 6, 2003. Beloved wife of Maxwell C. Huntoon, Jr. Loving mother of Carolyn Huntoon Connell of Arlington, VA, and Stephen Carpenter Huntoon of Manchester, NH. Devoted grandmother of Perry, Mollie, Ben and Emma. title: A Passion for the Blues Keeps Them Going
description: SAM TAYLOR, a member of the Blues Hall of Fame, is passionate about the music he has performed for most of his 68 years.

title: Belgium's Fashion Mecca
description: A SHOE sent me on my way to Antwerp. Brown and cloglike, with a toe that managed to be square, upturned and pointed all at once, it called to me from a display rack at Barney's a year or two ago. It looked as if it had been cobbled by elves. Greedily, I picked it up, discovered the designer's name, Dries van Noten, and the bad news -- 500 bucks.

title: Harold Ginsberg, Microbiologist, Dies at 85
description: Dr. Harold S. Ginsberg, a microbiologist whose research provided a foundation for the field of virology and expanded knowledge of infectious diseases, died on Feb. 2 in Woods Hole, Mass. He was 85.
