description: RANDOM FAMILY

title: In the Region/Long Island; Riverhead's Downtown Rebirth Proceeds, Slowly
description: WHILE planners in Riverhead say the town is a long way from fulfulling its nearly decade-old downtown revitalization plan, they also say there is visible evidence of progress this year, including a new bank, a restored music hall, a growing arts district and a zoning amendment favorable to retail tenants.

title: Rebels in Nepal Drive Down Tourism
description: A HALF-CENTURY after this Himalayan kingdom captured the world's attention in May 1953 with the bulletin that Sir Edmund Hillary had conquered Mount Everest, the news is mostly grim for a nation that still depends on mountaineers and other travelers from abroad for its economic vitality.

title: Some Unexpectedly Sunny State Economies
description: RISING costs for education, Medicaid and domestic security are deepening a fiscal crisis many states were already facing, according to a survey by the National Conference of State Legislatures. For the next budget year, which begins in June for most states, the aggregate shortfall could exceed $68 billion, the highest level since World War II and almost three times greater than projections for the current fiscal year.

title: Check That Label, Jake. I Think It's Chinatown.
description: ''Made in China.'' ''Made in Taiwan.'' ''Made in Vietnam.'' Sometimes even ''Made in India.''

title: In Cabs, Elmo And Friends Will Stop The Nagging
description: As a general rule, New Yorkers are required to tolerate a maddening barrage of chatter. It seems, for example, there is always someone at the local bar blathering into his cellphone.

title: When the Heart Sets the Itinerary
description: I WAS in my second year of college when I dropped out to chase a boy over to Europe. I hardly knew him; the idle rumor that he had once said he liked me provided enough spark to ignite the journey. Carefully I laid my plans. I wrote my parents of my unhappiness with school, the lack of challenge, my need for a break. I scrounged the air fare. I found a job waiting tables in a ski hotel outside Innsbruck, crammed Berlitz German, then dropped the fellow a casual line where he was studying in Vienna.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEPREE, JULIAN FRANCIS
description: DePREE-Julian Francis, 58. A resident of Lake Forest for 30 years, died unexpectedly February 1, 2003 in Lake Forest. He was born on March 9, 1944 in Mt. Kisco, NY. Husband of Joan Pillsbury DePree of Lake Forest, IL. Father of Katherine (Jess) DePree Belcher of Lake Bluff, IL, Edmund Austin DePree, Priscilla Rand DePree, and Spencer Pillsbury DePree of Lake Forest, IL. Grandfather of William Pillsbury Belcher. Son of Helen Clarke DePree of Louisville, KY. Brother of Robert DePree of Lake Forest, IL and Spencer DePree of Boulder, CO. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Lake Forest Open Lands, 350 Waukegan Road, Lake Forest, IL 60045. Memorial Service was held Thursday, February 6, 2003 at The Church of the Holy Spirit, 400 E. Westminster, Lake Forest, IL. Wenban Funeral Home, Lake Forest, 847/234-0022.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROOKS, SHELDON VON HAGEN
description: BROOKS-Sheldon von Hagen, 82. Of Key Largo, Florida, formerly of Wayzata, Minnesota died Saturday, February 1, 2003 at his home in Key Largo from complications of prostate cancer. Born in Minneapolis January 10, 1921, son of Paul Andros and Hazel von Hagen Brooks, he attended the Blake School, Hotchkiss and graduated from The Thacher School in 1939. A member of the Yale Class of '43, during World War II, Mr. Brooks served in the Navy Air Corps first as an instructor at Pensacola and later in the Pacific Theater flying for the Naval Air Transport Service. After the war, he was for 35 years the owner of the Minnetonka Boat Works, retiring in 1985. He was preceded in death by his parents, his sisters Polly Brooks Hollern, Barbara Brooks Kroos and his brother Anson Brooks. He is survived by Carroll, his wife of twentyone years, three children of a previous marriage to the late Frances Atkinson Hewitt, Paul Andros (Pam) Brooks, Sky Atkinson Brooks, Molly Moyer Brooks his sister, Stanley Brooks Gregory and four grandchildren. Mr. Brooks was a member of the Key Largo Anglers Club, the Ocean Reef Club, Woodhill Country Club, Shikar Safari Club International, The Bohemian Club, Quiet Birdmen and numerous conservation organizations. Contributions in his memory to the Ocean Reef Medical Center Foundation, Ocean Reef Drive, Key Largo, Florida 33037 or the Ridgeview Medical Center Foundation in C/O of Robert Stevens, 500 South Maple Street, Waconia, Minnesota, 55387 would be greatly appreciated. There will be a memorial service at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLIN, STEVE
description: CARLIN-Steve, 84. Died Tuesday, February 4, 2003 of the effects of Alzheimer's. Born in Brooklyn, the son of Russian immigrants, Steve was a brilliant, quiet, poetic man. His wife Peggy and his daughter Melissa loved him dearly and mourn his loss. He is survived by his brother Morty and his sisters Rose and Mabel. A television pioneer, Steve was in the forefront of television since its inception. Steve produced 19 television shows in the United States and six in Europe, including a children's program entitled ''Rootie Kazootie'', ''The $64,000 Question'' and ''Science All Stars'' which garnered an Emmy Nomination. ''Science All Stars'', was one of Steve's favorites; young people from 12 to 17 presented their scientific achievements. President Kennedy encouraged the endeavor on the first show, which also featured Colonel Chuck Jaeger, the first pilot to break through the sound barrier. In Italy, he created the first non-governmental TV show ''M'ama, Non M'ama'' (Love Me, Love Me Not) which was Number 1 on Italian Television for three years. In addition to the television shows, he also produced children's record albums for RCA Victor, featuring stars such as Joan Crawford, Jimmy Stewart, Danny Kaye, et al. ''Rootie Kazootie'', a TV favorite with children for several years, also became a series of Golden Books, distributed throughout the U.S. and Europe. Steve also wrote a Comic Strip, with artist Myron Waldman, entitled ''Happy the Humbug'' which appeared every Sunday for about 5 years as a full color page in newspapers all over the country. His many, good friends in the U.S. and Europe will miss Steve's understated humor, his wise observations and his devoted friendship. His beloved wife of 56 years, Peggy and daughter Melissa, missed him every day as Alzheimer's took him further and further away. They are bereft. A Memorial Service will be planned later in the year.

title: Solidly Feminist
description: To the Editor:

title: The Faithless Faith Worker
description: I am a member of the clergy (I will not identify the denomination), and I no longer believe in the tenets of my faith; indeed, I am an atheist. I am praised for my services, counseling, teaching, etc., and I receive glowing reports in staff reviews, but it is a futile, empty performance. On the one hand, my congregation is happy with me, but on the other, I feel like a fraud. Must I disclose my doubts to my congregation, knowing it would cost me my job? Anonymous

title: Business; Can Energy Ventures Pick Up Where Tech Left Off?
description: FOR Andrew Beebe, the light bulb went off almost two years ago at a computer technology conference in the Arizona desert. Mr. Beebe, who had just sold his profitable Internet start-up and was wondering what to do next, picked up a book on harnessing the sun's energy -- or, as he saw it, ''how to hack photosynthesis.''

title: Diva-Turned-Teacher to Open School Close to Home
description: RENATA SCOTTO, the glamorous diva who is celebrating her 50th year in opera, said her new relationship with the Music Conservatory of Westchester arose from a chance meeting with a neighbor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEE, IRWIN
description: ROSEE-Irwin. Family man, sports promoter, public relations genius, lover of life, eternal optimist and all around good guy. 93-1/2 years of excitement finally comes to an end. He's reminiscing with his old buddies now. Survived by his wife of 63 years Roslyn, children Marilyn and Richard, their spouses Sandra and Susan and grandchildren Eric and Jonathan. Donations can be made to Centra State Medical Center or New Jersey Library for the Blind. A memorial service to be announced.

title: A Woman of Power Was a Vowel Away
description: SOMETIMES the solution to a problem is so obvious that it's hard to see. Blair Brown, Tony Award winner, mid-career actress, thinks the solution to one longstanding problem may have been sitting there in plain sight all along: ''Instead of women of a certain age all complaining that there are no parts, just take the boys' parts from the boys.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JEHLE, FAUSTIN FRANCIS
description: JEHLE - Faustin Francis. Born September 16, 1914 in New York. Son of Anna and Augustus Jehle, died at the age of 88 in Palm Beach, Florida on January 21, 2003, from complications of cancer. He is survived by his loving and devoted wife of 54 years, Rosemary, by his three adoring daughters Michele, Patricia and Diane, by his son-inlaw Victor Somogyi and by his brother Philip Jehle. All who knew him will miss his playfulness and his gentle and generous spirit. He graduated St. John's Collge of Law with an LLB in 1937 and a Doctorate of Law in 1940. He served as Lieutenant Colonel with the 91st Infantry Division from 1942 until 1946. Among other decorations and citations, he was awared the Bronze Star in 1944 for outstanding service during the Italian campaign by Major General William G. Livesay. He was Associate General Counsel for McGraw-Hill Publishing Company for 29 years, retiring in 1979 to private practice in New York City before moving to Florida with his wife. In ''retirement,'' he authored ''The Complete and Easy Guide to Social Security, Health Care Rights and Government Benefits,'' which sold over 1 million copies of his 13 editions. A funeral mass will be held in New York City at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, at 11am, on February 13, 2003. A private military burial will be held on February 13, 2003 at 2:30PM, at the Calverton Veteran's Cemetery on Long Island, New York. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations are sent to the Hospice of Palm Beach County, which so lovingly cared for Mr. Jehle during his final days. Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, Florida 33407.

title: Tangled Up in Spam
description: I know what your in-box looks like, and it isn't pretty. It looks like mine: a babble of come-ons and lies from hucksters and con artists. To find your real e-mail, you must wade through the torrent of fraud and obscenity known politely as ''unsolicited bulk e-mail'' and colloquially as spam. In a perverse tribute to the power of the online revolution, we are all suddenly getting the same mail.

title: Milan
description: MILAN gets a bad rap from residents of Rome for its weather (more like London than Palermo) and for its propensity to put work before pleasure.

title: In Raves, an Israeli Finds His Woodstock
description: WHEN Tomer Ganihar first showed his photographs of Israeli raves to a New York curator a couple of years ago, she reacted incredulously to those images of dancing, praying, joyous young Israelis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAISSMAN, MONROE
description: RAISSMAN-Monroe. 83, of Mount Vernon, NY, passed away peacefully on February 7, 2003, in Boynton Beach, FL. Beloved husband of Doris. Devoted father of Laurel Perlman and Bob Raissman. Cherished grandfather of Rebecca and Billy Perlman. For three decades he was the proprietor of L. Raissman & Sons, a custom fur store in Manhattan, where he worked with his two brothers Renault and Jerome Raissman. Funeral services are private. The family will be at 23 Cherry Hill Road, Livingston, NJ, on Monday from 2 to 9 PM.

title: Magazine Editor's Bte Noire: News Trumps Story in the Works
description: Imagine Paige Rense's surprise when she picked up the newspapers last month to find that Gerald M. Levin was splitting with his wife of 32 years, Barbara Riley Levin.

title: How a Pathologically Blunt Producer Makes It in Suck-Up City
description: The surest way for a producer to pitch a TV show in Hollywood is to submit to mimicry, touting his idea as the next ''Frasier'' or ''Friends.'' The Gavin Polone way is to traffic in heresy. ''Shows like 'Friends' and 'Frasier,' which are aiming to be real yet are completely surreal, that's the kind of stuff I have a problem with,'' he says. ''I mean, you're 39 years old, and you're still living with your friends? It's pathetic!''

title: The Interior Designer
description: Alexandra Champalimaud adores rich colors and luxe fabrics  witness the lobby of the Algonquin Hotel in New York, which she refurbished in 1998. Since then, Ms. Champalimaud, an interior designer and the president of Alexandra Champalimaud & Associates in New York (the business also includes architecture) has left her mark on the Marriott Financial Center and the Embassy Suites in Lower Manhattan, as well as at the Hilton Times Square. She is now renovating the swanky Berkeley Hotel in London. Ms. Champalimaud, who was born in Lisbon and studied in Montreal, views getting dressed and transforming a space similarly. "I love layering textures and bringing different designers and cultures together in an eclectic but sophisticated way," she said. As a result, her everyday outfits tend to be an elegant hodgepodge of patterns and hues. Here, she wears a Marni blouse under a nubby Lanvin coat with silver pailettes dangling from the sleeves; a Missoni scarf; a khaki-colored denim skirt from Christian Dior; brown fishnet stockings from Wolford; and green suede Prada pumps. She bought her red gloves in London; the crocodile Kelly bag from Hermes is 15 years old. And while Ms. Champalimaud prefers, she said, not to think in seasons, she did concede that she will most likely veto wearing miniskirts come spring. "Other women," she said, "would look a lot better in them than I would." JENNIFER TUNG

title: Commercial Property; New Jersey Shipping Hubs Add Buildings
description: CRATE & BARREL, the home furnishings retail chain, recently signed up to be the sole user of a soon-to-be-built 675,000-square-foot warehouse and distribution center near Exit 8A of the New Jersey Turnpike and said it wanted to expand it to nearly 1 million square feet.

title: Living the Good Life, Writing the Low Life
description: IN 30 years of writing such celebrated novels as ''Clockers'' and ''The Wanderers'' and screenplays like ''Sea of Love'' and ''The Color of Money,'' Richard Price says he has had one freak-out moment, one time when he started to say, ''What the heck am I doing this for?''

title: Deciphering Tax Notices In the City
description: ON Jan. 15, the New York City Department of Finance mailed out nearly one million Notice of Assessment forms to property owners in the city to inform them of how much the city believes a property is worth for purposes of calculating local property taxes.

title: South Korea Has Too Much Rice and a Sticky Political Problem
description: On the Korean Peninsula, millions of people in the North are suffering for lack of rice, the staple of Asia, while people in the South face the opposite problem. There is more rice around than people can possibly eat. No one knows quite what to do about it.

title: Marcello Truzzi, 67; Sociologist Who Studied the Supernatural
description: Marcello Truzzi, a sociologist whose research interests included parapsychology, flying saucers and witchcraft, died on Sunday at his home in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 67.

title: A Vacant Mart, Symbol of Failure, Is a Candidate for Redevelopment
description: As a symbol of Harlem's long-promised renaissance, Mart 125 has embodied the failure of local black businesses. Now the Bloomberg administration is hoping to give the market a new lease on life.

title: Streetscapes/Charles Pierrepont Henry Gilbert; A Designer of Lacy Mansions for the City's Eminent
description: THE lacy limestone pinnacles of the 1899 Fletcher mansion at 79th Street and Fifth Avenue are gleaming, the streaks of soot and dirt removed by a cleaning late last year by its owner, the Ukrainian Institute of America. This neo-French Gothic house is one of the touchstone works of the architect Charles P. H. Gilbert, who not only designed mansions for the leading families of New York but could also shoot at a gallop from underneath a horse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VITT, SAMUEL BRADSHAW
description: VITT - Samuel Bradshaw. Died peacefully on February 2, 2003, in Newark, Ohio, at the age of 76. Mr. Vitt graduated from Dartmouth College in 1950 and served two years in the U.S. Navy. He then rose through the advertising ranks in New York City to Senior Vice President, Media Director at Ted Bates & Co. In 1969, he founded Vitt Media International, which under his leadership became a Fortune 500 company and revolutionized media time buying and placement. A legend in his field, Mr. Vitt pioneered the 30-second commercial and was dubbed by his peers as ''Mr. Media.'' Vitt was active member of the Republican Party. He served on the National U.N. Day committee for four years; as co-chairman in 1976. He also worked with the New Rochelle Hospital Medical Center with his wife, Marie, who was the first woman to Chair the Board of Governors. In addition to lecturing on advertising, Vitt also contributed to several publications, including the Handbook of Advertising Management, Advertising Procedure and more recently, Tomorrow's Global Community. His biography appears in the nineteenth edition of Who's Who in Finance and Industry. Sam Vitt was married to Broadway actress Marie Foster for forty years until her death. Mr. Vitt is survived by sons, Dr. Michael B. Vitt, of Newark, Ohio; Mark T. Vitt, of Tempe, Arizona; and daughter, Joanne V. Hastings, of Camp Verde, Arizona. Memorial contributions may be made to the Kid's Place of Licking County, C/O Licking Memorial Health Foundation, 1320 West Main St., Newark, Ohio 43055.

description: As a bruising recall campaign ended here this week, Mayor Barbara Connors was still in office and her policies to slow the growth of this old mining town northwest of Denver were intact.

title: Will the Arts Survive? The Alarms Are Sounding
description: Governor McGreevey's proposal to suspend all financing for arts and cultural programs is a bit like a college dean saying he is going to expel the most well-connected, smartest student in the class -- somehow you just know it's not going to happen.

title: 1970's New York, On an Album Cover
description: FOR thousands of New Yorkers who grew up far from the metropolitan area, the city was but a fantastic twinkle in the eye. For such youthful would-be cosmopolites, transport here was more readily achieved via tokens of jaded sophistication -- a book like ''The Catcher in the Rye,'' a movie like ''Valley of the Dolls'' -- than by the metal ones issued by the M.T.A.

title: Bus Driver Gets Summons After Crash That Killed 2
description: The driver of a casino-bound bus that spun off the Garden State Parkway on Friday, killing 2 of its 30 passengers, was issued a careless-driving summons yesterday as investigators recovered a ''black box'' data recorder from the vehicle, which witnesses said had been speeding and weaving before the crash.

title: Sexy It's Not, but Big Science Thrives on Earth
description: AMONG the science projects pursued by the crew of the space shuttle Columbia -- the dynamics of sand and soil under pressure or the effect of dust storms on global warming -- was one that in retrospect seems terribly poignant: an inquiry into the nature of fire and the best way to suppress it in space.

title: Buff Cashmere
description: Now that dressy workout clothes have established themselves as a semiacceptable style statement, designers are upping the ante and spinning hoodies and sweat pants in cashmere. Juicy Couture, the company that made the original matching velour fashion sweats, is offering luxury versions of its women's low-rise drawstring pants and rib-clinging hooded jackets in many colors (both $202 at Saks Fifth Avenue). Jackets and pants by Autumn Cashmere are super-ply versions of the original 70's track suit, complete with mesh racing stripes down the sleeves and zippers at the ankle ($308 for the jacket, $268 for the pants, at Henri Bendel). A new active-wear line by Banana Republic includes whisper-light hoodies ($198) in cashmere athletic mesh. And in a rare mix of cuteness and utility, hip workout hoodies (above) and ballet sweaters by FAL have a special slot in the back for hanging them on locker hooks ($230 to $265, at the Shop at Equinox, 212-752-5356). Of course, if they are hanging in your locker, it means that you aren't working out in them.

title: The Nation; For Republicans, Deficits Are Nothing to Be Ashamed of
description: THE idea of a balanced budget ranks high in the hierarchy of American political virtues. Thomas Jefferson proposed a balanced budget amendment to the Constitution in 1798, and Franklin D. Roosevelt ran with the promise of a balanced budget in 1932.

title: Mandela Unbowed
description: Against the tide of history, Nelson Mandela brought peaceful change to a country that was heading for civil war. An excellent biography by Yona Zeldis McDonough, PEACEFUL PROTEST: The Life of Nelson Mandela (Walker, $16.95; ages 6 to 10), highlights the turning points that made such a result possible. As a little boy, Mandela watched his family lose their cattle and their land because his father, a Thembu chief, would not recognize British authority, yet he sent his son to a British-style school, where he exchanged his birth name, Buti, for Nelson. At the ritual marking his passage into manhood, he heard a speech that determined the course of his life. The ''promise of manhood would remain unfilled,'' McDonough writes, ''because all black South Africans were a conquered people -- slaves in their own land, denied their freedoms and their rights.''

title: Amy Nauiokas, James Connolly
description: Amy Lois Nauiokas, a daughter of Lucinda and Francis Nauiokas of Southbury, Conn., was married yesterday to James Connolly, the son of Mary Van Allan of Coram, N.Y., and Jerome Connolly of Jackson Heights, Queens. The Rev. Dr. Jan Carlsson-Bull, a Unitarian-Universalist minister, officiated at the Space at Chelsea Market in Manhattan.

title: CRIME
description: Some people never learn -- nor should they. Inspector John Rebus, the abrasive, angst-ridden Edinburgh cop who keeps teeth on edge in Ian Rankin's hard-bitten police procedurals, has long made a virtue of bad behavior. So it comes as no surprise to find him taken off the investigation into the murder of an Edinburgh art dealer in RESURRECTION MEN (Little, Brown, $19.95) and dispatched to Tulliallan, the Scottish Police College, for an attitude overhaul. ''They were here to atone, to be resurrected,'' we are told of the six officers enrolled in a remedial course to expiate their sin of insubordination. Or were they? Rebus has a secret assignment to determine which of his classmates was corrupted in a botched drug case. But when the team exercise they are assigned -- the unsolved homicide of an underworld lowlife -- turns out to be one of his own unorthodoxly handled cases, he wonders if he is also under surveillance.

title: Symbol of Modern Ireland Finally Stands Tall
description: After four years of bureaucratic obstacles, six months of construction and five weeks of delays caused by gusty winds, the newest addition to Dublin's skyline was completed last month. The structure -- more a piece of sculpture than a traditional monument -- is a slender needle that shoots upward from the middle of O'Connell Street, the main thoroughfare, to 394 feet, double the height of Liberty Hall, the city's tallest building.

title: Singing Angel With a Human Pulse
description: The soprano Heidi Grant Murphy, who makes her Lincoln Center recital debut at Alice Tully Hall this afternoon, has the purity to sound like an angel. She did so recently in San Francisco as the celestial visitor to 13th-century Assisi in Messiaen's opera ''St. Franois d'Assise,'' climbing into the musical action like a real voyager from another world. But she is an angel with a human pulse and feeling -- and a human curiosity.

title: Ladybugs by the Can
description: In his promising first collection, GOBLIN FRUIT (Context Books, $23), David Marshall Chan offers up melancholy fables from a pop-culture California childhood. The title story finds the narrator pitching a screenplay that's a twisted variant on ''E.T.'': goblins steal a town's children and feed them a fruit that makes them forget who they are. (It's ''like 'Honey, I Shrunk the Kids' meets 'Aliens' meets the Persephone myth as written by Clive Barker,'' he helpfully notes.) For Chan, writing is the breadcrumb trail leading back out of the dark forest of adulthood into the brighter but no less sinister light of youth. Inspired by fairy tales as well as more modern mythologies like comic books, after-school specials and professional wrestling, ''Goblin Fruit'' centers on transformation. An actor assumes the identity of his brother, killed years ago on a movie set; an Asian-American teenager recreates himself as a white-bread boy detective; seven Chinese brothers metamorphose into seven swans. Short on plot but long on atmosphere, these tales rarely follow a traditional narrative path. Instead, Chan strings together images and the reflections they provoke. Unfortunately, he doesn't always have the pacing (or the prose) to make this structure work. Some stories are overlong, and a stronger editing hand could have made this a much better book. But his images remain haunting: ashes from a fatal apartment fire, falling like snow; a cloud of red ladybugs loosed from a can (''A dazzling waterfall of reds and oranges and shades in-between showered down onto the sidewalk in slow motion, a slow parade of winged marchers falling through the air''). Los Angeles has always been a city bathed in fantasy; in Chan's hands, however, the prevailing mood is less Disney than Grimm. Mary Park

title: Legal Latinisms Cloud Understanding
description: Re ''Legal Latinisms: Dead or Alive?'' [Jan. 26]: Justice James Hudson's defense of his writing style is as obscure as the Latin phrases he employs in his opinions. With all due respect, his opaque style is not ''plain language.'' At best, it is inefficient as lawyers must puzzle over the meaning of the foreign phrases and arcane historical references; at worst, it creates a risk that the decision will be misconstrued. Since a written opinion is a guide to future action, it should strive to be understandable to lawyers and clients. Justice Hudson has forgotten the lessons of clarity and conciseness that he learned in law school.

A fascination with ''regular'' people and an affinity for visual spontaneity spurred Gilden to make a career out of documenting street life around the world. He has trawled places like Coney Island, Tokyo and Haiti for his signature wide-angle, in-your-face close-ups; he calls his subjects ''characters.'' We were hoping to add a reading teacher, but that's now in jeopardy with the squeeze from state aid, and we were hoping to maintain class size. title: 'The Hipster Handbook'
description: You've seen them all over town with their mop-top haircuts, swinging retro pocketbooks, talking on cell phones, smoking European cigarettes, shading their eyes behind bug-eyed lenses, and strutting in platform shoes with a biography of Che sticking out of their bags. They come in all colors, shapes, sizes, and nationalities. Beck is one. Jack Kerouac was one. Meg from the White Stripes is one. And the girl at work in the Jackie-O dress is one too. title: Plea Deal for Muslim Charity Leader Linked to Al Qaeda
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10  The leader of one of American's biggest Muslim charities, depicted by federal prosecutors as one of Osama bin Laden's principal financiers, struck an 11th-hour plea agreement today without admitting any ties to Al Qaeda or terrorism.

title: A Bid by SBC For DirecTV Would Confirm Cable's Reach
description: The cable industry calls it the triple play. To Edward E. Whitacre Jr., the chairman of SBC Communications, the cable industry's ability to offer telephone, high-speed Internet and television services might as well be called the triple threat.

title: Webdenda
description: Lance M. Adeszko was named sales development manager at the Chicago office of USA Weekend , succeeding Brian Deleney , who left, the company said. Mr. Adeszko has been Midwest director at the Chicago office of Meredith Interactive, part of the Meredith Corporation. USA Weekend is owned by the Gannett Company. Peter Armour , senior vice president for consumer marketing at Conde Nast Publications , New York, part of the Advance Magazine Group , was named senior vice president for consumer marketing at the Advance Magazine Group as part of a reorganization. Advance Magazine is part of Advance Publications. Austin Kelley Advertising , Atlanta, promoted three employees to senior vice presidents. They are Patty Kinney , director for traffic services; Lou Ann Russell , account director; and Duncan Stone , associate creative director. Austin Kelley is part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Balance Sheet Manager , Burlingame, Calif., which assists loan transactions between banks, named Welch Nehlen Groome Advertising , Garden City, N.Y., to handle the company's first print and online advertising. Billings were estimated at $1 million. Bruce Brandfon , publisher at Scientific American magazine , New York, was promoted to vice president. Scientific American is part of Holtzbrinck Publishers, part of Verlagsgruppe Georg von Holtzbrinck. John Carter , creative director at T.G. Madison , Atlanta, was named to the new post of executive vice president and executive creative director. He assumes duties that had been handled by Virgil Shutze, president and chief creative officer, who continues as president. Mike Colt , executive vice president and executive creative director at Leo Burnett USA , Chicago, was named vice chairman. Burnett is part of the Leo Burnett Worldwide unit of the Publicis Groupe. Corey L. Cutler was named to the new post of executive vice president at the Ruth Group , New York, a financial public relations and investor relations agency. He had been senior vice president at FD Morgen-Walke, New York, part of the Cordiant Communications Group, heading the technology practice. Drew Fawcett , vice president and associate creative director at Rabasca & Company , Melville, N.Y., was named creative director, succeeding Rick Bodamer, who left, the agency said. Also, Bruce Richards was named to the new post of senior vice president and director for client services; he had been senior vice president and management supervisor at Bates North America, New York, part of the Bates Worldwide unit of the Cordiant Communications Group. Gear magazine , New York, and the Brand Entertainment Group , New York, part of the J. Walter Thompson division of the WPP Group, formed a joint venture to produce television programming. Terms were not disclosed. Gear is published by Guccione Media. Kevin Gelbard was named to help develop corporate partnerships at the Creative Artists Agency , Beverly Hills, Calif. He had been vice president for sales at Envision, Los Angeles, part of the Anschutz Entertainment Group division of the Anschutz Corporation. Michael Gentry was named to the new post of national account director at Roska Direct , Montgomeryville, Pa. He had been senior account manager at IMS Health, Plymouth Meeting, Pa. The Green Bay Packers named Lindsay, Stone & Briggs , Madison, Wis., as the first agency of record on the account of Lambeau Atrium , a convention center and restaurant complex being added to the facilities at Lambeau Field that is scheduled to open in September. Billings have not been determined. Bill Hewson , director for client strategy at Sharpe Partners , New York, was named to head a new department of relationship marketing and media, as director. Patrick Kiss was named to the vacant post of managing director at Butler, Shine, Stern & Partners , Sausalito, Calif. He had been executive vice president at the San Francisco office of Foote, Cone & Belding, part of the FCB Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Larry Kleehammer was named director for account services at Buck & Pulleyn, Rochester , N.Y. He had been vice president and worldwide account director at the Rochester office of Saatchi & Saatchi Rowland, part of the Saatchi & Saatchi unit of the Publicis Groupe. Bill Kolberg , senior vice president at the Los Angeles office of Porter Novelli , part of the Omnicom Group, was named general manager for Los Angeles. He assumes duties that had been handled by Steve Jursa, acting general manager, who continues as senior partner and global convergence practice leader. Liberty Bank , Portland, Ore., named Leopold Ketel & Partners , as agency of record on its account, which had been handled by B/O/C Advertising, Portland. Billings were estimated at $500,000. Linda McCutcheon was named director for publications at AARP , Washington, succeeding Martha Ramsey, who was named senior adviser to the chief executive. Ms. McCutcheon had been chief executive at KOZ Inc., Durham, N.C. Gordon McLeod was named to the new post of president at Sports Illustrated Interactive , New York, part of the Time Inc. division of AOL Time Warner. He had been vice president and general manager at Parenting.com and Parenting TV, New York, units of the Parenting Group at Time Inc. NKH&W , Kansas City, Mo., acquired the McIntosh Group , Fort Smith, Ark., and Image and Strategy , Little Rock, Ark. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Compressed Data; Looking After Life Without Leaving Office
description: It is not just the boss's imagination. Workers surf the Web to take care of personal business from the office, and that includes plenty of time visiting the online personals, according to two new surveys.

title: Indian Nurses Sought To Staff U.S. Hospitals
description: Annamma George has not taken an examination in 15 years, since she began her career as a nurse in a leading Bangalore hospital. But these days she pores over books alongside her 10-year old son, often studying late into the night. In a few weeks, Ms. George will take special exams that could qualify her for a nursing job in the United States.

title: Money Problems for U.N. Agency for Palestinians
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 10  The United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees warned today that without immediate international help it would run out of money next month to feed more than a million people in the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: New Economy; Even as it gazes toward the stars, the space program has broad benefits for those rooted to Earth.
description: SINCE the destruction of the space shuttle Columbia nine days ago, squads of men and women have fanned out across eastern Texas toting state-of-the-art global positioning devices to mark the precise location of fallen tiles, mechanical parts and assorted debris. The devices make their calculations by triangulating with satellites that carry atomic clocks and orbit the Earth at an altitude of 12,000 miles.

title: Day Care Workers Threaten One-Day Strike
description: Day care workers and directors are planning a one-day strike Wednesday at the 360 centers financed by New York City because they have not been able to secure a contract for more than two years.

title: Future of Animal Research Lab Is Questioned
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said today that residents of eastern Long Island have a right to know if the Bush administration plans to alter the mission of the Plum Island Animal Research Center after it transfers the facility to the Department of Homeland Security in June.

description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Two Precocious Stars, Two Different Fortunes
description: WHOSE shoes would you rather stand in? Whose path would you follow, Maurice Clarett's or LeBron James's? At a time of change, two young stars represent conflicting ways of negotiating a complex and often confusing sports world.

title: Publishers Give Classics a Makeover
description: Forget about agents and auctions and multimillion-dollar contracts. The stiffest competition in the book business may be among the many publishers staking claim to Dickens, Austen, Herodotus and Plato.

title: Grand Vision For Remaking The West Side
description: Where some people see the far West Side of Manhattan as a low-slung district of tenements, small shops, warehouses and parking lots, the Bloomberg administration envisions a neighborhood transformed.

title: Determined Devils Keep the Wild's Shooting Star in Check
description: The Devils' checking line of John Madden, Jay Pandolfo and Turner Stevenson was handed the responsibility of trying to contain the Minnesota Wild's top line, featuring the young scoring sensation Marian Gaborik.

title: Compressed Data; E-mail Spam Scam Is Sent in Bush's Name
description: At first, the e-mail message reads like all the others: There's the need for confidentiality. An assurance that the transaction is completely legal. And the inevitable appeal, in awkwardly formal language, for help in procuring a large amount of money.

description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell warned today that if Saddam Hussein was still not cooperating with United Nations inspectors at the end of this week, President Bush would press immediately for consideration of a Security Council resolution authorizing possible use of force against Iraq.

description: GERMANO-Edward. The Officers, Governors and Members of the New York Friars Club mourn the loss of their esteemed member Friar Edward Germano and they extend heartfelt sympathy to his family. We are indebted to him for his help in modernizing our audio archives. He shall be remembered for his unselfishness and dedication to the Club. Alan King, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean Jean-Pierre Trebot, Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, LEON
description: GROSS-Leon. Died on February 3, in Paris, France. Beloved husband of Dolly. Loving father of Steven and George. Devoted brother of Sam, Fred and daughter-inlaw Ellen, as well as his cherished grandchildren. He was a wonderful, kind and honorable man, loved by all who knew him. His friends in America wish that his entire family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Tension Tourism on Korean Border
description: Like excited birdwatchers, American tourists plunk 500 won coins into pay-per-view binoculars, studying a rarely seen species: three real live, fur-hatted North Korean soldiers patrolling the DMZ.

description: After more than 20 years of flying, the space shuttle's contributions to science are still a matter of debate.

title: Europe Shows a Growing Distaste for Genetic Foods
description: TOTNES, England, Feb. 7  At the Happy Apple green grocer in this Elizabethan town in England's west country, the Roasted Vegetable Pasty is labeled, clearly and proudly, as G.M.-free. So is the Hommity Pie and a scattering of other products crammed onto shelves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARBER, VIRGINIA MCCLAMROCH
description: BARBER-Virginia McClamroch. Widow of James F. Hoge and Anthony Barber, at age 95, at her Manhattan home on February 7, 2003. She is survived by two sons, James F. Hoge Jr. and Warren M. Hoge, a daughter, Virginia Hoge Verwaal, seven grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren; a daughter, Barbara Hoge Daine died in 2001. A native of North Carolina, Virgina Barber was a resident of NYC for 70 years and a longtime patron of the Metropolitan Opera, the New York Philharmonic Orchestra and Carnegie Hall. She was an active alumna of Hollins College and a devoted volunteer at the New York YWCA, Grosvenor Neighborhood House, the North Carolina Society, the Colonial Dames and the Blue Ridge School. Service Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Ave at 91 St, Tuesday, February 11, 10 AM.

title: Wanted: Rugged Individualists Who Work Well Together
description: When, in 1913, Sir Ernest Shackleton needed a crew for his planned expedition across the Antarctic, he announced his intentions in The Times of London.

title: Pentagon Mobilizes Commercial Planes To Fly Troops to Gulf Area This Week
description: The Pentagon mobilized a fleet of commercial aircraft late on Saturday to move troops and equipment in advance of a possible war with Iraq. It was only the second time in its 51-year history that the Civilian Reserve Air Fleet had been mobilized.

title: Traditional Country Music Is Bouncing Back on Radio
description: With their slick rock-style tunes and sexy videos, Faith Hill and Shania Twain have stolen the show in country music in the last decade. And their hipper brand of country has replaced the traditional sounds of Loretta Lynn and Tammy Wynette on radio dials across the country.

title: Iran's Failed Revolution
description: Few Iranians have been celebrating the 24th anniversary of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's Islamic revolution this month. It is easy to understand why. A movement that once brought millions into the streets demanding freedom from the shah's dictatorship has gone on to oppress its young, disillusion its middle-aged veterans and silence even grand ayatollahs who question its course.

title: Seton Hall of February Just Keeps on Strutting
description: St. Peter's might have had a chance against Seton Hall back on Dec. 5, when their game was postponed because of snow. But not tonight. Not now.

title: Even as the Big Airlines Struggle, Computer Booking System Prospers
description: As the airline industry heads closer to insolvency, it is no surprise that Sabre Holdings, the world's largest computer reservations system, is having a tough time.

title: White House Letter; An Appreciation for Space Not That Far From Earth
description: John H. Marburger III, President Bush's science adviser, is a Democrat who works light years from the White House -- in other words, two full blocks from the center of power in the West Wing -- in an H Street office building so silent that you feel you can hear the atoms move.

description: To the Editor:

title: A Proposal to Reduce U.S. Troops in Germany
description: The new supreme commander for American forces in Europe, Gen. James L. Jones, is considering a plan to scale back the presence of American troops in Germany in favor of lighter, more mobile units that could jump from country to country on a moment's notice, according to Congressional officials who were briefed on the proposal.

title: Iraq Agrees to U-2 Flights
description: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 10  The Iraqi ambassador to the United Nations delivered a letter from Baghdad today to the chief United Nations weapons inspectors agreeing to allow photographic surveillance aircraft to fly over the country.

title: MediaTalk; Scavenging for Cost Cuts at Knight Ridder
description: Top executives at Knight Ridder, the country's third-largest newspaper company, have recently drafted their subordinate newspaper executives around the country into a cost-cutting frolic that has been dubbed ''The $100 Million Scavenger Hunt.''

title: Telecom Offer Expected to Be $3.88 Billion
description: PCCW, the Hong Kong telephone company controlled by businessman Richard Li and formerly called Pacific Century CyberWorks, is expected to make an informal offer this week for Cable and Wireless, the British telecommunications company, people involved in the discussions said today. They valued the offer at 2.38 billion, or $3.88 billion.

title: HBO Offers 4 Networks Comedy Hit 'Sex and City'
description: In the latest indication that cable and network programming are becoming more interchangeable, HBO has offered all four major broadcast networks a crack at picking up its Emmy Award-winning comedy ''Sex and the City'' for use on a prime-time network schedule next season.

title: Bombing on Broadway, Thriving on the Road; With a Few Tweaks, Musicals Play in Peoria
description: By the time ''Seussical: The Musical'' closed its Broadway run in May 2001, it was, in no uncertain terms, a bomb. It had suffered through terrible reviews, run less than six months and lost some $10.5 million, making it one of the worst failures in Broadway history.

title: American Says Painting In Spain Is Holocaust Loot
description: The Spanish government is refusing to discuss an American citizen's claim to be the rightful owner of an Impressionist masterpiece stolen by the Nazis and now hanging in the Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum here. The museum is obviously proud of the work, ''Rue St.-Honor, Aprs-Midi, Effet de Pluie,'' a Parisian street scene painted by Camille Pissarro in 1897.

title: Winter? Rangers Face Another Meltdown
description: It has become something of a midwinter rite. With two months left in their season, the Rangers are in a state of denial about their chances of gaining a playoff berth.

title: Squabble For Name Of Cosmos
description: What's in a name? In the case of the Cosmos, it is an intercontinental shouting match that has broken out about the possible revival of a defunct, but storied, team that has not played a game for nearly 20 years.

title: An Antiwar Democrat Leaves Room To Wiggle
description: In Iowa, Howard Dean is widely known as an antiwar candidate for president, whose swift denunciation of President Bush's Iraq resolution set him apart in the Democratic field and established him as potentially strong contender in next year's Iowa's presidential caucuses.

description: Sun Microsystems is set to announce a series of new computer and software offerings today in an effort to regain a sense of momentum and leadership in the corporate computing business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHESLEY, WILLOUGHBY FREELAND
description: CHESLEY-Willoughby Freeland. 75, of Stuart, FL, died Saturday, February 8, 2003. Born in Baltimore, MD, he and his family resided in Larchmont, NY, throughout most of his school-age years. A 1948 Tau Beta Pi mechanical engineering graduate of Yale University, Sheffield School of Engineering. An accomplished sailor and multiple trophy winner, he held memberships with the Larchmont Yacht Club, The Yale Club, NY, and the Cedar Point Yacht Club, Westport, CT. His career included positions with General Electric in Lynn, MA; managerial positions in the New Haven, CT, Philadelphia, PA, and Detroit, MI, branches of Clark Equipment Company; National Branch Manager and National Service Manager with Baker Industrial Trucks, and president of Reflectone, an Otis Elevator Company, until his retirement; after which he pursued one of his longtime interests and became a financial advisor. He was predeceased by his parents, Willoughby Sprigg Chesley and Marian Craker Chesley of Stuart, FL. He is survived by his wife Constance Webber; six children, Frederica Marie Marden of Portsmouth, NH; Hollis Annibale of Charleston, SC; Willoughby Freeland Jr., of Stamford, CT; Helene C. Purdy of Sherman, CT; Mary Castleman of Cheshire, CT; and Frederick Schaefer of Norwalk, CT; two step-daughters, Lisa Pryor Fitzgibbon of Rutherford, NJ; Jennifer Leigh Fitzgibbon of New York City, NY; his former marital companion of 33 years, Winifred Hollis Schaefer; 11 grandchildren and one stepgrandson. Viewing Aycock Funeral Home, Monday, February 10, from 3-6 PM, Stuart, FL; (772) 287-1717. A memorial service will be held at his parish, St. Mary's Episcopal Church, Tuesday, February 11, 11 AM. Those who wish may contribute to Second Sight Taping Studio, Inc., 2153 SE Ocean Blvd., Stuart, FL 34996.

title: Scientists of Very Small Draw Disciplines Together
description: Nanotechnology, biotechnology, electronics and brain research are converging into a new field of science vital to the nation's security and economic clout.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Friday about participation in the Bush administration's smallpox vaccination plan gave an incorrect affiliation for Margaret Preston, the spokeswoman for a hospital that is not taking part. She works for St. Vincent Infirmary Medical Center of Little Rock, Ark., not for Catholic Health Initiatives, which owns the hospital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSSELL, BEATRICE
description: RUSSELL-Beatrice. Beloved wife of the late Henry. Devoted mother of Jody and Franck, Adam and Stacey, Scott and Dana and the late Laura. Loving grandmother of Rebecca, Harrison, Sarah, Alexander, Emily and Bennett. Dear sister of Irving and Gloria, Dorothy and Bernard, and the late Florence and Shy. Passed away from complications of cancer. Her spirit, energy and courage, and love of life, will always be cherished by her friends and family.

title: NATO Rift Widens Over Defense of Turkey in Case of Iraq War
description: The Bush administration's efforts to rally support for possible military action against Iraq hit a series of diplomatic roadblocks today with France, Germany and Belgium opening a division within NATO by blocking proposals to increase Turkey's defenses in case of a war.

description: HOCKEY

title: Y.& R. Hires Executive From BBDO for 2 Posts
description: Young & Rubicam Advertising is raiding a competitor, BBDO Worldwide, to hire a top creative executive to fill two posts, effective March 1.

title: Round 1 Goes to Mr. Big
description: Is the latest trans-Atlantic flare-up yet another ''Whither NATO?'' crisis, like those that have roiled the West for decades with the precision of a German cuckoo clock? No, this time it is war (and not the real war against Iraq, which hasn't even begun). In fact, it is two wars: one that pits Europe against Europe, and another that pits a French-German ''axis'' against the United States.

title: An Approaching Tide of Red Ink
description: The government is fast running out of money to meet its bills. Treasury officials warn that the nation will bang up against the legal debt ceiling of $6.4 trillion before the end of this month. There is little doubt Congress will back into its duty and vote to raise the debt limit, even as President Bush blithely compounds the deficits deep into the decade with new untax-and-spend stratagems. But the lawmakers' partisan shucking of responsibility for the rising tide of red ink promises to be exquisitely hypocritical this time around.

title: Bush Pushes Faith-Based Agenda
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10  President Bush campaigned today on behalf of his "faith-based initiative," telling a friendly audience that religious organizations can, with government's help, help America fulfill its vision of justice and prosperity for all.

title: Chief Weapons Inspectors See No Big Breakthrough After Talks in Baghdad
description: The top United Nations weapons inspectors said tonight that they had achieved no breakthrough in two days of talks here, ending inconclusively a last-hour visit in which they had hoped Iraq would demonstrate more significantly its full cooperation with inspectors.

title: Five Hours' Worth of Stars, Celebrating the Mournful
description: Dozens of blues, rock, rhythm-and-blues and hip-hop performers appeared at Radio City Music Hall on Friday night in ''Salute to the Blues,'' an unguided tour through blues history. B. B. King, Bonnie Raitt, Buddy Guy, Macy Gray, Chuck D, India.Arie, the Neville Brothers and members of Aerosmith were just a few of the musicians on the bill.

title: Columbia's Final Overhaul Draws NASA's Attention
description: The space shuttle Columbia arrived here in September 1999 for an overhaul that was scheduled to last about nine months.

title: Memory Enhances the Grimness of Slaves' Lives
description: Oprah Winfrey asks to see the picture one more time. In it Jennie Proctor looks desolate. She stands on the porch of a shack.

title: A Crush Of Applicants
description: Huge, unexplained traffic jams began building up on the North Side of Chicago last Tuesday morning. Drivers struggled for half an hour or more to travel just four blocks. The police had to close entrance and exit ramps at a couple of spots along Lake Shore Drive. Baffled officers raised their arms in frustration as motorists demanded to know what was going on.

title: As Cities Move to Privatize Water, Atlanta Steps Back
description: Privatization has hit the water sector, which has remained mostly the bastion of public utilities. Over the last five years, hundreds of American communities, including Indianapolis, Milwaukee and Gary, Ind., have hired private companies to manage their waterworks, serving about one in 20 Americans.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Two Men Sought In Pair Of Killings
description: The police said yesterday that they were seeking two men in connection with separate shootings about two hours apart Saturday morning at a bodega in Queens and a deli in Brooklyn. Detective Robert Price, a police spokesman, said the two men were caught on videotape in the Central Mini Market, in Ozone Park, Queens, where John Freddy, 43, who had dropped in for coffee, was shot and killed about 7 a.m. Detective Price said the two men on the videotape -- whom the police had not identified -- were also being sought for questioning in a shooting at the Around the Clock Mini Mart in Mill Basin, Brooklyn. The deli's owner, identified by the police as Sukhjit Khajala, 50, was killed. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Rising Costs Alter Rules for Shows on Tour
description: The news last week that the national tour of the Broadway production "Oklahoma!" would be cast with nonunion actors is just the latest indication of what union officials and producers alike say is the changing economic landscape on the road.

title: Pitino Has Louisville on Steady Diet of Winning
description: The broom closet has been turned into an exercise room and the fat has been trimmed. It has been cut literally (Louisville center Marvin Stone has slashed the percentage of body fat on his 6-foot-10 frame from 13 to 7 percent) and figuratively (a pair of former high school all-Americans are long gone from the team). Left behind is a senior scorer turned point guard and two freshmen, one from New Jersey and the other from the Bronx, neither of whom needed to visit the campus before buying into one man's vision.

title: Math Degrees -- Jobs
description: A mathematics or computer science degree does not offer the job guarantee it once did.

title: 3 Nations Call for Alternative to Iraq War
description: PARIS, Feb. 10  France, Russia and Germany issued a joint declaration today calling for intensified weapons inspections as an alternative to war in Iraq and publicly closing ranks against the United States for the first time in post-Cold War history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAUDHARY, BASUDEO, M.D.
description: CHAUDHARY - Basudeo, M.D. Age 75, of Smithtown, formally of Islandia and Brentwood, peacefully passed away on February 7, 2003. 1958 Graduate of Patna Medical College, India. Formerly Deputy Director of Pilgrim Psychiatric Center. Past President of American Psychiatric Association Suffolk Chapter. Life Fellow of A.P.A.; Fellow of Suffolk Academy of Medicine; Life member of A.A.P.I. and I.A.P.A.; Medical Advisor to Cooley's Anemia Foundation Suffolk Chapter; ''Deputy Sheriff'' of Riverhead Jail; Volunteer of Pederson Craig Center; Psychiatrist at Eastern Suffolk Boces. Beloved husband of Yvonne. Cherished father of Maria Wilkom (Jim), Neil (Jennifer) and the late Raj. Adored grandfather of Jimmy, Jackie, Darian and Jarrod. Dear brother of Satya Narain, Bhagya Narain and the late Kailli. Also survived by a loving extended family in the United States, India and Australia. Reposing at The Branch Funeral Home, Inc., 190 East Main St, Smithtown. Visiting Sunday and Monday, 2-4 and 7-9:30 PM. Religious services will be held at The Branch Funeral Home Tuesday, 10 AM. Cremation private. In lieu of flowers the family suggests donations to: The Cooley's Anemia Foundation, Inc, 738 Smithtown Bypass, Smithtown, NY 11787.

title: A Terror Lieutenant With a Deadly Past
description: Abu Mussab al-Zarqawi's disfigured body shows the hard reality of his life. A scar runs along the left side of his face, possibly the product of an accident with improvised explosives. He wears a prosthetic leg, fitted in Baghdad last spring where he received treatment for injuries caused by an American bomb in Afghanistan.

title: As Animation Goes Digital, Disney Fights For Its Crown
description: Rarely does Hollywood-style glamour spill into this suburban Los Angeles enclave. But as the animation industry's elite gathered here recently at the Alex Theater to toast their favorite films of 2002, champagne glasses were clinking. Or was it the sound of jagged nerves?

description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills, four-week bills and five-year notes on Tuesday and 10-year notes on Wednesday.

title: Where Scorpions Roam, and Snowbirds Flock
description: Desert or not, traffic along the busiest one-mile stretch of Main Street here can take half an hour to pass. Motor homes towing pickup trucks choke gas station entrances. Septuagenarians in shorts amble fearlessly between busy intersections. Waits for a table at Silly Al's restaurant stretch to an hour.

title: U.S. Won't Accept Refuge in Pakistan for Al Qaeda and Taliban
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Feb. 10  The American government will not accept that Al Qaeda and Taliban members chased out of Afghanistan can find refuge in the tribal areas across the border in Pakistan, where Al Qaeda members are present, the American special envoy to Afghanistan, Zalmay Khalilzad, said today.

title: Review/Fashion; War and Peace On the Runway As Designers Weigh the Mood

title: Spending Spree at the Pentagon

The $380 billion proposal throws billions around indiscriminately, financing the weapons of tomorrow, the weapons of yesterday and a middle generation of weapons headed for obsolescence even before they begin rolling off production lines. The budget doesn't include spending for possible combat in Iraq, but once this, the war on terrorism and defense programs in other agencies are added, total military spending next year seems headed well over $400 billion.

It cuts into health care for the needy and the elderly, whacks support for higher education and guts spending on the arts -- the price for keeping the governor's promise not to raise income taxes. Mr. McGreevey's message, a combination of ''Don't blame me,'' ''I told you so'' and ''Read my lips,'' sounded more like an excuse than a real plan.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Tornado's Toll Lowered
description: A tornado that swept through a remote town in western Congo earlier this month killed 17 people, not the 164 initially feared. A delegation of experts discovered that many residents of Yumbi, in the northwest of Bandundu Province, had been rescued from under the debris of their homes and others who had been declared dead had merely fled into the surrounding jungle. Despite the lower death toll, the impact of the storm on Feb. 2 remained devastating. At least 4,000 people were injured and at least 1,700 people lost their homes, officials said. Marc Lacey (NYT)

Tourists will travel about 25 miles by bus over a three-day period for rates far lower than those charged on the boat that now takes them to the region. title: DRUG IS APPROVED TO TREAT FORM OF ANXIETY
description: Pfizer Inc. said yesterday that the Food and Drug Administration had approved its Zoloft antidepressant for long-term treatment of social-anxiety disorder. Studies show the medicine, which had sales last year of $2.74 billion, helped reduce anxiety and fear in patients with social phobia, Pfizer said. People with the disorder have a persistent fear of social situations and experience symptoms including sweating, blushing, tremors or rapid heartbeat. Zoloft is already approved to treat depression, panic disorder and obsessive-compulsive disorder, among other conditions. Pfizer is based in New York.

title: Ethics? In New York's Legislature?

After an Assembly Democrat confessed recently to accepting a bribe, she apparently also began explaining to the authorities the multitudinous little favors lobbyists are happy to do to win good will in the New York State Legislature. Free rides to and from New York City have been provided to politicians whose vote or influence would be handy now and then. Company employees might help out in friendly campaigns or work in legislators' offices. And those lobbyists who want a lawmaker's ear on a more regular basis may have come up with the perfect solution -- providing a free cellphone.

description: BRUSSELS:  Blocking NATO's 16 other members, France, Germany and Belgium rejected a request from Turkey for access to surveillance aircraft and missile systems Monday, triggering what diplomats said was the one of the worst crises in the alliance's 53-year history.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Affirmative-Action Program Ends
description: Mayor Thomas M. Menino of Boston has ended a 25-year-old affirmative action program that favored businesses owned by minorities and women when awarding city contracts. Mr. Menino said the program would probably not withstand a legal challenge, and last week signed an executive order that preferences be given to small or locally owned contracting companies. A study released last month suggested that Boston set both race-conscious and race-neutral policies for awarding contracts. The study showed that blacks were prime contractors on 1.3 percent of city contracts from 1999 to 2001, while white males were prime contractors on 75 percent of the deals. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHASIN, RENA
description: CHASIN-Rena, 59. On February 9, 2003. Beloved wife of Mark Chasin, loving daughter of Grace Bleiweiss, adored mother of Jeffrey Chasin, Larry Chasin, and Marni Garfinkle, loving sister of Martin Bleiweiss, and worshipped grandmother of Shelby Chasin, Samara and Jack Chasin and Jake Garfinkle.

title: Flawed Snowfall Data Jeopardize Climate-Change Research
description: When it comes to snowfall, even a flurry is likely to provoke a blizzard of reporting.

title: Boeing Official Defends Reports Discounting Peril After Liftoff
description: A senior Boeing executive today defended the work of his company's analysts who concluded that the space shuttle Columbia faced no catastrophic safety threat from damage caused by debris that struck its left wing some 81 seconds after liftoff.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAIGHT, FRANCES HOGE
description: HAIGHT - Frances Hoge. Frances Haight, 90, died on January 27 in Fullerton, CA. Before moving to California in 1995, she lived in New York City, Stamford, CT, Bedford, NY and Loon Lake, NY in the summers. She dedicated her life to family and community service, working worldwide for child welfare and child adoption services. For many years she served as president of International Social Service, traveling to its affiliated agencies around the world. Among the many organizations she served in earlier years were the Spence-Chapin Adoption Agency in NY, the Family and Children's Center in Stamford, Planned Parenthood in NY and the Citizens Committee for Children. She is survived by two sons, Courtenay H. Haight of Blue Hill Falls, Maine, and Peter V. Haight of Los Angeles, eight grandchildren and stepgrandchildren, one greatgranddaughter, and two nieces and their families. Her husband of more than 50 years, Eric H. Haight, died in 1987. There will be a memorial service on Saturday, February 22, 10:30 AM at St. Matthews Episcopal Church, Bedford Village, NY. Donations in her memory may be made to International Social Service, 700 Light Street, Baltimore, MD 21230-3850.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ECKSTAT, JENNY
description: ECKSTAT-Jenny, 93. Widow of Charles Eckstat, on February 10, 2003. Beloved mother of Elsa Meyers; grandmother of Seth Meyers and Daniel Meyers; great grandmother of Miranda, Margeaux and Benjamin. Retired English teacher, NYC schools. Donations to the Summit Speech School, 705 Central Avenue, New Providence, N.J. 07974.

title: Renters Receiving U.S. Aid To Pay More Under Budget
description: The Bush administration is proposing to increase rents charged to thousands of poor people who receive federal housing aid.

title: Sather Makes a Move To Right a Wrong
description: The trade of Aleksei Kovalev from Pittsburgh to the Rangers yesterday was good for New York, bad for the Penguins and a mixed blessing for the N.H.L. Kovalev is a dynamic attacker who learned his craft with Dynamo Moscow in the Soviet Union and began his North American career with the Rangers. His return to Manhattan helps them correct one of the great mistakes of their long decline since their Stanley Cup championship in 1994.

title: Lively Gospel Music Riding a Wave of Love
description: 'A Pure Gospel Valentine'

title: Heavy Rains Threaten to Entomb Debris in Muck
description: Time is running out to recover space shuttle debris from the woods of East Texas, search officials said today, because heavy rains are beginning to bury objects under a layer of muck.

title: Ted Perry, 71, the Founder Of the Hyperion Record Label
description: Ted Perry, the founder of Hyperion Records, a British classical music label known for exploring the byways of the repertory as devotedly as it does the core literature, died on Sunday in London. He was 71 and lived in London.

description: To the Editor:

description: BARBER-Virginia McClamroch. The National Society of Colonial Dames in the State of New York records with deep regret the death of its distinguished former Board Member. Anna F. Duff, President

title: The Icy Hudson
description: Q. At the end of January, I was struck by the difference between ice conditions on the Hudson River and the East River off Manhattan. The Hudson was largely covered over with sheets of thick ice. The East River had a few small slabs of floating ice. Why?

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Custodians Accused Of Taking Bribes
description: Eighteen public school custodians and a window-cleaning contractor were arrested yesterday on charges that they took part in a kickback and bid-rigging scheme, the authorities said. Custodians in city schools have wide discretion over how maintenance money is spent. The contractor, Thomas Robinson of Family Window Cleaning in the Bronx, is accused of bribing the custodians, who worked at schools in Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island, with $1,000 to $4,000 apiece to land contracts that paid the cleaning company about $250,000, Attorney General Eliot Spitzer said. Efforts to reach Mr. Robinson for comment last night were unsuccessful. Mr. Robinson helped the custodians get around bidding requirements by supplying them with fake bids, sometimes from companies that did not even exist, the authorities said. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: From an Elegant Dignity to a Mercurial Lightness
description: The New York City Ballet danced works by four choreographers on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater, opening with an atmospheric performance of ''Opus 19/The Dreamer,'' Jerome Robbins's depiction of a brooding man searching for a mysterious beloved.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMBOS, CONSTANTINE PETER
description: LAMBOS-Constantine Peter, 76, of Tampa, Florida, formerly of Crestwood, New York, died peacefully in his sleep at home on Saturday, February 8, 2003. Born August 4, 1926, in Manhattan, Peter served in the United States Army as a rifleman-scout with the 63rd Infantry Division in France and Germany during World War II. He graduated first in his class from New York University Law School, where he was the Editor-in-Chief of the Law Review. This year marked his fifty-fifth year as a lawyer. He was the senior partner of Lambos & Junge in New York City and served as chief management counsel to the East Coast longshore industry for the past forty years. Peter had served as the President of Leewood Golf Club in Eastchester, New York and the Downtown Athletic Club in New York City. For the past twenty years he was the managing partner of The Eagles Golf Club in Odessa, Florida. He is survived by his devoted wife of fifty years, Theodora, his loving son, William, his grandchildren, Elizabeth, Katherine and Peter, his sisters, Theresa Coutroulos, Mary Lambos, Helen Papantonis, and Aphrodite Danas, and his daughters-in-law, Carol and Diane. The funeral will be held on Thursday, February 13, 2003, at 10 A.M. at the Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church in New Rochelle, New York. Memorial donations may be made to the Peter and Andrew Lambos Foundation, 16101 Nine Eagles Drive, Odessa, Florida 33556.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the guilt voiced by some Californians about the fuel consumption of their sport utility vehicles gave an incorrect spelling in some copies for the surname of the editor of Car and Driver magazine, who said the vilification of S.U.V.'s seemed somewhat arbitrary. He is Csaba Csere, not Csera.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONICA, MATTHEW CORBETT
description: MONICA-Matthew Corbett. August 7, 1961-January 24, 2003. Good night, sweet Corby. Get some rest. We love you.

title: Markitecture Merges With Clark, Martire
description: Markitecture in Norwalk, Conn., a marketing consulting company, is merging with Clark, Martire & Bartolomeo in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., a polling and research company, to form the Markitecture Systems Group in Norwalk. Terms were not disclosed. Robert S. Shulman, chief executive at Markitecture, was named chief executive at Markitecture Systems.

title: Economy Saddled by Worry Over Security, Fed Chief Says
description: The economy is laboring under a cloud of geopolitical tensions and uncertainties, but it remains in about the same shape as it was six months ago, the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan, told Congress today.

Menino of Boston has ended a 25-year-old affirmative action program that favored businesses owned by minorities and women when awarding city contracts. A study released last month suggested that Boston set both race-conscious and race-neutral policies for awarding contracts. The study showed that blacks were prime contractors on 1.3 percent of city contracts from 1999 to 2001, while white males were prime contractors on 75 percent of the deals. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

description: Three agencies owned by members of minorities have joined the Los Angeles office of Hill & Knowlton USA, part of the Hill & Knowlton division of the WPP Group, to form a partnership to collaborate on client services and business development.

title: Westchester Officials Say They Expect to Increase Property Taxes and Cut Jobs and Services
description: After a day of frantic meetings and last-ditch efforts to save a plan to raise the county sales tax by one percentage point, Westchester County officials acknowledged late today that they would almost certainly have to vote on Tuesday to raise property taxes nearly 15 percent, lay off police officers and prosecutors, cut services and trim $15 million from the county budget.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURROWS, ELIZABETH H. ''LIBBY''
description: BURROWS - Elizabeth H. ''Libby''. Of Summit, New Jersey on Sunday, February 9, 2003. Wife of the late Henry Morris Burrows and the late James Alexander Salmon. Also survived by many good friends. Memorial Service in Community Congregational Church, 200 Hartshorn Drive, Short Hills, N.J. on Wednesday, February 12 at 2 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions for a memorial fund would be appreciated to Community Congregational Church, Short Hills, NJ 07078, or the Summit Speech School 705 Central Avenue, New Providence, New Jersey 07974.

description: The director of one of America's largest Muslim charities, a man depicted by federal prosecutors as a crucial financier for Osama bin Laden, struck an eleventh-hour plea agreement today without admitting any ties to Al Qaeda or terrorism.

description: France and Germany closed ranks against the United States today, blocking attempts by NATO to begin military planning for a conflict with Iraq and issuing a joint declaration with Russia calling for intensified weapons inspections as an alternative to war.

description: FREEMAN - Mark. The members of The Lotos Club mourn the loss of their distinguished colleague and longtime friend, Mark Freeman, and send condolences to his family.

title: Creative Artists Buys Youth Intelligence
description: In an effort to increase its offerings to entertainment marketing clients, the Creative Artists Agency in Beverly Hills, Calif., has acquired Youth Intelligence in New York, a research and consulting company. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Ingram Micro May Exceed Estimates
description: Ingram Micro, the world's biggest distributor of computer parts, said yesterday that fourth-quarter sales would be at the high end of a company forecast and profit would meet or exceed analysts' expectations. Sales will be at the upper end of a forecast made in October for $5.75 billion to $5.90 billion, Ingram Micro said in a statement. The company said in December that sales would be at the lower range. Analysts expected profit of 18 cents a share, excluding some costs, according to Thomson First Call. The company did not provide an estimate for net income. Ingram Micro shares fell 16 percent on Friday after a rival, the Tech Data Corporation, said its fiscal 2004 earnings might decline as much as 25 percent from the previous year because of heightened competition and geopolitical uncertainty. Shares of Ingram Micro rose 8 cents yesterday, to $9.60. Ingram Micro will release full fourth-quarter results on Feb. 20.

title: U.S. Envoy's Effort to Recruit Iraqi Exile for Possible Future Government Sparks Protests
description: President Bush's special envoy to the Iraqi opposition is quietly trying to recruit a former senior Iraqi official to help provide a transition to democracy in the event that Saddam Hussein is ousted, administration officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATTERSON, MYRON C., M.D.
description: PATTERSON - Myron C., M.D. The entire St. Luke'sRoosevelt Hospital Center family acknowledges with sadness the passing of our beloved friend and colleague, Myron C. Patterson, M.D., a member of the hospital's Cardiology staff for over 50 years. Dr. Patterson forever will be remembered for his outstanding clinical expertise and his extraordinary commitment to the education of physicians in the diagnosis and treatment of heart disease. To his wife Michaeleen, his daughters Anne Baier and Linda Kocsis, the entire Patterson family and all who loved him, we extend heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman Board of Trustees Richard F. Daines, M.D. President and CEO William Winkler, M.D. President, Medical Board Michael Lesch, M.D. Chairman of Medicine Jonathan Steinberg, M.D. Chief of Cardiology

title: Card Companies May Be Forced To Return Fees
description: Visa International and MasterCard International may have to pay back $500 million in fees they collected from people who used their cards abroad, according to a tentative ruling by a California judge.

title: Editorial Notebook; Code Orange at Disneyland
description: Having security guards search through visitors' belongings at the entrance to his beloved park could not have been part of Walt Disney's idea of a ''big, big beautiful tomorrow'' when he opened Disneyland in 1955. But ever since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, that's become as much a part of the Disney experience as standing in line for the Pirates of the Caribbean. And after Tom Ridge decreed a heightened state of alert (Code Orange) last week, Disney's security was ratcheted up even further.

title: BellSouth Case Will Go to Arbitration
description: The BellSouth Corporation won an extension of a court order preventing its vice chairman, Gary D. Forsee, from becoming chief executive of a rival telephone company, the Sprint Corporation. The judge also dismissed BellSouth's contention that Mr. Forsee should be barred from working for a competitor for 18 months.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: MYANMAR: AMNESTY REPORTS ON FIRST VISIT Amnesty International reported on its first visit to Myanmar, urging the government to release more than 1,000 political prisoners. At the same time, the Burmese authorities announced that they had arrested 12 more pro-democracy activists, most of them members of the opposition National League for Democracy headed by Daw Aung San Suu Kyi. Amnesty, based in London, had been seeking access to Myanmar since 1988, the year of a brutal crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators, and a two-person delegation was there from Jan. 30 to Feb. 8.

title: Weak Retail Sales Push Out More and More Executives
description: The revolving door for retail executives has really started to spin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ATTINSON, CHARLES
description: ATTINSON-Charles. Passed away peacefully February 10, 2003. Loving husband and best friend to Marylin; devoted father to Andrew and Susan; caring father-in-law to Freda, cherished grandfather to Alex and Avery and brother to Miriam and Sol. He will be missed by all that knew him and his memory will live forever in our hearts. Highly decorated Veteran, he fought his illness with grace, dignity and courage. His sense of humor and love of life touched us all. A graveside service, Wednesday, February 12th. Donations may be made to the Myasthenia Gravis Alliance, 61 Gramercy Park North, New York, New York.
