title: Flaws Seen in Campus Policies Replacing Affirmative Action
description: The admissions policies that have replaced affirmative action at public universities in Texas, Florida and California in recent years have failed to create freshman classes as diverse as their predecessors or their state populations, according to two reports released yesterday by researchers at Harvard University.

title: Bloomberg, With Promises to Keep, Says He Kept Many
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg took the unusual step of offering New Yorkers a report on his campaign promises yesterday, listing those he fulfilled, explaining those he failed to accomplish or postponed and, in a few cases, suggesting that a promise was not such a great idea to begin with.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEHMAN, AILEEN TARROW
description: LEHMAN - Aileen Tarrow. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Aileen Tarrow Lehman, beloved mother of Mark Lehman, a cherished and active friend of UJA-Federation. Mark and his wife, Diane, are devoted to helping those in need and supporting the work of UJA-Federation. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to Mark and Diane; to their children, David and Abigail; and to the entire Lehman family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: SCIENTIFIC-ATLANTA SUBPOENAED Scientific-Atlanta Inc. has received a federal subpoena related to a marketing support arrangement with Charter Communications Inc. , the No. 3 cable provider, Scientific-Atlanta said in a recent government filing. Scientific-Atlanta, one of the largest makers of boxes used by cable subscribers to receive television programming, said in a Feb. 7 filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it received a subpoena in January from the United States Department of Justice in the Eastern District of Missouri. The subpoena regarded the production of documents in connection with Scientific-Atlanta's marketing support deal with Charter. Scientific-Atlanta said it was cooperating with the investigation, but provided no further details. Information regarding the marketing deal was not immediately available. In November, federal investigators began an inquiry into how Charter, which is based in St. Louis, accounts for subscribers who do not pay their bills. Charter is one of Scientific-Atlanta's top customers, along with AOL Time Warner and the Cablevision Systems Corporation . A Scientific-Atlanta spokesman was not immediately available for comment yesterday. A Charter spokesman declined to comment on the Scientific-Atlanta subpoena, but reiterated that Charter was cooperating with investigators. (Reuters)

description: The latest radar on the proposed lifestyle magazine Radar is that it will be aimed ''at 29-year-olds as interested in Iraq as they are in Jennifer Lopez,'' its editor, Maer Roshan, told Women's Wear Daily. In other words, it will be a fashion magazine. Fashion is precisely the sort of fungible nexus where one can imagine encountering ''Iraq; impending war on,'' filed alongside ''Iraq; camouflage inspirations for spring!''

Terms were not disclosed.

description: The Securities and Exchange Commission should rethink its stance on allowing accounting firms to market tax advice to corporate executives, some House Democrats urged today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENDER, WILLIAM
description: BENDER-William. Born September 3, 1917, died at home February 7, 2003. Survived by his daughters Debbie and Amanda; his niece Susan Rotgard and his dog Freyda. A lifelong leftist and union organizer, born and lived in NYC until retiring to his home in Southampton. Services Friday, February 14, 2003 at 2pm at Brockett Funeral Home, 203 Hampton Road, Southampton. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be sent to causes he cared deeply about, ARF, Southampton Hospital or ACLU.

title: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: OSI Pharmaceuticals To Buy Cell Pathways
description: OSI Pharmaceuticals Inc., a biotechnology company focused on cancer treatments, will acquire Cell Pathways Inc. for $32 million in stock, gaining experimental lung- and bowel-disease drugs. Each Cell Pathways share will be exchanged for 0.0567 of an OSI share. That values Cell Pathways at 80 cents a share, a 58 percent premium over the stock's Friday closing price. If OSI files for regulatory approval to sell either of Cell Pathways' most advanced experimental drugs, Cell Pathways stockholders may be eligible for another 0.04 share of OSI. The purchase will expand OSI's cancer drug pipeline with Aptosyn, which is in the final stage of clinical testing for small-cell lung carcinoma, and CP461, which researchers are testing at different doses in patients with several cancers. OSI shares fell 39 cents, or 2.8 percent, to $13.79, and Cell Pathways rose 24 cents, or 47 percent, to 75 cents.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Delay In Church Alteration
description: The city has delayed permission to alter the West-Park Presbyterian Church on the Upper West Side -- which some preservationists consider worthy of landmark status -- after City Councilwoman Gale A. Brewer and the community board protested that the alterations amounted to demolition. The permits granted last month by the Buildings Department called for removal of the steeple, walls, roof, floors and other parts of the church, at Amsterdam Avenue and 86th Street. Contractors for the church will have 10 days to explain the nature of the work, an agency spokesman said. The Rev. Robert L. Brashear, pastor of the church, said, ''Everything is under negotiation.'' David W. Dunlap (NYT)

title: Judge Refuses To Release Teenager Held In Boy's Death
description: A family court judge refused today to release the teenager accused of assault in the death of Faheem Williams, the 7-year-old boy whose body was discovered in a basement here last month.

description: A remarkable living legacy of the Mongol empire has been discovered by geneticists in a survey of human populations from the Caucasus to China.

title: Normal, But Not Too Normal
description: MORE times than anyone can possibly count, political leaders have pleaded since Sept. 11, 2001, that we have to go about our lives as usual, or else the bad guys will have won. But for them, it turns out, ''normal'' is confined to benign activities like shopping or eating out.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: International Court Advances
description: While the United States continues to oppose the International Criminal Court being set up to prosecute individuals for war crimes, genocide and crimes against humanity, Afghanistan became the 89th country to ratify the Rome Statute establishing the court. The latest accession comes three days after the election of 18 judges to serve on the court's first bench. The judges include seven women, as well as a balance of representatives from different regions and with different areas of legal expertise. They will be sworn in on March 11 in The Hague. Joya Rajadhyaksha (NYT)

title: Given the Chance, Chaney Grows Into Job
description: It seemed ridiculous. Don Chaney led the Knicks to a 12-27 record, broke a couple of marks for futility in the process, and received a contract extension. Then, after guiding the team into its first draft lottery in 15 years, he was granted another extension at the start of this season.

title: Dating Back to Sputnik, Long-Forgotten Debris May Pose a Fatal Threat
description: The domain of the space shuttle is relatively free of space junk, the flotsam from hundreds of satellite launches, but even so there is plenty to threaten the orbiters, and much of it escapes detection. So as investigators try to determine how the shuttle Columbia was lost, space debris is a suspect.

title: Aide Testifies That Mayor Was Obsessed With Bribes
description: By the late 1990's, Mayor Joseph P. Ganim of Bridgeport had grown so concerned about being caught that he had his City Hall office swept for listening devices and considered stashing kickbacks in a Cayman Islands bank account, the government's main witness testified today at the mayor's corruption trial.

title: A Long Wait for Winter
description: Our first real snowfall of the season was a beaut big, fat, lazy flakes that piled up through the day, nearly six inches in the cities, twice that up north. The only problem: It was just last week.

title: Terrorists Still a Threat, U.S. Official Tells Afghans
description: The American special envoy to Afghanistan said today that it was unacceptable that members of Al Qaeda and the Taliban were chased out of Afghanistan only to be given sanctuary in Pakistan's tribal areas, where Qaeda members are present.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, IRA L.
description: FISHER-Ira L., 81. Formerly of Long Island, NY passed away February 8, 2003. Survived by two children Ceil Fisher-Colson & Rick Fisher and his loving companion Florence Strauss. Lovingly remembered for his creative commercials for Fisher Brothers Famous Coat Store in Cedarhurst. Services in Florida.

title: London Journal; The Wedding Pictures: 2 Stars in Court Drama
description: None of the unauthorized photographs from the wedding of Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta-Jones were the least bit flattering. But the one showing the groom feeding wedding cake to the bride, reproduced in the newspaper The Sun under the headline ''Catherine Eater Jones'' was perhaps the most unfortunate of all.

title: Court Bans Peace March In Manhattan
description: Antiwar demonstrators may not march past the United Nations complex on Saturday, or anywhere else in Manhattan, a federal judge ruled yesterday. Agreeing with the city that a large, moving rally of 100,000 people or more raised serious security risks, the judge said the organizers would have to settle for a stationary rally five blocks north of the complex.

title: New York Arts Being Cut Back In Money Pinch
description: New York City has seen its rich cultural offerings seriously diminished by a weak economy, a drop in tourism, city budget cuts and a decline in private contributions following the terrorist attacks.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Parents Sue Over Children's Organs
description: A group representing more than 700 families whose children's organs were removed during post-mortem examinations in Irish pediatric hospitals without parental consent filed 50 legal suits against doctors, hospitals and public health authorities for damages on the grounds of psychological distress and breach of contract. The organization, Parents for Justice, said it would file several hundred more cases in the next month. The Irish government set up a formal inquiry into the matter in February 2000 after a Dublin hospital was found to have gathered pituitary glands from dead children for sale to a pharmaceutical company, a practice that is said to date from the 1970's. The parents' group said the investigation was ineffective, and stopped cooperating with it last year. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Scuba Diving Forever. Almost.
description: Older scuba divers who are wondering whether it is time to hang up their flippers can take heart: as long as they are in good general condition, a new study reports, there is no reason to give up the activity.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article yesterday about a high school basketball tournament in Trenton misidentified the relative whose death resulted in the absence of Bob Hurley Sr., the coach of St. Anthony of Jersey City, a participating team. She was his mother, not his wife.

title: Bush and Aznar New, if Unlikely, Allies
description: It seems an unlikely pairing the gregarious Texan and the reserved Castilian former tax inspector -- but a close friendship has formed between President Bush and Prime Minister Jos Mara Aznar of Spain.

title: Creative Artists Buys Youth Intelligence
description: In an effort to increase its offerings to entertainment marketing clients, the Creative Artists Agency in Beverly Hills, Calif., has acquired Youth Intelligence in New York, a research and consulting company. Terms were not disclosed.

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: EVENTS

title: Walking the Beat in Gaza
description: As Prime Minister Ariel Sharon tries to piece together a majority in Israel's Knesset, polls show that a despairing public does not believe any new government is likely to stop violence with the Palestinians. The only viable plan is the so-called road map of the ''diplomatic quartet.'' Yet there is no sign that this will soon become reality, as Mr. Sharon has criticized it and Washington is otherwise preoccupied with Iraq.

title: War-Jittery Kuwait Takes Bloom Off Desert
description: Kuwait's farmers are facing widespread crop failure this year, though the fault is not theirs -- or even Mother Nature's.

title: IMPATH CHIEF RESIGNS AFTER REVIEW OF EXPENSES
description: Impath Inc., which provides cancer testing and information on treatment to doctors, said yesterday that its chief executive, Anu Saad, had resigned after a review of her expenses over the last three years. Ms. Saad, 45, will reimburse the company $250,000 and the review will not result in a restatement of profit, said Robin Wagge, an outside spokeswoman for Impath. Ms. Saad had been chief executive since 1993, the company said. An Impath director, Carter Eckert, 59, was named chairman and chief executive, effective immediately. Mr. Eckert was chief executive of the Knoll Pharmaceutical Company from June 1995 to March 2001. ''Our board and management have zero tolerance for a lapse in corporate integrity at any level,'' Mr. Eckert said. He declined to comment on the nature of Ms. Saad's expenses.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Kills Intruder
description: The owner of a chain of music stores shot and killed an intruder who broke into his Queens home yesterday morning, the police said. Amalio Santos, the owner of Rincon Musical Inc., who is also a former federal air marshal, told the police he confronted two men in the basement of his home in Briarwood at 9:50 a.m. The men fled, but one turned and pointed a gun at Mr. Santos as the man ran across the lawn, Mr. Santos told the police. So Mr. Santos said he fired, killing the man with a shot to his face. Investigators said Mr. Santos had a permit for the weapon and has not been charged. Kevin Flynn (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; Quick Relief For Viewers: Tiger's Back
description: THE golf tournaments were the same. So were the courses, the palm trees or the cypress trees, the ocean or the desert. But for television viewers of the PGA Tour on its sunny swing through Hawaii, Arizona and California, something was absent. Somebody, really.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITCHELL, PETER HOWARD
description: MITCHELL-Peter Howard. Age 45 on February 7, 2003. Beloved son of Isabel Mitchell and Albert Mitchell, loving father of Zachary Nathan Mitchell, dear brother of Dr. Michael D. Mitchell and brother-in-law of Lynne. Caring uncle of Jake, Emma and Chris. Dear nephew and cousin. We will miss him always. Services on Wednesday, 11:15AM at the ''Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Colombia Will Tie Aid Request to Terror
description: Colombia's defense minister flew to Washington today to seek yet more aid from the Bush administration as the six-month-old government of President lvaro Uribe signaled that it would use the bombing of an exclusive Bogot club on Friday to press for renewed assistance in battling terrorism.

title: UConn Answers Call Without Calhoun
description: They were home, finally, before their customary rowdy crowd, which is always quick to comfort its team with a guttural bellow of ''UUUU-CONNN!'' Syracuse players sank into the visitor's bench in their familiar orange uniforms. One of the Big East's fiercest rivalries was about to tip off.

title: Giants Want to Retain Petitgout
description: The Giants want to re-sign left tackle Luke Petitgout, the team's most notable free agent, but one official familiar with their salary cap structure said it is highly unlikely the team would designate Petitgout with a transition or franchise tag.

title: For Transit Officials, An Earful of Revenge
description: ''In all very numerous assemblies, of whatever characters composed, passion never fails to wrest the scepter from reason.'' -- the Federalist Papers, No. 55.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BRONX: CUSTODIANS ACCUSED OF TAKING BRIBES Eighteen public school custodians and a window-cleaning contractor were arrested yesterday on charges that they took part in a kickback and bid-rigging scheme, the authorities said. Custodians in city schools have wide discretion over how maintenance money is spent. The contractor, Thomas Robinson of Family Window Cleaning in the Bronx, is accused of bribing the custodians, who worked at schools in Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island, with $1,000 to $4,000 apiece to land contracts that paid the cleaning company about $250,000, Attorney General Eliot Spitzer said. Efforts to reach Mr. Robinson for comment last night were unsuccessful. Mr. Robinson helped the custodians get around bidding requirements by supplying them with fake bids, sometimes from companies that did not even exist, the authorities said.

title: Intensive Rewards as Well
description: To the Editor:

title: Irresponsible Tax Cuts
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND In Greenwich; Wall Street By the Sea, Exclusively
description: Greenwich, Conn., is known for its rolling hills, expansive coastline and mansions, and for its rich and powerful residents. But don't expect a celebrity map. Exclusivity defines the place. Consider that after World War II when the newly formed United Nations was looking for a home, Greenwich said no, setting an anti-development tone that prevails to this day.

title: Hawks and Doves Line Up on Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Fish Evolve and Multiply, but Not in the Traditional Way
description: It all began on that fateful day when one fish evolved legs. Suddenly transformed from a silver swimmer into a bold pioneer, this creature stood on the threshold of what would become an explosion of evolutionary diversification. But this flowering of forms would be played out, not in the muck of primordial seashores, but on automobiles.

title: Agencies Establish Public Affairs Units
description: Two public relations agencies are making moves in public affairs services.

title: Russia to Build 2 Pipelines in the East
description: Along a snow-swept highway, an oil pipeline with a capacity of one million barrels a day is running at a relative trickle. The pipeline comes to an abrupt end at a giant refinery in Angarsk, a short distance from this Siberian city 150 miles from the Mongolian border. That is as far east as the Russian crude oil pipeline system goes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOSLOW, FAYE
description: KOSLOW-Faye. Beth El Synagogue of New Rochelle mourns the passing of the dear mother of Ellen Resnick and mother-in-law of our Trustee Merill Resnick. Heartfelt condolences to the family. Melvin N. Sirner, Rabbi Bertram S. Schwarz, Pres.

title: At Tax Time, Health Care Costs May Be a Factor
description: When James Busby, a Brooklyn music teacher, was battling Kaposi's sarcoma, an AIDS-related cancer, his doctor prescribed some blood-building drugs to help him deal with the side effects of chemotherapy. The drugs allowed Mr. Busby to regain much of his strength. But, he said, they cost about half of his annual income.

title: Parents' Rite of Passage: Shopping for a Camp
description: In searching for a suitable camp for her 11-year-old daughter, Linda Friedman Schmidt of Franklin Lakes, N.J., interviewed at least a dozen camp directors.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: When Facial Wrinkles Are Ironed Away for Good
description: Like many of her friends in Miami, Ana Alvarado was starting to feel older, and the deepening wrinkles on her face and forehead only made her feel worse.

title: Resounding No Greets a Plan To Increase L.I.R.R. Fares
description: Proposals to raise Long Island Rail Road fares as much as one-third drew a virtually unanimous reaction from elected officials, transportation advocates and everyday commuters speaking out tonight at a hearing here.

title: Monk in Rebelling Greek Order Dies in Accident
description: A monk who was a member of a conservative order that had been told to leave Mount Athos died late Saturday after he drove a tractor off a cliff. But religious authorities denied accusations today that the monk died after a police chase related to the directive to leave.

title: Longhorns Defeat Sooners
description: Brandon Mouton scored 14 points and Royal Ivey hit the key 3-pointer last night as No. 6 Texas defeated No. 5 Oklahoma, 67-61, to snap an eight-game losing streak against the visiting Sooners.

title: Dancers Meet and Part, but Emotion Remains
description: Lynne Taylor-Corbett's ''Chiaroscuro'' was created for Jock Soto in 1994 as part of the New York City Ballet's Diamond Project series. Performed by the company on Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater, the ballet remains a fine vehicle for Mr. Soto, a longtime City Ballet principal dancer who came of artistic age with the company. The ballet's title is said to refer to the construction of the dance and to the six performers' interactions. But Mr. Soto himself has always been a dancer of clear light and deep shadow. This season he has danced with a newly sharp edge that came to the fore in ''Chiaroscuro.''

title: Truck-Van Crash Kills 3 in Harlem, Including 2 Sisters
description: Three members of a Canadian family, including two young sisters, were killed yesterday afternoon when a dump truck filled with construction debris and rocks collided with a van at an intersection in Harlem. The truck flipped onto its side and spilled its contents onto the van, the police said. The fourth person in the van, the girls' mother, was hospitalized.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN DECLINES. The dollar rose against the yen on signs that Iraq was cooperating more with United Nations weapons inspectors. In New York, the dollar settled at 121.15 yen, from 120.22 on Friday.

title: Plea Bargain In '85 Blast On Indian Jet
description: A suspect charged in the bombing of an Air-India Boeing 747 in 1985 that killed 329 people surprised a Vancouver courtroom today by pleading guilty to 329 counts of manslaughter, apparently as part of a plea-bargain agreement that could help prosecute two other suspects.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANE, JOHN
description: KANE-John. Born October 27, 1928, died suddenly February 6, 2003. John leaves behind his much loved and beautiful wife Mary, as well as his daughter Janet and son-in-law Daniel Scapin, whom he loved completely. John also leaves behind his sister Mary. John was a good, honest, hard working, kind and generous person who built a beautiful life for his family. His loss leaves our lives utterly altered.

title: Ruby Braff, an Old-Style Jazz Trumpeter and Cornetist, 75
description: Ruby Braff, a jazz trumpeter and cornetist who defied the odds by rising to fame in the modern era with a resolutely old-fashioned style, died on Sunday in North Chatham, Mass. He was 75 and lived in Harwich, Mass.

title: When Allies Don't See Eye to Eye
description: To the Editor:

title: New Map Unveiled of Universe at Start of Time
description: Astronomers unveiled today what they said was the most detailed and precise map yet produced of the universe at the beginning of time, one that confirms the Big Bang theory in triumphant detail and opens new chapters in the prehistory of the cosmos.

title: Accused Kidnappers Flee Manila Jail in Blow to Crackdown
description: DAVAO CITY, the Philippines, Feb. 11  In a setback to President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo's campaign to eliminate widespread kidnapping gangs, six accused gang members escaped this morning from a Manila jail where they were being held while standing trial on abduction charges.

title: Full Text: Words of C.I.A. and F.B.I. Chiefs
description: Following are full transcripts from opening statements in testimony yesterday by George J. Tenet, director of central intelligence, and Robert S. Mueller III, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, before the Senate select intelligence committee as recorded by Federal News Service Inc.

title: Loss and Illness
description: To the Editor:

title: Whoosh, Rattle or Buzz In Spine-Tingling Sounds
description: Tiny clicks. A hum. The buzz of static. A whoosh of breath through a trumpet. The rustle of a stick brushing a drumhead. The distant clang of a gentle touch on an electric guitar string. Those were among the sounds receiving intent concentration from both performers and audience on Thursday night at Tonic, starting the two-night Amplify 2003 festival of improvised music.

title: 'Surcharge' by Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: Vendors Rally Round the War Protesters
description: The greenbacks were waving from outstretched hands even before the antiwar protesters flooded the square and the peace flags were unfurled.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Profit At British Airways
description: After reducing costs by cutting jobs and abandoning money-losing routes, British Airways posted a 13 million ($21 million) profit in the third quarter in contrast to a net loss of 144 million one year earlier. The company plans further job reductions by next year to offset the global economic slowdown and the lingering impact on air travel of the Sept. 11 attacks. Rod Eddington, British Airways' chief executive, warned that 2003 would be tougher than 2002, reflecting worries about a war in Iraq. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Consumers in Europe Resist Gene-Altered Foods
description: At the Happy Apple greengrocer in this Elizabethan town in England's West Country, the roasted vegetable pasty is labeled, clearly and proudly, as GM-free. So is the hommity pie and a scattering of other products crammed onto shelves.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Hockey Father Seeks New Trial
description: Thomas Junta, who was convicted of beating another man to death at their sons' hockey practice, asked for a new trial, saying prosecutors had withheld information that could have undercut a prosecution witness. After claiming self-defense in the fight, Mr. Junta, left, was convicted of involuntary manslaughter in the death of Michael Costin and sentenced to 6 to 10 years in prison. A medical examiner testified that Mr. Costin's injuries were too severe to be accidental. Mr. Junta's motion contended that the examiner suggested in a speech before the trial that the injuries could have been accidental. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: Murder Defendant's In-Laws Tell Jurors Why They Remain Her Strongest Supporters
description: As Dr. Clara Harris sits in court every day, her staunchest supporters are the parents of her husband, the man she is accused of killing with her Mercedes-Benz.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Farm Adjustments
description: The government has proposed a 36 percent cut in tariffs on farm products and a 55 percent cut in its agricultural subsidies over a six-year period, beginning in 2006. The government made the proposals to the World Trade Organization in keeping with the Doha Development Agenda that emerged from last year's World Trade Organization meeting in Doha, Qatar. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Another Big Name, Kovalev, Added to Star-Heavy Rangers
description: Nearly a decade after he helped the Rangers win their only Stanley Cup since 1940, and four seasons after he was shipped out by an exasperated coaching staff, Aleksei Kovalev is a Ranger once more.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISNER, EDWARD
description: EISNER-Edward: The Jewish Center of the Hamptons mourns the passing of Edward Eisner, beloved brother of Florence Matthews. We extend condolences to Florence and family. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Rabbi Alon Levkovitz Cantor Debra Stein Donald Zucker, President

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: DirecTV To Raise As Much As $295 Million
description: DirecTV, a unit of the Hughes Electronics Corporation, said yesterday that it planned to raise as much as $2.95 billion through a note sale and bank financing. DirecTV will privately sell as much as $1.4 billion of 10-year senior notes and raise $1.55 billion through senior secured credit facilities, the company said in a statement. The company said it expected to complete the financing by early next month. Hughes will use proceeds from the note sale and the term-loan portion of the credit facilities to repay existing debt and pay for operations. Hughes had $568 million in long-term debt as of Dec. 31, a spokesman, Richard Dore, said in an interview. Deutsche Bank, Bank of America, Credit Suisse First Boston, Goldman Sachs Group and Salomon Smith Barney are managing the note sale, said people close to the offering. Hughes Electronics' credit is rated Ba3 by Moody's Investors Service, three levels below investment grade, and B+ by Standard & Poor's, four levels below. The new credit facilities will have a term of five to seven years and will be secured by almost all of DirecTV's assets. As much as $500 million of the facilities will not be drawn at closing, DirecTV said. Hughes shares rose yesterday 45 cents, or 4.7 percent, to $10.20.

title: Administration Gives Advice on How to Prepare for a Terrorist Attack
description: The Bush administration issued detailed advice today on how the public should prepare for a possible terrorist attack using chemical, biological or nuclear weapons, insisting that it was motivated by a sense of caution, not any specific intelligence that such an attack was imminent.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Stem-Cell Bill Withdrawn After Protest
description: After protests from anti-abortion groups, a bill to authorize research on stem cells from human embryos was withdrawn just hours before a final vote was scheduled yesterday in the New Jersey State Assembly. The bill's lead sponsor, Assemblyman Neil M. Cohen, said it would be revised to address opponents' concerns that the wording might permit the cloning of human beings. Laura Mansnerus (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: TRADE SURPLUS FALLS Japan's current account surplus contracted in December as export growth slowed. It was only the second time in the last 15 months that the surplus has declined, suggesting that the country's export-led recovery is losing steam. For all of 2002, the surplus grew 34 percent, the first expansion in four years. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLEEMER, NORMAN S.
description: BLEEMER-Norman S. Of Manhattan and West End, N.J. on February 10, 2003, age 69, after a short valiant fight with cancer. Loving husband, devoted father, beloved grandfather and dear brother. He was kind, honest and ethical. Services Wednesday, Feb 12, 11:30AM at Riverside, 76 St. & Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Olberman to Anchor Olympics on Cable
description: Keith Olbermann, who worked for NBC Sports and MSNBC from 1997 to 1998, will anchor CNBC's and MSNBC's Olympic coverage next year at the Summer Games in Athens. He will fill the role handled by Jim Lampley at the 2002 Salt Lake Winter Olympics. Lampley will play an unspecified role in NBC's Olympic coverage.

title: Ron Ziegler, Press Secretary to Nixon, Is Dead at 63
description: Ron Ziegler, President Richard M. Nixon's press secretary, died of a heart attack on Monday in his home in Coronado, Calif., his wife, Nancy, told The Associated Press. Mr. Ziegler, who was known for referring to the Watergate break-in as a ''third-rate burglary'' and for steadfastly speaking for President Nixon as his presidency crumbled, was 63.

title: Stewart Is Finally Learning to Temper His Tantrums
description: Maybe it will be easier now for Tony Stewart. He does not have to prove he can be a champion in Nascar's Winston Cup series. He already did that. He does not have to feel the pressure of expectations anymore. He has met them.

title: NASA SAYS IT HAS ELECTRONIC PARTS FROM THE SHUTTLE
description: NASA officials said today that they had identified a two-foot-long piece of wreckage from the space shuttle Columbia as a piece of the left wing, where evidence suggests the doomed craft's troubles began. The officials also said that on Sunday they recovered electronic equipment that they hope might contain data about the shuttle's last seconds.

title: Suitor Won't Pursue Cable and Wireless
description: In an abrupt reversal, PCCW, the Hong Kong telecommunications company, said today that it would not pursue a takeover of Cable and Wireless, a British rival, explaining that the probability of reaching a friendly deal remained too uncertain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVY, RAYMOND P.
description: DAVY-Raymond P. On February 8, 2003, of Marlton, N.J. and formerly of Rockville Centre, New York, Reston, Virginia and Vero Beach, Florida. Born February 9, 1914, he was the beloved husband of Muriel for 64 years. Devoted father of Robert and Christopher; cherished grandfather of Erin, Robert, Jr., Lauren and Sean and greatgrandfather to Ryan, Jackson and Grace. Former Senior Vice President with R & H Macy's and Company until 1973; avid golfer, lover of crossword puzzles and a good joke. He will be missed by all who loved him.

title: As an alternative to pop-up ads, marketers are trying to create useful Web sites to draw viewers.
description: A WEB site built by MSN for Lexus, the maker of luxury cars, hopes to attract customers by applying the increasingly important dictum of online advertising: make yourself useful.

title: Calls To Fire Jarvis Grow Loud
description: It began with boos during St. John's humiliating 71-54 loss to Virginia Tech on Saturday. It continued yesterday with irate fans on radio talk shows and in Internet chat rooms.

title: Cablevision's Feud With YES Persists
description: After months in a dormant state, the feud between the YES Network and Cablevision has revived. Newspaper advertisements by YES shouted claims of Cablevision's anticompetitive behavior. Cablevision replied with bile. Legislative action to try to resolve the dispute is possible, at least in New Jersey. Round-the-clock talks in a lawyer's office were suggested, although a steel cage on Jerry Springer's stage might be more appropriate.

title: Manila Calls Cease-Fire in a Push Against Rebels
description: DAVAO CITY, the Philippines, Feb. 11  The government today called off a military offensive against Muslim separatist rebels in the southern Philippines in deference to the Muslim holiday of Eid.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Assembly Speaker Urges Cellphone Reform
description: Standing with the relatives of two of the four teenagers who disappeared in the icy waters off the Bronx on Jan. 24, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver yesterday proposed borrowing $300 million for cellphone technology to pinpoint those needing emergency aid. Calling such spending overdue, Mr. Silver said the bonds would be paid back over time with some of the millions of dollars in cellphone surcharges collected each year in New York. The teenagers, who are still missing, used a cellphone to call for help, but 911 operators did not have technology to locate callers. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENLEAF, SYBIL CONRAD
description: GREENLEAF-Sybil Conrad. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of our fellow member, Sybil Conrad Greenleaf, and extend our sincere condolences to her family. Alex C. Solowey, President

title: Iraq Militants Who Killed Kurd Minister Take Hostage
description: The Islamic group Ansar al-Islam, which the United States claims has ties to both Saddam Hussein and Al Qaeda, abducted a man from a village in northern Iraq on Sunday, bringing to three the number of hostages it has taken in recent days, Kurdish officials said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a decision by the General Accounting Office to end its efforts to get records of Vice President Dick Cheney's energy task force misstated the given name of the agency's comptroller general. He is David M. Walker, not Kenneth.

title: A Centennial Celebration Of All Things Crosby
description: Centennial celebrations of songwriters and performers tend to be laudatory. But the cabaret world has seldom seen a revue that piles on the hyperbole as indiscriminately as ''Bing Sings Whilst Bregman Swings! A Centennial Show Celebrating Bing Crosby'' at the Firebird Upstairs Supper Club.

title: MetLife Posts Profit From Strong Sales
description: MetLife Inc., the life insurer, earned $561 million in the fourth quarter, reversing a loss as it took market share away from rivals and sold real estate investments.

title: Blow a Gasket, for Your Heart
description: Studies have suggested that people who have a lot of anger may be at higher risk for cardiovascular disease, but a new report finds that the relationship may not be so clear.

title: STEVEN MADDEN TO SELL NAME-BRAND SHOES IN EUROPE
description: Steven Madden Ltd., signed an agreement with Footwear Europe and Export Trading to sell its name-brand shoes in some European countries. Financial terms were not released. F.E.E.T., a Paris-based joint venture of Groupe Royer and Guy Rapp, was formed to sell Steve Madden-branded footwear in Europe, Steven Madden said. F.E.E.T., which already distributes about 20 brands of footwear, will sell the shoes in France, Germany, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg, beginning later this year. Steven Madden is based in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Roche to Buy No. 2 Maker Of Pumps For Insulin
description: Roche Holding, the giant Swiss drug maker, said today that it had agreed to buy Disetronic Holding, the world's second-largest maker of insulin pumps, for 1.6 billion Swiss francs ($1.2 billion) in cash and stock. It said it would then resell the injection-products part of the business to Disetronic's founder and chairman, Willy Michel, for 420 million francs ($310 million).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOCKNOFF, ALAN
description: STOCKNOFF - Alan. The most caring, kind, friendly, fun person we've ever known. Linda, Michelle, Michael and his many, many friends will keep his memory alive forever. You'll always be our best friend. Ellen, Richard and Sean

title: New York State Releases List of Schools With Steep Gains on Tests
description: New York State education officials released a list yesterday of 712 schools that have posted steep gains on standardized math and reading tests since 1999. The officials declared the results proof that all schools, even those with the poorest students, could meet high standards.

title: When Weight Wears Out the Hips
description: Teenage girls who are obese may be much more likely to need hip replacement later in life, researchers are reporting.

title: L.I. Diocese Deceived Victims Of Abuse, a Grand Jury Says
description: A Suffolk County grand jury accused Roman Catholic Church officials on Long Island yesterday of protecting scores of pedophile priests for decades by using sham policies and a bogus ''intervention team'' to trick and silence victims, cover up crimes, avoid scandals and hold down financial consequences.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEEDS, MURRAY
description: LEEDS-Murray. The Officers, Directors, Administration and Staff of the Gurwin Jewish Geriatric Center extend their sympathy to Alfred W. Levy, Chairman Emeritus of our Board on the loss of his brother Murray, a founding supporter of Gurwin. Our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Joseph Gurwin, Chairman Lawrence Simon, President Herbert H. Friedman, E.V.P.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Wanted in Space: Gregarious Loners Who Take Risks, Cautiously
description: When, in 1913, Sir Ernest Shackleton needed a crew for his planned expedition across the Antarctic, he announced his intentions in The Times of London.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank Results Slip
description: Woori Finance Holdings, the Korean banking group, reported a net profit of 586 billion won ($489 million) last year, 100 billion below last year's net of 686 billion. The lower profit reflected mounting defaults and late payments on consumer loans, a problem that has cut profits of most Korean banks. Korea Exchange Bank, the sixth-largest bank, also reported a sharp decline in profit, from 222 billion won ($185 million) in 2001 to 113 billion last year. Korea Exchange Bank's problems reflect its role as lead creditor for Hynix Semiconductor, taken over by its creditors last year, and other ailing firms.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Uganda Sets Withdrawal Date
description: Uganda said it planned to withdraw its estimated 2,000 troops from northeastern Congo by March 20 and join the Congolese government in trying to pacify the troubled Ituri region. President Joseph Kabila of Congo and President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda reached the deal at a meeting in Tanzania. It comes as the United Nations has accused both Uganda and Rwanda of building up troop levels in recent weeks in the area near Uganda's border with Congo. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Group Contests Winnow Pack At Westminster
description: A year ago, the thinking was that a Kerry blue terrier known as Mick was a sure bet to win the Westminster Kennel Club show, the Super Bowl of American dogdom. It was his show to lose, and he lost, probably because of too much undisciplined enthusiasm.

title: A Test for the Cleveland's New Leader
description: The appointment of the young Austrian conductor Franz Welser-Mst as music director of the Cleveland Orchestra in 1999 came as quite a surprise. Though a serious, accomplished and respected musician, he just did not seem to have the stature and dynamism to take charge of one of the world's great orchestras. But everyone in the institution, from the board members to the bass players, had performed so well during the illustrious tenure of the conductor Christoph von Dohnanyi that you wanted to trust that they knew what they were doing.

title: Hundreds in U.S. Have Ties to Al Qaeda, F.B.I. Director Says
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11  F.B.I. Director Robert S. Mueller III said today that several hundred Islamic extremists linked to Al Qaeda are in the United States, with some organized in cells that could be ordered to carry out terrorist attacks in this country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, MORTON E.
description: HERMAN-Morton E. Beloved husband of Sally. Devoted father of Ellen & David Aston-Reese. Service today 1:00 PM ''Parkside'' Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave, Bklyn, NY

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: PROFIT AT BRITISH AIRWAYS After reducing costs by cutting jobs and abandoning money-losing routes, British Airways posted a 13 million ($21 million) profit in the third quarter in contrast to a net loss of 144 million one year earlier. The company plans further job reductions by next year to offset the global economic slowdown and the lingering impact on air travel of the Sept. 11 attacks. Rod Eddington, British Airways' chief executive, warned that 2003 would be tougher than 2002, reflecting worries about a war in Iraq. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: The Wimps of War
description: George W. Bush's admirers often describe his stand against Saddam Hussein as ''Churchillian.'' Yet his speeches about Iraq -- and for that matter about everything else -- have been notably lacking in promises of blood, toil, tears and sweat. Has there ever before been a leader who combined so much martial rhetoric with so few calls for sacrifice?

title: For U.S. Women's Team, A Changed Landscape
description: For the first time in the short history of the United States women's national team, the coach, in this case APRIL HEINRICHS, will not have the players under one roof for an extended length of time in the run-up to the World Cup.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This leaves those doctors who are treating psychotic, condemned prisoners in an untenable position: treating the prisoner may provide short-term relief but ultimately result in his execution.''

title: Vivendi Picks Auction Houses To Sell Seagram Building Art
description: Vivendi Universal, the troubled French entertainment conglomerate, said yesterday that it had chosen Christie's to sell the collection of modern art that adorned the offices and public spaces of the Seagram Building on Park Avenue.

title: Economy Saddled by Worry Over Security, Fed Chief Says
description: The economy is laboring under a cloud of geopolitical tensions and uncertainties, but it remains in about the same shape as it was six months ago, the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan, told Congress today.

title: Behold the Clouds: Spaceflight Made the Familiar New
description: Even in the best of circumstances, landing a space shuttle is never routine.

title: With Air Travel Soft, Priceline Widens Its Loss
description: Priceline.com, the Internet vendor of travel services, reported today that its quarterly loss increased to $7.41 million as sales continued to fall amid a slump in the airline business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZELL, RAYMOND A.
description: KATZELL-Raymond A. Age 83. Of Medford, New Jersey. Died February 5, 2003. Loving husband of Kitty, his wife of almost 50 years. Memorial services to be arranged in New York and Medford. Memorial contributions to New York University.

title: Wandering in a Wilderness Of Old Testament Passages
description: It's a happy thing when a chorus devotes virtually its whole New York concert to works by living composers. And Gloriae Dei Cantores, a chorus from the Community of Jesus in Orleans, Mass., upped the ante by commissioning a major new work by Mark O'Connor, ''Folk Mass,'' which had its world premiere at St. Thomas Church on Tuesday night.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Man Dies In Robbery Attempt
description: One man was killed yesterday as he and two others tried to rob a wholesale beverage distributor at gunpoint, said Officer George Jensen, a Police Department spokesman. The suspect, who was 41, struggled with three employees at the business, on East 146th Street in the South Bronx, and was shot in the chest and head. The suspect, whose name was not released, was pronounced dead at the scene, Officer Jensen said. One of the employees, a 56-year-old man, was hit in the head with a gun and was taken to Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center for evaluation. The other robbery suspects fled, and it was not known early this morning if they had taken anything, Officer Jensen said. Two guns were recovered at the scene, the police said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Times Appoints 2 Editors to New Positions
description: The New York Times has appointed two editors to new positions.

title: Chief Protector of Wetlands Redefines Them and Retreats
description: The first time the Army Corps of Engineers counted how much federally protected wetlands would be lost to a colossal new container port being planned here, it came up with more than 100 acres. The next time, the agency revised that count to fewer than three acres.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, HON. CORNELIUS J.
description: O'BRIEN-Hon. Cornelius J. On Feb. 9, 2003, Appellate Division. Beloved husband of Alice (nee Dunn). Loving father of Alice Gunther and son-in-law Chris. Loving grandfather of Alice, Mary, Clair, Bernadette and Cornelius O'Brien Gunther. Funeral Wednesday, 9 A.M., from The Urban Funeral Home, 42-17 69th Street, Woodside, NY. Mass of Christian burial, St. Mary's Church, 10 A.M. Interment, Holy Rood Cemetery. Visiting Tues., 2-5 and 7-9 P.M.

title: Robust Reflections on a Solitary Journey
description: Frederic Rzewski's first moves at the Kitchen on Thursday night were to sit down on the piano bench, put on his glasses and look uncomfortable, get up and stand in front of the piano, cock an ear and then ask rather firmly that the fan, which was basically undetectable, be turned off. It was. The ambience improved, and the room was prepared for his obdurate and sometimes beautiful new music.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEUSCHLE, KURT W., MD.
description: DEUSCHLE-Kurt W., MD. The Mount Sinai Medical Center mourns the passing of Kurt W. Deuschle, MD. Known as the ''father of community medicine'', Dr. Deuschle defined the discipline, founded the first department of community medicine in a medical school in the US, and, in 1968 founded the nation's first urban department of community medicine at Mount Sinai. He served as the Ethel H. Wise Professor and Chairman of the Department of Community and Preventive Medicine at Mount Sinai School of Medicine until 1990. His commitment to empowering people through community medicine grounded in the priorities of the community led to better health for populations in locals ranging from East Harlem to Appalachia. His contributions to medicine and society live on in the generations of clinicians and researchers he inspired to follow in his footsteps. We extend condolences to his colleagues, his wife Jeanne and his children & grandchildren. Peter W. May Chairman of the Boards of Trustees, The Mount Sinai Medical Ctr Kenneth I. Berns, M.D., PhD CEO and President, The Mount Sinai Medical Ctr Kenneth L. Davis, M.D. Dean, Mount Sinai School of Medicine Larry Hollier, M.D., President The Mount Sinai Hospital

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Austria: Gas Stations Acquired
description: OMV of Austria is poised to become Central Europe's largest oil and gas company after agreeing to pay 377 million euros ($404 million) to BP for 313 Aral gas stations in Germany, Hungary and Slovakia. OMV will also buy a 45 percent stake in the Bayernoil refinery and an 18 percent stake in the Trans Alpine Pipeline from BP, which has been forced to sell the stations by German antitrust regulators. OMV will now have 1,615 gas stations, or a 12 percent share, of Central and Eastern Europe's growing markets, where it is battling for supremacy with MOL Rt., of Hungary and PKN Orlen of Poland. description: When Penn State opened for a new term in January, about 300 students were turned away from their dormitories because they had not complied with a new law requiring students to be vaccinated for meningococcal disease or sign a waiver opting out.

title: Divisive Diplomacy With Europe
description: The NATO alliance is facing what may be its greatest crisis in a generation -- an unnecessary argument about whether to fortify Turkish defenses in advance of a war in Iraq. Obviously, Turkey should get what it needs. But this has become a charged debate because it is a proxy for another more fundamental argument -- whether our allies should be expected merely to accede to American policy. The question of war in Iraq has turned into far too personal a dispute over American leadership. The French, who are leading the rebellion, are showing poor judgment. But the fault lies as well with the Bush administration's destructive ''with us or against us'' approach, which is being foolishly applied to some of our most important allies.

title: High Above Earth, Shuttle's Loss Resonates on Space Station

Lukoil's chief executive, Vagit Y. Alekperov, said that the site was close to the center of the Caspian and that it was thought to contain recoverable reserves of about 730 million barrels of oil. Lukoil already owns stakes in three projects in Kazakhstan, including a holding in TengizChevroil. Led by ChevronTexaco, TengizChevroil is the largest oil development project in the former Soviet Union including Russia.

Mikhail V. Babich resigned as prime minister over the weekend after an unusually public dispute over finances with Akhmad Kadyrov, a Chechen who under the republic's convoluted political leadership serves as the head of the local administration. Mr. Babich, appointed by the Kremlin only three months ago, will be replaced with Anatoly A. Popov, above, a Russian official who now oversees reconstruction efforts in the Chechnya. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMBOS, CONSTANTINE PETER
description: LAMBOS-Constantine Peter, 76, of Tampa, Florida, formerly of Crestwood, New York, died peacefully in his sleep at home on Saturday, February 8, 2003. Born August 4, 1926, in Manhattan, Peter served in the United States Army as a rifleman-scout with the 63rd Infantry Division in France and Germany during World War II. He graduated first in his class from New York University Law School, where he was the Editor-in-Chief of the Law Review. This year marked his fifty-fifth year as a lawyer. He was the senior partner of Lambos & Junge in New York City and served as chief management counsel to the East Coast longshore industry for the past forty years. Peter had served as the President of Leewood Golf Club in Eastchester, New York and the Downtown Athletic Club in New York City. For the past twenty years he was the managing partner of The Eagles Golf Club in Odessa, Florida. He is survived by his devoted wife of fifty years, Theodora, his loving son, William, his grandchildren, Elizabeth, Katherine and Peter, his sisters, Theresa Coutroulos, Mary Lambos, Helen Papantonis, and Aphrodite Danas, and his daughters-in-law, Carol and Diane. The funeral will be held on Thursday, February 13, 2003, at 10 A.M. at the Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church in New Rochelle, New York. Memorial donations may be made to the Peter and Andrew Lambos Foundation, 16101 Nine Eagles Drive, Odessa, Florida 33556.

What the pictures quickly call to mind is that the cold war, America's previous age of anxiety, produced its own uniform etched in sharp angles.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: ANOTHER SAFEWAY BIDDER Philip Green, a British retailing executive, forged ahead with his plan to join the bidding for Safeway, a British supermarket chain that is up for sale, by filing a formal proposal with the Office of Fair Trading, one of the country's two antitrust bodies. The office is reviewing proposals from four other bidders: Tesco; J Sainsbury; ASDA, a unit of Wal-Mart Stores ; and William Morrison Supermarkets. If those proposals raised serious antitrust concerns, they would be referred to the second antitrust body, the Competition Commission, for a more in-depth review. A ruling is expected within 45 days. title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Network Appliance Profit Almost Triples
description: The world's largest maker of network-attached computer storage devices, Network Appliance, said yesterday that its third-quarter profit almost tripled, and sales rose faster than expenses. Net income in the quarter ended Jan. 24 increased to $19.7 million, or 6 cents a share, from $6.98 million, or 2 cents, a year earlier, the company said on its Web site. Sales rose 15 percent to $228.5 million from $198.3 million, outpacing a 6.1 percent gain in total operating costs. Network Appliance makes storage systems that attach to existing computer networks, which is less costly than building separate storage networks. Shares of Network Appliance fell as low as $10.47 in after-hours trading, down 30 cents. They rose 24 cents, to $10.77, in regular trading.

title: Elmo's Last Ride
description: The Taxi and Limousine Commission has decided to yank its series of recorded taxi seat-belt announcements in the next few months. The reason, though no one puts it this way, is that good intentions get you nowhere in New York City. No matter how important the advice to buckle your seat belt in a taxicab is -- and the unforgivingly hard plastic dividers between front and back seats makes it really important -- the announcements ended up sounding like low-fidelity nagging. According to an official study of the program, New Yorkers didn't learn to buckle up. They learned to shut up, at least until the announcement stopped droning in the back seat. Then they flagrantly left their belts unfastened. Every day the city was full of desperate acts of back-seat freedom.

The company also donated $25,000 for a program to help the school create an engineering curriculum, develop an auto shop specializing in Mercedes-Benzes, establish an after-school robotics team, and finance two student-run companies. ''The only people more excited than the faculty are the students,'' said EVARISTO JIMENEZ, the school's principal.

title: Suspect in Bali Bomb Attack Says Americans Were Target
description: A principal suspect in the bomb attack in Bali last October that killed nearly 200 people, most of them Australians, said today that Americans had been the primary target.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Loss At Chemical Concern
description: The Swiss chemical maker Clariant said it lost 648 million Swiss francs ($475 million) last year as a result of a write-off related to its purchase of BTP of Britain. The company lost 1.2 billion Swiss francs a year earlier. The write-off, 790 million Swiss francs, represents the remaining good will, or the difference between the price Clariant paid for the company and the cash value of its assets, that resulted from the acquisition. Clariant, based in Muttenz, said sales fell 3.3 percent. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: Excerpts From NASA's Final Communications With the Shuttle Columbia
description: Following are excerpts from NASA communications with the space shuttle Columbia on Feb. 1, beginning at 8:31 a.m., as recorded by The New York Times. NASA assisted in clarifying parts and identifying the speakers, who included Jeff Kling, the shuttle's maintenance, mechanical arm and crew systems officer, or MMACS; Leroy Cain, the flight director; Bill Foster, the ground controller; Charlie Hobaugh, the capsule communicator; Col. Rick D. Husband, the flight commander; Mike Sarafin, the guidance, navigation and control officer, or GNC; Laura Hoppe, instrumentation and communications officer, or INCO; Katie Rogers, emergency, environmental and consumables operation manager, or EECOM; and Richard Jones, flight dynamics officer, or FDO.

title: Seeking Customers in a Blighted Area
description: All along South Van Ness Boulevard the royal palms, craning too high to offer shade, tower over small frame houses where paint peels from the walls but not from the bars over the windows.

title: Words of the Poets
description: To the Editor:

title: Greenspan Throws Cold Water On Bush Arguments for Tax Cut
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, today rebutted many of President Bush's arguments in favor of big new tax cuts, saying that the economy probably does not need any short-term stimulus and warning that budget deficits could spiral out of control.

title: Words of the Poets
description: To the Editor:

title: Conferees Approve G.O.P. Provisions to Expand Development in Alaska National Forests
description: Republicans have tucked provisions into the spending bill that the House and Senate conferences are negotiating to permit road building in two Alaska forests, expand timber harvesting in national forests and open the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to exploratory oil drilling.

title: For Your Health or Their Business?
description: IT is difficult enough to sort right and wrong when the junk food people fight with the healthy food people. It's even more confusing when the healthy food people fight among themselves.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Entertainment Executive Named
description: The children's entertainment company Cinar named Stuart C. Snyder as its president and chief executive. Mr. Snyder, 43, was previously president of World Wrestling Federation Entertainment, now World Wrestling Entertainment, of Stamford, Conn. Cinar, the creator of Arthur the Aardvark, recently settled claims from thousands of shareholders seeking damages for losses from revenue diverted to an investment firm in the Bahamas. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Betting on War's Outcome? 1991 Clues May Be Misleading
description: The betting on TradeSports Exchange Ltd., an Internet site based in Dublin, is that there is an 80 percent chance that Saddam Hussein will be ousted as Iraq's leader by the end of June, a 63 percent chance by the end of April and a 37 percent chance by the end of next month, when a lot of analysts think a war will begin.

title: For Sprint Chief, a Hard Fall From Grace
description: To hear the Sprint Corporation's board tell it, the fall from grace of its longtime chief executive, William T. Esrey, is the consequence of his having followed bad tax advice in handling stock options that Mr. Esrey and his No. 2, Ronald LeMay, received in 1999 and 2000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINNICK, ROY
description: WINNICK-Roy. February 11, 2003. Survived by cherished daughters, Tracy and Kimberly, and loving brother and sister. Services private.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Lawmakers Clear Way For Tax Increase
description: The Westchester County Board of Legislators voted last night to adopt a contingency plan that includes a nearly 15 percent increase in property taxes, cuts to services and law enforcement layoffs to close a $67 million budget gap. The 9-to-5 vote came after the Westchester delegation in the Assembly refused to back a bill allowing an increase in the county sales tax. Lydia Polgreen (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANN, ROSE
description: DANN-Rose, 101, of Hollywood, FL, died Wednesday, February 5, 2003, eight days before her 102nd birthday. Rose died peacefully in her home surrounded by those who loved her. Formerly from Mt. Vernon, NY, Rose survived two husbands, Bertram Goldfield and Herbert Dann, and her daughter, Joan Goldfield Lifland. Those who mourn her passing include her son, Joseph Goldfield, her granddaughters, Sandra Lifland Rubin, Laurie Levey, Ellen Bakker, and Julie Yadgaroff, nine great-grandchildren, her niece, Janet Baker, her nephew, George Keller, her stepdaughter, Dani Sonnenblick, her stepson, Richard Dann, her stepgrandchildren, Jon Sonnenblick, Micki Hirsch, Robert Sonnenblick, and Patricia Dann Loyde. Those who knew Rose remember how much she enjoyed the ballet, theatre, concerts, and playing cards. She was a beautiful, caring, and generous woman who was gracious and kind to everyone she encountered. She will be missed by all who knew her. A memorial service will be held at Ferncliff Cemetery in Hartsdale, NY, on Sunday February 23, 2003.

title: Chinese Freer to Speak and Read, but Not Act
description: An article last month insisted that China's Communist leaders must learn from the capitalist West, embracing ''democracy and the rule of law.'' But this screed did not come from a dissident's pen, and its author is not in hiding. It appeared in the Communist Party's Southern Breeze magazine -- the words of a senior retired official.

title: Senior U.S. Officials Tell Lawmakers of Iraq-Qaeda Ties
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11  Senior Bush administration officials intensified the effort to make the case for military action against Saddam Hussein today, with testimony by Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and the director of central intelligence, George J. Tenet, linking Iraq and Al Qaeda.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOODBURN, JAMES W.
description: WOODBURN-James W. On February 7, 2003. Survived by his wife MaryAnn & brother Jerry. He was the beloved uncle of 46 nieces and nephews including Matthew and Jessica Woodburn.

title: Ronald L. Ziegler, Press Secretary to President Nixon, Is Dead at 63
description: Ronald L. Ziegler, the White House press secretary whose dogged defense of President Richard M. Nixon through the travails of Watergate made him the public face of a presidency struggling for survival, died of a heart attack on Monday at a hospital in Coronado, Calif., where he had a home. He was 63.

title: Inspectors Move to Destroy Shells Filled With Mustard Gas
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 12  United Nations arms inspectors began work today to destroy 10 old artillery shells filled with mustard gas, as a peace envoy sent here by the pope announced he would soon meet with President Saddam Hussein.

title: Sports of The Times; A Stand On Death And Life
description: Editors' Note Appended

title: Tapes of Shuttle's Descent Show Dawning of Disaster
description: The first hint of trouble came from Jeff Kling, the maintenance and mechanical officer at Mission Control who was monitoring the descent of the space shuttle Columbia.

title: KMART ASKS COURT TO PUNISH FORMER SUPPLY EXECUTIVE
description: The Kmart Corporation has asked a judge to hold a former supply-chain chief in contempt of court for not cooperating with the company's investigation into former management. The former executive, Anthony D'Onofrio, has not complied with seven subpoenas from the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Northern District of Illinois as part of Kmart's investigation, according to documents filed with the court. Mr. D'Onofrio was a ''critical player'' in the events that led to Kmart's bankruptcy filing in January 2002, the filing said. Mr. D'Onofrio left Kmart in March and now works at Linens 'n Things. He did not respond to a message left with his assistant, who said Mr. D'Onofrio would be traveling through Monday. Mr. D'Onofrio told Kmart he had not complied with the subpoenas because he was looking for a lawyer, the filing said.

title: Rivals of Microsoft File Antitrust Complaint in Europe
description: An alliance of technology companies said today that it had filed a new complaint with European antitrust regulators about the Windows XP operating system of Microsoft, just as the regulators were nearing the end of an investigation into earlier versions of Windows.

title: The Knicks Are Long Shots In More Ways Than One
description: After each Knicks practice and pregame shoot-around, Latrell Sprewell moves around the arc and focuses on the rim, his gaze leaving the basket only when he looks to catch the basketball. He does not stop shooting until he has made 7 of 10 3-pointers from seven spots on the floor. Sometimes it takes 10 minutes, sometimes 15, sometimes 20 or 25.

title: SOME CREDITORS OPPOSE OWENS CORNING RECOVERY PLAN
description: Credit Suisse First Boston and other creditors of Owens Corning, a leading maker of insulation, oppose a plan they say would give too much of the bankrupt company's assets to asbestos victims. A reorganization proposal to value asbestos-related claims at $16 billion would leave less money for Owens Corning's bank lenders, bondholders and other creditors, a lawyer, Andrew Rahl, said. Mr. Rahl represents a group of bondholders. Creditors intend to ask a federal bankruptcy judge to reduce the $16 billion valuation. Owens Corning has been in bankruptcy protection for 26 months.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Kidnapping Suspects Escape
description: In a setback to President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo's campaign to wipe out kidnapping gangs, six suspected gang members escaped from a Manila jail, where they were being held while standing trial on kidnapping charges. The prisoners apparently cut through a metal grill enclosing an annex building, the warden, Superintendent Emilio Culang, said before he was dismissed from his post. The police claim to have eliminated 6 of 21 known kidnapping syndicates since President Arroyo ordered a crackdown last year.

title: Duck and Cover
description: The nation has been so focused on the Bush administration's plans for war with Iraq that the war against Al Qaeda seemed to slip into the background. But the fear of terrorism was front and center again yesterday, as the F.B.I. director warned Congress about Qaeda cells inside this country and a new audio tape surfaced purporting to be a recording of Osama bin Laden urging Iraqis to undertake suicide missions against the United States. All this occurred at a time when the national terrorism alert level was at the nervous-making Code Orange level and the government was issuing guidelines on how to gird the family home against chemical or biological warfare.

title: In Our S.U.V.'s: A Love-Hate Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Wyeth Drug Is Approved
description: Wyeth said today that the Food and Drug Administration had approved use of its antidepressant Effexor as a treatment for social anxiety disorder.

title: Rules Eased for Surveillance of New York Groups
description: A federal judge in Manhattan, citing what he called ''fundamental changes in the threats to public security,'' agreed to modify a longstanding court order that had restricted the New York Police Department's ability to conduct surveillance of political groups.

title: Adding an Extra Dimension, Color, to World War II
description: In the late 1980's, a decade before the Greatest Generation hysteria fully kicked into gear, the historian Paul Fussell, among others, was already issuing bitter complaints about how World War II ''has been sanitized and romanticized almost beyond recognition.'' Channel surfers who arrive late to the new PBS documentary ''The Perilious Fight: America's World War II in Color'' may initially feel that they've stumbled on the ultimate insult to the actualities of that war: has some blundering archivist actually thought to ''colorize'' hundreds of hours of battle scenes and other period film shots?

title: More Jets Appear Before Grand Jury
description: A grand jury in Nassau County continued to hear testimony yesterday regarding the possible involvement of the Jets backup offensive tackle Jumbo Elliott in a scuffle with a limousine driver outside a Long Island restaurant on Dec. 9.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLYNN, JOSEPHINE M.
description: FLYNN-Josephine M. On February 6, age 75, in Norwalk, CT. Daughter of the late Laurence F. and Eugenie Bissell Millet. Survived by husband Harry L. Flynn; brother Frank D. Millet of Milton, MA, five children and five grandchildren. Her eternal optimism, sharp mind and generous spirit will be greatly missed and always remembered. A private family Mass will be held in East Bridgewater, MA. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her name may be made to The Multiple Sclerosis Society.

title: A Washington Art Museum Expands
description: The Phillips Collection here is by no means as large as the Museum of Modern Art in New York, but it does lay claim to being this country's oldest modern art museum and, like the Modern, it is rebuilding. Or perhaps moving into the house next door is a better description.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOENIG, MORTIMER
description: KOENIG-Mortimer. Age 100 died peacefully February 10, 2003. Pre-deceased by his late wife, of over 72 years, Stella, son Glenn and sister Rose. Survived by loving daughterin-law, Connie McIntyre and her husband Tom, devoted grandchildren Mark and his wife Debra and Scott and two great-grandchildren Alexandra and Samuel. Volunteered during WWII as neighborhood warden and in NJ shipyards. A Columbia University BA and JD, he was a partner in the NYC law firm of Koenig, Siskind and Drabkin for over 55 years. Over fifty years of service to the Bronx County Bar Association. He was loved by many for his kindness, integrity, and wonderful sense of humor. His passing leaves us with a loss that cannot be filled but also with a legacy of love and admiration. Services Thursday 11:30 am at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations to M. Glenn Koenig Memorial Lecture at Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ATTINSON, CHARLES
description: ATTINSON-Charles. Passed away peacefully February 10, 2003. Loving husband and best friend to Marylin; devoted father to Andrew and Susan; caring father-in-law to Freda, cherished grandfather to Alex and Avery and brother to Miriam and Sol. He will be missed by all that knew him and his memory will live forever in our hearts. Highly decorated Veteran, he fought his illness with grace, dignity and courage. His sense of humor and love of life touched us all. A graveside service, Wednesday, February 12th. Donations may be made to the Myasthenia Gravis Alliance, 61 Gramercy Park North, New York, New York.

title: Daniel Toscan du Plantier, 61; Noted French Film Producer
description: Daniel Toscan du Plantier, a French movie producer who over the last 15 years has presided over Unifrance, the French movie promotion agency, collapsed and died of heart failure here today while attending the Berlin film festival. He was 61.

title: Threats to the Forest
description: A Senate-House conference has now approved an omnibus appropriations bill loaded with destructive anti-environmental riders. Since President Bush has no intention of vetoing the bill -- as President Clinton did in 1995 when presented with a similarly offensive measure -- the House should remand it to the committee for repairs.

title: FEDERATED MELDS CATALOG AND WEB SITE UNIT INTO STORES
description: Federated Department Stores is folding the Bloomingdale's catalog and Macy's Web site into its department store chains. The company's Federated Direct division, which ran the operations, is being closed, a spokeswoman, Carol Sanger, said. Macys.com has about 100 employees and the Bloomingdale's by Mail catalog has about 75. None of those jobs will be lost through the changes, which take effect on March 1, and Federated does not expect any related costs, she said. The department store chains will directly supervise promotions, advertising and finances of the catalog and Internet units bearing their names, the chief operating officer, Terry Lundgren, said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZMAN, LORRAINE
description: KATZMAN - Lorraine. Be loved friend, we will never forget you. Love to Debbie, Brian, Lindsay, Andrea, Thomas, William and Alex. Doris, Hank, Gwenn, Dean, Scott and Jaclyn

title: Outside Do-It-Yourself Store, Men Yearn to Do It for Them
description: It is near the corner of Sunset Boulevard and Western Avenue that the inalienable law of supply and demand collides with the rule of law and order.

title: An Antiwar March, Banned by a Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEUSCHLE, KURT W., M.D.
description: DEUSCHLE-Kurt W., M.D. It is with profound sorrow that The Mount Sinai Alumni mourns the passing of our dear friend and colleague. Dr. Deuschle served as the Ethel H. Wise Professor and Chairman of the nation's first urban department of Community Medicine, which he established at Mount Sinai in 1968. In 1989, The Mount Sinai Alumni presented its most coveted award, the Jacobi Medallion, to Dr. Deuschle in acknowledgment of his many contributions to the delivery of health care throughout the world and the great distinction he brought to Mount Sinai. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. Jeffrey S. Freed, M.D.-Pres. William G. Stein, M.D.-V.P. Maria L. Padilla, M.D.-Secy. George Raptis, M.D.-Treas.

title: Love Burns In Carthage, Destiny Calls In Rome
description: Joseph Volpe, the pugnacious general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, hates making the same mistake twice. So you might have thought that after the director Francesca Zambello, in her 1992 Met debut, turned a new production of the Donizetti favorite ''Lucia di Lammermoor'' into what was widely deemed a symbolism-strewn fiasco, she would be finished in Mr. Volpe's book.

title: Victims Say Report on L.I. Priest Abuse Breaks New Ground
description: A grand jury's assertion that the Diocese of Rockville Centre secretly battled to protect priests while pretending to extend a pastoral hand to sexual abuse victims goes beyond anything seen since the scandal in the Roman Catholic Church erupted a year ago, victims of abuse and their advocates said yesterday.

title: France Offering Plan to Expand Iraq Arms Hunt
description: France, offering an alternative to the United States' drive to disarm Iraq by force, circulated a detailed plan today to Security Council nations for extending and strengthening United Nations weapons inspections.

title: Officials Urge a Wider Use Of a 20-Minute H.I.V. Test
description: Federal health officials today urged greater use of a rapid H.I.V. test to identify newly infected people as early as possible and so reduce their chances of transmitting the virus to others.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILANO, SALLY
description: MILANO-Sally, of Yonkers died February 10, 2003. She was 80 years old. Sally was a Real Estate Appraiser for almost 50 years, employed most recently by Appraisers & Planners Inc. of New York City. Loving sister of two brothers, Frank of Yonkers & Peter of Bedford and a sister Anne Dalrymple of Coral Springs, FL. Another sister, Angela Antonaccio predeceased her. Calling hours will be at Flynn Memorial Home, 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers, NY, on Wednesday & Thursday from 2-4 & 7-9 pm. Funeral Mass Friday, 10am, at St. Joseph's Church in Bronxville. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Rivals for Meadowlands Project Take Final Jabs on Eve of Decision
description: The contest to redevelop the Meadowlands sports complex remained fierce even in its final hours today, as two of the three competitors fired final shots.

title: Olbermann to Anchor Olympics on Cable
description: Keith Olbermann, who worked for NBC Sports and MSNBC from 1997 to 1998, will anchor CNBC's and MSNBC's Olympic coverage next year at the Summer Games in Athens. He will fill the role handled by Jim Lampley at the 2002 Salt Lake Winter Olympics. Lampley will play an unspecified role in NBC's Olympic coverage.

title: Cracks in an Alliance
description: Germany and France, the cold war allies of old, may have lost their value to President Bush as he pursues a new battle against terrorism. News analysis, Page A16.

title: Democrats Redraw Map For Districts In Nassau
description: Democrats in the Nassau County Legislature unveiled a map of new district boundaries today that they hope will expand their tenuous one-vote majority in next fall's elections.

title: Recounting Obsession With a 1972 Author
description: In the author's photograph on the dust jacket of the 1972 novel ''The Stones of Summer,'' Dow Mossman is lean and rangy with a defiant mustache and a look of conviction. The producer and director Mark Moskowitz has, by comparison, friendlier facial hair but an ingratiating and determined manner: he's going to find Mr. Mossman. It's what his film ''Stone Reader'' is all about: the director's search for a writer whose single work is still a touchstone in his life.

title: In Our S.U.V.'s: A Love-Hate Story
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NORTHROP GRUMMAN CORP., Los Angeles, a leading military contractor, received a $302.9 million Air Force contract to expand production of its Global Hawk unmanned spy plane.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Affirmative Action Upheld
description: A federal appeals court ruled that the City of Denver can show preference to construction companies owned by minorities and women, upholding the city's affirmative action law. The case began in 1992 when the owner of a concrete company said he had lost jobs because of the program, which since 1990 had set aside 16 percent of contracts for minority-owned firms and 12 percent for companies owned by women.
