In 2000, a federal judge ruled for the concrete company, and the city replaced the program with one that favored small, struggling businesses. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Despite Truce, Fighting Continues in Southern Philippines
description: DAVAO CITY, the Philippines, Feb. 12  Fighting continued in the southern Philippines today despite a cease-fire declared by President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo on Tuesday. The military said as of midday 60 Muslim rebels and 3 soldiers had been killed. The rebels said they had killed 49 soldiers.

title: Crazy for Romance and Manhattan
description: George Balanchine's ''Ballade'' is a pink and purple ballet in which one expects the women's long hair to come unbound at any moment. It doesn't. And that is one of the great pleasures of the piece, presented by New York City Ballet on Thursday night at the New York State Theater. Set to music by Faur, ''Ballade'' is essentially a pure romantic pas de deux with a fleeting bit of introspection to make it even more interesting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LICHT, DAVID E.
description: LICHT-David E. February 11, 2003. Beloved husband of Louise, father of Jonathan and Joanne Licht; Andrea and Michael Simon; grandfather of Samantha and Jason Simon; Iszy, Aitan and Yadid Licht; brother of Charles and Fran Licht; Sheldon and Rosalind Licht. He dedicated his life to service as a Federal Judge and Community Leader. He will be missed by everyone. Funeral services at SchwartzBros. Funeral Home, 114-03 Queens Blvd., 11AM, today.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Another Safeway Bidder
description: Philip Green, a British retailing executive, forged ahead with his plan to join the bidding for Safeway, a British supermarket chain that is up for sale, by filing a formal proposal with the Office of Fair Trading, one of the country's two antitrust bodies. The office is reviewing proposals from four other bidders: Tesco; J Sainsbury; ASDA, a unit of Wal-Mart Stores; and William Morrison Supermarkets. If those proposals raised serious antitrust concerns, they would be referred to the second antitrust body, the Competition Commission, for a more in-depth review. A ruling is expected within 45 days. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: A Pretty Penny's Worth of Prime Beef
description: IT'S really important to spend the money for prime steak,'' Bobby Flay said, as he unwrapped a package from Lobel's, a butcher shop on the Upper East Side not celebrated for its discount prices. ''Have I said that already?''

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Would You Like Water With Your Water?

title: U.S. Beats Jamaica in Exhibition
description: The United States men's team rebounded from a 1-0 loss to Argentina in Miami last Saturday, getting goals from Carlos Bocanegra and Chris Klein in the first 13 minutes last night on the way to a 2-1 victory over Jamaica at National Stadium in Kingston.

title: M.I.T. to Open Two Programs For Minorities To All Races
description: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology will open two summer math and science programs intended for minority high school students and incoming freshmen to students of all races. M.I.T. officials said they did so out of fear that the programs, which are under federal investigation, would not withstand a court challenge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEF, RUTH ANN
description: LIEF-Ruth Ann. Lehman College and The City University of New York mourn the death of Ruth Ann Lief, Lehman's First Lady for 23 years. Leonard Lief was President of Lehman from its founding in 1968 until his retirement in 1990. Mrs. Lief was a gifted cellist and writer whose books include ''George Orwell,'' ''Geriatric Junkie'' and a forthcoming collection of poetry. We extend deepest sympathies to the family. Contributions may be made to the Ruth Ann and Leonard Lief Scholarships, Lehman College Foundation. Matthew Goldstein Chancellor, CUNY Ricardo R. Fernandez President, Lehman College

title: Cheney Keeps His Distance From the President (Yet Again)
description: Since the administration put the nation on ''high'' terror alert on Friday, the White House has tightened its practice of keeping President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney apart, aides said today.

title: Afghans Report 17 Civilian Deaths in U.S.-Led Bombing
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Feb. 12 — Afghan officials said 17 civilians have been killed in American-led bombing in a mountainous region of southern Afghanistan where United States Special Forces have been battling rebels for two days.

title: Words of the Poets
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POVLICH, ROBERT J.
description: POVLICH-Robert J. January 31, 2003, age 65. Service in West Allis, WI. Schaff Funeral Home: 414-541-7533

title: Mixing Up Papa's Tales And Porter's Melodies
description: Ernest Hemingway did write a play -- ''The Fifth Column,'' set during the Spanish Civil War -- and the dialogue in his novels and short stories is famously spare and direct. But that doesn't make him a ''a true playwright manqu,'' as his daughter-in-law Carol Hemingway claims in the program of ''It Just Catches,'' a patchwork stage adaptation of Hemingway excerpts now at the Cherry Lane Theater.

title: World Briefing: Middle East
description: WEST BANK: ARREST IN OLIVE TREE THEFTS An Israeli hired by the Defense Ministry to supervise the building of a fence along the Israel-West Bank border was arrested and accused of helping to steal Palestinian-owned olive trees and resell them in Israel, the police said. The trees represent Palestinian ties to the land, as well as their livelihood in some cases. Arnon Avneri, the supervisor, is suspected of collaborating with building contractors to uproot the trees and sharing the resale profits with them, a police spokesman said. Some of the trees had to be uprooted because they were in the way of the construction. A Defense Ministry spokeswoman said the contractors were told to return the trees to their owners or replant them on Palestinian land.    (AP)

title: Bush Gains Crucial Backer For His Tax Plan in Senate
description: President Bush's $674 billion economic plan drew surprising support today from Senator Charles E. Grassley, the Iowa Republican who said in January that the centerpiece of the plan, eliminating the dividend tax, would be tough sell in Congress.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Education Domain Expands Eligibility
description: The Department of Commerce said yesterday that it would open eligibility for online addresses in the .edu domain to Bible colleges, some dance and art studios and many other educational institutions in the United States. Educause, the nonprofit group that administers the domain, said it intended to accept new members in mid-April. Educause expanded the domain to the nation's 1,600 community colleges in 2001. A spokesman for Educause, Peter DeBlois, said the domain now included about 7,500 addresses. Mr. DeBlois said the Career College Association and the Distance Education and Training Council had lobbied for the expansion, which will allow institutions teaching mortuary science or acupuncture, for example, to register for a .edu address. To be considered for the domain, however, a school must be accredited by an agency approved by the Department of Education, officials said. The .edu domain was one of seven original Internet domains established in 1985.

title: Forget Iraq. I'm Scared!
description: To the Editor:

title: One Man, One Team, 29 Bosses
description: From an early baseball age, Omar Minaya was unusual. He had no pretensions, for example, about his playing ability.

title: Robben Island Journal; With Vivid Palette, Mandela Depicts the Jailhouse Years
description: The elderly black man hobbled across the stage and the predominantly white crowd leapt to its feet with rapturous applause. In this racially charged nation, Nelson Mandela is that rarity of rarities: a hero to blacks and to many whites.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDELKERN, BARUCH
description: MANDELKERN-Baruch. It is with great sadness that the entire Beth Israel medical center community joins with the leadership of its parent company, Continuum Health Partners, in noting the passing of Baruch Mandelkern, beloved father-in-law of our good friend, The Honorable Sheldon Silver, Speaker of the New York State Assembly. To Sheldon, his wife Rosa, the Mandelkern and Silver families, and all their loved ones, we extend heartfelt sympathies. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, Continuum and Beth Israel Gail F. Donovan, Interim President/CEO, Continuum Thomas Killip, M.D. Interim President and CEO, Beth Israel Shelley B. Mayer, Vice President, Government and Community Affairs

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GONZALEZ, CARMEN
description: GONZALEZ - Carmen. 90, died peacefully on February 10, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Emilio, sister to the late Jose Lopez, dearest mother to Ted, Peter and Linda Velez, and Cynthia Cichon, devoted grandmother and great grandmother. Viewing at Ortiz Funeral Home, 141 E 103 St, Wednesday February 12, from 2-5 and 7-10 P.M. Memorial Service St Cecilia's Church, 120 E 106 St, Thursday February 13th at 10 A.M.

title: A Culinary Holiday Mere Hours Away
description: WHEN Claudio Vigilante was a waiter at Le Gavroche, the last redoubt of classic French haute cuisine in London, the demanding and unsmiling proprietor, Albert Roux, often upbraided him for joking with the customers.

title: Former Money Manager Going to Prison
description: The former money manager Alan B. Bond was sentenced yesterday to 12 1/2 years in prison for cheating clients and taking kickbacks from brokers.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''When you're up here this long, you can't just bottle up your emotions and focus all the time. I mean it's important for us to acknowledge that the people on STS-107 were our friends, that we had a connection with them and that we feel their loss. And each of us had a chance to shed some tears. But now it's time to move forward and we're doing that slowly.''

title: Rheingold hopes to rekindle the romance between the beer and New York City.
description: RHEINGOLD BEER was once a top New York brew guzzled regularly by a loyal cadre of workingmen who would just as soon have eaten nails as drink another beer maker's suds.

title: Law Limits Aid to Russia to Maintain Space Station
description: Plans for more Russian help in maintaining the International Space Station while American space shuttles are grounded are limited by a law that bars direct financial support for the Russian program, NASA officials said today.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Higher Bid For Toll Company
description: Italy's Benetton family raised the value of its bid for Autostrade S.p.A., Europe's biggest operator of highway tolls, after fewer than 4 percent of shareholders sold their stock in the first two weeks of the tender period. The Benetton-controlled company Schemaventotto raised the bid 5.3 percent, to 10 euros a share in cash; the previous offer was 9.5 euros a share. That values all of Autostrade, 30 percent of which is already owned by Schemaventotto, at 11.8 billion euros. The bid will run until Feb. 21 and the Benettons have said they reserve the right to refuse the shares if they do not end up with a stake of at least 67 percent. Eric Sylvers (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Miner Posts Loss
description: Citing write-downs on a three-year-old magnesium plant in Quebec, the Noranda mining group reported a fourth-quarter loss of 673 million Canadian dollars ($440 million), up from a loss of 84 million Canadian dollars a year earlier. The magnesium plant, one of the biggest in the world, has been hit by low prices caused by intensifying competition from China, which exported virtually no magnesium in the early 1990's but now makes up more than half of global supply. The plant is currently being mothballed. Noranda is a unit of Brascan. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Hundreds of Day Care Centers Set to Close for Walkout Today
description: Hundreds of city-financed day care centers plan to close today as the unions representing day care workers and directors said they would stage a one-day strike to demand a 4 percent raise.

title: A Test for America and Europe
description: To the Editor:

title: Too Early to Give Up On St. John's Jarvis
description: Joe Lapchick, Lou Carnesecca and Mike Jarvis.

title: Exhibit A for Mainstreaming; A Boy With Brain Damage, Happy in a Regular School
description: Rocking slowly in his chair, Malcolm Thomas stared into space, while the other 24 students in his seventh-grade class began to share their poems. One classmate recited an ode to climbing trees; another read verses about chasing ice cream trucks.

title: A Dual Role For Chicken
description: HERE is a recipe that gives you two alternatives right from the start: a straightforward Thai-style chicken saut or a caramelized Vietnamese-style dish. Either one is spectacularly flavored and amazingly simple to prepare.

title: Salmonella Survivor Endorses Push for Food Safety Agency
description: When Representative Rosa L. DeLauro was 2 years old, she was stricken with salmonella poisoning, taken from her frightened parents and quarantined for two weeks in a hospital. Though she remembers little of the experience herself, her parents talked about their fears for years afterward.

title: Filibuster On Judgeship Halts Business In the Senate
description: Senate Democrats began a filibuster today, speaking on the Senate floor without respite, to block a vote on President Bush's nomination of Miguel Estrada to a federal appeals court in Washington.

title: Democrats in Albany Vow to Fight Pataki's Cuts in Higher Education
description: State legislators today attacked the size of budget cuts for higher education proposed by Gov. George E. Pataki, and they promised to fight them.

title: U.S. to Ask Atom Agency To Chastise North Korea
description: With its policy toward North Korea under fire in Congress and many Asian capitals, the Bush administration on Wednesday will ask the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna to find Pyongyang in violation of international nuclear weapons agreements.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: French Court Rejects Suit Against Yahoo
description: After a three-year legal fight, a Paris court yesterday rejected a lawsuit by French human rights advocates and Holocaust survivors who sued Yahoo for one symbolic euro. They accused Yahoo of having condoned war crimes when it sold Nazi paraphernalia, including flags with swastikas, on its auction pages. French law forbids the display or sale of racist material, but the items were available to French users who clicked on the American pages. The court said that Yahoo did not seek to ''justify war crimes and crimes against humanity'' when it sold the items on its Web site. It was the second lawsuit against Yahoo by French human rights advocates; the first was started in 2000. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PECKMAN, IAN
description: PECKMAN-Ian. It is with profound sorrow and a deep sense of regret that we, the Board of Trustees and the Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center family, mourn the passing of Ian Peckman, son of Bruce Peckman, our Senior Vice President of Ambulatory/ Managed Care and Regulatory Services, and his wife, Susan. Our sincere condolences are extended to the Peckman family. Rita DiMartino, Chairman, Board of Trustees Miguel A. Fuentes, Jr., President and CEO

title: Car Struck Husband 3 Times, Jury Hears
description: Lawyers for Clara Harris, the dentist accused of running over her husband in a jealous rage and killing him, are to present closing arguments on Wednesday. It will be their last chance to persuade the jury that David Harris's death under the wheels of her car was an accident.

title: Cablevision Swings to Profit in 4th Quarter
description: Cablevision Systems said today that it had a profit in the fourth quarter, reversing a loss a year earlier, when restructuring charges and slow sales at the Wiz consumer electronics unit pulled down earnings.

title: 150-Year Sentence in Sex Abuse of Teenager After Internet Meeting
description: A man convicted of luring a 15-year-old girl from an Internet chat room into a week of torture and rape was sentenced today to a prison term of 150 years to life.

title: Hey, Stupid Cupid, It's Just Dinner
description: HOW do I loathe Valentine's Day? Let me count the ways. Sweet pink cocktails. Lobster with truffle sauce. Truffles with lobster sauce. Flavorless filet mignon. Chocolate-covered everything.

title: 'Chicago' Tops Oscar Nominees; Miramax Lifted Into Front Ranks Among Studios
description: ''Chicago,'' a flashy adaptation of the Broadway musical about murdering floozies in the Roaring 20's, was the leader among four movies from Miramax Films that together dominated the nominations for the 75th annual Academy Awards, announced here today, and propelled its New York-based studio into Hollywood's front ranks.

title: Freddy Adu, Still Only 13, Already Plays Like a Man
description: The ball slices some 40 yards from midfield over a baffled defense on a balmy Sunday morning; the waiting striker flips it into the goal, leaving the goalkeeper stunned.

title: A Latin Outpost in Inwood Where Tables Often Wait
description: THERE was a time not so long ago when I assumed Manhattan had reached Starbucks saturation. What did I know? Two or three thousand more have surely opened since then.

title: Pivotal Switch in Executive Pay Led to Huge Stock Option Grants
description: The roots of the management turmoil at Sprint lie in a decision by directors six years ago to turbocharge the pay of William T. Esrey, its chief executive, with huge grants of stock options, according to experts on executive compensation and corporate governance.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Pharmaceutical Profit Warning
description: The Dutch chemicals and pharmaceutical concern Akzo Nobel warned investors that its profit this year would fall at least 10 percent from last year. It blamed increased competition from generic drugs. The company's best-selling antidepressant, Remeron, which generated 717 million euros ($770) in sales in 2002, is expected to lose market share. Akzo made the forecast after it reported a profit of 892 million euros last year, which was down from 930 million euros a year earlier and fell short of market forecasts. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Boycott of PepsiCo Is Called Off
description: A threatened boycott of PepsiCo was called off yesterday after Pepsi agreed to donate millions of dollars to nonprofit groups benefiting young people.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  AGAPITO, KARIN HEIDER
description: AGAPITO-Karin Heider. 2/12/87. Dear, dear Karin. You are forever in my heart and mind. Love, Tony

title: Violence Follows a Ban on Palestinians' Holiday Travel
description: Israeli security forces shot dead an 8-year-old Palestinian boy today when they opened fire on a crowd throwing stones in the West Bank city of Qalqilya, Palestinians said. Later, in Bethlehem, an Israeli soldier was killed by a Palestinian sniper as he patrolled near Manger Square, the army said.

title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- TriBeCa; A Building for Dot-Coms Switches to General Users
description: When the Rudin family acquired the former AT&T Long Distance Building at 32 Avenue of the Americas in late 1999 the telecommunications industry was expanding to meet the expected demand from dot-com companies.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Friuli at a Discount

title: Escaping North Korea's Nuclear Trap
description: North Korea already has one or two nuclear bombs, according to the C.I.A. It is probably building five or six more. At its meeting in Vienna today, the International Atomic Energy Agency will most likely refer the North Korean crisis to the United Nations Security Council. The last time the agency took such a step, in 1994, it led to a discussion of sanctions, which North Korea made clear then -- and has made clear now -- would constitute a declaration of war.

title: White House Builds Case That Tape Links Al Qaeda to Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 — The White House said today that the latest audiotaped message believed to be from Osama bin Laden was further evidence of an "unholy partnership" between Al Qaeda terrorists and Iraq. And the head of the Central Intelligence Agency noted that previous messages from the terrorist leader had often been followed by attacks.

title: THREATS AND RESPONSES: Briefly Noted; UTAH TAKES ON U.N.
description: In the latest example of antipathy in Utah toward the United Nations, a state House Committee passed a resolution that urges Congress to get the United States out of the world body. The bill now goes to full house, and if passed, would be sent to Utah's Congressional delegation. The measure was introduced by Rep. Don E. Bush of Clearfield who blamed the United Nations for a divided Korea and for the failure of the United States to oust Saddam Hussein in the 1991 Persian Gulf War. ''If no U.N,, no Iraq,'' said Mr. Bush, who is not related to President Bush. ''We could have finished them off.'' Several years ago, a town in Utah, LaVerkin, passed an ordinance that banned United Nations personnel from town limits. The ban was later dropped. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Polish Tale of Bribery and/or Politics and/or Journalism
description: It reads like the script of a ''B'' movie: A tough-talking, Russian-born heavy promises to smooth out the legislative obstacles facing one of post-Communist Poland's most successful companies. All he wants, he tells one of the country's most influential men, is $17.5 million.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: WHITE PLAINS: LAWMAKERS CLEAR WAY FOR TAX INCREASE /> The Westchester County Board of Legislators voted last night to adopt a contingency plan that includes a nearly 15 percent increase in property taxes, cuts to services and law enforcement layoffs to close a $67 million budget gap. The 9-to-5 vote came after the Westchester delegation in the Assembly refused to back a bill allowing an increase in the county sales tax. Lydia Polgreen (NYT)

title: American Officials Disclose 2-Year Plan to Rebuild Iraq
description: In the first detailed public discussion of the Bush administration's plans for a postwar Iraq, senior officials told Congress today that it would take more than two years for the United States military to transfer control of Iraq's government to Iraqi leaders.

title: In Our S.U.V.'s: A Love-Hate Story
description: To the Editor:

title: NATO Talks Fail to Mend Rift Over Iraq and Defense of Turkey
description: The members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization failed today to heal the rift that erupted on Monday over Iraq, causing one of the worst crises the alliance has ever faced.

title: RAND MCNALLY FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY WITH RECOVERY PLAN
description: Rand McNally & Company, the world's biggest commercial mapmaker, has filed for bankruptcy protection with a plan approved by debtholders to reduce debt to $100 million from $400 million, a lawyer for the company said yesterday. The company said last month that it would seek Chapter 11 protection. It expects to emerge from bankruptcy protection in about 30 days, the lawyer, Robert Richards, said. At a hearing yesterday, Judge Eugene Wedoff of United States Bankruptcy Court in Chicago approved the company's request to pay $30 million in trade debt, Mr. Richards said.

title: Tape Ascribed to bin Laden Urges Muslims to Stand With Iraq
description: A recorded message apparently made by Osama bin Laden called on Muslims today to repulse any United States attempt to invade Iraq, urging them to apply the lessons learned by Al Qaeda, his terror network.

title: Report Says 13 in Child Agency's Case Files Died of Abuse or Neglect in 2002
description: Thirteen children served by the New Jersey Division of Youth and Family Services died of child abuse or neglect last year, according to a new report prepared by state officials.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: SOUTH CAROLINA: BUDGET WOES FOR GOVERNOR The Governor's Mansion may have to close by June 30 because of a $150,000 shortfall in operating money, Gov. Mark Sanford said. Mr. Sanford, a newly elected Republican, said the only way to avoid the closing was to raise private money to pay for 11 employees, utility bills and food. If the mansion closes, Governor Sanford and his family would have to cook their own meals. (AP)

title: Bank of England Cuts Economic Growth Forecast to 2.5%
description: LONDON, Feb. 12  Less than a week after it cut interest rates to their lowest level in almost 50 years, the Bank of England reduced its forecast for economic growth today, signaling worries that a war in Iraq will deepen the gloom just as Britain's feel-good spending spree begins to fizzle.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; The man who built up El Paso is leaving it in disarray.
description: WILLIAM A. WISE, the longtime chairman and chief executive of the El Paso Corporation who helped transform it into the nation's largest natural gas pipeline company, announced plans yesterday to step down as the company's fortunes continue to sour from the collapse of Enron.

title: 17 Accused of Creating Ways To Steal Satellite Television
description: Seventeen people have been charged with developing technology used to steal millions of dollars in satellite television service. The charges culminated a yearlong federal investigation into the underground world of computer hackers, the authorities announced today.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Parent Group Seeks Advocate Office
description: A parent advocacy group proposed a plan yesterday to create an independent office to deal with parent concerns and oversee advocates at each of the city's 1,200 schools. The group said that creating the office, known as public education advocate, would cost about $15 million, about $3 million more than the Education Department allocated for community school districts. The group, the People's Coalition to Take Back Our Schools, also proposed appointing advocates for each of the 32 community school districts. Jennifer Medina (NYT)

title: Bloomberg Tells Trial Jury Of His Part In Taped Sting
description: Michael R. Bloomberg may have flown to London to take part in a sting with Scotland Yard and the F.B.I. He may even have feared for his safety at times during the operation. But, he conceded yesterday, he is not likely to be assigned his own double-0 number anytime soon.

title: In Brooklyn Murder Case, Doubts on Identification
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft ordered the death penalty sought in a Brooklyn case last spring even though federal prosecutors had recommended against it largely because of problems with a witness's identification of a murder suspect, according to lawyers familiar with the prosecutors' analysis and court filings.

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: EVENTS

title: Designs Leave Blanks for 9/11 Memorial Contest to Fill
description: When rebuilding officials selected the finalists for the design of the World Trade Center site, their choices instantly raised a difficult question: In light of the finalists' designs for memorials to victims of the attack of Sept. 11, 2001, what is left for a memorial competition?

title: BP Completes Big Oil Deal With Russians
description: BP, the world's third-largest oil company, agreed today to pay $6.75 billion to form a new Russian oil company. The deal underscores the growing attractiveness of Russia to foreign oil concerns and could increase the country's already significant role as an exporter of crude oil.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: SOUTH AFRICA: `NO DECISION' ON ZIMBABWE Government officials denied reports that President Thabo Mbeki, left, and the Nigerian president, Olusegun Obasanjo, had decided to call for an end to Zimbabwe's suspension from the Commonwealth, a group of 54 nations, mostly former British colonies. Bheki Khumalo, a spokesman for Mr. Mbeki, said, "There's no final decision on the matter." But African officials have long been sympathetic to Zimbabwe despite the government's crackdown on the opposition and its condoning of violence.    Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Atom Agency Finds Pyongyang in Violation of Arms Accords
description: The United Nations' chief nuclear arms inspector declared North Korea in breach of international weapons accords today and sent the matter to the Security Council for its consideration, raising the ante in an already-tense standoff with Pyongyang over its nuclear aspirations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATTERSON, MYRON C., M.D.
description: PATTERSON - Myron C., M.D. On February 8, 2003. Associate Clinical Professor of Medicine, Columbia University, College of Physicians and Surgeons. Attending physician at the Roosevelt Hospital for for over fifty years. Survived by his wife of sixty years, Dr. Michaeleen (O' Rourke), daughter Anne Baier, son-in-law J. Cletus Baier, M.D., daughter Linda Kocsis, M.D., son-in-law William A. Kocsis, M.D. and grandchildren Gregory, Marc, Kevin, Allison, Kathleen and Alexander Baier and Barbara and Julia Kocsis. Contributions may be made to the Dr. Myron C. Patterson Heart Fund, Roosevelt Hospital, 1000 Tenth Avenue, NY NY 10019

title: 'Not Again' Is Reaction of the Faithful
description: For lawyers, public officials and victims' advocates, the report on abusive priests that was prepared by a Suffolk County grand jury offered the first independent account -- apart from newspaper articles or civil lawsuits -- of how the Diocese of Rockville Centre handled abuse complaints.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: COLOMBIA: REBELS DEMAND OWN ZONE The country's largest Marxist rebel group called on President Álvaro Uribe today to create a demilitarized zone for them, a proposal the government immediately rejected. In a communiqué, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia said such a zone was necessary if exploratory peace talks were to be held or if an exchange of hostages held by rebels for guerrillas held in government prisons is ever to take place. Mr. Uribe lampooned the idea, which came after the rebels set off a powerful car bomb on Friday that killed 34 people.    Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Painstaking Work Ahead For Investigative Panel
description: Ten days after the shuttle Columbia broke up over Texas, here is all that is known for sure: The seeds of disaster appear to have been rooted in a failure of the left wing, but no one is willing to bet what triggered that failure.

title: Briefly Noted
description: TARGET PULLS CARDS Target Stores across the nation pulled a box set of children's Valentines Day cards from their shelves after a parent in Pittsburgh thought it contained a terrorist-related message. The card, based on a series of "I Spy" books published by Scholastic Inc. in New York City, contained the word "Jihad," which can mean holy war. A spokeswoman for Scholastic said the word was actually a child's name. A Target spokesman said the company did not believe the card was appropriate for its customers and called on its 11,048 stores to remove the item. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Words of C.I.A. and F.B.I. Chiefs: Dangers America Faces From Al Qaeda
description: Following are excerpts from opening statements in testimony yesterday by George J. Tenet, director of central intelligence, and Robert S. Mueller III, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, before the Senate select intelligence committee as recorded by Federal News Service Inc. A full transcript is at nytimes.com/international.

title: Return By Woods Real Start Of Tour
description: At the crack of dawn today, despite a driving rainstorm and heavy fog, Tiger Woods was at Torrey Pines North Golf Course, playing a practice round in preparation for Thursday's opening round of the Buick Invitational.

title: Kerry to Undergo Surgery for Prostate Cancer Today
description: Senator John F. Kerry of Massachusetts, a Democratic candidate for president, disclosed today that he had prostate cancer and would have his prostate removed in an operation at a Baltimore hospital early on Wednesday.

title: Philips Electronics Lost $3.4 Billion Last Year
description: Royal Philips Electronics today joined a growing parade of companies announcing annual losses in the billions, in large part because of write-downs on the value of stakes in other businesses.

title: An Antiwar March, Banned by a Court
description: To the Editor:

title: They're Called Divini And Taste Heavenly
description: These scrumptious little bites, called divini, are truffles made from ice cream. They are sold 4 to a box for $5, or 12 for $12, at Il Laboratorio del Gelato, 95 Orchard Street (Delancey Street). Among the flavors are raspberry with white chocolate sprinkles, dark chocolate with hazelnuts, creamy chocolate walnut with walnuts and vanilla covered with coconut. Though they come with a cold pack, it is best to get them into a freezer within 40 minutes -- if you can wait that long.

title: For a Family Of Survivors, A Wrong Time And Place
description: The young Canadian family was accustomed to surviving.

title: Words of the Poets
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Rebels Demand Own Zone
description: The country's largest Marxist rebel group called on President lvaro Uribe today to create a demilitarized zone for them, a proposal the government immediately rejected. In a communiqu, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia said such a zone was necessary if exploratory peace talks were to be held or if an exchange of hostages held by rebels for guerrillas held in government prisons is ever to take place. Mr. Uribe lampooned the idea, which came after the rebels set off a powerful car bomb on Friday that killed 34 people. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: The Bubbly Gets Sexy In Slippers
description: A frivolous bit of dress-up for flutes of Champagne for Valentine's Day are little muffs of marabou that fit over the base. They double as coasters and can be used for other types of stemware -- glasses filled with St.-Amour Beaujolais, perhaps. The muffs tend to shed, so store them in the refrigerator, like an angora sweater. A set of four is $14.95 at Broadway Panhandler, 477 Broome Street (Wooster Street). The store calls them glass slippers.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Sentencing In 1995 Murder
description: A man who federal prosecutors said was part of the Tanglewood Boys, a gang that terrorized Westchester County and the Bronx through murder, robbery and extortion, has been sentenced to life in prison for a 1995 murder. The conviction of the man, John Petrucelli, was ''absolutely justified,'' Judge Thomas P. Griesa said on Friday as he imposed the sentence in United States District Court. The evidence showed that Mr. Petrucelli killed Paul Cicero to enhance his position in the gang, which included some sons of members of the Luchese crime family, prosecutors said. A lawyer for Mr. Petrucelli said the conviction would be appealed. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO STEADY. The dollar was flat against the euro after some traders speculated a message from Osama bin Laden would make an attack on Iraq more likely. In New York, the dollar was 1.0738 to the euro, from 1.0745.

title: A Record Night for Westminster
description: The Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show attracted a record 4.6 million viewers on the USA Network for the two-night event at Madison Square Garden. Last year, the show averaged 4.3 million viewers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERTZ, RUTH RUDDY
description: HERTZ-Ruth Ruddy. 92, died on February 10, 2003, in Miami Beach, FL. Ruth was one of the first women to play a leading role in the American fur industry. Beginning in the 1950s, the distinctive Ruth Ruddy Inc. label became a Seventh Avenue icon. She was a dominant and stylish innovator in her field for several decades. A longtime resident of New York City, she was the beloved mother of film producer Albert S. Ruddy of Beverly Hills and his wife, Wanda McDaniel; of her late son Gerald Ruddy and his wife, Helene Ruddy of New York City; of her late daughter Selma Levey. Also survived by her sister Joyce Katske of NY, and preceeded in death by her brother and sister, Arthur and Jean. She was a beloved grandmother and great-grandmother to many. Ruth lived her life with courage, grace, humor, intelligence and dignity. Her indomitable spirit will be deeply missed and long remembered by all who loved her. A graveside service will take place at 1 PM Thursday at Kensico Cemetery's Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY

title: Present at . . . What?
description: The tension that is now rising within the Western alliance, NATO and the U.N. over how to deal with Iraq is deeply disturbing. It raises fears that the postwar security system, which stabilized the world for 50 years, could come unglued if America intervenes alone in Iraq. At the birth of this security system, Secretary of State Dean Acheson wrote a memoir titled ''Present at the Creation.'' Can we deal with Iraq and still ensure that Secretary of State Colin Powell's memoir is not titled ''Present at the Destruction''?

title: TOP U.S. OFFICIALS PRESS CASE LINKING IRAQ TO AL QAEDA
description: Senior Bush administration officials intensified the effort to make the case for military action against Saddam Hussein today, with testimony by Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and the director of central intelligence, George J. Tenet, linking Iraq and Al Qaeda.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about Sabre Holdings, the online travel reservation system, misstated its revenue forecast for this year. The prediction is for growth of 4 to 9 percent, not decline of a few percentage points. The article also misstated Sabre's reason for selling part of its computer operations to Electronic Data Services. The goal was to exit unattractive lines of business, not to respond to a slowdown in business travel.

title: It's Harvey Weinstein's Turn to Gloat
description: Just months after being vilified by his peers in magazine articles and derided by the Hollywood grapevine as a mogul in decline, Harvey Weinstein and his New York-based ministudio, Miramax Films, are at the head of the pack, dominating the Academy Awards race in a way that no single studio has done in more than half a century.

title: Pass the Duct Tape
description: Osama bin Laden came to the rescue of George W. Bush yesterday.

title: Official Raised Concerns About Quality of Images Produced by Contractor
description: In the months before Columbia's disastrous mission, the NASA photography editor at the Kennedy Space Center repeatedly raised concerns about a contractor who he said produced substandard film images of shuttle launchings, NASA officials said this week.

title: Japan's Used Cars Find New Lives On Russian Roads
description: Boots crunching on the packed snow of Siberia's largest car lot, Anatoly M. Kiselev passed row upon row of the cars that keep the Russian Far East rolling: Toyota Land Cruisers, Mitsubishi Pajeros, a delivery van from Osaka, and strings of sensible Hondas and Nissans, many still bearing stickers from parking garages in Tokyo.

title: Technology Briefing: Internet
description: EDUCATION DOMAIN EXPANDS ELIGIBILITY The Department of Commerce said yesterday that it would open eligibility for online addresses in the .edu domain to Bible colleges, some dance and art studios and many other educational institutions in the United States. Educause, the nonprofit group that administers the domain, said it intended to accept new members in mid-April. Educause expanded the domain to the nation's 1,600 community colleges in 2001. A spokesman for Educause, Peter DeBlois, said the domain now included about 7,500 addresses. Mr. DeBlois said the Career College Association and the Distance Education and Training Council had lobbied for the expansion, which will allow institutions teaching mortuary science or acupuncture, for example, to register for a .edu address. To be considered for the domain, however, a school must be accredited by an agency approved by the Department of Education, officials said. The .edu domain was one of seven original Internet domains established in 1985.   (NYT)

title: Determined Islanders Outmuscle Lightning
description: The Islanders had hoped to take 40 shots at Tampa Bay goaltender Nikolai Khabibulin tonight. They fell short, but only by seven. For a change, they had been given room to attack, and they used every precious inch of open ice.

title: New Head Named at Cathedral School
description: MARSHA K. NELSON has been named head of the Cathedral School of St. John the Divine, a coeducational day school on the Upper West Side. Ms. Nelson, who was director of choral music and upper school dean before becoming associate head of the Trinity School for the last six years, will be the first woman to lead Cathedral, a 101-year-old school that has 265 students in kindergarten through eighth grade. She succeeds PHILLIP G. FOOTE, who is retiring at the end of the academic year. Ms. Nelson, 52, is a graduate of the University of Texas and has a master's degree from Teachers College at Columbia University.

title: Terrier Adds Best in Show To Name List
description: Call it revenge or retribution or whatever. The dog most insiders thought would win America's most important show last year has finally won it, a year late.

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: NEW PRISONS DIRECTOR The federal official who supervised the execution of Timothy J. McVeigh, the Oklahoma City bomber, will become director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons later this year, Attorney General John Ashcroft said. The official, Harley Lappin, director of the bureau's Mid-Atlantic Region, was warden of the Federal Penitentiary in Terre Haute, Ind., when he presided over Mr. McVeigh's execution by injection in June 2001. (AP)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Former Head Of State Police To Be Trenton Chief
description: Joseph J. Santiago, who was forced out as the superintendent of the New Jersey State Police last fall, has been chosen to lead the Trenton Police Department. Mayor Douglas H. Palmer, making the announcement yesterday, said he was not concerned about an investigation by the state attorney general into Mr. Santiago's use of hundreds of thousands of dollars in state money to furnish his office. Before his seven-month tenure with the state police, Mr. Santiago was the police director in Newark. Laura Mansnerus (NYT)

title: Giants Would Like To Retain Petitgout
description: The Giants want to re-sign left tackle Luke Petitgout, the team's most notable free agent, but one official familiar with their salary cap structure said it is highly unlikely the team would designate Petitgout with a transition or franchise tag.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONTANA, HELENE BORTNOVSKI
description: MONTANA-Helene Bortnovski. Died February 7, 2003, after a prolonged illness. Widow of anti-Fascist humanitarian Vanni Buscemi, mother, grandmother, a beautiful woman from the old world bringing strength to the new. Happy birthday, Mama. Memorial is planned for the spring. For inquiries, email: jmontanaMDnyc@msn.com

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLOTKIN, BARNETT
description: PLOTKIN-Barnett. The officers and members of The Society of Illustrators deeply mourn the passing of beloved member, Barney. He will be missed by all who knew him.

title: An Antiwar March, Banned by a Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBENSTEIN, MORRIS
description: RUBENSTEIN - Morris. On February 10. Devoted husband of the late Fran. Beloved father of Jodi Rubenstein, Jamie and Kevin Honig, and David and Sarah Rubenstein. Cherished grandfather of Miranda, Dylan, Joshua, and Hannah. Dear brother of Willie, Hy, and Charlotte Posner. Graveside service today, 1:00 pm at the Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

title: St. John's Wins After Losing A Big Lead
description: Now that Coach Mike Jarvis is wounded, and fans are booing and calling for his resignation, the scoreboard is ticking down the potential end of his St. John's career, not just the minutes on a clock.

title: Nets Come Out of Break Sluggishly
description: As the Nets shook the rust off their hands from the All-Star Game break tonight, their shots had trouble finding their way into the basket.

title: Teaching in Your Pajamas: Lessons of Online Classes
description: One of my favorite parts of college teaching is dressing up and putting on a good show. I plan my outfits, apply makeup, coordinate accessories, even rework my lecture cue cards.

title: A Bring Your Own Burgundy Party
description: IF you had happened to be in New York last Saturday evening with $1,200 in your pocket and nothing to do, you could have joined me at the Paule that Daniel Johnnes put together at the W New York hotel on Lexington Avenue. That's pau-LAY, as in ol or toupee, not Paulie, as in the guy on ''The Sopranos.''

title: Grim Reality Dominates Berlinale Film Festival
description: The past is coming closer to Berlin. It had long been traditional for each Berlin International Film Festival to present several movies about the Holocaust and the Nazis. This continued after the festival moved in 2000 to the Potsdamer Platz, barely a half-mile from Hitler's bunker. But this year the program's political thrust involves more recent history. With Europe increasingly alarmed about illegal immigration, three movies in competition are addressing this issue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANNON, ANNA MASCOLO, M.D.
description: GANNON - Anna Mascolo, M.D., 66, of New York City and Shelter Island, died at home on February 11, 2003, after a prolonged illness. A graduate of Brooklyn College and the Women's Medical College of Pennsylvania. Dr. Mascolo, an internist, served as Vice President at Long Island College Hospital and as the Medical Director for the ILGWU. She was also associated with Downstate, Columbia and Mt. Sinai Medical Schools. She is survived by her husband Frederic L. Gannon, M.D., her four children Anna Gannon, Lisa Gannon, Andrea Gannon Brereton and Ted Gannon, seven grandchildren and her sister Vivian Mahon. Family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. on Wednesday 2-5 and 7-10 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Thursday 9:30 AM at St. Ignatius Loyola R. C. Church. Interment Friday at Our Lady of the Isle Cemetery, Shelter Island. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Loyola School, 980 Park Avenue, NY 10028 or Bishop Loughlin H.S., 257 Claremont Ave., Brooklyn, NY 11238.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Silence Rule Set In Abuse Cases
description: A state trial judge has issued a sweeping silence rule in sex abuse cases against the Roman Catholic Diocese of Albany. Under the rule, issued on Monday and made public yesterday, Justice Joseph C. Teresi of State Supreme Court banned lawyers, plaintiffs and defendants in all current and future sexual abuse cases involving the diocese from speaking to the news media. Justice Teresi said in his ruling that without such an order, three civil lawsuits currently filed against the church would have a ''very difficult time obtaining an impartial jury.'' Bishop Howard Hubbard of Albany, under increasing scrutiny for his handling of allegations of sexual abuse, has removed two priests from the ministry in the last week. Laurie Goodstein (NYT)

title: Lawmakers Question NASA's Ability to Investigate Disaster
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12  The head of NASA encountered skepticism from lawmakers today that the agency was able to accurately report all accident data from the space shuttle disaster and that an inquiry board it had appointed would act with full independence.

title: A Movie Tough Guy Tells of a Shakedown That Wasn't Scripted
description: Steven Seagal, the taciturn martial arts star known for shooting, beating and throwing people in movies, testified in court yesterday that he had been the victim of an old-fashioned mob shakedown in a dark Brooklyn restaurant.

title: Jordan Pressing U.S. to Offer Exile to Hussein And His Aides if They Yield Power in Iraq
description: Officials at high levels of Jordan's government say they are pressing the United States to offer President Saddam Hussein and perhaps 50 of his top aides a guarantee of safe haven elsewhere in the Arab world if they will quit power in Iraq.

title: Hockey Fever Hits The South
description: Fans of the National Hockey League teams in Nashville and Atlanta might disagree, but Huntsville, Ala., is the Hockey Capital of the South, according to a 1986 proclamation by George Wallace when he was in his fourth and final term as governor of Alabama.

title: Ketchup With a Pedigree, A Far Cry From Goo
description: IN the depths of this frigid February, the taste of ripe summer tomatoes seems as distant a memory as the warm days that went with them. One of the last places you would expect to find that deep flavor is in a bottle of ketchup.

title: GOODRICH TO CUT 500 JOBS AT UNIT IT BOUGHT LAST YEAR
description: The Goodrich Corporation will cut 8 percent of the work force in an aircraft-control business it bought in October from TRW, the chief operating officer, Marshall Larsen, said. The unit had 6,200 employees when Goodrich bought it for $1.5 billion, he said. Eight percent of that is about 500 people. Mr. Larsen wants to cut the unit's annual costs as much as $40 million over the next three years. The profit margin at the unit was 3 percent in the fourth quarter, compared with Goodrich's overall 17 percent margin. Mr. Larsen will become chief executive in April. Goodrich is based in Charlotte, N.C.

title: INSIDE
description: Exile Proposed for Iraqis

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, NOEL H.
description: KAPLAN-Noel H. On February 11, 2003. Beloved husband of Ronni, adored father and best friend of his sons, Sean and Matthew, cherished brother of Gail. He was very involved in local community government and sincere and dedicated in all he did. Service Wednesday, 12 noon, Temple Beth Shalom of Roslyn Heights.

title: An Enchanted Evening, If You Have the Right Attitude
description: FOR serious diners, there are a few unspoken rules governing when and where you dine. You do not eat out in New York during Restaurant Week, when your desires are hemmed in by a rigid fixed-price menu and diners are shooed in and out of restaurants like flies. You do not go to a fine restaurant on a Saturday night because the chef is probably not in and the room is filled with out-of-towners.

title: Congress Agrees to Bar Pentagon From Terror Watch of Americans
description: House and Senate negotiators have agreed that a Pentagon project intended to detect terrorists by monitoring Internet e-mail and commercial databases for health, financial and travel information cannot be used against Americans.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the role of Sheldon Silver, the speaker of the New York State Assembly, misstated his age in some copies. He will turn 59 tomorrow, not 69.

title: Good Ship Oceana Adjusts the Compass
description: OCEANA opened just over a decade ago, but it seems much longer than that. Within a few short years, it made an enviable reputation that now seems carved in marble. In surroundings that suggest a private yacht, diners look forward to top-quality seafood interpreted in a highly refined, original way. That has been the deal, especially under Oceana's longest-running chef, Rick Moonen. There seemed no reason to think that anything would ever change.

title: Ruiz Labels Jones A Too Heavy Favorite
description: John Ruiz, the World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, is 7 inches taller than Roy Jones Jr. and has a 7.5-inch advantage in reach.

title: Consumption, Conspicuous or Not
description: A CONSUMERS' REPUBLIC

title: A Day for Two Hearts (in Three-Quarter Time?)
description: Torta Romantica, right, a delectable heart-shaped first course for two, consists of crepes layered with chive-flecked crme frache, caviar and smoked salmon. The top is decorated with American sturgeon caviar.

title: Mets Sign a Veteran Infielder
description: Jay Bell, a free-agent infielder who has played 17 seasons in the major leagues, was signed by the Mets yesterday to a minor league contract and invited to spring training.

title: Marc-isms, Palau's Comb And Anna Who?
description: ''There are an awful lot of Marc-isms this week'' on the runways, Kal Ruttenstein, the fashion director of Bloomingdale's, was heard saying as he sat in the front row at the Marc Jacobs show on Monday -- a presentation that helped restore to Fashion Week the sense that, whatever else was going on in the world, there would be a safe place in it for people who recall the French designer Jean-Charles de Castelbajac's early years.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL GAINS. Crude oil rose after Iraq rejected the presence of United Nations peacekeepers under a plan by France and Germany to avoid a war. In New York, oil for March delivery was up 96 cents, to $35.44 a barrel.

title: Loan Guarantee For US Airways Is Reaffirmed
description: The federal government renewed its approval of a $900 million loan guarantee for US Airways yesterday, moving the airline a step closer to exiting bankruptcy.

title: Tyson and Foe Look to the Future
description: When Mike Tyson fights Clifford Etienne, a journeyman heavyweight, on Feb. 22 in Memphis, both of them hope the bout will be a springboard to an even bigger payday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Fed Chief Rebuts Bush Plan For New Round of Tax Cuts

title: Boycott of PepsiCo Is Called Off
description: Athreatened boycott of PepsiCo was called off yesterday after Pepsi agreed to donate millions of dollars to nonprofit groups benefiting young people.

title: Report Suggests Use of Facial and Fingerprint Scanning on Foreigners
description: Government scientists are recommending a combination of facial recognition and fingerprint scanning technologies as the federal standard for identity documents to be issued to foreigners starting next year.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Outlook Cut
description: South Korea's outlook was cut to negative by Moody's Investors Service, underlining concern that North Korea's nuclear weapons program will hamper its economy. The step means Moody's is more likely to cut South Korea's A3 rating.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: U.S. Experts Help At Bomb Site
description: Seven American explosives experts, several of whom sifted through debris after the Oklahoma City terror attack in 1995, have begun work in Bogot in the rubble of an exclusive social and sports club that was badly damaged by a powerful car bomb. The experts, members of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, are helping Colombian officials determine what kind of bomb was used in the attack on Friday against the club, El Nogal. The government blamed Colombia's largest rebel group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, for detonating the 330-pound bomb, which killed 34 people and injured more than 160. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: A Test for America and Europe
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Towns; So Little Cash For Prisons, So Much Time
description: MIGUEL ARENAS has now served more than eight years of a 15-year-to-life sentence for selling two ounces of cocaine. At his sentencing in 1994, Justice Steven W. Fisher of State Supreme Court in Queens observed that he had recently given the same sentence to someone who pleaded guilty to possession of 800 pounds of cocaine.

title: Brit Hume Renews Deal With Fox News
description: The Fox News Channel has struck a deal to renew the contract of Brit Hume, its political anchor, through 2005, executives said yesterday.

title: Arms Makers See Great Potential in India Market
description: Leading military equipment makers from around the globe are aggressively promoting their products to India's huge defense market, with its $100 billion in expected spending in the next decade.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: $2 Billion In U.S. Aid To Be Released
description: The Bush administration will release about $2 billion in federal assistance to cover costs stemming from the attack on the World Trade Center, according to three members of the state's Congressional delegation. Senator Charles E. Schumer, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Representative James T. Walsh said the money would be used to cover Police Department and Fire Department expenses, defray the cost of insurance for contractors and pay for other expenses not covered under a federal aid package. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Philippine Government Halts Southern Drive Against Rebels
description: A government offensive against Muslim separatist rebels in the southern Philippines -- the largest operation since President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo took power two years ago -- was suspended today amid widespread chaos in the region.

title: African Cricket Matches Disrupted by Political Turmoil
description: It was born as an African sportfest, a mammoth 54-match tournament across three nations to celebrate cricket -- the game Britain once took to its colonies and now finds as ornery as its one-time empire turned out to be.

title: The Other Korea
description: It's hard to see how Washington can successfully manage the delicate nuclear weapons crisis with North Korea without close cooperation from South Korea. But right now, relations between the Bush administration and the South's president-elect, Roh Moo Hyun, are decidedly tense. A get-acquainted visit to Washington by Mr. Roh's emissaries last week didn't help much. Each side could use a crash course in understanding the other's views and needs. North Korea is certain to take advantage of continued tensions between these two traditional allies.

title: THREATS AND RESPONSES: Briefly Noted; TARGET PULLS CARDS
description: Target Stores across the nation pulled a box set of children's Valentines Day cards from their shelves after a parent in Pittsburgh thought it contained a terrorist-related message. The card, based on a series of ''I Spy'' books published by Scholastic Inc. in New York City, contained the word ''Jihad,'' which can mean holy war. A spokeswoman for Scholastic said the word was actually a child's name. A Target spokesman said the company did not believe the card was appropriate for its customers and called on its 11,048 stores to remove the item. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Sweets Are a Mini-Splendored Thing
description: Kee Ling Tong, below, owns Chocolate Garden, 80 Thompson Street (Spring Street), a serene sliver of a storefront. She makes candies that are delicate, rich and yet often powerfully seasoned, with fragile pastel or chocolate shells surrounding bracing mango, passion fruit and orange confit fillings. Dark chocolate with white and black sesame seeds, and chocolate cream in a cordial cherry, are some of Ms. Tong's many appealing combinations. (Never mind the corset shop next door.) The chocolates are $1.75 each, a box of 6 costs $10, 12 are $19 and 18 are $28.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Insurer Reverses Loss
description: The reinsurance company Converium said it earned $106.8 million last year, topping expectations and reversing a year-earlier loss of $367.4 million. The company, which was spun off from Zurich Financial Services in 2001, said net premiums written in 2002 rose 33.8 percent, to $3.32 billion. The company, based in Zurich, voted to pay its first dividend, of $1 a share. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: Grandma's Pan, Straight From the Attic
description: THIS enameled steel pan, or one like it, is the one your grandmother bought as a bride and may still be using. Granite Ware makes these pans, which are lightweight, inexpensive and widely available, in rectangle or oval, with lids. The two pieces, with handles, fit together to make a covered roaster or can be used as separate pans.

title: Ambushed In Afghanistan, G.I.'s Call In Airstrikes
description: American Special Forces troops ran into an ambush early Monday during a reconnaissance mission in a remote mountain valley of southern Afghanistan. They escaped injury after calling in airstrikes on at least five gunmen positioned in caves, an American military spokesman said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLSON, PAUL
description: OLSON-Paul. The Musicians, Trustees, and Staff of The Marlboro Music School and Festival mourn the loss of a valued Board Member and Officer, and a good friend, and send our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Dorothy. Paul played a key role in the incorporation of Marlboro in 1951, and generously gave his legal counsel and served as Board ''Clerk'' for almost fifty years. The devotion of Paul and Dorothy to Marlboro and its musicians, and to each other, will be cherished by us all for years to come. Stephen Stamas, Chairman Board of Trustees Marlboro Music School and Festival

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Defending a Deal
description: In Parliament, Prime Minister Bertie Ahern defended an agreement the government reached last year with 18 religious orders, indemnifying them against claims of abuse at state-financed schools that they ran. The ''industrial schools'' housed thousands of children who were orphans, delinquents or born to single mothers considered unfit parents by church authorities. A state compensation body is expected to pay as much as $1 billion to thousands of victims from the schools. Victims' groups and opposition parties say the orders should pay, but Mr. Ahern said the state did not want to drive them out of business. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: NETWORK APPLIANCE PROFIT ALMOST TRIPLES The world's largest maker of network-attached computer storage devices, Network Appliance, said yesterday that its third-quarter profit almost tripled, and sales rose faster than expenses. Net income in the quarter ended Jan. 24 increased to $19.7 million, or 6 cents a share, from $6.98 million, or 2 cents, a year earlier, the company said on its Web site. Sales rose 15 percent to $228.5 million from $198.3 million, outpacing a 6.1 percent gain in total operating costs. Network Appliance makes storage systems that attach to existing computer networks, which is less costly than building separate storage networks. Shares of Network Appliance fell as low as $10.47 in after-hours trading, down 30 cents. They rose 24 cents, to $10.77, in regular trading.

title: Words of C.I.A. and F.B.I. Chiefs: Dangers America Faces From Al Qaeda
description: Following are excerpts from opening statements in testimony yesterday by George J. Tenet, director of central intelligence, and Robert S. Mueller III, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, before the Senate select intelligence committee as recorded by Federal News Service Inc. A full transcript is at nytimes.com/international.

title: Bypassing Cottrell, 49ers Dip Into College Ranks for Erickson
description: The monthlong search for the San Francisco 49ers' new coach, which at times appeared so confused that the team's own quarterback blasted the process, ended with a surprise yesterday when San Francisco hired Dennis Erickson of Oregon State to replace Steve Mariucci.

title: Cosmos Sits for Early Portrait, Gives Up Secrets
description: The most detailed and precise map yet produced of the universe just after its birth confirms the Big Bang theory in triumphant detail and opens new chapters in the early history of the cosmos, astronomers said yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Comptroller Urges Full-Scale Recycling
description: William C. Thompson, the city's comptroller, called yesterday for a return to full-scale recycling of metal, glass and plastic, saying the current metal-only recycling confuses the public and costs the city more than it is saving. Mr. Thompson estimates that the overall cost of removing waste, including metal, could increase to $69 from $66. That compares with a $70-per-ton contract bid for waste removal that includes full-scale recycling, he said. Nichole M. Christian (NYT)

title: Teenager Gets 24 Years to Life for Killing Girl He Met on Phone
description: SYRACUSE, Feb. 11  A teenager was sentenced to 24 years to life in prison today for fatally stabbing a girl on their first date, after they met on a telephone chat line, and then burning down her home.

title: The Season Isn't Over For Rutgers
description: It was a meaningful victory for Rutgers, but, of course, that's all relative. Get to this point in the season with such a poor record in the conference, and the goals become modest ones. What's important now is making the Big East tournament and, maybe, the National Invitation Tournament.

title: IDT Sues CNN For Ad Rejection
description: The IDT Corporation in Newark, a telecommunications company, has sued CNN, accusing the cable network of refusing to accept an IDT commercial to avoid offending other telecommunications companies that advertise on CNN.

title: Hearings Open at Capitol Today With Vast Range of Queries for NASA
description: When lawmakers convene on Wednesday morning for a hearing on the space shuttle disaster, they will examine both the technical aspects of the tragedy and broader issues about safety, costs and the ultimate goals of the nation's space program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEFF, ALAN
description: SEFF-Alan. On February 10, 2003, age 87. Beloved husband of Gloria Seff, loving father of Gina Freis, Barbara Hurlbutt, and step father of Liane Onish, cherished grandfather of Stacy and Michelle Freis, Bryan and Julie Hurlbutt. Services Thursday 11:15 A.M. at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: In Our S.U.V.'s: A Love-Hate Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Mississippi Flood Pump
description: To the Editor:

title: The Chef Has a Word For It: Chocolate
description: For lovers (of chocolate, that is), Scott Campbell, the chef and owner of @SQC, 270 Columbus Avenue (72nd Street), has devised a menu that is cocoa-dusted from soup to nuts. Dinner can start with a savory oxtail-based chocolate soup, above, which has a strong chocolate aroma as it is poured over a garnish of carrot, wild rice and hominy, but tastes rich and beefy. Mr. Campbell has infused salad dressing with chocolate and has even concocted chocolate ketchup -- no sweeter than Heinz's -- for the fries served with beef tenderloin. Of course, there is no shortage of chocolate desserts.

title: Dude's Future? On Web, He Could Look Up Mitchum
description: Robert Mitchum, star of 1940's film noir classics, once commented on his reputation as a Hollywood bad boy: ''Booze, broads, it's all true. Make up more if you want.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 1,000 Jobs To Leave New York City
description: The New York Life Insurance Company has signed a tentative agreement to move a quarter of its 4,000 Manhattan-based employees to Westchester County, the company announced yesterday. The company, the largest mutual life insurance company in the United States, decided to diversify the work location of its employees in case of disaster, a spokesman said. If the deal is completed, New York Life will buy a 383,000-square-foot complex on 76 acres in Mount Pleasant for $38 million by the end of March and begin moving in in 2004. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POPPER, CHARLES
description: POPPER-Charles. Son of the late Samuel and Sadie Popper, passed away February 11, 2003. Resided in Manhattan all of his life. Survived by his brother, Gerald, sister-inlaw Anne, many nieces and nephews, and cousins, Sara Anne and Mayer Gusik. Services Friday February 14 at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 Second Avenue, NYC at 10 A.M. Burial service at Baron Hirsch Cemetery to follow immediately after.

title: Talk Therapy
description: The Bush administration seems to have decided that it has no good options on North Korea. It regards military strikes as too dangerous and too complicated in light of Iraq. It refuses to negotiate a new deal for fear of rewarding bad behavior. It has tried to mobilize multilateral pressure on North Korea to back down, but this strategy has been undercut by the reluctance of North Korea's neighbors to squeeze it too hard.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15, 21

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MIRELOWITZ, SEYMOUR
description: MIRELOWITZ-Seymour. A stranger to no-one. Gone twenty years. Lovingly remembered and missed by his family, students and friends

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLMAN, NEVILLE, M.D., PH.D.
description: COLMAN - Neville, M.D., Ph.D. The Beth Israel Medical Center (BIMC) and St. Luke'sRoosevelt Hospital Center (SLRHC) families join with the leadership of their parent company, Continuum Health Partners, in acknowledging with deep sadness the passing of our dear friend and beloved colleague, Neville Colman, M.D., Ph.D, Chairman of Diagnostic Pathology and Laboratory Medicine. An international leader in pathologic medicine, Dr. Colman dedicated his life to the clinical advancement of his field, the expansion of its applications in research, and the education of tomorrow's physicians. His tireless efforts to bring greater synergy and sharing of services between our institutions, including advancing the burgeoning field of robotic pathologic testing, will forever stand as his legacy. He was a kind and gentlemanly individual who will be greatly missed by everyone who knew and worked with him. To his wife, Dr. Glenys Lobban, his children Jessica and Stephen, the entire Colman family and all of his loved ones, we extend heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, Continuum, BIMC and SLRHC Gail F. Donovan, Interim President/CEO, Continuum Richard F. Daines, M.D., President and CEO, SLRHC Thomas Killip, M.D., Interim President and CEO, BIMC William Winkler, M.D., President, Medical Board, SLRHC Donald Kastenbaum, M.D., President, Medical Board, BIMC Bruce Wenig, M.D., Interim Chair, Diagnotic Pathology & Laboratory Medicine, BIMC & SLRHC Bernadine Flezjor, Admin. Director, Diagnostic Pathology & Laboratory Medicine, BIMC & SLRHC Robert L. Salant, M.D., President, Doctors Alumni Assoc, BIMC

title: Cheney's Help Is Sought in Budget Snag Over Aid to Farmers
description: Congressional negotiators turned to Vice President Dick Cheney today to help resolve an impasse over drought relief for farmers that was imperiling the current year's financing for much of the federal government.

title: French Move Toward Curbs on Smoking by Minors
description: A ''mini-revolution'' is how the daily tabloid Le Parisien characterized the move today. In an effort to curb smoking among minors, the French Senate today approved bill to ban cigarette sales to children under 16.

title: Taking Apart a Toy Fair And Hoping It Still Works
description: When it opens on Sunday in Manhattan, the 100th American International Toy Fair, the nation's largest trade show for toys, will be the last of the traditional extravaganzas that have crammed a year's worth of hoopla and ballyhoo into a single show.

title: Women's Studies Online at Barnard
description: The Center for Research on Women at Barnard College has begun offering a journal, ''The Scholar and Feminist Online,'' at www.barnard.edu/sfonline. The first issue, ''Writing Toward Hope: Literature, Art and the Struggle for Human Rights,'' was edited by MARJORIE AGOSN. An issue on Margaret Mead, for example, includes film clips from a panel discussion sponsored by the center. An issue on family photography and American Jewish identity provides specially commissioned photographic essays. Future issues will include live chats between students and selected contributors. JANET JAKOBSEN, the center's director, said the journal would allow the center to archive its best programs and reach a wider audience. DEBORAH SIEGEL, a researcher at the center who is working on a book about women and marriage, will edit the Web journal, which will appear three times this year and twice a year after that. Karen W. Arenson

title: World Business Briefing: Americas
description: CANADA: ENTERTAINMENT EXECUTIVE NAMED The chil- dren's entertainment company Cinar named Stuart C. Snyder as its president and chief executive. Mr. Snyder, 43, was previously president of World Wrestling Federation Entertainment, now World Wrestling Entertainment , of Stamford, Conn. Cinar, the creator of Arthur the Aardvark, recently settled claims from thousands of shareholders seeking damages for losses from revenue diverted to an investment firm in the Bahamas.

title: Showrooms Are Blooming
description: New designs for the house may offer relief from the winter blahs.

title: A Design Statement With an Open Door
description: Francisco Pinedo and his wife, Alba Pinedo, have opened the L.A. Design Center in South Central Los Angeles.

title: The Work of Diller + Scofidio
description: Images from the work of Diller + Scofidio, including the planned Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston.

title: Alone but Together
description: Arthur and Nan Kellam leave California to create a fairy tale on the Maine coast.

title: Terrorism Fears and Jitters
description: The rest of the country is not immune to the fears of terror felt by many in New York and Washington. But that fear is nowhere near as widespread, or as keenly felt.

title: Food, Glorious Food?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Equipping a Kitchen With Its Own Dinner Views
description: Stainless steel refrigerators with glass fronts have made the leap from the deli to the appliance showroom. Sub-Zero is introducing the 650G, a 36-inch-wide model (above), with a transparent door and a freezer drawer. ''It's a Beverly Hills refrigerator that will work for a modern house in Venice Beach,'' said Ron Radziner, an architect in the Los Angeles firm of Marmol Radziner. An inside light with a dimmer turns fresh fruit, artichokes and frise into a still life. The 650G, which is $6,200, will be available in the spring from the Westye Group in Los Angeles, (323) 770-3610; the 30-inch-wide 611G is $5,700. Platinum stainless and carbon stainless finishes will be available in June. Other locations: www.subzero.com. CRAIG KELLOGG

title: Wind-Fueled Fire Kills a Woman and 3 Children in Queens
description: A fire fueled by high winds swept through a Queens home early yesterday morning, killing a woman and her two young children and a niece who was visiting them, fire officials said.

title: Strong Water and Juice Sales Increase Coke Profits by 1.8%
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 1.8 percent and its volume growth outpaced its competitors in every major category last year. Coke attributed most of its gains to strong sales of noncarbonated drinks, acquisitions and licensing agreements for bottled water.

title: Woods and Mickelson Try to Clear the Air
description: Saying he had made a mistake, Phil Mickelson said today that he regretted calling Tiger Woods's Nike golf equipment inferior.

title: Race Peers Out Of Masks
description: If there is a more dauntless ensemble in New York than the Classical Theater of Harlem, I don't know what it is. With a modest budget, a rudimentary theater space at the Harlem School of the Arts and a company made up of a few actors with significant professional experience and many others who are hungry for it, this four-year-old troupe has taken on colossal works like ''Lysistrata,'' ''Rhinoceros,'' ''King Lear'' and ''Medea.''

title: How Albany Drafts a Media Event
description: The greatest danger facing the nation today is terrorism. The greatest danger facing the New York State Legislature is a budget deficit of over $11 billion. In what was either a confused sense of priorities or a desperate attempt to change the subject, New York's governor, George Pataki, and his fellow Republicans in the State Senate turned their attention to terror this week. In order to justify an elaborate photo opportunity, senators swiftly pulled together a package of antiterrorism bills and passed them in less than 24 hours. The governor and his supporters trampled the legislative process in their stampede to get before the cameras.

title: Sharon Faces Belgian Trial After Term Ends
description: Belgium's highest court said today in Brussels that Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel could be tried for war crimes under the nation's laws, but not as long as he enjoyed the immunity of his office.

title: Ground Zero Designers Are Asked for Revisions To Solve Problems in Pit
description: The two teams of architects working on designs for the World Trade Center site have been asked to modify their plans to address engineering problems in the pit at the site, according to people involved in the rebuilding effort.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HAIGHT, CAPT. STANLEY REED, JR.
description: HAIGHT-Capt. Stanley Reed, Jr. (1924-1973). Died at sea 30 years ago today. He lives on forever in our hearts. Love always, Taube, Karen, Margaret & Laur

title: Medical Center Issues Memo On Possible Cyanide Threat
description: The chief medical officer of New York University Hospitals Center issued a memo to staff members yesterday alerting them to the possibility of a cyanide attack, saying his message was based on information from the government.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Cruise Missile Is Tested
description: India test-fired a cruise missile jointly developed with Russia and capable of hitting major cities in Pakistan, officials said. The missile, called the Brahmos, cannot carry a nuclear warhead, but it has a range of 185 miles, can carry 440 pounds and can be launched from ships, submarines and planes. The test comes as relations between the two nuclear-armed neighbors are increasingly strained. Last week Delhi expelled Pakistan's acting high commissioner and four staff members; Islamabad responded in kind. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: To Counter Iraq, Let's Compromise
description: To the Editor:

title: The Mood? In a Word, Anxiety
description: To the Editor:

title: Protesters Are Denied Potent Tactic Of the Past
description: There have been marches that looked like rallies and rallies that looked like marches and demonstrations that were a little bit of both. But when a federal judge ruled this week that antiwar demonstrators could rally in Manhattan on Saturday but not march through the streets, she was drawing a distinction that historians and others say can have great symbolic weight.
