description: MANHATTAN

title: A War for Oil? Not This Time
description: When Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld visited ''Old Europe'' last week, the placards and protesters lining his path were a visceral reminder of what the Bush administration already knew: Solid majorities in key European countries think that greed is our motive for wanting to depose Saddam Hussein. In fact, in a recent Pew Research Center poll 75 percent of respondents in France, 54 percent in Germany and 76 percent in Russia said that America wants to invade Iraq because ''the U.S. wants to control Iraqi oil.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELMAN, ESTHER MUSKIN
description: EDELMAN-Esther Muskin. Of Brookline, MA, passed away surrounded by her family on February 10, 2003, and was laid to rest in Israel on February 12, 2003. Beloved wife and partner of Julian, and devoted mother and cherished friend to Elazer (Cheryl), Theodore (Jewel), Raphael (Leslie) and Daniel (Nancy). She is survived as well by 15 loving grandchildren. ''She opens her mouth with wisdom, her tongue is guided by kindness.'' Shiva will be observed at her home through Wednesday, February 19th. Contributions in her memory can be made to The Maimonides School, Brookline, MA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, JACK, M.D.
description: LEVINE-Jack, M.D., 88. Of NYC, died peacefully at home on February 11, 2003. Cherished husband of the late Esther (Quitt), adored father and father-in-law of Michael and Janet, Carol and David, Susan and Malcolm, Jed and Jerry, loving Poppy to 13 grandchildren and five greatgrandchildren. Beloved by his brother and sister-in-law Danny and Annette and many nieces, nephews and cousins. Lovingly cared for by Rosa Bradley. Decorated WWII veteran, retired chairman of orthopedic surgery, Brookdale Hospital Medical Center, researcher, inventor, teacher, avid tennis player, and world traveler. MEDICO/ CARE physician in Afghanistan, Indonesia and other remote locations. He loved good food and good times with his family and many friends. He lived life to the fullest and will be missed. Memorial service Sunday, February 16, 2003, 1:30 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St and Amsterdam. Memorial donations may be made to Alzheimer's Association, NYC 360 Lexington Ave, NYC 10017 or Pediatric Orthopedic Fund of NY Orthopedic Hospital, 3959 Bway 8 North, NYC 10032.

title: Inspectors Begin Destroying 10 Iraqi Mustard Gas Shells
description: United Nations arms inspectors began work today to destroy 10 old artillery shells filled with mustard gas, as a peace envoy sent here by Pope John Paul II announced that he would soon meet with President Saddam Hussein.

title: For Top 3-Year-Olds, Florida Is Stop on Road to the Derby
description: The best 3-year-old in South Florida these days is no doubt the undefeated Sky Mesa. But he hasn't raced since October and won't be ready for at least another few weeks. Who's second best? That should be decided Saturday in the Fountain of Youth at Gulfstream, this year's first Grade I prep race for the Kentucky Derby.

title: NASA Chief Takes a Seat In the Arena
description: Among the briefing books and photographs of fallen astronauts strewn upon the desk from which Sean O'Keefe faced Congress today were two slips of paper, each bearing a quotation about the nature of courage. One was from Robert F. Kennedy. The other, from Theodore Roosevelt, was first spoken in 1899, long before the era of space flight.

It was an administration official speaking on condition of anonymity, not Condoleezza Rice, President Bush's national security adviser.

title: DELTA WANTS PILOTS TO DISCUSS COST REDUCTIONS
description: The chief financial officer of Delta Air Lines said yesterday that the company intended to open talks with its pilots' union to renegotiate terms in its labor agreement, but the union said it would not start any such talks unless the company delivers specific proposals. Michele Burns, Delta's chief financial officer, said at a conference in New York that the airline had to get cost cuts from its pilots to stanch its financial losses. But the Delta pilots' contract does not become amendable until 2005, and the union said yesterday that it had no plans to meet with executives over it. William C. Buergey, chairman of the Delta chapter of the Air Line Pilots Association, said that if executives gave a proposal to the union, its leaders would examine it and decide whether to enter into talks. Edward Wong (NYT)

description: During a routine self-examination last May, Shirley Magee found a lump on her breast. Within weeks she had it and some lymph nodes removed. So far so good, until it came to the follow-up therapy.

title: In Connecticut And New York, Doctors Plan To Join Protest
description: Doctors in New York and Connecticut are planning to protest rising malpractice insurance costs next month in Albany and Hartford, voicing their anger over the same rancorous issue that led New Jersey doctors to stage a work slowdown.

title: FARM TALKS TO BEGIN
description: Trade ministers will meet in Tokyo this weekend to discuss reductions in agricultural tariffs and other measures. World Business, Section W.

title: Editors' Note; Editors' Note
description: The main article in Sunday Styles this week reported that business lunches had grown fewer and smaller in the economic squeeze since 9/11. It quoted restaurateurs' accounts of dwindling crowds, saying that the owner of Gabriel's, near Columbus Circle, called the erosion of corporate spending the worst since the crash of 1987.

title: Russia, U.N. Swing Vote, Plays a Waiting Game
description: With some deft diplomatic maneuvering in Berlin and Paris, President Vladimir V. Putin has vaulted Russia this week into the unexpected position of being the potential swing vote in a looming United Nations debate over military action against Iraq.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: COLOMBIA: OFFICIAL CONFIRMED DEAD IN PLANE CRASH Rescuers found the body of Colombia's social welfare minister, Juan Luis Londoño, 44, and those of four others who were killed when the small plane in which they were traveling crashed in the mountains of southeastern Colombia on Feb. 6. The small private plane, carrying Mr. Londoño, two aides, a bodyguard and the pilot, slammed into a fog-covered Andean peak shortly after takeoff. Rescuers faced difficult conditions and the presence of leftist rebels, who last week fired upon a helicopter that had been trying to search for the wreckage.

title: Praising American Classical Theater, Not Burying It
description: THE theater company founded by Jeffrey Horowitz nearly 25 years ago was born out of a conflagration -- literally.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Pataki Purchases Farm For $1.2 Million
description: Gov. George E. Pataki paid $1.2 million last month for a farm just south of Plattsburgh, his spokeswoman confirmed. The farm, overlooking Lake Champlain, covers 377 acres near the village of Essex. Mr. Pataki obtained a $980,000 mortgage from the sellers, who include Donald Duley, a real estate agent based in Plattsburgh. ''It's just a place that he really enjoys and where he likes to spend time with his family,'' said Lisa Stoll, the governor's spokeswoman.

title: Giant Playground Is Chosen for Site of Meadowlands Arena
description: More than 100 acres of the New Jersey Meadowlands would be developed as a family entertainment complex with an indoor ski slope, indoor surfing, a Formula One racetrack, a minor league baseball stadium and office towers, under a $1.3 billion redevelopment plan chosen today by the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority.

title: Excerpts From Joint Congressional Hearing on Loss of Shuttle Columbia
description: Following are excerpts from a joint Congressional hearing yesterday into the loss of the space shuttle Columbia, as recorded by The New York Times. Among those who questioned the NASA administrator, Sean O'Keefe, were Senators Olympia J. Snowe, Republican of Maine, and Bill Nelson, Democrat of Florida; and Representative Sherwood Boehlert, Republican of New York. Fuller excerpts are online at nytimes.com/columbia.

title: Europe Proposes Rules On Phone Competition
description: The European Commission proposed detailed new rules today meant to ensure that regulators in the 15 member nations keep careful watch over the business practices of the giant former state telephone monopolies that still dominate on the Continent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUDNICK, GERTRUDE
description: BUDNICK-Gertrude. Of the Bronx. Passed away February 11, 2003. A 10AM graveside service is scheduled for today at the Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. For information, Garlick Funeral Homes, 914-235-5341.

title: THREE AUTOMAKERS IN JOINT VENTURE TO BUILD ENGINES
description: Hyundai Motor has joined with DaimlerChysler, which owns 10 percent of Hyundai's equity, and Mitsubishi Motors, which also has a small stake in Hyundai Motor, to build an engine plant in Dundee, Mich. The plant, to employ 400 workers, would develop four-cylinder gasoline-driven engines. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: VODAFONE MOVES AHEAD WITH DUTCH DEAL The Vodafone Group proceeded with an offer to buy the 22 percent of Vodafone Libertel, a Dutch mobile phone company, that it does not already own for 771.1 million euros ($827 million), even though the management of the phone company, that it does not already own for 771.1 million euros ($827 million), even though the management of the company had previously said the offer was too low. Unlike rivals that are selling assets to raise money to pay debt, Vodafone has continued expanding during the telecommunications slump by increasing its stakes in regional operators. Vodafone, which is based in Britain, offered to pay 47 kronor ($5.52) a share last week to take control of Europolitan Vodafone of Sweden. Vodafone said it reserved the right to withdraw the offer for Libertel unless investors controlling at least 17 percent of the company agreed to sell their shares.  Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Rather Than Curse the Darkness, Why Not Design Your Own Light?
description: Matt Gagnon, an architectural designer in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, makes lights that he calls ''surrogates for architectural projects I am thinking of.'' His 27-inch-tall table lamp (left) is made of hinged poplar ($600). Customers can design lamp shapes themselves, said Mr. Gagnon, who has worked for Gaetano Pesce and, until recently, for Frank Gehry in Los Angeles. An iridescent 14-inch-tall block light (near left, $600 to $900) is made of bands of acrylic and hardboard. At Homework, 1153 North Highland Avenue, Los Angeles, (323) 466-1153; Move Lab, 803 Washington Street, Manhattan, (212) 741-5520; and Bark, 369 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, (718) 625-8997.

title: Greenspan's Doubts Prod Bush Defense Of Tax Cuts
description: The White House moved quickly today to shore up support for President Bush's economic plan and took the rare step of bluntly disagreeing with Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, over the need for an immediate new round of tax cuts.

title: Yahoo Outlines Plans for Adding Premium Services
description: At its last meeting with analysts, 15 months ago, Yahoo gave each of them a gift of a yo-yo to make the point that what goes down can come up. At a dinner on Tuesday before its meeting yesterday, the company gave analysts a set of balls, to show that it has stabilized its finances and is now juggling several opportunities for growth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUPFER, STANLEY
description: KUPFER-Stanley. Beloved and devoted husband of Frieda, father of Andrew and Steven, brother of David and Lenore. His smile will always warm us.

title: NASA Responds to Lawmakers by Loosening Panel's Ties to Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12  Responding to sharp bipartisan criticism from lawmakers today about the independence of the board investigating the Columbia space shuttle disaster, NASA rewrote the board's charter tonight in ways it said would ensure that the panel was free from the influence of the space agency.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Nobody wants war, but sometimes it's necessary when you need it to maintain international order.''

title: Ballet Pupils On a Bridge That Spans The Atlantic
description: The Royal Ballet School in London is the latest European ballet academy to send its students on international tours, and its showcase performance, to be repeated tonight at the Kaye Playhouse, is a welcome and gentle treat.

title: Knicks Face Make-or-Break Road Trip
description: Before the Knicks left their practice facility in Greenburgh, N.Y., yesterday to begin a six-game trip west, Coach Don Chaney had them watch the film of Wednesday night's 113-107 loss to the Golden State Warriors at Madison Square Garden.

title: $102 MILLION OFFER FOR CALIPER TECHNOLOGIES
description: The Caliper Technologies Corporation, which makes tools for laboratory experiments, received an acquisition offer from LB Acquisitions, a unit of Little Bear Investments. The offer totals about $101.7 million, or $4.15 a share, and it represents a 38 percent premium over Caliper's closing price of $3 a share Tuesday. Caliper of Mountain View, Calif., had about 24.5 million shares outstanding as of Nov. 6, according to a federal filing. Caliper is developing a technology called lab on a chip, which allows genomic and pharmaceutical experiments to be conducted on a microchip. In the fourth quarter, Caliper's net loss widened to $10.5 million, or 43 cents a share, from $8.02 million, or 33 cents a year earlier. Revenue slid 37 percent, to $4.93 million from $7.87 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIERING, JESSE
description: ZIERING-Jesse. 100 years young. Beloved husband of the late Laurette. Father of Susan and Gerald (Judy). Loving grandfather and great-grandfather. Rest with Mom.

title: Review/Fashion; An 80's Revival Under the Tents
description: Narciso Rodriguez kept the steam in his ultrasexy clothes, picking up where he left off last season, while Michael Kors did the proverbial Manhattan shuffle in a collection that mixed high and low -- and shades of Claude Montana.

title: Wooing Youth, Staying Afloat, Playing Shill
description: She's a mod, she's Penelope Tree, she's Siouxsie from Siouxsie and the Banshees. She's what people in the advertising business call a ''culture driver.'' She's too young to remember any of the references above as invoked on the runways all week, and so for her all the go-go boots and Courrges dresses and ripped fishnets and leggings are not period reruns. They're brand new.

title: A Radio Remote Frees Xbox Users To Roam the Den Unfettered
description: With the release of new wireless controllers, gamers using any of the current generation of consoles -- the GameCube, PlayStation 2 and, now, the Xbox -- can play without a tangle of cords stretched across the floor. Relying on the same radio frequency technology used for cordless phones, Mad Catz's Lynx Wireless Controller and Logitech's Cordless Controller allow you to play untethered from your Xbox.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Brocade Loss Caused By Job-Cut Costs
description: Brocade Communications Systems Inc., the world's largest maker of switches used in computer data-storage systems, had a first-quarter loss because of job-cut costs. Sales were unchanged. The net loss in the quarter ended Jan. 25 was $6.89 million, or 3 cents a share, in contrast to net income of $11.7 million, or 5 cents, a year earlier, the company said in a statement. Sales were about $123.1 million in both periods. Shares of Brocade fell as much as 33 cents, or 7.8 percent, to $3.92 in after-hours trading. They rose 7 cents, to $4.25, in regular trading.

title: A Love Seat That Has Eyes Only for You
description: Rick Lee, an industrial designer born in Korea to Chinese parents, has designed furnishings that he says are ''based on the five elements of Chinese cosmology'' -- fire, water, earth, wood and metal. The polished aluminum Mask love seat (near right, 60 inches long, $9,500) and the red powder-coated Liquid accessory table (far right, 20 inches tall, $950) both evoke liquid metal. The Mask seat also brings to mind contemporary theater: it was designed for a celebration of the San Francisco Opera's staging of ''The Phantom of the Opera.''

title: Privacy Invasion Curtailed

title: Nods to Love, Nasty and Nice
description: Perhaps it was just that the manager had a bummer of a year in the relationship department, but one large bookstore in Manhattan has a prominent Valentine's Day display of what can best be described as dumping manuals, as in how to get rid of your lover.

title: Living to the Power of Two
description: NO man is an island, but a couple was.

title: BAUSCH & LOMB LOSES APPEAL ON PUREVISION LENSES
description: Bausch & Lomb, the contact lens maker, lost an appeals court bid to sell its PureVision brand in the United States. The Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit upheld a trial judge's ruling that the company infringed a patent owned by a bigger rival, the Wesley Jessen Corporation, a unit of Novartis. The court left in place a ban on PureVision sales in the United States until 2005. Bausch & Lomb, which is based in Rochester, has spent $60 million to bring the continuous-wear product to market. After the lower court's ruling in June, the company moved PureVision manufacturing to Waterford, Ireland, so it could continue to sell the lenses outside the United States.

title: Nets Miss Everything, Especially a Victory
description: If the Nets were missing something Tuesday in Orlando, namely shots and energy, tonight they were missing everything -- jumpers, defense, flow and intensity -- against a Memphis Grizzlies team that had lost its last seven games.

title: Duct Tape and Plastic Sheeting Can Offer Solace, if Not Real Security
description: Duct tape and plastic sheeting can be useful for chores around the house, but experts are uncertain how well they might protect against chemical, biological or ''dirty bomb'' attacks.

title: Behind Roses' Beauty, Poor and Ill Workers
description: In just five years, Ecuadorean roses, as big and red as the human heart, have become the new status flower in the United States, thanks to the volcanic soil, perfect temperatures and abundant sunlight that help generate $240 million a year and tens of thousands of jobs in this once-impoverished region north of Quito.

title: New York Will Sue 2 Big Drug Makers On Doctor Discount
description: New York plans to sue two major pharmaceutical companies today, accusing them essentially of paying doctors and pharmacists to choose the companies' drugs over competing medicines.

title: Group Sues Christian Program at Iowa Prison
description: Two federal lawsuits filed yesterday in Iowa contend that a state-financed evangelical Christian prison program that gives privileges to participating inmates violates the separation of church and state.

title: Republican Leaders Reach A Deal on Spending Measure
description: Congressional negotiators reached a deal today on a $397.4 billion spending measure that finances most of the federal government through Sept. 30 after they resolved disputes over farm aid and environmental provisions.

title: Judge Grants the Government A Delay of Moussaoui's Trial
description: A federal judge indefinitely postponed the trial of Zacarias Moussaoui today while the Justice Department appealed a court ruling that would give his lawyers access to another member of Al Qaeda accused of conspiring in the September 2001 terror attacks, according to a court order and people with access to classified information about the case.

title: As Blix Report Nears, Debate Swirls on Iraqi Weapons
description: As United Nations inspectors prepare to present a pivotal briefing on Friday about the state of Saddam Hussein's weapons programs to a Security Council divided by conflicting agendas, the Iraqi leader's military capabilities remain a matter of heated debate.

title: A Design Statement With an Open Door
description: No longer exclusive to West Hollywood, contemporary furniture showrooms have opened in Santa Monica, Pasadena, Newport Beach -- and now in the South Central section of Los Angeles. This month Francisco Pinedo (at far right with his wife and partner, Alba Pinedo) opened the L.A. Design Center in South Central, an area that, though long associated with poverty and crime, is the heart of the city's furniture manufacturing industry.

title: Not One to Advise and Tell; Bloomberg Companion, a Pataki Aide, Separates Roles
description: Diana Taylor spent a recent Sunday at the side of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, joining him in visiting several churches of the city. She listened as he vowed to protect the poor during the current budget crisis and, at his request, she shared in the blessing bestowed upon him at a Baptist church in the Bronx.

title: Tufts of Color Herald the Next Season
description: READY for a respite from winter? Some of the newest designs for the house may offer relief. Housewares displayed at the Maison & Objet show in Paris last month and the Accent on Design section of the New York International Gift Market last week emphasized images borrowed from nature. Many were colored in hues of green and lilac. And in a departure from the emphasis on plastic in past years, this year's shows were full of natural materials like wicker and cotton. So take heart: in the showrooms, spring is already here.

title: Cease-Fire Fails in the Philippines as Soldiers Clash With Rebels
description: Fighting between government soldiers and Muslim rebels continued in the southern Philippines today, a day after President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo declared a cease-fire. The military said 60 Muslim rebels and 3 government soldiers had been killed as of midday, while the rebels said they had killed 49 soldiers.

Contestants flex their pectorals and tighten their buttocks before a panel in an exercise that could pass for a Marine Corps physical, if the military condoned red lighting, pop music and words like hottitude.

title: Viacom Rebounds to Quarterly Profit, but Shares Decline

title: Neville Colman, Pathologist and DNA Expert, Dies at 57
description: Dr. Neville Colman, a prominent New York hematologist and forensic DNA expert as well as the founder of the West Side Soccer League, a boon for thousands of young Manhattan players, died Tuesday at New York Presbyterian Hospital.

description: United Airlines plans to shift about 30 percent of its domestic capacity into the new discount airline that the carrier hopes to form as it plots its escape from bankruptcy, executives said yesterday, giving their most detailed public accounting of United's recovery plan.

description: Were it not for the circumstances of its earliest performances, Hans Krasa's chamber opera ''Brundibar'' might have become a pleasantly innocuous staple of the children's choral repertory.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Steel Acquisition
description: Hanbo Iron and Steel, the first South Korean company to encounter severe legal as well as financial difficulties in the 1997 economic crisis, will be sold to AK Capital, a Seoul investment company. AK Capital agreed to pay $377 million for Hanbo before taking over next summer, according to Korea Asset Management, the government concern that is Hanbo's lead creditor. The sale was delayed while negotiators tried to get a much higher price. Hanbo is finishing construction of a new steel mill capable of processing 11.5 million tons a year. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: New Hong Kong Security Bill Still of Concern to Rights Advocates
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 13 - Four months after announcing plans for stringent internal security laws, Hong Kong leaders unveiled the actual legal language today and urged the territory's Legislative Council to pass it swiftly.

description: Some games are a challenge for the Devils, others merely a chore.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZERKOWITZ, PETER
description: ZERKOWITZ-Peter. Age 91. On February 5, 2003. A Hungarian war hero who worked for the Resistance in World War II and fought against the communists, Peter emigrated to the U.S. in 1949. Described as a Renaissance man, he possessed a keen intellect and was knowledgeable on a world of subjects. Peter was a generous patron of the arts, compassionate humanitarian, devoted bridge player who will be missed by his longtime partners, and fine organist and remarkable musician. Cherished companion for 39 years of Ilona Katonah and loving second father to Peg Lehman and John Katonah, and beloved uncle of Kristof, Ferenc, Tamas, and Babszi Zerkowitz and their families in Budapest, Hungary and Maria Zankowits and her family in the U.S. We will miss the strength of his spirit and his caring presence in our lives.

title: Shutting Down the Snoops
description: Amid the confusion and backdoor deals involved with finishing up the federal government's nearly $400 billion appropriations bill, there have been bits of good news. We're happy to note that the Senate and House conferees agreed to impose severe restrictions on Total Information Awareness, a Pentagon surveillance scheme concocted by John Poindexter that could have threatened the civil liberties of ordinary Americans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, MARVIN
description: COHEN - Marvin. Devoted husband, father and community leader. Metropolitan Council on Jewish Poverty mourns with his beloved wife Margie, their children Abba, Akiva and Devorah and their grandchildren. Marvin served on our Board for over two decades. His vision and dedication helped us serve thousands of needy New Yorkers. He will be sorely missed. Joseph C. Shenker, President Merryl H. Tisch, Chairman William E. Rapfogel, CEO

description: In a coincidence almost too morbid for pulp fiction, tomorrow -- Valentine's Day -- Robert E. Chambers Jr. will be freed from an upstate prison.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about the way New York City arts institutions are coping with a reduction in income misstated the fiscal year for which the city has projected an 18 percent reduction in its cultural budget. It is 2004 (which starts on July 1), not 2003.

title: U.S. Rebounds By Beating Jamaica
description: The United States men's team rebounded from a 1-0 loss to Argentina in Miami last Saturday, getting goals from Carlos Bocanegra and Chris Klein in the first 13 minutes last night on the way to a 2-1 victory over Jamaica at National Stadium in Kingston.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cadbury Lowers Outlook
description: Cadbury Schweppes reported a modest increase in earnings for 2002, but warned that results for 2003 would fall below initial guidelines. Per-share earnings are now expected to grow 5 percent to 10 percent, not in excess of 10 percent as Cadbury original predicted, John Sunderland, the chief executive, told Bloomberg Television. Cadbury attributed the shortfall to slower sales of the Dr Pepper and 7Up soda brands, as well as costs related to the integration of Adams, a maker of cough drops and chewing gum that Cadbury bought last year from Pfizer. In 2002, pretax profit -- excluding amortization of good will, restructuring charges and one-time gains or losses on the sale of assets -- grew 6 percent, to 935 million ($1.5 billion), compared with 886 million for the prior year. Sales rose 7 percent, to 5.3 billion, from 5 billion in 2001. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Sorenstam Will Shoot With Men At Colonial
description: Annika Sorenstam will become the first woman to play on the PGA Tour in 53 years, after accepting a sponsor's invitation today to compete in the Colonial tournament in May.

title: ANTITERROR MONEY STALLS IN CONGRESS
description: Many state and local governments say they are unprepared to deal with a major terrorist attack because of Washington's delay in providing them with billions of dollars in emergency-response aid that was promised shortly after the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Bin Laden Tape May Hint at Attack, C.I.A. Says
description: The country's intelligence chief warned today that the latest taped message attributed to Osama bin Laden was an ''exhortation to his followers,'' like statements made by the terrorist leader last year that were quickly followed by deadly attacks overseas.

title: The America's Cup Up Close, Without Binoculars
description: HOW can you enjoy a race when you can't tell who's ahead?

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about Alan Greenspan's rebuttal of many of President Bush's arguments for new tax cuts misstated the party makeup of the Senate when Congress passed tax cuts in 2001. It was split 50-50; Democrats did not have a slim majority.

title: No Pattern of Fraud Found Beyond the Breeders' Cup
description: A continuing review of large horse-racing payoffs in 2002 has yielded no evidence of irregularities or suspicious betting patterns similar to last October's $3 million Breeders' Cup pick-six scam, the National Thoroughbred Racing Association says in a report to be released today.

title: Treats to Mollify a Crabby Cellphone
description: IT did not surprise anyone who knows me to learn six months ago that I gave up my cellphone. In fact, given my reputation as a techno-crank, a lot of people probably thought the world would be a generally safer place if I were cellphone-free.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: NII Holdings Posts 18% Rise In Revenue
description: NII Holdings, an operator of wireless systems in Latin America that emerged from bankruptcy protection last year, reported unexpectedly strong financial results yesterday with revenue for 2002 climbing 18 percent, to $780.4 million, from $662.4 million a year earlier. NII, which uses wireless technology from Nextel Communications, reduced its long-term debt to $430 million, from $2.8 billion, and sold a unit in the Philippines, recording a pretax gain of $37 million from the transaction. A group including MacKay Shields, a New York investment firm, and Merrill Lynch took control of NII last year, significantly diluting the stake of Nextel, the company's largest shareholder. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: McCarthy and Kovalev Give Rangers a Reason to Shout
description: Sandy McCarthy could only laugh this morning when Aleksei Kovalev recalled the game nearly a decade ago when Mike Keenan, then the Rangers' coach, would not let him off the ice, punishing him with an exceptionally long shift.

title: Pro-Qaeda Oil Workers A Sabotage Risk for Saudis
description: The government of Saudi Arabia has increased security around its oil fields and processing centers after the discovery that employees of the state-owned oil company sympathetic to Al Qaeda were discussing sabotage plans late last summer, American and Saudi officials say.

title: In a Slim Frame on Your Wall, The Monitor as Masterpiece
description: If desk space is at a minimum, why not hang that computer monitor on the wall? Samsung Electronics has introduced a new line of flat-panel liquid crystal display monitors that are about an inch thick and come with removable base stands. That makes it easy to hang the screen with standard wall-mounting hardware, just as you would a framed picture.

title: Deal Almost Done: Mets Likely to Sign Cone
description: David Cone was extremely close last night to agreeing on a minor league contract to return to the Mets and make a comeback attempt at age 40. The discussions between Cone and the Mets intensified in the last two days, and some contract language was all that remained to be resolved before Cone became a Met and competed for the fifth spot in the starting rotation, a baseball official said.

title: ONLINE DIARY
description: Love Clicks

title: How Ethics Have Changed!
description: Bridge old-timers agree that the standard of ethics has risen in the last half century. It is also true, although less obvious, that the standard of bridge journalistic ethics has risen, too.

title: Lawyer for Bridgeport Mayor Cross-Examines Top Accuser
description: A lawyer for Joseph P. Ganim, the mayor of Bridgeport, tried to distance him from bribery schemes outlined in court by his former close friend and fund-raiser, now his chief accuser, Paul J. Pinto, in Mr. Pinto's first day of cross-examination.

title: Attica Group Accuses State of Foot-Dragging on Reparations
description: A group of Attica prison employees who survived the 1971 uprising will release a report on Thursday that accuses Gov. George E. Pataki and other state officials of not acting quickly enough to investigate their demands for compensation.

title: Hey, Hasn't My Computer Heard You Somewhere Before?
description: HELEN of Troy's face may have launched a thousand ships, but some faces have launched at least that many awkward silences. For a piece of information that requires so little memory, a forgotten name can create a world of anxiety.

title: Reponses to Warning on Terror Fall Between Fear and Fatalism
description: Lynn Smith dashed off a letter to her two small children, just in case: ''Mommy's with God now,'' it says. Then she dashed off to the Home Depot here for supplies to stock the safe room where she says she hopes her family will be able to ride out a terrorist attack.

title: Instead of Mah-Jongg, Marching on Albany
description: The social calendar for elderly residents of Co-op Village, a sprawling apartment complex on the Lower East Side, is packed with a variety of classes in tai chi, knitting, jewelry-making and even Jewish history.

title: Jets' Cowart Open to Restructuring Contract
description: The Jets have asked linebacker Sam Cowart to restructure his contract, which includes a $3.5 million bonus due Cowart on March 1 if the team picks up an option that triggers another five years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARFIELD, NEWELL
description: GARFIELD-Newell. 79. Died Wednesday in Maine. Yale 1945 W. Great-grandson of J.A. Garfield, 20th US President. Newell was a consultant in NYC and lived in the Bahamas and Maine. A memorial will be in July. Email: elizagarfield@attbi.com

title: NASA Engineer Warned of Dire Effects of Shuttle Liftoff Damage
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 12  Two days before the Columbia broke apart, a NASA safety engineer warned of the possibility of "catastrophic" consequences if damage from the foam insulation that struck the shuttle in liftoff allowed the heat of re-entry to penetrate the wheel well and burst the shuttle's tires.

title: Scientists Seek Clues in Solar Storm That Enveloped Shuttle on Its Way Toward Earth
description: A storm of particles and radiation from the Sun, a kind of disturbance that has disabled or destroyed satellites on dozens of occasions, crossed the path of the space shuttle Columbia just as it was making its descent to Earth, scientists said yesterday.

title: Bell Sets Sights on Third Base
description: Jay Bell had begun flying lessons near his home in Phoenix when Mets General Manager Steve Phillips left a phone message in the past two weeks expressing interest in having him play for the Mets.

title: Primedia Reports Narrower Loss
description: Primedia Inc., the publisher of 250 magazines, said yesterday that a change in accounting rules and rising magazine sales helped the company post a narrower loss in the fourth quarter.

title: Pataki's Poll Numbers Drop as Budget Shrinks
description: With New York facing a gigantic budget shortfall and the economy still staggering, the percentage of voters who approve of how Gov. George E. Pataki is handling his job has fallen to the lowest level in seven years, according to a statewide poll by Quinnipiac University.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTER, HAROLD
description: ALTER-Harold. On February 10, 2003. Beloved husband of the late Elsie. Father of Henry and Leslie Alter, Rosalind and Ronald Freeman. Brother of Belle Rosenberg. Grandfather of Michael and Margherita, Leigh, Michele and James, and Eric. Services today 11:15AM at ''Gutterman's'' (Parkside Building), 98-60 Queens Boulevard, Rego Park, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTMANN, RUTH P.
description: HARTMANN-Ruth P., 86 years, died on February 12, 2003 at her home. Wife of the late Wayne J. Hartmann. Mother of Ann Miller, Elizabeth Hartmann, D.V.M. and Wayne Hartmann, Jr. ''Jud''. Funeral service at St. Matthew's Church, Bedford, NY on Saturday, February 15, 2:30PM. Burial at St. Matthew's Cemetery.

title: Ziccardi Wins Four Accounts
description: Ziccardi Partners Frierson Mee in New York has been awarded accounts by four clients, with billings estimated at $13 million to $15 million.

title: Explicit Sex Education Is Opposed by Most Parents in Survey
description: Most parents want schools to teach their children the ABC's of sex education but disapprove of the more explicit guidance commonly used in sex-education classes, according to a survey released here today by a coalition of conservative groups.

title: A Cash Infusion for Digital Archives
description: IN the strongest signal to date of its commitment to preserving the nation's digital legacy, Congress has set aside $100 million for the Library of Congress to carry out a plan for collecting and preserving digital information, including images, CD's, Web pages and electronic journals.

title: Day Care Workers Stage a Daylong Strike Over Raises
description: Nearly 7,000 day care workers staged a one-day strike yesterday, protesting Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's demand that they accept lower raises than those that most municipal employees received.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIMPFHEIMER, RUTH
description: WIMPFHEIMER-Ruth. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Henry Wimpfheimer and his children, Michael Wimpfheimer and Vivian Neiss, on the loss of their beloved wife and mother. We will always remember and cherish Ruth's leadership as a Founder and President of the Medical Center's Women's Jr. League. Likewise, we greatly value Henry's exceptional efforts to introduce and motivate individuals in the community to support the life-saving work of Shaare Zedek. May the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem

title: National Briefing: South
description: MISSISSIPPI: MOVE TOWARD SMOKING BAN The Senate voted overwhelming to prohibit smoking in most buildings that are open to the public, including office buildings, restaurants, retail stores, and sporting arenas. The legislation, which still requires approval in the House of Representatives, would exempt private homes, bars and casinos. (NYT)

title: Woman to Coach Men, for a Game
description: As Teresa Phillips sees it, she will make only inadvertent history tonight when she becomes the first woman to coach a major college men's basketball team.

title: For the Fit or the Flabby, A Digital Conscience
description: IN the dead of a long, cold winter, many people like to think ahead to the pleasures of summer. If you are one of those people, and you dream of losing some weight to show off that swimsuit or those bright summer clothes, now is the time to start. Naturally, there are digital tools that can help. Here are some popular ways to use the Web, a hand-held organizer or PC software to keep track of what you are eating, and how you are burning it off.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: PEUGEOT' S PROFIT SLIPS Europe's second-biggest auto maker, Peugeot Citroen, said profit for 2002 fell 1 percent but that it expected to increase car sales about 2.5 percent, to 3.35 million units, in 2003. Second-half net income rose 6.2 percent, to 705 million euros ($756.8 million), from 664 million euros in the period a year earlier, helped by the sales of small cars. The Peugeot 206 car, for example, has become the best-selling car in Europe, overtaking the Volkswagen Golf. The chief executive of Peugeot, Jean-Martin Folz, warned that he expected the European auto market to shrink about 2 percent next year. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: A Storm in the Heavens
description: A storm of particles and radiation from the sun crossed the path of the space shuttle Columbia just as it was making its descent. Page A38.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nokia To Cut Jobs At Networks Unit
description: The mobile phone maker Nokia said it would cut 550 of the 18,500 jobs at its networks division, laying off workers in Britain, Finland, Sweden and the United States. The Finnish company said it would also close research operations in California and Sweden. The networks division has lost about $350 million in the last six months as phone companies hit by the global economic slowdown cut back on orders for wireless network equipment. Nokia shares fell 32 cents, or 2.3 percent, to $13.77. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: The Mood? In a Word, Anxiety
description: To the Editor:

description: SHAIN-Leah. On February 11, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Sam. May their love endure forever. Loving sister of Sarah Magalnick. Dear aunt of Jerome, Jo-Ellen and Jedna Magalnick and many nieces, nephews and dear friends. Services Thursday 1PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Any donations in her memory may be made in the name of Sam Shain to the Alzheimer's Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RASHBAUM, MAURICE
description: RASHBAUM-Maurice. February 11, 2003. Son of Maurice and Clem, brother of William. Memorial service tentatively planned for May 2, 2003 at the John Jay College.

title: Doctor Says Surgery to Remove Senator's Prostate Is Successful
description: Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts had his cancerous prostate removed this morning at a hospital in Baltimore.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: I.B.M. WINS $2 BILLION CONTRACT FROM VISTEON I.B.M., the world's largest seller of computer services, won a 10-year, $2 billion contract yesterday from the Visteon Corporation, the maker of car and truck interiors, to manage computer networks. I.B.M.'s services will include maintaining mainframe computers, running help desks and overseeing software programs and upgrades. An unspecified number of Visteon workers will join I.B.M., said Kelli Gail, an I.B.M. spokeswoman. The Visteon contract is the second automotive deal that I.B.M. has won in the last week. I.B.M. and Dassault Systemes S.A. of France won vehicle-design software and services contracts from Ford on Feb. 6. Electronic Data Systems had been Ford's main supplier of such programs. Visteon, based in Dearborn, Mich., is trying to reduce costs and to shed some units including its automotive seat and glass businesses. I.B.M. shares fell 89 cents, to $76.50. They had dropped 28 percent in the last year. Visteon fell 11 cents, to $6.59.  (Bloomberg News)

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: ANOTHER BANK LOSS A leading Japanese bank, Resona Holdings, has followed other large banking groups in announcing deeper losses, more job cuts and plans to raise more capital. Resona said it expected to lose 185 billion yen ($1.5 billion) for the year that ends March 31. The group will also cut 4,450 jobs, or 21 percent of its work force, by 2007. To help cover the cost of writing off its nonperforming loans, Resona hopes to raise 100 billion yen from Credit Agricole of France and Bank of East Asia of Hong Kong. The Resona holding company includes Daiwa Bank, Asahi Bank and local lenders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANNON, ANNA MASCOLO, M.D.
description: GANNON - Anna Mascolo, M.D., 66, of New York City and Shelter Island, died at home on February 11, 2003, after a prolonged illness. A graduate of Brooklyn College and the Women's Medical College of Pennsylvania. Dr. Mascolo, an internist, served as Vice President at Long Island College Hospital and as the Medical Director for the ILGWU. She was also associated with Downstate, Columbia and Mt. Sinai Medical Schools. She is survived by her husband Frederic L. Gannon, M.D., her four children Anna Gannon, Lisa Gannon, Andrea Gannon Brereton and Ted Gannon, seven grandchildren and her sister Vivian Mahon. Family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. on Wednesday 2-5 and 7-10 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Thursday 9:30 AM at St. Ignatius Loyola R. C. Church. Interment Friday at Our Lady of the Isle Cemetery, Shelter Island. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Loyola School, 980 Park Avenue, NY 10028 or Bishop Loughlin H.S., 257 Claremont Ave., Brooklyn, NY 11238.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Guatemala: 6 Killed In Prison Riot
description: A soldier jailed for the 1998 killing of a bishop who campaign for human rights was decapitated during a prison riot in which six inmates were killed. The authorities are unsure what set off the clash between inmates in a capital prison, but one early report said it stemmed from complaints that some inmates had smuggled in guns. Another report suggested that it erupted over animosity toward several officers who were implicated in the killing of Bishop Juan Gerardi. Obdulio Villanueva, a former soldier who was convicted in that killing, was among the inmates killed during the uprising. David Gonzalez (NYT)

description: Riverside Symphony

description: * IPromotions, Seattle, completed a management buyout from 24/7 Real Media, New York, which will retain a minority stake in iPromotions, an online marketing and promotions agency. Financial terms were not disclosed.

description: KESSLER-Walter. Age 91; died on February 9, leaving behind his loving wife, Dita; his brother, Ernie; cousin Trude, and their families.

description: Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain and Prime Minister Bertie Ahern of Ireland jointly met with the leaders of the major Northern Ireland political parties at Hillsborough Castle outside Belfast today in an effort to break a deadlock over implementing a peace accord there.

title: Solving a City's Problems One Solar Panel at a Time
description: The Case Study Housing program after World War II explored ways to mass-produce housing using industrial materials like steel beams, concrete and plate glass. Now some architects are again trying to apply new technology to Los Angeles's housing problems. In downtown Santa Monica, a complex called Colorado Court, left, offers 44 low-cost apartments that rely heavily on solar power.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLACH, BEN
description: WALLACH-Ben, 91. On February 11, 2003. Former NY teacher/Catskills maven. Son, George 310-278-4574.

title: Iraq Debate Intensifies Within European Union and NATO
description: PARIS, Feb. 13  The deep divide over Iraq threatened to engulf the European Union as well as the North Atlantic alliance today after Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain demanded that a European Union summit meeting next week support a war, if necessary to uphold the authority of the United Nations.

title: INSIDE
description: Korea's Nuclear Tactics

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Machinery Orders Rise
description: Orders for new machinery grew 5.2 percent in December from November, defying forecasts for a small decline. Still, machinery orders, a proxy for corporate capital investment, suffered their worst year on record in 2002 and orders are expected to continue that slide in the January-March quarter. Capital spending makes up about 15 percent of Japan's economy and the 12 percent decline in machinery orders last year suggests that companies believe that the economy will not pick up steam this year. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: A Former Indonesian Dissident Makes His Peace With America
description: When the State Department's official history of Indonesia for the stormy years of 1964 to 1968 was released, Joesoef Isak asked a group of students to download it from the Internet and assigned them a quick translation into Indonesian of its more than 600 pages.

title: A Web Site in India That Revealed Graft Becomes a Target
description: Nearly two years ago, Tehelka, which means sensation in Hindi, caused one. Nine months after its founding, the news Web site burst forth with videotape showing politicians, bureaucrats, military officers and middlemen seeking and taking bribes from arms dealers.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: White House Disagrees With Fed Chief on Tax Cuts

description: To the Editor:

title: Midcentury Modern For the Feathered Set And Those Who Watch
description: Even the birds seem to like midcentury modern. This earthenware birdhouse ($75), whose design dates from the late 1950's, is now being stocked at Ten10, a store in the Silver Lake area. Each birdhouse is hand-thrown, with one or two holes, in sand, terra cotta or brown. (The punched-out pieces are attached to the cord for decoration.) Joanna Nadeau, an owner of Ten10, said she added the birdhouses to her vintage and custom lines because ''when they are hung outside they look great in a cluster, like little mud huts, a nice accent to a Spanish or modern house.'' Ten10 is at 1716 Silver Lake Boulevard; (323) 663-3603.

title: China Asserts It Has Worked to End Nuclear Crisis
description: In recent weeks, President Bush and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell have complained loudly that China should be doing more to defuse the nuclear crisis in North Korea, China's reclusive neighbor and closest ally.

title: Barrick Gold Fires Its Chief As Stock Price and Profits Lag
description: Barrick Gold, one of the world's largest gold producers, dismissed its chief executive today over missed profit targets and the company's languishing stock price.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ECKMAN, PATRICK
description: ECKMAN-Patrick, 49. On February 9. We'll long remember his friendship, tenacious intellect and spirit, extraordinary culinary talents, and exemplary service to NYC, HUD and affordable housing. Our sincere condolences to Renee, Lucas, Anna, Katrina and family. The City Friends

title: Sports of The Times; Matsui Beat Baffles Some, Irks Others
description: AS a self-appointed member of the 50-plus-person Japanese news media contingent yesterday at the Yankees' minor league complex, I found myself taking exception to Joe Torre's referring to our coverage of Hideki Matsui as a circus, and the insinuation by our American counterparts that the important public service we do here is tantamount to watching grass grow.

title: A Midwinter Brain Dump
description: It finally happened: Last night, at 9:31 pm, my home office became officially non-navigable. As I set down a final computer magazine on top of the last remaining stack, wedged between the two computer boxes that had flanked the final egress from my overpacked office, I finally boxed myself in completely. This time, no amount of excuses would permit me to avoid cleaning the place up.

title: Jones Says He Is Ready to Move Up
description: As a boxer of distinction, Roy Jones Jr. approaches his fights with a simple credo: kill or be killed, and the message resonates through the 80-acre ranch he owns in this town 19 miles north of Pensacola in the Florida Panhandle.

title: Shares Post Decline In Initial Offering Of an Auto Insurer
description: Shares in the Infinity Property and Casualty Corporation, the automobile insurance unit of the American Financial Group, fell yesterday, a day after being sold in a $198.1 million initial public offering, the first in the United States this year.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Defending The Right To Curse In Foreign Tongues
description: Russia's upper house of Parliament, the Federation Council, overwhelmingly rejected legislation yesterday that would have made Russian the country's official language and banned the use of foreign words and vulgarities. The lower house, the Duma, declared last week that ''the use of colloquial, disparaging or obscene words and expressions, as well as foreign words having Russian equivalents in common use, is inadmissible.'' Several senators criticized the legislation as hasty and impractical, saying in particular that foreign words, not to mention obscenities, regularly pepper Russian discourse. Sergei M. Mironov, the council's speaker, noted that the Constitution itself contained 30 words with foreign roots. The two houses will now form a commission to consider compromise legislation. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: School Defibrillators
description: The City Council has scheduled a public hearing on requiring heart defibrillators in school and other public places. Council Hearing Room, 14th floor, 250 Broadway, Manhattan, 1 p.m. Information: (212) 768-4344.

title: Kids of New York
description: This is what I remember: they were a boy and a girl and they traveled in a fast crowd, a rich crowd, though she was richer than he was, and they went to a bar and afterward to the park and the boy strangled the girl. It was 1986, the New York of Bernhard Goetz and Donald Trump and Keith Hernandez.

title: Giants Make Offer to Petitgout
description: Giants executives are early in their contract negotiations with their primary free agent, left tackle Luke Petitgout. According to a person familiar with the discussions, the Giants have made an initial proposal of a five-year contract with a signing bonus of about $6 million and annual salaries of about $3 million to $3.5 million.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: The High Road Goes Through
description: Ireland's High Court ruled against protesters who sought a legal injunction that would have prevented construction crews for Dublin's long-delayed ''ring road'' highway from paving over nearby Carrickmines Castle. The castle, a 13th- century fortress that has been reduced to ditches, walls and piles of stones, became a popular cause last year for Irish archaeologists and heritage campaigners, who physically blocked bulldozers from entering the site on several occasions. An Irish state anticorruption inquiry is investigating whether the planning process which permitted the highway's route to go over the castle was improperly influenced by companies that owned the land. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: As Blix Report Nears, Debate Swirls on Iraqi Weapons
description: As United Nations inspectors prepare to present a pivotal briefing on Friday about the state of Saddam Hussein's weapons programs to a Security Council divided by conflicting agendas, the Iraqi leader's military capabilities remain a matter of heated debate.

title: Global Talks On Farming Begin Friday
description: Trade ministers from two dozen of the world's largest economies will meet in Tokyo this weekend to discuss guidelines for the reduction of agricultural tariffs and other measures, part of a round of talks the World Trade Organization began last year in Doha, Qatar.

title: G.M. PLANS TO SELL 150,000 CARS FROM KOREAN VENTURE
description: General Motors said yesterday that it planned North American sales next year of as many as 150,000 cars from its venture in South Korea. The cars, built by the GM Daewoo Auto and Technology Company, will be sold primarily under the Chevrolet name, said John Smith, the G.M. group vice president for sales and marketing. General Motors introduced one GM Daewoo model, the 2004 Chevrolet Aveo small car, at the Chicago Auto Show yesterday. The Aveo has a starting price of about $10,000.

title: No Need to Touch That Dial For Emergency Weather News
description: When severe weather conditions or other natural disasters may be imminent, many Americans rely on special radios that automatically sound an alarm and speak an alert. That technology, which relies on a service of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, will soon be available in a new version for televisions as well.

title: Rockville Centre Bishop Rebuts Grand Jury Report
description: Bishop William F. Murphy of Rockville Centre responded yesterday to a scathing grand jury report about his diocese's handling of clerical sex abuse on Long Island with an impassioned and sometimes personal defense.

title: Stephanie Reinhart Service
description: ''A Celebration of Stephanie Reinhart'' will be held on Friday at 3 p.m. at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street). The memorial service, which is open to the public, will pay tribute to Ms. Reinhart, a co-director with her husband, Charles, of the American Dance Festival. She died on Sept. 23 of leukemia. Members of several modern-dance companies and Ariane Reinhart, the Reinharts' daughter and a singer and actress, will perform and there will be reminiscences by speakers, including Joan E. Spero, president of the Doris Duke Charitable Foundation. Information is available from (718) 850-2488.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: HARTFORD: JUNK-FOOD LIMITS URGED State lawmakers are considering a ban on junk food from school vending machines. Food sold from the machines would be limited to snacks and drinks that meet federal nutrition standards. Representative Mary M. Mushinsky, a Democrat and the chairwoman of the Select Committee on Children, said the bill was part of an effort to reduce childhood obesity. Senator Catherine W. Cook, the committee's ranking Senate Republican, said she was not convinced that the state should regulate children's diets. "I concur there are a lot of things we as the Legislature can do to help parents raise kids," she said, "but we are not parents." (AP)

title: U.S. Faults Safety Study On Indian Pt.
description: The chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission yesterday criticized a state-commissioned report on emergency planning at the Indian Point nuclear power plant in Westchester County for possibly giving ''undue weight'' to the impact of a terrorist attack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOBART, RUTH
description: KOBART-Ruth. Singer and actress, who performed on Broadway, opera, theatre, films and TV, died December 14, 2002 in San Francisco. Early on, she sang mezzo soprano roles with The Lemonade, NBC, NYC Operas. On Broadway, her performance in ''A Funny Thing Happened On The Way To The Forum'' was Tony-nominated. She also played Miss Jones in both the Broadway musical and film of ''How To Success In Business Without Even Trying.'' A founding member of San Francisco's American Conservatory Theatre, she worked for many years in the California theatre, film and TV community. She is survived by a brother, Howard, of Minneapolis, and nieces and nephews. A public memorial will be held at The Geary Theatre in San Francisco on Sunday, March 9, 2003 at 7 P.M.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Huntington: Bill To Ban Ephedra Advances
description: The Suffolk County Legislature has passed a bill banning the sale of ephedra, an herbal dietary supplement that supporters say is valuable for weight loss and body building but that the Food and Drug Administration says is implicated in heart attacks and strokes. The Legislature's 12-to-5 vote on Tuesday night followed six months of often-heated debate and opposition by local ephedra manufacturers and distributors. The supplement, whose active ingredient, ephedrine, stimulates the central nervous system, is also banned by the International Olympic Committee. County Executive Robert J. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, JILL WARREN
description: GREENBERG-Jill Warren (Mary Audrey Rochlen). Beloved mother of Peter Greenberg and Dr. Karen Greenberg Rudman. Wife of the late Dr. Sidney Greenberg. Sister of Kendis, David, Hartwell, Gail and the late Donald Rochlen and a longtime devoted friend of Lucille Fore, died on February 7, 2003, at her home in Manhattan. The daughter of journalist and aviation industry pioneer A.M. Rochlen, she was born July 4, 1915 in Los Angeles. She was an actress, singer, a magazine and newspaper journalist, and for many years a real estate broker in Manhattan and Fire Island, NY. She had boundless energy and an extraordinary spirit that touched and enriched countless lives. A selfless woman devoted to her siblings and her children, her legacy is a life eternally distinguished by not merely being interesting-for she was a great story teller and philosopher-but of being interested in the stories and philosophies of everyone she ever met. She is survived by her son, daughter, and son-in-law Richard Rudman. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, February 15, 12 noon at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In honor and celebration of the life of Jill Warren Greenberg, please send donations to the Union Settlement Association, 237 E. 104 St. NY, NY 10029 attention Laura Johnson. We will love her always.

Unlike rivals that are selling assets to raise money to pay debt, Vodafone has continued expanding during the telecommunications slump by increasing its stakes in regional operators. title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: I.B.M. Wins $2 Billion Contract From Visteon
description: I.B.M., the world's largest seller of computer services, won a 10-year, $2 billion contract yesterday from the Visteon Corporation, the maker of car and truck interiors, to manage computer networks. I.B.M.'s services will include maintaining mainframe computers, running help desks and overseeing software programs and upgrades. An unspecified number of Visteon workers will join I.B.M., said Kelli Gail, an I.B.M. spokeswoman. The Visteon contract is the second automotive deal that I.B.M. has won in the last week. I.B.M. and Dassault Systemes S.A. of France won vehicle-design software and services contracts from Ford on Feb. 6. Electronic Data Systems had been Ford's main supplier of such programs. Visteon, based in Dearborn, Mich., is trying to reduce costs and to shed some units including its automotive seat and glass businesses. I.B.M. shares fell 89 cents, to $76.50. They had dropped 28 percent in the last year. Visteon fell 11 cents, to $6.59.

Mark Sanford has accepted a donation of grits and other corn and wheat products from Adluh Flour, a local milling company. ''At least we've got breakfast covered,'' said Mr. Sanford, who is considering closing the mansion to the public until July. State tax revenues have been in free-fall, shrinking last year for the first time since 1955. On Tuesday, state spending was reduced 3.7 percent, the second cut this year, after a 4.5 percent cut in December.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: No Primary For Peronists, Judge Says
description: In a blow to former President Carlos Menem's hopes of returning to power, a judge has ruled that the Peronist party, of which he is a member, is not required to hold a primary this month to choose a single candidate for president in an election scheduled for Apr. 27. The decision paves the way for the Peronists to offer three separate candidates in the April balloting and is seen as damaging Mr. Menem's prospects for getting enough votes to move on to a determining runoff round in mid-May. title: ROADWAY CHIEF TO STEP DOWN; PRESIDENT TO SUCCEED HIM
description: The Roadway Corporation, the trucking company, said its chief executive, Michael Wickham, would step down next month and be replaced by its president, James Staley. Mr. Wickham is retiring after 35 years with the company and will remain chairman, a Roadway spokesman said. Mr. Staley heads Roadway's long-haul trucking unit, which last year accounted for 93 percent of the company's $3 billion in sales. Mr. Wickham has been chief executive since 1996. Roadway has been trying to extend its business beyond long-haul routes that take at least two days to complete.

title: By Frank Lloyd Wright, And Better Than New
description: KATIE BUEHLER, who radiates elegance at age 87 in pearls and a pink Chanel jacket, is not what she calls a ''crying person.'' But when fire ravages a lifelong love -- in this case a Frank Lloyd Wright house commissioned by Mrs. Buehler and her husband, Maynard, in 1948 -- brave intentions can feel suddenly remote. ''It was not one of my better days,'' she recalled with characteristic understatement, sipping Champagne from a crystal goblet.

title: STATE STREET TO CLOSE 2 OFFICES AND CUT 1,000 JOBS
description: The State Street Corporation, which last month completed its largest acquisition by adding the record-keeping and securities-lending businesses of Deutsche Bank, said it would close two offices in the United States and eliminate about 1,000 jobs. Employees will be laid off starting in June over a 12- to 18-month period, State Street said. Deutsche Bank offices in Nashville and Jersey City will be shut in the third quarter of 2004, and the customer-service operations will be moved to a new location in New York. The company said the work force reduction was part of a plan to save $125 million to $150 million.

title: Scrawl To Screen, With a Pen
description: A LAPTOP may make a powerful portable office, but as a pure note-taking device, it is not universally considered an improvement over handwriting. In meetings, the laptop's screen becomes a wall that psychologically isolates you from the group. For people who don't touch-type, handwriting is faster, too. And then there's the clicking of the keys -- a distinct liability when it comes to note-taking in, say, church.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Official Confirmed Dead In Plane Crash
description: Rescuers found the body of Colombia's social welfare minister, Juan Luis Londoo, 44, and those of four others who were killed when the small plane in which they were traveling crashed in the mountains of southeastern Colombia on Feb. 6. The small private plane, carrying Mr. Londoo, two aides, a bodyguard and the pilot, slammed into a fog-covered Andean peak shortly after takeoff. Rescuers faced difficult conditions and the presence of leftist rebels, who last week fired upon a helicopter that had been trying to search for the wreckage. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Ubiquitous Yet Little Used, the Diskette Hangs On

Yet like a lingering party guest who hasn't realized that it's time to go home, it somehow holds on as a form of removable storage.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Peugeot's Profit Slips
description: Europe's second-biggest auto maker, Peugeot Citron, said profit for 2002 fell 1 percent but that it expected to increase car sales about 2.5 percent, to 3.35 million units, in 2003. Second-half net income rose 6.2 percent, to 705 million euros ($756.8 million), from 664 million euros in the period a year earlier, helped by the sales of small cars. The Peugeot 206 car, for example, has become the best-selling car in Europe, overtaking the Volkswagen Golf. The chief executive of Peugeot, Jean-Martin Folz, warned that he expected the European auto market to shrink about 2 percent next year. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Keep Talking About Miguel Estrada

Democrats who have vowed to filibuster the nomination are not engaging in ''shameful politics,'' as the president has put it, nor are they anti-Latino, as Republicans have cynically charged. They are insisting that the White House respect the Senate's role in confirming judicial nominees.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Tobacco Sales Fall
description: Sales of cigarettes by Japan Tobacco fell 4.9 percent in the October-December period, the 11th consecutive quarterly decline. Japan Tobacco, formerly a government monopoly, controls 73 percent of the Japanese market. With the economy slowing and tax increases leading to price rises, sales in the quarter fell to 766 billion yen ($6.3 billion). Japan Tobacco is the world's third-largest manufacturer of cigarettes and owns the Camel, Winston and Mild Seven brands in Japan. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: 13-Year-Old Can Play for U.S.
description: Freddy Adu became eligible to play for the United States under-23 soccer team yesterday after he received a passport in Potomac, Md., following the granting of citizenship to his mother, Emilia, according to Jim Moorhouse, a U.S. Soccer spokesman.

title: Strong Franc Skews Swiss Profit Picture
description: Switzerland's biggest companies are discovering the pain of being based in a country with a strong, stable currency as they report their annual performance for 2002.

title: When a Too-Rosy Affair Takes an Unlikely Turn
description: Laetitia Colombani's devious romantic thriller ''He Loves Me, He Loves Me Not'' uses the iconographic radiance of its pixielike star, Audrey Tautou, as a springboard for playing a diabolical narrative game. Ms. Tautou, with her wistful crooked-toothed smile and doe eyes, became a symbol of Parisian-style toujours l'amour in ''Amlie,'' that vertiginous, wildly popular ode to romantic pie in the sky in the City of Light. And during the first half hour of ''He Loves Me, He Loves Me Not,'' which is set in Bordeaux, Ms. Tautou's character, a talented painter sweetly named Anglique, suggests a frilly, sugar-coated caricature of her signature role.

title: MCKESSON SAYS IT IS PART OF A FEDERAL INVESTIGATION
description: McKesson, the drug wholesaler, said yesterday that it was the subject of an industrywide federal investigation into the sale of nutritional products. In a report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, McKesson said the United States attorney for the Southern District of Illinois was conducting the investigation of the company and two employees. The investigation focuses on the sale and marketing of nutritional products used to feed bedridden nursing home patients, Larry Kurtz, a company spokesman, said. The employees were not named, but Mr. Kurtz said they were sales representatives for a subsidiary, McKesson Medical-Surgical Solutions. McKesson said it was cooperating with the investigation and was responding to a subpoena.

title: Arafat to Name Prime Minister, a U.S. Demand
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank, Feb. 14  Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, announced today that he would appoint a prime minister, in a step toward meeting a central demand of the Bush administration for a resumption of the peace process.

title: Chambers Stays Silent as He Is Freed From Upstate Prison
description: Robert E. Chambers Jr., whose "preppie murder" case brought him national attention, walked out of the Auburn Correctional Facility in upstate New York this morning after serving his full 15-year maximum sentence for killing an 18-year-old woman in Central Park in 1986.

title: New Video Releases
description: Sweet Home Alabama

title: National Briefing: Rockies
description: UTAH: LAKE POWELL AT LOW LEVEL Lake Powell is at its lowest level in 30 years, a result of low snowmelt and heavy demand from three states that use it for drinking water. The lake, a 252-square-mile body created by the the Glen Canyon Dam on the Arizona-Utah border, is down 87 feet from its highest level. When full, the water averages 560 deep. The last time levels were so low was in 1973, when the reservoir filled. The water will dip an additional five feet before late March, when the snow starts to run off, said the Bureau of Reclamation, which manages the reservoir. (AP)

title: Scenes of Colonial Africa With Racist Overtones
description: ''In and Out of Focus: Images From Central Africa, 1885-1960,'' at the National Museum of African Art here, is the equivalent of a precision-made machine: the material is top-flight; the workmanship superb; the packaging smooth, immaculate, right to the point.

title: Ban on Internet Cigarette Sales Is Upheld
description: Reversing a lower court ruling, a federal appeals panel yesterday upheld a New York State ban on Internet and mail-order cigarette sales.

title: Kemmons Wilson, 90, Dies; Was Holiday Inn Founder
description: Kemmons Wilson -- who was so angered by the shabby lodgings he encountered on a family vacation in 1951 that he vowed to start a motel chain, a decision that led to Holiday Inn -- died on Wednesday at his home in Memphis. He was 90.

description: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 14 - The chief United Nations weapons inspectors today reported some progress in Iraq, and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell faced deep resistance to his call for a Security Council decision to authorize military force.

description: The Senate remained deadlocked tonight over a filibuster by Democrats against a Bush administration appeals court nominee as its members prepared for their midwinter recess.

description: The Newspaper National Network in New York, a sales and marketing division of the Newspaper Association of America, is hiring Jason E. Klein, a longtime magazine advertising sales executive, as president and chief executive, effective on Feb. 24.

title: Advertisers decide it's time for 'reality' -- at least on television.
description: BLUE-CHIP advertisers are beginning to shed their disdain for the reality television genre, as the soaring popularity of these shows -- particularly among young consumers -- has persuaded many to embrace Robin Williams's motto: ''reality . . . what a concept.''

title: Playing Desert Solitaire With a Friend
description: Gus Van Sant's bleak, minimalist film ''Gerry'' is such a radical about-face from his flagrantly commercial movies like ''Finding Forrester'' and ''Good Will Hunting'' that it feels like a self-mortifying act of contrition. Having succumbed to the lure of big bad Hollywood and made a bundle, he appears to be purging himself with a project that he has described as a homage to the austere Hungarian filmmaker Bela Tarr.

title: Insurance Price Rate Determined for Cities At Risk of Terrorism
description: The Insurance Services Office, which sets guidelines for insurance pricing across the country, said yesterday that it had agreed on benchmark rates for terrorism coverage in New York and Washington, regarded by the agency as cities at the greatest risk of an attack, along with Chicago and San Francisco.

title: A Warning on Iraq, From a Friend
description: Reading the papers from both sides of the Atlantic, I sometimes wonder whether the impending war is not between France and the United States. I would like to strongly reaffirm what, in the heart of the French people, is a longstanding reality: the friendship between France and America began in the early days of your fight for independence and has endured throughout the centuries.

title: Prospects for Economy Mixed Ahead of Possible Iraq War
description: The American economy remains stuck in a choppy rut, statistics released today from various sources suggest. And as Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman, told Congress earlier this week, conditions are likely to remain much as they are now until the uncertainty surrounding a possible war with Iraq is at least temporarily removed.

The bill, amended to include the translation, would require the donated plaques to be visible from 20 feet and allows suits if the act is not enforced. Mindy Sink (NYT)

description: A black World War I private who fought off German soldiers and saved a comrade in 1918 was posthumously awarded the Distinguished Service Cross today, eight years after a coalition of New York veterans' groups, military organizations, historians and politicians began seeking recognition for him.
