description: Wall Street banks, acting on the advice of leading lawyers and accounting firms, helped Enron devise shelters that let the company operate tax-free for years while exaggerating its reported profits by billions, the Senate Finance Committee was told today.

title: Treasury Secretary Hits the Road to Promote Administration's Tax Cut Proposal
description: For a while today, John W. Snow sounded less like the secretary of the Treasury and more like an evangelist.

title: Coming Together In Time of Remorse
description: The people in East Texas feel lucky. Or, more specifically, blessed. Thousands of pieces of flaming wreckage rained down on them on Feb. 1 when the space shuttle Columbia ripped apart in the upper reaches of the atmosphere. A chunk the size of a truck axle landed in downtown Nacogdoches. Another piece fell on the sheriff's front lawn.

title: Espada Runs Again in Election for a Bronx Council Seat
description: Sprinting up a staircase to his campaign headquarters on a recent afternoon, Pedro Espada Jr. seemed energized by the prospect of spending the next five hours, well into darkness, campaigning door to door in the Soundview neighborhood of the Bronx.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: CORNING TO SHUT PHOTONICS PLANT IN CALIFORNIA Corning Inc. said yesterday that it would shut a photonics technology plant in Fountain Valley, Calif., and eliminate about 190 jobs. In an attempt to rebound from a sharp slowdown in the telecommunications industry, the company is taking aim at a division that makes components designed to increase or redirect transmission of data traveling long distances at high speeds through fiber optic lines. Corning said that by mid-2003 it would discontinue wavelength-switch and wavelength-blocker products made at the California factory. The shutdown will save the company $20 million to $30 million before taxes in the first and second quarters. In January, the company, the world's biggest maker of optical fiber and cable, posted a fourth-quarter loss of $709 million, its seventh quarterly loss in a row. Shares of Corning rose 10 cents, to $5.05, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. (AP)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Girl Shot Dead In Harlem
description: A 16-year-old girl was killed and three other people were wounded in Harlem yesterday, the police said. About 5:47 p.m., the girl and a 17-year-old boy were approached by two men in front of 529 West 135th Street, between Amsterdam and Broadway, the police said. An argument ensued, possibly regarding the ex-boyfriend of the young woman, said Detective Kevin Czartoryski. One of the two men pulled a gun and began firing at least 17 rounds, and the girl was hit once in the back, the authorities said. The boy she was with was shot in the legs. Four men were walking nearby, and two of them were grazed by bullets, a 23-year-old being hit in the head, and a 20-year-old in the side. The girl and two of the men were taken to St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, where she died. The 20-year-old man was taken to Harlem Hospital. The three men were in stable condition, the police said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Australia/New Zealand
description: AUSTRALIA: JOBLESS RATE FALLS Australia's economy unexpectedly added 111,000 jobs in January, the most in more than a decade, and the unemployment rate fell to 6.1 percent from 6.2 percent in December, the government announced. Officials said the figures underscored the economy's resilience at a time of global weakness, but some analysts said they might be the last good news for a while, as the worst drought in a century erodes growth. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Elusive Qaeda Connections
description: Nothing would make it easier for President Bush to overcome the nation's doubts about going to war with Iraq than proof that Saddam Hussein is in league with Osama bin Laden. Talk about an axis of evil! In truth, however, there is little hard evidence of such a connection, and the administration should stop peddling that line to the American people. There are legitimate reasons to confront Iraq. Imagining a full-blown Baghdad chapter of Al Qaeda is not one of them.

title: South Korea Has Big Plans For the Area Around Seoul
description: The sprawling urban region around South Korea's capital is determined to plunge ahead with ambitious plans to make itself a business hub for the Pacific Rim -- never mind that the tense and heavily militarized border with North Korea is just a long-range artillery shot away.

title: Antidotes at the Ready, Hospitals Give Doctors the Drill
description: In a scene repeated at hospitals throughout New York City, about 60 emergency room doctors from St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center filed into a first-floor conference room yesterday at 8 a.m. to think once more about the unthinkable.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Profit For Retailer
description: South Korea's second-largest department store operator, the Hyundai Department Store, reported a net profit for 2002 of 85.5 billion won ($71 million). Profits were up 1.6 percent from 2001, largely as a result of increased consumer spending, while sales totaled 1.75 trillion won, up 15 percent from the year before. Prospects for this year were cloudy, however, in view of declining consumer confidence, with Korean retailers reporting a 17 percent decline in sales in December. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Monarch Butterflies Alive and Well in Mexico
description: A little more than a year after the largest known die-off of monarch butterflies occurred in the mountains of Mexico, researchers say the monarchs that migrate there appear to have recovered to near normal population levels.

title: Networks Scramble for Anything Jackson
description: With his recording career in sharp decline, Michael Jackson may no longer be the king of pop, but he certainly is the king of sweeps.

title: Veracity of Olympic Committee's Tax Returns Questioned
description: The United States Olympic Committee has filed inconsistent and opaque tax returns with the Internal Revenue Service, according to a letter that the head of John Hancock Financial Services, a major Olympic sponsor, said the committee's chief executive, Lloyd Ward, had written him.

title: Old Trading Partners Are Concerned About Effects of the Split Over War
description: To celebrate its 100th anniversary, the American Chamber of Commerce in Germany gathered 1,000 business people last Tuesday at a Baroque palace on the banks of Rhine River in Wiesbaden near here for Champagne, canaps, and a rousing speech about German-American friendship, delivered by a local conservative leader, Roland Koch.

title: Klein Reveals How He Chose Top Schools
description: After weeks of public anticipation, Chancellor Joel I. Klein unveiled his formula for picking the roughly 200 New York City schools that will be exempt from the system's new mandatory curriculum. The formula is a complicated methodology, meant to ensure a mix of schools in rich and poor neighborhoods.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Briefs On University Admissions
description: More than 100 House Democrats signed a brief urging the United States Supreme Court to uphold the University of Michigan admissions policy, which gives a preference to members of racial and ethnic minorities. The brief, at odds with the Bush administration, says race remains a factor in American society and should be considered by institutions of higher education. The president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Charles M. Vest, said another brief would back the university. Stanford University, DuPont, I.B.M., the National Academy of Science, the National Academy of Engineering and the National Action Council on Minorities in Engineering, as well as M.I.T., will file that brief.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANGLESEY, ZOE
description: ANGLESEY-Zoe. Of Brooklyn, NY, passed away on February 12, 2003 surrounded by her family. Beloved mother, sister, grandmother and comrade. We mourn the loss of a committed writer, activist, teacher, critic and cook. A celebration of Zoe's life with jazz and poetry will be held at Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church, 85 South Oxford Street, Brooklyn on Sunday, February 16 at 4 PM.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: INDIANA: ARCTIC SNOW `ROLLERS' Winds across Indiana and Illinois whipped snow into balls, some as big as bales of hay, a phenomenon that mystified residents. Called "rollers" by meteorologists, the formations are usually found in the Arctic because they need the right combination of wind speed, temperature and snow condition. "It's the same sort of idea as when you make a snowman, but the wind is doing all the work," said Jason Puma, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Indianapolis. (AP)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGRAW, JAMES H. III.
description: McGRAW - James H. III. Passed away February 12, 1928. Loving husband of Allola McGraw. Father of Virginia M. Seaverns, James H. McGraw IV, W. Scott McGraw and David D. McGraw. Grandfather to eight grandchildren. Graduate of Deerfield Academy, Princeton University and MIT. Served in the U.S. Air Force. Business executive and private investor, as well as accomplished musician and songwriter. His passions in life were his family, his music and his Golden Retrievers. Resident of Hobe Sound, FL, Short Hills, N.J., and Lake Placid, N.Y. A memorial service will be held at Christ Memorial Chapel in Hobe Sound, FL on March 1, 2003 at 4PM. In addition, services will be held in Lake Placid, N.Y., April 12, where he will be laid to rest. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Humane Society of the Treasure Coast, 4100 S.W. Leighton Farm Avenue, Palm City, FL. 34990.

Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Blind Lawyer As Hero In Red
description: SOMETIMES playing a comic-book hero gives actors a chance to show suave, stylized moves. After stripping off their civvies, they emerge from the phone booth a star. Christopher Reeve gave a breezy, farcical charge to Superman and Clark Kent. As Batman and his alter ego, the wastrel playboy Bruce Wayne, Michael Keaton seemed to have a thousand things on his mind, most of them unpleasant. Hugh Jackman, Wolverine of ''X-Men,'' had a combative, compulsive snarl. He came to life when prodded to fight.

title: Chronicling History, And Finding a Role in It; Interviewers Shaping an Oral Account Are Entangled in the Stories of Sept. 11
description: About a year ago, 30 interviewers armed with tape-recorders and resolute curiosity fanned out across New York City, seeking true-life stories of 9/11. The 449 accounts they came back with, on more than 400 hours of tape, captured the horror, and sometimes, the spiritual transcendence of those days.

description: In the most detailed examination to date of how the Sept. 11 attacks are changing the face of law enforcement, a study found today that federal officials have sharply increased their prosecution of terrorism-related crimes, but often by bringing minor charges that have resulted in jail sentences of only a few months.

title: Police Are Focusing More On Protecting the Subways
description: In all the murky intelligence that led to the latest terrorism alert, New York City police officials have focused this week on the threats suggested to them by one word gleaned from communications among suspected terrorists: ''Underground.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: The Bronx: Bakery Strike Extends To 3 Warehouses
description: After being on strike for seven days against Stella D'Oro, the International Brotherhood of Teamsters decided yesterday to expand the strike to three warehouses in New England, seeking to increase pressure on the company's parent, Kraft-Nabisco. The strike, which began Feb. 6, has shut down the Stella D'Oro bakery in the Bronx and warehouses in Farmingdale, N.Y., and Carlstadt, N.J. Richard Volpe, the director of the union's bakery division, said Nabisco was trying to eliminate 50 jobs by merging Stella D'Oro's New York delivery routes with Nabisco's. The company said it was trying to eliminate needless duplication of drivers' jobs. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Big Protests Planned in Europe
description: LONDON, Feb. 14  From London to Paris to Berlin to Moscow, hundreds of thousands of protesters are set to march this weekend in what could be among Europe's biggest ever coordinated peace demonstrations. London's could be the most telling of all.

title: Maternity Leave At 65 Miles Per Hour
description: FIFTEEN hundred miles and 60 diaper changes into a trip around the country late last year, I pulled our Volvo station wagon into a gas station in Kondoka, S.D. The tank was almost full, but the baby had been wailing for the last 40 miles. My wife, Lisa, and I smiled lamely at each other and passed the baby back and forth from the front to the back seat, holding her warily aloft.

description: IF you're thinking of skipping ''Matisse Picasso'' at the Museum of Modern Art because you don't want to feel squeezed into a confined space like one of those Qin dynasty tomb sculptures, I'm sorry. That's not a good enough excuse. Ignore the world-weary know-it-alls who grouse about yet another Picasso exhibition or yet another Matisse exhibition, as if this were a burden rather than a gift, or who say the show's not perfect.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Bank Posts Gain
description: The Dutch banking concern ABN Amro reported a 2.1 percent increase in profit last year but refrained from making any specific forecasts for 2003, saying it could not predict what a possible war in Iraq might mean for its bottom line. ABN Amro reported a profit of 2.4 billion euros ($2.6 billion) last year, excluding extraordinary items, on revenue of 18.3 billion euros. The results were aided by a 23.4 percent increase in the United States, where a surge in mortgage refinancing contributed to a profit of 1.1 billion euros. In the United States, ABN Amro owns the LaSalle Bank of Chicago; Standard Federal of Troy, Mich.; and the ABN Amro Mortgage Group. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the conclusion by arms experts that an Iraqi missile exceeds range limits set by the United Nations Security Council misstated the name of the missile in some copies. It is Al Samoud 2, not Al Samoud. The article also rendered a word incorrectly, reversing the meaning, in a comment by Secretary of State Colin L. Powell about the possibility of violence against the United States in the event of war with Iraq. He said, ''But we can't say that because there's going to be blowback, we shouldn't act, either with or without U.N. permission'' -- not ''should act.''

description: The Bush administration is drafting a United Nations Security Council resolution with Britain declaring that Saddam Hussein has failed to disarm, and must now face unspecified ''consequences,'' senior administration officials said today.

description: Plans for an underground concourse at the World Trade Center would allow for the building of several hundred thousand square feet of retail space below ground, or nearly as much as existed at the site before the 2001 attack, officials from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Lawsuit Over School Reorganization
description: State Senator Carl Kruger, a Brooklyn Democrat, has filed a lawsuit against Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein, contending that they essentially eliminated the 32 community school districts without approval from the State Legislature. He said he would press for an injunction on putting the plan in effect. ''The mayor and the chancellor have clearly exceeded the scope of their authority,'' Mr. Kruger said yesterday in a statement. ''This is not a corporate reorganization. It is a reorganization that affects the lives of our children. The city's public school system cannot be revolutionized in a vacuum.'' Mr. Klein said he was confident the plan was legal. Last month, five Republican senators issued a statement contending that the plan needed approval from the Legislature. Jennifer Medina (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Delay In Defibrillators For Schools
description: A New York City school official said yesterday that it would take at least eight more months before city schools were fully equipped with state-mandated defibrillators. Anthony Shorris, a deputy chancellor, testifying before a City Council committee, said the Education Department had failed to meet the December deadline because it was still struggling to determine how many teachers and staff members would have to be trained to use the devices and how to compensate them. The hearing was held in response to the deaths earlier this year of three New York City high school students on school property. Advocates believe defibrillators -- devices that can shock the heart out of cardiac arrest -- may have saved the teenagers' lives. Nichole M. Christian (NYT)

title: A Table for 15, Please, and Can Someone Laugh at Our Jokes?

title: 36 Hours | Vail, Colo.
description: VAIL is unarguably one of the world's greatest ski mountains: a stunningly beautiful 5,289 acres surrounded by glistening snow-capped peaks in the White River National Forest. The town of Vail, however, is sometimes derided as a prefab ersatz Bavarian alpine village, more Epcot than Colorado Rockies. It doesn't have the authentic Victorian architectural bones of old mining towns like Telluride or Crested Butte.

It will be the first internationally owned power station in Spain. ESB arranged financing of 690 million euros ($740 million) to cover the cost of initial construction and long-term maintenance from Royal Bank of Scotland and eight other European banks. ESB's Spanish subsidiary, Bizkaia Energia S.L., will manage the 755-megawatt plant, while Royal Dutch Shell will provide natural gas for fuel and buy its entire output for 15 years. It made sense when Mr. Bart won a Tony Award for playing Snoopy, the ebullient comic strip dog, in the revival of ''You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown.'' When this actor smiles, the world smiles with him. And when he frowns, the world smiles again.

On a makeshift bandstand that takes up about a quarter of the room, Seleno Clarke is going crazy on a Hammond B-3 organ. Along a wall by the door, young men with saxophones and trumpets lean forward reverently as the tenor saxophonist Max Lucas steps up between the drummer and guitarist to take an impassioned solo.

Weakening exports and the waning of a housing boom will damp consumer spending this year, analysts said. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

When her would-be boyfriend, Paul (Paul Schneider), asks her why she didn't go to college, Noel replies that she didn't see much point in spending four years writing bad-girl poetry. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, JILL WARREN (MARY AUDREY ROCHLEN)
description: GREENBERG-Jill Warren (Mary Audrey Rochlen). Beloved mother of Peter Greenberg and Dr. Karen Greenberg Rudman. Wife of the late Dr. Sidney Greenberg. Sister of Kendis, David, Hartwell, Gail and the late Donald Rochlen and a longtime devoted friend of Lucille Fore, died on February 7, 2003, at her home in Manhattan. The daughter of journalist and aviation industry pioneer A.M. Rochlen, she was born July 4, 1915 in Los Angeles. She was an actress, singer, a magazine and newspaper journalist, and for many years a real estate broker in Manhattan and Fire Island, NY. She had boundless energy and an extraordinary spirit that touched and enriched countless lives. A selfless woman devoted to her siblings and her children, her legacy is a life eternally distinguished by not merely being interesting-for she was a great story teller and philosopher-but of being interested in the stories and philosophies of everyone she ever met. She is survived by her son, daughter, and son-in-law Richard Rudman. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, February 15, 12 noon at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In honor and celebration of the life of Jill Warren Greenberg, please send donations to the Union Settlement Association, 237 E. 104 St. NY, NY 10029 attention Laura Johnson. We will love her always.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Ultralight Crash In Cancn Kills 2
description: An ultralight aircraft crashed in the Caribbean resort of Cancn, killing both people aboard, police said. The crash, in the gardens of the Avalon Bay hotel in the city's tourist zone, caused little damage on the ground. The plane was used for carrying advertising and publicity banners aloft, and it was operated by a company called What Goes Up Must Come Down Inc., a Cancn police spokesman said. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: Scientists Link Harmless Virus To Slowing of H.I.V.'s Effects
description: Infection with a common harmless virus seems to slow the progress of H.I.V. and prolong the survival of AIDS patients, according to new evidence reported by American scientists at a meeting here today.

title: BANK OF AMERICA SAYS IT WILL CUT 110 JOBS IN TOKYO
description: Bank of America said yesterday that it was laying off half its staff in Tokyo because of the continued downturn in Japanese markets. The bank, which has operated in Japan for half a century, will keep 110 people in Tokyo and shift some jobs to Singapore. The move follows similar steps by Morgan Stanley, ABN Amro and other foreign brokers that expanded operations in 1999 and 2000, when Japan's equity market was growing. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Weak Response on Global Warming
description: In a transparent bit of salesmanship that should not be mistaken for a serious policy, the Bush administration announced Wednesday that it had persuaded several major industries to make voluntary reductions in the rate at which they produce carbon dioxide and other gases that contribute to global warming. It was the administration's latest effort to show that voluntary controls will make unnecessary the mandatory reductions called for by many scientists, environmentalists and members of Congress -- as well as by the 1997 Kyoto Protocol that Mr. Bush rejected after taking office.

description: Just how do you go about portraying someone whose boyfriend compares her to the Blob because she's ''as sentient as protoplasm''? A woman, moreover, whose roommate says she has ''all the charisma of fungus or mold''?

title: Joking Aside, a Serious Antipathy To Things American Rises in Europe
description: When a comedian at Boom Chicago's comedy club here asked the audience for their most embarrassing confessions Wednesday night, a European-accented voice called out from the gloom, ''I'm from the United States.''

title: SCHWAB SAYS FIRST-QUARTER PROFIT WON'T MEET FORECAST
description: The Charles Schwab Corporation said yesterday that first-quarter earnings might fall below analysts' estimates because of reduced customer trading. Profit forecasts of 8 cents a share are ''too aggressive,'' the chief financial officer, Christopher V. Dodds, said. Schwab's eight million customers made 19 percent fewer trades in January than a year earlier and volume is lower this month on concern about a war with Iraq, the company said. Schwab said its customers made an average of 126,300 trades a day last month versus 155,900 the previous January. In the first seven days of February, average daily trades tumbled to 103,000. Shares of Schwab fell 9 cents, to $7.76.

title: Teenage Screenplays Get Personal on Sex
description: What would today's teenagers make of ''Splendor in the Grass''? In that deliciously overwrought movie about teenage sexuality, released in 1961, Natalie Wood and Warren Beatty star as high-school sweethearts, seething (naturally) with romantic notions and hormonal overload. Their parents won't let them marry, leading him into the arms of a floozy and her into a mental institution.

title: Africans Press to Refurbish Zimbabwe's Battered Image
description: The presidents of Nigeria and South Africa are urging the Commonwealth nations to reinstate Zimbabwe -- and thus its leader President Robert Mugabe -- to full membership, saying the troubled country has made meaningful progress toward resolving its political crisis.

description: The corridors of the Capitol here, where Republicans control everything, are abuzz with talk about taxes. Not about cutting them. Raising them.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: For years, 60th Street at Third Avenue has been one of the busiest restaurant corners in Manhattan. The Santo family, owners of Sign of the Dove, operated a kind of restaurant minimall, consisting of Yellowfingers on the corner, Arizona 206 down the block and, more recently, Little Dove. Last year, the Santos retired, sold their building to the owners of Patsy's Pizzerias, and a new constellation of restaurants has risen at the old location. Arizona 206 is now another Patsy's, and the Yellowfingers and Little Dove building has been combined into Brasserie 360, one restaurant with two floors and two personalities.

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: VERIZON WIRELESS TO OFFER WALKIE-TALKIE SERVICE Verizon Wireless Inc., the biggest United States mobile phone company by subscribers, plans a walkie-talkie service this year that will let customers talk at the push of a button, a feature now sold only by Nextel Communications Inc. "You will see us introduce a push-to-talk product well before the end of the year," the company's chief executive, Dennis Strigl, said yesterday at an investor conference in New York. Verizon Wireless joins rivals like Alltel in trying to match the walkie-talkie technology that has made Nextel unique in the mobile phone industry. Investors and analysts have said the popularity of that product among business customers helped Nextel increase sales and add subscribers at a faster pace than competitors last year. Shares of Nextel, the fifth-largest United States mobile phone company by customers, fell 45 cents, or 3.5 percent, to $12.31. Nextel phones include a technology developed by Motorola , the big maker of mobile phones, that lets customers talk to another person or a group of users by pushing a button, rather than dialing a number. Verizon Wireless does not trade publicly. The company is a joint venture of Verizon Communications Inc., the largest United States local phone company, and the Vodafone Group of Britain, the world's biggest mobile phone company.

title: GLAXO SAYS IT WILL FIGHT NEW YORK LAWSUIT
description: The chief executive of GlaxoSmithKline, one of two drug makers accused by the New York attorney general of inflating drug costs for government health programs and consumers, said yesterday that it would fight the accusations. The executive, Jean-Pierre Garnier, said: ''We will fight because we've done nothing wrong. The money goes into the pocket of the physician. Why they're suing us is hard to understand.'' Mr. Garnier made the comments on Bloomberg Television after the New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, filed suit against Glaxo and Pharmacia, accusing them of trying to gain market share by giving discounts on certain drugs to doctors, who then bill government programs for the full price. A spokesman for Pharmacia, Paul Fitzhenry, said the company was cooperating with the attorney general's office and hoped to avoid litigation. He said the company thought the issue should be determined by federal legislation.

title: The Antiwar Non-March
description: When antiwar protesters gather in Manhattan tomorrow, they will not be allowed to march and will not be permitted near the United Nations. New York City officials have decided to limit the protest to a stationary rally several blocks away. The city has the right to impose reasonable restrictions to protect public safety, particularly now when the Police Department's resources are strained by a heightened terrorist alert. But the way this demonstration is being handled should not become the standard for the future.

title: A Dollop of 'Nice' For a Modern Woman
description: With all the roles that fashion, in recent memory, has invited women to play -- the dominatrix, the call girl, the Anne Sexton devotee, the cream-rinsed murderess, the Stepford wife -- it has rarely suggested that they should look like the sort who checks in on aged neighbors with bunches of pink tulips. The lexicon of modern fashion translates ''nice'' as uncool, unsophisticated, unnecessary.

title: U.S. Increased Alert on Evidence Qaeda Was Planning 2 Attacks
description: The government raised the national threat level last week after American intelligence obtained evidence that agents of Al Qaeda might be positioning themselves to carry out two major attacks, including one inside the United States, government officials said today.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: BANK'S PROFIT FALLS Britain's third-largest bank, Barclays, said higher provisions for bad loans ate into pretax profit for 2002, which fell 6 percent, to 3.2 billion ($5.2 billion), compared with 3.4 billion a year earlier. But the bank said it expected business to pick up, setting off a sharp gain in its share price. Barclays, which made large loans to telecommunications companies, many of which have suffered in the economic downturn, said provisions for bad debt rose 29 percent, to 1.5 billion.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Electronic Data's Debt Rating Is Cut 2 Levels
description: Debt of the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, the world's No. 2 seller of computer services, was cut two levels, to Baa2, by Moody's Investors Service yesterday on concern about cash flow and customers' ability to pay their bills. The senior unsecured debt had been rated A3, Moody's said. Electronic Data's short-term rating was cut to Prime-3 from Prime-2, Moody's said. About $4 billion of securities were downgraded. The Baa2 ranking is the second-lowest investment-grade rating at Moody's, which said Electronic Data may be hurt by reduced demand and by ''credit weakness'' at major customers like WorldCom. Moody's also said Electronic Data will continue using cash to provide contracted services to the United States Navy, and declines in business from General Motors were greater than expected. Electronic Data's notes maturing in October 2009, carrying a 7.125 percent interest rate, last traded at 104 cents on the dollar to yield 6.39 percent, according to Bloomberg data. The extra yield, or spread, on the notes is 3.17 percentage points higher than Treasury debt of similar maturity.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Vichy Official Will Stay Free
description: France's highest appeals court upheld a decision to free Maurice Papon, the former official in France's Vichy government who was convicted in 1998 of Nazi war crimes in World War II. Mr. Papon, 92, was given early release from prison in September because of poor health. But the sight of Mr. Papon smiling and walking unaided out of La Sant prison touched off a wave of public anger, and the justice minister ordered prosecutors to seek a reversal. Yesterday, an appeals court accepted the defense's argument that the ministry's request stemmed more from outrage than from a question of the legality of Mr. Papon's release. Elaine Sciolino (NYT)

title: CONCORD EFS, OWNER OF A.T.M. NETWORK, NAMES CO-CHIEF
description: Concord EFS, owner of the largest A.T.M. network, named Bond R. Isaacson co-chief executive yesterday. Mr. Isaacson, 45, a former Visa USA executive, was hired in September from Bank of America and will share the top job with Dan M. Palmer, the company said. The president, Edward A. Labry III, who was named Mr. Palmer's successor last year, will no longer take over in May. Concord, which operates the Star Systems A.T.M. and debit network, has lost 66 percent of its value in 12 months amid concern that Visa's Interlink network will take over agreements that expire next year.

description: With the America's Cup finals only a day away, the skippers Russell Coutts and Dean Barker today took seats on either side of the Auld Mug -- the 132-ounce silver ewer at the root of all the hubbub here -- to answer questions about Saturday's matchup. But as the skippers joked, attention quickly turned to a man whose decisions could affect the outcome of the race at least as much as the skippers' do -- the principal race officer, Harold Bennett.

title: CASUAL MALE TO CLOSE OUTLET STORES AND CUT 500 JOBS
description: The Casual Male Retail Group, operator of Casual Male Big and Tall, plans to close its Levi's and Dockers outlet stores as it focuses on selling clothing to big and tall men. The company will cut 500 to 600 jobs as it exits the business. It plans to close 50 to 55 Levi's and Dockers stores in the next 24 months. Thirty remaining stores will be sold or shut at the end of their lease terms, the chief financial officer, Dennis R. Hernreich, said. Casual Male will take an expense of $27 million to $30 million in its fourth quarter for the closings.

title: Ex-Jail Official Is Charged With Misusing Staff and Stealing Property
description: A former high-ranking official with the New York City Department of Correction was charged yesterday with looting a storage shed on Rikers Island and taking everything from ladders to weed whackers to hundreds of bags of mulch. The official was also charged with ordering correction officers to cut the lawn, repair the driveway, remodel the bathroom and take out the garbage at his home in Putnam County.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBLICH, DANIEL PARKE
description: LIEBLICH-Daniel Parke, 85. Of Deal, NJ, passed away peacefully on February 11 in Palm Beach, FL. Born and raised in Paterson, NJ, grandson of a major silk manufacturer, he was a graduate of the Hun School, Princeton University '38, and Yale Law School. Co-founding the firm of Lieblich and Cole, he practiced corporate law in Paterson. In 1957, he established and was Chairman/CEO of a public hospitality corporation, which became Treadway Companies, retiring in 1983. He served on active duty for five years as a military officer during WWII, the last two with the 8th Air Force in England. He served an additional 15 years as commander of the 907th unit of the NJ Air Force Reserves, retiring as Colonel. Among his many charitable and civic board activities were Princeton University, The Hun School, Barnert Temple, and Monmouth Medical Center. He most recently served five years as President of The Princeton Club of NY. He is survived by his devoted daughters, Nancy Bracken Garson and Lynn Jeffery, his loving grandchildren, Genevieve Bracken Jaffe, Emily Bracken; Todd Daniel, Diana, and Carolyn Jeffery, and his two sisters, Selma Kramer and Ruth Davis. He was predeceased by his adored wife of 52 years, Mannette Neuman Lieblich. Funeral services at noon Sunday, February 16 at Barnert Temple, Franklin Lakes, NJ. Family will receive visitors Sunday 7-9 PM at home in Deal. Donations may be made to: The Lieblich Scholarship at Princeton University, Hospice at Monmouth Medical Center (Long Branch, NJ), The Barnert Temple.

title: Flowery Thoughts
description: Valentine's Day has always been a time for shy sweethearts and special friends to exchange sentimental gestures, perhaps a heart-shaped card or a rose. We fully intend to share in this glow, even if it is a touch unnerving to recall that the first card to be inscribed ''From Your Valentine'' was sent to a Roman jailer's daughter by a Christian priest waiting to be beheaded.

As for "The Mystery of Picasso" (1956), the director Henri-Georges Clouzot died in 1977, but he has plenty of good current representation to help explain his thinking on a DVD available from Milestone (distributed by Image).

title: MARATHON AND AUSTIN WITHDRAW BID FOR HOOVER'S
description: Hoover's, a publisher of corporate data, said yesterday that Marathon Partners and Austin Ventures had withdrawn their bid to buy the company for $8 a share. Marathon and Austin made the offer last week, seeking to outbid D&B, the business-information provider formerly called Dun & Bradstreet. D&B agreed in December to pay $7 in cash for each Hoover's share, or about $117 million. Marathon, based in New York, owns almost 10 percent of Hoover's stock. D&B, based in Murray Hill, N.J., is counting on Hoover's revenue to almost double by 2005 as it expands product distribution.
