title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUWISCH, JOACHIM, MD
description: LUWISCH-Joachim, MD, 97, neuro - psychiatrist, former Director Psychiatry at Goldwater Memorial Hospital, Professor Emeritus NYU. Loving husband of Eileen (nee Costigan). Cherished father of Michael, Edward, Ruth, and the late Elizabeth and Joseph. Adoring grandfather to Jennifer and Lauren. Father-in-law to Cathleen and Diana. Survived by sister Anna Scherz. His many dear friends and relatives will miss his warmth, wisdom, humor and compassion. His memory is our legacy. Service today at 2:30, Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, 718-263-7600. Visitation 3-5:30. Burial Saturday, February 15, 10:30 at Flushing Cemetery, 163-06 46th Ave, leaving Schwartz Bros. 9:30

title: Israel Rejects Belgian Court Ruling on Sharon
description: Israeli officials reacted with outrage today to a decision by Belgium's highest court that Belgium could try Prime Minister Ariel Sharon for war crimes once he leaves office.

title: Germany Says NATO Rift Over Turkey Is Near an End
description: Signaling that the NATO deadlock over planning Turkey's defense in an Iraq war would be resolved by the weekend, Germany indicated today that it would drop opposition to such planning after a report on Friday by United Nations weapons inspectors.

title: Duct Tape, Plastic Sheeting and Other Advice
description: To the Editor:

title: Poll Finds Most In U.S. Support Delaying a War
description: Even after the administration's aggressive case for going to war soon in Iraq, a majority of Americans favor giving United Nations weapons inspectors more time to complete their work so that any military operation wins the support of the Security Council, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ulster: British General Is Suspect In Killing
description: Brig. Gordon Kerr, the former head of the British Army's secret intelligence division in Northern Ireland, may face prosecution in the 1989 killing of a prominent lawyer, Pat Finucane, who was known for legally defending members of the Irish Republican Army. Brigadier Kerr, now the British military attach in Beijing, ran the Force Research Unit in Belfast when Mr. Finucane was shot dead by Protestant militia members. Prompted by testimony from militia informers, a formal inquiry into collusion by British security forces and Protestant gunmen will forward files on Brigadier Kerr and other officers to Britain's public prosecutor. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Chaos Erupts at Panel's Meeting on Future of Newark School Superintendent
description: A meeting of the advisory board of the state-controlled Newark school district -- called to decide on a contract extension for a popular superintendent -- erupted tonight into shouting, chaos and near fistfights after board members announced to a crowd of nearly 500 that they would first vote on whether to retain the superintendent or hire someone else before hearing public comments.

title: Roy Jones Jr. In PETA Row
description: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, concerned that the celebrated boxer Roy Jones Jr. is mistreating some of the animals on his 80-acre ranch in Cantonment, Fla., has drafted a letter to the Escambia County sheriff calling for an investigation into Jones's suspected involvement in cockfighting.

title: Much Ado about Nothing?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Pivotal Security Council Meeting
description: On Feb. 14, the chief arms inspectors delivered an update to the Council on disarming Iraq.

title: The Little Rascals
description: Even cute new clothes can't deter them.

title: Not Yet Ready for His Last Mile
description: In June 1944, Anthony and Louise Zamperini were at their home in Torrance, Calif., when they received the following message regarding their son, an airman who at age 19 had been a member of the 1936 United States Olympic track and field team:

title: Seven Killed as a Church Bus Overturns in Texas
description: Their journey did not end. Their destination just changed.

title: Americans Among 2 Killed and 3 Missing in Colombia
description: An American working for the United States government and a Colombian soldier were shot dead after their small plane crash landed on Thursday in a region of southern Colombia dominated by guerrillas, Colombian and American officials said tonight. The rebels are believed to have then made off with three other Americans who had also been aboard the United States government plane when engine failure forced it down.

title: Editorial Observer; Matisse and Picasso Bring Their Old Rivalry to Queens Boulevard
description: If you go to the Museum of Modern Art's temporary home in Queens, where the exhibition ''Matisse Picasso'' has just opened, you find yourself almost lost in a world of contrasts, and not only the one between the Frenchman and the Spaniard. MOMA Queens looks like nothing more than a freshly painted version of the low-slung warehouses that crowd Long Island City, so different from the vertical proclivities of Midtown Manhattan. Down the street is a Dominican diner, whose aesthetics MOMA's curators, in curatorial fashion, have embraced. A few blocks farther on lie the prewar houses of an older Queens, where the brickwork and stonework feel both massive and ornamental, not yet pared back to dull, anonymous postwar regimentation.

title: Police Warn Wrong Town Of 911 Threat To a School
description: When the the New York Police Department received a 911 call on Tuesday night warning that a bomb was set to go off in a Westchester school, the response was swift. The department notified the police here, who evacuated the Croton-Harmon high school and middle school and began a search that stretched into Wednesday, delaying the start of classes.

title: Tracking Wayward Shepherds
description: In a scathing report that adds another disturbing layer to the national scandal of pedophile priests, a grand jury found that Roman Catholic authorities on Long Island conspired for decades to protect scores of rogue clergymen rather than the young innocents they sexually ravaged. The diocese said it ''unequivocally rejects'' the finding. But the jury's nine-month inquiry found that lawyer-priests had run a ''sham'' counseling program whose mission was to keep the scandal secret, hold down settlement costs and intimidate parents not to complain.

title: Three Airlines Increase Fares To Help Cope With Fuel Prices
description: Three leading airlines increased nearly all their fares by $10 each way yesterday.

title: Those Sunny Brothels Where Sin Has No Sting
description: Had there been bordellos in Eden, they would surely have been something like the soul-soothing brothels in ''House of Flowers,'' the fabled 1954 musical by Harold Arlen and Truman Capote.

title: Outside Experts Focusing On Blow to Shuttle Wing
description: Several independent space experts said yesterday that the recent findings in the shuttle investigation sharpened a theory that a blow to the orbiter's wing triggered a cascade of failures that ended in the fiery destruction of Columbia and its seven astronauts.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Money Policy Unchanged
description: The Bank of Japan left its monetary policy unchanged after a two-day board meeting but promised to pump extra liquidity into the financial markets before the end of the fiscal year on March 31, if needed. Leading lawmakers have called on the central bank to take additional steps to strengthen the economy, but stronger-than-anticipated economic figures out yesterday appear to have squelched that debate temporarily. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Broadcaster Posts Profit
description: British Sky Broadcasting, the pay TV company, said its mixture of pay movies, news, increased subscriptions and sports coverage delivered a third consecutive quarterly profit in the period ended Dec. 31, beating analysts' forecasts of a $10 million loss. The company, controlled by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, said quarterly net income was $26 million. The chief executive, Tony Ball, left, said the company still thought it would achieve its target of increasing the number of digital-satellite subscribers by the end of the year to 7 million from 6.6 million. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: TYSON FOODS CHANGES DUTIES OF TWO TOP EXECUTIVES
description: Tyson Foods named a former IBP executive, Richard L. Bond, as its president and chief operating officer. Mr. Bond, who held the same job at IBP before Tyson acquired the company in September 2001, will be responsible for Tyson's domestic business, the company said. Greg W. Lee, who had shared duties with Mr. Bond, was named chief administrative officer and president of international operations. The management change will give Mr. Bond ''the opportunity to pull all our domestic operations together and focus on enhancing that huge part of our business,'' the chief executive, John H. Tyson, said.

title: Disarming Iraq
description: As much as the feuding members of the United Nations Security Council might like Hans Blix and Mohamed ElBaradei to settle the question of war or peace with Iraq, these two mild-mannered civil servants can't make that fateful judgment. All they can do, which they did again yesterday, is to tell the Council how their inspection efforts are faring. So-so was the answer. It's up to the Council members -- especially the veto-wielding quintet of the United States, Britain, France, Russia and China -- to decide whether Iraq is disarming.

title: Leetch Is Back And Kovalev Lifts Rangers
description: The fans came to Madison Square Garden last night prepared to see Aleksei Kovalev play his first home game since the Rangers acquired him from Pittsburgh on Monday in an eight-player trade.

title: Arafat Will Appoint a Prime Minister, a Major U.S. Demand
description: Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, announced today that he would appoint a prime minister in a step toward meeting a central demand of the Bush administration for a resumption of the peace process.

title: Into the Quicksand Of Endless War
description: Omer Bartov teaches history at Brown University. He is the author of ''Mirrors of Destruction: War, Genocide and Modern Identity'' (2000) and an editor of ''Crimes of War'' (2002). Chris Hedges spoke with him.

title: Bishop Urged Predator Priest To Go to Rome On Sabbatical
description: Bishop Thomas V. Daily of Brooklyn suggested to one of the nation's most notorious predator priests that he go on sabbatical in Rome in 1979 to help soothe the ''traumatic experience'' of a sexual abuse charge, according to documents and testimony released in Boston yesterday.

title: Never Mind the Contract: The Real Game Is 2 Hearts
description: Imagine a bridge fairy tale, in a mixed pair championship. A beautiful young woman, not very experienced at the game, reaches a contract of five diamonds, is doubled, and redoubles. Her partner, a handsome young man, has overbid and is ashamed of his dummy. As he puts it on the table, he announces jestingly, ''Make this and I will marry you.'' She makes the game, because she has compensated for his overbid by underbidding, and five years later they do indeed marry, between sessions at a bridge tournament.

title: Market Place; Fiscal Officer Ousted At Auditor's Request
description: Auditing firms often emphasize that the financial statements they audit are the responsibility of the company's management. But companies often rely on the auditors for advice.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Immigration Accusations
description: The government urged the United States to examine the case of a Canadian who accused American officials of mutilating her passport at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago and putting her on a plane to India. Berna Cruz, a native of India, said that Immigration and Naturalization Service officials claimed she was using a fake passport and that they threatened to put her in jail without the benefit of consular assistance. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Toasting a Wallace Victory Becomes an Improbability
description: Not even a stock car that can fly like a rocket can catch the attention of most race fans the way these two wondrous words can: free beer.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Rally as Inspectors Ask for More Time in Iraq

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Charges In Spice Girl Plot
description: Five men were charged with conspiracy to kidnap Victoria Beckham, a former Spice Girls star and the wife of David Beckham, the Manchester United football captain. The five will be tried later in connection with the foiled plan, which was uncovered in November by undercover reporters from the tabloid News of the World, who tipped off the police. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Another Death Sentence Is Lifted
description: The Supreme Court has lifted the death sentence issued last November for a reformist university lecturer, Hashem Aghajari, the Islamic Republic News Agency quoted one of the judges, Muhammad Sajadi, as saying. Mr. Aghajari was given the sentence after he called for Islamic reformation in a speech last July. The court will soon issue the new sentence, Judge Sajadi said. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: BANK'S PROFIT FALLS The British bank Lloyds TSB Group reported a 40 percent decline in profit for the second half of 2002, blaming rising provisions for bad loans and a lingering bear market for stocks. Net income for the period was 668 million ($1.1 billion), compared with 1.1 billion ($1.8 billion) a year earlier. The bank froze its dividend and said it would need to invest money in its pension fund to compensate for falling stock prices. Rising provisions for bad loans and falling stock prices have also hit other British banks, including Barclays and Abbey National . Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Central Parking Withdraws Profit Forecast
description: The Central Parking Corporation, an operator of parking lots, withdrew its earnings forecast for the year today and said its chief financial officer had resigned. Its shares fell 22 percent.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Trade Deficit
description: China posted a trade deficit for the first time in more than six years as the nation stockpiled crude oil ahead of a possible war in Iraq and as consumers took advantage of tariff cuts and bought more imported cars. The deficit in January was $1.25 billion, the first time China has posted a shortfall since December 1996, the Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation said. Imports rose 63 percent, to $31 billion, driven by a 78 percent increase in the volume of oil imported. Exports rose 37 percent, to $29.8 billion.

title: If, and When: War's Timing
description: With the United States poised to launch a military strike against Iraq within a matter of weeks, the question of whether war should replace United Nations inspections as the primary instrument to disarm Saddam Hussein became one of timing yesterday.

title: Shares Rally, Sending S.&P. to Biggest Gain in 6 Weeks
description: Stocks rallied yesterday, sending the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index to its biggest gain in almost six weeks, as United Nations weapons inspectors pressed for more time to work in Iraq.

title: London driver, toll is for thee
description: LONDON:  Gray London is a long way from the sunny Riviera, but sales of Italian scooters are careering along like out-of-control Vespas.

title: Vatican Opens Files to Rebut War Criticism Of Pius XII
description: The Vatican will open secret archives on Saturday in an effort to allay accusations that Pope Pius XII, whom the Vatican wants to make a saint, did not do enough to save Jews from the Holocaust.

title: Jets Will Release Robinson
description: The Jets have decided to release free safety Damien Robinson on Thursday, according to a person with knowledge of the team's plans. Robinson's departure was not unexpected. He was brought in by Coach Herman Edwards two years ago to help smooth the transition to a Tampa Bay style of defense. His release will conclude a tenure marked by struggles on and off the field.

title: Agency Urges Tougher Code For Buildings
description: Trying to apply the lessons learned at a terrible cost on Sept. 11, 2001, the New York City Buildings Department yesterday outlined a future in which office towers could have larger, sturdier and more numerous stairwells; full sprinkler systems; and better protected ductwork.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Fund Official Is Detained
description: A member of an International Monetary Fund mission, sent to scrutinize the Argentine government's economic policies, has been detained on his arrival in Buenos Aires on corruption charges at the request of the Peruvian government. Jorge Baca Campodonico, a former minister of finance in Peru, is accused of illegally waiving the tax payments of hundreds of people at the orders of Vladimiro Montesinos, a former head of Peruvian intelligence who is now jailed and awaiting trial on accusations of murder, arms trafficking and corruption. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Lionizing Venice
description: It has often been said that there is no city in the world like Venice, but the city's mayor has made sure of it, introducing a new trademark to stamp on authentically Venetian goods with the goal of preventing imitators from exploiting the city for profit. The new seal, with a burgundy lion's head that has a wing shooting out of its ear, might be confused with a college's varsity logo, but according to the city's official Web site, www.comune.venezia.it, ''it will protect the image of Venice.'' The city says it is a ''proud face'' that embodies the fundamental elements of the city -- ''its past, its richness, history, authority, wisdom.'' Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Europe: Central Bank Succession
description: The European Central Bank president, Wim Duisenberg, will probably have to delay retirement because the European Parliament cannot confirm his successor before September, said Christa Randzio-Plath, head of the legislature's economic and monetary committee. The fate of Mr. Duisenberg's designated successor, the Bank of France governor, Jean-Claude Trichet, will not be clear until June 18, when a Paris court is to rule on charges that he helped Crdit Lyonnais falsify its accounts a decade ago. Mr. Duisenberg is scheduled to retire on July 9.

title: Reports to the Security Council by the Chief U.N. Weapons Inspectors
description: Following are a transcript of a report delivered before the United Nations Security Council yesterday by the chief inspector for biological and chemical weapons, Hans Blix, and excerpts from a report by the chief nuclear weapons inspector, Dr. Mohamed ElBaradei, as recorded by Federal News Service Inc. A full transcript of Dr. ElBaradei's report is online at nytimes.com /international.

title: BANKRUPTCY COURT APPROVES FAO EXECUTIVE PAY PLAN
description: FAO Inc., owner of the F. A. O. Schwarz and Zany Brainy toy store chains, won court permission yesterday to pay $1.1 million in bonuses to keep several managers with the company through its bankruptcy reorganization. Judge Lloyd King of United States Bankruptcy Court found the executive-retention plan reasonable given the company's goal of pushing through its Chapter 11 recovery plan by April. The plan provides $775,000 in bonuses for senior managers and $350,000 to lower-level supervisors. FAO filed for bankruptcy protection last month in Wilmington, Del. The judge also approved more than $1.2 million in severance payments for FAO workers who were laid off.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES. Crude oil rose to a 29-month high on continuing concern about a possible war with Iraq. In New York, crude oil for March delivery rose 44 cents, or 1.2 percent, to $36.80 a barrel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEFF, ALAN
description: SEFF-Alan. On February 10, 2003, age 87. Beloved husband of Gloria Seff, loving father of Gina Freis, Barbara Hurlbutt, and stepfather of Liane Onish, cherished grandfather of Stacy and Michelle Freis, Bryan and Julie Hurlbutt. Services were held on Thursday.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: NEW MARKET FOR LUXURY CAR The Toyota Motor Corporation will start selling its luxury Lexus brand in Japan in 2005, part of the company's efforts to strengthen its grip on the domestic market. Until now, Lexus cars have been sold only in the United States. Toyota will also combine two of its five domestic sales divisions, as it consolidates ownership of its 5,000 nationwide dealerships. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Being Mark Twain
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINGARTEN, FELICE
description: WEINGARTEN-Felice. On February 14, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Marcus. Loving mother of Laurel Paymer and Robert Weingarten. Adoring grandmother of Lisa Dodge, Andrew Paymer and Steven Paymer. Cherished great-grandmother. Service Sunday 11:15AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: No Waiting in Line, Just Online; Moviegoers Say Buying in Advance Can Be Confusing, Not Convenient
description: Going to the latest movie used to mean long lines and the prospect of reaching the box office just as the last seat was spoken for. Then about a decade ago, many moviegoers in the New York region figured out that they could avoid the hassle by ordering tickets in advance.

title: Woods's Left Knee, And His Game, Hold Up Just Fine
description: Tiger Woods may have left for a while, but his game did not go anywhere.

title: The Fundamental Right to March
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: New Market For Luxury Car
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation will start selling its luxury Lexus brand in Japan in 2005, part of the company's efforts to strengthen its grip on the domestic market. Until now, Lexus cars have been sold only in the United States. Toyota will also combine two of its five domestic sales divisions, as it consolidates ownership of its 5,000 nationwide dealerships. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We just don't want folks sealing up their doors or sealing up their windows.''

title: 20,000 More Troops Sent to Persian Gulf; Jets Hit Iraqi SAM's
description: The Pentagon has ordered 20,000 additional Army troops to the Persian Gulf, including an armored unit from Colorado, as part of the steady buildup for a potential war with Iraq, military officials said today.

title: Cone Says Comeback With Mets Is a Long Shot
description: David Cone climbed a bullpen mound in the rear of the Mets' complex here this morning, rocked back and began throwing to a catcher. After warming up, he produced 26 pitches, all fastballs at less than full speed, over five minutes.

title: Gotham Sold Shares After Urging Others To Buy Stock
description: Gotham Partners L.P. sold about 500,000 shares of Pre-Paid Legal Services Inc. less than five weeks after recommending that investors buy the stock in a research report issued in November, according to a regulatory filing by David P. Berkowitz, a Gotham hedge fund manager.

title: South African To Join MetroStars
description: The MetroStars leave on Tuesday for two weeks of training at the IMG Academy in Bradenton, Fla., and will be met by a promising young South African player who could stick with the club.

title: Hussein Issues Decree to Ban Weapons of Mass Destruction
description: Waiting until almost the last possible moment, Saddam Hussein complied today with one demand of the United Nations weapons inspectors by issuing a presidential decree banning the construction or import of weapons of mass destruction.

title: 13-Year-Old Can Play For U.S.
description: Freddy Adu became eligible to play for the United States' under-23 soccer team yesterday after he received a passport in Potomac, Md., following the granting of citizenship to his mother, Emilia, according to Jim Moorhouse, a U.S. Soccer spokesman.

title: Glimmers of an Investor-Friendly Russia
description: With a pen stroke at 9:45 Tuesday morning, BP agreed to make the single largest foreign direct investment in Russia's post-Soviet history. BP's $6.75 billion commitment to create a giant new oil company here left businesspeople asking whether Russia, after a decade of zigzagging economic policies, had finally become safe, fertile ground for foreign investors.

title: Congressmen urge U.S. boycott of Paris air show
description: PARIS:  Because France is not falling into line with the Bush administration's policy on Iraq, 18 members of the U.S. House of Representatives have urged the American aeronautics and space industry to boycott this year's Paris air show  joining calls to shun a range of other products from wine to Asterix.

title: Envoys Abandon Scripts on Iraq And Bring Emotion to U.N. Floor
description: It was supposed to be a moment for dueling bugles, with the French foreign minister, Dominique de Villepin, rallying his troops against the rush toward war in Iraq, and the American secretary of state, Colin L. Powell, rallying his against any delay in the disarmament of a dictator.

title: Democrats Try to Turn Debate Back to Home
description: Around the country, in coffee shops and bookstores, offices and schools, Americans are debating the pros and cons of war with Iraq. But here in the Capitol, where armed guards stand sentry to defend against a terrorist attack, leading Democrats have sought to shift the debate away from war and toward domestic security.

title: White House Scales Back Cyberspace Plan
description: The White House today scaled back plans for a more active government role in protecting cyberspace from attacks from terrorists, criminals and nation states, emphasizing voluntary industry initiatives instead.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Eruption!
description: Popocatepetl, the nation's biggest volcano, has erupted, throwing rocks and ash more than two miles from the crater. No injuries were reported. Nearly 30 million people live within view of the 17,945-foot peak, most of them in Mexico City, 40 miles west, and Puebla, 30 miles east. Its last major eruption was on Dec. 18, 2000, when thousands living near the mountain had to flee their homes. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAPLACE, MAURICE L.
description: LAPLACE-Maurice L. On February 13, he passed away at the age of 85. He was the loving and devoted husband of Dorothy, his wife of fiftyone years. He was an adoring and caring father of Karen, Robin and Lisa and a proud and doting grandfather of Jennifer, Athina, Alex, Lauren and Sophia. He was survived by his cherished sister and brother, Frances and Saniel. He was predeceased by his dear sisters and brothers: Helen, Ruth, Mildred, Alma, Oscar and Noa. He was a partner of L.J. & M. Laplace Chemicals. As a WW II veteran of the U.S. Army, he was decorated with the American Defense Ribbon, American Theater Ribbon, the European-African-Middle Eastern Ribbon, the Good Conduct Medal and the Victory Medal. We will remember his generosity of spirit and love for his family. He will be in our hearts forever. Relatives and friends are invited to services on Sunday, February 16 at 12:30PM at Gutterman Musicant on the corner of Park St. and Passaic St., Hackensack, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to: Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Hepatobiliary Research (Fund Number 205355), Box E, 1275 York Avenue, New York, New York 10021.

title: A Musical Dispute of the 60's Now Seems Mostly Resolved
description: Loose; Fully Celebrated Orchestra

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the Albany role of Sheldon Silver, speaker of the State Assembly, misspelled the given name of a Lower East Side constituent who has known Mr. Silver since their boyhood. He is Fischel Fisch, not Fischer.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Jan. 23 about Irene Diamond, a philanthropist who had an earlier career scouting Hollywood film scripts, including one that became the classic ''Casablanca,'' misstated the year of that film's release. It was 1942, not 1943.

title: One Prosecutor Is Praised, Another Criticized in Priest Abuse Cases
description: They are both district attorneys on Long Island, home of the Diocese of Rockville Centre, where allegations of sexually abusive priests started circulating last year in the early stages of what became a national scandal. They are both also practicing Roman Catholics.

title: Columbia Hires Architects and Planners to Help Design Long-Term Expansion
description: Columbia University, long pressed for room to expand, has hired the Renzo Piano Building Workshop and Skidmore Owings & Merrill to help it figure out how it can double its usable space over the next 50 years, Lee C. Bollinger, Columbia's president, said yesterday.

title: The Fundamental Right to March
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Nation also bans military overflights : Austria bars U.S. troops from crossing country
description: PARIS:  Austria on Friday lined up with other European Union countries opposing U.S. plans for a possible war in Iraq by saying it would not allow American troops to cross its soil on the way to the Middle East unless the UN Security Council approved a resolution authorizing military action.

title: Settlement Cuts Biogen Net
description: Biogen Inc., maker of the $1 billion multiple sclerosis drug Avonex, said today that its fourth-quarter profit was half of what it reported earlier because of a legal settlement with a German rival, Schering A.G. Net income fell 30 percent, to $41.4 million, or 27 cents a share, from $58.9 million, or 39 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier, Biogen said. Last month, the company reported quarterly net income of $81 million, or 53 cents a share. Biogen last week said it would pay $55 million to settle a dispute with Schering's Berlex Laboratories Inc. over patents for multiple sclerosis drugs. The case focused on rights to a technology that uses hamster cells to make Avonex.

title: Washington Advises Against Sealing Doors and Windows
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14  The Bush administration tried today to calm a jittery public after a week of heightened terrorism warnings, with Homeland Security Secretary Tom Ridge saying that "we just don't want folks sealing up their doors or sealing up their windows." Senior administration officials said the government had received no new intelligence in recent days to suggest an imminent attack.

title: Putting Some Pizazz Back in the Skyline
description: The good news is that two thoughtful and innovative designs were named finalists for the rebuilding of the World Trade Center site. Unfortunately, the Port Authority and Larry Silverstein, the developer who holds the lease, are under no obligation to use either of these schemes. And thus far, neither has demonstrated much inclination to heed to the public demand for great urban spaces and imaginative architecture.

title: National Briefing: New England
description: RHODE ISLAND: PROBE OF SECRET TAPES The state will conduct a criminal investigation into a system that secretly recorded phone calls into and out of the Providence complex that houses police, fire and court officials, the attorney general said. Officials said they shut down the recording system at the public safety complex on Thursday, after it was discovered in a review of the building. Conversations that were recorded included those made by crime victims to their families and criminal suspects to their lawyers. Attorney General Patrick Lynch announced the investigation after meeting with Chief Dean Esserman of the Providence Police Department. It was unclear who ordered the recording system at the complex, which opened last year. Mayor David Cicilline blamed the former police chief Urbano Prignano Jr., but Mr. Prignano denied any knowledge of the system. (AP)

title: How Four Countries Reacted, And What the Iraqis Said, Too
description: Following are excerpts from a meeting of the United Nations Security Council yesterday after reports by the chief weapons inspectors, as recorded by Federal News Service Inc. Iraq's ambassador to the United Nations, Mohammed Aldouri, attended as an invited speaker. Translations of Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan's remarks (from the Chinese), Foreign Minister Igor S. Ivanov's remarks (from the Russian) and Mr. Aldouri's remarks (from the Arabic) are by the United Nations.

title: The Price We Pay
description: War in Iraq will not come cheap -- and neither will peace. The aftermath of a war can be even more costly than the war itself. No one knows what the ultimate price will be. Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., director of the Office of Management and Budget, says the conflict could cost $50 billion to $60 billion, less than half of what Lawrence B. Lindsey, the former chief economic adviser to the White House, estimated last fall. The cost of the war is not included in the budget President Bush submitted to Congress earlier this month.

title: 2 Are Bound And Strangled In Apartment In Brooklyn
description: A teacher's aide and her boyfriend were bound, gagged and strangled and her first-floor Brooklyn apartment was set on fire early yesterday morning, the authorities said.

title: The Cost of Slavery
description: Marching across the South in 1865, Union soldiers seized up to 900,000 acres of ''abandoned property.'' Some radical Northerners hoped to use this land to provide freed slaves with the now-legendary ''40 acres and a mule'' as restitution for slavery. Their hopes were obviously dashed. But the argument for reparations lives on nearly 140 years later.

title: Wells Is Siding With Jeter In Dispute With Steinbrenner
description: David Wells has always been George Steinbrenner's favorite rascal. But today Wells took Derek Jeter's side in the dispute between the team's principal owner and its All-Star shortstop.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bank's Profit Falls
description: The British bank Lloyds TSB Group reported a 40 percent decline in profit for the second half of 2002, blaming rising provisions for bad loans and a lingering bear market for stocks. Net income for the period was 668 million ($1.1 billion), compared with 1.1 billion ($1.8 billion) a year earlier. The bank froze its dividend and said it would need to invest money in its pension fund to compensate for falling stock prices. Rising provisions for bad loans and falling stock prices have also hit other British banks, including Barclays and Abbey National. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: F.B.I. and C.I.A. to Move Their Counterterror Units To a Single New Location
description: In a major organizational shift, the entire counterterrorism sections of the F.B.I. and the C.I.A. will move into a single complex as a way of better coordinating the analysis and tracking of information, the White House said today.

title: Powell's Response: Iraq Fails To Comply With U.N. Terms
description: Following, as recorded by Federal News Service Inc., are excerpts from remarks by Secretary of State Colin L. Powell to the United Nations Security Council yesterday after reports by the chief weapons inspectors. A full transcript is online at nytimes.com/international

title: MERRILL'S GLOBAL HEAD OF STOCK RESEARCH RESIGNS
description: The global head of stock research at Merrill Lynch & Company resigned, the company said yesterday. The resignation of the executive, Deepak Raj, came one week after the head of the research division, Robert McCann, resigned and was replaced by Candace Browning. Mr. Raj helped oversee stock research during the time that regulators said Merrill and other Wall Street firms had published biased reports to win investment banking assignments. Merrill paid $200 million as part of an industrywide $1.4 billion settlement of those allegations. Mr. Raj, 53, who joined Merrill in 1979, said his resignation was a personal decision. He will remain a senior adviser to the company until April 1, Merrill said.

title: Americans Turning Eagerly to Gibes at the French
description: If people missed Dennis Miller's quip to Phil Donahue that the only way the French are going into Iraq ''is if we tell them we found truffles in there,'' there was the St. Valentine's Day mock photograph on the cover of The New York Post that showed United Nations representatives from Germany and French as weasels.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Outlook For Telecom
description: Telecom Italia presented its three-year business plan to investors, promising cost cuts, asset sales, profit growth of about 8.5 percent a year and a one-third reduction in debt. The company also said it would invest as much as 16 billion euros ($17.3 billion) over the next three years to update its network and offer new services. The chairman, Marco Tronchetti Provera, shook off questions from investors seeking details about a possible merger between Telecom Italia and its parent, Olivetti, saying only that the merger remains an objective. Some fund managers said uncertainty about the merger had led to the stock's underperformance compared with rivals over the last six months. Eric Sylvers (NYT)

title: His 15-Year Sentence Served, Chambers Walks Free, Quietly
description: The reporters began gathering in front of the Auburn Correctional Facility here on Thursday night, staking out their spots like fans waiting for a glimpse of a rock star or a guru.

title: Powell Says More Inspectors in Iraq Are 'Not the Answer'
description: A different face of Colin L. Powell was on view today -- not the confident, smiling, bear-hugging secretary of state accepting compliments all around the United Nations Security Council after his presentation of the case against Saddam Hussein a week and a half ago.

title: The Iraq Crisis: In Search of an Exit
description: To the Editor:

title: Knicks Overcome Marbury's Flash to Beat Suns
description: Stephon Marbury had been weaving through the Knicks' defense all night, getting whatever shot he wanted, scoring seemingly at will. So when he squared up against Charlie Ward with his Suns down by a point and six seconds left on the clock, the crowd of 15,438 at America West Arena was at peace, confident that their star would deliver the victory.

title: Poets as Leaders
description: To the Editor:

title: Johnny Longden, 96, Jockey Who Won the Triple Crown
description: Johnny Longden, the British-born jockey who rode 6,032 winners in a racing career that covered nearly 40 years, including a sweep of the 1943 Triple Crown aboard Count Fleet, died yesterday in Banning, Calif. It was his 96th birthday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELMAN, ROSE
description: EDELMAN-Rose. The Officers, Board and Staff of The American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of Rose Edelman, beloved mother of Sandra Hittman of Baltimore, a Technion Guardian and devoted supporter of the ATS & Technion-Israel Institute of Technology. Mrs. Hittman's late husband, Fred, was president of the Baltimore Chapter of ATS. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Sandy, and the entire Edelman and Hittman families. The American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Evelyn Berger, President Lawrence S. Jackier, Chairman, Board of Directors Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President Ivan Stern, President, Baltimore Chapter

title: Holiday on Monday -- Presidents' Day
description: NEW YORK

title: MORGAN CUTS CHIEF'S STOCK AND OPTIONS BONUS IN HALF
description: The annual stock and options bonus of William B. Harrison Jr., the chief executive of J. P. Morgan Chase, was cut in half after profit fell for a second year. J. P. Morgan awarded Mr. Harrison 316,873 stock options valued at $2.3 million, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. That compares with options worth $4.8 million a year earlier. He also received 105,625 shares of common stock worth $2.3 million, down from $5.2 million. Compensation for Mr. Harrison and his counterparts at other firms is falling after the first back-to-back declines in industry profits in at least 12 years.

title: Millar Is Returned to Marlins
description: In a resolution that sends everything back to the beginning, Outfielder Kevin Millar was freed from his agreement with the Chunichi Dragons last night and returned to the roster of the Florida Marlins. The next step, a lawyer close to the situation said, will be for the Marlins to sell or trade Millar to the Boston Red Sox, who want him to play first base.

title: Away From Darkness Into Radiant Light
description: You can go home again, at least in modern dance. That was the subliminal message of a glowing performance by Elisa Monte Dance this week at the Joyce Theater. Ms. Monte has re-established her company as the single-choreographer troupe it was at its founding in 1981. As a result, there is a fresh, vital new look to her work, particularly in her new ''Light Lies'' and in her signature ''Treading.''

title: Corrections
description: A credit line on the front page of Circuits on Thursday, for an illustration with the article about data trapped on old computers, was reproduced illegibly. The illustrator was Matt Collins.

title: U.S. TRIES TO EASE JITTERS ON TERROR
description: The Bush administration tried today to calm a jittery public after a week of heightened terrorism warnings, with Homeland Security Secretary Tom Ridge saying that ''we just don't want folks sealing up their doors or sealing up their windows.'' Senior administration officials said the government had received no new intelligence in recent days to suggest an imminent attack.

title: Sports of The Times; Age Can Be An Asset On the Mound
description: MORE oldies, please. More near-ancient warriors, with receding hairlines and bags under their eyes and bulges above their waists. More crafty veterans who are hanging on for a last shot, for that elusive milestone, for the redemption of one championship ring.

title: Agonizing Decision Awaits if Root Cause of Disaster Remains Elusive
description: Hard as they try and long as they take, NASA engineers may never isolate the exact, root cause of the Columbia's fatal disintegration.

title: Coke Bottler Narrows Loss
description: Coca-Cola HBC, Europe's biggest bottler of Coke drinks, said today that its pretax loss narrowed in the fourth quarter as it sold more single-serve bottles and cans that command higher margins.

title: Nations Join In an Effort To Investigate PVC Prices
description: Regulators from the United States, the European Union, Canada and Japan have made coordinated raids on 14 companies that are suspected of possibly fixing the price of chemicals used to manufacture PVC, a plastic material used to make pipes.

title: Michelin's Briton Keeps France's Cuisine Haute
description: DEREK BROWN strides into the room, all brisk self-assurance, firm handshake, impeccable tailoring, dossier-laden assistant four paces behind. A prosperous banker, perhaps, or a clever chap in the City.

title: Kid Gavilan, 77, Welterweight Champion in the Early 50's
description: Kid Gavilan, who came out of the Cuban sugar fields to become the world welterweight champion of the early 1950's, displaying a flashy style that featured his signature bolo punch, died Thursday at a hospital in Miami. He was 77.

title: DYNEGY AGAIN RESTATES INCOME FOR 2001 AND 2002
description: Dynegy, the energy supplier, said yesterday that it was revising financial statements for the third time since November, with $24 million of changes to net income for 2001 and 2000. Net income was reduced by $11 million for 2001 and $13 million for 2002 in amended filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company said. The changes primarily involve the company's ''forward power curve methodology,'' it said. Dynegy restated net income for 1999 to 2001 in November and in January.

title: FLEMING WINS CONTRACT TO SUPPLY CONVENIENCE STORES
description: Fleming, the grocery distributor, said yesterday that it had won a contract to supply 114 convenience stores for ConocoPhillips in five states. The agreement, which begins in April, will generate about $35 million a year in sales, Fleming said. The stores will be added to an existing contract to supply more than 700 Phillips 66 and Circle K outlets owned by ConocoPhillips. Fleming, which is based in Lewisville, Tex., is trying to add customers as it ends deliveries to Kmart next month. Kmart accounted for about 20 percent of Fleming's third-quarter sales and was the company's biggest customer.

title: Her Weight Is Low; Her Throws Are Long
description: Laura Gerraughty has this weight problem. She is eating six meals a day, 3,500 to 4,000 calories in all, and is still having trouble gaining weight.

title: In Performance
description: CLASSICAL

title: First Mammal Clone Dies; Dolly Made Science History
description: Dolly, the sheep who made history as the first clone from a mammal, died yesterday in Edinburgh. She was 6.

title: 4 in Radical Group of 70's Are Sentenced in Murder
description: In an emotionally wrenching hearing that took the authorities nearer to closing the books on the radical Symbionese Liberation Army, four former members of the group were sentenced today to state prison terms ranging from six to eight years for the murder of a bank customer during a robbery nearly 28 years ago.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the risk to European-American commercial ties posed by the divisions over Iraq omitted the given name of the chairman of the German office of the Lazard Freres investment bank, who commented on the possibility that American investments could be withdrawn from Germany. He is John Kornblum.

title: It's True. Winter Has Its Die-Hard Fans.
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: INDIANA: SENTENCE IN VIDEOTAPED HITTING A woman caught on a department store security video hitting her 4-year-old daughter in a parking lot pleaded guilty and was given a year of probation and fined $500. The woman, Madelyne Toogood, 26, could have received up to three years in prison for battery. The case drew nationwide attention in September after television stations broadcast the videotape, which showed Ms. Toogood repeatedly hitting and shaking her daughter, Martha, who is now 5. Martha is living with her maternal grandmother while Ms. Toogood tries to regain custody. (AP)

title: New Zealand Forced to Bail Out of America's Cup Opener
description: After all the innovations the lightweight boom, the 22-foot-long keel bulb, the high-tech rig -- the fate of Team New Zealand today came down to the performance of the most primitive piece of onboard gear: the bucket.

title: Trying to Walk the Line Between Fear and Ridicule
description: Bush administration officials acknowledge that they are still learning how to strike the right balance between encouraging people to take prudent precautions without crying like Chicken Little. And Tom Ridge, the secretary of homeland security, showed this week that they were still struggling to get it right.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Ted Perry, the founder of Hyperion Records, misspelled the first name of a singer his company recorded. She is Arleen Augr, not Arlee.

title: Contrasting Sound and Words In Schubert and Barber
description: Emerson Quartet

title: INSIDE
description: Walt Rostow Is Dead

title: Republicans in Senate Preparing Agenda With a Surgeon's Touch
description: Republican Senate leaders unveiled a legislative agenda today that mixed tax cuts with an unusually wide variety of health issues, showing the influence of Senator Bill Frist, the surgeon who is their new majority leader.

title: Critical of Judge's Ruling, Antiwar Protesters Brace for Rally
description: Spelling out phrases like ''war is terrorism'' on protest signs and making arrangements for demonstrators to ride trains and buses into Manhattan, antiwar organizers spent yesterday preparing for today's rally on the East Side, a few blocks from the United Nations -- a gathering they said should have included a march.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SOKOLOW, MEL
description: SOKOLOW-Mel. We adore you, we miss you, and we are inspired by you. Love and hugs forever, Diane, Betsy, Alec and Sam

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: CHARGES IN SPICE GIRL PLOT Five men were charged with conspiracy to kidnap Victoria Beckham, a former Spice Girls star and the wife of David Beckham, the Manchester United football captain. The five will be tried later in connection with the foiled plan, which was uncovered in November by undercover reporters from the tabloid News of the World, who tipped off the police. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: The Iraq Crisis: In Search of an Exit
description: To the Editor:

title: Joy and Anger Greet List of Top City Schools
description: Public School 321 in Park Slope made the list, but the middle school that many of its graduates attend, M.S. 51, did not. Public School 87 on the Upper West Side made it, but not the Computer School, a small alternative school in the same neighborhood.

title: Review/Fashion; Playing Pretend Or Growing Up
description: Returning home from a fashion show one evening this week, I peeked over the shoulder of a college-age woman seated next to me on the subway. She was looking skeptically at a magazine on her lap, which was open to an article titled ''Is 40 Sexier than 20?'' The answer to that question, the editors had determined, was a resounding yes. Illustrating their conclusion were pictures of bikini-clad women on the precipice of life's fifth decade side by side with those of women younger by half.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDIN, PAUL
description: GOLDIN-Paul. At age 81, on February 12, 2003. Beloved husband of Bernice. Devoted father of Steven & Rochelle. Father-in-law of Marjorie. Loving grandfather of Russell and Brian. A gentle and honorable man, he was loved and will be missed by all. Services will be held on Sunday, 10 AM, at I.J. Morris Funeral Chapel, 46 Greenwich Street, Hempstead, New York.

title: Exuberant and Somber, Both at Byron's Invitation
description: Leon Botstein and the American Symphony Orchestra, performing at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday afternoon, invited their audience to think about what it means to be Byronic -- or at least what it meant to be Byronic in the middle of the 19th century, when Schumann wrote his music for Byron's poem ''Manfred'' and Liszt his symphonic poem ''Tasso,'' after another of the poet's works.

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: SUBSIDY IS SUFFICIENT, AMTRAK SAYS Amtrak, the nation's passenger railroad, said it could maintain all its service this year even though Congress, in approving $1.05 billion in subsidies to it on Thursday, gave it $150 million less than the railroad's officials had said it needed to continue operations. "The amount appropriated by Congress only reinforces that sustaining Amtrak operations will be an ongoing challenge," the railroad said in a statement. Lawmakers allowed Amtrak to defer payment on a $100 million loan granted by the Bush administration in last summer's budget crisis. (Reuters)

title: Gay Couples Pop Big Question, But the States' Reply Is the Same
description: When the Rev. Troy D. Perry and his partner went to the marriage bureau today, they knew that the odds were not in their favor. But what better time than Valentine's Day to try?

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about the fashion designer Cynthia Rowley referred incorrectly to an industry term for an individual product listing. It is SKU -- for stock keeping unit; ''skew'' is the pronunciation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACCOCIO, FRANK
description: SACCOCIO-Frank. On February 13th, 2003. Beloved husband of Marian. Loving father of Robert, John, Sandra, Barbara and the late Frank. Dear brother of Ann Santelli and the late Paul and John. Cherished grandfather of six grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Memorial service Sunday, February 16 at 11AM at Redden's Funeral Home, 325 West 14th Street, New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOTSILIBAS, DAVIS, JAMES
description: KOTSILIBAS - DAVIS - James. There is a certain fizz missing. We will toast you every month. Cheers and love, The Champagne Club. Carol, Mary, Stephen

title: The Death Penalty: A Witness for The Prosecution
description: ''I'll just give you a moment to reflect,'' the actress playing Sunny Jacobs says to the audience near the end of ''The Exonerated,'' the wrenching Off Broadway documentary play about six innocent people released after years on death row. ''From 1976 to 1992,'' she says, ''just remove that entire chunk from your life, and that's what happened.''

title: Industrial Production Rises 0.7%
description: Though consumers remain the economy's main engine, figures released yesterday suggest that companies are starting to contribute as well. New jobs, however, may still be a distant prospect.

title: The Fundamental Right to March
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, BILL
description: KRAMER-Bill. The National Board of Hadassah, WZOA, mourns the death of Bill Kramer, husband of Sylvia Kramer, our esteemed colleague. Our heartfelt condolences go to the entire family. May his memory be for a blessing. Bonnie Lipton, Nat'l President

title: Jury Gives 20-Year Term In Murder of Husband
description: A jury sentenced Dr. Clara Harris to 20 years in prison today for attacking and killing her husband with her car in a hotel parking lot near where they were wed 11 years ago on St. Valentine's Day.

title: It's True. Winter Has Its Die-Hard Fans.
description: To the Editor:

title: Shelter, as Distinct From Tax Shelter
description: There is one impressive quality to President Bush's budgeting plan, with its outsized tax cuts and deficits: His social planners still manage to keep their eye on the sparrow out there, aiming to squeeze a rent rise from some of the poorest Americans who live in public housing. The proposed increase amounts to mere budgetary breakage in comparison with the big numbers for the rolling red ink and the second wave of upper-bracket tax cuts at the heart of the Bush plan. But it is a striking example of the administration's range of priorities: to be further easing the tax burden at the high end while pointedly ratcheting up the revenue for shelter required from the least of us.

title: APPEALS COURT BLOCKS SALE OF DRUG BY RIVAL OF GLAXO
description: The Court of Appeal in Britain banned Apotex Inc. from selling its form of GlaxoSmithKline's best-selling drug until court hearings are held over the patent. Apotex, which is based in Toronto, had challenged a November ruling by a lower court preventing it from selling the drug, Paxil. The drug, a depression and anxiety treatment called Seroxat in Britain, had sales of 2 billion ($3 billion) in 2002. Glaxo, which is based in Brentford, England, is currently defending a United States patent for Paxil in a Chicago court against a challenge by Apotex, which makes generic drugs. A victory by Apotex could cut revenue from Paxil by 80 percent or more within a month, Glaxo has said.

title: Walt Rostow, Adviser to Kennedy and Johnson, Dies at 86
description: Walt W. Rostow, an economic historian who became one of the principal architects and passionate defenders of the Vietnam War as an adviser to Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson, died on Thursday night at a hospital in Austin, Tex., where he lived. He was 86.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Merrill Raises Investment
description: Merrill Lynch said it would invest an additional 20 billion yen ($167 million) in a joint venture with the bank UFJ Holdings to manage UFJ's nonperforming loans. In total, Merrill plans to invest 120 billion yen ($994 million). A banker from Merrill will also lead the venture, which will help sell 1.4 trillion yen in loans. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Charge Against Berlusconi Is Dismissed
description: An Italian judge dismissed a false accounting charge against Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, citing a new law that limits the statute of limitations for such cases. But Mr. Berlusconi's legal troubles continue, as he faces more serious criminal charges of bribery in an ongoing Milan trial. In the accounting case, Mr. Berlusconi and more than 20 of his business partners had been accused of running a billion-dollar slush fund through his Fininvest holding company, but a law passed by Mr. Berlusconi's government reduced the time allowed for accounting fraud investigations. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Lavin Senses End Approaching With the Bruins
description: Steve Lavin watched U.C.L.A. make another turnover, watched Arizona turn it into another resounding dunk during a splurge of 21 straight points on Thursday, and looked as if he wanted to say something. He opened his mouth, but nothing came out. Then he tried again, opening it a little wider, but Lavin either could not speak or did not know what to tell his players.

title: French Minister Delivers Appeal For More Time
description: Following, as translated by the United Nations and recorded by Federal News Service Inc., are excerpts from remarks by Foreign Minister Dominique de Villepin of France to the United Nations Security Council yesterday after reports by the chief weapons inspectors. A complete transcript is online at nytimes.com/international.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OREFICE, LILLIAN (BERN STEIN)
description: OREFICE - Lillian (Bern stein). Of Brooklyn; February 1, 2003. She is survived by her daughters and sons-in-law, Rachel and Ted Wilson, and Judi and Paul Heidel. She also leaves three grandchildren. Services were on February 7. Mom, we all loved you so much, and we will always remember your generous nature and independent spirit.

title: With Its Nuances, Iraq Report Can't Resolve U.N. Stalemate
description: If the United Nations inspectors had a little bit for everybody in their reports today, they did not have enough of anything to resolve the stalemate in the Security Council, European analysts and political figures said.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABBINO, MITCHELL
description: RABBINO-Mitchell. Central Synagogue of New York mourns with great sadness the passing of our esteemed and beloved Past President Mitch Rabbino. With a great love of Judaism, he led our congregation with dignity and vision. Mitch was a learned man with a fierce loyalty and dedication to our synagogue. Our clergy, leadership, and entire membership will remember Mitch with deep affection and extend condolences to Skit, their children Alissa, David and Hal, and their families. May his memory be a blessing. Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi Samuel Wasserman, Pres

title: Mayor Trims Money for Arts But Donates Own $10 Million
description: There are times when disgruntled New Yorkers, frustrated by crippling budget cuts, are known to implore the billionaire mayor to open his checkbook and help plug the city's budget gap.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bank's Profit Triples
description: The French bank Crdit Lyonnais said that net profit more than tripled in the fourth quarter, helped by strong retail growth. Fourth-quarter net profit was 241 million euros ($261 million), up from 78 million euros ($84.5 million) a year earlier. For the year, net profit rose 5 percent, to 853 million euros ($924 million). The chairman, Jean Peyrelevade, said earnings should continue to rise in 2003 if economic conditions did not deteriorate. The results improve its case for a planned merger with a French rival, Crdit Agricole. The plan is being reviewed by the French bank regulator. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Comforts of Home Help Nets Improve Mind-Set
description: Before the game, Byron Scott was in a bad mood. With time to think about the Nets' back-to-back losses this week, he found himself wondering if his team had become too soft and comfortable. And when Kenyon Martin was scratched from the lineup because of a sprained left knee, Scott's mood worsened.

title: It's True. Winter Has Its Die-Hard Fans.
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITCHELL, NATALIE
description: MITCHELL-Natalie. Beloved wife of the late Mannie. Devoted mother of Patricia Mitchell and Jay Mitchell and mother - in - law of David Marell and Tricia Townsend. Cherished grandmother of Gary Mitchell, Betsy Mencher, Gabrielle Mitchell-Marell, Emily Mitchell-Marell and Alexander Mitchell and great grandmother of Julia Mencher. Services Sunday, 12 Noon, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: U.S.O.C. Criticized Over Cost Efficiency
description: Documents provided yesterday by the United States Olympic Committee to John Hancock Financial Services, a major Olympic sponsor, show that the U.S.O.C. depends heavily on the International Olympic Committee for its funding.

title: South Koreans Visiting North, Despite Tensions
description: An all-girl brass band with rank upon rank of matched hairstyles and gold-piped blazers -- greeted 22 tour buses from South Korea that rumbled past barbed wire and antitank barriers today on a new dirt crossing through the demilitarized zone.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: W. W.GRAINGER INC., Lake Forest, Ill., a supplier of building maintenance products, said it agreed to acquire a direct marketing unit from the closely held Gempler's, Belleville, Wis., a supplier of agriculture and maintenance products. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHILL, LIBBIE
description: CHILL-Libbie. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the mother of its distinguished member, Mr. Daniel Chill. May his entire family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion & Jerusalem. Ari Berman, Rabbi Andrew Mendes, President Rachel Lurie, Sisterhood

title: Antiwar Marchers Are Hoping They Can Change Blair's Mind
description: Hundreds of thousands of peace demonstrators have gathered in European capitals to march on Saturday against the United States-led campaign that threatens war in Iraq. But nowhere is a huge turnout so politically fraught as it is in London.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the risk to European-American commercial ties posed by the divisions over Iraq omitted the given name of the chairman of the German office of the Lazard Frres investment bank, who commented on the possibility that American investments could be withdrawn from Germany. He is John Kornblum.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR GAINS. The dollar rose as Hans Blix, the co-chief United Nations weapons inspector, asked for more time to determine whether Iraq had disarmed. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0794, down from $1.0834.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Steel Maker Posts Profit
description: ThyssenKrupp, the German steel and heavy industry giant, posted a profit in its most recent quarter, reversing a loss from a year earlier, after raising steel prices. The company said it earned 81 million euros ($87.8 million) as sales rose 4.3 percent, to 8.7 billion euros ($9.42 billion). Pretax profit in the period, which ended Dec. 31 and was the first quarter of ThyssenKrupp's fiscal year, was 141 million euros ($153 million), but that fell short of analysts' forecasts. New orders were up 2 percent, at 9 billion euros, the company said. The company said it expected a significant increase in earnings in the second quarter and aimed to achieve a substantial improvement in pretax profit for the year. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: NASA OFFICIAL SAYS HE HELD OUT HOPE IN FINAL MOMENTS
description: The NASA official in charge of shuttle Columbia's re-entry said today that despite the accumulating signs of trouble aboard the spacecraft as it crossed the southwestern United States, he had remained confident that it would land safely.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYMAN, HERBERT A.
description: HYMAN-Herbert A. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Herbert A. Hyman, beloved father of Rabbi Fred A. and Tova Hyman; grandfather of Talya, Rachel and Rebecca. To them and his wife, Stella, brothers, Jerrold and Joseph; sister, Leora, we extend our deepest sympathy. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President

title: UNION SAYS UNITED IS SEEKING GREATER COST CUTS
description: United Airlines, the world's second-largest carrier, has increased its annual target for labor cost savings to $2.56 billion from $2.4 billion, its flight attendants' union said yesterday. United, based in Chicago, also asked flight attendants to contribute a greater share of those cost cuts, asking the workers for $314 million, the United Association of Flight Attendants said in a statement. The company, owned by the UAL Corporation, also wants to eliminate thousands of flight attendant jobs as it transfers 30 percent of flight capacity to a new low-cost airline unit, the union said. The company could not be reached immediately for comment. United filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in December and has been in negotiations with all of its unions to lower costs.

title: Beliefs; The new archbishop of Canterbury is known for taking stands, and often stirring controversy.
description: No doubt about it, the Most Rev. Rowan Williams, who will be formally enthroned as archbishop of Canterbury on Feb. 27, makes good copy.

title: The Iraq Crisis: In Search of an Exit
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Eases Ban on AIDS Money to Pro-Abortion Groups Abroad
description: President Bush has decided to allow organizations that promote or perform abortions in poor countries to qualify under some circumstances for part of the $15 billion he has proposed to fight AIDS in Africa and the Caribbean, an administration official said tonight.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Plans To Extract Leaking Oil
description: The Spanish government will try to pump out 37,500 metric tons of toxic fuel oil slowly leaking from the oil tanker Prestige, which sank in more than two miles of water in November, polluting much of the northern Spanish coastline. Scientists seeking a solution to leaks of fuel from the wreck believe the operation would cost around $249 million. If pumping the fuel to the surface proves impossible, the scientific committee set up to advise the government has proposed covering the halves of the wreck with a concrete shell, which would cost about $141 million. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: Powell Calls for U.N. to Act on Iraq and Meets Deep Resistance
description: The chief United Nations weapons inspectors today reported some progress in Iraq, and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell faced deep resistance to his call for a Security Council decision to authorize military force.

title: Iraqi Minister, Visiting Pope, Warns Europe That a War Would Be Seen as Anti-Muslim
description: The Iraqi deputy prime minister, Tariq Aziz, warned European countries today not to join or support an American-led military strike against his country, saying that it would be seen as a crusade against Muslims and have bitter consequences.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZOWITZ, MAX
description: KATZOWITZ-Max, 88. On February 14, peacefully and with dignity. Beloved father of Adele Hoffman and Lauren Katzowitz Shenfield, loving father-in-law of Barry Hoffman and Marc Shenfield. Services, Sunday, 10:00 AM, Riverside Mount Vernon Chapel, 21 West Broad Street. 914-664-6800.

title: Here's the Beef. So, Where's the Butcher?
description: Over the summer, a new Pathmark supermarket opened in a fast-growing corner of Staten Island. From the outside, it looks unremarkable. But inside, it holds the latest in supermarket meat -- steaks and cutlets that are not merely someone's future meal, but byproducts of the industry's battle to keep up with Wal-Mart, its biggest rival.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Rushdie Death Sentence Is Renewed
description: The hard-line Revolutionary Guards renewed a death sentence issued 14 years ago by the founder of the Islamic revolution, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, against the British author Salman Rushdie for his book ''The Satanic Verses,'' the Islamic Republic News Agency reported. In a statement, the Revolutionary Guards said, ''The edict was irrevocable.'' Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: McGreevey Seeks Unified Agency to Run 2 Main Toll Roads
description: Trying to set into motion an idea that has been proposed and abandoned by several of his predecessors, Gov. James E. McGreevey announced legislation today to combine the operations of the state's two main toll roads.

title: Security Costs Add Burden To a City Short on Cash
description: At a time of tight budgets for New York City and its emergency services, hospitals, utilities and transportation agencies, the cost of extra security in the last week as a result of the federal terrorism alert is expected to run into many millions of dollars, including about $1 million for the police alone.

title: Project Alabama Is All Business
description: All the folksy Americana attached to the design company Project Alabama is cloying enough that, by rights, it should make a gorge rise. Press reports on the company -- founded two years ago in Florence, Ala., by a native of the town, Natalie Chanin, a former filmmaker, and her partner, Enrico Marone-Cinzano -- invariably refer to the 120 Southerners who sew the clothes as ''ladies.'' Rarely do the reports fail to point out that the women infuse their work with affection (they ''love their threads,'' to quote Ms. Chanin) and that they tend to use their earnings to buy objects that strike city sophisticates as quaintly rustic. ''Last Christmas I bought him a new shotgun with the money I made,'' one of the home-sewers told Vogue. Cue in the Loretta Lynn.

title: Russia Moves Toward a Breakup of Its Vast Electricity Network
description: Russia took another step toward one of its most ambitious economic overhauls today, when the lower house of Parliament approved legislation that allows the breakup of the country's vast electricity network.

title: Mixed Picture On Bankruptcies
description: More bankruptcies were filed in the United States in 2002 than in any previous year as the sluggish economy made it harder for many people and businesses to repay debts, a government report said today.

title: City Hall Memo; Bloomberg The Warrior Has Begun To Emerge
description: Whatever terrorist attacks might await New York City, the events that followed Sept. 11, 2001, have sealed in history Rudolph W. Giuliani's place as wartime healer. Mr. Giuliani, who left the mayor's office in January 2002, earned international recognition for leading and comforting a broken city after the World Trade Center attack, a role he appeared to savor above eight years of other mayoral duties.

title: Oil Barge Spills Thousands of Gallons in Sound

title: Hibernation Helpers
description: Perhaps because of centuries of experience sleeping in drafty bedrooms with poor heating, Europeans excel at finding stylish ways to stay warm while they sleep (witness the now ubiquitous down duvet). This winter, a few more cozy bed accessories found their way over the Atlantic. At Caravane Chambre 19 in Paris, a sleeping bag made of whisper-thin silk retains heat between the sheets. The bag ($31 at www.caravane.fr) comes in many colors and folds into a tiny pouch, making it handy for travelers who don't like the feel of hotel sheets. The bag also has a flap that covers a bed pillow.

title: Fixing the Shuttle Inquiry
description: Investigation of the Columbia disaster moved into a new phase last week when a special board took charge of the inquiry and Congress began its own hearings. These were important steps to broaden the inquiry beyond NASA's own technical investigations. But we remain concerned that the board now in charge still lacks the independence needed to give its findings maximum credibility.

title: Forget Diversity
description: James Traub (The Way We Live Now, Feb. 2) has identified the crux of the issue for college-admission officials, that ''the problem is minority access to elite institutions, not white access to minority students.'' But he has addressed only half of the problem: what about those who benefit from such ''critical mass'' admission policies and achieve that access? Often, once these students arrive on campus, they seek out like-minded students and effectively segregate themselves in clubs, classes and residence halls. It is not racist that they do so, but simply human nature. However, when campuses discourage such activity for the sake of collegiate harmony, offended parties cite their right to intellectual freedom.

''I knew his firehouse was in downtown Brooklyn and that he was a singer, so I thought it would be a nice thing to do.''

title: Mrs. Myles Went to Washington
description: About a week before the State of the Union address, I got a page from a 202 number. I thought, I'll call when I get home and kind of forgot about it. Then, after I left church Thursday, I retrieved my messages. One said: ''Hello, I'm trying to reach Tonja Myles. This is Jim Towey from the White House. Please call me back at your earliest convenience.'' I told myself, This is a joke. But then I remembered the 202 call on my pager, so I called him back. He had come across an article that was done on my husband and me and our work ministering to people with drug, sex and gambling addictions at our church in Baton Rouge. He said: ''Look, I'll call you back: I'm just really interested in what you guys are doing. This is what faith-based initiatives are all about, helping people who can't help themselves.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERG, SEYMOUR, M.D.
description: BERG-Seymour, M.D. 4/3/2110/12/02. Seymour Berg, M.D. died on October 12, 2002 at Grosvenor Park Nursing Home in Salem, MA, after a long illness. He was born on April 3, 1921 in the Bronx, to Gustave Berg and Anna Levine Berg. He graduated in 1937 from DeWitt Clinton High School in the Bronx, received a B.A. from N.Y.U. College of Arts and Science in 1941, and obtained a medical degree from N.Y.U. School of Medicine in 1945. After an internship at City Hospital on Welfare Island, he served as 1st Lieutenant and then Captain in the Army Medical Corps AUS, at the V.A. Hospital in Sheridan, WY, where he met his future wife of 33 years, Margaret Irene (Peggy) Walden. Dr. Berg did his residency in psychiatry at Bellevue Psychiatric Hospital, and remained on staff there for over 30 years, ultimately serving as Psychiatric Unit Chief of Ward No. 6 for many years. During that time, he also taught at the N.Y.U. School of Medicine and Hunter College-Bellevue School of Nursing, and maintained a part-time private practice. Dr. Berg served as Honorary Surgeon in Psychiatry to the New York City Police Department and Consulting Psychiatrist to the Triboro Bridge & Tunnel Authority and The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Dr. Berg was a member of the American, New York and Massachusetts Medical Associations, a member and Fellow of the American Psychiatric Association, a member of the Association for Research in Nervous and Mental Disease and the Society of Biological Psychiatry, and a Diplomate Member and Member of the Council of the Section on Psychiatry & Neurology of the Pan American Medical Association. He also served on the editorial board of the medical journal ''Behavioral Neuropsychiatry''. Dr. Berg was most proud of his teaching and his early research on electroshock therapy. Dr. Berg and his wife Peggy raised their four children in Lake Success, New York, where they lived for 28 years. Peggy predeceased him in 1981; he was later married for several years to Florence Preschel. He was an avid power boater, and was active for many years in the Sands Point Yacht Club (serving as Commodore in 1975), and the Bayshore Power Squadron. Dr. Berg is survived by his daughters Deborah Berg of Seattle, WA, Sherry Berg of Newburyport, MA, Mary Moreau of Waterbury, CT, his son G. David Walden-Berg of Oakland, CA, his brother Sheldon (Buddy) Berg of Northvale, NJ, grandchildren Tyler Fey, Cooper Neal, Hannah Moreau and Esther Moreau, nieces Eileen Berg and nephews Gary Berg, Gerald Berg and Jeffrey Berg. A private service was held and, at his request, his ashes will be strewn in the Long Island Sound. The family requests that any memorial donations be made to the N.Y.U. School of Medicine Office of Development, specifying that the funds be used for research relating to strokes or dementia.
