The back seats of taxicabs used to be a place where TV was not -- where you could, if you wished, let your mind drift or becalm itself. Supermarkets were another -- shopping alone, you could glide through their fish-tank fluorescence in your own little world. And the back seats of family vehicles were another. Anything could go on there -- sibling fights, tearful reconciliations, the vouchsafing of sexual information, the grinding of fast food into upholstery -- but none of it was broadcast; all of it was yours.

title: Elizabeth Uzielli, Dennis O'Donnell
description: Elizabeth Anne Uzielli, the daughter of Anne Dubonnet Shaio of New York and the late Philip Uzielli, was married yesterday to Dennis Charles O'Donnell, a son of Margaret O'Donnell of Toms River, N.J., and the late Charles P. O'Donnell. Canon Petero A. N. Sabune performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Hibernation Helpers
description: Perhaps because of centuries of experience sleeping in drafty bedrooms with poor heating, Europeans excel at finding stylish ways to stay warm while they sleep (witness the now ubiquitous down duvet). This winter, a few more cozy bed accessories found their way over the Atlantic. At Caravane Chambre 19 in Paris, a sleeping bag made of whisper-thin silk retains heat between the sheets. The bag ($31 at www.caravane.fr) comes in many colors and folds into a tiny pouch, making it handy for travelers who don't like the feel of hotel sheets. The bag also has a flap that covers a bed pillow.

title: A Sports Dad Speaks Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Peking Duct Tape
description: After a recent U.N. session on the Iraq crisis, I asked a Bush aide how China was behaving. ''The Chinese?'' the official said. ''They don't think they have a dog in this fight.''

title: Uproar As Law Bites Dogs
description: AS so often happens when the rights of humans and animals clash, the debate over what would normally be considered frivolous has taken on more serious overtones, at least for some. And so as residents of this Bergen County community of 8,914 people, 397 registered dogs, 144 registered cats and an undetermined number of geese, squirrels and raccoons, confront that most profound question -- where is a dog to relieve itself? -- they are engaging in much soul searching as well as sole searching.

title: If the Rules Are Changed, Will Options Disappear?
description: WOULD a new accounting rule requiring companies to take a charge against earnings for option grants really make stock options an endangered species?

title: After a Weekend of Protests, Blair Looks Lonely
description: LONDON, Feb. 16  After a watershed weekend following setbacks at the United Nations and on the streets of his own capital, Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain  Washington's main ally in the effort to disarm Iraq  looked lonely today, his destiny pinned to the uncertain progress of the campaign against Saddam Hussein.

title: Jersey Meet Postponed
description: The New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association indoor Meet of Champions, scheduled for yesterday at Jadwin Gymnasium at Princeton, was postponed because of the snow and rescheduled for Saturday.

title: Ailing Tyson Continues to Prepare for Fight, but His Trainer Is Skeptical
description: An ailing Mike Tyson, who was given antibiotic shots on Friday but who was still reeling from the flu today, will nonetheless depart Sunday for Memphis and his fight next Saturday with Clifford Etienne.

title: Alta Journal; Mayor's Passion Is Protecting a Utah Ski Haven
description: He kept out the Olympics. He has kept out the snowboarders. And now, as the world seems increasingly full of uncertainty and doom, well, then, Bill Levitt will do his best to keep that out, too.

title: Swollen Joints, Sore Throat and Fever, 'Wandering' pain
description: 1. Symptoms

title: February 9-15: INTERNATIONAL; NEW BIN LADEN TAPE
description: Threatening attacks against the United States and urging Muslims to defend Iraq against an American-led invasion, the latest tape attributed to Osama bin Laden and broadcast by Al Jazeera television jangled the frayed nerves of Americans already fearful that a terror attack might be imminent. Senior Bush administration officials like Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said the tape buttressed the case for military action against Saddam Hussein, saying it showed Mr. bin Laden was ''in partnership with Iraq.'' David Johnston

title: Private Sector; Aiming at Hearts, Not Wallets
description: GENE CASE said he was feeling a bit like Roy Hobbs, the character in ''The Natural,'' Bernard Malamud's novel, who disappears from baseball only to miraculously return decades later with his swing intact.

title: Bronze Star: Gregg LeFevre Is the City's Busiest Public Sculptor
description: NEW YORKERS with an eye for public art often point to the pre-eminence of Augustus Saint-Gaudens, the sculptor who gave Grand Army Plaza its statue of William Tecumseh Sherman and Cooper Square its -- what else? -- Peter Cooper. Other critics praise Daniel Chester French or Frederick MacMonnies, who separately sculptured their share of civic monuments in the early 1900's.

title: Habitats/112th Street Near Frederick Douglass Boulevard; Architect Couple Build A New House in Harlem
description: JOAN BLUMENFELD and Bob Krone live in something extremely unusual for Manhattan, though it's no big deal anyplace else. They live in a new house.

title: February 9-15: INTERNATIONAL; KURDISH LEADER KILLED
description: Gunmen from the militant group Ansar al-Islam assassinated a Kurdish minister of Parliament and two security officials in northern Iraq. The gunmen posed as peace negotiators in sessions with the minister, finally luring him away from his security. He was killed while refining terms for a possible peace settlement between the secular government and a faction of the Islamic group, which the U.S. says is supported by both Al Qaeda and Saddam Hussein. C.J. Chivers

title: Businesswomen Get Another Advocacy Group
description: THREE years ago, Linda McCabe learned that the two brothers who owned the auto glass company where she worked in Islip planned to dissolve the business. Having worked for others throughout her career, including the Long Island Association, where she marketed a health-insurance program for members, Ms. McCabe decided the time was right to go into business for herself.

title: Ego Problems
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDMAN, ANNABEL HENRY
description: SEIDMAN-Annabel Henry. 85, of Falls Church Virginia. Passed away peacefully on February 13. Beloved wife of Bert, beloved mother of Peggy, Joan and Betsy, grandmother and step-grandmother of Kayti, Robb, Alice, Jamie and Matthew. President of the Class of 1937 of Brooklyn College. Teacher, social worker, activist. She fought for justice all her life with love, compassion, intel ligence and unmitigated persistence. Memorial service February 19, at 3 PM, at Goodwin House West, Falls Church, VA. Celebration of her life on March 12, at the National Headquarters of the AFL-CIO, Washington, DC. In lieu of flowers please contribute to the Northern Virginia Training Center, Fairfax, VA, or to the National Citizens' Coalition for Nursing Home Reform, Washington, DC.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''When there are this many people, there's a special feeling. It's as if we really have the ability to change the world.''

title: The World: Hearing Osama; Al Qaeda's Audience in Iraq
description: THE audiotape thought to carry the words of Osama bin Laden traveled the airwaves last week, imploring Muslims to wage war against supporters of the United States. The faint voice almost certainly reached a compound in Sarget, a village in northern Iraq that is out of the control of both Saddam Hussein and the pro-American Kurds who govern the region.

title: Nonprofit Groups Face Cuts and Hard Choices
description: IT has been a winter of mood swings for directors of nonprofit organizations as politicians in the county and state have wrangled over a particularly difficult budget. They have been worried, cautiously optimistic, disappointed and, finally, resigned. They attended countless budget meetings and lobbied hard for their special cases over coffee and lunch.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: WELL, what would you do if you were an unappreciated Iowa farm wife and one day, while your husband was out of town, Clint Eastwood pulled into your driveway asking for directions? You'd be helpful, of course, climb into his pickup truck, invite him in for iced tea later and have an intense four-day affair that would nourish you emotionally for the rest of your life. THE BRIDGES OF MADISON COUNTY (1995) is a good movie based on a bad book, Robert James Waller's overblown best seller. Maybe it's the cast: Meryl Streep as the farm wife and Mr. Eastwood, who also directed, as the weathered National Geographic photographer who finds his soul mate while on assignment shooting covered bridges. If nothing else, this is one of the few appealing portrayals of middle-aged lovers in recent film history -- Sunday at 8 p.m. and Saturday at 4 p.m. on Channel 9.

title: February 9-15: NATIONAL; G.O.P.'S HEALTH GOALS
description: Republican Senate leaders unveiled a legislative agenda that mixed tax cuts with an unusually wide variety of health issues, showing the influence of Senator Bill Frist, the surgeon who is their new majority leader. Many bills that Republicans plan to introduce reflect Dr. Frist's medical background, particularly a measure to combat the spread of AIDS, which has also been championed by President Bush, and one that bans a form of late-term abortion. Other medical bills would add a prescription drug benefit to Medicare, limit medical malpractice insurance costs and make it easier for drug companies to manufacture vaccines.

title: Let There Be Not So Much Light
description: Q. My partner and I live on the 12th floor of a condominium on West 57th Street. Many of our apartment windows face Seventh Avenue. Directly across the avenue from us is an apartment whose residents are raising some sort of plant that requires a great deal of artificial light. This apartment has no window coverings whatsoever, and the amount of light that shines out of the apartment is quite offensive. At various times, especially when the sun goes down, the light emanating from across the avenue is blinding. I know there are noise regulations in the city, but are there light regulations as well? . . . Daniel Sager, Manhattan.

title: Recalling the Calm Days of Yesteryear
description: DINERS nostalgic for the dining scene of 40 years ago have a new place to go. The Crestwood in Northport is a time-warp restaurant. The newcomer, where the Australian Country Inn had been, is reminiscent of places our parents and grandparents chose for special-occasion dinners.

title: Unice Lieberman, Stephan Diamond
description: Unice Beth Lieberman and Stephan Lewis Diamond are to be married today by Rabbi Jeffrey A. Wohlberg at the National Museum for Women in the Arts in Washington.

title: Latest Airport Question: You Weigh How Much?
description: Air travelers who have accustomed themselves to such intrusions as removing their shoes may have to get used to another indignity: telling their weight.

title: INSIDE
description: 4 Israeli Soldiers Killed

title: Forgotten Streak
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Riesling To Savor
description: An ounce of charming, low-alcohol Joachim Flick Rheingau riesling can woo you from boring chardonnays. Unscrew the cap, fill a glass, savor this 2001 German white's fruit and brio, then stow the liter bottle until tomorrow and the next day. (Imported by Wines for Food.) Chambers Street Wines, 160 Chambers (West Broadway), charges $10. While there, ask about Loire bargains. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: NATO Settles Rift Over Aid to Turks in Case of War
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 16  Resolving a bitter dispute that pitted the United States against France and Germany over military plans on Iraq, NATO agreed tonight to an American request to supply Turkey with equipment to defend itself in the event of a war to overthrow Saddam Hussein.

title: Paperback Advice
description: This

title: I'm Still Living in Al Bundy's America
description: AL BUNDY is my hero. He's a working-class loser who's defeated by life but refuses to lay down and die. He is stupid but wily. Deeply dissatisfied with family, fatherhood and his work as a shoe salesman, he's still proud of his name and the pitiful patch of earth he calls home. His favorite room is the toilet and his pet peeve is the French.

title: County Rates Excellent In Tobacco Control Programs
description: The American Lung Association of Hudson Valley has given Westchester a grade of A for its spending of $2.2 million last year on tobacco control programs. The money was provided by the four-year-old legal settlement with tobacco companies. According to the Lung Association, the county spent $2.37 per person on such programs. Rockland received an A, spending $2.90 per capita on tobacco control programs, more than any other county in the state.

title: A Defeat
description: To the Editor:

title: F.Y.I.
description: Come a Long Way

title: Paris, Always New
description: I ONCE spent almost a month exploring a single neighborhood in Paris, the Sixth Arrondissement. I can imagine visits to Napoleon's Paris or medieval Paris or Hemingway's Paris, and visits concentrating on cafes or flea markets. Gastronomic blowouts, too, of course, and couture shopping sprees, and museum marathons.

title: In Shuttle Disaster, Families Lost More Than Mere Heroes
description: Lani McCool's husband hid 16 large black-and-white photographs of himself around their apartment before he left, one for each day of his mission on the space shuttle Columbia.

title: He Can't Drive, but He Dreams at About 180 Miles an Hour
description: LAMOTT EBRON has a thing about cars. Fast cars, the kind that hug a road's every curve and leave smoking tread in their wake. ''For everyday, I like the luxury and handling of a Mercedes,'' he says. ''On the track, I prefer a Monte Carlo, for its speed and agility.''

title: Corrections
description: A cabaret listing on Page 41 of Arts & Leisure today for Ben Vereen and Marla Gibbs at Feinstein's at the Regency has become outdated. After the section had gone to press, the engagement was canceled.

title: Hamas Blames Israel for Gaza Blast That Killed 6
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 16  At least six members of the Palestinian group Hamas died in a mysterious explosion in Gaza City today, hours after Israel's defense minister vowed retaliation for a Hamas bombing in Gaza on Saturday that destroyed an Israeli tank and killed the four soldiers inside.

title: There's a Futures Contract for Everything (Even Iraq's Fate)
description: FEW people would disagree with the forecast that stocks would drop if war started tomorrow in Iraq. But two Stanford economics professors, Eric Zitzewitz and Justin Wolfers, go further, predicting that the market would drop 5 percent.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: STARVING TO DEATH

title: Arctic Rescue
description: By February, most stores are already filled with skimpy spring clothes. Meanwhile, real people living in real time are still facing weeks of frigid temperatures; the unfortunate soul who rips an overcoat or loses a glove can have a tough time finding a replacement. Luckily, some places that stock winter items year-round, making it possible to ride out the season in style.

title: Pilgrims Find Changes on Both Ends of Journey
description: On the way home from the hajj, his emotion-laden pilgrimage to Islam's holy shrines in Saudi Arabia, Shamsul Quadir began to worry that he might get in trouble for coming back a changed man.

title: No, You May Not Sit This One Out
description: DO they really dance 28 straight hours? No way.

title: Another Snub To Black Coaches
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Voodoo vs. 'Rubinomics'
description: Large deficits matter. Those three words sum up Alan Greenspan's testimony before Congress last week, testimony that will make it more difficult for the White House to get its proposed tax cuts enacted. That such an incontrovertible statement of basic economic thought could roil Washington and create problems for the Bush administration is an indication of how surreal, and cynical, budgetary politics have become.

title: Searching the Wings For the Fourth Tenor
description: ORDINARILY, you would not expect a concert performance of Verdi's familiar ''Forza del Destino'' to pack Carnegie Hall on a bitterly cold night, as happened last month. But the draw on this occasion -- what New York opera buffs had been buzzing about for months -- was Salvatore Licitra, the 34-year-old Italian tenor, who sang the role of Don Alvaro.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; After Long Drought, High-End Housing for Hartford
description: HARTFORD lost much of its middle and upper middle class to the suburbs in the last part of the 20th century, but there are signs that the exodus may be ending.

title: Rutgers's Offense Drops Below the Freezing Mark
description: It is understood that Rutgers is not an offensive juggernaut or anything close to one, but the ineffectiveness of its attack today was nonetheless astonishing. The Scarlet Knights scored a mere 46 points while losing to a mediocre West Virginia team, shot 32.1 percent from the floor, missed a number of crucial free throws and at times were so lethargic they seemed half asleep.

title: They Love Tango, And Are Hoping You'll Love It Too
description: FEW topics stir more passionate debate among classical music fans than crossover, which is routinely blamed for many things, including burning up the marketing budgets of classical labels while starving serious music of publicity, space on record shelves and room on the charts. Yet despite its marketing associations, crossover is often a genuine effort by classically trained musicians to embrace popular or ethnic styles.

title: In Chelsea, A Little Dal Spells Home
description: BY day, the 29th Street Deli is as generic as they come, a tiny convenience store tucked between a parking lot and a shop selling imported silk saris on a barren stretch of 29th Street known as Norman Vincent Peale Way. There's a stand of shiny produce near the front door and a selection of frozen desserts near the cash register, but nothing that would merit a second glance.

title: A One-Woman Paean To the Joy of Cooking
description: FOOD is love.

title: A Writing Life
description: ON the corkboard above Beth Ann Bauman's desk, a washed-out photograph hangs from a tack: Ms. Bauman, age 2, stares out at the camera, her blue eyes stubborn and searching, her mouth pressed into a resolute line. ''I love how stoic I look,'' she said, fingering the edge of the picture.

title: In Hollywood, the Best Young Hunks Are Imported
description: NOT since the ascendancy of Tyrone Power and Gregory Peck has Hollywood been as mesmerized by a pair of bushy male eyebrows as it is by the ebony foliage adorning the forehead of the 26-year-old Irish actor Colin Farrell.

title: In Mount Vernon, They've Got Game
description: IN Mount Vernon, everybody knows about the high school basketball team, the Knights. The team finished its regular season 20-0, won the Division 1-A championship and this weekend began the long road to perhaps another sectional and even another state championship as Section 1's top-seeded team. The Knights have won 20 sectional and 7 state basketball crowns.

title: The Outsider
description: I agree with Gary Hart that it is unfair that he continues to wear a scarlet A 15 years after the fling he was accused of having with Donna Rice, while John Poindexter and Elliott Abrams have re-entered public life without controversy (Matt Bai, Feb. 2). The political arena, however, is not governed by the same rules of evidence and devotion to justice that prevail in a court of law. Politicians who can frame their misdeeds as the unfortunate byproducts of a sincere commitment to a policy or a cause are much more readily forgiven than those who appear to be motivated by hubris or self-righteousness. Hart's decision in both 1984 and 1988 to admonish his opponents for selling their souls to venal political bosses and predatory special interests invited public condemnation when he was caught committing a moral transgression. Hart's long exile from public life demonstrates that the only thing that Americans dislike more than a hypocrite is a pious hypocrite.

title: Evelyn Waugh Kissed Me
description: ANY HUMAN HEART

title: The Efficient Way to Not See Each Other
description: I JUST finished the upgrade of our cellphones, the time every two years when I re-enlist with my provider in exchange for more minutes for less money than my previous plan. As part of the deal, I also get a new phone, one that does tricks that were not yet invented the last time I got a phone, and which I won't learn how to use until it's time to replace this one.

title: Seaport Hopes to Restore Hemingway's Boat
description: THE shipwrights and curators at Mystic Seaport have restored Franklin Delano Roosevelt's sailboat, built a replica of the schooner Amistad and spent decades preserving the Charles W. Morgan, the country's last wooden whaling ship.

title: Polish Cuisine Reminscent of Krakow
description: A HEARTY, Eastern European peasant food fix is what's offered at B&B Polish Restaurant II in Lindenhurst. It is a Weight Watcher's nightmare and a trencherman's fantasy.

description: Weeks

title: Eliza Ahn, Steven Choe
description: Eliza K. Ahn, a daughter of Yoo-Kyong Ahn and Kenneth Ahn of Chungju, South Korea, was married yesterday to Steven Kent Choe, the son of Nancy Silver of Lafayette, Calif., and Victor Choe of Liberty, N.Y. The Rev. Tony M. MacNaughton, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Crystal Plaza, a caterer in Livingston, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRACE, JOHN F.
description: GRACE-John F. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of John F. Grace, associated with The Times from 1931 until retiring in 2002.

title: High-Need Children to Lose in Pataki Cuts
description: CAROL WALSH'S pre-kindergarten class seems more playful than academic, but the 17 four-year-olds are learning how to write, read and count. They are developing fine motor skills, making decisions and solving problems.

title: W. L. Pforzheimer, 88, Dies; Helped to Shape the C.I.A.
description: Walter L. Pforzheimer, one of the founding fathers of the Central Intelligence Agency and the creator of its historical archives, died on Monday at his home in Washington. He was 88.

title: Islanders Move Up After Yashin Drops to Checking Line
description: Aleksei Yashin is now a fourth-line forward. This is what it has come to for the Islanders, who apparently do not know what else to do with their $90 million man.

title: Van Horn Returning To Scene Of Scorn
description: There was a moment late last season when Keith Van Horn was loved in New Jersey.

title: STEM-CELL BILL WITHDRAWN
description: After protests from anti-abortion groups, a bill to authorize research on stem cells from human embryos was withdrawn hours before a final vote was to be taken. The lead sponsor, Assemblyman Neil M. Cohen, said the bill would be revised to address concerns that it might permit human cloning. Laura Mansnerus

title: With Fury Silenced, Song Raised Its Voice
description: TEN years ago, a 20-year-old New Yorker named Lee Hirsch left for Johannesburg with $600 in his pocket and the phone numbers of two local contacts. Mr. Hirsch was on a mission: he had become obsessed with the popular music that had sprung up around the antiapartheid movement, and he was determined to make a film about it. If his undertaking seemed quixotic -- Mr. Hirsch was white, had never before been to South Africa and had no previous research to guide him -- well, he thought, so be it.

title: Forewarned Is Forearmed? Not Always
description: BARBARA LEY TOFFLER taught business ethics at Harvard Business School, then ran a small ethics consulting firm before joining Arthur Andersen in October 1995. She was the founder of the company's ethics consulting group.

title: Music Listings
description: Opera

title: Wide Range of Ages, Races and Parties Unite on Iraq
description: LONDON, Feb. 15  Like many people in this country, Christine Gibbon is the first to admit she is not likely to put up a fuss when things go wrong. She is not the type to raise her voice or shake her fists or take to the streets.

description: The dashing French diplomat dashed around the U.N. like a rock star.

description: THE VATICAN'S WOMEN

title: Festive Gatherings, Somber Messages, From London to Berlin
description: Like many people in this country, Christine Gibbon is the first to admit she is not likely to put up a fuss when things go wrong. She is not the type to raise her voice or shake her fists or take to the streets.

title: THREATS AND RESPONSES: THE SCENE -- Rome; A Festive Tone, But Somber Ideas
description: So many people took to the streets for an antiwar march here today that the starting time was moved up three hours to make room for protesters who kept arriving from around the country in packed train cars and buses.

title: February 9-15: NATIONAL; GREENSPAN IS GRUMPY
description: Speaking before lawmakers at a Senate committee hearing, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, cast doubt on the need for President Bush's economic stimulus plan. He rebutted many of Mr. Bush's arguments in favor of big new tax cuts, warning that budget deficits could spiral out of control, but did not criticize the specifics of the president's $674 billion proposal. But Mr. Greenspan took issue with the administration's argument that the best way to balance the budget is by promoting faster growth.

title: Benefit Cuts May Bring Deductions
description: TAXPAYERS who explore the nooks and crannies of the tax code, which is full of provisions applying to many special situations, may be able to pare their bills, both on 2002 returns and in the future.

title: Hide-And-Seek
description: 'Their job is not to play an elaborate game of hide-and-seek with Saddam,'' Prime Minister Tony Blair told Sir David Frost about the U.N. inspectors, ''where they go in and try to find the weapons and he tries to hide them.'' The game metaphor was emblematic of a considered British government position, following Foreign Secretary Jack Straw's warning in the House of Commons that ''the international community must maintain pressure on Saddam Hussein to end his games of hide-and-seek.''

title: Real Diversity In the Boardroom
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Wall: The Rarely Seen Segal
description: THE George Segal retrospective at the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum focuses on a little-known part of Segal's career: work that hangs on the wall. This includes paintings and drawings but especially the relief sculpture that he loved to make but that never captivated the public. In addition to this rarely seen work, the show also includes some of the tableaux of freestanding plaster figure groupings on which Segal's fame largely rests.

title: Praising the Lord on the Island's Airwaves
description: TO spread the gospel for her Soul Winners for Christ Ministry, Theresa Buckrham, the pastor, does not need a church. Believers receive her blessings and hear her testimony and a sermon over the airwaves. Ms. Buckrham, a nondenominational minister, preaches on Saturday afternoons from 3:15 to 3:30 on WTHE, the only gospel radio station on Long Island.

title: February 9-15: NATIONAL; JOINT ACTION ON S.U.V.'S
description: Acknowledging that sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks present serious hazards to cars, the automotive industry agreed for the first time to work together to make cars safer when hit by bigger vehicles and to make S.U.V.'s and pickups less dangerous. The industry's main lobbying group said in a letter to the Bush administration's top safety regulator that the auto makers would take steps toward voluntary standards to ensure broader deployment of air bags and to lower the bodies of large S.U.V.'s, among other measures.

title: Australia Shocks England as 88 Nations Watch on TV
description: LONDON, Feb. 15  Try as they might, the supposed superpowers of soccer cannot make history bend to their whim. That message was writ large when England, so sure it can still lord it over any team from Down Under, contrived to lose to Australia in London.

title: On a Road That Has Claimed Lives, a Push to Save Them
description: When a major thoroughfare is the scene of one or more fatal accidents, it can acquire a reputation. Boulevard of Death was the name given to Queens Boulevard a couple of years ago after a series of pedestrian fatalities; the road has since undergone changes to make it safer.

title: Sports of The Times; In an Apparent Sweetheart Deal, Beware the 'You da Man!' Chants
description: THERE were floodlights fit for a prison yard bathing Annika Sorenstam one summer night as she stood on a 14th green, reading a 25-foot putt that had the arch of a raised eyebrow on its bending line to the hole.

title: Business Shouldn't Lose The Benefit of Wisdom
description: To the Editor:

title: James Thomas Flexner, Washington Biographer, 95, Dies
description: James Thomas Flexner, a prolific and graceful writer on subjects from American art to steamboats to medicine, who achieved his greatest fame for prize-winning biographies of George Washington, died on Thursday in his Manhattan apartment. He was 95.

title: An Earlier Interview
description: To the Editor:

title: Got to Have Art and Heart
description: Feb. 10: The World Monuments Fund held its first Paul Mellon lecture series, which will deal with architecture and preservation in Britain. The event at the Frick Collection was attended by 130 guests and was followed by dinner.

title: A Short but Sweet Break in Florida
description: I WAS flopped on a raft in the pool, cocktail in hand, when the pool butler called my name. I'd asked him to sound the alarm at 3 so I could hustle over to the spa for my pedicure. But 3 o'clock came too soon: I'd just figured out how to sip my drink in a recumbent position.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THE BOY AND THE DOG

title: Fees, as Surely as Taxes, Will Rob the State of Jobs, Critics of Pataki Budget Say
description: In a letter accompanying the budget plan he released last month, Gov. George E. Pataki upheld the importance of jobs and vowed his proposal ''preserves promised tax cuts and avoids job-killing tax increases,'' so that businesses will stay in New York and flourish.

title: A New Yankee Remembers a Legend
description: When Roger Clemens leaves the Yankee Stadium bullpen after warming up before a start, it is part of his ritual to rub Babe Ruth's plaque for good luck. Clemens and Ruth have much in common -- as former Red Sox, after all -- but Ruth died years before Clemens was born.

title: Sprewell Is Resigned to Bryant's Dazzle
description: Nearly everyone in basketball was thrilled by Kobe Bryant's wicked dunk last week against the Denver Nuggets. One-on-one in transition against a defender, Bryant put the ball behind his back while crossing the lane before he put down a twisting, one-handed slam in the poor Nuggets' face.

title: AND THE WINNER IS . . .
description: Ending a contentious process, the state Sports and Exposition Authority last week chose a $1.3 billion plan, Meadowlands Xanadu, for redevelopment of the Continental Airlines Arena site in the Meadowlands Sports Complex. The vote was 9 to 2 for Xanadu, a proposal of the Mills Corporation, a mall developer from Virginia, and Mack Cali Realty, an office developer from Cranford. It would include an indoor ski slope, a children's village, a baseball stadium, four office buildings, a hotel and 700,000 square feet of retail space. A rival, Hartz Mountain Industries, said Xanadu was a mega-mall in disguise that would hurt businesses and traffic. The authority hopes construction will start by summer. A major selling point of the Xanadu plan was a promise of $160 million upfront in lease payments that would help retire debt on the arena. George James

title: Elizabeth King, William Baker
description: Elizabeth Robinson King and William Victor Baker are to be married today at the Candlewood Inn in Brookfield, Conn., where Lt. Gov. M. Jodi Rell of Connecticut will officiate.

title: Italy's Leader Balances Ambitions and Trials
description: A short while back, Italy's leading newspaper, Corriere della Sera, ran a cartoon that imagined Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi's continuing evolution. In the first panel, he was chief of state. In a later panel, he was king. Finally, years hence, he morphed into a new-era Napoleon.

title: Low Point for Money Markets
description: The paltry returns on money market accounts have fallen even lower, dropping to less than 0.8 percent, on average, for the first time.

title: Treasure Troves: A Peek at the Glories Of Private Holdings
description: IN a two-part exhibition, the Bruce Museum of Arts and Science, in Greenwich, has been lifting the veil from the private art collections of its local patrons. Last fall's ''The Pleasures of Collecting: Part 1'' presented art from the Renaissance through the 19th century, culled from the holdings of these patrons. The sequel, now on view, is ''The Pleasures of Collecting: Part II, 20th-Century and Contemporary Art.''

description: The United States' prospects for achieving a quick and clean resolution authorizing war with Iraq in the coming days dimmed suddenly after the chief weapons inspectors, Hans Blix and Mohamed ElBaradei, gave mildly positive reports on Friday on progress in their work in Iraq.

description: IT would be easy to twist ''Everything Waits to Be Noticed,'' the title of Art Garfunkel's latest recording, into a plaintive metaphor for a man who, since the breakup of Simon and Garfunkel in 1970, has been struggling to emerge from the shadow of his former partner.

title: Rudy Sablo, 84, Weight Lifter And U.S. Olympic Team Official
description: Rudy Sablo, a leading athlete, coach and administrator in American weight lifting and other sports for more than 60 years, died Feb. 4 in his home in Manhattan. He was 84.

description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Deals That Were Struck
description: WHEN a company is offered benefits through Westchester County's Industrial Development Agency, public notice is given and a public hearing is held within 30 days. If the benefits are approved, the agency enters into an agreement with the company in which the firm leases the property to be bought to the agency and then the agency leases it back. This process enables sales tax and mortgage tax abatement, and also gives the agency a degree of control. The company signs an agreement to return certain benefits if it moves jobs out of the county during the period of the agreement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ECKSTAT, JENNY
description: ECKSTAT-Jenny, 93. Widow of Charles Eckstat, on February 10, 2003. Beloved mother of Elsa Meyers; grandmother of Seth Meyers and Daniel Meyers; great grandmother of Miranda, Margeaux and Benjamin. Retired English teacher, NYC schools. Donations to the Summit Speech School, 705 Central Avenue, New Providence, N.J. 07974.

title: Nassau Tax Assessments May Violate Settlement
description: Re ''Nassau Tax System May Be Fairer, but Protests Mount'' [Feb. 2]: One significant fact is omitted with respect to the 6 percent annual limit on increases in tax assessments. The stipulated settlement between Nassau County and the New York Civil Liberties Union plaintiffs provides for assessment of all residential property so as to limit the applicability of the 6 percent cap to no more than 0.5 percent (approximately 1,800) of the homes in any assessment roll. Therefore, if the 6 percent rule were to be applied to market value, even though the plain language of the statute reads assessment, the number of homes affected would be in the many thousands and therefore in violation of the judicially ordered settlement terms.

title: From Beehive To Kitchen Table To Mass Production
description: ROXANNE QUIMBY was just looking for a little extra income when she teamed up in 1989 with Burt Shavitz, a local beekeeper, and started a kitchen-table production line to bottle honey and make beeswax candles in rural Maine.

title: A Wall Street Tribute to a Mayor (And Criticism of a Governor)
description: When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York spoke at a dinner in his honor last Monday, he was so careful not to blame state officials for the city's financial predicament that guests might have thought Gov. George E. Pataki was in the room.

title: Corrections
description: Four classical music listings on Page 41 of Arts & Leisure today for the New York Philharmonic, and a related picture, have become outdated. On Friday, after the section had gone to press, the orchestra announced that Leonard Slatkin would conduct on Wednesday through Saturday, replacing Riccardo Muti, who is ill. The program will include Respighi's ''Ancient Airs and Dances'' in place of Nino Rota's Concerto for Strings.

title: Thousands of Schools May Run Afoul of New Law
description: Jerry Krumbein, the principal of Bracher Elementary School here, delivered a dispiriting message recently: because the test scores of some students had declined, the school could be considered under a federal law as one that shortchanged students so seriously that parents could transfer them to other public schools.

title: Shared Costs
description: My brother, his wife and I rented a car for a vacation in Greece. When the bill came, my brother and his wife thought they should pay half and I should pay half. I thought we should split it three ways; they shouldn't be considered one unit just because they're married. They paid two-thirds of all restaurant bills but argued that bringing my sister-in-law did not increase the car-rental price. How should we split the costs? G.B., East Elmhurst, New York

On Tuesday, after the magazine had gone to press, the F.B.I. director, Robert S. Mueller III, testified before the Senate Intelligence Committee that it was several hundred, not 5,000.

description: Thanks to a rally on Friday, all three major stock market gauges rose for the first week in the last five.

description: LIKE Ponce de Leon hoping to splash in the Fountain of Youth, automakers seeking young customers are venturing into strange territory. Honda has crammed its hopes into a box called the Element. Toyota is turning to small cars with big speakers, called Scions. General Motors has taken the sci-fi route with its Saturn Ion, a plastic-sided capsule that could have been a prop in ''Plan 9 From Outer Space.''

title: February 9-15: NATIONAL; MIRAMAX LOADS UP
description: When the Oscar nominations were announced in Beverly Hills, the New York-based mini-studio Miramax came away with 13 nominations for ''Chicago,'' 10 for ''Gangs of New York,'' 6 for ''Frida'' and 1 for ''The Quiet American.'' And ''The Hours,'' which Miramax produced in partnership with Paramount Pictures and which is considered the race's front-runner along with ''Chicago,'' had nine nominations. description: WHEN Edward H. Braun led the 1991 management buyout at Veeco Instruments in Woodbury, he knew the company would have to branch out to cushion itself from the cyclical semiconductor industry, one of Veeco's largest markets.

title: Corrections

description: The Devils exited the ice after 20 minutes of nightmarish play tonight at Continental Arena to a loud chorus of boos for perhaps their worst period this season. They had to be expecting a tirade from their emotional coach, Pat Burns, during the intermission.

It was the Continent's biggest coordinated peace demonstration in memory and left many protesters jubilant at the show of antiwar sentiment.

title: February 9-15: INTERNATIONAL; SETBACK ON IRAQ
description: The Bush administration signaled all week that it was as determined as ever to go to war in Iraq unless Saddam Hussein disarms. But by week's end, the chances of proceeding with the support of allies in the United Nations and NATO seemed to diminish. The chief U.N. weapons inspectors reported some progress, and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell faced deep resistance to his call for a Security Council decision to authorize military force. France and Germany, in particular, demanded more time for the inspectors to complete their work, creating the biggest cleavage in the NATO alliance in a generation.

The one-inch dog biscuits ($10 at www.dogchewz.com) come in Parmesan or chicken flavor and are packaged in a diminutive gold gift box that fits neatly into the inside pocket of a handbag -- so convenient, because that's where darling Fifi spends most of her time, anyway.

title: The Man Who Mistook His Wife For a Deer
description: As a psychologist who has also been a sleep specialist for more than 16 years, I have had the opportunity to evaluate and treat many people with the sorts of parasomnias described in your article. I must take issue with the suggestion that many, if not most, complex-behavior parasomnias are neurological events. REM behavior disorder, in my experience, is often an aspect of post-traumatic stress disorder. Adult sleep terrors, to my mind, are much more likely to occur in people who experienced serious abuse as children. Nocturnal eating disorder, in my opinion, is rare in people who do not also have some form of compulsive-behavior problem in their waking lives. Further, while you can treat these problems with medications, it is certainly an open question whether the medications are correcting a ''chemical imbalance'' or simply reducing a symptom.

title: Yes, Plant Acorns, But Other Nuts, Too
description: Re the article about starting oak trees from acorns [''Springing a Mighty Oak From an Acorn,'' Cuttings, Feb. 2]: These same guidelines could be applied to more tasty nuts, like chestnuts, hazelnuts, black walnuts, hickory nuts and butternuts. If we started nut trees from seeds this year, we could harvest a hearty and nutritious addition to our breakfast in seven years, for most kinds of nuts. Buy grafted stock from a reliable nursery and eat three or four years earlier.

title: February 9-15: NATIONAL; TEXAS DENTIST GUILTY

A Texas jury found that Dr. Harris ran down her husband with her Mercedes-Benz after discovering him with the mistress he had promised to leave. She was sentenced to 20 years in prison for first-degree murder, and was also fined $10,000. The jury maintained that Dr. Harris acted with ''sudden passion'' when she killed her husband.

A native of Fujian province, on China's southeastern coast, he emigrated to Hong Kong and then, 27 years ago, came to New York and finally North Jersey. He has owned Marco-Polo's Secret for 12 years, and from time to time he still finds it necessary to race into the kitchen and take a hand with a wok. The Soviet government sent me on a concert tour of Britain in 1963, and I was -- exceptionally -- allowed to take my Icelandic-born wife and our child with me. We seized this chance to stay in the West.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; They Kept On Truckin'
description: Starting around 1963, underground comics constituted satiric and ribald alternatives to mainstream comic books and found an enthusiastic audience among young people. They also opened a frontal attack on the Comics Code Authority, which had been established in 1954 to enforce editorial standards, prohibiting visual and written depictions of crime, horror, violence, race, politics, and sex (war, however, was acceptable). The new comix (the ''x'' suggested both unconventional and taboo themes) began as mimeographed handouts, then found outlet as pages or spreads in underground tabloid newspapers, then were ultimately published as comic books and sold through head shops and record stores and on the streets. ''These cartoons were perceptive reflections of the antiwar, antiestablishment fervor of the times,'' Patrick Rosenkranz writes in his profusely illustrated and thoroughly detailed history, REBEL VISIONS: The Underground Comix Revolution, 1963-1975 (Fantagraphics, $39.95). Rosenkranz, a filmmaker who has chronicled the comix for decades, proceeds with a year-by-year narrative, using interviews with scores of publishers, editors and leading artists, including Gilbert Shelton, Rick Griffin, Victor Moscoso, R. Crumb, Kim Deitch, Trina Robbins, S. Clay Wilson and Art Spiegelman. As a movement comprising iconoclasts with individual styles and obsessions, underground comix transformed banal comics into hilariously raucous and often perverse social commentaries and inspired film, literature and the graphic novel, which today is hard to call underground. Steven Heller

Without telling the Whitney what they were up to, they had obtained permission from friends at the Modern to remove a MOMA wall fragment to install in their show. A work by Marcel Duchamp once hung in exactly this spot. The former white-walled museum gallery was now a command station for the MOMA demolition crew.

title: When Al Qaeda Calls

That Fouda looks cool in a leather jacket, a suit or traditional Pakistani garb? That he advances his career by passing on propaganda from Al Qaeda? That he is a terrific investigative reporter, despite his having concluded his report on the Sept. 11 attacks by suggesting that American authorities might have let it happen? Maass's excuse for Fouda: playing to the Arab street is something Fouda must do if he is to maintain credibility with his audience. What Maass fails to point out is that Al Jazeera and journalists like Fouda have helped create the very Arab street monster they must continue to feed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REYNOLDS, WARREN J.
description: REYNOLDS-Warren J. Publisher emeritus of PARADE Magazine, Died February 10, 2003, after a short illness, in Sarasota, FL. During his 36 years at PARADE, Reynolds was instrumental in building PARADE into the widest circulated weekly magazine in the world. Reynolds was born in Chicago in 1918 to Bradford Jay Reynolds and Bessie (BonDurant) Reynolds. He was graduated from DePauw University in Indiana in 1939, where he was a Rector Scholar. Reynolds attained the rank of lieutenant commander in the United States Navy and served in World War II as a communications officer in the Pacific. After working for Capper Publications, Inc. as a sales representative, Reynolds joined PARADE Magazine, where he became the advertising sales manager in the Chicago office. In 1960, Reynolds moved to New York City and became publisher of PARADE in 1967 until his retirement in 1983. In 1940, Reynolds married Mary Ellen Seaman of Milwaukee, WI. They were married for 55 years until Mrs. Reynolds' death while on a cruise in the Mediterranean in 1995. Reynolds is predeceased by his daughter, Linda E. Reynolds. He is survived by his children, William B. (Ivonne) Reynolds of Orange, CA, Nancy R. Davis of Rensselaer, NY, David S. (Patricia) Reynolds of Naperville, IL; seven grandchildren and one great-grandchild. A memorial service will be held at the Venice Presbyterian Church, 111 Firenze Ave. E., Venice, FL, on February 21, 11:00 AM. title: The Granny Dress
description: My grandmother Miriam Wells Byers -- a blank in my otherwise vivid memories of growing up -- saw to it that I dressed like a princess when I was little, the last time this was indisputably so. She made for me a collection of smocked dresses, some with pinafores, in two different sizes and styles, and a matching set for my dolls. Some had a tiny frill of lace around the collar, others white-cuffed sleeves embroidered at the edge. But what made Miriam's dresses different were their colors. I have often gone into children's shops that sell this type of dress -- now machine made and hideously expensive -- and wondered if mothers were in cahoots with their decorators. The colors seem chosen for the correct display of little girls in expensively tasteful rooms. Miriam, on the other hand, chose colors straight from the garden -- violent lilac, soft cornflower blue, pink as clear as sweet peas.

title: On Writers and Writing; The Color Brown
description: IT'S fashionable now to say that race is a construct -- a physical, legal, political and cultural artifact. Genetics teaches us that bloodlines cross and mingle at points we never thought possible -- or to put it another way, all DNA leads back to Africa. I say ''fashionable'' not because I disagree, but because it is clearly easier to say that race is a construct than it is to live as if it were. If you are a writer, you need to turn such a pronouncement into prose that has intellectual resonance and emotional complexity. This is what Richard Rodriguez has done in ''Brown: The Last Discovery of America.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICE, DAN (DANIEL STACEY)
description: RICE-Dan (Daniel Stacey). 76, of Madison, CT. After a long and brave battle with emphysema died peacefully at home overlooking his salt marsh January 28, surrounded by his loving family. Younger member of the New York School, an abstract impressionist, master of color and light. Admired by friends from Franz Kline to Bill Scharf and a regular part of the Cedar Gang. He lived, worked and exhibited in Manhattan for many years then moved to Connecticut nature and taught grateful students. In 1994 founded and lead the Friday Night Painters in Madison. Born June 17, 1926, Long Beach, CA. As a teenager played trumpet for AllCalifornia Orchestra, The National Youth Orchestra and Los Angeles Philharmonic. From 1939-1943 played when they were in area with big bands, Goodman, Dorsey, Shaw, Herman and Rayburn. Enlisted in the Navy on 17th birthday and volunteered in Pacific from 1943-1946 on one of twelve experimental vessels equipped with two and half times firing power of a battleship. Opening up for island invasions, Iwo Jima, Okinawa, etc. After the war he studied at UC Berkley, then Black Mountain College, NC, where he worked with artists Albers, deKooning, Rauschenberg and Motherwell. He earned a masters degree in architectecture at MIT. Survived by his daughters Hilary Dawn Rice and Shauna Rice, partner Virginia S. Foster, former wife and friend Jacqueline Miller Rice and granddaughter Jasmine. A memorial gathering will be planned for the summer. Honest, brilliant, gentle, warm, decent; he will be missed all who knew him. Contributions may be made to the Union of Concerned Scientists www.ucsusa.org, 800-666-8276, 2 Brattle Square, Cambridge, MA, or the War Resisters League, www.warresisters.org, 212-228-0450, 339 Lafayette St, NY, NY 10012.

title: 'Any Human Heart'
description: "Yo, Logan," I wrote. "Yo, Logan Mountstuart, vivo en la Villa Flores, Avenida de Brasil, Montevideo, Uruguay, America del Sur, El Mundo, El Sistema Solar, El Universo." These were the first words I wrote-or to be more precise, this is the earliest record of my writing and the beginning of my writing life-words that were inscribed on the flyleaf of an indigo pocket diary for the year 1912 (which I still possess and whose pages are otherwise void). I was six years old. It intrigues me now* to reflect that my first written words were in a language not my own. My lost fluency in Spanish is probably my greatest regret about my otherwise perfectly happy childhood. The serviceable, error-dotted, grammatically unsophisticated Spanish that I speak today is the poorest of poor cousins to that instinctive colloquial jabber that spilled out of me for the first nine years of my life. Curious how these early linguistic abilities are so fragile, how unthinkingly and easily the brain lets them go. I was a bilingual child in the true sense, namely that the Spanish I spoke was indistinguishable from that of a Uruguayan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEMAN, MARK
description: FREEMAN-Mark. Died on February 6 at age 94. Predeceased by his wife of 67 years, Polly Allen. Survived by two loving sons, David and Stephen, and seven grandchildren. A noted artist whose prints and paintings from the 1930's chronicle a seminal period of New York City's architectural growth in a style that has been described as ''a beautiful blend of the poetic and historical.'' His works are represented in the collections of the world's leading art museums, including the Museum of Modern Art, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Brooklyn Museum, the Whitney Museum, the British Museum, the Corcoran Gallery, and the Library of Congress. He gave generously of his time to support the cause of art and artists, serving as executive officer to numerous art organizations. He was a lifetime Honorary Member of the Lotus Club and has had one-man shows at the Hirschl & Adler Gallery and the Sylvan Cole Gallery in New York. In 1992 he published a book of his work from the 1930's, ''Reaching for the Sky''. A man with a great passion for life, his passing leaves a void which will be sadly felt by friends and family.

title: Briefly Noted
description: ROME MAYOR CANCELS AZIZ MEETING Rome's mayor, Walter Veltroni, canceled a meeting with the Iraqi deputy prime minister, Tariq Aziz, because Mr. Aziz had refused to answer a question from an Israeli journalist at a news conference on Friday. Mr. Veltroni said he sent a letter to Mr. Aziz canceling a scheduled meeting because of the incident. "Rome is a city of dialogue and peace, where the Israelis and the Palestinians have met numerous times and I believe it is unacceptable to tell an Israeli journalist, `I will not answer the question because you are Israeli,' " Mr. Veltroni said. At the news conference on Friday, Mr. Aziz refused to answer a question from an Israeli correspondent, saying "When I came to this press conference it was not on my agenda to answer questions by the Israeli media." Other journalists at the packed news gathering heckled and hissed Mr. Aziz for the reply. Mr. Aziz had visited Rome and the Vatican to urge opposition to a military assault on Iraq.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRIEGEL, REGINA
description: KRIEGEL-Regina. Devoted wife of the late Samuel Goldfield and the late Jacob Kriegel. Beloved mother of Esther and Hal Pollock, Yitzchak Goldfield, Rita and Sy Rotter, and Ruth and Sheldon Kriegel. Dear sister of Clara Rongil and the late Josef Halpern. Cherished grandmother, great-grandmother and aunt. Born in Poland in 1907, she grew up in Holland and settled in Belgium. Armed with courage and foresight, she rescued herself, her husband, and her two young children from Hitler's Holocaust. A true eshet chayil, she was untiring in her lifelong support of the Zionist movement, the State of Israel and of the Jewish people. Hadassah was her passion and she gave to that organization energy, time, and her vast knowledge of Judaica during five decades. She was unique: wise, witty, insightful, charming, generous and loving; and a role model and inspiration to her family and to all who knew her.

title: READYING RELIEF FOR IRAQIS
description: Representatives of 29 countries and 21 aid groups warned of devastating humanitarian consequences of a war in Iraq as they ended a two-day meeting in Geneva over the weekend aimed at preparing relief efforts in case of a conflict. Foreign Minister Micheline Calmy-Rey, who organized the meeting on behalf of the Swiss government, said in her opening comments that faced with the numbers of Iraqis who could be injured, killed or made refugees in a war, ''inaction and indifference cannot be permitted.'' Absent from the meeting was the United States, which declined an invitation saying its relief planning has been under way for several months. All other Security Council members, as well as states neighboring Iraq, were represented. Iraq was not invited, organizers said, because of an effort to avoid politicizing the event. Issues on the agenda included caring for distressed civilians, ensuring that humanitarian laws are respected, assessing environmental damage and helping neighboring countries share the burden of the huge number of refugees expected to flee during and after any war. The United Nations has estimated that in the event of a war, around two million Iraqis would be forced to leave their homes, while anywhere between 500,000 and 1.5 million would flee the country altogether. Further, Iraq's current level of food supplies are expected to last no more than six weeks from the start of a war, and drinking water supplies could be affected immediately. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: Nokia-Led Group Forms Cell-Phone Alliance With Samsung
description: CANNES, France, Feb. 17 -- Symbian Ltd., the British phone software consortium led by Nokia Oyj, got a financially small but symbolically important endorsement today from the Samsung Electronics Company, the aggressive South Korean maker of cell phones. Samsung acquired ownership of 5 percent of Symbian for 17 million, or more than $10 million, in its first minority investment outside of South Korea. Some telecommunications industry analysts said the move would help give the British group's systems a major role in the next generation of cell phones. Samsung joins the other four top mobile phone manufacturers as part owner of Symbian, entitling it to a seat on the board. The move intensifies Symbian's rivalry with the Microsoft Corporation for future control of the software that runs cell phones. The price paid values Symbian at 340 million, up from 285 million a year ago, when Siemens A.G .of Germany purchased a 4.8 percent stake in the company. ''Clearly, all the shareholders felt the value had increased,'' David Levin, chief executive of Symbian, said today. The deal was announced at the 3GSM World Congress for the wireless industry in Cannes, a day after Microsoft announced an alliance with T-Mobile, which agreed to use Microsofts operating systems in an advanced phone to be released this summer. ''For Symbian, it's good because there have always been lingering doubts about it,'' said Lars Vestergaard, analyst for the International Data Corporation. ''And Samsung is showing it's being bold enough to drive things in the market.'' The T-Mobile and Samsung deals also demonstrate that the next business model for the cell phone world has not yet become clear. While Microsoft is courting mobile phone operators like Orange S.A., Symbian has pursued the hardware makers. The split shows that customers around the world are divided over whether their loyalty is to the brand name on the phone itself or to that of the company that provides the mobile services. ''In the next year, there will be a tug of war over who owns the customer,'' said Juha Christensen, corporate vice president for mobility at Microsoft. Microsoft's research shows Europeans buy for the handset name, while Japanese and Koreans are wedded to their service providers, like NTT DoCoMo Inc., he said, adding that Americans are split. Both the Microsoft and Symbian factions argue that their approach will bring simplicity and uniformity to the use of cell phones at a time when the phones' functions are growing more diverse and complicated. Mobile phones can now send photos, show video and e-mail spreadsheets, for example, and carriers are counting on more such uses over so-called third-generation networks to drive revenue in saturated markets. To be safe, Samsung is covering its bets. It has licensed both Microsoft's software and that of Palm Inc. for different versions of its phones for different buyers. Sang Jin Park, Samsung executive vice president, has said the company believes ''the victor will be decided by the market.
