description: The Bush administration is developing plans for sanctions against North Korea, that would include halting its weapons shipments and cutting off money sent there by Koreans living in Japan, in the event that North Korea continues its march toward developing nuclear weapons, senior administration officials say.

title: The Canadian Way: Health Care for All
description: To the Editor:

title: Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu Chief to Inherit a Changed Firm
description: The accounting firm that William G. Parrett will likely take over in June will be far different from the one his predecessor inherited four years ago.

title: For Angels, Same Team And Same Approach
description: On a warm, sunny Saturday morning, along an immaculate green and brown baseball field, the Anaheim Angels quietly went back to work for the first time since they ended 42 years of misery with their first World Series title. The Angels ran sprints, tossed fastballs and fielded grounders. There was no mention of the magic they worked four months ago.

title: David E. Feller, 86; Lawyer Who Argued Key Labor Cases
description: David E. Feller, a lawyer and law professor who researched and argued important civil rights and labor cases, including more than a dozen that went to the Supreme Court, died on Monday in Oakland, Calif. He was 86 and lived in Berkeley, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ONGIONI, EDWARD ANTHONY
description: ONGIONI-Edward Anthony. On February 15, 2003. Devoted husband of the late Eleanor. Beloved father of Adrienne Burroughs, Diane Gibson, Marie, Regina Fletcher and father-in-law of Daniel, Lamont, Carmela and Dave. Cherished grandfather of Nora, Regina, Elizabeth, Paul, Christopher, Mark and greatgrandfather of Sam, Maria, Eleanor and Adrienne. Loving brother of Joseph and sister-in-law of Rita. Lovingly cared for by Thelma Lue. Mass Tuesday, 9:45 a.m., St. Saviour Church. Reposing at the chapel of Joseph G. Duffy Funeral Home, 9th Street between 4th and 5th Avenues, Brooklyn.

title: Iran Reports Sweep Against Qaeda Smugglers
description: Iran has arrested several suspected members of Al Qaeda in recent weeks as part of a crackdown that American and Iranian officials say has shut down a major smuggling operation on the Iranian border with Pakistan.

title: Storm Lumbers Up East Coast, Dumping Snow and Disrupting Travel
description: A major storm swamped a winter-weary East Coast today, dumping snow over a large swath of the Middle Atlantic, slowing commerce and travel and affecting national security during a three-day weekend.

title: Compressed Data; Dell's on the Cutting Edge, but It's Only a Movie
description: Dell Computer, the PC maker, is known more for its production efficiency than for cutting-edge research. But in ''The Recruit,'' a spy thriller starring Al Pacino and Colin Farrell, Dell is made to look like the employer of choice for young technology geniuses -- thanks to a product placement deal.

title: On Day of Their Own, Thousands Rally in San Francisco
description: Some people were concerned that the protest here today would be forgotten, coming as it did the day after millions of people attended peace rallies around the world.

title: Iraq and Oil, Still Inseparable
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Old Lessons for a New Company
description: It should come as no surprise that Twyla Tharp's new touring company, which performed tonight at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center here, is filled with distinctive-looking virtuoso ballet dancers who hit the ground running. But Ms. Tharp gave them a course in ballet mannerisms in ''Even the King,'' her first piece for the company.

title: Op-Art
Waltrip Dodges Raindrops to Win the Daytona 500
description: Michael Waltrip found a big umbrella and a cozy spot in the pits with his wife, Buffy. He put his arm around her, and they watched the rain for more than an hour, as if they were spending a quiet night on their front porch.

title: Bombing Site Fuels Politics Of Bitterness
description: The horror that dropped down 12 years ago on the Amiriya neighborhood of Baghdad has now become two stories. The first is of real and deep suffering: on Feb. 13, 1991, two American missiles cut cleanly through a bomb shelter there and killed perhaps 408 people, most of them women and children who had been sleeping.

title: Strategic Advice From the Public
description: Maude LeFrem, a woman in her 60's, put on a brave face as she waited for a train at the Broadway-Nassau subway stop in Lower Manhattan. She, too, had heard the rumors. The terrorists were coming. They had their eyes on the subways. Chemical weapons. Any day now. Any moment.

title: Washington Talk; Medicare Plan's Trouble Could Offer a Lesson
description: One month into the legislative season, the tensions over the Bush administration's $400 billion proposal for overhauling Medicare are striking -- and, perhaps, cautionary for a White House trying to juggle threats of terrorism, the possibility of war and an ambitious domestic agenda.

title: Electronic Tracking System Monitors Foreign Students
description: Mandated after terrorists first bombed the World Trade Center a decade ago and financed after they destroyed it, a vast new electronic tracking system became the central element on Saturday in the government's effort to keep tabs on nearly a million foreign students and scholars in this country.

title: Hamas Says Israel Killed at Least 6 in Blast
description: At least six members of the Palestinian group Hamas died in a mysterious explosion in Gaza City today, hours after Israel's defense minister vowed retaliation for a Hamas bombing in Gaza on Saturday that destroyed an Israeli tank and killed the four soldiers inside.

title: Lincoln Returns to the Old South
description: Richmond had finally fallen, its ruins still smoldering when Abraham Lincoln discreetly stepped off a boat from Washington and walked the enemy streets in long-legged curiosity. With no entourage or fanfare, but heartfelt greetings from newly emancipated African-Americans passing by, the war president meandered with his youngest child, Tad. Lincoln asked the way to the home of Jefferson Davis, his rebel counterpart.

title: Business turns out to help North Koreans celebrate
description: HONG KONG:  Even as cash-strapped North Korea faces a showdown with the United Nations over suspected nuclear weapons development, the country's Hong Kong consulate found the time and money this weekend to give a spirited cocktail party.

title: Group Program Manager Bids Flippant Farewell to Microsoft
description: People leave Microsoft all the time, and many of them pass along their departing thoughts in e-mail messages to their colleagues. But the missive sent by David Stutz, a respected technical thinker within the company for more than 10 years, is more intriguing than most.

title: Con Man, Lonely Woman and Love Swirling on the Prairie
description: It was a moment for flashy dames in plumes and sequins who belted brassy hymns to their own special talents. So what hope could there have been that anyone would pay much attention to a lonely, unsure woman who wore simple cotton dresses and sang hopelessly about how unattractive she was?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FERBER, STEVEN
description: FERBER-Steven. 2/17/619/27/97. Happy Birthday. We miss you and love you. Mom, Family and Friends

title: U.S. Appeals Court Expands Patients' Rights Over H.M.O.'s
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17  A federal appeals court has expanded patients' rights, ruling that consumers can sue a health insurance company for injuries resulting from the company's refusal to authorize medically necessary treatment.

title: What now, Mr. President?
description: Chancellor Schroder is approaching foreign policy energetically and not exactly diplomatically, quarreling with the United States and, together with Russia and France, forging the axis of the stubborn. In the wake of Friday's report by the inspectors, there was one person who seemed to have been left out in the cold: George W. Bush.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHAN, HAROLD
description: COHAN-Harold. On February 15, 2003, of Old Westbury, NY. Beloved husband of Roslyn. Devoted and loving father of Sharon and Philip Ross, Seth and Lori Cohan. Dear brother of Leonard Cohan. Cherished and adored grandfather of Carley, Elliot, Alexandra, Danielle and Hannah. All sought his counsel. He is in our hearts forever and ever. A Senior Partner of Ernst & Young and former President of the Old Westbury Golf and Country Club. Services Tuesday, 10 AM, at Temple Sinai, 425 Roslyn Road, Roslyn Heights, NY. Interment Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, NY.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''They are moving heaven, earth and snow to have that wedding today.''

title: 2 Phone Giants in Court to Fight Turkish Family
description: After more than a year of pretrial maneuvering, an effort by two of the world's largest phone equipment companies, Motorola and Nokia, to paint themselves as victims of a huge fraud by a secretive Turkish family is scheduled to go to trial tomorrow in a federal court in New York.

title: Chicago Job Seekers
description: To the Editor:

title: Rumors Of a Trade For Ward Persist
description: For nine seasons, there have been boos, skepticism, controversy, newcomers who were considered better players and trade speculation. Charlie Ward has outlasted it all, providing the Knicks with solid defense, timely 3-point shooting and consistent hustle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHENSTEIN, CONSTANCE
description: ROTHENSTEIN - Constance. On February 15, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Guy Rothenstein. Loving daughter of the late Dr. Charles and Leah Mark. Devoted mother of Richard Grimes. Graveside services 10 AM, Wednesday, February 19, at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery.

title: Germans Near Air Base Don't Hate U.S., Just the Noise
description: For some angry lawmakers in Congress, the best punishment for Germany's refusal to back a war against Iraq would be to scale back the number of American troops stationed here. The Pentagon, they were told recently, is weighing the idea.

title: Google Deal Ties Company To Weblogs
description: Google, the operator of the Web's leading search engine, has bought Pyra Labs, the creator of software for publishing Weblogs, a form of hyperlinked online journal that has become an increasingly popular way to distribute and collect information on the Web.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Harlem: Arrest In Killing Of Girl, 16
description: The police have arrested a Harlem teenager on charges that he fatally shot a 16-year-old girl and wounded three young men late Thursday afternoon, the authorities said. The teenager, Emmanuel Valerio-Sanchez, 16, was arrested on Friday and charged with second-degree murder, the police said. They recovered a loaded 9-millimeter pistol that they say they believe was used in shootings. The girl, Natasha Camilo, 16, was shot in the back on Thursday about 5:45 p.m. in front of 529 West 135th Street, a few doors from where Mr. Valerio-Sanchez lives, the authorities said. She was taken to St. Lukes-Roosevelt Hospital Center, where she died a short while later, the police said. A 17-year-old to whom she was talking, Jonathan Medrano, was shot in the legs, the police said, and two other men, Jorge Briu, 20, and Junior Vincio, 23, were grazed by bullets. The police said that the gunman fired at least 17 shots. Investigators believe that Mr. Valerio-Sanchez opened fire on the four because they had robbed him and had been harassing him, the police said. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Miller Leaves an Opening, And Kostelic Skis Through It
description: Instead of making more history, Bode Miller made too many mistakes today in the final event of the Alpine world championships. Instead of winning his third gold medal, he lost one of his poles midway through the first run of the men's slalom.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Long Hill Township: Suspicious Letter
description: A post office in Long Hill was closed on Friday after brown powder fell from a padded envelope as it passed through a postmark machine, the authorities said. An initial test was negative for anthrax; results on a second test were inconclusive. There were no customers in the building when the powder was discovered about 6:30 p.m., a Postal Service spokesman said, but five employees who were in the building have been prescribed the antibiotic Cipro as a precaution. The spokesman said the letter was addressed to a Pennsylvania resident, but would not identify the person or town. It is unclear when the post office will reopen, the spokesman added. Several stores surrounding the post office were closed until 1 p.m. Saturday as a safety precaution, a Long Hill police officer said. Several apartments near the post office were also evacuated.

title: Corrections
description: New York Stock Exchange tables in the Money & Business section were incomplete yesterday, omitting a page of entries that preceded InvTech in the alphabet and a chart that summarized trading for last week. The omitted page appears today, on Page C9.

title: U.S. Sees Kidnapping of 3 as Shift by Colombia Rebels
description: The three Americans believed kidnapped by Colombian rebels could be held as war booty by a guerrilla group that is believed to be making a major change in tactics to bring about an aggressive confrontation with Colombia and its main backer, the United States, political analysts and former rebels said today.

title: Ridge Says Warning Levels Might Be Lowered in Days
description: The country's domestic security chief said today that the heightened alert level warning of possible terrorist attacks might be lowered in coming days depending on assessments of threats received by the government.

title: Dresden Treasures Await Refuge; Artworks Escaped Flood Damage Once, But Need a Haven if Rivers Rise Again
description: In theory, a disaster averted should leave few traces. Yet six months after the dramatic rescue of Dresden's art treasures from incalculable flood damage, the mood in this city's leading museums is sour. Heralded for their heroic salvage effort, museum administrators and curators are now complaining that Saxony's regional government has refused to provide them with a safe place to store their art.

title: MediaTalk; U.S. Reaches Out to Younger Readers, in Arabic
description: Is there room for yet another magazine that hopes to attract the 18-to-25 audience?

title: New Economy; Telecom gear makers look beyond a war in Iraq and see some opportunities.
description: THE telecommunications equipment industry is quietly pinning its hopes on a quick Iraqi war that would be followed by an American-led effort to rebuild the country after the ouster of Saddam Hussein.

title: From the French Alps to the Colorado Rockies
description: GILLES GRIMANDI has seen the soccer world from the apex of the English game as a member of last year's Arsenal team, which won the English Premier League and the F.A. Cup, the fabled double. Now he has assumed a new perch, a mile high in Denver with the Colorado Rapids, as the first Frenchman to join Major League Soccer.

title: Service Groups Struggle As City's Payments Lag
description: In Brooklyn, a group of workers who help low-income women deliver healthy babies are facing dismissal. In Staten Island, a nonprofit organization that tries to reunite foster children with their families has been dipping into a credit line for the better part of a year. And in the Bronx, a settlement house has spent much of its reserve fund.

title: Webdenda
description: The Association of Independent Commercial Producers , New York, named national officers for 2003. Alfred Califano , partner at Wildlife Management, New York, was re-elected chairman. Mark Androw , partner at the Story Companies, New York, was re-elected vice-chairman. And Robert L. Sacks , counsel at Kane Kessler, New York, was named secretary, succeeding Stephen Steinbrecher, senior counsel at Kane Kessler. Stephanie Brown was named to the new post of senior creative director for interactive services at Media Logic, Albany . She had been director for creative services at Dynamic Applications, Troy, N.Y. Doctors Vision Centers , Rocky Mount, N.C., named Howard, Merrell & Partners, Raleigh , N.C., as agency of record on its account, which had been handled internally. Spending was estimated at less than $2 million. The Hospitality Sales and Marketing Association International , McLean, Va., named the recipients of its 2002 International Travel Awards Competition. They included: Peter Warren , president at Warren Kremer Paino Advertising, New York, who received the Alebert E. Koehl Lifetime Achievement Award; Bunny Grossinger , among the first executives in advertising to aim campaigns at female business travelers, who received the Winthrop W. Grice Lifetime Achievement Award; the Mumbai, India, office of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide , part of the WPP Group; which received the Adrian Advertising Best of Show award for its work for the Maharashtra Tourism Development Corporation; the Meridian Group , Virginia Beach, Va., which received the Golden Bell Public Relations Best of Show Award for its work for the Norfolk, Va., International Airport; and Fairmont Hotels and Resorts, Toronto, which received the Golden Click Best of Show Award. Chris Hunton , deputy managing director at the London office of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising , was promoted to chief executive, assuming some duties that had been handled by Tamara Ingram, chairwoman at McCann-Erickson United Kingdom, London, who left last month. McCann-Erickson is part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Marc Kiven was named to the new post of vice president for sales and marketing at Liquid Generation , Chicago. He had been senior director for sales and business development at Avenue A, Seattle. Debi Leibovitz was named to the new post of vice president and West Coast manager at the Los Angeles office of Parade, part of Advance Publications. She had been Western region manager at the Los Angeles office of Netscape Communications, part of the America Online division of AOL Time Warner. Luria Digital Productions , White Plains, N.Y., was opened by Dick Luria , president at Dick Luria Photography, White Plains. Lushadelic , San Francisco, is being opened by Bob Kerstetter as writer and director, and Stelio Kitrilakis as executive producer. Mr. Kerstetter had most recently been creative director at Black Rocket Euro RSCG, San Francisco, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide unit of Havas. Mr. Kitrilakis continues as executive producer at Complete Pandemonium, San Francisco, a commercial production company. MediaCom Worldwide , New York, part of the Grey Global Group, promoted three employees. Duane Bruner , regional director for Latin America, was named to the added post of regional director for the Asia-Pacific region, succeeding Michael Townsin , who was named to the new post of global business development director. Mr. Bruner will be based in Bangkok, Thailand; Mr. Townsin will be based in London. Adrian King , research director for China and Hong Kong, was named to the new post of research director for the Asia-Pacific region; he continues to be based in Hong Kong. The Mosaic Media Group , Beverly Hills, Calif., a movie production and talent management company, formed an entertainment marketing joint venture with the Elevation Group of Companies , Cleveland, called Elevation Entertainment. Mosaic also bought a 50 percent stake in the marketing division of the Steven Rifkind Company, Los Angeles. MRM Partners Worldwide , New York, promoted two employees and hired another. Michael Hughes , worldwide group account director on the Microsoft account at the San Francisco office, was named North American regional director. Steven Woolford , executive vice president and managing director at Zentropy Partners, Los Angeles, part of MRM, was named to the new post of worldwide managing director at Zentropy. And Jane Tubb was named to the new post of regional director for the Asia-Pacific region, based in Sydney, Australia; she had been group managing director at Clemenger Direct, Sydney, part of Clemenger Communications. MRM is part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. National Cable Communications , New York, hired two account executives. Peter D'Urso had been regional sales manager at the Dallas office of Rainbow Media Holdings, part of Cablevision Systems. April Panster had been account executive at the Miami office of AT&T Media Services, now part of Comcast. Palio Communications , Saratoga Springs, N.Y., promoted six employees. Cathy Cotten , director for editorial services, was named vice president and director for editorial services. Ken Messinger , senior art director, was named group art supervisor. And four assistant account executives were named account executives: Erin Armstrong, Kergin Bedell, Ed Decker and Matthew Geandreau . Park Place Entertainment , Las Vegas, named Avenue A , Seattle, to handle online advertising for the account of the Bally's, Caesars, Flamingo, Grand Casinos, Hilton and Paris casinos, which had been handled by Avenue A on a project basis. Billings were not disclosed. Rob Perota was named to the new post of associate creative director at Einson Freeman , Upper Saddle River, N.J. Mr. Perota had been freelancing and before that worked at agencies including Saatchi & Saatchi, New York, part of the Publicis Groupe. Einson Freeman is part of the WPP Group. Anita Stewart was named vice president for corporate sponsorship at the Sesame Workshop , New York, succeeding Lynn Lehmkuhl, who left, the company said. Ms. Stewart had been national marketing and sales director for the sponsorship group at the New York office of the Public Broadcasting Service. The Syndicated Network Television Association , New York, introduced a Web site at www.snta.com, for advertisers and media planners and buyers. T3 (The Think Tank) , Austin, Tex., hired five employees. Rebecca Butler was named direct-mail marketing consultant on the direct marketing and catalogue account of Dell Computer; she had been account supervisor at Makos Advertising Marketing and Design, Austin. Jamieson Mackie was named copywriter on the Dell account; he had been copywriter at the Austin office of Advanced Micro Devices. Michael Rosenthal was named copywriter on the Dell account; he had been freelancing at T3. Michelle Smith was named project manager for the Sprint and Samsung accounts; she had been vice president for Web development at Digital Cheetah, Austin. And Leslie Williams was named art director on the Dell account; she had been art director at Williams Design, Austin. Three's Company , Lake Forest, Ill., a public relations agency, was opened by Thomas Harris , Kathy Rand and Judith Rich , who will also continue their individual consulting practices. Marco Tinelli was named jury president for the Cyber Lions interactive competition at the 2003 Cannes Lions International Advertising Festival. Mr. Tinelli is president and chief executive at Fullsix, Paris, part of Inferentia. The festival is to be held June 15-21 in Cannes, France. Vocus, Lanham , Md., a maker of Web-based software for corporate communications management, acquired Public Affairs Technologies, Alexandria, Va., a public relations software company. Terms were not disclosed. L.S. Williams & Associates , Chicago, Ill., hired two employees. Katrina Berezniak was named to new the post of director for research design and analysis; she had been practice leader at the Ragan Consulting Group, Chicago, part of Lawrence Ragan Communications. Gregory Gordon was named vice president for research and strategy, succeeding Dan Hough, who left, the agency said. Mr. Gordon had been managing director at Ragan Consulting. Young & Rubicam Advertising , New York, part of the Young & Rubicam Inc. division of the WPP Group, acquired Guye Benker , Zurich, which has 10 employees and revenue of $2 million. Terms were not disclosed.

description: ''Urinetown'' is many things -- exuberant and impudent and satirical, to mention three. But none of those things were what Brian Stavrides liked most about the Tuesday performance he saw recently. What he liked most was the curtain time: 7 p.m.

description: ESKAY - Richard Spencer. Beloved husband of Marion Miller. Loving father of Marjorie, Linda, and Julie; grandfather to seven grandsons. President of RSK Associates, a representative of Specialty Planners; Producer, with his wife, of Pathways to Children's Literature. title: Wind Shift Dooms Kiwis' Effort As They Lose Third Straight
description: After all the high-tech innovations on America's Cup yachts, it's easy to forget that sailing is about mastering the wind. A shift of just five or six degrees will do more to affect a boat race than the most far-out design gadgets.

title: New Generation Storms Slopes at the World Championships
description: ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Feb. 17  In a village where you can shop at Prada and Hermes before prying yourself out of your ski boots, wealth has its privileges. Yet not all of the ski teams rich in tradition enjoyed their customary perquisites during their 15-day stay here.

Ms. Acogny lived up to expectations.

description: SEOUL  Korea is in the headlines again, and as usual the news is not good. North Korea, desperately defiant, has restarted its nuclear program; tensions with the United States are rising. But that will not stop Kim Soon Kwon sowing corn in his enemy's field  literally, and in the full light of day.

description: PARIS  In 1950, South Korea and Zambia were roughly at the same economic level. That Korea is one of the world's most economically advanced nations today and Zambia one of the most backward is due almost entirely to a half century of investment in education, development experts say.

title: Reuniting the Security Council

With last Friday's show of resistance in the Security Council to early military action against Baghdad, it's easy to imagine some of them saying ''I told you so,'' and urging President Bush to bypass the Council and prepare for an invasion joined only by Britain and a narrow coalition of smaller nations. She was also the Co-Chairman and Owner of the Buck Hill Inn of Buck Hill Falls, PA. Buck Hill was the largest resort in the Northeast. Community work included Trustee Republican Committee of Millburn, Short Hills, NJ, Director Millburn Chapter of the American Red Cross and active volunteer work at St. Barnabus Hospital and Meals on Wheels. She resided in Maplewood, NJ, for 20 years and there participated in the Maplewood Junior League and Jefferson School PTA. She was a member of the Short Hills Racquet Club and her family belongs to the Baltusrol Club of Springfield. She is survived by her husband of 55 years Walter and three children Walter, Jr., the CEO of Sabo Media, Richard, the CEO of Dreyfus-Founders Fund, of Denver, CO, and Elizabeth Pauza, an attorney in Tyler, Texas, sister Claire Chiaravalotti, and five grandchildren, Richard Lewis Sabo, Gregory Sabo, Olivia Sabo, Dorothy Rose Sabo, Kevin Pauza, Jr. ''She was a piece of work,'' comments loving son Walter. The family requests in lieu of flowers a gift to Parents Anonymous, 325 South Broadway Ave, Tyler, TX 75702. Her Memorial Mass will be Saturday, Feburary 22, 11 A.M., St. Rose of Lima Church, 50 Short Hills Avenue, Short Hills, NJ.

title: When the Buffalo Roam
description: In the fairy-tale setting of Yellowstone National Park, it's easy to imagine the majestic bison as a free-roaming creature, symbol of the not-quite-vanished Western frontier. The Yellowstone bison (which we grew up calling buffalo) are a distinct breed, descended from a few dozen native wild bison and bison from private herds that were combined in the 1920's. Today the park's herd is nearly 4,000 strong. But while the bison of Yellowstone remain an American icon, they are free only within the invisible boundaries of the park -- a pen approaching the size of Connecticut. What happens when they roam outside the park has set off an uproar that reaches far beyond the rugged land along the border of Wyoming and Montana.

title: World Briefing: Middle East
description: JORDAN: JOURNALISTS ARE JAILED A military court convicted three journalists for the Crescent weekly newspaper of libeling the Prophet Muhammad and sentenced them to prison terms of two to six months. The State Security Court said their Jan. 14 article about the prophet's sex life harmed Jordan's image, "destabilizing the society, propagating perversity and circulating false rumors." The journalists said the article was based on historic and religious references about the prophet's life with his wife Aisha. The writer of the article was sentenced to six months in prison. The article's editors were given two and three months, respectively. The court also ordered the paper closed for another month as punishment. The police closed it on Jan. 16 after arresting the journalists.    (AP)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRAIG, GEORGE M.
description: CRAIG - George M., 87. Passed away peacefully Sunday, February 9 at his home in Cambridge, NY from renal failure. Originally from Elmhurst, Queens, he moved upstate to live with his godson John Carlson and family. He leaves no surviving blood relatives, but many friends and chosen family who love and cherish him. Retired from his work at the Port Authority, he had a life-long love affair with trains. His dedication to children and disabled veterans led him to support many organizations and charities. A student of Lincoln and the Civil War, he was three times President of the NY Civil War Roundtable and the recipient of the prestigious Barondess/ Lincoln Award. He raised funds to restore Grant's Tomb and General George Thomas' gravesite in Troy, NY, as well as founded the Thomas/Longstreet Trust at the Chickamauga National Military Park in GA. At the time of his death he was making a documentary on Thomas' life, who was his hero. Both Thomas and Craig possessed many of the same qualities; quiet, unassuming and brave men, both dedicated to their sense of duty. His remains were cremated privately. There will be a Memorial service at the 7th Regiment Armory at 66th and Park Ave, 4th floor, NYC, Wednesday February 19 68pm. In lieu of flowers you can make a gift in his name to one of his causes: St. John's Home for Boys, 50 Beach 110 St, Rockaway NY, 11694, or General Films, 1 Washington St, Cambridge NY, 12816 (to support the completion of the Thomas documentary).

description: For the first time since World War II and on a scale never before seen in the American military, journalists covering any United States attack on Iraq will have assigned slots with combat and support units and accompany them throughout the conflict.

title: Blazers, and Fatigue, Stop the Knicks
description: The Knicks' surprising romp through the Western Conference's Pacific Division ended tonight when the Portland Trail Blazers used their size, athleticism and depth to overwhelm the Knicks, 99-91, at the Rose Garden, dropping the Knicks to 2-1 on this six-game trek.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: TRACKING FOREIGNERS Russia has begun distributing migration cards to all foreigners entering the country, including tourists. Boris V. Gryzlov, the interior minister, warned that foreigners without the cards might be deported. Officials say the goal is to keep track of the influx of migrant workers, especially from poverty-stricken former Soviet republics like Ukraine, Moldova and Armenia, which have visa-free relations with Russia. Critics say the new cards, which Russia began distributing on Friday, will simply offer opportunities for bribe-taking by the authorities.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: SOUTH AFRICA: OUTCRY AFTER SPEECH Opposition parties accused President Thabo Mbeki of neglecting critical issues, including AIDS and South Africa's support for Zimbabwe, in his state of the nation speech. Last week, demonstrators marched through the streets of Cape Town to press the government to provide AIDS drugs in this country, which has more people infected with H.I.V. than any other country. In his speech, Mr. Mbeki did not announce any plans to widen access to the lifesaving medicines.    Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Mexican Drug Agent Crossed the Line Once Too Often
description: The border is its own country. The Mexicans go to work ''al otro lado,'' on the other side. The Texans come south to drink. The men wear the same kinds of cowboy boots, speak the same Spanglish and mix Miller Lite with their tequila in the border bars that double as bordellos.

title: Those Gliding Feet
description: No, it is not Vail. But it is cheaper and more convenient, say the ranks of cross-country skiers who made their way around Central Park with poles and tinted goggles yesterday, as though they were gliding past rugged mountains instead of snow-capped apartment buildings.

title: Editorial Observer; The Tumultuous Republic of California Is Still Different, Only More So
description: The Walt Disney Company's decision to open a new amusement park here two years ago with a California theme -- Disney's California Adventure -- was an exercise in redundancy. In many ways, Americans have long treated the whole state as a theme park -- if not a roller-coaster ride that provides exhilarating highs and gut-wrenching drops.

title: A campaign takes sides in the fight between competing high-fiber and high-protein diets.
description: THE continuing battle between diet gurus promoting a low-fat, high-fiber lifestyle and those preaching a high-protein, low-carbohydrate approach is taking to the air this week, with a 30-second television commercial sponsored by the Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Ruling Favors Czech Brewer
description: The Czech brewer Budejovicky Budvar has won the latest round in its battle with the Anheuser-Busch for the right to use the Budweiser and Bud trademarks. Yesterday, the House of Lords rejected an appeal by Anheuser-Busch to bar the Czechs from using the trademark Bud in Britain. The Czechs say they have been brewing beer in the city of Ceske Budejovice, originally known by its German name, Budweis, for more than 600 years. Anheuser-Busch says that it began using the Budweiser trademark in 1876, 19 years before Budejovicky Budvar was established. Britain is Anheuser-Busch's second-largest market. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: Islanders Come Back to Tie Mighty Ducks
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Feb. 17 - The Islanders were hoping a demotion to the fourth line would inspire Aleksei Yashin to rediscover the work ethic needed to take advantage of his considerable talent. The psychological ploy appears to have paid off.

title: Global Ad Agency Picks No. 2 Officer
description: In a significant reorganization of its senior creative ranks, TBWA Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, has filled a post with a top executive from the agency's South African operation, who will move to New York.

title: Brooklyn's Democratic Leader Hopes New Clout in Assembly Gets Him Over a Rough Patch
description: Two weeks after he was selected as the New York State Assembly's deputy speaker, Clarence Norman Jr., the Brooklyn assemblyman and head of the Democratic Party organization in Brooklyn, still seemed dazzled by his new title.

title: Public Shareholders Support Offer for Taubman
description: Pressure on the family and directors of A. Alfred Taubman's shopping mall empire appeared to intensify when the two companies seeking to take it over said yesterday that they had the support of 85 percent of the publicly traded shares in Taubman Centers.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Pledge On Rates
description: The Bank of Korea has promised to hold down interest rates amid reports the economy may not grow as much as anticipated. The central bank cited ''uncertainty over war in Iraq and North Korea's suspected nuclear programs'' as reasons for its decision. Without taking those factors into account, the bank earlier this month predicted 5.5 percent growth this year. Last year it had forecast that the economy would expand by at least 6 percent this year. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSHALL, JOHN C.
description: MARSHALL-John C. Of Bronxville, NY, passed away peacefully on February 8, 2003. He attended the College of William and Mary and was a graduate of Swarthmore College Class of 1948. He spent most of his career at American International Group, retiring as a Managing Director in their Global Investment Group. Beloved husband of Barbara Dexter. Devoted father of Candace D., John C. Jr., and James Steuart. Cherished grandfather of Jack, Page, Sarah and Katie. He was a Member of the Reformed Church in Bronxville and a longtime member of the Shenorock Shore Club in Rye, NY. An avid sailor and music enthusiast, he was a wonderful, kind and honorable man, loved by all who knew him. We love you, Dad, and will miss you always. A private memorial service for the immediate family will be held at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HAY, ABRAHAM S.
description: HAY-Abraham S. February 18, 1983. Remembered always by loving daughters and a granddaughter inspired by shared memories of you.

title: Pataki, Environmentalist? Little and Late, Critics Say
description: Three years and four months ago, Gov. George E. Pataki said New York would impose the nation's toughest restrictions on the power plant emissions that can damage trees and lakes and set off asthma attacks. Yet no new regulations have been set.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUMENTHAL, SAMUEL
description: BLUMENTHAL-Samuel. A gentle person, a builder of consensus and community, a lover of culture and the Jewish people, he helped build and served as chair of each of the major institutions of the Jewish Reconstructionist movement, where his good work continues to touch the lives of thousands. We extend our condolences to his family. May his memory be a blessing. Aaron Ziegelman General Chair Donald Shapiro Chair, Board of Governors Rabbi Dan Ehrenkrantz President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOHL, RONALD GENE
description: WOHL-Ronald Gene. Of Roslyn Estates, NY, on February 16, 2003. Very devoted to his family and friends. Beloved husband of Linda. Loving father of Allison and her husband Christopher George, Arthur and Amanda. Belovedgrandfather of Emma, Elizabeth, Caroline and Julia. We will miss him dearly. Funeral service Wednesday 12 noon, Temple Sinai of Roslyn, 425 Roslyn Rd. Interment Mount Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, New York.

title: BLIZZARD BURIES NORTHEASTERN U.S., DISRUPTING TRAVEL
description: The biggest blizzard in seven years buried the New York region and much of the Northeast in one to two feet of snow yesterday, disrupting air and highway travel and raising chest-high drifts on the wintry landscapes of 10 states. But for millions home on Presidents' Day, it offered a holiday break, not hardships.

title: Webdenda
description: The Association of Independent Commercial Producers , New York, named national officers for 2003. Alfred Califano , partner at Wildlife Management, New York, was re-elected chairman. Mark Androw , partner at the Story Companies, New York, was re-elected vice-chairman. And Robert L. Sacks , counsel at Kane Kessler, New York, was named secretary, succeeding Stephen Steinbrecher, senior counsel at Kane Kessler. Stephanie Brown was named to the new post of senior creative director for interactive services at Media Logic, Albany . She had been director for creative services at Dynamic Applications, Troy, N.Y. Doctors Vision Centers , Rocky Mount, N.C., named Howard, Merrell & Partners, Raleigh , N.C., as agency of record on its account, which had been handled internally. Spending was estimated at less than $2 million. The Hospitality Sales and Marketing Association International , McLean, Va., named the recipients of its 2002 International Travel Awards Competition. They included: Peter Warren , president at Warren Kremer Paino Advertising, New York, who received the Alebert E. Koehl Lifetime Achievement Award; Bunny Grossinger , among the first executives in advertising to aim campaigns at female business travelers, who received the Winthrop W. Grice Lifetime Achievement Award; the Mumbai, India, office of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide , part of the WPP Group; which received the Adrian Advertising Best of Show award for its work for the Maharashtra Tourism Development Corporation; the Meridian Group , Virginia Beach, Va., which received the Golden Bell Public Relations Best of Show Award for its work for the Norfolk, Va., International Airport; and Fairmont Hotels and Resorts, Toronto, which received the Golden Click Best of Show Award. Chris Hunton , deputy managing director at the London office of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising , was promoted to chief executive, assuming some duties that had been handled by Tamara Ingram, chairwoman at McCann-Erickson United Kingdom, London, who left last month. McCann-Erickson is part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Marc Kiven was named to the new post of vice president for sales and marketing at Liquid Generation , Chicago. He had been senior director for sales and business development at Avenue A, Seattle. Debi Leibovitz was named to the new post of vice president and West Coast manager at the Los Angeles office of Parade, part of Advance Publications. She had been Western region manager at the Los Angeles office of Netscape Communications, part of the America Online division of AOL Time Warner. Luria Digital Productions , White Plains, N.Y., was opened by Dick Luria , president at Dick Luria Photography, White Plains. Lushadelic , San Francisco, is being opened by Bob Kerstetter as writer and director, and Stelio Kitrilakis as executive producer. Mr. Kerstetter had most recently been creative director at Black Rocket Euro RSCG, San Francisco, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide unit of Havas. Mr. Kitrilakis continues as executive producer at Complete Pandemonium, San Francisco, a commercial production company. MediaCom Worldwide , New York, part of the Grey Global Group, promoted three employees. Duane Bruner , regional director for Latin America, was named to the added post of regional director for the Asia-Pacific region, succeeding Michael Townsin , who was named to the new post of global business development director. Mr. Bruner will be based in Bangkok, Thailand; Mr. Townsin will be based in London. Adrian King , research director for China and Hong Kong, was named to the new post of research director for the Asia-Pacific region; he continues to be based in Hong Kong. The Mosaic Media Group , Beverly Hills, Calif., a movie production and talent management company, formed an entertainment marketing joint venture with the Elevation Group of Companies , Cleveland, called Elevation Entertainment. Mosaic also bought a 50 percent stake in the marketing division of the Steven Rifkind Company, Los Angeles. MRM Partners Worldwide , New York, promoted two employees and hired another. Michael Hughes , worldwide group account director on the Microsoft account at the San Francisco office, was named North American regional director. Steven Woolford , executive vice president and managing director at Zentropy Partners, Los Angeles, part of MRM, was named to the new post of worldwide managing director at Zentropy. And Jane Tubb was named to the new post of regional director for the Asia-Pacific region, based in Sydney, Australia; she had been group managing director at Clemenger Direct, Sydney, part of Clemenger Communications. MRM is part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. National Cable Communications , New York, hired two account executives. Peter D'Urso had been regional sales manager at the Dallas office of Rainbow Media Holdings, part of Cablevision Systems. April Panster had been account executive at the Miami office of AT&T Media Services, now part of Comcast. Palio Communications , Saratoga Springs, N.Y., promoted six employees. Cathy Cotten , director for editorial services, was named vice president and director for editorial services. Ken Messinger , senior art director, was named group art supervisor. And four assistant account executives were named account executives: Erin Armstrong, Kergin Bedell, Ed Decker and Matthew Geandreau . Park Place Entertainment , Las Vegas, named Avenue A , Seattle, to handle online advertising for the account of the Bally's, Caesars, Flamingo, Grand Casinos, Hilton and Paris casinos, which had been handled by Avenue A on a project basis. Billings were not disclosed. Rob Perota was named to the new post of associate creative director at Einson Freeman , Upper Saddle River, N.J. Mr. Perota had been freelancing and before that worked at agencies including Saatchi & Saatchi, New York, part of the Publicis Groupe. Einson Freeman is part of the WPP Group. Anita Stewart was named vice president for corporate sponsorship at the Sesame Workshop , New York, succeeding Lynn Lehmkuhl, who left, the company said. Ms. Stewart had been national marketing and sales director for the sponsorship group at the New York office of the Public Broadcasting Service. The Syndicated Network Television Association , New York, introduced a Web site at www.snta.com, for advertisers and media planners and buyers. T3 (The Think Tank) , Austin, Tex., hired five employees. Rebecca Butler was named direct-mail marketing consultant on the direct marketing and catalogue account of Dell Computer; she had been account supervisor at Makos Advertising Marketing and Design, Austin. Jamieson Mackie was named copywriter on the Dell account; he had been copywriter at the Austin office of Advanced Micro Devices. Michael Rosenthal was named copywriter on the Dell account; he had been freelancing at T3. Michelle Smith was named project manager for the Sprint and Samsung accounts; she had been vice president for Web development at Digital Cheetah, Austin. And Leslie Williams was named art director on the Dell account; she had been art director at Williams Design, Austin. Three's Company , Lake Forest, Ill., a public relations agency, was opened by Thomas Harris , Kathy Rand and Judith Rich , who will also continue their individual consulting practices. Marco Tinelli was named jury president for the Cyber Lions interactive competition at the 2003 Cannes Lions International Advertising Festival. Mr. Tinelli is president and chief executive at Fullsix, Paris, part of Inferentia. The festival is to be held June 15-21 in Cannes, France. Vocus, Lanham , Md., a maker of Web-based software for corporate communications management, acquired Public Affairs Technologies, Alexandria, Va., a public relations software company. Terms were not disclosed. L.S. Williams & Associates , Chicago, Ill., hired two employees. Katrina Berezniak was named to new the post of director for research design and analysis; she had been practice leader at the Ragan Consulting Group, Chicago, part of Lawrence Ragan Communications. Gregory Gordon was named vice president for research and strategy, succeeding Dan Hough, who left, the agency said. Mr. Gordon had been managing director at Ragan Consulting. Young & Rubicam Advertising , New York, part of the Young & Rubicam Inc. division of the WPP Group, acquired Guye Benker , Zurich, which has 10 employees and revenue of $2 million. Terms were not disclosed.

title: U.S. Treasury Schedules Bond Auctions
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week comprises today's auction of three- and six-month bills and an auction tomorrow of four-week bills. There was no trading Monday in in Treasury futures on the Chicago Board of Trade and of United States Treasury securities.

title: Sports of The Times; Jeter Is Right To Counter Boss's Bluster
description: OH, let him talk. That's what George Steinbrenner does, who he is, making many big headlines and very little sense. Just let the windbag have his say, blow off steam for the paltry playoff dividend he received from the Yankees last season on his investment of mind-numbing millions.

title: G.E. Said to Explore Sale of Motor Unit
description: General Electric is seeking to sell its motor manufacturing business for as much as $900 million, according to people briefed on the company's plans.

description: MEYERS-Eve Hirsch. On February 16, 2003, age 92, a resident of The Jewish Home for the Elderly, Fairfield, CT. Memorial contributions to Jumpstart for Children, 93 Summer Street, 2nd floor, Boston, MA. 02110, would be greatly appreciated.

title: Defense precedents : Japan breaks ground in naval cooperation
description: TOKYO  The Aegis-class destroyer Kirishima recently left the Japanese port of Yokosuka for the Indian Ocean. The Kirishima will replace one of three other Japanese destroyers escorting support ships that have been refueling other countries' ships involved in the war on terrorism in Afghanistan.

title: Some Urge Type of Pap Test To Find Cancer in Gay Men
description: Some doctors and researchers at major medical centers have started to recommend that gay men undergo regular anal Pap smears to screen for cell changes that could lead to anal cancer.

title: Toronto Journal; A Veil of Deterrence for a Bridge With a Dark Side
description: Toronto is not known as a city of romance or beauty like Montreal, Quebec City or Vancouver, but it has its share of alluring views of powerful skyscrapers, moody Lake Ontario and the deep leafy furrows of the Don Valley that divide the city's ethnic neighborhoods.

title: Review/Fashion; From Karan, Sensuality And Steel
description: For the last several years, Donna Karan hasn't been herself. She lost her husband to cancer. She went through the trauma of taking her company public and then selling it to LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton. She has gone on a diet, embraced Zen, and endured rumors that she was about to be fired. Her collections, tending to reflect her moods rather than her principles, have been received as politely as a successful woman suddenly announcing she had fallen in love with the milkman.

title: Questions Outnumber Answers on P.S.A. Test
description: Many women have hesitated to get mammograms because they know the unpleasant realities they face if anything suspicious appears, especially since there are no guarantees that treatments will be lifesaving or even necessary.

title: A City's Jitters, Muffled in the Swirling Drifts
description: On another day, the blizzard would have been a disaster, or at least an annoying interruption. But on a day that was already a holiday, it was more of a lark, a break from terror alerts, budget crises and the dreary routine of a February in New York City. Blessed paralysis enveloped a city of hustlers and strivers.

title: Jeter's Focus Is on the Game, Not Fun and Games
description: Derek Jeter wanted to avoid this. When George Steinbrenner chastised him publicly in late December for lacking focus, Jeter was vacationing in Belize. When he came home, Jeter ignored a pile of interview requests. He was not going to respond.

title: Using Genetic Tests, Ashkenazi Jews Vanquish a Disease
description: A number of years ago, five families in Brooklyn who had had babies with a devastating disease decided to try what was then nearly unthinkable: to eliminate a terrible genetic disease from the planet.

title: From Flowing Chiffon and Serenity to Nutty Invention
description: It is a novel bit of programming to open an evening with Jerome Robbins's ''Antique Epigraphs'' and Richard Tanner's ''Soire,'' as the New York City Ballet did on Thursday night at the New York State Theater. The 1984 Robbins ballet is all decorous calm. Mr. Tanner's ''Soire'' explodes in a tangy fizz.

Services Wednesday, February 19 at 12 Noon at Schwartz BrosJeffer Funeral Home, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills.

title: Wanted: Traffic Cops For Space
description: After decades of relatively ungoverned exploration and exploitation, rules of the road may be coming to the final frontier.

title: The Snowmobile as a Hot Rod: More Thrills, and More Worries
description: Beyond the thick stands of hemlock and pine, the Great Sacandaga Lake glinted like an icy straightaway, its expanse coated with a patchy layer of snow as white and crisp as an eggshell. Plunging onto it from the wooded trail, Jim Bogert, 60, a retired math teacher, revved his Yamaha sled, reaching 70 miles per hour in white-knuckle spurts.

title: An Artist Who Stayed In Hitler's Germany
description: For many painters, exile from Hitler's Germany offered the only hope of surviving as artists. Klee, Kandinsky, George Grosz and Max Beckmann were among those who fled. Otto Dix did not. Even though denounced by the Nazis as degenerate and ousted from his teaching post, Dix stayed in Germany, opting for what he called ''internal exile'' and abandoning provocative works for inoffensive landscapes and religious themes.

title: Britain Charges Venezuelan Who Had Grenade in Airport
description: A Venezuelan man arrested at Gatwick Airport last week with a live grenade in his luggage was formally charged with terrorist crimes today, and the government said army patrols at Britain's airports would be kept in place for the foreseeable future.

title: Chirac Upsets East Europe by Telling It to 'Shut Up' on Iraq
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 18  The continental rift over Iraq widened sharply today after East European candidates for European Union membership reacted indignantly to advice from President Jacques Chirac of France to pipe down on the subject or risk losing their chance to join Europe's most powerful economic and political club.

title: Terra-Cotta Army From Early Han Dynasty Is Unearthed
description: The Chinese have raised another army of remarkable dimensions, hundreds of foot-tall terra-cotta warriors, along with horses and chariots, that come from the depths of a tomb site south of Beijing.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Tracking Foreigners
description: Russia has begun distributing migration cards to all foreigners entering the country, including tourists. Boris V. Gryzlov, the interior minister, warned that foreigners without the cards might be deported. Officials say the goal is to keep track of the influx of migrant workers, especially from poverty-stricken former Soviet republics like Ukraine, Moldova and Armenia, which have visa-free relations with Russia. Critics say the new cards, which Russia began distributing on Friday, will simply offer opportunities for bribe-taking by the authorities. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: From the French Alps To the Colorado Rockies
description: GILLES GRIMANDI has seen the soccer world from the apex of the English game as a member of last year's Arsenal team, which won the English Premier League and the F.A. Cup, the fabled double. Now he has assumed a new perch, a mile high in Denver with the Colorado Rapids, as the first Frenchman to join Major League Soccer.

title: Snowfall Tally Can Be a Game of Inches
description: Measuring snowfall, it turns out, is not unlike financial accounting. Both are official-looking collections of numbers trying to capture something dynamic. And both are often characterized by a desire to inflate the numbers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHAN, HAROLD
description: COHAN-Harold. On February 15, 2003, of Old Westbury, NY. Beloved husband of Roslyn. Devoted and loving father of Sharon and Philip Ross, Seth and Lori Cohan. Dear brother of Leonard Cohan. Cherished and adored grandfather of Carley, Elliot, Alexandra, Danielle and Hannah. All sought his counsel. He is in our hearts forever and ever. A Senior Partner of Ernst & Young and former President of the Old Westbury Golf and Country Club. Services Today, 10 AM, at Temple Sinai, 425 Roslyn Road, Roslyn Heights, NY. Interment Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENSTADTER, ALFRED
description: EISENSTADTER-Alfred, 86. Died February 13, 2003. Born in Germany, he risked his life by joining a resistance group to fight the Nazis before leaving for New York City in 1940. A lifelong believer in social justice, he was a devoted guidance counselor and a volunteer lawyer for New York Legal Aid, fulfilling his life's ambitions. He leaves his family with a sense of a life well spent. Friends are asked to contribute to the peace movement in Israel in the name of Dr. Julius Eisenstadter, a martyr of the Holocaust.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Bishop Criticizes China
description: Bishop Joseph Zen, the leader of the Roman Catholic Church in Hong Kong, said that mainland China had been stepping up its repression of the Catholic Church and warned that Hong Kong, an autonomous Chinese territory, might become less free if the government wins legislative approval of anti-subversion legislation. The mainland authorities have closed one Catholic seminary but face a younger generation of Catholic priests who are less obedient than older priests, the bishop said. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Global Markets Gain on Optimism That Iraq War Can Be Avoided
description: Major stock indexes gained around the world yesterday on speculation that a war with Iraq might be delayed or averted.

title: Britain Joins U.S. to Draft New Measure Aimed at Iraq
description: Diplomats from the United States and Britain worked today on a new resolution intended to present a short-term ultimatum to Iraq and to enlist the maximum possible support on the Security Council for military action.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGEE, BENJAMIN (RUSTY)
description: MAGEE-Benjamin (Rusty). We will always cherish your friendship, your humor and especially our Thursday morning music sessions. Your music and your spirit will live on in your hundreds of friends, and especially in Nat and Alison. Love, Betsy Berg & Magee Hickey

title: World Business Briefing | World Trade: Singapore and Australia In Deal
description: Wrapping up two years of negotiations, Singapore and Australia signed a free trade agreement that eliminates tariffs on about $5.7 billion in trade. Both countries are already largely open to free trade, and the pact will save Singapore exporters only an estimated $18 million in annual tariffs. For Singapore, the accord follows similar agreements made with New Zealand, the European Free Trade Area, Japan and the United States. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Trouble For Mobilcom Founder
description: The founder and former chief executive of MobilCom, Gerhard Schmid, left, filed for protection from his creditors because of slumping shares in the German phone company. The filing applies to Mr. Schmid's stake in MobilCom, his private wealth and real estate. A MobilCom shareholder, France Tlcom, agreed to keep the company out of bankruptcy last year in exchange for ending an agreement to finance a faster mobile-phone network. The French company, which owns 28.5 percent of MobilCom, ousted Mr. Schmid in June.

title: Heatstroke Kills Minor Leaguer at Orioles' Florida Camp
description: A 23-year-old pitcher in the Baltimore organization died yesterday at a hospital in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., after collapsing Sunday during an Orioles workout. The team's doctor said the pitcher, Steve Bechler, whose temperature had reached 108 degrees, died of multiple organ failure from heatstroke.

title: More Than 120 Die in Arson Attack on South Korean Subway
description: TAEGU, South Korea, Feb. 18  More than 120 people were killed today in an arson attack on a crowded subway train here, and rescue workers feared many more may have died as the fire swept through a second train as well.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Economy Grew 3.7% Last Year
description: The Indonesian economy grew 3.7 percent in 2002, according to data released yesterday, topping the government's forecast of 3.5 percent. Before the nightclub bombing in Bali in October, the government had been forecasting 4 percent growth for the year. The economy grew 3.82 percent in the fourth quarter. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Sumitomo Mitsui Share Sale
description: The Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group will raise 300 billion yen, or $2.5 billion, by selling preferred shares next month in a bid to improve the strength of its capital in the face of stiffer government inspections. The shares, which will be sold to investors overseas, can be converted into common stock as early as April. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERRMANN, JACQUELINE KOLIN
description: HERRMANN-Jacqueline Kolin, 61. On February 14, 2003. Loving daughter of the late Oscar and Berthe Kolin, cherished mother of Edward and Nancy Levin, beloved grandmother of Daniel and Benjamin, adored sister of Diane and Robert Moss. Funeral service will be held on Tuesday, February 18 at noon at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, at 91st Street. Burial immediately following ceremony. Contributions may be made to The Children's Museum of Manhattan, Vassar College, or a charity of your choice.

title: A Slow, Deliberate Process of Judging 9/11 Victim Awards
description: In a well-appointed conference room with wraparound windows, high above the streets of Manhattan, one judge presides over what some families say is a singularly sad, deeply intimidating institution: the unofficial Supreme Court for the families of Sept. 11 victims who are in line to receive financial awards.

title: The Blizzard of 2003
description: There's one thing to be said for the powerful snowstorm that brought the East Coast to a near-standstill over the past two days. It restored us all to the immediacy of the moment. This was an event that had nothing to do with human will. All the official resolutions and declarations in the world would not have abated a single flake of falling snow. Humans have always been disposed to read something symbolic into the grand cataclysms that nature brings, and in the hush that fell over New York, Washington and the other cities on the Eastern Seaboard you could hear an extraordinary peace, as if the storm had momentarily overshadowed the war against terrorism and the escalating crisis with Iraq. The run on duct tape and plastic sheeting stopped temporarily, replaced by a run on snow blowers and ice salt. That free-floating dread was replaced by free-floating flurries.

description: More than 100 people were killed Tuesday morning in an arson attack on a crowded subway train in Taegu, South Korea.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS EXPECTS CHIP SALES TO RISE Texas Instruments Inc., the biggest maker of chips that power mobile phones, expects sales of semiconductors to builders of cellular networks to rise 50 percent in 2003 as operators introduce faster wireless services. Sales of chips that power so-called third-generation networks will rise to about $150 million as customers like Ericsson , the No. 1 maker of wireless networks, gain more business from operators including the Vodafone Group , David Shepard, general manager of Texas Instruments' network infrastructure unit, said. Texas Instruments' shares rose 76 cents, to $16.24.  (Bloomberg News)

title: A Rocky Road Led to Big Russian Oil Deal
description: Russia's deal of the decade got off to a rough start.

title: Sponsor Critical of U.S.O.C.
description: The United States Olympic Committee's fund-raising is floundering, its revenues are stagnant, its licensing royalties are paltry and its salaries have grown too quickly, the chairman of John Hancock Financial Services, a major Olympic sponsor, said yesterday.

title: Death Toll in Korean Subway Arson Climbs to 120
description: Forensic investigators gathered ashes and bones today from the scorched metal skeletons of two subway trains here, seeking to identify scores of commuters who disappeared in the underground inferno here on Tuesday.

title: 600 Ugandans Struggle for Recognition by Israel as Jews
description: The Abayudaya have five synagogues, although three of them are little more than mud huts. They wear skullcaps, which are knitted by local women, and their name means ''people of Judah'' in the local Luganda language. Jewish visitors from overseas have donated five Torahs, which the Abayudaya pull out on Shabbat, the Jewish day of rest.

title: German Court Convicts Student of Aiding Sept. 11 Terrorists
description: HAMBURG, Germany, Feb. 19  Delivering the first verdict connected to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, a German court convicted a Moroccan student today of assisting airline hijackers in the murder of more than 3,000 people, and it sentenced him to the maximum term of 15 years in prison.

title: America's Cup Has Whiff Of a Rout After 3 Races
description: Only three races into a five-of-nine-race series, the America's Cup is beginning to feel like one of those Super Bowls where the team with the vaunted offense is thrown out of its rhythm in the first quarter by turnovers and mental mistakes and finds itself horribly behind before the fans at home have managed to get the nachos out of the microwave.

title: HoJo to Go? Say It Ain't So
description: NEW YORK may be down to its last fried clam strip. A few weeks ago, The New York Post reported that Howard Johnson's, in business at 46th Street and Broadway for more than 40 years, might be leaving Times Square forever. The owners of the building, who also hold the HoJo license, apparently decided that they could make more money renting out the ground floor than running a restaurant, even one that's been in the family since 1959.

title: U.S. and Turkey Remain Deadlocked on Aid
description: ISTANBUL, Feb. 19  The Bush administration's plans for a northern front against Iraq were thrown into doubt today, as negotiations with Turkish leaders failed to break a deadlock over how much economic aid their country should receive if war came.

title: 2 War Foes Take Steps on Seeking Presidency
description: Two strong opponents of war with Iraq, Representative Dennis J. Kucinich of Ohio and former Senator Carol Moseley-Braun of Illinois, made plans today to take the first step toward running for the Democratic nomination for president.

title: New Charter for Shuttle Board, But Critics Are Not Appeased
description: NASA officials released a new charter today for the panel investigating the shuttle disaster, the third revision in less than two weeks. But the changes failed to quell concerns in Congress about whether the board is sufficiently independent.

title: Attending to the Needs Of the Musical Food Chain
description: There are all sorts of reasons that the New York Youth Symphony is a worthy project, and if some are purely educational -- for 40 seasons it has offered talented musicians from 12 to 22 a place to learn orchestral playing -- others have to do with its place in the larger music scene.

title: Building on Lure of Burbank, Entertainment Hub
description: A slightly harrowing helicopter ride is one way that officials of this city demonstrate to prospective business tenants the close relationship of Burbank to Hollywood.

title: The Elegance of Open Space
description: Americans are used to heaping plates, but Japanese food is presented in a minimalist style and was a profound influence on nouvelle cuisine starting in the 1970's. ''The Fine Art of Japanese Food Arrangement'' by Yoshio Tsuchiya (Kodansha, $35), explains the rules, which depend not only on the kind of food and type of vessel used, but also on the seasons. Food, the book explains, is usually arranged to honor ''the beauty of empty space'' in patterns called flat, bowl, piled up, jumbled, nestled, scattered, even cedar tree, a kind of pyramid, all diagrammed in the book. To prevent dull symmetry, pieces of food look best in odd numbers; sashimi is always arranged with three, five or seven slices. The book includes many photos of utensils and containers, as well as their history.

title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE REGIONAL MARKET -- Midtown Manhattan; Maker of Luxury Goods Burnishes 57th St. Image
description: LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the Paris-based producer of luxury goods, has acquired a real estate portfolio on 57th Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues and is helping burnish the street as a prime destination for high-end shopping.

title: Recipe: Chicken With Mixed Mushrooms and Cream
description: Time: 1 1/4 hours

title: The Dough
description: Pizza might be our most-eaten and least-made food. Its popularity is obvious: almost every town in America has a pizzeria; most cities have dozens, and some have a signature slice (thin crust in New York, deep dish in Chicago). And yet when was the last time you had a homemade slice? A good pizza dough can be made easily, quickly and without any special hardware (a baking stone is great, but it can easily be substituted with a simple sheet pan).

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the recent killing of a Mexican drug policeman misspelled the name of a United States drug agent who was murdered by Mexican dealers in 1985. He was Enrique Camarena, not Camerena.

title: Magazine Advertising Shows a Rise This Year
description: Magazine advertising began 2003 on a positive note, the Publishers Information Bureau in New York reported yesterday. Ad pages rose in January, the third consecutive monthly increase.

title: With O'Neal and Yao Out, Bryant Steals the Show
description: With his head buried in his hands as he sat on the bench in the second overtime, Yao Ming was closer to going to bed Tuesday night than going back into the game.

title: Business on the Bubble
description: Thirty feet up, a half-dozen people were bouncing around with shovels on what looked like a sloped and synthetic moon surface. None of them were beholden to gravity, but the snow was: as the crew shoveled, it came crashing down to the ground in caked sheets.

title: Jets' Elliott to Testify Before Grand Jury
description: Jets offensive tackle Jumbo Elliott is expected to testify before a Nassau County grand jury in Mineola, N.Y., today about his role in an incident outside a steakhouse on Long Island last December. A limousine driver has accused the player of assaulting him. Testimony was postponed a day because of the snow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOATE, ELSIE K.
description: SLOATE-Elsie K., 96, a model mother, friend and philanthropist, she passed peacefully on February 18. She was there for me throughout my life, particularly when I needed her most. A woman of boundless generosity to her family and far-reaching circle of friends. She left an indelible mark on those she touched with her gifts of spirit and kindness. She was a great philanthropist and a major force behind the Fight for Sight League of Manhattan for more than 35 years. My mother was blessed with a great life and I know that I will live my life in her spirit. In lieu of flowers a research fund has been established in her honor, The Elsie K. Sloate Fellowship Fund, New York Presbyterian Hospital. Your loving daugher, Laura

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERNER, ELIZABETH G.
description: WERNER-Elizabeth G. The Auxiliary of Lenox Hill Hospital records with sorrow the death of our cherished and devoted member of many years. Our deepest condolences to her family. Katherine T. McEnroe, Chairman

title: The Adventure of Stenography, And Other Fulfilling Careers
description: 'The Typographer's Dream'

title: Justifying a Liberal Arts Education in Difficult Times
description: Liberal education is under siege. Critics, of whom there are many, call it an overpriced indulgence for the affluent few who do not have to worry about earning a living upon graduation. Fewer and fewer of today's undergraduates are pursuing the liberal arts, with most of them studying practical subjects like finance, marketing, real estate and pharmacy.

title: Deadly Stampede Prompts Debate on Club's Defiance
description: City officials acknowledged today that they had done nothing to ensure that a restaurant-nightclub where 21 people died in a stampede early Monday was obeying a court order barring entry to its second floor but laid the responsibility on the club's owners, whom they described as reckless and negligent.

title: New on the Cheese Lover's Map
description: The Bedford Cheese Shop is tucked into a funky little mall at 218 Bedford Avenue (North Fifth Street) in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. It has plenty of funky cheeses, too, including Ardrahan from Ireland ($10.99 a pound), which is described by its tag as smelling "like a drunken sailor on shore leave." But don't let that put you off, because Ardrahan is a richly complex cheese and not nearly as pungent as pecorino with truffles ($17.99 a pound). Pere Joseph from Belgium ($9.99 a pound) and the well-aged blue, Monty's Reserve from Point Reyes in California ($19.99 a pound), are other good bets from a selection of about 60 cheeses. The cheesemonger, Frank Shuck, at right, opened the shop with his partners after years at the temples of cheese: Fairway, Dean & DeLuca, Balducci's and Murray's. None of the cheeses are cut in advance and there is no minimum amount that must be purchased. Breads by a local baker, soups from a local chef and even marble and ironwork from local artisans firmly root this new shop.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBACH, KURT
description: ROSENBACH-Kurt. Died after a brief but courageous battle with cancer on February 17, 2003 at age 75. He was surrounded by Bernice, his loving wife of 50 years, his children Karen and Gary, and their spouses Tom and Susan. Kurt was cherished and adored and will always be remembered by his five grandchildren Nicole, Joshua, Brandon, Bess and Sophie. He was a positive force behind his family, a kind, gentle, generous man who will be sorely missed by all those he touched. Services will be held Wednesday, February 19 at 11:15 AM, at ''the Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Some Concerns Thrive On Medicaid Patients
description: As President Bush presses Congress to let private insurers take over more of Medicare and Medicaid, a handful of for-profit managed care companies are already hard at it, running state programs for five million low-income people in Medicaid plans.

description: Blame in Chicago Stampede

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Campaign-Finance Bills
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday signed a variety of bills into law, including two bills affecting the campaign-finance program and one broadening the whistle-blower-protection law. The mayor, a billionaire, did not participate in the finance program. One bill prevents candidates who face little or no opposition from qualifying for maximum public funds and requires campaigns to file disclosure statements electronically. The bill also included other technical changes to the program. The other law will permit candidates who have participated in the program to receive post-election contributions to repay debt. The bill allows David N. Dinkins, pictured, the former mayor, to clear $200,000 in debt from his failed 1993 campaign. Mr. Bloomberg also approved broadening the definition of whistle-blower, as well the category of complaints covered. He also signed a law requiring the Department of Records and Information Services to place city publications on its Web site. Several streets were also renamed yesterday, many after victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attack.

title: MAKER OF LOW-TOXIN CIGARETTES AGREES TO SELL BUSINESS
description: Star Scientific Inc., a maker of discount, low-toxin cigarettes, agreed to sell the cigarette business operated by its Star Tobacco unit to the closely held North Atlantic Trading Company for $80 million in cash. Sales of the four cigarette brands made and sold by Star Tobacco accounted for the ''majority'' of Star Scientific's revenue, according to the company, which is based in Chester, Va.

title: Exile Talks of His 'Duty' To Free Iraqis of Hussein
description: He deserted Saddam Hussein's army, was locked up in Saddam Hussein's prisons and eventually escaped from Saddam Hussein's tyranny to make his way here.

title: Looking for Answers in Aftermath of Korean Subway Fire
description: TAEGU, South Korea, Thursday, Feb. 20  She liked to joke so much, everyone thought she was joking again when she called on her cellphone saying, "Mom, there's a fire in the tunnel."

description: JARHEAD

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Attorney General To Step Down
description: Attorney General Mike Moore, 50, who spearheaded a nationwide legal battle against cigarette makers in the 1990's and won a record multibillion-dollar legal settlement, will not seek re-election this fall. Mr. Moore, left, who is serving his fourth, four-year term, said he was taking a break from politics, but emphasized his longstanding interest in one day running for the United States Senate. Mr. Moore toyed with bids for governor both in 1999 and again this year, but said he wanted instead to focus on his family and would probably practice law.

title: The Driver's Quandary: A Shovel Today, or a Chisel Tomorrow
description: Go to work or stay home? Wear the boots or the cross-country skis? The day after the big storm, the New York region faced its share of tough choices. But in New York City yesterday, the toughest question for many was this: Move the car or let it sit?

title: A Menu Journeys to the Back of Beyond
description: A VERY slender idea weaves its way through Voyage, like a faint but pleasing tune. It's a theme of sorts, but not enough of one to make Voyage a theme restaurant. That would be too coercive for the personality of the place, which might as well have been called Whatever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GWERTZMAN, ADELAIDE
description: GWERTZMAN-Adelaide. On February 18, 2003, at age 92. Loving wife of the late Max J. Gwertzman. Cherished mother of Bernard M. Gwertzman and his wife Marie-Jeanne, and Stephen N. Gwertzman & his wife Sheila. Grandmother of Dr. Alan Gwertzman, Lisa Donnelly, Lynn Hendricks, John Spencer, James S. Gwertzman and Michael D. Gwertzman. title: Intel Will Overhaul Plant
description: Intel, the world's biggest computer-chip maker, said today that it would spend $2 billion to overhaul a factory in Arizona to use a less-expensive manufacturing method. The plant, which is in Chandler and known as Fab 12, will use 300-millimeter wafers instead of 200-millimeter ones. The work will begin in the first half of 2004, and production will start in late 2005. Intel said it would spread out payments for equipment from now to 2005.
