title: Chirac Scolding Angers Nations That Back U.S.
description: ''New Europe'' barked back at ''old Europe'' today, deepening the continental rift over Iraq after President Jacques Chirac of France told Central and Eastern European countries to keep their views on Iraq to themselves or risk losing their chance to join the European Union.

title: Tyson-Etienne Fight Appears Once Again to Be Back On
description: ROBINSONVILLE, Miss., Feb. 19  The promoter of the off-again, on-again, off-again heavyweight fight between Mike Tyson and Clifford Etienne said here today that Etienne is back in and that the match is on again.

title: THREATS AND RESPONSES: OUT IN THE WORLD -- Germany; Skepticism About U.S. And Its Motives
description: Joshua B. Kalish, a 38-year-old consultant from New Jersey who has lived in Frankfurt for a year, says that when he asks Germans their opinion about the White House's campaign against Saddam Hussein, they answer in a single word: oil.

title: Tobacco Cash As Budget Fix: In Albany, No Consensus
description: The rough outlines of a political face-off between Gov. George E. Pataki and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver took shape today as Mr. Silver repudiated the centerpiece of the governor's plan to solve the state's fiscal crisis: securing billions of dollars in tobacco settlement money.

title: THREATS AND RESPONSES: OUT IN THE WORLD -- Pakistan; Most Dangerous Spot For Americans
description: Don Graybiel, a soft-spoken 54-year-old music, English and social studies teacher from Port Huron, Mich., does not talk politics with his Pakistani friends. But he still hears the anger. His seventh-grade students express it to him.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Industrial Production Rises
description: Argentina's industrial production rose in January for a third consecutive month for the first time in more than two years, signaling that the country may be recovering from its worst economic slump in a century. January's output rose a nonseasonally adjusted 18 percent from the month a year earlier. Production rose 4 percent from December, the National Statistics Institute reported. Argentine exports became more competitive after the country ended a currency peg with the U.S. dollar in January 2002 and the peso lost 70 percent of its value last year. Demand for locally made goods increased after imports became too expensive for most Argentines to afford. Argentina froze bank deposits, defaulted on $95 billion of bonds and devalued the currency more than one year ago, causing the economy to contract about 12 percent last year.

title: Red Storm Shows Up But Misses In Syracuse
description: Ball after ball soared from the hands of St. John's players toward the Carrier Dome's inflated roof tonight. Most of them landed with a clank.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Politician Is Slain
description: A ranking member of Cambodia's royalist party was shot to death at a restaurant, in what was apparently the latest in a series of political killings that have begun in advance of a parliamentary election in July. As with the other killings, the motive could not be confirmed, but the victim, Om Radsaday, was the 10th political figure to have been killed in recent months. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: With Martelli as Coach, St. Joseph's Is on the March
description: There is the deadly serious defense, retooled before the season into a claustrophobic full-court press. There is a trove of perimeter players -- the cool-handed point guard Jameer Nelson, the stop-and-pop scorer Delonte West and the nation's most accurate 3-point shooter, Pat Carroll. But to get at the soul of St. Joseph's basketball means attending the taping of the ''HawkTalk'' television show.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Silicon Graphics Wins $26 Million Contract
description: Silicon Graphics Inc., whose computers are used in missile systems, won a $26 million contract yesterday from the Defense Department and said similar deals may be forthcoming. The department ordered hardware, software and services for its High Performance Computing Modernization Program, which conducts simulations of weapons and weather, said Tony Celeste, director of Silicon Graphics' military business. Silicon Graphics, which has posted net losses for three straight quarters, has increased revenue from the military sector to 35 percent, from 20 percent about two years ago. Its shares rose 16 cents, to $1.28.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ACKERMAN, SAMUEL I.
description: ACKERMAN-Samuel I. Attorney at law. Beloved husband of Rosetta. Loving father of Stefanie and Melissa and stepfather of John. Cherished grandfather of Jesse and Alex. Devoted brother of Gary. Services Thursday, 10:30AM at Parkside Chapel, 98-60 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills (66th Avenue).

title: Neither Side Yielding in Debate Over War With Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19  As thousands of additional British and American troops headed toward the Persian Gulf today, leaders on both sides of the Iraq war debate dug in their heels with more uncompromising statements of policy.

title: Where Talk of War Includes 'Mom' or 'Dad'
description: Club USA, with 14 third and fourth graders, was in session at Holbrook Elementary School here. The club is for children whose fathers or mothers are in the Army and have been deployed abroad, many of them now to the Persian Gulf or Afghanistan as part of the war on terrorism.

title: NEW LINE AT CAMPBELL TO INCLUDE PIZZA-FLAVORED SOUP
description: The Campbell Soup Company, whose stock fell to a three-month low last week after reducing a profit forecast, will broaden its ready-to-eat soup line in July. Seventeen microwavable soups, including one tasting like pizza, will be introduced, Campbell, the world's biggest soup maker, told securities analysts in Scottsdale, Ariz. Shipments of condensed soups by Campbell, which is based in Camden, N.J., declined 3 percent in the three months ended Jan. 26.

title: A Hot New Technique
description: It is the ashes-to-ashes school of snow removal. Loud, hungry and orange, the new snow-melting machines in New York City churned around the clock, turning the snow from city streets back into water.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, FRANCES B.
description: CLARK-Frances B. Passed away peacefully on February 18, 2003. Dearly beloved wife of Robert L. Clark, who survives her. Also survived by her sister-in-law and brotherin-law Donna and Eugene Famera. Predeceased by her brother Richard Wayne Bohle. Attended Brown University and graduated from Beloit College; a talented college textbook editor and legal assistant. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Salvation Army. A private memorial service for the immediate family will be held at a later date.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: ITALY: TIRE MAKER'S PROFIT SOARS Fourth-quarter operating profit at Pirelli surged more than fourfold, to 22 million euros ($23.6 million) as the company cut costs and shed capacity to offset a decline in sales. The company, which manufactures tires and cable, is beginning to reap the benefits of efficiency measures put in place to counter what the chairman, Marco Tronchetti Provera, called the disappearance of the market for telecommunications cables. Pirelli cut its work force by 9 percent in 2002 and is planning further reductions this year. Demand for tires and nontelecommunications cables has continued to rebound in the first two months of 2003, Pirelli said. The company will release final fourth-quarter financial results next month.

title: Call In the 'Cavalry,' Or Try Other Ways?
description: To the Editor:

title: FARMLAND SEEKS TO SELL ITS FERTILIZER BUSINESS
description: Farmland Industries Inc., which is seeking to reorganize under bankruptcy protection, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its fertilizer businesses to a unit of Koch Industries for $270 million in cash and assumed debt. The purchase price includes $104.4 million for assets of Farmland's domestic fertilizer business and $86.5 million for its 50 percent stake in Farmland MissChem Ltd., Farmland said. The Koch Nitrogen Company unit will assume $79.1 million in debt under the agreement, which is subject to approval by the bankruptcy court, Farmland said. Farmland, based in Kansas City, Mo., is owned by 600,000 farmers and is the largest United States farm cooperative. It filed for bankruptcy protection in May 2002 after a slide in fertilizer sales left it unable to make payments on $1.5 billion in debt.

title: CINTAS, MAKER OF UNIFORMS, LOWERS ITS OUTLOOK
description: The Cintas Corporation, the country's largest maker of uniforms, said yesterday that it had lowered its fiscal 2003 expectations even further, as sales during the holidays fell significantly below its expectations. The company, based in Cincinnati, attributed the revenue shortfall to job cuts and hiring freezes by its corporate customers. Shares of the company were fell to $35.09, down $4.37, on heavy volume on the Nasdaq exchange. Cintas now expects to earn $1.43 to $1.50 a share for the fiscal year ending May 31.

title: The Messages From the Protests
description: To the Editor:

title: The Tyson Fight Is On Again, Then Off Again
description: In a boxing farce worthy of a Bernie Mac routine, Mike Tyson reversed his decision on Monday to cancel his fight Saturday night against Clifford Etienne, only to be trumped by Etienne's decision hours later to back out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALDWIN, EILEEN N. (MRS. JAMES FRENCH)
description: BALDWIN-Eileen N. (Mrs. James French). Died suddenly, and unexpectedly at her home in Delray Beach, FL on Monday February 17, 2003 in her 86th year. She is survived by her daughter, Mimi Rosenwald of Ossining, NY; her son John Moore of NYC; her step-daughter Susan Johnson of Newport, RI; her stepson Jay Baldwin of Annapolis, MD; by many grandchildren and several greatgrandchildren. Memorial services will be held in Delray Beach and in Locust Valley.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELF, ESTELLE
description: SELF-Estelle. Died February 17, 2003, peacefully at the age of 93. Preceded in death by husbands, Lowell Self and Nathan Grief, and son Martin Self. Survived by daughter Lenore Katkin, son Steven and wife Judy, seven grandchildren, five great-grandchildren. Services private. Shiva observed at home of Lenore Katkin. Donations to charity of one's choice.

title: Donor Mix-Up Leaves Girl, 17, Fighting for Life
description: A 17-year-old girl is in critical condition after mistakenly being given a heart and lung transplant from a donor with the wrong blood type at Duke University Hospital in Durham, N.C.

title: For Federal Lawmakers, Some New Dos and Don'ts
description: Here are 4 of a set of 15 questions and answers in a Jan. 3 memorandum sent by Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, the House minority leader, to Democratic lawmakers and aides in response to confusion about the new campaign finance law. (A second memorandum, with 14 more questions and answers, was issued on Jan. 29.)

title: When a Sexual Decision Wound Up With a Fatality
description: 'Sleeping With Straight Men'

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about New York City public schools that are exempt from the new mandatory curriculum misattributed part of a quotation from a parent upset over the failure of Middle School 167 to make the list. It was Kerry Crowe, a co-president of the parent association, not Karlai Lee, who said, ''It's definitely upsetting because people use something like this to judge a school, and it's going to hurt our reputation.''

title: Iraq Factor Complicates Euro Issue For Britain
description: With many Britons troubled by the prospect of their soldiers fighting in Iraq, new uncertainties have arisen over Prime Minister Tony Blair's chances of maintaining his schedule for Britain's entry into the euro currency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIDALY, WALTER
description: GIDALY-Walter. On February 17. Beloved husband of Barbara Gidaly. Devoted uncle of Ronnie, Glenn and Jed. Also survived by many grandnieces and grandnephews. Memorial service to be held at a later date.

title: Playing From the Men's Tee
description: It was encouraging to hear Tiger Woods react not by oozing graciousness but by flashing competitiveness at the news that Annika Sorenstam, the No. 1 woman golfer, will challenge the men at the Colonial golf tournament in Fort Worth this May. ''It will only be great for women's golf if she plays well,'' said Tiger, not missing the opportunity for some early psyching. Ms. Sorenstam is hardly subject to jitters, having won more women's tournaments in the last two years, 19 of 49, than Woods has won in dominating the men's tour.

title: An Herb Under Scrutiny
description: Xenadrine, the weight-loss aid that pitcher Steve Bechler had reportedly been taking before his death on Monday, contains ephedra, a stimulant derived from the Asian ma huang plant. As an herbal product, ephedra is not regulated by the Food and Drug Administration. But its side effects are so potent that the agency is considering limitations on its use.

title: Another March of Folly?
description: Twenty years ago this month, I was an aide to Vice President George Bush during another trans-Atlantic crisis. There were demonstrations in European capitals in which America was portrayed as the threat to world peace and the American president was called a warmonger, a ''cowboy'' and worse. Vice President Bush's response in February 1983 may hold some lessons for President Bush in February 2003.

title: Market Place; Holder Seeks Ouster of Board Of El Paso
description: A dissident shareholder of the El Paso Corporation kicked off what is expected to be an especially rancorous corporate proxy season yesterday by saying he hoped to oust the company's entire board.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLITE, L. JOHN JR.
description: POLITE-L. John Jr. 81. A longtime resident of Saddle River, N.J and Jupiter, Florida died Sunday, February 9, from complications of surgery. Born on April 30,1921 in McKeesport, Pennsylvania, Mr. Polite attended Aspinwall H.S. and went on to graduate from Williams College in 1942. Thereafter, he became a commissioned officer of the U.S. Navy and served aboard the USS Minneapolis as well as the USS Bremerton. Enjoying a distinguished business career, Mr. Polite was the President of the Essex Chemical Corporation from 1962 to 1988 and served as a director for numerous corporations and non profit organizations. He will be remembered most for his generosity and giant heart. He is survived by previous wife Marilyn Bewie, first wife Katherine Loresch, their sons John (Tuxedo, N.Y.), Daniel (Hillsborough, CA) and David (Carlton, OR), as well as two granddaughters, his brother Willis (Belvedere, CA), and his sister Barbara Grant (Lincoln, NE). A memorial service will be held on February 22 from 4-6:00 P.M. at the Chemist Club, 40 West 45th Street in New York City. Those wishing to do so may make a memorial donation to the National Organization for Alzheimer's Disease, 919 North Michigan Avenue, Chicago, IL. 60611.

title: For Bonds, Life as a Giant Is About Wishing and Praying
description: It took Barry Bonds 17 often frustrating years to play in a World Series last season. He wants everyone to believe that it took him about 17 minutes to forget the agonizing way the San Francisco Giants wrapped a bow on the Anaheim Angels' title.

title: When the Snow Flies, It's the Season for Shrimp
description: The depth of winter brings a bright seasonal delicacy to the seafood counter. Fresh shrimp gathered off the coast of Maine will be nestled on ice in some markets until the end of the month. These are wild shrimp, never frozen. They are often sold headless, which extends the shelf life a bit. But they are more flavorful with the heads on. Toss the shrimp into water as salty as the sea, and cook ever so briefly -- until the pot has just returned to a boil. Peel and eat them hot or chilled, with mayonnaise or some other dip. At Citarella markets, Maine shrimp are $7.99 a pound, heads and all. Wild Edibles market sells them for $7.95 a pound, also heads on. And at Agata & Valentina, they are $3.99 with heads, $5.99 with none.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Electronic Data Chief Received No Bonus
description: Electronic Data Systems, the world's second-largest seller of computer services, paid no bonus or stock options to the chief executive, Richard H. Brown, last year, when the company's stock fell 73 percent. Mr. Brown's salary was unchanged at $1.5 million, according to a preliminary version of the company's proxy statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday. In 2001, Mr. Brown received a $7 million bonus, $27.7 million in restricted stock and 750,000 stock options. The company reduced its profit forecast three times last year, including a Sept. 18 cut that sent shares down 53 percent. The September warning, and a bet the company made on its share price, are under investigation. Its shares rose 70 cents, to $16.34.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Central Bank To Limit Moves
description: Masaru Hayami, the Bank of Japan governor, said that the central bank would not increase purchases of stocks or bonds. The central bank has promised to buy up to 2 trillion yen ($16.8 billion) in equities from Japanese banks to help them reduce their exposure to risk assets. Less than half of that money has been used so far. The bank is also buying 1.2 trillion yen ($10 billion) in government bonds from the market every month. Mr. Hayami warned last month, however, that a decline in bond prices would burden the central bank with more than $8 billion in losses. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: The Coalition of the Willing
description: The White House was able to clear enough snow from the driveway to play host to the president of Latvia on Monday, and this weekend President Bush will show Prime Minister Jos Mara Aznar of Spain around his Texas ranch. In recent weeks Mr. Bush has also greeted Italy's prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, and Tony Blair, prime minister of Britain. All this hospitality is an effort to demonstrate that the United States does not stand alone in its determination to force Iraq to disarm, or in its belief that the time is approaching when a war to do so might be justified. The red carpet treatment is fine, but no one should mistake the coalition that Mr. Bush is assembling for the United Nations Security Council.

description: Masashi Teranishi, the chairman of the Japanese Bankers Association and president of UFJ Holdings, said that Japan's largest lenders might invest in a new government agency charged with overhauling troubled borrowers. The organization, tentatively called the Industrial Revitalization Corporation, will lend money to companies that are viable but have been hurt because banks have been forced to call in loans. title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: LONG HILL TOWNSHIP: ANTHRAX RULED OUT Tests have ruled out anthrax as the substance that fell from a letter at a post office. The post office has been closed since the substance was discovered Friday. It is scheduled to reopen today, said Tony Esposito, a spokesman for the Postal Service. Mr. Esposito said only that the State Department of Health and Senior Services had determined that the substance was not dangerous. The envelope with the substance contained a threatening letter, Mr. Esposito said. (AP)

title: Defining Success In Narrow Terms
description: THE students, the parents, the teachers at Gonzales Elementary thought they had a terrific school. Though the mostly Mexican-American student body is very poor (83 percent receive free lunches), though Spanish is the first language of half the children, though many are migrants and the school's annual mobility rate is 29 percent, though they live in a drab little town that smells of blood from the nearby meat-packing plant, they are proud of their handsome school.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Texas Instruments Expects Chip Sales  To Rise
description: Texas Instruments Inc., the biggest maker of chips that power mobile phones, expects sales of semiconductors to builders of cellular networks to rise 50 percent in 2003 as operators introduce faster wireless services. Sales of chips that power so-called third-generation networks will rise to about $150 million as customers like Ericsson, the No. 1 maker of wireless networks, gain more business from operators including the Vodafone Group, David Shepard, general manager of Texas Instruments' network infrastructure unit, said. Texas Instruments' shares rose 76 cents, to $16.24.

The Sharks, in last place in the Pacific after winning the division a year ago, are the most disappointing team in the league this season.

title: Seeing Virtue In Life's Tribulations
description: Mistakes, regrets and tentative second chances were the makings of the new songs that Rosanne Cash sang at Joe's Pub last Wednesday night. She is Johnny Cash's daughter, and while she had country hits back in the 1980's, at this point she is content to stay far from the smiley country mainstream. Her songs have less transitory virtues: durable folky melodies, chiseled lyrics and quietly telling insights. She observes past errors and the scars and lessons they've left.

She adored and was adored by her 8 grandchildren and their spouses. Her ten great grandchildren brought immense joy to her. title: World Briefing: Asia
description: CAMBODIA: POLITICIAN IS SLAIN A ranking member of Cambodia's royalist party was shot to death at a restaurant, in what was apparently the latest in a series of political killings that have begun in advance of a parliamentary election in July. As with the other killings, the motive could not be confirmed, but the victim, Om Radsaday, was the 10th political figure to have been killed in recent months.    Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Israelis Kill 12 Palestinians in Clashes With Gunmen

Lost amid the clatter is that many decent people of enlightened and pragmatic views oppose an invasion against Iraq, even many who supported the Persian Gulf war.

title: A Whole Lot of Care

title: After a Day of Powdery Play, The City Faces Slushy Reality
description: Monday was like a dress rehearsal, a holiday when millions of people could spend hours conquering snowdrifts or trying out shovels and snowblowers or humming the Sammy Cahn lyric (music by Jule Styne), Let it snow, let it snow, let it snow. On a no-pressure day, no problem.

title: New on the Cheese Lover's Map
description: The Bedford Cheese Shop is tucked into a funky little mall at 218 Bedford Avenue (North Fifth Street) in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. It has plenty of funky cheeses, too, including Ardrahan from Ireland ($10.99 a pound), which is described by its tag as smelling ''like a drunken sailor on shore leave.'' But don't let that put you off, because Ardrahan is a richly complex cheese and not nearly as pungent as pecorino with truffles ($17.99 a pound). Pre Joseph from Belgium ($9.99 a pound) and the well-aged blue, Monty's Reserve from Point Reyes in California ($19.99 a pound), are other good bets from a selection of about 60 cheeses. The cheesemonger, Frank Shuck, above, opened the shop with his partners after years at the temples of cheese: Fairway, Dean & DeLuca, Balducci's and Murray's. None of the cheeses are cut in advance and there is no minimum amount that must be purchased. Breads by a local baker, soups from a local chef and even marble and ironwork from local artisans firmly root this new shop.

title: Shift at Broadcasting Unit Puts Turner Ally in Top Post
description: Jamie Kellner, a television executive who built two successful networks from the ground up but could not reverse the slide of CNN against the onslaught of the Fox News Channel, said yesterday that he would leave his job as chairman and chief executive of Turner Broadcasting System next month. The move revives questions about Ted Turner's lingering influence at AOL Time Warner.

title: Muslim Lands Say War Could Bring Havoc
description: A phalanx of Muslim nations, including two of the United States' closest allies and Iraq's closest neighbors, warned today that the Middle East could face a harvest of political, human and economic havoc in the event of an American-led war against Saddam Hussein.

title: Top Comic Is the Hero of 'Defrauded' Argentines
description: By night, Nito Artaza is Argentina's most popular comedian, playing here to packed houses that roar as he imitates and ridicules the politicians and financiers who have led this country to ruin. But it is his new day job that is really making the establishment squirm.

title: The Rhythm of Flamenco Wins American Hearts
description: The latest of Jazz at Lincoln Center's excursions into foreign music was ''Flamenco Nights,'' Thursday's concert at Alice Tully Hall, and the connecting of flamenco to jazz went off well, if a little stiff-jointed at the American end.

title: Fearing a Big Flood, Paris Moves Art
description: In the largest relocation of artworks in France since World War II, museums here have begun evacuating about 100,000 paintings, drawings, statues, sculptures, books and other valuable objects from underground storage rooms that would be expected to flood if the River Seine were to rise to or beyond the record level of 28 feet, reached in 1910.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Delay On Pier 40 Decision
description: Faced with four proposals that have drawn varying degrees of criticism, the Hudson River Park Trust is delaying selection of a developer for Pier 40 in Greenwich Village, a trust spokesman said yesterday. The trust let last Saturday's selection deadline lapse because some members said they lacked enough information to choose a winner, said the spokesman, Alex Dudley. Assemblywoman Deborah J. Glick plans a bill to extend the deadline to June 15, her chief of staff, Karen Feuer, said. All four plans include open space as well as retail space to help support the five-mile-long park that the trust is building along the river. One developer proposed an aquarium, while two others proposed ''big-box'' stores.

title: Gephardt Opens Campaign With Critique of Bush
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 19  Representative Richard A. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Unrest Roils Steel Maker
description: Arcelor, the world's largest steel maker, said protesters held six managers from its Cockerill Sambre unit, including the chief executive, captive for 23 hours over plans to close blast furnaces in Belgium. The officials, including Alain Bouchard, the managing director, were meeting with about 150 workers at the University of Liege in eastern Belgium when the protesters entered the room just after midday Monday. They held the managers until about 11 a.m. yesterday, said a Cockerill spokesman, Etienne Botton, who was also held captive. Police officers were nearby but were not asked to intervene and there was no violence, Mr. Botton said. The protesters were reacting to a plan to close six furnaces in Belgium, France and Germany.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINDEK, JOANNE LESKO
description: GINDEK - Joanne Lesko. Joanne Lesko Gindek died peacefully in Ridgefield, Connecticut on February 17, 2003 at the age of 66. Born in Danbury, Connecticut, Joanne was the daughter of George M. Lesko, an army captain in World War II, and Zillah Ellis Lesko, a renowned children's book illustrator. Educated at the prestigious Pratt Institute in New York City, Joanne was regarded as one of the most influential, talented, creative individuals in the cosmetics industry. In four decades, working in her own firm and with industry giants, she created over 150 cosmetic packaging, merchandising and advertising designs that set the pace in beauty, elegance and glamour for the industry. In her work as in her private life, Joanne radiated restraint and strength. She was at her best under a crunch with a defiant resolve to make things happen no matter what. Her style was timeless, her charm without blemish, her grace under pressure unassailable. She faced down the diagnosis of cancer with her usual style and composure. The true measure of a woman is not in the wealth she leaves behind but the richness of the memories she gave to others. In that respect Joanne was the most successful woman, we know. Joanne is survived by Leslie Rowe, her family and friends who miss her companionship and treasure her memory. Friends will be received on Friday from 7-9:00 PM at the Hull Funeral Home, 60 Division Street, Danbury, Connecticut. Funeral Services will be held at the Hull Funeral Home, Saturday, February 22, 2003 at 10:30 AM. Burial will follow at Mountain Grove Cemetery in Bridgeport, Connecticut.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: CENTRAL BANK TO LIMIT MOVES Masaru Hayami, the Bank of Japan governor, said that the central bank would not increase purchases of stocks or bonds. The central bank has promised to buy up to 2 trillion yen ($16.8 billion) in equities from Japanese banks to help them reduce their exposure to risk assets. Less than half of that money has been used so far. The bank is also buying 1.2 trillion yen ($10 billion) in government bonds from the market every month. Mr. Hayami warned last month, however, that a decline in bond prices would burden the central bank with more than $8 billion in losses.

title: Roundup Unready
description: One of the most pervasive chemicals in modern agriculture is a herbicide called glyphosate, which is better known by its trade name, Roundup. When it was first introduced in 1974, by Monsanto, no one could have predicted its current ubiquity or the way it would change farming. Roundup was safe, effective and relatively benign, environmentally speaking. It became one of the essential tools that made no-till farming -- a conservation practice in which farmers spray weeds rather than plowing the ground -- increasingly popular. But what really made Roundup pervasive was the development of genetically modified crops, especially soybeans, cotton and corn, that could tolerate having Roundup sprayed directly on them. The weeds died but these crops, designated Roundup Ready, thrived. Seventy-five percent of the soybean crop planted in this country last year was Roundup Ready, as was 65 percent of the cotton and 10 percent of the corn. On soybeans alone last year, farmers sprayed about 33 million pounds of glyphosate.

title: The Sounds and Rhythms That Helped Bring Down Apartheid
description: From ''The Marseillaise'' to ''We Shall Overcome,'' there has probably never been a revolution that did not use songs to give voice to its aspirations or rally the morale of its adherents. As the South African pianist Abdullah Ibrahim remarks in ''Amandla!,'' a documentary directed by Lee Hirsch that opens in Manhattan today, the toppling of apartheid may be a special case, the first revolution ever to be conducted ''in four-part harmony.'' Mr. Ibrahim's observation, which supplies this restless, moving film with its subtitle, points to the central role that music -- in the streets, on records, in prison and in exile -- played in black South Africa's long struggle for liberation from white domination.

title: BIG STEEL MAKER TO RAISE SHEET PRICES BY 8.6%
description: The Nucor Corporation will raise steel-sheet prices by $30 a ton next quarter because of higher raw material costs and more demand in Asia, the chief executive, Dan DiMicco, said. ''Most of the price increase is to cover costs,'' Mr. DiMicco said in an interview. Nucor, which makes steel from recycled metal like junked cars, said the cost of that scrap rose 19 percent last quarter. Rivals like U.S. Steel and AK Steel Holding will probably try to match Nucor's higher price for sheet, which is used in cars and appliances and is the most common steel product, analysts said. Domestic steel companies have been able to raise some prices because of import tariffs, the dwindling number of competitors, and demand from overseas. Mr. DiMicco said the first-quarter average price for steel sheet will be about the same as the fourth-quarter price of $349 a ton. Adding $30 to that price in the second quarter would result in an increase of about 8.6 percent.

Pirelli cut its work force by 9 percent in 2002 and is planning further reductions this year. Opening the newly assembled Parliament, Mr. Kibaki promised that anticorruption bills seen as crucial to wooing donors would be among those tackled in this session.    (Reuters)

description: LONDIN-Trudy. April 16, 1920 to February 17, 2003. At home as per her wish. Beloved mother of Sandy & Irwin Freifeld, Betty Renaudo, David & Karen Londin. Loving grandmother of Steven & Dorothy, Scott & Lauren, Lauri & Aaron, Lisa & Paul, Michael & Debbie, Hal, Bradley, Howard, Jeffrey & Nancy. Remarkable great-grandmother of Joshua, Matthew, Brittany, Samantha, Jared & Zachary. Visiting Wednesday 7-9 PM at the Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers, NY. Funeral service Thursday 12 PM at funeral home. Interment Beth El Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. ''Farewell to our matriarch. We will miss you and always love you.''

title: Not Exactly a New Man, But Vaughn Looks Good
description: For five months, Mo Vaughn kept a low profile, dodging interview requests while hunkered down in his Columbus, Ohio, home, working with a nutritionist and a personal trainer to reinvent himself and to satisfy the Mets' mandate to lose weight and salvage his career.

title: Under-20 Tourney Is Threatened
description: On the day Joseph S. Blatter, president of FIFA, was named the winner of the American-Global Award for Peace, he said that a military action against Iraq might force him to consider postponing the under-20 World Cup, which is scheduled in the United Arab Emirates from March 25 to April 26.

title: LA JOLLA SHARES PLUNGE ON RESULTS OF KIDNEY DRUG TESTS
description: Shares of La Jolla Pharmaceutical sank as much as 82 percent after the company said an experimental kidney drug, its most advanced product, did not work as well as expected in a study. The shares tumbled $5.47, to $2.08. About 24.8 million shares changed hands, more than 100 times the three-month daily average. La Jolla Pharmaceutical, based in San Diego, is testing the medicine, Riquent, for lupus patients who suffer from kidney disease. The study found that Riquent did not significantly delay the occurrence of a flare-up, compared with patients treated with a placebo, a company spokesman, said.

title: A Voice and Piano Team Pays Hugo Wolf His Due
description: Sometimes a less than full house serves music better. Monday's blizzard cut Carnegie Hall's expected audience for the Thomas Hampson-Daniel Barenboim-Hugo Wolf evening perhaps in half, but those who came evidently wanted to badly, creating in the process an almost electric intensity of listening.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a ruling by Belgium's highest court that after his term as Israel's prime minister, Ariel Sharon could face trial for 1982 war crimes misstated the role of an Israeli who was tried on the same charges -- involving the massacre of Palestinians at two refugee camps in Lebanon. That man, Amos Yaron, was a military commander but was never chief of staff.

title: Whisking Out the Dirt
description: Some people played in the snow. Others tried to get rid of it. The woman standing on the beach near the boardwalk here in this Brooklyn neighborhood was sweeping it onto a tan rug with a medieval-looking straw broom.

title: Storm Adds a Measure of Insult to an Injured Economy
description: The Presidents' Day blizzard may have been only a glancing blow, but the storm will not help an economy that was already struggling to get back on its feet.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Death Ruled A Homicide
description: A woman whose skeleton was discovered in the basement of a Midtown building on Feb. 10 was killed, the police said yesterday. The medical examiner's office ruled that unidentified woman was the victim of a homicide, said Detective Kevin Czartoryski. The skeleton was discovered during an excavation at 301 West 46th Street. The police said they did not know how long the woman had been dead. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Overture Services to Buy AltaVista for $140 Million
description: Overture Services, the leading seller of advertising that accompanies and looks like the results of Internet searches, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy AltaVista, one of the first Internet search engines, for $140 million.

title: Seeing More Darkness at the End of the Tunnel
description: FRANK A. FERNANDEZ is pessimistic.

title: Space Savers
description: Classier than a closet for keeping skeletons.

title: Europes Last Resort
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Secret Hideaway for the Chef Who Values Space
description: Just because you have have a concealed kitchen doesn't mean you don't like to cook.

title: Escape to Vancouver
description: For two escapees from Hollywood, Kurt Russell and Goldie Hawn, there's room in one house for two styles of living.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Ex-Police Superintendent Named Chief
description: After a contentious confirmation hearing, the City Council on Tuesday night approved the appointment of Joseph Santiago as Trenton's police chief. The vote was 5 to 2. In October, Mr. Santiago resigned under pressure after serving as state police superintendent for seven months. The attorney general began an investigation into possible abuse of office when Mr. Santiago obtained a disputed report used in his background clearance. Mr. Santiago was backed by Mayor Douglas Palmer and by Sharpe James, the mayor of Newark, where Mr. Santiago was police chief before Gov. James E. McGreevey named him to head the state police. Iver Peterson (NYT)

title: A Gardener Grows Balmy In Winter
description: ORDERING leek seeds when it's 15 degrees with three feet of snow on the ground is an act of faith. But I'm setting up my grow lights down in the cellar to start the Albinstar leeks as soon as they arrive from John Scheepers Kitchen Garden Seeds. I'm also waiting for my American fringe tree, Chionanthus virginicus, to arrive from Arborvillage, in Holt, Mo., and a species canna from Yucca Do Nursery in Hempstead, Tex. And I couldn't resist trying Tomato Red Pear from the Franchi Sementi seed company in Bergamo, Italy, where the same family has been growing vegetables and herbs since 1783. An old north Italian variety, Red Pear is a large beefsteak-type tomato with heavy ribbing, and it won a little taste test that took place in Massachusetts last summer.

title: Everything in Its Place
description: NO matter what you do, there is always more to store. For those living in apartments or small homes, anything that helps conceal or organize belongings is a blessing.

title: The Dry Beer Is Back, Looking for a Lush Shelf Life
description: THE corporate headquarters of the reborn Rheingold Brewing Company, desperately seeking status as New York's macrobrew of choice for carb-, calorie- and cutting-edge-conscientious young urban things, are less than lush: a couple of dingy rooms in a commercial building that squats above Fifth Avenue and 27th Street. You can't even get a cold beer here: so much for sampling the merchandise.

title: Ankara's Dance of Politics and Cash
description: Though the Bush administration is withholding public judgment, the potential loss of Turkey on the northern flank of a military campaign against Iraq is regarded within the government as a potentially serious political calamity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TROOBNICK, EUGENE E.
description: TROOBNICK-Eugene E. 75, actor. Founder: Playwrights Theatre Club. Founding member: Second City. Dozens of television appearances, most recently as Stavroson Guiding Light. Broadway plays: 8, Off: 12 Movies: The Imported Bridegroom, Harvey Middleman Fireman, Funny Lady, All That Jazz, among others. Taught and acted at Yale Drama School and Yale Rep. His wife, Carol, his son, Mark, and his daughters, Aviva and Jennifer survive him. Condolences to Mark at: 703-447-0250.

title: Future of New York Theater: Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Turner Plans Role as Gadfly Without Portfolio
description: Some thought Ted Turner's resignation last month as vice chairman of AOL Time Warner might muffle his often unruly voice in its management. But Mr. Turner is letting it be known that he has just begun to roar.

title: Some on Security Council Want to Avoid Taking Sides on Iraq
description: Caught between domestic opposition to a war against Iraq and increasing pressure from the pro-war countries, diplomats from some of the uncommitted members of the Security Council said today that the Council's nonpermanent members should not be forced to take sides in the fight over a new resolution paving the way for war.

title: The Yes-But Parade
description: After his resounding re-election in 1936, Franklin D. Roosevelt turned on the right wing of his Democratic Party. ''He invented a new word,'' recalled his speechwriter, Samuel Rosenman, ''to describe the congressman who publicly approved a progressive objective but who always found something wrong with any specific proposal to gain that objective -- a yes-but fellow.''

title: Support Builds For One Plan For Center Site
description: State and city officials involved in choosing a design for the World Trade Center site have begun lining up in favor of a plan by Studio Daniel Libeskind, which uses the ground zero pit as the setting for a memorial to victims of the terrorist attack, giving that plan important momentum in the week before the final site plan is chosen.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Profit At Bank
description: Ireland's largest financial institution, Allied Irish Bank, reported a profit of 1.07 billion euros ($1.14 billion) for 2002, more than doubling its earnings a year earlier, when it wrote off losses related to fraud at a subsidiary in Baltimore. The company's domestic operations were a major contributor in the most recent quarter, posting pretax income of 590 million euros ($634 million) on a 20 percent increase in loans and a 15 percent increase in fees and commissions. The company has agreed to sell its Baltimore subsidiary, Allfirst Financial, to the M&T Bank of Buffalo. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Federal Debt Near Ceiling; Second Time In 9 Months
description: With budget deficits climbing rapidly, the Bush administration acknowledged today that the government had reached its legal limit on borrowing and would run short of cash by early April unless Congress once again raised the debt ceiling.

title: After 27 Years, Pauley Plans to Leave NBC in May
description: Jane Pauley, the co-anchor of ''Dateline NBC'' and previously the longtime anchor of the ''Today'' show, said yesterday that she would leave NBC in May after 27 years with the network.

title: Shuttle Inquiry Is Again Focusing On Damage From Debris at Liftoff
description: After more than two weeks of evaluating scores of theories about what led to the disintegration of the shuttle Columbia, investigators are concentrating again on their early idea that a piece of insulation or other flying debris from the shuttle's 15-story external fuel tank damaged a wing at liftoff, dooming the craft.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOATE, ELSIE K.
description: SLOATE - Elsie K. Died peacefully in Manhattan on February 18, 2003. Beloved wife of her late husband, Kalman, devoted mother of her daughter, Laura, and her sons, Martin and Alan, and of her daughters-in-law, Phyllis and Roxene. Cherished grandmother of Paul, Pamela, Kenneth and Jonathan and of her granddaughtersin-law, Amy and Patricia, and of her great grandchildren, Jordan, Samuel, Stacey and Elliott, and loved sister of Marcia. Her kindness and generosity touched many lives with love and she will remain in their hearts. As the guiding light of Fight for Sight of Manhattan, she raised countless funds for eye research at her legendary luncheons and other charitable functions. Her extraordinary spirit enriched many lives and she will be sorely missed. Donations in memorial may be made to the Elsie K. Sloate Fellowship Fund at New York Presbyterian Hospital, C/O Laura J. Sloate, 230 Park Ave, 7 Flr, NY, NY 10169. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. & Amsterdam Ave, on Thursday, February 20 at 11:45 AM.

title: Yankees' Infielders Are Planning to Address Their Defensive Shortcomings
description: Five teams in baseball made more errors than the Yankees last season. The average number of victories for those teams was 68. The Yankees won 103 games.

title: Johnny Paycheck Dies at 64; Hard-Living Country Singer
description: Johnny Paycheck, one of the most influential country singers of the last 40 years and yet for stretches of his career a Nashville pariah who became more famous for what he did spectacularly wrong than what he did right, died yesterday at 64.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Bird Flu Confirmed In Humans
description: A local boy who visited Fujian Province on the mainland is recovering from the H5N1 avian influenza virus at a Hong Kong hospital, but his father and one of his sisters have already died, possibly of the same virus. A different strain of H5N1 virus spread from chickens to people here in 1997, causing six deaths. Thousands of chickens have died at Hong Kong farms this winter, and the government ordered the slaughter of chickens at one of the largest open-air markets here yesterday after a dozen died of an H5 virus strain. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

description: The stress of Boston's record snowfall may have been too much for at least one person this week.

description: GARBER-Harry J. Beloved husband of Blanche. Devoted father of Keith (Florine) and Joan (Richard) Gold. Cherished grandfather of Jonathan, Daniel, Michael and Adam. Loving brother to Bessie, Sidney, Lillie and the late Charles. Services Friday, 12:15 PM at ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expwy, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Stash away the duct tape. Don't use it. Stash it away.''

title: FIRST CONVICTION IN 9/11 ATTACKS
description: Nearly a year and a half after more than 3,000 people died in the Sept. 11 attacks, a Hamburg court today delivered the first conviction of a suspect in the plot set in motion from this northern German city by a small terrorist cell.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, MORTON
description: GREENBERG-Morton. On February 17, 2003. Beloved husband of Joyce, loving father of Katrina, Gregory and Joshua, cherished brother of Leah. Memorial service Sunday, February 23, 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, NYC The Funeral Chapel.

title: Hospitals Spend Millions In Terrorism Preparations
description: Post-9/11 vigilance has placed wide-ranging burdens on New York's hospitals, from adding guards to building germ decontamination units -- more than $200 million in expenses so far, and a similar amount is expected this year, according to a new report by a hospital lobbying group.

title: Qwest Reports Decreases In Revenue and Phone Lines
description: Qwest Communications International said yesterday that its business would continue shrinking this year but that some of the pressure on it had eased in the last quarter of 2002.

title: Few Signs of Less Terror Threat As a Lower Alert Is Considered
description: Even as the Bush administration considers whether to lower the government's terrorism alert level, American officials said today that there was scant new and specific intelligence to show that the potential threat of another terrorist attack had actually been reduced.

description: LAST week I tried to work, I really did, but all I could think about was pink.

description: Nikon Inc. in Melville, N.Y., has named McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising in New York as agency of record on its account, which had been handled by Fallon Worldwide in Minneapolis, part of the Publicis Groupe. Spending was estimated at $18 million.

title: Long-Term Effects of Post-Trauma Events
description: Among New Yorkers who suffered from post-traumatic stress disorder after Sept. 11, 2001, those who have lost family members, lost jobs or experienced other stress since the attack are the most likely to still be having symptoms, researchers have found.

title: A Thin Line Between Film And Joystick
description: AS if in a shadow play of a major Hollywood premiere, photographers pressed up to a procession of film stars strolling into a theater aglow with hype and klieg lights. Keanu Reeves chatted on camera with ''Access Hollywood'' and MTV reporters. Will Smith and his wife, the actress Jada Pinkett Smith, waved to onlookers. Carrie-Anne Moss and Laurence Fishburne glittered on a black carpet ordered for the occasion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDERSON, QUENTIN
description: ANDERSON - Quentin, 90. Died peacefully at home in New York City on February 18, 2003. Devoted husband of Thelma; cherished father of Martha, Brom and Maxwell and his wife Jacqueline; adored grandfather of Chase; and loving brother of Alan, Terence, and Hesper. Julian Clarence Levy Professor in the Humanities, Emeritus, Columbia University. A memorial service will be held at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University on March 22.

title: U.S. IS PESSIMISTIC TURKS WILL ACCEPT AID DEAL ON IRAQ
description: White House officials sounded pessimistic today that their offer of $26 billion in aid to Turkey would be enough to win the country's approval for the United States to open a northern front against Iraq if war comes.

title: Who Says No New Taxes?
description: The new Republican administration in the Maryland statehouse is little more than a month old, but someone should start collecting the sayings of John Kane, the triumphalist G.O.P. state chairman, on the subject of campaign donations. He could rival the enduring political candor of George Washington Plunkett, the Tammany Hall boss famous for admitting: ''I seen my opportunities and I took 'em.''

description: I was the first Confederate to die in the Battle of Central Park. At least, I think I was.

description: There was the Rev. Jesse Jackson in the early-morning chaos, consoling relatives of the 21 people killed in a nightclub stampede and vowing to help them seek justice in court.

description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about information that German authorities say they were provided by a Qaeda informer, Shadi Abdullah, referred imprecisely to a visa that offers unobstructed access to 15 European countries. Thirteen of those countries  all but Norway and Iceland  are European Union members.

title: Firms Try To Delay Law On Cigarettes, Say Advocates
description: More than two years after New York passed a landmark law requiring that cigarettes be made to extinguish quickly to avoid setting fires, some state legislators and advocacy groups are accusing the tobacco companies of trying to delay the regulation.

title: Steinbrenner Reminds Jeter Just Who the Boss Is
description: George Steinbrenner smiled contentedly as he stood in the back of an elevator at Legends Field today and said he was glad ''things have calmed down'' around the Yankees in spring training. It was an obvious reference to the controversy involving Steinbrenner, the principal owner of the Yankees, and his recent criticism of Derek Jeter over what he perceived as Jeter's lack of focus.

Thirteen of those countries -- all but Norway and Iceland -- are European Union members.

title: Ruby Tuesday Chain Selects Kaplan
description: Ruby Tuesday in Maryville, Tenn., which operates 600 casual restaurants, has named the Kaplan Thaler Group in New York as agency of record on its creative account, and MediaVest U.S.A. in New York as agency of record on the media duties. Both assignments had previously been handled internally.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIN, GERHARD, PH.D.
description: LEWIN-Gerhard, Ph.D. Age 96, died peacefully February 15, 2003 in West Orange, NJ. Married 65 years to Gerda who predeceased him, father of Gabriela and Vivian, grandfather of Nicole, Alyssa, and Meredith (Puppeli). A research physicist and nature lover, he used his brilliant inquisitive mind in a life long pursuit of projects to improve the lives of humankind and preserve our environment. This included work at Princeton University and CERN Switzerland to develop hydrogen fusion as a source of clean energy, the invention and application of synthetic diamond coatings at The Technion in Israel; at the Beth Israel Center, Newark, he developed the electrode used in all cardiac pacemakers. Contributions in his memory may be made to Sierra Club or to The Pacemaker Center, C/O Dr. Victor Parsonnet, Newark Beth Israel Medical Center, 201 Lyons Avenue, Newark, NJ 07112. For information O'Boyle Funeral Home 309 Broad Street, Bloomfield.

title: U.S. Official Cites Progress In Trade Ties With China
description: The top United States trade official gave a generally favorable assessment of China's first year in the World Trade Organization today, saying that progress had been made on many issues even as China's annual trade surplus with the United States approaches $100 billion.

title: KRISPY KREME ACQUIRES MARKETING RIGHTS IN 4 AREAS
description: Krispy Kreme Doughnuts said it acquired the marketing rights to four Kansas and Missouri areas from a partnership. Krispy Kreme did not disclose the price of the partnership, whose operating partner is a former company employee. Krispy Kreme, which operates more than 270 stores, will be gaining five stores in Kansas City, Wichita and Topeka, Kan.; and Springfield, Mo., it said.

title: Kraft Announces Pension Costs
description: Kraft Foods Inc. said today that it would have 5 cents a share in noncash expenses next year because it spread out low returns from a pension program.

title: Rwandan Pastor and His Son Are Convicted of Genocide
description: A Protestant clergyman and his son, a physician, were convicted yesterday of genocide and sentenced to prison by the United Nations tribunal dealing with the Rwandan killing frenzy of 1994, in which members of Hutu gangs killed an estimated 800,000 minority Tutsi and moderate Hutu over three months.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: QUEENS: FOUR STUDENTS ARRESTED IN SEX CASE Four 17-year-old male students at a Roman Catholic high school in Queens were arrested yesterday and charged with having sex with a 15-year-old female classmate last Halloween. The defendants, all seniors, were expelled from Christ the King High School in Middle Village this month. They were charged with sexual misconduct and endangering the welfare of a child, and face up to six months in prison if convicted, said a spokesman for the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown. Lawyers for three of the defendants said that rape had not been claimed, but Madeline Bryer, the girl's lawyer, said that the sex was not consensual. An official at the high school declined to comment. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANTON, FLORENCE V.
description: MANTON - Florence V. ''Gretchen,'' passed away on February 14, 2003, after a long illness. She is survived by her husband, Sir Edwin A. G. Manton; a daughter, Diana Morton; two grandchildren, Julia Kropf and Sandra Niles; and five great-grandchildren. Services are scheduled for 3:00PM, Saturday, February 22, at The Church of the Ascension on Fifth Avenue at 10th Street in Greenwich Village. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Church of the Ascension, 12 West 11th Street, New York, NY 10011, or to a charity of your choosing.

title: Where's the Remote? A Tiny New Answer
description: The Griffin Mobile Total Remote started off as an attempt to create a remote control for the Apple iPod music player. It ended up as a tiny module that turns a hand-held Pocket PC computer into a master remote that can operate more than 300 kinds of gadgets, from DVD players to ceiling fans.

title: Dollar Diplomacy
description: After taking a hard look at the poker game being played by President Bush and Saddam Hussein, Turkey, in effect, told Mr. Bush this week to ante up $32 billion if he wants Ankara to take a seat at the table. That's serious money and the demand, which Washington is pondering, says a great deal about the tradeoffs taking place beneath all the lofty arguments about going to war with Iraq. The business of lining up reluctant governments to provide bases and support for possible military action is not exactly an exercise in Wilsonian idealism.

title: Federal Indictment Charges 8 With Operating Terrorist Network
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 - Federal prosecutors today brought racketeering charges against a Florida professor and seven other people, accusing them of financing and helping support suicide bombings in Israel.

title: A Strange Budget Cut
description: Say it ain't so, Mr. President.

title: Trailer Factory to Close
description: Fleetwood Enterprises, a leading maker of mobile homes, said today that it would close a factory in Lumberton, N.C., next month because of falling sales. As many as 95 people will be laid off when the plant closes on March 3, and 15 to 20 employees will be allowed to transfer to a factory in Pembroke, N.C., a spokeswoman, Kathy Munson, said. Fleetwood has closed 17 plants and eliminated 7,000 jobs since May 1999, when manufactured-housing sales began falling.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: BANK'S PROFIT RISES The British bank Standard Chartered said its second-half profit rose a better-than-expected 45 percent because of reduced bad-loan provisions. Standard Chartered said net income increased to $428 million, or 38.8 cents a share, from $295 million, or 26 cents, in the period a year earlier. The company reduced the amount it set aside for bad loans to $299 million from $463 million and trimmed administrative expenses by 1.8 percent, to $1.13 billion. (Bloomberg News)

title: BBDO Worldwide enters the lucrative category of marketing prescription drugs to consumers.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Starbucks Profit Falls
description: Profit at Starbucks Coffee Japan fell 70 percent in the first nine months of the fiscal year because of growing competition from rival coffee chains. Starbucks earned a pretax profit of 353 million yen ($3 million) from April to December. Sales rose 17.9 percent, to 41.4 billion yen, with most of the gains from new stores. Sales at stores open more than one year fell 16 percent. The company reaffirmed that it expected to report a loss of 500 million yen for the full year, which ends March 31.

title: F.C.C. Eases Some Rules on How Bells Treat Rivals
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  The Federal Communications Commission today issued the most comprehensive overhaul of the nation's telephone rate regulations in more than six years, handing both a partial victory and partial defeat to the four large regional Bell companies that have spent almost as long in a ferocious lobbying and litigation campaign to overturn them.

description: A judge today rejected a motion filed by the Archdiocese of Boston that sought to dismiss nearly 500 civil lawsuits filed in the scandal of sexual abuse by members of the clergy.

Those of us who knew and worked with Rusty were indeed privileged. My deepest thoughts are with his son Nat, and remarkable wife Alison Fraser. Charles Busch

title: Editorial Observer; The Trouble With Corporate Radio: The Day the Protest Music Died
description: Pop music played a crucial role in the national debate over the Vietnam War. By the late 1960's, radio stations across the country were crackling with blatantly political songs that became mainstream hits. After the National Guard killed four antiwar demonstrators at Kent State University in Ohio in the spring of 1970, Crosby, Stills, Nash and Young recorded a song, simply titled ''Ohio,'' about the horror of the event, criticizing President Richard Nixon by name. The song was rushed onto the air while sentiment was still high, and became both an antiwar anthem and a huge moneymaker.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOEHM, BEATRICE R.
description: BOEHM-Beatrice R. Age 92. Beloved wife of the late Irwin. Much loved aunt of Beth & Gene Kava, Paul & Ellen Boehm, and their children. Graveside service 1 PM Sunday, February 23, 2003, Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ.

title: Israel Kills 12 Arabs in Clashes in West Bank and Gaza
description: Israel sent armored columns storming into the northern Gaza Strip and this West Bank city today, killing at least 12 Palestinians as troops clashed with gunmen, demolished metal shops and homes and searched for suspects.

title: For Some, the Jitters Help the Bottom Line
description: SOON after Homeland Security Secretary Tom Ridge urged Americans to stock up on duct tape and plastic sheeting in the face of a heightened terrorism alert, Mike McWethy put together his own homeland security kit and started selling it on eBay. It included 100 feet of plastic sheeting, a 60-yard roll of duct tape and a copy of the Department of Homeland Security Preparedness Advisory Document, for $15 plus $15.80 shipping and handling.

title: Claim of U.S.O.C. Sex Harassment Denied
description: The lawyer for Toby Wong, who resigned last week as the chief marketing officer of the United States Olympic Committee, yesterday denied statements by a leading Senate critic of the organization that she would be filing a sexual-harassment suit against a top U.S.O.C. official.

title: Corrections
description: The Books of The Times review on Feb. 7, about ''The Dante Club,'' a novel set in 19th-century Boston whose characters include many historical figures, misstated the given name of a publisher of that era. He was George Ticknor, not William.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Arrested In Bank Robberies
description: A New Jersey man has been arrested in connection with five bank robberies and an attempted robbery in New York City in the past month, the police said. The man, Jimmy Carswell, 58, of Fifth Street in Elizabeth, was arrested about noon Tuesday at the Greenpoint Savings Bank at One Penn Plaza after a police officer recognized him, the authorities said. Mr. Carswell was charged with robbing $1,700 from Independence Bank on Lexington Avenue; $170 from M&T Bank on West 42nd Street; $1,095 from North Fork Bank on Park Avenue; $550 from the North Fork Bank on Fifth Avenue; and $195 from HSBC Bank on the Avenue of the Americas. He also tried to rob the Commerce Bank on West 26th Street, the police said. The robberies were committed between Jan. 24 and Feb. 14. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: National Briefing | West: California: 124 Years For Max Factor Heir
description: A fugitive heir to the Max Factor cosmetic fortune was sentenced to 124 years in state prison and ordered to pay $1 million in restitution for drugging and raping three women whom he had lured to his beach house. Andrew Luster, 39, the great-grandson of Mr. Factor, was convicted in absentia in Ventura County Superior Court on 86 counts, including rape, sodomy and poisoning. The police found videos in Mr. Luster's home of him engaging in sex with women who appeared unconscious. His whereabouts have been unknown since Jan. 3 when he ran out on his $1 million bail. Charlie LeDuff (NYT)

title: Air Force Begins an Inquiry Of Ex-Cadets' Rape Charges
description: A team of senior Air Force officers from the Pentagon began an investigation here today after a number of women who had attended the United States Air Force Academy said they had been raped or sexually assaulted, only to face indifference, inaction or retaliation by academy officials.

title: Attacks on Civilians Intensifying in Southern Philippines
description: MANILA, Feb. 20  Sixteen people were killed in a series of violent episodes in the southern Philippines the past two days. In one incident, about 50 armed men raided a remote village in the dead of night and massacred 14 civilians, 3 of them children, the military announced today.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CONSTELLATION ENERGY CORP., Baltimore, agreed to buy most of a power trading business from CMS Energy, Dearborn, Mich., a provider of electricity and natural gas. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Should You Shred or Save? Two Ways to Streamline
description: AMONG the things the Internet has not changed -- at least not yet -- is the amount of paper kept around. Consider personal record-keeping practices. How many folders, boxes and drawers are stuffed with old tax filings, pet vaccination records and product warranties that expired long ago?

description: MANILA, Feb. 20  Sixteen people were killed in a series of violent episodes in the southern Philippines the past two days. In one incident, about 50 armed men raided a remote village in the dead of night and massacred 14 civilians, 3 of them children, the military announced today.

title: Connecticut Beats Rutgers at the Line
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 19 — How can a team like Rutgers have such gaudy defensive statistics and still keep losing? It could be because the Scarlet Knights have trouble scoring.

title: In Full Swing
description: Highlights from this week's forum discussions, including Clifton Brown's golf outlook and a conversation with Harriet McBryde Johnson.

title: Rangers Look Better at Times And Get Badly Needed Victory
description: The night and the effort called for something defining. Instead of that, Bobby Holik answered a reporter's question with a question.

title: How friendly can Europe be with the U.S.?: Chirac's outburst exposes contradiction within EU
description: PARIS:  President Jacques Chirac's warning to the new Europeans of EU and NATO enlargement that they cannot side too much with America and fit his definition of membership in the family of Europe has exposed, with an outburst of pure rage, a profound, long-term contradiction that could tear the EU apart from within.

title: Pretty Soon, These Nomads May Find a Permanent Home
description: Rare nomadic rugs from central Turkey will be on sale March 1 at the NYIT Design showroom in SoHo. Most of the one-of-a-kind rugs, 70 to 100 years old, are 4-by-6 feet. There are three types: felt (once used as tent insulation), tulu (once used as beds) and filikli (made of angora-like wool and often used as blankets). The filikli rugs, from left, are $2,380, $2,240 and $1,860; a tulu rug, right, is $2,680. New filikli rugs can also be custom-made in a variety of colors and patterns, at $100 a square foot.

title: St. John's Continues to Be a Team in Transition
description: After making just 9 of a Big East record 41 3-point attempts in a 66-60 loss to Syracuse on Wednesday night, St. John's (12-10 over all, 5-7 Big East) stumbles into tomorrow's game at Connecticut (16-6, 7-4) with cloudy personnel matters.

title: Secret Hideaway For the Chef Who Values Space
description: Just because you have a concealed kitchen doesn't mean you hate to cook. Sometimes it is a matter of saving space.

title: A Trio Tries Something New
description: What's missing in Mark Turner's new trio is a chordal instrument, like a guitar or a piano, which Mr. Turner has usually used to support and shape his saxophone improvisations. The saxophone-trio format puts pressure on the saxophonist, who must embrace all that open space or valiantly fight it.

title: After Korean Subway Fire, New York Rechecks Safety
description: Both subway cars were packed with people wary of a passenger who was acting strangely. Then, in an instant, the cars filled with fire.

title: As Gasoline Prices Rise, Drivers Have Doubts About Why
description: Beyond antiwar demonstrations and troop deployments, gasoline prices that have jumped to more than $2 a gallon in some places seem to many drivers to be the most tangible evidence of the Bush administration's plans for a possible attack on Iraq.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RADE, ARTHUR
description: RADE-Arthur. The Jewish Center of the Hamptons notes with sadness the passing of our congregant, Arthur Rade. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Wendy and sons, Sam and Danny, and their families. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Rabbi Alon Levkovitz Cantor Debra Stein Donald Zucker, President

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: EBay To Open Service Center In Canada
description: EBay Inc., the Internet auctioneer, will open a service center in Burnaby, British Columbia, in April, and hire about 600 workers to handle queries from customers in the United States, Canada and Australia. EBay is adding the center near Vancouver as it seeks to increase revenue to $3 billion in 2005 from an estimated $1.9 billion this year. The new center will join those in Salt Lake City, Omaha and Germany. The new workers, who represent a 15 percent increase in eBay's work force of about 4,000, will be added over the next two to three years, a company spokesman, Kevin Pursglove, said.

title: Designs That Have Seen the Future, and Now Are Here
description: WALLS that light themselves. Curtains that reflect radar. Blast doors made of foam. Five years ago, these were the domain of defense contractors and technophile billionaires. Now such breakthrough materials are in from the fringe and within easy reach of homeowners. More important, they don't require a military budget or arcane expertise -- just a willingness to try something new.

title: Briefly Noted
description: SUICIDE ATTEMPTS AT GUANTANAMO Three more men have attempted suicide at the United States prison camp at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, in the past week, lifting the total to 19, the Pentagon said yesterday. The three were treated at the nearby American naval base and are back in their cells, said Lt. Cmdr. Barbara Burfeind. Also yesterday, Commander Burfeind acknowledged that some of the camp's detainees, who are generally terrorism suspects and are considered by the United States to be combatants, were being transferred to detention elsewhere. "From time to time the transfer and release of detainees will occur without notice or mention," she said, refusing to comment on specific cases or locations involved. (AP)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zambia: High Court Clears Way To Prosecute Ex-President
description: The country's Supreme Court ruled that Frederick Chiluba, who was president from 1991 to 2001, had been rightfully stripped of his immunity from prosecution. Mr. Chiluba, who has been accused of looting his country's treasury, had appealed a parliamentary decision to lift his immunity, citing procedural irregularities. Mr. Chiluba's hand-picked successor, President Levy Mwanawasa, has vowed to arrest Mr. Chiluba on charges of corruption. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Kirin Forecasts Profit
description: The Japanese beverage company, Kirin Brewery, said profit would grow 20 percent this year, helped by cost-cutting measures and strong sales of its liquor brands. Kirin expects to earn 39 billion yen ($328 million) in 2003, with sales rising 5.5 percent, to 1.67 trillion yen. This year, Kirin's net profit grew 41 percent. With overall beer sales unchanged, brewers have been forced to cut prices for popular low-malt brands. They are also emphasizing soft drinks and cocktails. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Meeting Set On Unity By Umpire Groups
description: For the first time since their disastrous mass resignation meeting three and a half years ago, major league umpires will meet as a group Sunday. The two factions that emerged from that July 1999 debacle will try to put their differences behind them and effect a reunification.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Ecuador: Melting Ice Reveals 1976 Plane Crash
description: An airliner that disappeared nearly 27 years ago in the Ecuadorean Andes has been discovered, along with the remains of 59 people who were aboard. Climbers found the plane Monday about 2,000 feet below the peak of the 20,700-foot Chimborazo volcano. A French glaciologist said the discovery was made possible by the melting of thick ice on Chimborazo. Relatives of the passengers traveled to the mountain yesterday to recover belongings. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Dutch Helping As U.S. Sends Troops to Gulf
description: Under heavy security, the United States is quietly moving troops, transport vehicles and other military supplies to the Persian Gulf through the Netherlands, helping to minimize potential complications in Germany and Belgium, where the opposition to immediate military action in Iraq is formidable.

title: Sports of The Times; The Phenomenon Who Came Back
description: THE guy was obviously a bust, sitting on the bench like a cardboard cutout for four years, four years that he might have been playing someplace, at a college, for example. And getting an education to boot.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Volkswagen's Profit Falls
description: The German car maker Volkswagen said its net profit for 2002 fell 11 percent, to 2.58 billion euros ($2.76 billion), because of declining sales in Europe and the United States. Pretax profit was 3.99 billion euros, 9.6 percent less than a year earlier but meeting the company's target. Revenue and production were slightly lower but were in line with market expectations. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Better Child Health Is Seen As Environment Ills Decline
description: A new government report concludes that children's health has improved in areas where the government has taken aim at environmental hazards, White House and Environmental Protection Agency officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HABACH, SAM
description: HABACH-Sam, 96. Beloved husband of Eleanor, died at the Hebrew Hospital Home February 19. Graveside service at Riverside Cemetery, Saddle Brook, NJ today 1 PM.

title: Japan's Fiscal Year Winds Down, With Less Anxiety
description: Few events here stir up as much anxiety as the closing of the books at the end of the Japanese fiscal year on March 31.

title: Arab Summit to Be Held in Cairo
description: CAIRO, Feb. 20  The Arab League announced today that leaders of its member states would meet here on March 1 in a new effort to forge a united position on President Bush's threats to attack Iraq over its weapons programs.

title: Nassau Judge Is Censured For Remarks And Donation
description: A state judicial panel censured a Supreme Court justice from Nassau County today, saying he had made ''threatening, intimidating statements'' to a lawyer and engaged in partisan political activities that ''represent a significant departure from the proper role of a judge.''

title: Some States Propose End to Arts Spending
description: Last year, struggling to control a ballooning budget deficit, state legislators in Arizona reduced funds for the arts. This year, facing an even larger deficit, they are proposing a simpler approach: cutting arts financing altogether.

title: Devils' Standard of Play Is Down And Their Late Rally Falls Short
description: If the Devils are to make a serious challenge for the Eastern Conference title, or for the President's Trophy, which goes to the team with the most points, their game tonight against the Ottawa Senators presented a grand opportunity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREINDLER, LEE S.
description: KREINDLER-Lee S. Distinguished trial and appellate lawyer, the Senior Partner of the Law Firm Kreindler & Kreindler, that he and his father, Harry Kreindler foundeded in 1952. Beloved and dedicated husband of his adoring wife Ruth, revered father of James P. Kreindler and Laurie Kreindler and father-in-law of Dr. Lidia Pousada and Tom Laster, adored grandfather of Katie, Sara, Jason, Anna, Jamie, Abbie and Victoria, and loving brother of Rosamand Koffman. Funeral services to be held Thursday, February 20, at 2 P.M. at Temple Beth El, 220 South Bedford Road, Chappaqua, New York.

title: Shifting the Burden of Funding Pensions
description: The savings accounts proposed by the Bush administration are meant to produce fundamental changes in the way Americans think about saving for retirement and to shift the primary responsibility from the business community to the individual.

title: Iranian Crash Kills 302
description: A military transport plane went down in southeastern Iran yesterday, killing all 302 aboard, mostly members of the elite Islamic Revolutionary Guards. The pilot had reported bad weather conditions.
