description: PROBBER-Harvey. On February 16, 2003, at the age of 80. Loving husband of Joan; brother of Edwin; father to Jonathan, Jory, Jamian and Jeremy, and grandfather to Benjamin, Samuel, Sara and Michael. Memorial service on Sunday, February 23rd, 11:00 AM, at The Wainwright House in Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to: Hospital Albert Schweitzer, PO Box 81046, Pittsburgh, PA. 15217.

title: Russia Suggests U.S. Pressuring Inspectors in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  With American officials and United Nations weapons inspectors asserting that Iraq has slowed the pace of its cooperation, Russia suggested today that the inspectors were being pressured to produce negative reports that could serve to justify military action.

title: Taking Aim at an Enemy's Chips
description: AS the United States readies for a possible conflict in Iraq, many of the star weapons from the Persian Gulf war of 1991 are back and deadlier than ever. The smart bombs are smarter. The stealth planes are sneakier. Even the ground troops are better equipped than they were a dozen years ago.

title: UConn Women Extend Streak With No. 64
description: After an early struggle, Diana Taurasi took over tonight and Connecticut extended its record winning streak for women's college basketball to 64 games.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: KOSOVO: ALBANIAN GUERRILLA LEADER ARRESTED A Kosovo Albanian leader indicted by the United Nations war crimes tribunal was captured in a Slovene ski resort after fleeing from NATO peacekeepers who arrested three of his accomplices. Fatmir Limaj, an ally of the former Kosovo Liberation Army commander, Hashim Thaci, is accused of committing atrocities against Serbian and Albanian civilians in a Kosovo Liberation Army prison camp in 1998. The indictment, which also covers three other former K.L.A. fighters detained by NATO, is the first to be brought against Kosovo Albanians by the tribunal in The Hague.    Daniel Simpson (NYT)

title: Devers Takes Break From Sprinting by Hurdling
description: Among her many achievements in 19 seasons as a world-class runner, Gail Devers has won two Olympic gold medals in the 100-meter dash and three world championships in the 100-meter hurdles. So what is she, a sprinter or a hurdler?

title: Dancing in the Mush Pit: It's Heel, Toe, Hop, or Wade Right In
description: As temperatures rose yesterday, New York suddenly became a city of uncharted lakes, ponds and yawning canyons of slush. Brave explorers hopped, skipped and inched their way across the treacherous terrain, sometimes soaking a shoe or trouser leg. At intersections, in particular, a certain amount of negotiation, etiquette and athleticism came into play. And there seemed to be a need for invention.

title: National Briefing: South
description: ARKANSAS: $62 MILLION IN BUDGET CUTS Citing lower corporate income tax receipts, Gov. Mike Huckabee ordered $62 million cut from the state budget by June 1, the end of its fiscal year. The spending reduction, the fifth in the state's two-year appropriations cycle, brings to $363 million the sum eliminated from what was intended to have been a $3.6 billion budget. Public schools would absorb half the latest cuts, but Medicaid programs would also be affected. Mr. Huckabee, a Republican, has said additional taxes will be necessary merely to maintain services at existing levels.   (NYT)

title: At Vail, It's the Men Who Made the Mountain
description: Out of breath, sweating and knee-deep in snow, Pete Seibert would not have been easily convinced that a day of mountain climbing was to put him on the precipice of American history. It was March 19, 1957, and Seibert, then 33, was following his friend Earl Eaton, a local uranium prospector, up a deserted, nameless Colorado mountain, and all Seibert knew for sure was that it was hard work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JUSTMAN, JOSEPH
description: JUSTMAN-Joseph. Passed away on February 17, 2003 at age 91. Predeceased by his beloved wife Gussie. Survived by his loving daughters Judith Justman, M.D. and Norma Greenfield, Ph.D. and his dear grandsons, Lawrence and Samuel Greenfield. Dr. Justman received a Ph.D. from Columbia University, conducted research at the NYC Board of Ed., and was a professor at Fordham University. He published two books and over 40 monographs and articles. He was an avid collector of modern glass sculpture, served as a docent for the Museum of Contemporary Crafts, and volunteered at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. A memorial gathering will be held next month.

title: Hoping to Set an Example, Mayor Gets Smallpox Vaccination
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg received a smallpox vaccination yesterday, administered in his ceremonial office at City Hall.

title: Pianist Devotes an Evening To the Concept of Fantasy
description: The painist Mitsuko Uchida built her recital at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening around the idea of fantasy. And if only one of the three works on the program actually bore that title, Schumann's Fantasy in C (Op. 17), both the music at hand and Ms. Uchida's performances supported the notion.

description: CLOSE TO HOME

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Lucent Board Names Chairwoman
description: The board of Lucent Technologies, the maker of telecommunications equipment, said yesterday that Patricia F. Russo, left, the chief executive, would succeed the chairman, Henry B. Schacht. Ms. Russo, who was appointed chief executive last year, said Mr. Schacht would remain on the board as an outside director and at the company as a senior adviser for a time to handle issues including pending litigation. Mr. Schacht, who was Lucent's first chairman and chief executive when the company was spun off from AT&T in 1996, had returned in 2000 to oversee a restructuring. Ms. Russo also reaffirmed her expectation that Lucent would become profitable by September after three years of losses. Separately, shareholders allowed Lucent to carry out a reverse stock split, a measure that, if pursued, would enable the company to keep its share price above $1 and avoid being delisted by the New York Stock Exchange. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Inching Toward America, So Near but So Far
description: The Belgian filmmaker Chantal Akerman created at least one of the definitive European films of the 1970's, ''Jeanne Dielman, 23 Quai du Commerce, 1080 Bruxelles,'' a 210-minute study of a middle-aged woman (Delphine Seyrig) tidying up her Brussels flat. Equally engaged with feminists politics (the woman is a sort of housewife-prostitute, who receives clients while her son is in school) and the postmodernist concern, raging at the time, with deconstructing classical narrative, ''Jeanne Dielman'' remains a touchstone of 70's cinematic radicalism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEEDS, ROBERT LEWIS JR.
description: LEEDS-Robert Lewis Jr. (1930-2003) died February 17, 2003. Born in NYC, son of Robert L. Leeds and Elizabeth Bandler Hale. He was a Professor at the University of South Florida and former CEO of Manhattan Industries. Company was founded by his great-grandfather Lewis Levi in 1857. He is survived by his wife Joan Wrigley Leeds and his children Leslie Leeds Kitziger and Robert L. Leeds, III.

title: 7 States Suing E.P.A. Over Carbon Dioxide Emissions
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  Seven state attorneys general, mostly from the Northeast, announced a lawsuit today accusing the Environmental Protection Agency of failing to enforce the Clean Air Act by neglecting carbon dioxide emissions.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft To Buy Some Assets Of Connectix
description: Microsoft said late yesterday that it would purchase some of the assets of the Connectix Corporation, a small maker of so-called virtual machine software, based in San Mateo, Calif. The deal includes the company's flagship product, Virtual PC, which permits Macintosh users to run applications written for Microsoft Windows and Intel-based personal computers. Virtual PC software is crucial for Apple Computer because it permits corporate users to run Windows-based applications that do not exist for the Macintosh. Of greater interest to Microsoft, Connectix has developed a similar product for Windows-based PC's that permits computer users to run multiple operating systems, including Linux, simultaneously. The Silicon Valley company also recently entered the market for server computers used by corporations. The software permits a single Intel computer to simultaneously run a variety of operating systems, including Windows 2000 Server, Unix and Linux. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. John Markoff (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMUELS, HELEN PECK
description: SAMUELS-Helen Peck. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of the Mount Sinai Medical Center are saddened by the passing of Helen Peck Samuels, mother of Stephen M. Peck, immediate past Chairman of our Boards of Trustees. Stephen Peck and his family have provided important leadership to Mount Sinai for many years, and we extend our sincere condolences to the entire family. Peter W. May, Chairman Kenneth I. Berns, M.D., Ph.D., President and CEO Mount Sinai Medical Center Larry H. Hollier, M.D., President The Mount Sinai Hospital Kenneth L. Davis, M.D., Mount Sinai School of Medicine

title: North Korean Fighter Intrudes on South's Airspace
description: SEOUL, Feb. 20  A North Korean fighter plane swooped over the Yellow Sea off the west coast of South Korea for two minutes today, raising the question of whether the flight was strategically timed to precede the arrival of Secretary of State Colin L. Powell here on Monday.

title: Seattle Theater in Peril As Money Runs Out
description: Officials at A Contemporary Theater in Seattle, a respected regional troupe with some 9,000 subscribers and a history of acclaimed productions, were trying yesterday to fix a financial crisis that could shut their 38-year-old nonprofit theater.

title: Photography Lessons Right in the Viewfinder
description: Whether they capture photographs on film or on chips, cameras with automatic programmed settings for taking specific kinds of pictures are common. Such cameras can pick the best shutter speed and aperture settings for, say, photographing a speeding race car as opposed to a static landscape.

title: Weather Slows Search for Victims, and Answers, in Iran Crash
description: TEHRAN, Feb. 20  Rescue workers continued searching today through fog and storm in the mountains of Sirach, in southeastern Iran, where a military aircraft crashed on Wednesday, killing all 302 soldiers and crew members aboard.

title: Wilpon Has Mets Feeling Warm and Fuzzy After Team Meeting
description: Across Florida and Arizona, in spring training complexes everywhere over the past few days, reporters have been escorted out of the major league clubhouse and doors have been shut behind them. It is a longstanding tradition: the first full-squad workout is preceded by the first teamwide meeting. No big deal.

title: Ex-Tyco Executive Indicted in New Hampshire in U.S. Tax Case
description: The former chief financial officer of Tyco International, Mark H. Swartz, was indicted yesterday by a federal grand jury in New Hampshire on a charge of tax evasion, adding to state charges against him that include looting the company of hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: A Little Swimming Behind the Curtains
description: A clear vinyl shower curtain called Cool Dunk is patterned with stylized female swimmers from vintage illustrations. ''We are always attracted to images that relate to our lives,'' said Susan Wittenberg, one of the designers. ''I love to swim.'' The curtain ($30) was designed by Ms. Wittenberg and Carol Stein, who have added design through their SoHo company, Turf, to their careers as filmmakers. At Gracious Home, 1217 Third Avenue (70th Street), (212) 517-6300. For stores outside New York, (212) 274-1103. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: BANK'S PROFIT RISES The British bank Standard Chartered said its second-half profit rose a better-than-expected 45 percent because of reduced bad-loan provisions. Standard Chartered said net income increased to $428 million, or 38.8 cents a share, from $295 million, or 26 cents, in the period a year earlier. The company reduced the amount it set aside for bad loans to $299 million from $463 million and trimmed administrative expenses by 1.8 percent, to $1.13 billion. (Bloomberg News)

title: African Leaders Arrive in France for Talks
description: France welcomed African leaders today to a summit meeting overshadowed by the conflict in Ivory Coast and by the attendance of Robert Mugabe, the leader of Zimbabwe, who has been banned by the rest of the European Union for his autocratic rule and human-rights abuses.

title: Arab League Is Struggling For Consensus On Iraq Crisis
description: Arab leaders quarreled openly today over how to respond to the growing likelihood of an American-led war in Iraq -- even over whether they should meet in an emergency session to debate how to respond.

title: Versatile Masks of Dye Speed the Chip-Making Process
description: FOOD dye, it turns out, is not just for coloring Easter eggs and adding roses to birthday cakes.

title: New Defendant in Hague to Aim Defense at Serbs of the Future
description: After a year of tirades from Slobodan Milosevic, the United Nations war crimes tribunal is likely to be treated to more bellicose nationalism next week when Vojislav Seselj travels to The Hague to face trial.

title: The Worst Defense
description: In announcing his ''Ready Campaign'' to prepare Americans for terrorist attack, Secretary of Homeland Security Tom Ridge declared yesterday: ''Terror forces us to make a choice. We can be afraid or we can be ready.'' Mr. Ridge's remarks, meant to calm people unnerved by two weeks of life at Code Orange, might have more resonance if the Bush administration were investing more wisely in national defenses against a catastrophic attack.

description: To the Editor:

title: No Longer Worldbeaters, Knicks Show True Colors
description: In what could be their final game together as a unit, the Knicks, worldbeaters at the start of this Western Conference trip, reverted to their maddening habit of blowing winnable games tonight.

title: PRE-PAID LEGAL SERVICES SAYS MEMBERSHIP IS INCREASING
description: Pre-Paid Legal Services, under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission over trading in its stock before the company disclosed a decline in subscribers, expects a first-quarter increase in its customer base. ''The membership base is currently up from where we ended the year,'' the chief operating officer, Randy Harp, said. The company said on Jan. 3 that it lost about 7,200 subscribers in the fourth quarter, the first decline in almost 10 years. Prosecutors and the S.E.C. are investigating trading in the company's shares ahead of the announcement that membership had fallen, which was made after the close of regular trading. The stock fell 25 percent the next trading day. Pre-Paid Legal Services, which sells insurance policies that pay for some legal services, is cooperating with investigators, Mr. Harp said.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Refiner's Records Seized
description: Prosecutors seized more documents from the SK Corporation in their investigation into allegations of insider trading on the part of Chey Tae Won -- vice chairman of the company and nephew of the founder of the parent SK Group -- and some of his top executives. Moody's Investors Service has lowered its outlook on the the company to negative from stable. It was the second raid in a week on the SK Corporation, Korea's largest oil refiner and one of its biggest trading companies.

title: Lord Wilberforce, 95, Keeper Of an Antislavery Tradition
description: Richard Orme Wilberforce, a retired member of Britain's highest court and keeper of his family's antislavery tradition, died on Saturday at a hospital in London. He was 95.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about a ruling by Belgium's highest court that after his term as Israel's prime minister, Ariel Sharon could face trial for 1982 war crimes misstated the role of another Israeli, Amos Yaron, who faces the same charges -- involving the massacre of Palestinians at two refugee camps in Lebanon. And a correction in this space yesterday referred incorrectly to the status of his case. Mr. Yaron was a military commander but was never chief of staff; the ruling about Mr. Sharon also cleared the way for Mr. Yaron to be tried. He has not already been tried.

title: U.S. to Send Nearly 2,000 Troops to Fight Militants in Philippines
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  The United States will send nearly 2,000 troops to Philippines in the next few weeks to fight Muslim extremists in the southern part of the country, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Being Prepared
description: The Department of Homeland Security began an education campaign yesterday about how to prepare for terrorist attacks, including advertisements and a Web site, www.ready.gov. These were among the department's recommendations.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Disappointing Bank Result
description: Germany's second-largest bank, the HVB Group, posted a worse-than-expected loss of 858 million euros ($919 million) for 2002 because of high provisions for bad loans. The provisions amounted to more than half of the 6.6 billion ($7 billion) of revenue. HVB took bad-debt provisions and charges for its revamping program, which involves cutting 9,100 jobs. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Safe Opens With a Touch, But Only if It's the Right One
description: If you have nightmares about standing in front of your high school locker, fumbling with the lock as the bell rings, or if you just want the latest in security, the Inprint safe from 9G Products might interest you.

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: LUCENT BOARD NAMES CHAIRWOMAN The board of Lucent Technologies, the maker of telecommunications equipment, said yesterday that Patricia F. Russo, left, the chief executive, would succeed the chairman, Henry B. Schacht. Ms. Russo, who was appointed chief executive last year, said Mr. Schacht would remain on the board as an outside director and at the company as a senior adviser for a time to handle issues including pending litigation. Mr. Schacht, who was Lucent's first chairman and chief executive when the company was spun off from AT&T in 1996, had returned in 2000 to oversee a restructuring. Ms. Russo also reaffirmed her expectation that Lucent would become profitable by September after three years of losses. Separately, shareholders allowed Lucent to carry out a reverse stock split, a measure that, if pursued, would enable the company to keep its share price above $1 and avoid being delisted by the New York Stock Exchange.   Simon Romero (NYT)

title: As Animosity Grows, Pataki And Silver Take Rift on the Road
description: Both the Republican governor and the Democratic speaker of the Assembly went to western New York today and trumpeted their sides in an increasingly bitter debate over the state budget, another sign of a growing animosity between the two men.

title: Blight Is Issue at Proposed Site for The Times
description: WELL-REHEARSED drama is a staple of 42nd Street, even in the legal battles that have accompanied each step of its state-sponsored redevelopment.

title: The Osbournes Plan for Summer
description: The Osbournes opened their Beverly Hills home for a news conference on Tuesday to announce the lineup of Ozzfest, the summer hard-rock tour led by Ozzy Osbourne.

title: Accounts
description: * Brown-Forman Corp., Louisville, Ky., expanded its relationship with Universal McCann, New York, by consolidating the worldwide media planning and buying for its wine and liquor brands like Jack Daniel's, Finlandia and Southern Comfort and naming Universal McCann as global agency of record. Billings were estimated at $60 million. Universal McCann, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies, already handled media duties in countries like France and Spain. Media planning for the United States had been handled by the St. Louis office of PHD, part of the Omnicom Group, and domestic media buying had been handled internally. Creative duties for the brands are divided among various agencies.

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: MICROSOFT TO BUY SOME ASSETS OF CONNECTIX Microsoft said late yesterday that it would purchase some of the assets of the Connectix Corporation, a small maker of so-called virtual machine software, based in San Mateo, Calif. The deal includes the company's flagship product, Virtual PC, which permits Macintosh users to run applications written for Microsoft Windows and Intel -based personal computers. Virtual PC software is crucial for Apple Computer because it permits corporate users to run Windows-based applications that do not exist for the Macintosh. Of greater interest to Microsoft, Connectix has developed a similar product for Windows-based PC's that permits computer users to run multiple operating systems, including Linux, simultaneously. The Silicon Valley company also recently entered the market for server computers used by corporations. The software permits a single Intel computer to simultaneously run a variety of operating systems, including Windows 2000 Server, Unix and Linux. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.   John Markoff (NYT)

title: 5 Hurt, 2 Critically, As Bus Crashes Into L.I. Terminal
description: An arriving bus smashed through the glass wall of Long Island's main bus terminal here this afternoon, injuring five people, one of them critically, the police said.

title: GENERAL MOTORS RESPONDS TO FUEL EFFICIENCY PROPOSAL
description: Improving the fuel efficiency of light trucks under a federal proposal would cost General Motors more than $1 billion and make its vehicles less safe, the automaker said in a filing with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. Under the administration's proposal, all light trucks, including sport utility vehicles and minivans, would have to increase their fuel economy level by 1.5 miles a gallon by 2007, a deadline G.M. says it will not be able to meet. A G.M. spokesman, Mike Morrissey, said the agency had overestimated what was feasible. To comply with the proposed rules, G.M. said it would have to reduce the vehicle's weight, which would increase the risk of rollover accidents. Ford Motor also filed a response to the proposal saying that the uniform standards were unfair and inefficient.

title: No Homicide Charge for Man Who Killed an Armed Intruder
description: It was said around the neighborhood that Grecia Gutierrez, who works in a Manhattan clothing store, had just won $100,000 in the lottery.

title: Government Tells Vigilantes Their 'Help' Isn't Necessary
description: GOVERNMENT officials have warned for some time that pro-Iraqi hackers might take aim at computers in the United States as international tensions rise. But now officials are also trying to discourage Americans who might be tempted to mount attacks on the computers and Web sites of Saddam Hussein's supporters.

title: Corrections
description: Articles on Tuesday and Wednesday about European deliberations on how best to disarm Iraq misstated the title of Costas Simitis of Greece. He is prime minister, not president.

title: Curbs on North Korea
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, ROBERT G., M.D.
description: MILLER-Robert G., M.D. On February 19, 2003. Beloved husband, father, son and brother who helped so many. Service Thursday, 1:15PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street at Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Regain a Familiar View Within Windows XP
description: Q. Sometimes the instructions for finding and adjusting settings in the Control Panel in Windows XP do not seem to match what is on my screen. For instance, I don't see separate icons for things like Sound. Why is that?

title: Remedy for Slavery: Give Reparations?
description: To the Editor:

title: MBNA, CREDIT CARD ISSUER, SAYS ITS LOAN LOSSES ROSE
description: The MBNA Corporation, the credit card issuer, said loan losses rose in January and would not subside until the second half of 2003. Uncollectible loans rose last month to an annualized 5.59 percent of loans, including those sold to investors as securities, compared with 5.04 percent in the fourth quarter, according to a company filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. MBNA set aside $1.4 billion for bad loans in the fourth quarter because it expected higher losses from personal loans and credit lines. Shares of MBNA, which is based in Wilmington, Del., fell $2, to $14.50.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A court says insurance companies should be accountable for damage to a patient's health.
description: A FEDERAL appeals court ruling issued in New York this month could crucially weaken the multibillion-dollar managed care industry, the H.M.O. trade association contends. Spokesmen for employers said they were concerned that the decision could result in higher costs for health care.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in World Business yesterday about the talks that led to a $6.8 billion investment by BP in the Russian oil industry omitted a word, reversing the meaning of a quotation from Mikhail M. Fridman, the leading investor negotiating with BP. Recalling a point at which he held out for a better offer, Mr. Fridman said (with the omitted word shown in capitals), ''I didn't want to agree in a way that felt like I had NOT resolved the issue.''

title: U.S. Stays Among Top 10 in the World
description: A victory in Jamaica and a loss to Argentina in Miami within the last month did nothing to change the position of the United States men's national team in the February issue of FIFA's world ranking.

title: All Governors To Be Asked To Back Bush On Medicaid
description: Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, said today that he wanted the nation's governors to endorse President Bush's proposal for sweeping changes in Medicaid when they meet here next week.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Governor Vetoes Budget Bill
description: Gov. John G. Rowland yesterday vetoed a Democratic bill intended to close the state's $650 million budget deficit. The governor, a Republican, had long vowed to kill the bill, which passed both chambers of the Legislature. Mr. Rowland opposed the bill because of its requirement to rehire the roughly 3,000 state workers laid off since December, a move he deems fiscally irresponsible. He also said the bill relied too heavily on tax increases, raising $5 in taxes for every $1 in cuts. Paul von Zielbauer (NYT)

title: Final Calls Add to Anguish Over Korean Subway Fire
description: As Koreans numbly digested the latest numbers on victims of subway fire here on Tuesday -- 125 dead, 146 injured and dozens missing -- recordings of victims' final cellphone calls added to the sense of horror.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCARPELLI, VICTOR L.
description: SCARPELLI-Victor L. Of Hawley, PA and Naples, FL. Formerly of East Northport, LI on February 18, 2003. Beloved husband of Margaret (Peggy). Devoted father of Karen Wills and her husband Anthony, Dr. David Scarpelli and his wife Noreen and Susan Scarpelli. Loving grandfather of Jamie, Jackie, Jennifer, Daniel, Andrew and Michael. Dear brother of Ann Augello. Visitation will be held on Thursday 7-9 PM and Friday 2-5 and 7-9 PM at Brueggemann F.H., 522 Larkfield Rd, East Northport, NY. Funeral Mass Saturday 9:15 AM at St. Anthony of Padua R.C. Church, East Northport. Interment to follow at Saint John's Cemetery, Middle Village, New York.

title: Light Doctors Make House Calls
description: Finding a shop to fix broken lamps (with their frayed wires, cracked plugs or incompatible European plugs) is tedious, and it is no fun lugging a broken lamp around. Now Roy and Lois Schneit of the Lamp Doc make house calls. The couple, who recently closed their lighting store in Greenwich Village, repair lamps at homes in the New York City area. Changing a three-way socket is about $45; converting a European plug to an American one is $60 to $85. They also sell light bulbs.

title: In Tough Hockey East, Have-Nots Have Something
description: ''The most difficult thing to do in our league,'' New Hampshire Coach DICK UMILE said about Hockey East, ``is to win the regular-season championship.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LERNER, HELEN
description: LERNER-Helen. On February 17, 2003. Beloved mother of Michael, Frank and Ira. Grandmother of Christopher, Dori, Julie and Alan. Her love, enthusiasm and boundless sense of humor will be forever missed. Services will be held on Friday, February 21, 2003 at the Redden Funeral Home, 325 W. 14 St, NYC at 11AM. Interment at Beth Israel Memorial Park Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The American Lung Assn, City of New York, PO Box 905, NY, NY 10159.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: MISSOURI: LESS IN DAMAGES FOR PHARMACIST A judge upheld a verdict in favor of a cancer patient who received watered down drugs from a pharmacist but cut damages from $2.2 billion to $330 million. The judge, Lee Wells of Circuit Court, ruled in the lawsuit against Robert Courtney, who was sentenced to 30 years in prison in December after pleading guilty to diluting two cancer medications. He admitted in his plea agreement that he had been diluting drugs since 1992, affecting as many as 4,200 patients. The $2.2 billion damage award came in October in the case of Georgia Hayes, who brought the first of more than 400 lawsuits against Mr. Courtney.    (AP)

title: Bush, With a Democratic Supporter, Promotes His Tax Cut
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  President Bush picked up the support of a friendly Democrat today as he traveled to the Deep South to promote his tax cut proposals.

title: Police Seek Handyman In Kidnapping
description: Investigators are looking for a homeless handyman who worked one afternoon at the house in Salt Lake City where Elizabeth Smart, 14, was abducted.

title: Study Finds Vaccine Doesn't Lead to Child Bacterial Infections
description: There is no evidence that the measles, mumps and rubella vaccine overloads children's immune systems or makes them more vulnerable to bacteria infections, researchers in Britain have found.

title: Here's a Franchise Player In Search of a Franchise
description: Along the hallways of the Indianapolis Convention Center, Willis McGahee is moving more slowly than everybody else. He insists he lost his limp days ago, but his gait still holds a limp's echo.

title: Reshaping Message on Terror, Ridge Urges Calm With Caution
description: A week after his warnings about terror threats touched off a buying spree of duct tape and plastic sheeting, Tom Ridge, the secretary of homeland security, tried today to recalibrate his message, urging calm while still imploring Americans to take precautions.

title: Ad Agency Creates a New Unit
description: HE New York office of BBDO Worldwide makes a belated entrance this week into one of the advertising industry's more lucrative categories with the creation of a division dedicated to pitching prescription drugs directly to consumers.

title: Benefit for AIDS Patients, And Moving Help for Top Bidder
description: You want to move, or maybe buy an apartment, but your depressed mutual funds won't cover the costs? Bailey House, a nonprofit group that helps homeless people with AIDS, is holding its Open Your Heart auction, and one of the items will help with your expenses. DJ Knight & Company, a residential broker, is putting together a package worth $10,000 that includes its services (mortgage fee, appraisal, credit check), help with moving expenses, weekly maid service for a month, three months of digital cable television service and a couch from Todd Hase. Duct tape and bottled water are your responsibility.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bank's Profit Rises
description: The British bank Standard Chartered said its second-half profit rose a better-than-expected 45 percent because of reduced bad-loan provisions. Standard Chartered said net income increased to $428 million, or 38.8 cents a share, from $295 million, or 26 cents, in the period a year earlier. The company reduced the amount it set aside for bad loans to $299 million from $463 million and trimmed administrative expenses by 1.8 percent, to $1.13 billion.

title: Write on Your Pictures (Without Ink Smudges)
description: A picture may be worth 1,000 words, but that's a moot point if you can't remember where you put it. PhoTags, a new picture organization program from a company of the same name, allows digital photographers to quickly insert labels and messages within JPEG picture files. The PhoTags software can then be used to search for pictures by their specific labels and messages, making it easy to round up all the photos scattered around the hard drive from that Paris vacation or graduation party. Captions, borders, dates and greetings can be added to help photographers remember where and why the photo was taken. The annotated photos can be sent by e-mail; recipients can open them just as they would normal JPEG files and see the text displayed on the pictures without having to have the PhoTags software.

title: F.C.C. Ruling Is Expected To Favor Bells
description: Unable to muster a majority of support, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission is preparing to issue a rare dissent over aspects of the most significant changes in the regulation of the telephone industry since the Telecommunications Act of 1996, people involved in the proceedings said late this afternoon.

title: Malibu Invents A Sound Of Its Own
description: The Malibu Inn is not your normal dive bar, especially tonight. The parking lot is full of BMW's, Lexuses and Mercedes-Benzes. The bar has several liquid-crystal televisions. The room is packed with so many gorgeous high-school students that it looks like a casting call for ''Are You Hot?'' Several proud mothers are also in the audience, looking about five years older than their daughters. And there are the stars in the crowd: the actress Kate Hudson, the producer David Foster, the former Eagles guitarist Don Felder and half a dozen professional surfers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GWERTZMAN, ADELAIDE
description: GWERTZMAN-Adelaide. On February 18, 2003, at age 92. Loving wife of the late Max J. Gwertzman. Cherished mother of Bernard M. Gwertzman and his wife Marie-Jeanne, and Stephen N. Gwertzman & his wife Sheila. Grandmother of Dr. Alan Gwertzman, Lisa Donnelly, Lynn Hendricks, John Spencer, James S. Gwertzman and Michael D. Gwertzman. Sister of Dr. Sidney Schreiber and the late Dr. William Schreiber. Funeral service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street, Friday, February 21st, at 11 AM. Interment to follow at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

title: Reason No. 11: I've Got Big Plows
description: The business of cleaning up after a blizzard has been a political barometer since Mayor John Lindsay met his frigid Waterloo on the snow-clogged streets of Queens in February 1969. Now, advances in forecasting storms and removing snow -- backed by a battalion of sanitation workers, plows and salters -- have left Mayor Michael Bloomberg feeling so good about the job being done that he appeared Tuesday on ''Late Night With David Letterman,'' touting the top 10 reasons to love the snow. Strangely, the list did not include the invigorating exercise that comes with digging out a car buried under a mound of plowed snow. Still, the mayor had reason to feel chipper about the city's response to one of the worst storms in New York history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLEN, JANET Y.
description: WILLEN-Janet Y. On February 15, 2003, at age 84. Beloved wife of the late Joseph Willen and Hans A. Sonnenthal. Loving mother of Peter Y. Sonnenthal and Valerie J.R. Sonnenthal. Adoring grandmother of Hudson and Sawyer Klebs. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison at 81st Street, Friday, February 21, 12 noon. Interment Beth Olem Cemetery. Contributions in her memory may be made to the UJA Federation, 130 East 59th Street, NY, NY 10022, or the American Cancer Society, 19 West 56th Street, NY, NY 10019.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURSTEIN, CHARLES
description: BURSTEIN-Charles. Age 90, beloved husband of Anna, father of David Burstein, M.D. and Emanuel Burstein, L.L.M., Ph.D., father-in-law of Dr. Joan Bregstein, adored grandfather of Shana and Jonah. Born in Kolno, Poland, emigrated to America at age 7, raised on the Lower East Side, World War II veteran and Purple Heart recipient, he raised and educated two sons in Queens. A universally loved man of quiet dignity, consummate honesty and genuine charitable inclination. His kindness touched many lives. He will be sorely missed, but his memory and example live on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKINNER, DAVID B., M.D.
description: SKINNER-David B., M.D. A memorial service for president emeritus of NewYorkPresbyterian Hospital and professor of surgery and cardiothoracic surgery at Weill Cornell Medical College Dr. David B. Skinner will be held on Saturday, February 22, 2003 at 3:00PM at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Ave. at 55th St. A reception will follow at the University Club, 1 West 54th St.

title: Economic Scene; Are corporate scandals just greed, or a predictable result of a theory?
description: TO many, the recent corporate scandals are a direct consequence of widespread greed. Managers and their lawyers, investment bankers and accountants simply lied to investors for their own avaricious gain.

title: Side Issues Crop Up, But Sprewell Is Unruffled
description: There were all sorts of distractions awaiting the Knicks today. Naturally, there was Thursday's trade deadline, but there was also the issue of critical comments made by Nets Coach Byron Scott about Latrell Sprewell.

title: Hevesi Orders M.T.A. Board To Release Finance Data
description: The public battle to get the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to release financial information as it considers a fare increase grew more heated yesterday when State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi issued a subpoena ordering the M.T.A. board to open its books by next week.

title: DaimlerChrysler Says Kerkorian Favored Merger
description: In its first detailed response to a long-simmering problem, DaimlerChrysler made public yesterday a lengthy legal rebuttal to a suit filed on behalf of Kirk Kerkorian, the billionaire Las Vegas casino operator who was the biggest shareholder of Chrysler before it was acquired by Daimler-Benz in 1998.

title: Gephardt, in Formally Taking Aim at the White House, Sharply Attacks Bush
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt began his second campaign for president in 16 years today with a fierce attack on President Bush's economic and domestic polices and a pledge to push for health care coverage for all Americans.

title: New Star Shows Restraint, And It Defeats a Contract
description: In Houston last March, Reese Milner of Beverly Hills, Calif., emerged from nowhere to score a big victory in the Spingold Knockout Teams. He had replaced George Rosenkranz of Mexico City as the captain of a cosmopolitan team that included two Polish stars.

title: Trial Near in Patent Case on Key Internet Technology
description: The patent claims of a 74-year-old inventor over a technology that is the foundation of virtually all online commerce will come to trial next week in a court test that could force huge payments from some of the Internet's most powerful companies.

title: A Hothouse In SoHo, Floor To Ceiling
description: Don't despair over the mushy stuff outside: a green wall grows in SoHo. Orchids, anthurium, ficus, philodendrons and 50 other plants are growing on a 16-foot stainless-steel frame in the new Marith & Franois Girbaud boutique at 47 Wooster Street (Broome Street), above. The vertical garden, cultivated on felt, is by a French botanist, Patrick Blanc, who has created two similar walls in Paris, at the Pershing Hall hotel and at the Girbaud store on Rue du Cherche-Midi. Plants, he said, thrive ''on boulders, mosses and trunks of trees, and can live with very little light.'' The cost: $80,000, irrigation system and orchids included. ELAINE LOUIE

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  EPSTEIN, DR. CHARLES C.
description: EPSTEIN-Dr. Charles C. You never really left us. We live our lives as you taught us-with honesty, respect, dignity and love. Sydne, Amy and Susa

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDON, STEPHEN L. JR.
description: LANDON-Stephen L. Jr. 79. Of Washington, Connecticut died on February 18, 2003. Husband of the late Joanne Woodworth Landon and Frances S. Sweat Landon. Father of Linda G, Russell W, Stephen (Scudder) and Matthew J. Landon. Brother of Howland Landon. Also survived by two grandchildren, Halsey and Chelsea Landon. Predeceased by a brother Frederick Landon. Funeral services Saturday, February 22, 2003, 11:00 AM at St. Johns Episcopal Church, Washington, CT. Memorial contributions may be made to St. Johns Episcopal Church, Washington, CT. 06794.

title: Corrections
description: Articles on Tuesday and Wednesday about European deliberations on how best to disarm Iraq misstated the title of Costas Simitis of Greece. He is prime minister, not president.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: RealNetworks And Ericsson Create Alliance
description: RealNetworks Inc., a maker of software that plays Internet audio and video, said yesterday that it would sell software to Ericsson to help cellphone users connect to the Internet. RealNetworks' Helix software system will be installed on Ericsson equipment that is used to connect calls and that is sold to wireless phone providers, said Ian Freed, RealNetworks' vice president for mobile products and services. Content like news, movie previews and the audio of baseball games will soon be widely available on cellphones connected to the Internet, Mr. Freed said. About 300 million personal computers are linked to the Internet. The number of connected devices, including cellphones, will rise to about one billion in a few years, he said. Shares of RealNetworks rose 20 cents, to $4.07.

title: Deaths at Sea: Grim Numbers
description: With the revision of the death toll this month to 1,863, the sinking of the ferry Joola is thought to be the second-worst nonmilitary maritime disaster. Here are the other four worst tolls, according to the World Almanac and New York Times research.

title: Central Park Gardener Wins A Central Park West Income
description: For Phin Suy, a gardener for the Central Park Conservancy, a day like yesterday would have ordinarily found him shoveling snow near West 81st Street. Instead, he scooped up enough money to buy several park-front penthouses.

title: Poise Amid Senegalese Thunder
description: An exciting concert was getting off to a boring start. People were still wandering into Irving Plaza at 12:30 on Friday night, ready for a rare local performance from Thione Seck, one of Senegal's most popular singers. But Mr. Seck was nowhere to be seen, and instead, without him his band, Raam Daan, was exploring a listless funk groove.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Mystery Maple

title: Nations Squabble, but Don't Touch My Toile
description: IN the great French-American spat of 2003, the talking heads have paid scant attention to the role of dcor in international diplomacy. As a few impassioned voices call for a boycott of French food and wine, and some Republicans urge tighter scrutiny of French bottled water, the salient home furnishing questions loom unanswered: If you stuff your socks into a French provincial dresser, are you taking a position against war in Iraq? As protesters filled the streets last weekend, did the flea market masses tacitly lend support by throwing their MasterCards at Louis XVI-style commodes?

title: Mouse With Ear Appeal Can Tune In FM Stations
description: Multitasking may get a little easier with a new two-button computer mouse that doubles as a digital FM radio receiver. The device, called the MouseCaster, plugs into the computer's PS/2 port; a second cord attaches the mouse to the PC's sound card, and a third functions as an antenna. An onscreen control panel allows listeners to program favorite stations much as they would a car radio, autoscan the dial and even set an alarm or play selected programs.

title: Elliott Tells Grand Jury His Side of Scuffle With Driver
description: Jumbo Elliott, a Jets offensive tackle, said he told a Nassau County grand jury today that he was reacting in self-defense after a limousine driver grabbed him outside a restaurant in December. Elliott said he shrugged the driver away, causing him to fall to the ground.

title: Race 4 Is Postponed By Unsteady Winds
description: A hundred Maori tribesmen performed a war chant as Team New Zealand left Viaduct Harbor this morning for the America's Cup racecourse, but eventually the battle with the Swiss team Alinghi was postponed because of shifting winds on the Hauraki Gulf.

title: The President and the Protesters
description: To the Editor:

title: Panel Says School Boards Should Stay Largely Intact
description: The legislative task force charged with recommending ways to replace New York City's local school boards said yesterday that the boards should remain largely intact and focus on representing parents.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about a ruling by Belgium's highest court that after his term as Israel's prime minister, Ariel Sharon could face trial for 1982 war crimes misstated the role of another Israeli, Amos Yaron, who faces the same charges -- involving the massacre of Palestinians at two refugee camps in Lebanon. And a correction in this space yesterday referred incorrectly to the status of his case. Mr. Yaron was a military commander but was never chief of staff; the ruling about Mr. Sharon also cleared the way for Mr. Yaron to be tried. He has not already been tried.

title: 2 Introduce Legislation That Is Close to Homes
description: Two years ago, Ral M. Grijalva came to the Capitol to lobby Congress for a bill that went nowhere. It was a measure to grant citizenship to every member of the Tohono O'odham Nation, an Indian tribe whose land straddles the United States-Mexico border in the hardscrabble desert south of Mr. Grijalva's native Tucson.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Deal Lets Wachovia Control Prudential Brokerage Unit

title: 2 Tacks on Threat of War, for the Young and the Older
description: ''I'm still not sure why now,'' a teenage boy leaning against his high school locker tells an MTV News camera. ''I'm still not so sure why so drastic.'' Youth's inchoate fears about the threat of war in Iraq is the focus of ''Confronting Iraq,'' shown tonight, the channel's first half-hour special on the conflict, another sign that the gathering storm is now dark enough to cast a shadow over even the most oblivious MTV viewers.

title: L.I. Monsignor Scorns Jury, Insisting He Is No 'Monster'
description: Although his name never appears in the recent Suffolk County grand jury report on sexual abuse by Roman Catholic priests on Long Island, Msgr. Alan J. Placa acknowledges that he emerges as a central villain. Not only does the report suggest that he is the imperious architect of policies that protected pedophiles, but it says that three decades ago he groped teenage boys through their clothes and made ''feeble attempts'' to grope an altar server.

title: Hope Only Glimmers for Transplant Victim
description: Fearing severe brain damage, doctors for Jsica Santilln, the 17-year-old girl who was mistakenly given a heart and lung transplant from an organ donor with the wrong blood type, told her family yesterday that even on the off chance that suitable organs could be found for a second transplant, she might no longer be a candidate.

title: People-Rating on the Web?
description: At a dinner party last weekend, my wife and I were chatting with two recently divorced moms. They were tragicomically bemoaning the awkwardness of re-entering the dating world in middle age.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AHERN, JOHN P.
description: AHERN-John P., February 16, 2003, of Seaford and Breezy Point. Proprietor of Great Western Packing & Fine Foods, Park Slope, Brooklyn, NY. Beloved husband of Catherine, loving father of John M., Patricia Ahern Ruben, James E., and Deborah Ahern Parmiter. Loving grandfather of Bryan, Scott, Christopher, Keith, Lindsey, Meaghan, Caitlyn & Breanna. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Reposing at the Charles G. Schmitt Funeral Home, 3863 Merrick Road, Seaford (2 traffic lights East of Route 135). Mass of Christian burial Saturday, 9:00AM, at St. William The Abbot R.C. Church. Interment Greenwood Cemetery. Hours today and Friday, 2:00-4:30 and 7:00-9:30 PM. Donations to St. Jude Children's Hospital, 501 St. Jude Place, Memphis, TN 38105-1905

title: Ex-Chicago Trader Is Accused of Fraud
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 19 (Bloomberg News)  A former hedge fund manager and Chicago Board Options Exchange trader was indicted today on charges that he swindled about 55 investors out of more than $21 million.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Woman May Use Initials In Lawsuit
description: A woman who accuses the New York Blood Center of giving her a blood-borne disease can bring her lawsuit using initials to protect her privacy, a federal judge in Brooklyn ruled yesterday. The woman said she feared being stigmatized because hepatitis B, which she says she contracted through a blood transfusion, can also be transmitted by sexual activity. Judge Edward R. Korman wrote that it was unnecessary to require ''an invasion of privacy as the price for litigating a legitimate private complaint.'' He would not allow the woman to use the name Ella Woe because of concern that it could prejudice the center's case, but said she could use the initials E.W. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: EVENTS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDERSON, BRIAN GREGORY, M.D.
description: ANDERSON-Brian Gregory, M.D. Peacefully in Grenada on Tuesday, February 18, 2003, after a long illness courageously borne. Brian Gregory Anderson, MD., Latterly Associate, Clinical Director of The Stairs Unit at Manhattan Psychiatric Center. Much loved brother of Philip and the late David, and cherished uncle of Susan and Michael. Services Sunday, February 23rd, 1:30 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. NYC

title: Briton May Bid for Hotel Giant
description: As speculation swirled about a possible bid for Six Continents, the world's second-largest hotel chain, Hugh E. Osmond, a British entrepreneur who made a fortune from pizza restaurants and pub chains, said today that he might make an offer but did not say how much it might be.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: People
description: * Lor Gold, executive creative director for promotional marketing at Draft Worldwide, Chicago, was named to the new post of chief creative officer, as part of a reorganization combining the direct and promotional creative departments. Kathy Bucaro-Zobens, executive creative director for direct marketing, was named to the new post of executive creative director, reporting to Ms. Gold. Draft is part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: 302 Killed in Crash of Iranian Military Plane
description: A military transport plane carrying members of the elite Islamic Revolutionary Guards crashed in southeastern Iran today, killing all 302 people on board, the Islamic Republic News Agency reported.

title: For Sale: Nostalgia, and Its Frustrations
description: NOSTALGIA is a powerful sales tool, and the people from Konami thought I would be very excited about Contra: Shattered Soldier, a sequel to the 1987 video game Contra. When they told me that a sequence of button presses would activate a cheat code to make the game easier, as in the original game for Nintendo, it was as though they were heralding the Second Coming.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Kosovo: Albanian Guerrilla Leader Arrested
description: A Kosovo Albanian leader indicted by the United Nations war crimes tribunal was captured in a Slovene ski resort after fleeing from NATO peacekeepers who arrested three of his accomplices. Fatmir Limaj, an ally of the former Kosovo Liberation Army commander, Hashim Thaci, is accused of committing atrocities against Serbian and Albanian civilians in a Kosovo Liberation Army prison camp in 1998. The indictment, which also covers three other former K.L.A. fighters detained by NATO, is the first to be brought against Kosovo Albanians by the tribunal in The Hague. Daniel Simpson (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ulster: Arrest In Omagh Bombing
description: The Irish police arrested Seamus Daly, 32, who is suspected of being a member of the Real I.R.A. paramilitary group and of being involved in the 1998 car-bombing of Omagh, Northern Ireland, which killed 29 people and maimed dozens more in the deadliest attack of the province's sectarian conflict. Largely ineffectual investigations prompted victims' families last year to sue five men, including Mr. Daly, for damages in the attack. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: African Town's Pride and Joy Vanished When Ferry Sank
description: A single mother in a tin-roofed shack, Marie Joseph Tendang once plied these streets long past midnight selling palm wine to pay school fees for her daughter. Franoise was her name.

title: Blizzard Takes Toll on Sports Team Bubbles
description: During the blizzard Monday afternoon, workers tried to keep the practice bubble next to Giants Stadium from collapsing.

title: Venice's New Logo: A Wing (and a Prayer)
description: WHEN New York State commissioned Milton Glaser to produce a tourist-friendly logo 26 years ago, no one guessed it would become a world-famous icon. Nor did anyone predict that millions of dollars in licensing revenue would be generated by sales of T-shirts, mugs and bumper stickers bearing the I Love New York design.

title: Retelling Jewish History, Abraham to Israel
description: THE history of the Jews spans thousands of years, crosses hundreds of countries and touches cultures from Ramses II's Egypt to Nero's Rome to modern America. So perhaps it should not be surprising that an effort to tell the tale interactively became a two-decade, multimillion-dollar epic in itself.

title: Military Contractor Gets Deal To Limit Its Losses in Britain
description: BAE Systems, Europe's largest military contractor, said today that it had reached an agreement with the British government to limit its losses on two major contracts that have been plagued with cost overruns. The deal lifted a cloud from the company's financial prospects and inspired investors to bid up its shares by more than 10 percent.

title: Pondicherry Journal; The Zoo Is Fiction, but It Just Might Spring to Life
description: When a Canadian novelist, Yann Martel, published a novel more than a year ago about the deeply spiritual son of a zookeeper here, local officials were quietly pleased that it might help tourism.

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: TEXAS: REPRIEVE FOR DAMAGED BANK TOWER The Bank One building, a 37-story reminder of the tornado that damaged downtown Fort Worth in March 2000 will be spared from the wrecking ball. The City Council on Tuesday approved $7.4 million in tax abatements, economic development grants and other incentives for a project to refurbish the building, which once housed the bank, 200 lawyers' offices and a restaurant. Developers say they plan 270 apartments as well as stores and restaurants. The building, heavily damaged in the tornado, had been scheduled for demolition.    (AP)

title: Do-It-All Palmtops: New Tricks
description: WHEN it comes to generating enthusiasm among the masses, not all electronics are created equal. Almost anyone can see the appeal of, say, a DVD player. But describe a palmtop that does nothing but let you check your e-mail at any time of the day or night, and people may stare at you as though you had just grown antlers.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Prison Firm Testifies On Lobbying
description: Executives for a prison company indicated yesterday that they were unaware of many of the activities of a former executive, Franklin Chris Jackson, who is now under scrutiny. Two executives of the firm, Correctional Services Corporation, testified privately before the state lobbying commission about Mr. Jackson, who is at the center of an inquiry into favors to lawmakers, like minivans provided for personal use. Correctional Services until recently had state contracts. Mr. Jackson has not responded to a commission subpoena, and his lawyer has said he is too ill to testify. But officials said the lawyer has offered some information to the commission, which is seeking to determine whether the favors were lobbying expenditures that the company failed to disclose. Clifford J. Levy (NYT)

title: Found: Rottweiler Who Thinks It's a Penguin
description: It was a strange sight, out of a Jack London novel or a ''Lassie'' episode -- a dog adrift on an ice floe, swiftly moving down the Passaic River.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Mapics To Cut 23% Of Work Force
description: Mapics Inc., a software maker that acquired its rival Frontstep Inc., plans to cut about 250 jobs, or about 23 percent of its work force. The combined company had about 1,100 workers when the transaction was announced in November, Mapics, based in Alpharetta, Ga., said. The purchase of Frontstep was completed yesterday after 4.2 million Mapics shares were exchanged for Frontstep's common stock. Mapics, which makes software for manufacturing companies, also assumed about $20.1 million in Frontstep debt. Shares of Mapics rose 6 cents, to $6.95.

title: Photos Bolster Idea of Water, and Possibly Life, on Mars
description: A new theory and a revised interpretation of earlier observations have bolstered the idea that Mars has more water than previously thought and encouraged speculation about the possibility of life on the planet.

title: Despite the Danger Warnings, Ephedra Sells
description: Investigators say it may never be known whether the dietary supplement ephedra contributed to the death of Steve Bechler, the 23-year-old Baltimore Orioles pitcher who died of heatstroke on Monday after collapsing during a workout in the Florida sun.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: REFINER'S RECORDS SEIZED Prosecutors seized more documents from the SK Corporation in their investigation into allegations of insider trading on the part of Chey Tae Won  vice chairman of the company and nephew of the founder of the parent SK Group  and some of his top executives. Moody's Investors Service has lowered its outlook on the the company to negative from stable. It was the second raid in a week on the SK Corporation, Korea's largest oil refiner and one of its biggest trading companies.

title: Ruby Tuesday Chain Selects Kaplan
description: Ruby Tuesday in Maryville, Tenn., which operates 600 casual restaurants, has named the Kaplan Thaler Group in New York as agency of record on its creative account, and MediaVest U.S.A. in New York as agency of record on the media duties. Both assignments had previously been handled internally.

title: Dancers Talk, But Can You Believe Them?
description: In the simplest sense, anything that takes place onstage is real: it happens. But there can be different kinds of theatrical realities. For instance, if performers unexpectedly pause, does that mean they have forgotten their lines or dance steps? Or is the pause part of the work?

title: Conservancy Reaches Deal To Preserve Hearst Land
description: The Hearst Corporation and conservationists reached an agreement today that will potentially protect tens of thousands of unspoiled acres around Hearst Castle.

title: Corrections

title: MORGAN STANLEY CUTS THE PAY OF ITS CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: Morgan Stanley cut the compensation of its chairman and chief executive, Philip J. Purcell, by 27 percent last year as profit at the securities company slumped. The company paid Mr. Purcell $11 million in 2002, down from $15 million in 2001, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Purcell received $775,000 in salary and a cash bonus of $5.6 million. He was also awarded restricted stock, which Morgan Stanley valued at $2.3 million, and $2.3 million in stock options. Mr. Purcell exercised $14 million in stock options in 2002, according to the filing. The cut in pay follows a 15 percent decline in net income at Morgan Stanley.

title: Tattooed Tyson At Center Of Storm
description: Mike Tyson did not want to show his face here Tuesday and most of today. Who could blame him? The last time Tyson came to the Memphis area for a heavyweight fight, he was tattooed by Lennox Lewis in an eight-round knockout on June 8, 2002.

description: CAIRO, Feb. 20  A British defense worker was shot and killed today in Saudi Arabia's capital, Riyadh, in the latest of a series attacks on Britons, Americans and other Westerners in Saudi Arabia and other Arab countries.

description: ADC Telecommunications Inc., the maker of equipment that increases the capacity of telephone and cable networks, said today that its fiscal first-quarter loss narrowed to $41.5 million as costs declined.

description: After three tough, close road games, the Islanders might have needed a breather on their schedule. Fortunately, the San Jose Sharks played host for the final game of the Islanders' four-game trip last night. The Sharks, in last place in the Pacific after winning the division a year ago, are the most disappointing team in the league this season.

description: As the director of ''Les Troyens,'' the Metropolitan Opera's current megahit, Francesca Zambello has made an excellent choice in her choreographer, Doug Varone.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Four Students Arrested In Sex Case
description: Four 17-year-old male students at a Roman Catholic high school in Queens were arrested yesterday and charged with having sex with a 15-year-old female classmate last Halloween. The defendants, all seniors, were expelled from Christ the King High School in Middle Village this month. They were charged with sexual misconduct and endangering the welfare of a child, and face up to six months in prison if convicted, said a spokesman for the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown. Lawyers for three of the defendants said that rape had not been claimed, but Madeline Bryer, the girl's lawyer, said that the sex was not consensual. An official at the high school declined to comment. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bigger Budget For West Nile Virus Research
description: The federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will receive an additional $8 million this year to detect and fight the mosquito-borne West Nile Virus, said Representative Joseph Crowley, Democrat of Queens. There were 29 reported cases of the virus in New York City last year, including two deaths, and 2,600 cases nationally. The spending package passed by Congress last week includes $37 million to combat the virus, up from last year's $29 million. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: Northrop Elevates Its President To Complete Succession Plan
description: The Northrop Grumman Corporation, the nation's third-largest military contractor, announced yesterday that Ronald D. Sugar, the company's president, will become its next chief executive. He succeeds Kent Kresa, the longest-serving chief executive of a big Pentagon contractor, who is retiring.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: $62 Million In Budget Cuts
description: Citing lower corporate income tax receipts, Gov. Mike Huckabee ordered $62 million cut from the state budget by June 1, the end of its fiscal year. The spending reduction, the fifth in the state's two-year appropriations cycle, brings to $363 million the sum eliminated from what was intended to have been a $3.6 billion budget. Public schools would absorb half the latest cuts, but Medicaid programs would also be affected. Mr. Huckabee, a Republican, has said additional taxes will be necessary merely to maintain services at existing levels.

title: COCA-COLA NOMINATES MORGAN EXECUTIVE TO ITS BOARD
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it had nominated Maria Elena Lagomasino, the chairwoman and chief executive of the J. P. Morgan Private Bank, to its board. If elected, Ms. Lagomasino will replace Paul F. Oreffice, the former chairman and chief executive of Dow Chemical, who is retiring. In September, Coke was criticized by an independent diversity task force for failing to choose minority candidates when it nominated two people to its board last spring. Ms. Lagomasino, who is a native of Cuba and has spent most of her career in private banking, serves on the board of Avon Products. Coke said in a separate announcement that it had raised its quarterly dividend to 22 cents a share, from 20 cents. Sherri Day (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: PHILIPPINES: IMPORTS COOLING The Philippines imported 20 percent more goods in December 2002 than December 2001, but the growth rate slowed from the torrid 47 percent increase reported in November. Imports are a leading indicator in the Philippines because much of the volume is made up of electronic and other components for assembly and re-export; the slowing trend raised doubts about the government's target for growth of 5.2 percent this year. title: A Traditional Balladeer Old Beyond His Years
description: Meticulousness is not a quality one normally associates with young musical hotshots, who typically try to shoot the moon with every performance. But when the gifted 19-year-old singer and pianist Peter Cincotti takes the stage, the restraint and care that go into everything he does bespeak the concentration of an intensely dedicated craftsman. Singing in a clear, steady voice that recalls the young Jack Jones, Mr. Cincotti articulates every syllable in elegant, long-lined phrasing that infuses lyrics with an elastic sense of swing. Few young pop singers exhibit such impressive breath control and mastery of dynamics.

title: Young Love, Tragedy And a Poem
description: So few movies demonstrate any interest in serious poetry that when the rare one comes along flashing a silver tongue and a fine-tipped quill, you're tempted to give it half a cheer simply for daring to exist. The poem that winds through ''Till Human Voices Wake Us,'' a romantic ghost story from Australia, is T. S. Eliot's ''Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock.'' The movie bases much of its imagery (as well its title) on the mellifluous last three lines of ''Prufrock'': ''We have lingered in the chambers of the sea/By sea-girls wreathed with seaweed red and brown/Till human voices wake us, and we drown.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERT, SAM
description: ALBERT-Sam. Information technology industry pioneer, consultant and the creator, producer and voice of COMPUTIPS on 1010 WINS, died Sunday, February 16th, 2003. In his 30 years with the IBM Corporation, he created IBM's business partner program and pioneered the firm's worldwide relationships with the management consulting, accounting, auditing, legal and information services professions. Upon retiring from IBM, he established Sam Albert Associates, a consulting practice specializing in Information Technology industry relationships, mergers and acquisitions. He was a highly respected industry analyst, credited with credited with first coining the term, ''co-opetition,'' to describe ways in which traditional competitors could work together to achieve mutual benefits. He was often seen on CNBC and quoted in The Wall Street Journal, The New York Times, Time magazine and other media. During the past decade, Mr. Albert also became well known for his CompuTips program on 1010 WINS radio. He was known throughout the business world for his ideas, knowledge, enthusiasm and optimism. He is survived by his wife, Joice; son, Gavin; daughter, Corey-Jan; son-inlaw, Joel Deitch; and grandchildren Cameron and Maxxe Albert-Deitch. Funeral service Sunday February 23, 11 AM at Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Ave, Scarsdale, NY.

title: National Briefing: South
description: KENTUCKY: PATIENT SUES SURGEON OVER BRANDING A hysterectomy patient has sued, accusing her surgeon of branding the initials of his alma mater, the University of Kentucky, on her uterus as he removed it. Nine other patients have asked to join the suit. The women say they discovered the branding after watching videotapes of their procedures that the surgeon, Dr. James M. Guiler, provided. Dr. Guiler has defended the practice, saying letters marked the organ's midline. "Not only am I always able to remain oriented for the patient's safety," he said, "I felt this was honorable since it made reference to the college of medicine where I received my medical degree." (AP)

title: Blair's Stand on Iraq Hurts Him Politically but Seems Unlikely to Topple Him

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Little Risk Seen In Downtown Air
description: Federal health officials have concluded that it is ''very unlikely'' that dust from the World Trade Center attack posed a significant health risk to people who lived downtown. The study, published yesterday by the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, compared air and surface dust samples collected in November and December 2001 in 30 downtown buildings with samples from buildings above 59th Street. The downtown samples had more glass fibers and asbestos than those uptown, but in concentrations below those considered hazardous, the study said. The report, however, encouraged residents concerned about dust to continue using damp mops and HEPA vacuums, or to seek federal cleanup assistance. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Ciena Loss Widens On Costs To Retire Debt
description: The Ciena Corporation, the No. 4 American maker of fiber optic network equipment, posted a sixth consecutive quarterly net loss yesterday because of slumping sales and costs to retire debt. The loss in the first quarter, which ended on Jan. 31, widened to $107.1 million, or 25 cents a share, from $70.6 million, or 22 cents, a year earlier. Sales slid by more than half, to $70.5 million from $162.2 million, Ciena said. The company has pared expenses, and cut 450 jobs in September, to cope with falling demand from telecommunications companies for equipment. Still, Ciena's revenue exceeded the company's December forecast. Ciena said sales in this quarter would be little changed to up slightly from the preceding three months. Ciena expects a second-quarter loss of 11 cents to 13 cents, the chief financial officer, Joseph R. Chinnici, said. In the period a year earlier, Ciena reported a net loss of $1.86 a share. Ciena shares fell 11 cents, or 2 percent, to $5.41. First-quarter results included $20.6 million in costs to retire debt from ONI Systems, a rival that Ciena acquired in June.

title: UNIVERSAL HEALTH OFFICIAL DRAWS S.E.C. INQUIRY
description: Universal Health Services said yesterday that the Philadelphia office of the Securities and Exchange Commission had begun an informal inquiry into the departure of the company's chief financial officer, Kirk Gorman. Mr. Gorman was fired last week after he told the auditing firm KPMG that he did not have the expertise to verify details of the company's financial records. KPMG took the matter to Universal Health's board because auditors were concerned that Mr. Gorman could not sign off on results as required by the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, which passed Congress last year after a string of corporate scandals. Universal Health, based in King of Prussia, Pa., operates hospitals.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Ingram Micro Posts $10.3 Million Loss
description: Ingram Micro Inc., which distributes computer parts, had a fourth-quarter loss of $10.3 million because of restructuring costs, and the company said yesterday that first-quarter profit would not meet analysts' forecasts. The net loss was 7 cents a share, in contrast to a profit of $5.66 million, or 4 cents, a year earlier. Sales fell 4.1 percent, to $5.89 billion from $6.14 billion. North American sales, which account for half the company's total, declined 10.6 percent, the company said. Ingram Micro had costs after taxes of $39.5 million to pay for job cuts and the closing of operations in a program intended to generate $160 million in annualized operating income. The company said it expected a first-quarter profit of $21 million to $24 million, or 14 cents to 16 cents a share, excluding some costs, with revenue of $5.40 billion to $5.55 billion. Analysts expected profit of 17 cents a share and $5.55 billion in sales, according to a Thomson First Call survey. Shares of Ingram Micro were unchanged at $10.05.

title: Bridge Tolls: Old Debates And New Ideas
description: A BUNCH of elected officials from Brooklyn gathered yesterday on the Brooklyn Bridge, there to unburden themselves about the mayor's desire for tolls on the four East River bridges. Brooklynites they may have been. But these men and women knew a thing or two about Bronx cheers.

title: A Modernist Sees Luster In Old Silver
description: You can never predict what somebody will collect. A perfect example is Margo Grant Walsh, an award-winning modernist interior architect in New York. Ms. Walsh grew up in on the Great Plains in North Dakota, on the Turtle Mountain Indian Reservation in Belcourt, with a Chippewa father and a mother of Scottish lineage. Her very early years were without electricity, running water or indoor plumbing. She attended classes in the one-room schoolhouse on the reservation, where her mother taught.

title: Steinbrenner Tosses More Wood on Fire Jeter Says Is Out
description: On another day, in another season, George Steinbrenner might have marched onto Legends Field and wrapped an arm around Derek Jeter, with cameras clicking everywhere. Steinbrenner would have called Jeter his warrior and called a truce to their verbal warfare.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDERSON, QUENTIN
description: ANDERSON-Quentin. The Board of Trustees of the Whitney Museum of American Art note with great sadness the passing of Julian Clarence Levy Professor in the Humanities Emeritus, Columbia University, Quentin Anderson. His extraordinary spirit enriched many lives and he will be sorely missed by family, friends and colleagues. We extend our most heart felt condolences to his entire family, especially his beloved wife, Thelma, and Brom, Max, Jacqueline and Chase. Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Robert J. Hurst, President

title: Cordiant Seeks To Sell More Assets
description: The Cordiant Communications Group in London, the troubled agency company, said yesterday that it would seek to sell additional assets to reduce debt as it renegotiates its loan agreements with banks for a second time.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Slower Privatization
description: The government said that from March 3 to 5 it would sell only a fifth of the 500 million shares in Chunghwa, Taiwan's largest telecommunications company, that it had previously promised to sell. The government controls 82 percent of Chunghwa but will dispose of slightly more than 1 percent of the company in the sale in early March. The initial sale is to test the market, with a subsequent auction of at least 1 billion shares still planned, possibly by the end of March. The government said on Wednesday that it would sell part of its 71 percent stake in China Airlines, the island's flag carrier. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Car Dealer Dodges Brickbats For 'S.U.V. for Saddam' Pitch
description: Brad Benson has learned this much, at least: there are people who can take a Saddam Hussein joke, and there are people who just don't get it.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums, children under 12 and museum members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Frustrations for South American Oil
description: With crude prices edging toward $40 a barrel and a shortfall looming in world production, South America's two main oil producers, Petrobras of Brazil and the Spanish-owned Repsol YPF of Argentina, might be forgiven for spotting a silver lining among the clouds of war gathering over Iraq.

title: At ESPN.com, new technology comes with commercials.
description: NEW video delivery system on ESPN.com, the sports Web site, promises Internet users the most seamless integration of multimedia yet, playing highlight clips and interview excerpts that rival television in their quality.
