description: To the Editor:

title: In This Corner, the S.U.V.; There, a Corolla
description: To the Editor:

title: Kidd Sparks the Nets And Rattles the Pacers
description: Jason Kidd clenched his fist defiantly after his fast-break basket in the third quarter and unleashed a quick, curdled yell so his Nets teammates, the Indiana Pacers and the raucous crowd could hear him.

title: New Video Releases
description: One Hour Photo

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERES, DAVID
description: BERES-David, M.D. The Officers and Members of The New York Psychoanalytic Society and Institute express their sorrow at the death of their esteemed and beloved colleague. Dr. Beres was a highly respected clinician, teacher and was President of the Society from 1969-1971. Our deepest sympathy is extended to his family. Paul Rosenbaum, M.D., President/Institute Leon Kupferstein, M.D., President/Society Edward Nersessian, M.D., Chairman/ Educational Committee/Inst.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDENBERG, ANNE HOROWITZ
description: GOLDENBERG-Anne Horowitz. Died peacefully in Florida on February 20th, 2003. Beloved wife of 66 years of Arthur. Devoted mother of Robert and Jill (Berke), cherished grandmother of Danielle (Jack), Adam (Alyse), Edan and Kimberly, and great-grandmother of Noah and Jordan, and loved sister of Jerry. Donations to National Parkinson's Foundation. Services at Plaza Memorial, 91st and Amsterdam, Sunday, February 23, 11:30 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, JAMES EUGENE
description: WALSH-James Eugene (Big Jim). Suddenly on February 18, 2003. Loving husband of Catherine Patricia, devoted and adored father of Karen Byrnes (Tom), Laureen Paul (Jeff), John Walsh (Michele Pisani). Beloved ''Poppie'' of Jeffrey, Thomas, Jonathan, Katie Beth, Ryan, Kirsten and Lauchlan. Cherished son-inlaw of Beatrice Munnelly, dear brother-in-law of Patrick Munnelly, Mary Carmichael and Evelyn Hannigan. Devoted uncle of 15 nieces and nephews, 12 grandnieces and nephews. Predeceased by his parents Elizabeth (nee Kelly) and John J. Walsh, his sister Margaret (Joan) Moore. Citibank employee for past 43 years. We will miss our laid back Gentle Giant. Mass of the Resurrection Monday 10:30AM Church of the Immaculate Conception, N. Broadway, Irvington, NY. Visiting Friday, Saturday & Sunday 24 and 7-9PM EdwardsDowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue, (exit 17 Saw Mill), Dobbs Ferry, NY.

title: Los Angeles Is Called Example Of Competitors Not Competing
description: Given the size and affluence of Los Angeles, the presence of the biggest names in the telephone business, and the efforts of aggressive state regulators, the city would seem an ideal place for vibrant competition in telecommunications.

title: Free To Play And Be Gooey
description: THESE days, the closest we get to an American art star with reach beyond the art world is Matthew Barney, whose exhibition at the fiscally pinched Guggenheim, delayed a year, opens today. It is far and away the most anticipated show by anyone to have come onto the scene in a decade or more. It arrives via Cologne and Paris, where it was a hit especially among young fans, who get Mr. Barney instantly, and predictably mystified innumerable other people uninitiated into the Barney mythos. No doubt it will have a similar reception here.

title: Successful Road Trip Buoys Isles
description: The Islanders avoided the East Coast blizzard, heading out for a seven-day, four-game road trip before the first snowflakes fell in New York. But they faced a another kind of danger on their swing west.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Imports Cooling
description: The Philippines imported 20 percent more goods in December 2002 than December 2001, but the growth rate slowed from the torrid 47 percent increase reported in November. Imports are a leading indicator in the Philippines because much of the volume is made up of electronic and other components for assembly and re-export; the slowing trend raised doubts about the government's target for growth of 5.2 percent this year. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: INSIDE
description: Seven States to Sue E.P.A.

title: Racing Delay Gives New Zealand Time to Adjust to a New Tactician
description: For the first time in its America's Cup matchup against the Swiss team Alinghi, Team New Zealand left the dock and returned without a loss. Sure, racing was postponed Thursday, but when you are trailing the best sailors in the world, 3-0, in a five-of-nine-race series, you learn to be thankful for the little things.

title: Disagreement Emerges Over Foam on Shuttle Tank
description: Contrary to what NASA officials have said, the foam insulation on the space shuttle's external fuel tank is not waterproof and so can absorb moisture, especially if the dense outer layer of the foam is cut or removed, foam experts say.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: United Nations: New Action On African AIDS Crisis
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan announced that he would establish a high-level commission on AIDS and governance in Africa to help countries provide essential public services while stemming the spread of the disease across the continent. Addressing the opening session of the Africa-France summit meeting in Paris, Mr. Annan said that in addition to devastating agricultural production, AIDS has weakened the most vital and productive sectors of African civil society, ushering in ''a governance and development crisis of catastrophic dimensions.'' Daniel B. Schneider (NYT)

title: When Talk Is the Cure For the Morning After
description: The words have the brevity and resonance of an epitaph carved on a tombstone: ''I'm sorry. Hangover. Has me chatty.''

title: Reality TV Confession Leads to Real-Life Conviction
description: The gawking paralegals, prosecutors on their lunch breaks and assorted curiosity seekers came to court today to see a man whose notorious crimes had fueled a series of HBO specials, a true-crime paperback and a stream of relentlessly gruesome newspaper accounts.

title: Please, Just the Facts, Mr. Ridge
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, MORRIS R.
description: FRIEDMAN-Morris R. On February 14, 2003, of Brooklyn, Belle Harbor and Kingston, NY. Born January 4, 1912, Tarnow, Poland to Aaron and Manya, he escaped the chaos of W.W. I with his mother and sister Fay when Queen Wilhelmina of Holland provided passage to NY. Morris worked 55 years for Barclay Knitwear and reigned for 16 years as dean of trivia and poetry at the Council Center. Predeceased by his beloved wife of 53 years, Ethel, and daughter, Florence, he is survived by children, Robert, Richard and Deborah, and seven grandchildren. Service: February 28, 2:30 PM, Parkside Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn.

title: Three Heartbreaks and a Funeral: Knitting With Time
description: ''Lawless Heart,'' which opens today in Manhattan, begins with a funeral. The deceased, a restaurant owner named Stuart, drowned in a boating accident off the Isle of Man, where the film takes place. We see him only in old home movies and photographs, and we acquire, through the offhand recollections people who knew him, the barest sense of his life. His death -- not the event, but the fact and its aftermath -- is another matter, since we will return to the funeral twice before reluctantly taking leave of Stuart's baffled and careworn friends and relations.

title: Democratic Presidential Hopefuls Unite to Criticize Bush
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21  Democratic leaders from across the country gathered in Washington today to give themselves a pep talk, express their disdain for the policies of President Bush and shout their determination to win back the White House and both chambers of Congress next year.

title: Man's Death Of 'Bird Flu' In Hong Kong Raises Fears
description: Health officials announced here tonight that a 33-year-old man died at a local hospital on Monday of a potentially deadly strain of chicken-borne influenza, while the man's 9-year-old son is in a hospital isolation ward with what appears to be the same virus.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Mayor Loses A Race
description: Mayor Willie Brown of San Francisco suffered a rare political defeat when he lost a vote for president of the California Public Employees' Retirement System, the nation's largest pension fund. Mayor Brown, left, who has been in politics 40 years, lost to Sean Harrigan, a labor leader, in an 8-to-4 vote by the governing board of the system. The mayor must leave office in January because of term limits. A spokesman for Mr. Brown said the defeat was ''not the end of the world for him.'' Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Police Criticized On Child Arrests
description: The group Human Rights Watch criticized the Egyptian police in a report on Wednesday, saying that street children and truants were being arrested on the basis that they were ''vulnerable to delinquency,'' even if they had committed no crime. The report's author, Clarisa Bencomo, said many of those arrested, ostensibly for their own protection, were often held for longer than 24 hours and faced beatings or sexual abuse in detention centers by police officers or adult prisoners. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Nissan Settles Bias Suit by Minority Buyers
description: The finance unit of Nissan Motor has reached a tentative settlement with black and Hispanic car buyers who said that the company discriminated against minority customers by charging them higher interest rates.

title: Effort to Fix Responsibility for Deadly Korean Subway Fire
description: TAEGU, South Korea, Feb. 21  A tragedy of errors was responsible for most of the 130 deaths in the subway fire here on Tuesday, investigators said today. The police are considering criminal charges of negligence.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Rabbi Arrested Over Internet Exchange
description: A New Jersey rabbi was arrested yesterday after arranging to meet a person he met on the Internet whom he thought was a 13-year-old girl, the police said. In reality, the Police Department's Computer Investigation and Technology Unit was monitoring his sexually explicit exchanges, and the ''girl'' he arranged to meet at a Starbucks was an investigator, the police said. The rabbi, Israel Kestenbaum, 54, of Highland Park, N.J., was taken yesterday to the 17th Precinct station house on East 51st Street for questioning, where he was arrested and charged with attempted endangerment of a child and attempted dissemination of indecent material to a minor, according to Detective Kevin Czartoryski. The rabbi could not be reached for comment last night.

title: A Former Wrestler Takes On Issues of the Disabled
description: LATE in the afternoon, Matthew P. Sapolin sat at his computer in an office at 100 Gold Street. He is the executive director of the Mayor's Office for People With Disabilities, and he is blind. His golden retriever, Compass, was at his side in the dark, windowless room, where one would be hard pressed to comfortably accommodate a constituent in a wheelchair.

title: LOCAL PHONE RULES TO STAY IN PLACE
description: A deeply divided Federal Communications Commission today largely left in place rules that are meant to foster local telephone competition by requiring the four regional Bell companies to lease their local networks to their rivals at low prices set by state regulators.

title: Highlands Area Needs More Protection, Study Says
description: About 40 percent of the New York-New Jersey Highlands, a swath of the Appalachians, is worthy of protection from overdevelopment, according to a study released today by the United States Forest Service. But less than half of the area, which encompasses 1.5 million acres from the Delaware River on the west side of New Jersey to the New York-Connecticut border in northern Westchester County, is now under such protection, the federal study found.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Starbucks Plans to Offer Its Own Credit Card in Fall
description: Starbucks customers will soon be able to pick up revolving credit lines with their double tall mocha lattes.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Diageo Posts A Loss
description: The world's largest liquor company, Diageo P.L.C., posted a net loss in its fiscal first half, hurt by the sale of its Burger King unit, but said it expected improvement in the second half. The company said it lost 459 million ($733 million) in the first half, ended Dec. 31. It earned $810 million a year earlier. Results for the most recent quarter included a loss of 1.4 billion ($2.2 billion) related to its sale of Burger King. Excluding one-time items, the company's profit rose 6 percent.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the announcement by Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri that he would seek the Democratic nomination for president in 2004 misstated the number of state primaries and caucuses he won in 1988. It was three -- Iowa, South Dakota and Missouri -- not two. The article also misstated his finish in the Michigan caucuses that year. It was third; first place was won by the Rev. Jesse Jackson, and Mr. Gephardt's showing of 12.8 percent prompted him to drop out shortly afterward.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Garden City: Accused Psychiatrist Held On $2.5 Million Bond
description: A Long Island psychiatrist arrested last month after the authorities said he had plotted to kill as many as six people was indicted yesterday on a charge of conspiracy to commit murder. The psychiatrist, Richard J. Karpf, 50, left, was initially charged with weapons possession and ordered held without bail. Yesterday, after a grand jury indictment was unsealed, Judge Donald E. Belfi of Nassau County Court set bail at $2.5 million cash or bond. Dr. Karpf's lawyer, Stephen P. Scaring, called the bail ''excessive,'' saying Dr. Karpf never planned to kill anyone. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the country singer Johnny Paycheck yesterday credited him with one distinction erroneously in some copies. He was not inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Teenager Sentenced In School Shootings
description: Vincent Rodriguez, 19, was sentenced yesterday to 10 years in prison for wounding two fellow students at Martin Luther King Jr. High School on the Upper West Side last year. Mr. Rodriguez pleaded guilty on Jan. 27 to assault and attempted assault, prosecutors said. Mr. Rodriguez admitted that he had taken a gun into the school, hid it in his locker, and later used it to shoot the two students, Andre Wilkins and Andrel Napper. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Turkey Assesses Question Of Kurds
description: As Turkish and American diplomats struggled this week to strike a deal on the use of American troops in northern Iraq, one of the most intractable hurdles for negotiators has proven to be Turkey's bitter history with the Kurds.

title: Governing Body Expands Drug Tests
description: The International Tennis Federation signed an agreement yesterday to have expanded out-of-competition drug testing performed by the World Anti-Doping Agency, which handles testing for most Olympic sports.

title: A Hunger for Frito Pie, From the Artery-Clogged Heart of Texas
description: NOT too long ago, I was seized by a craving.

title: St. John's Remains In Transition
description: After making just 9 of a Big East record 41 3-point attempts in a 66-60 loss to Syracuse on Wednesday night, St. John's (12-10, 5-7 Big East) stumbles into tomorrow's game at Connecticut (16-6, 7-4) with cloudy personnel matters.

title: Donald Moffett -- 'The Extravagant Vein'
description: Marianne Boesky Gallery

title: Pop and Jazz Listings
description: Aselective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: High-Speed Service May Cost More
description: Of the roughly 20 million users of high-speed Internet service, only a few hundred thousand customers are likely to have their rates increased as a direct result of yesterday's ruling by the Federal Communications Commission. But some executives argue that eliminating this form of price competition will lead to increased overall prices for the service, also known as broadband.

title: A Jumble of Categories For Screenwriter Awards
description: Controversies come in many colors at the Academy Awards, but rarely have they emerged in such shades of gray as govern this year's screenwriting categories.

title: Benyoussef Ben Khedda, 82, Algerian Leader
description: Benyoussef Ben Khedda, an Algerian nationalist leader who announced his country's negotiated independence from France on July 3, 1962, but was quickly swept from power by the revolutionary forces he had helped unleash, died on Feb. 4 at his home in Algiers. He was 82.

title: An Ethical Dilemma With Few Precedents
description: With the nation facing a dire shortage of human organs, the case of Jsica Santilln renews long-simmering questions in medical ethics: Should surgeons perform second transplants on patients like Ms. Santilln, whose chances of survival are diminished because they have rejected their first organs? Or should others on the waiting list come first?

title: The Drifts Piled Up, and Nobody Sneered at Four-Wheel Drive
description: REHABILITATING the reputations of the drivers of sport utility vehicles was not what hospitals in Washington and other East Coast cities had in mind this week when they sent out a plea to owners of four-wheel-drive behemoths. They just wanted the S.U.V. drivers to transport doctors, nurses and patients through streets knee-deep in snow.

title: Never Too Late to Have an Adolescence
description: Can you sue yourself for plagiarism? If so, then ''Old School'' has presented Ivan Reitman with a case. This sloppy, dumb, though occasionally funny comedy is so derivative of ''Animal House'' (and, more specifically, its children) that it's like one of those by-the-numbers imitative movies Homer Simpson is so obsessed with.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUTHAMER, BARBARA
description: KRAUTHAMER - Barbara. On February 18, 2003. Loving sister of Elissa. Cherished and adored aunt of Jonathan, Sarah, Benjamin and Anne. Great-aunt of Julia, Mariah, Sophia and Elvis. Beloved companion of Jon Huntington. Remembered always for her grace and warmth, and admired for her artistic achievement. She will be deeply missed by her many dear friends. Service Friday 11:30 AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. There will be a memorial held at Westbeth, 55 Bethune St. in the courtyard, 7 P.M., Saturday, February 22, 2003.

title: SPORTS AUTHORITY AND GART SPORTS AGREE TO MERGE
description: Sports Authority, the largest sporting goods retailer in the nation, said yesterday that it had agreed to merge with a rival, Gart Sports, in a transaction valued at $182.6 million. Sports Authority shareholders will receive 0.37 share of Gart Sports for each Sports Authority share. Shares in the new company, to be known as Sports Authority, will be about equally divided between holders of the two companies' shares. The new company will have 385 stores in 45 states. Sports Authority operates 205 stores in 33 states, most in the East. Gart Sports is the largest sports apparel and equipment retailer in the West, with 180 stores in the Sportmart, Oshman's and Gart Sports chains.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: CIENA LOSS WIDENS ON COSTS TO RETIRE DEBT The Ciena Corporation, the No. 4 American maker of fiber optic network equipment, posted a sixth consecutive quarterly net loss yesterday because of slumping sales and costs to retire debt. The loss in the first quarter, which ended on Jan. 31, widened to $107.1 million, or 25 cents a share, from $70.6 million, or 22 cents, a year earlier. Sales slid by more than half, to $70.5 million from $162.2 million, Ciena said. The company has has pared expenses, and cut 450 jobs in September, to cope with falling demand from telecommunications companies for equipment. Still, Ciena's revenue exceeded the company's December forecast. Ciena said sales in this quarter would be little changed to up slightly from the preceding three months. Ciena expects a second-quarter loss of 11 cents to 13 cents, the chief financial officer, Joseph R. Chinnici, said. In the period a year earlier, Ciena reported a net loss of $1.86 a share. Ciena shares fell 11 cents, or 2 percent, to $5.41. First-quarter results included $20.6 million in costs to retire debt from ONI Systems, a rival that Ciena acquired in June.  (Bloomberg News)

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: PROFIT AT OIL CONCERN The French oil company TotalFinaElf said its fourth-quarter profit more than doubled, helped by an increase in production and higher prices. Excluding one-time items, however, its income fell short of market expectations, hurt by a charge of 310 million euros ($333 million) to write down the value of assets in Argentina. Sales in the period rose to 26.9 billion euros ($28.9 billion) from 23.7 billion euros ($25.5 billion). The company's chairman, Thierry Desmarest, said TotalFinaElf was determined to compete in Iraq after a possible war there, despite France's opposition to military action. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: General Asks Air Force to Build Trust at Academy
description: With more women emerging to say they were raped or sexually assaulted at the Air Force Academy, the commandant of cadets conceded today that a survey last month showed that a fifth of cadets, and a much higher proportion of those who are women, lacked confidence in academy programs to help victims of sexual attacks.

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: NEXTEL REPORTS 4TH-QUARTER PROFIT Nextel Communications posted a quarterly profit yesterday and provided an upbeat forecast for 2003, in part because ofo its walkie-talkie-like service. Bucking a slowdown in the industry, Nextel posted a profit for the third straight quarter because of the popularity of its Direct Connect feature. The service, similar to a walkie-talkie, is used by technicians, construction crews and public safety officials. The company said that it expected its business to be helped this year by continued strong demand from the government and public safety sector, as well as its new nationwide Direct Connect service, which is expected in the third quarter. For the fourth quarter, Nextel reported net income of $1.46 billion, or $1.38 a diluted share, in contrast to a loss of $1.80 billion, or $2.25 a diluted share, a year ago. Excluding gains related to the retirement of debt and preferred stock and a gain on the divestiture of an international unit, NII Holdings, fourth-quarter net income was $209 million, or 21 cents a share. In the fourth quarter a year ago, Nextel posted a loss of 24 cents a share, excluding losses from NII. Shares rose 5 cents, to $13.53.  (Reuters)

title: Please, Just the Facts, Mr. Ridge
description: To the Editor:

title: Less Is More: Unlike Last Year, Mets Are in Shape
description: The roll call could have gone through the Mets' clubhouse at various times last season. Ask who was out of shape, and a number of hands could have been raised. Mo Vaughn received the most notoriety, and his arrival in camp Tuesday was greeted with the anticipation given a celebrity leaving a weight-loss clinic.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOATE, ELSIE K.
description: SLOATE-Elsie K., 96, a model mother, friend and philanthropist, she passed peacefully on February 18. She was there for me throughout my life, particularly when I needed her most. A woman of boundless generosity to her family and far-reaching circle of friends. She left an indelible mark on those she touched with her gifts of spirit and kindness. She was a great philanthropist and a major force behind the Fight for Sight League of Manhattan for more than 35 years. My mother was blessed with a great life and I know that I will live my life in her spirit. In lieu of flowers a research fund has been established in her honor, The Elsie K. Sloate Fellowship Fund, New York Presbyterian Hospital. Your loving daugher, Laura

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Airline Profits Up
description: Qantas Airways reported a profit of 352.5 million Australian dollars ($209.5 million) in the six months ended Dec. 31, more than double the figure from the period in 2001, mainly because of strong international traffic. But it warned that it might have to reduce service soon as anxiety over possible war in Iraq depresses passenger loads. The warning prompted a 12 percent decline in the price of Qantas stock. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: A Past Vision Of Future Life
description: ''To the new Tower of Babel!'' cries the wild-eyed young Freder Fredersen to the cab driver in ''Metropolis,'' released this week on DVD by Kino. And step on it. It's 2026 in Fritz Lang's 1927 classic, beautifully restored and accompanied by a documentary with some comments by the dapper Lang himself, complete with monocle (and later with monocle and a patch for the other eye).

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the space shuttle's efforts to right itself in its final moments misspelled the surname of a NASA spokesman who said investigators had been searching for clues in the ''mostly ragged, mostly unintelligible data'' from the 32 seconds after mission control lost radio contact. He is Rob Navias, not Navius.

title: Sprewell Is a Knick as Deadline Passes
description: Twenty minutes after the Knicks' loss to Seattle on Wednesday night, Latrell Sprewell was not in the locker room. While his teammates showered, dressed and spoke with reporters, Sprewell sat on the team bus, waiting patiently to leave Key Arena. It was an odd move for Sprewell, who usually answers reporters' questions thoughtfully and amiably after every game.

title: De La Hoya and Mosley Talk
description: Oscar De La Hoya and Shane Mosley have not yet agreed to fight again, but De La Hoya offered today to give Mosley $500,000 out of his own guarantee if they fight and Mosley beats him.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Soldier Kills 4 Comrades, Then Himself
description: A private in Russia's Strategic Missile Forces opened fire in a guardroom of his unit's fuel depot in the Siberian region of Krasnoyarsk, killed four fellow servicemen, and then killed himself, the Interfax news agency reported. Col. Gen. Nikolai Solovtsov, commander of the missile forces, has reportedly flown to Krasnoyarsk to investigate. No motive has been given, but such incidents are becoming frequent in the Russian military, although they are rare in the missile forces. Brutal hazing by superiors has usually been the cause. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Searching for Walleye, A Winter's Tale
description: CRAIG WECKWERTH and Keith Kelley didn't care that they were flirting with danger in their Ahab-like pursuit of the regally regarded walleye, Minnesota's official fish. In mid-January, after weeks in which the temperature had dipped just barely below freezing (a relative heat wave for Minnesota), the full force of winter had finally struck Lake Mille Lacs, bringing with it the much anticipated whiteouts and below-zero wind chills. At last, Mr. Weckwerth, 42, and Mr. Kelley, 39, friends and fishing companions since high school, could stop daydreaming of swirling windblown drifts the size of sasquatch and a landscape that looked like a sunless, otherworldly vision of post-apocalyptic doom. It was now time to head out onto the lake.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHORR, DAVID
description: SHORR-David. 2/21/18-6/19/92 Wish you were here. Love, the Family

title: Immersed In Buddhism
description: ''Montien Boonma: Temple of the Mind'' at the Asia Society in Manhattan is a retrospective of the Thai contemporary artist, whose work was rooted in Buddhism. Left, a 1982 self-portrait.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Utility Posts Profit
description: The Korea Electric Power Corporation said its fourth-quarter profit tripled, to 459 billion won ($386 million), helped by the sale of its interest in Powercomm, a high-speed data cable network, to Dacom. The strength of South Korea's currency also helped the company's results by reducing fuel costs and debt payments, analysts said. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Explosion Sparks Massive Fire at Refinery on Staten Island

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: National Semiconductor Will Lay Off 500
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation, which makes chips for computers and cellphones, plans to lay off 500 workers, or 5 percent of its staff, and sell some slower-growing businesses. The company will sell the unit that makes its Geode chip for television set-top boxes and hand-held computers, and a business that develops technology for cellphone networks, a spokesman, Jeff Weir, said. National Semiconductor, which has about 10,000 workers, said the units being sold accounted for about 5 percent of its sales. The company, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., will focus its research and development on analog chips that improve the sound quality in cellphones and make their batteries last longer, Mr. Weir said. National Semiconductor shares rose 97 cents, or 6.8 percent, to $15.35. They had fallen 46 percent in the last 12 months. The Goldman Sachs Group has been hired to help sell the units.

title: 36 Hours | Lenox, Mass.
description: UNDER a storybook blanket of snow, Lenox, Mass., may look like just another well-groomed New England town. In fact, this hamlet in the southern Berkshires is a retreat where world-weary types seek sustenance for body and soul. Home to the Canyon Ranch and the Kripalu Center for Yoga and Health, it is also summer headquarters for the Boston Symphony Orchestra, which performs at Tanglewood. The Gilded Age equivalent of the Hamptons, Lenox offers sweeping vistas and mild summer weather that, in the 19th century, brought Vanderbilts, Carnegies and Westinghouses to the Housatonic River valley to build showy villas that they called Berkshire cottages. Along with the Mount, above, Edith Wharton's magnificent house, many of those enormous houses are still standing -- some as inns, others as private homes. A hundred and fifty years after this mill and farming village was discovered by swells, it is a town with an air of luxe, calm and voluptuous pleasure. But since this is New England, there is an athletic twist: summer brings hiking, biking and riding; winter is about skating, skiing and snowshoeing. (When it comes to clothing, it's Harvard Square all the way; if it looks good in Park City, Utah, don't pack it.) MICHELLE GREEN

title: Why Albany Doesn't Mend the Courts

And it would stop the arcane overlapping that, as one example, can bring a single troubled family into as many as three separate courts. (One covers any domestic violence, a second child custody issues, and a third would deal with a divorce.)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Bellsouth Case Moves To Georgia Supreme Court
description: The BellSouth Corporation's fight to prevent its vice chairman, Gary D. Forsee, from becoming chief executive of the Sprint Corporation was sent yesterday to Georgia's Supreme Court. The state's Court of Appeals requested that the case be transferred, saying the high court should determine whether a lower-court judge had the authority to throw out one of BellSouth's major arguments. BellSouth, the largest local-telephone company in the Southeast, appealed the dismissal earlier this week. At issue is a Feb. 10 ruling by Judge Stephanie B. Manis of Fulton County Superior Court, who said a noncompete clause in Mr. Forsee's contract that bars him from joining a competitor within 18 months is unenforceable. BellSouth's remaining claim -- that Mr. Forsee might share trade secrets if he joined Sprint -- should be decided in arbitration, Judge Manis ruled. The judge also extended for 30 days a restraining order that prevents Mr. Forsee from joining Sprint, which wants to replace William T. Esrey as chief executive because of his use of tax shelters.

A high-level inquiry has begun, and officials said they had not ruled out the possibility of sabotage. In 1988, Pakistan's military ruler, Gen. Until the end, when it begins to go soft, the movie takes two strands of soap opera convention -- a life-changing accident and an adulterous affair -- and spins their suds into gold.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Huge Shipment Of Khat Is Seized At Airport
description: Customs officers at Dublin Airport seized two consignments of the natural amphetamine khat, each weighing at least 1,100 pounds, in freight packages en route from London to New York. The police made no arrests and said the total value of the shipments was $2.7 million. Khat leaves are legal in Britain, but Ireland banned them in 1990, and they have been found there on just a handful of occasions. It is commonly used in the Middle East and northeastern Africa, where people chew the leaves for a stimulant effect. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Shopping List | Taming Car Clutter
description: ON a cross-country road trip you don't have to live like a college student. First, clean out car clutter. No more crumpled-up newspapers, fast-food wrappers and empty soda cans littering the floor. No more fishing for change or pens in a console jammed with single mittens, scratched CD's and melted M&M's. No more hunting for maps in a glove compartment crammed with gasoline receipts and drive-through A.T.M. records. With just six items costing less than $150 total, you can put trash in its place, keep what you need handy, and make the most of the precious space in your car. NANCY M. BETTER

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Church Seeks Moratorium In Abuse Suits
description: The Archdiocese of Boston and lawyers for several hundred plaintiffs in sexual abuse lawsuits accusing priests have asked a judge to approve a 90-day moratorium on activity in those lawsuits in an effort to give the two sides time to settle the cases. If approved, the moratorium would mean a temporary halt to depositions, discovery and other activity while lawyers meet with mediators. One lawyer, Mitchell Garabedian, who represents 108 plaintiffs, did not join the effort, saying he was preparing to go to trial. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Profit At Oil Concern
description: The French oil company TotalFinaElf said its fourth-quarter profit more than doubled, helped by an increase in production and higher prices. Excluding one-time items, however, its income fell short of market expectations, hurt by a charge of 310 million euros ($333 million) to write down the value of assets in Argentina. Sales in the period rose to 26.9 billion euros ($28.9 billion) from 23.7 billion euros ($25.5 billion). The company's chairman, Thierry Desmarest, said TotalFinaElf was determined to compete in Iraq after a possible war there, despite France's opposition to military action. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

description: CANTOR-Irene. A Golden Founder of the Shaare Zedek Medical Center and supporter of its Concert and Journal drives together with her late husband, Alexander. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem

title: Immersed in Buddhism and Its Meditation on Paradoxes
description: I can't shake an image from a short film about the Thai artist Montien Boonma (1953-2000), which introduces his haunting exhibition at the Asia Society. In most of the film we see him at work or in conversation, smiling, maybe even relaxed in his alert, springy way. But in one interview he is not working or smiling or relaxed.

description: Along the Hudson River in Paulus Hook, one of this city's oldest neighborhoods, a new enclave of high-rise apartments and office buildings is taking shape where a soap and toothpaste factory once stood.

description: A Manhattan businesswoman who had been charged with stealing money from agencies after the Sept. 11 terrorist attack was indicted for a second time yesterday on new charges of using her business to falsely obtain emergency funds.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Auto Insurer Swamped By Customers
description: New Jersey's largest auto insurance company wants to stop preparing rate estimates for some policies while it clears a two-month backlog of applicants. The company, New Jersey Re-Insurance, has so many new customers that callers wait half an hour to speak to a telephone representative, the company said. Its customer base grew by more than a third last year. New Jersey Re-Insurance's request was outlined in a letter Wednesday to the state insurance commissioner, Holly C. Bakke. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 10 about Gilbert E. Kaplan, a businessman whose avocation is conducting Mahler's Second Symphony with a variety of orchestras, missated the names of two with which he has worked. They are the London Symphony (not the London Philharmonic) and the Los Angeles Philharmonic (there is no Los Angeles Symphony).

title: When Corruption Comes In a Law-and-Order Guise
description: In real life, young police officers encounter all kinds of risks, but in the movies the greatest danger they face tends to come from older police officers, in particular those who serve as their partners, protectors and mentors. This is especially true if the veterans are part of an elite, special unit, elite and special being cop-movie synonyms for corrupt and vicious. Think, for example, of poor Ethan Hawke in ''Training Day,'' being menaced by the murderous caprices of Denzel Washington's garrulous, sociopathic senior detective.

description: MILLER-Robert G., M.D. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family is saddened by the untimely passing of our friend and colleague, a dedicated and respected family practitioner who was beloved by the hospital staff and his patients. We extend our deepest sympathy to the Miller family, particularly his wife Susan and their children. Morton P. title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the announcement by Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri that he would seek the Democratic nomination for president in 2004 misstated the number of state primaries and caucuses he won in 1988. It was three  Iowa, South Dakota and Missouri  not two. The article also misstated his finish in the Michigan caucuses that year. It was third; first place was won by the Rev. Jesse Jackson, and Mr. Gephardt's showing of 12.8 percent prompted him to drop out shortly afterward.

title: Telekom Malaysia Pushes for the Fast Lane
description: With Malaysia's prime minister, Mahathir Mohamad, looking on, Telekom Malaysia opened its new headquarters building in Kuala Lumpur last week. The curvilinear $150 million building is meant to resemble a fast-growing bamboo shoot, emblematic of the company's desire to transform itself from a lumbering former monopoly into a speeding juggernaut.

title: Inside the Music: A Cellist's Perspective
description: CARTER BREY could be having a major solo career. He used to have just that, appearing with virtually every leading orchestra in the United States, becoming the first musician to win the Arts Council of America's Performing Arts Prize and earning international attention as a prizewinner in the Rostropovich International Cello Competition.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday with an article about the influence of Ted Turner at AOL Time Warner misstated the new role of his ally Philip I. Kent. Mr. Kent is succeeding Jamie Kellner as chairman and chief executive of Turner Broadcasting System -- not succeeding Mr. Turner as vice chairman of AOL Time Warner.

title: Market-Driven Survey Through the 20th Century
description: The Art Show at the Seventh Regiment Armory, one of the best of the many New York art fairs filling the season, usually takes place concurrently with the Armory Show, the annual contemporary-art extravaganza on the Hudson River piers. But this year the Armory Show's organizers met scheduling conflicts, so the 15th annual Art Show has this weekend all to itself. That is unfortunate for people from out of town but good for locals, who won't have to exhaust themselves trying to take in two such richly populated exhibitions in one fell swoop.

title: Baseball Doctors Nearly Took a Stand, but Didn't
description: Two months ago, at baseball's annual off-season meetings, team doctors expressed misgivings over the sport's new labor agreement because the list of substances subject to drug testing did not include many amphetamines and dietary aids.

title: Arab Bloc Calls Meeting in Cairo
description: The Arab League announced today that leaders of its member nations would meet here March 1 in an effort to forge a united position on President Bush's threats to attack Iraq.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Priest Robbed At Church
description: A priest was robbed at gunpoint yesterday in the rectory of St. Teresa of Avila Roman Catholic Church in Prospect Heights, the police said. About 11 a.m., a man who seemed to be in his 20's knocked on the door of the rectory, at 563 Sterling Place, and insisted on talking to a priest, the police said. The priest asked the man to come back later. When the man returned, he had a companion and a handgun, Detective Kevin Czartoryski said. The man, who was allowed inside while his companion waited outside, pulled a gun on the Rev. Thomas Ahern, robbing him of $160 from the church's petty cash box before escaping. The priest was not hurt, the police said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Brooklyn Council Candidates Find a Common Foe: the Property Tax Increase
description: In civic meetings in the Bay Ridge and Bensonhurst sections of Brooklyn, one topic seems sure to ratchet up community fury: the 18.5 percent increase in the property tax enacted by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the City Council.

title: BARNES & NOBLE SALES WERE MOSTLY DOWN IN QUARTER
description: Barnes & Noble, the world's largest bookseller, said yesterday that fourth-quarter sales at its large bookstores open at least a year fell 3 percent. Same-store sales at its smaller B. Dalton chain fell 11 percent in the quarter, which ended Feb. 1, the company said. Total fourth-quarter sales at the large stores rose 4 percent, to $1.2 billion, as the company increased the number of its stores to 628 from 591 a year earlier, Barnes & Noble said. Sales at B. Dalton declined 21 percent, to $88.9 million, as the company closed 47 stores. Barnes & Noble plans to report fourth-quarter results on March 20.

title: Removal Pro in a City of Snow; Blanket Over Buffalo Keeps Cleanup Boss on His Toes
description: As always, Paul V. Sullivan emerged from his warm bed at 3:30 a.m., moving instinctively toward the bedroom window. He had gone to sleep thinking Buffalo would get, at most, three inches of snow overnight.

title: The Death Row Syndrome
description: Kevin Spacey now seems determined to make the move from jaunty, caustic leading man to martyr: he sacrificed himself for the betterment of mankind, though not necessarily the moviegoing public, in ''K-Pax'' and ''Pay It Forward.'' And now, in the would-be thriller ''The Life of David Gale,'' he plays a death-penalty opponent facing execution for murder. The film's ironies must have made him delirious.

title: Jack Brodsky, 69, a Movie Producer And a Publicist Close to 'Cleopatra'
description: Jack Brodsky, who combined a career as a marketing and publicity executive at a half-dozen movie studios with a second career as a movie producer, died on Tuesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 69.

title: Troubled Sotheby's Pulls Itself Off the Auction Block
description: Sotheby's Holdings Inc. , the venerable auction house that has struggled through a bid-rigging scandal, sagging profits and the incarceration of its former chairman, A. Alfred Taubman, said today that it was no longer exploring a sale of the company or the Taubman family's controlling stake in it.

title: Reclaiming Wintry Parks of Childhood
description: The photo captions, in Dad's handwriting, say Riverside Park. I'm on a sled, squinting in the sunny foreground, and even from the black-and-white I recall my green snowsuit with its red-lined hood. Behind me are young trees, smooth benches, fresh-looking apartment houses. Clean snow, deep chunks of it all over, and a baby carriage stuck on an angle. New Jersey is a slope of virgin forest across the sparkling river.

title: Spain Shuts a Basque Newspaper, Accusing It of Aiding Separatists
description: The Spanish police ordered a Basque-language newspaper to shut down today and arrested 10 members of its staff, including the editor, accusing them of helping the violent separatist group E.T.A. in its campaign for an independent Basque country.

title: Blair Repeats Call for Iraq to Be Disarmed
description: ROME, Feb. 21  British Prime Minister Tony Blair said today that he was eager to avoid war in Iraq and determined to try to work through the United Nations, but that his belief in the need for Iraq to be disarmed  by force, if necessary  was firm.

description: A British defense worker was shot and killed today in Saudi Arabia's capital, Riyadh, in the latest of a series of attacks on Britons, Americans and other Westerners in Saudi Arabia and other Arab countries.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Man Waives Extradition In 1957 Killings
description: A retired South Carolina businessman accused of killing two Los Angeles-area police officers 45 years ago has agreed to go to California to face charges. The man, Gerald F. Mason, 69, of Columbia, S.C., will not fight extradition if he is allowed to stay in South Carolina until March 6, prosecutors said. Mr. Mason, left, is accused in the killings of the El Segundo officers, Milton G. Curtis and Richard A. Phillips, and in the assault of two teenage couples and the rape one girl, all on July 22, 1957. He was arrested last month after a new F.B.I. database helped match his fingerprints with those on the teenagers' car. John M. Broder (NYT)

title: Giants Cut Punter And 3 Others
description: The Giants cut punter Matt Allen, who served as the holder on their failed field-goal attempt at the end of their playoff game against San Francisco on Jan. 5. The team also released linebacker Clayton White, fullback Adam Wright and the veteran wide receiver Herman Moore, after Moore had drawn interest from another team.

title: Iraq Is Strategic Issue for Oil Giants, Too
description: Even though Iraq has the world's second-largest oil reserves, after Saudi Arabia, oil companies do not expect to reap the benefits quickly if Saddam Hussein is ousted.

title: Were Trojans Proto-Americans?
description: Virgil promises to sing of ''arms and the man'' as he opens ''The Aeneid,'' though arms can sometimes seem to overshadow the man. Aeneas and the exiled survivors of Troy must make their way to Italy where they will create a mighty empire, one that ''will know no end.'' But however assured Aeneas' destiny, the path is strewn with mangled corpses, split heads and fractured shields.

title: Cases of New Bird Flu in Hong Kong Prompt Worldwide Alerts
description: The World Health Organization said today that it had alerted health officials around the world to increase somewhat their preparedness in response to two human cases of an apparently new strain of bird flu that surfaced here this week.

title: Puccini Neat (Unmiked)
description: Since Baz Luhrmann's ''Bohme'' opened on Broadway last December, people have been asking about the difference between seeing the piece in an opera house and in a Broadway theater. It was something to ponder on Wednesday night, when the Metropolitan Opera revived Franco Zeffirelli's 1981 production for the first time this season.

title: At Columbia, Journalists and the Faculty Rewrite a Journalism Curriculum
description: Lee C. Bollinger's aim was keen and his angle well considered. As one of his first acts as president of Columbia University, he declared the curriculum at the heart of the Graduate School of Journalism ''insufficient.'' At the same time, he refused to select either of two finalists for the school's vacant deanship.

title: Grave Diagnosis After 2nd Transplant
description: A day after doctors performed a desperate second heart and lung transplant on a teenage girl, they announced she had permanent brain damage and little chance to live.

title: The Telephone Wars
description: It is rare for the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission to be outvoted on a major policy issue, but that is what happened on Thursday to Michael Powell in a showdown with Kevin Martin, a fellow Republican, and two Democratic commissioners.

title: Boeing Satellite Unit Changes Leadership
description: Boeing said today that Randy Brinkley had resigned as president of the satellite unit, which had just one commercial order last year and had higher costs because of product defects.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: THE NETHERLANDS: BANK'S PROFIT SLIPS The Dutch financial services and banking concern ING said its fourth-quarter profit fell 2.7 percent from the period a year earlier, to 922 million euros ($998 million) because of an increase in the money it set aside for bad loans. For the year, ING's profit fell 1.7 percent, to 4.5 billion euros, in part because of 510 million euros it set aside in the fourth quarter to make up for bond losses at a subsidiary of National Century Financial Services in the United States. The company declined to make a forecast for the current year; its chairman, Ewald Kist, above, said he was concerned about the growing dispute between the United States and some European countries over Iraq. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  URQUHART, NORMAN R.
description: URQUHART-Norman R. Of Pearl River, N.Y. on February 21, 2003. Survived by his wife Dorothy Urquhart, five daughters Rhea Fletcher, Amy Urquhart, Heidi Besold, Julia Cescot and Vera Schofer; two sons Norman Urquhart and Angus Urquhart and 11 grandchildren. Mr. Urquhart was an agricultural and commodity economist for Citibank. He was also an Economist for the Chicago Federal Reserve Bank and the U.S. Department of Agriculture. Funeral service will be 10:30AM Monday at the Good Shepherd Church, Pearl River, N.Y. Burial will be at St. Paul's Cemetery, Nanuet, N.Y. Visitation will be Sunday 3-5 and 7-9PM at the WymanFisher Funeral Home, Inc. Donations may be made to the Good Shepherd Lutheran Church in Pearl River, N.Y. or the Pearl River Ambulance Corp.

title: Taubman Centers Responds To Accusations by Simon
description: Taubman Centers, the shopping mall empire founded by A. Alfred Taubman, responded yesterday to its hostile suitor, Simon Property Group, and accused it of filing misleading documents in court.

title: With Luster Faded, Tyson Places Career On the Line Tonight
description: There is a benchmark in Mike Tyson's career that stands out as much as his mischievous smile. It came on Nov. 9, 1996, in Las Vegas. Evander Holyfield dared to stand within snarling range of Tyson, the fiercest heavyweight in the world, to trade blows.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-5

title: Gentex to Build New Auto Mirror Plant
description: The Gentex Corporation, the world's largest maker of automatically dimming mirrors for cars and light trucks, plans to build a factory for $97 million that will create 625 jobs, a spokeswoman said today.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: GURKHAS LOSE PAY-DISCRIMINATION LAWSUIT A British court rejected assertions that the British Army unlawfully denied equal pay and conditions to Gurkha soldiers recruited in Nepal. Cherie Booth, a leading employment rights lawyer and the wife of Prime Minister Tony Blair, argued that the Gurkhas had suffered from institutionalized discrimination because they received lower pay and pensions than other soldiers in the British Army. But the court said the differences in working conditions were legal in light of the divergent economies of Britain and Nepal, one of the world's poorest countries.    Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Coping with terrorism : In Thailand, parents wonder just what to tell their children
description: BANGKOK:  One August night in 2001, the nine-year-old son of Sharon Cox Bhasavanich asked his mother as she tucked him into bed in their Bangkok home if "planes flying in the sky could hurt us?"

title: Religion Journal; Churches Try to Protect Hawaii's Native Tongue
description: On a bright, tropical Sunday, the pews at Kawaiahao Church are filled with the faithful: locals in suits or flowered muumuus, tourists in shorts, conspicuous with their name tags and camera bags.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Economy Stalls
description: France's economy, Europe's third largest, stagnated in the fourth quarter as companies cut investment and the euro's 25 percent gain against the dollar in the last year reduced exports. Gross domestic product rose 0.2 percent from the previous three months, the least since the final quarter of 2001 when the economy shrank, the government said. The pace of expansion in the third quarter was revised to 0.3 percent from 0.2 percent.

title: Trembling, Asleep and Awake, As Nightmares Become Reality
description: Wendy Osserman Dance Company

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: ThyssenKrupp Downgraded
description: The rating agency Standard & Poor's downgraded the debt of the industrial conglomerate ThyssenKrupp to junk status. The downgrade came earlier than the market had expected and ThyssenKrupp called it ''incomprehensible,'' saying that its financial situation has improved since S.& P. gave it a rating one level higher in the summer of 2001.

title: Officials Say Case Against Professor Had Been Hindered
description: Senior law enforcement officials have suspected for years that Sami Al-Arian, the Florida professor indicted this week on charges of supporting terrorism, posed a serious national security risk, but they were slow to take action against him because of legal, political and operational roadblocks, officials said today.

title: Heavy Rain and Melting Snow May Cause Floods in Region
description: Forget last year's drought. Now, local governments across the region are hurrying to prepare for having too much water from heavy rains and snow melt this weekend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAKER, J. STEWART JR.
description: BAKER - J. Stewart Jr. Passed away on February 20 after a long illness. Mr. Baker was born in Short Hills, NJ and attended The Hill School and Princeton. During WWII, he was a Lieutenant in the Army Air Corps, serving as a pilot forward artillery observer in Europe. After the war, Mr. Baker joined his father, J. Stewart Baker, at The Bank of Manhattan where he became senior vice president of the merged Chase Manhattan Bank. He was named President of The Alpha Portland Cement Co. in 1964 and later served as President of The Garden State Bank in Hackensack, NJ. Mr. Baker is survived by his loving wife, Robin, four children, Beverly Baker Vincent (Kenneth), John Stewart III (Pamela), Charles Dabney (Karen), and Elizabeth Baker Karafa (James), three step-children, Todd, Leslie and Clay Banister, his sisters, Barbara Baker McPherson and Priscilla Baker Hill, 14 grandchildren and four great - grandchildren. Calling hours are 12:301:30PM, Monday, February 24th at St. Anne's Episcopal Church, Trexlertown, PA., after which a funeral service will be held. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to The American Diabetes Foundation or The American Heart Association.

title: INSPECTOR ORDERS IRAQ TO DISMANTLE DISPUTED MISSILES
description: A chief United Nations weapons inspector demanded today that Iraq start destroying -- within a week -- all its Al Samoud 2 missiles and any illegally imported engines designed for use in the rockets, which United Nations experts say exceed the allowed range of 92 miles.

title: In Performance
description: CABARET

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: African Refugees Are Rescued After 2-Week Ordeal
description: Six Africans are recovering in a Spanish hospital after being rescued from the small wooden boat in which they spent two weeks adrift in the Atlantic Ocean, survivors of a group trying to reach Europe through Spain's Canary Islands. Twelve others drowned during the treacherous voyage, which began in Western Sahara. The survivors, five men and one woman from Ghana and Mali, are suffering from dehydration, malnutrition, hypothermia and exhaustion, but may be released from the hospital soon -- though they will face a harder struggle to stay in Europe legally. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEDLIS, GABRIEL
description: SEDLIS-Gabriel. Architect AIA. Son of Dr. Elias and Anna Sedlis. During W.W. II, fought Nazis with partisans of Wilno. Will be missed for his warmth, wit and high standards by wife Joanna, daughter Sophia Anna, son James, daughter-in-law Amy, brother Alik, sister-in-law Mila, nephews and nieces Steven, Danny, Melissa and Cynthia. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell Memorial Chapel, Madison and 81st St., on Monday, February 24, 2003 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, you may send donations to your favorite charity.

title: Corrections
description: The detail area of a map in Business Day on Wednesday with an article about the acquisition and leasing of property by LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton on East 57th Street reversed the labels for two avenues. Fifth Avenue marks the western edge of the tract and Madison Avenue the east.

title: FEMA Says It Can't Approve Emergency Plan For Indian Pt.
description: The future of the Indian Point nuclear power plant in Westchester County grew cloudier last night after the Federal Emergency Management Agency reported it could not give ''reasonable assurance'' that emergency plans for the area around the plant would work.

title: Doctors Discuss Transplant Mistake
description: The Duke University Hospital surgeon who gave Jsica Santilln a heart and lung transplant on Feb. 7 does not recall receiving or requesting information about the donor's blood type, the university said yesterday. The mistake was ''the critical failure'' in a series of events that have left Ms. Santilln desperately ill, with signs of irreversible brain damage, the hospital said.

title: Devils Stall the Bruins' Playoff Drive
description: For the fourth time in four games, the Devils faced an opponent hungry to improve its positioning in the crowded Eastern Conference playoff race. And for the first time in those four games, the Devils came away with a victory.

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: LAWMAKER SAYS CAMPAIGN IS STILL ON Senator Bob Graham, Democrat of Florida, said that although surgery last month to replace a damaged heart valve was more extensive than expected, he intended to file paperwork next week to establish a presidential campaign committee. "The only remaining question is the issue of getting medical clearance" for a White House run, Mr. Graham said. When he underwent heart surgery on Jan. 31 to replace his aortic valve, which controls blood flow, doctors performed a discretionary double bypass procedure to close a hole between the chambers of his heart, he said. A spokesman said the senator expected to announce his candidacy in April. (NYT)

title: Walking with Lily : An eager guide to real Tokyo
description: TOKYO  She is blonde, she is beautiful. She has unwittingly coaxed me into seeing a side of Tokyo many business travelers and resident foreigners may not know: the labyrinthine alleys of unassuming Tokyo at dawn. Perhaps, our early morning view of Tokyo is Japan at its finest: serene, gentle, cautiously curious, dynamic, coy.

title: Iran Pardons Five Jews Jailed as Spies
description: Iran's supreme religious leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, pardoned five Jews today who had been jailed on charges of spying for Israel, said Haroun Yashayai, a leading Jewish figure in Tehran.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERNSTEIN, ELLIOTT
description: BERNSTEIN-Elliott. Happy Birthday, my sweet Elliott. It was a beautiful day. Love, Mom

title: KEYSPAN TO SELL PART OF STAKE IN HOUSTON EXPLORATION
description: KeySpan, a leading seller of natural gas in the Northeast, said yesterday that it would sell part of its majority stake in a gas producer, Houston Exploration, to pay off debt. Houston Exploration plans an offering of at least three million new shares to finance the purchase of the same number of shares held by KeySpan, the companies said. The sale will raise about $79 million for KeySpan and reduce its stake in Houston Exploration to 56 percent from 66 percent. KeySpan netted $473 million last month in a share sale to cut debt, causing the stock to fall on concern that the move will dilute earnings.

title: Bids Scarce, Sotheby's Takes Itself Off the Block
description: Sotheby's Holdings, the auction house that has struggled through a price-fixing scandal and financial troubles, has been successful in selling multimillion-dollar paintings in this poor economy, but cannot seem to find a buyer for itself.

title: Blair Says He Wants to Avoid War and Work With U.N., but That Iraq Must Disarm
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain said today that he was eager to avoid war in Iraq and determined to try to work through the United Nations, but that his belief in the need for Iraq to be disarmed -- by force, if necessary -- was firm.

title: The Middle East Belongs in the World Economy
description: For much of history, the Middle East was the commercial and intellectual bridge between Asia and Europe. It was among the most cosmopolitan regions of the world, the birthplace of religions and alphabets, even the source of some terminology common in today's globalized era; technical terms like ''tariff,'' and commodity names like ''cotton'' and ''coffee,'' have their roots in Arabic.

title: Harry Jacunski, 87, One of Fordham's Seven Blocks of Granite
description: Harry Jacunski, a member of the Fordham football team's line known as the Seven Blocks of Granite, died Thursday at the Connecticut Hospice in Branford of congestive heart failure. He was 87.

title: Koufax Cuts Ties With Dodgers; Newspaper Retracts Gossip Item
description: For 48 years, Sandy Koufax was a Dodger, from Brooklyn to Los Angeles, from his days as a wild-throwing kid to his last six seasons of unmatched, powerful brilliance.

title: SPX CORP. SAYS IT HAS ACQUIRED BROOKSTONE TELECOM
description: The SPX Corporation, which provides industrial products and services, said yesterday that it had acquired Brookstone Telecom, a provider of construction and maintenance services to the telecommunications industry. SPX, based in Charlotte, N.C., said the acquisition fitted its strategy of increasing service offerings. Terms of the acquisition were not disclosed. Brookstone, based in Temecula, Calif., has annual revenue of about $40 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARPENTER, DORIS
description: CARPENTER - Doris. Of South Setauket, Long Island and Brooklyn, New York on February 19, 2003. Beloved wife of Albert. Loving mother of Margery and Richard. Cherished grandmother of seven. Funeral services were held in private.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR GAINS. The yen fell after the Japanese finance minister said the government might counter ''speculative activity'' in the currency market. In New York, the dollar settled at 118.80 yen, up from 118.31 on Thursday.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Holocaust Denier Is Returned By U.S.
description: Immigration officials are trying to bar a Holocaust denier, Ernst Zundel, from earning refugee status in Canada. Mr. Zundel, 63, who faces hate-crime charges in his native Germany, was returned from the United States on Wednesday after being arrested at his home outside Knoxville, Tenn., for overstaying a visitor's visa. Mr. Zundel moved to Canada in 1958, but was never granted citizenship. He left for the United States in 2001 amid attempts here to shut down his anti-Semitic Web site. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Economic Index Slips
description: An economic index that measures industrial activity fell 0.6 percent in December from November as retail spending slowed. The index, which is known as the all-sector activity index and is a proxy for gross domestic product, slipped 4.1 percent in the October-December quarter. The numbers were in contrast to the strong quarterly G.D.P. figures released last week and suggest that those figures may have to be revised downward. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Another Chance to Play for Knicks' Williams
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 21  When Frank Williams first joined the Knicks, he enjoyed junk food. Candy was a regular meal and his poor eating habits became obvious after he broke his left wrist in July. Unable to work out while he healed, he gained weight, became pudgy and lost a bit of his quickness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKLOOT, GUSSIE AUGUSTA ROSEN
description: SKLOOT - Gussie Augusta Rosen. Passed on February 20, 2003. Cherished mother of Michael Skloot, cherished grandmother of Tal Skloot, Anette Skloot, Shira Skloot Henry, Roland Henry, Ori Skloot and Alison Skloot. Beloved mother of James P.C. of Buchanan, NY, Jane A. of NYC and Thomas W. of Atlanta, GA. Sister of Dwight (Bill) Webb of Cambridge, MA., and the late Barbara Nichols of Farmington, CT. Also survived by three granddaughters and one great-granddaughter. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2 to 5 PM, Sunday. Service at the Christ Church, Bronxville, on Monday, February 24, at 10 A.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan - Kettering Cancer Center.

title: Same Suspects Tied to Mombasa and '98 Embassy Attacks
description: Investigators have found evidence suggesting that some of the same operatives of Al Qaeda involved in the American Embassy bombings in East Africa in 1998 may have helped carry out the attack in November on a Kenyan resort.

title: Club Co-owner Is Also Prominent TV Reporter
description: When Jeffrey Derderian, a reporter for WPRI-TV in Providence, R.I., began working on a report about nightclub safety after the fatal stampede on Monday in Chicago, he knew exactly whom to call and where to go.

title: TEXAS JURY AWARDS $132 MILLION TO FLUORINE ON CALL
description: A Texas jury yesterday ordered the BOC Group, a maker of gases used in industrial work, to pay $132 million to Fluorine on Call in a breach-of-contract case. The case involved Fluorogas Ltd., a gas-equipment maker that BOC acquired in September 2001. Fluorogas had canceled an agreement to sell computer-chip-making technology to Fluorine on Call, a BOC rival. The jury awarded $120 million to Fluorine on Call for lost profits and $12 million in punitive damages. BOC was also found liable for Fluorogas's cancellation of a 2000 agreement to give Fluorine on Call an exclusive license for gas-delivery equipment used in making silicon chips, said Kevin M. Sadler, the plaintiff's lawyer. BOC said it would ask Judge James R. Nowlin of United States District Court in Austin to review the award.

title: New York Seeks Looser Police Surveillance Rules
description: The city asked a federal judge yesterday to ease the limits on police surveillance of political groups, a move that would enable officers to initiate investigations without evidence of a crime and to share their information with other law enforcement agencies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALDSTON, MORTON
description: GALDSTON-Morton, M.D. The faculty of The Pulmonary/Critical Care Division of the NYU School of Medicine and Bellevue Hospital Chest Service regrets the passing of our esteemed colleague, Dr. Morton Galdston. A noted scientist and scholar, and humane physician who served NYU since his mecical intership at Bellevue Hospital in 1938. His wisdom and contributions will be missed by his colleagues. We express condolences to his wife Irene and family. William Rom, M.D., Director Pulmonary/Critical Care Div Dept of Medicine NYU School of Medicine Dir, Chest Service Bellevue Hospital

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, MATTHEW H.

description: When David Natanovich Bell first applied for a visa to visit the United States, at the American Embassy in Moscow in October 1987, the consular official took one brief look at his Soviet passport and one long look at him. She left the room, then returned with her boss.

title: An Arab Gadfly With a Memorable Bite
description: If you can judge a man by the company he keeps, you can also judge him by the enemies he makes. And Mohammed Harbi, Algeria's most renowned intellectual, has certainly made some formidable enemies. Over the last decade, his writings on Algerian history and politics have landed him death threats from the Algerian secret police, radical Islamists and right-wing French settlers still angry over their loss of Algeria to the National Liberation Front or F.L.N., of which he was a high-ranking member as a young man.

title: Shoreline Fire Tests Security Plan of a City on Edge
description: At 10:10 yesterday morning, when an explosion shook Staten Island and sent a tower of smoke skyward, a series of events was set into motion around New York City that had little to do with fighting a raging shoreline fire.

title: Use of Dangerous Materials Cited in Korean Subway Fire
description: Investigators looking into the fire that took the lives of more than 130 people on two subway trains here on Tuesday zeroed in on flammable materials, especially seat covers, used in building the cars as the main reason so many lives were lost.

title: Barge Blast In Staten Island Leaves 2 Dead
description: A barge offloading gasoline at an oil depot in Staten Island exploded with earthquake force yesterday, shaking businesses, homes and nerves for miles around as towering black smoke spread a pall over much of New York City. Two barge crewmen were killed and a depot worker on shore was critically burned.

title: A Lifelong Dissident Defies Iran's Rulers on Torture
description: Ezatollah Sahabi is a war horse of the revolution. He began his dissident activity half a century ago after the Central Intelligence Agency staged a coup that overthrew the government and reinstated the monarchy. He spent 12 years in the shah's prisons, and in the heady early days of revolution he was rewarded with a seat on the ruling Revolutionary Council.

title: Suddenly, Rock Show Turns Stage For Horrors
description: At first it seemed like nothing but the blazing beginning of a rock show, like so many other concerts Christopher Travis had seen. Jack Russell, the singer for Great White, belted out the opening line of ''Desert Moon,'' and the crush of people inside The Station gyrated and screamed in head-banging delight. Two pinwheel pyrotechnics spun on either side of the stage, and two rockets shot sparks into the air.

description: KORNREICH-Jean. Age 94, on February 20, 2003. Beloved and devoted mother of Steve and Sherri; adored grandmother of Peter, Josh, Rob, Noah, Helene and Jennifer; and cherished great-grandmother of Matthew and Adam. She will be in our hearts and the angel on our shoulders always.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERTINE, MARGARET
description: ALBERTINE - Margaret. A true American beauty, died at home on Friday, February 7, after a long and courageous battle with breast cancer. Her physical beauty was only surpassed by her passion for social justice and her love for animals. A lawyer and an expert on Arabian-Egyptian horses, she was an ardent advocate for the environment and animal rights. She was also a collector of equine art. Intellectually brilliant, she was an honor graduate of Douglas College of Rutgers University and Syracuse Law School where she wrote for Law Review. Margaret is survived by her mother, Elsie F. Albertine, a brother, Michael O. Albertine, a sister Julie A. Levin, and three nephews, Michael J. Albertine, Stephen C. Albertine, and Aaron V. Levin. A memorial service will be held at the B'Nai Shalom Synagogue on 300 Pleasant Valley Way, in West Orange, Sunday, February 23, 2003, at 10:15 A.M. The family requests, that, in lieu of flowers, donations be sent to Greenpeace, Defenders of Wildlife, or the Humane Society of New York City. For information Jewish Memorial Chapel, Clifton, New Jersey.

title: Residency permits : Getting a legal foot in the door
description: LONDON  The British are reasonable people. Before I moved here eight years ago to work for an American news service, I only had to take my U.S. passport into the British Embassy in Paris (where I lived at the time), along with a letter from my employer. In a few minutes, I was given a visa under the category "representative of an overseas news organization."

title: Julian Bigelow, 89, Mathematician and Computer Pioneer
description: Julian Bigelow, a mathematician and electrical engineer who was a pioneer in the fields of cybernetics and computing, died on Monday in Princeton, N.J., where he lived. He was 89.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Arts Briefing column on Feb. 12 about an exhibition of photographs by Margaret Bourke-White referred incompletely to her education. While she did study at Columbia University, she graduated from Cornell.

title: A Blank Page in Schools' Future; Many Strive to See Effects of a List of Top Performers
description: In Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, parents hope that their beloved elementary school will remain exactly the same, even though it was not deemed successful enough to control its own curriculum.

title: Davenport Passes On Playing Men
description: With Annika Sorenstam, the dominant female golfer, about to play in a men's tournament, Lindsay Davenport, who was the No. 1-ranked woman in tennis 13 months ago and now ranks No. 8, was asked if she was hankering to play in a men's tournament.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICHOLAS, BARBARA JOHNSTON
description: NICHOLAS-Barbara Johnston, 94. Daughter of the late Franklin and Daisy Johnston. Cherished mother of David, Joan, Philip, Mary and the late Paul and Ann Nicholas. Dearest mother-in-law of Carole and Donette. Beloved grandmother of Michelle, Sean, Terry, Danielle, Michael, Diane, Catherine and Brendan. Wake at home Sunday, 1-7 PM. Funeral St. Mary's Church, Manhasset, 11:15 AM, Monday.

title: No Long-Lasting Effects From Blast, Officials Say
description: The environmental and health consequences of the fire at the Port Mobil terminal are not expected to be lasting or dire, scientists and government officials said yesterday. Because the fuel that was being unloaded at the terminal was unleaded gasoline, they said, the plume contained the same mix of pollutants, for better or worse, that people breathe every day from the millions of automobiles burning the exact same stuff.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about ties between the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Dwain J. Kyles, the owner of a Chicago nightclub where 21 people were killed in a stampede, referred incorrectly to former Mayor Harold Washington, for whom Mr. Kyles once worked. While he was Chicago's first black mayor, he was not its only one; Eugene Sawyer was acting mayor after Mr. Washington died in 1987.

title: New Jersey Teacher Gets Jail Term in Sexual Assaults of Girls
description: There were tears and sobbing in a Union County Superior Court room today as a former teacher at a private high school for girls here was sentenced to seven years in the state prison for sex offenders for sexually assaulting three of his students.

title: Illinois Joins Suits To Collect Taxes On Internet Sales
description: Illinois has joined lawsuits against Wal-Mart Stores, Target, Office Depot and three smaller retailers, accusing them of failing to collect taxes on Internet and catalog sales.

title: Design for Transit Hub Lets Travelers See Sky
description: A transportation hub at the World Trade Center site that planners envision as a downtown Grand Central Terminal would include a great hall with a soaring glass atrium stretching the block from Church to Greenwich Streets, according to a preliminary design released Thursday night by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: CALPERS STEPS UP PRESSURE ON TYCO TO RETURN TO U.S.
description: The California Public Employees' Retirement System, the largest pension fund in the nation, is stepping up pressure on Tyco International to move back to the United States, sending letters to the company's top shareholders two weeks before an annual meeting. Tyco, based in Pembroke, Bermuda, has already said it will consider a return to the United States when it has its annual meeting on March 6. Calpers, which owns 1.4 million Tyco shares, sent a letter on Tuesday to Tyco's 100 largest stockholders asking for support of a position the fund initially took in November.

description: SCHREIBER - Arlene. On Thursday, February 20, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Julius Schreiber. Daughter of the late Ethel and Jacob Perlman. Sister of brother Harold and late brother Lawrence Perlman. Cherished aunt of Yvonne Margo, Peter Frankel, Edith Cohen of Montreal, Canada and Yitzchak Cohen of Lugano, Switzerland. Great nephews & nieces Benjamin and Joshua Margo, Tamara, Noah and Talya Frankel, Bracha Hoffert, Laizar, Chaim, Motti, Binyamin and Schlomo Cohen. Services from Hirsch & Sons Funeral Home, 1225 Jerome Avenue, Bronx, NY, corner of 167 Street on Sunday, February 23rd at 10:30 AM. Interment to follow at Mt. Carmel Cemetery, Glendale, Queens, New York.

title: THREATS AND RESPONSES: A Heritage of Protest; The Germans Who Toppled Communism Resent the U.S.
description: Every Monday at the Nikolai Church in the former East German city of Leipzig -- the very church and the very day of the week where the demonstrations that brought down the former Communist government began -- residents protest the possibility of war with Iraq. The rally is both a symbol and a paradox of the great European schism on the question of Iraq.

title: Policy Defeat Puts F.C.C. Chief in Awkward Spot
description: Michael K. Powell, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, has set an ambitious agenda of relaxing or removing many regulations that have limited the nation's largest media conglomerates from becoming bigger or entering new markets.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Economy Expanded In 2002
description: The Finance Ministry said that Mexico's economy was worth 6.15 trillion pesos in 2002, or $593 billion using the Dec. 31 exchange rate, a 5.5 percent expansion, including inflation, from 2001. The economy, the largest in Latin America, expanded a slower-than-expected 0.9 percent last year in real terms as a sluggish United States recovery hurt demand for Mexican goods.
