title: 3 PIECES OF DEBRIS HIT SHUTTLE WING
description: During Columbia's liftoff, not one but three chunks of debris flew off the 15-story external fuel tank and hit the shuttle's left wing, according to a document NASA made public yesterday. Previously, the public inquiry into what caused the craft to break up on re-entry focused only on the largest chunk.

title: Corrections
description: Two articles about the space shuttle Columbia on Wednesday, one about findings that it began to break up on re-entry over California and the other about the quirks of the craft itself, gave differing figures -- both accurate -- for its weight. The shuttle weighed about 178,000 pounds empty; in flight, with payloads, crew members and supplies on board, it weighed about 234,000 pounds.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: NIGERIA: RADIOACTIVE MATERIAL IS MISSING Nigerian authorities said they were searching for highly radioactive material used in the oil industry that had disappeared in the oil-producing Niger Delta. The Nigerian Nuclear Regulatory Authority, in a public notice broadcast on radio and television, warned people to avoid contact with the "highly radioactive, dangerous material," but would not identify the exact substance. An oil engineer in the country said it was probably either cesium 137 or sodium iodide, used in oil-well-mapping operations, and that "two parcels" of the material disappeared around Dec. 3.   (Reuters)

title: New Zealand Fans Despair, but They Are Still Cheering
description: They come each morning to send their boys off, wearing all black -- the national color -- except for their socks, which are red, after the superstition of the Kiwi yachtsman Sir Peter Blake. Their faces are painted with fronds of a silver fern -- Team New Zealand's logo -- and the word Loyal, the team motto that sums up the intense and complicated emotions surrounding the current America's Cup.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank Profits Fall
description: Two banks reported disappointing profit for last year as a result of the need to cover delinquent consumer loans. Hana Bank, Korea's third-largest bank as a result of its acquisition of SeoulBank, said earnings last year were 323.6 billion won ($271 million), slightly less than the 325.3 billion won that it made in 2001 before taking over SeoulBank and far less than the 472.7 billion won that it had forecast in December. Korea First Bank, in which Newbridge Capital acquired a 51 percent stake in 1999, reported a profit of 102 billion won ($85.4 million), less than half its profit of 225 billion won that it had reported a year earlier. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bridgestone's Profit Soars
description: The tire manufacturer Bridgestone said profit for the year that ended in December more than doubled as sales rebounded in the United States. The company earned 45.4 billion yen ($382 million) last year, compared with 17.4 billion yen the previous year, as sales rose 5.3 percent. Sales in the period a year earlier were damaged when Bridgestone was forced to recall millions of tires at its United States subsidiary. Bridgestone expects profit to grow 54 percent, to 70 billion yen, this year. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: HEWLETT-PACKARD WINS $242 MILLION CONTRACT IN ITALY
description: Hewlett-Packard said yesterday that it had won a five-year contract worth 225 million euros ($242.3 million) to manage computer systems at Telecom Italia, Italy's biggest telephone company. Hewlett-Packard, based in Palo Alto, Calif., will provide management, maintenance and help-desk services for 90,000 workers, Telecom Italia said, and will form a unit with 600 Telecom Italia computer specialists. The agreement requires the approval of labor unions and the Italian Antitrust Authority.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: GUILTY PLEA FOR LAST S.L.A. MEMBER James Kilgore, a former member of the Symbionese Liberation Army who spent decades on the run from bomb and murder charges, pleaded guilty to federal explosives and passport fraud charges. The authorities said he was the last member of the group that kidnapped the newspaper heiress Patricia Hearst to face justice. Mr. Kilgore, 55, faces 10 years in prison for possession of a pipe bomb and another 5 years for obtaining a passport under a false name. (AP)

title: Four Nancy Drews and One Serial Killer
description: The one bright spot in ''James Patterson's '1st to Die,' '' the television movie based on Mr. Patterson's sell-all novel, is the wild woman Sean Young, who plays Joanna Wade, the opaque ex-wife of a sadistic novelist.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Lawmaker Says Campaign Is Still On
description: Senator Bob Graham, Democrat of Florida, said that although surgery last month to replace a damaged heart valve was more extensive than expected, he intended to file paperwork next week to establish a presidential campaign committee. ''The only remaining question is the issue of getting medical clearance'' for a White House run, Mr. Graham said. When he underwent heart surgery on Jan. 31 to replace his aortic valve, which controls blood flow, doctors performed a discretionary double bypass procedure to close a hole between the chambers of his heart, he said. A spokesman said the senator expected to announce his candidacy in April.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Gazprom Sells Bonds
description: The natural gas producer Gazprom raised $1.75 billion in Russia's biggest corporate bond sale, tapping resurgent investor confidence four and a half years after the government's debt default. Gazprom received more than $6 billion of orders for the 10-year bonds.

title: For Democrats, an Early Chance to Sample the 2004 Line of Presidential Candidates
description: Four Democratic presidential candidates strongly criticized President Bush's economic policies today in speeches before party leaders here. But they clashed over United States policy toward Iraq, a hint of one of the few issues about which the Democratic field disagrees.

title: A New Literature With Asian Roots
description: As a writer, Mai Neng Moua can braid bits of dreams and imagination with the remnants of the past. As the editor of ''Bamboo Among the Oaks,'' a first anthology of Hmong American writers, she is midwife to the birth of a literary tradition.

title: A Pollutant by Any Other Name
description: The pressure on President Bush to abandon his irresponsibly passive approach to global warming was ratcheted up this week. On Thursday the attorneys general of seven Northeastern states announced their intention to sue the administration -- in the person of Christie Whitman, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency -- for its failure to regulate power plant emissions of carbon dioxide, the main global warming gas, as required by the Clean Air Act.

title: QUEST DIAGNOSTICS WINS F.T.C. APPROVAL TO BUY UNILAB
description: Quest Diagnostics, the largest operator of medical testing labs in the nation, won approval from the Federal Trade Commission yesterday for its $813 million purchase of Unilab. The F.T.C. approved the acquisition after Quest agreed on Feb. 4 to sell four medical-testing contracts in California to its chief competitor, the Laboratory Corporation of America. Quest said it went along with the sale of the contracts to ease F.T.C. concerns that the Unilab purchase would hurt competition for lab services in Northern California.

title: League Executives Challenged On Ephedra
description: Officials stepped up efforts on two fronts yesterday to confront the potential dangers of dietary supplements, particularly ephedra, which might have contributed to a baseball player's death earlier this week.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Bank's Profit Slips
description: The Dutch financial services and banking concern ING said its fourth-quarter profit fell 2.7 percent from the period a year earlier, to 922 million euros ($998 million) because of an increase in the money it set aside for bad loans. For the year, ING's profit fell 1.7 percent, to 4.5 billion euros, in part because of 510 million euros it set aside in the fourth quarter to make up for bond losses at a subsidiary of National Century Financial Services in the United States. The company declined to make a forecast for the current year; its chairman, Ewald Kist, above, said he was concerned about the growing dispute between the United States and some European countries over Iraq. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

description: Charlotte Adams and Dancers

title: Benetton Family to Control Italian Toll Road Operator
description: The Benetton family has won control of Autostrade, Europe's largest toll road operator, paying 6.46 billion euros ($6.97 billion) to increase its stake to 85 percent from 30 percent in a tender offer that concluded today.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Scalia To Miss Sessions
description: Justice Antonin Scalia of the Supreme Court will probably miss arguments before the court next week while he recovers from shoulder surgery, a spokeswoman for the court said. Justice Scalia, 66, had surgery on Thursday at Virginia Hospital Center in Arlington to repair a torn rotator cuff in his right shoulder. He plans to participate in the rulings, said the spokeswoman, Kathleen L. Arberg, with the assistance of written briefs and transcripts of the oral arguments. The court will hear arguments in six cases next week.

title: DOUBLE WINNERS IN MANHATTAN
description: Shana Cox was a double winner in girls' elite events and Chris Jacques won twice in boys' elite field events in the Long Island Challenge meet at the Armory Track and Field Center in Manhattan. A total of 56 schools and 610 competitors from Long Island took part in this inaugural meet.

title: Eastern Europe, On a New Stage
description: Most Eastern Europeans are looking forward to becoming full members of a European system that they hope will bring economic salvation and stability in a region scarred by memories of war and dictatorship.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about ties between the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Dwain J. Kyles, the owner of a Chicago nightclub where 21 people were killed in a stampede, referred incorrectly to former Mayor Harold Washington, for whom Mr. Kyles once worked. While he was Chicago's first black mayor, he was not its only one; Eugene Sawyer was acting mayor after Mr. Washington died in 1987.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Playwright Announces He Is H.I.V. Positive
description: Gibson Kente, one of South Africa's best-known playwrights, announced that he had H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. Mr. Kente, who is among a very few celebrities in the country who have gone public with their infection status, said he hoped to inspire other South Africans living with AIDS. South Africa has more H.I.V.-positive people than any other nation. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Los Angeles Council Adopts Resolution Against Iraq War
description: With the gallery packed with peace advocates, the City Council passed a resolution today opposing unilateral war against Iraq and urging President Bush to employ all diplomatic options to deal with the crisis.

title: Streak Gives Seton Hall a Reason for Hope
description: Greg Morton admits that Seton Hall Coach Louis Orr's public spirituality makes him uncomfortable.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Gurkhas Lose Pay-Discrimination Lawsuit
description: A British court rejected assertions that the British Army unlawfully denied equal pay and conditions to Gurkha soldiers recruited in Nepal. Cherie Booth, a leading employment rights lawyer and the wife of Prime Minister Tony Blair, argued that the Gurkhas had suffered from institutionalized discrimination because they received lower pay and pensions than other soldiers in the British Army. But the court said the differences in working conditions were legal in light of the divergent economies of Britain and Nepal, one of the world's poorest countries. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Two articles about the space shuttle Columbia on Wednesday, one about findings that it began to break up on re-entry over California and the other about the quirks of the craft itself, gave differing figures -- both accurate -- for its weight. The shuttle weighed about 178,000 pounds empty; in flight, with payloads, crew members and supplies on board, it weighed about 234,000 pounds.

title: S.U.V.'s and Satire
description: To the Editor:

title: Yanks' Johnson Concerned About a Painful Left Wrist
description: Nick Johnson missed the entire 2000 season with a strained muscle in his right hand. That was the best diagnosis the Yankees could get, anyway, and Johnson's latest injury is another mystery.

title: Orville Freeman, 84, Dies; 60's Agriculture Secretary
description: Orville L. Freeman, who as secretary of agriculture under Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson aggressively promoted food assistance for poor people and exports of American farm goods, died on Thursday in Minneapolis. He was 84.

title: Blurring Reality With Soap Suds
description: Viewers who doubt that anyone would ever say ''my walls have finally crumbled and I can now tell you without reservation that I am in love with you'' are too skeptical.

title: EL PASO SAYS CHANGE IN DIRECTORS WOULD COST MILLIONS
description: The El Paso Corporation, an owner of natural gas pipelines, said that a proposal by dissident shareholders to remove its directors would force the company to pay the chief executive and other officers millions of dollars. The officers will receive three times their maximum salary and bonuses if there is a change in control of the company, El Paso said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Based on his 2001 pay, the chief executive, William A. Wise, would get at least $14.2 million. An El Paso shareholder and former director, Selim K. Zilkha, said on Tuesday that he would ask investors to oust El Paso's 11 board members; the company's shares have fallen by half this month.

title: Experts Were Surprised: Low Cards and High Score
description: Experts nearly always know what the score is. In competition, they write down 140, or 650, or 1,510 without pausing for thought. But on rare occasions something happens that forces them to do a complex calculation, or seek enlightenment by inspecting the back of a bidding-box card.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 12 about a decision by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to recruit students of all races for two summer math and science programs originally intended for minority students referred incompletely to the first disclosure of the plan. Besides The Boston Globe, it was reported in The Chronicle of Higher Education.

title: 6-Year-Term For Woman In Forest Fire
description: The woman who admitted to starting the largest wildfire in Colorado history apologized here today and was sentenced to six years in prison.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOWEEK, CLARA J.
description: KOWEEK-Clara J. February 21, died in her home in Hudson, NY. Beloved wife of Albert for 66 years; loving mother of Barbara (Arthur) and Robert (Susan); devoted sister of Thyra; loving sisterin-law of Janice and Arthur; cherished grandmother of Marc (Janet), Lisa (Bill), Kira (Alan), Sharon, Jeffrey (Lynn) and Andrea; adoring great-grandmother of Jade, Joshua, Alex, Noah, Layla and Rebecca. Loving aunt to numerous nieces and nephews. Born in NYC she is a graduate of Hunter College. She was both a teacher and dedicated volunteer on behalf of mental health causes and her synagogue, Anshe Emeth. She was the first woman trustee of the Congregation. She so enriched our lives and will be missed by all. Services will held at Bates & Anderson on February 23 at 10:30AM. Donations may be made to the Congregation Anshe Emeth, or Community Hospice, Catskill, NY.

title: Kerry, the Other Earnhardt, Is Coming On
description: Dale Earnhardt Jr. was assigned a stall at the farthest end of pit road for a Nascar Busch Grand National race last week. Race fans soon found out, and the area behind his crew's tools and spare tires quickly became jammed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHILLER, JOSEPH
description: SHILLER - Joseph. Passed away on Thursday, February 20, 2003, in Fairfield, CT. Beloved husband of Marcia Rothfeld Shiller. Loving father of Barbara Shiller, Linda Shiller Cormany and Sam Shiller. Cherished grandfather of four grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Dear brother of Mitty Shiller and Dr. Jack Shiller. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, February 23, 2003, 11:30 AM, at the Leo P. Gallagher and Son Funeral Home, 2900 Summer Street, Stamford, CT. Interment will follow at Cedar Park Cemetery in Emerson, New Jersey.

title: THREATS AND RESPONSES: On Washington's Side; Poles Cherish U.S. as Friend, Fondly Recalling Its Support
description: Waiting for a McKielbasa sandwich at a downtown outlet of the world's most ubiquitous American fast food chain, a 29-year-old economist did not hesitate when asked where he would stand if asked to choose between the United States and Europe.

title: An Emptiness Made Crueler By Closeness
description: In the neighborhood known as Rhode Island, nearly everyone knew where this place was: next to Knight's Garage, across from the Cowesett Inn. Long ago it had been an Italian restaurant, Papa something, and then it became a music club for a younger crowd, but still, nearly everyone knew where this place was.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEPASQUALE, EUGENIA
description: DePASQUALE-Eugenia. Of Southampton, NY died on February 20. Wife of the late Nicholas, mother of Josephine Theodorou and Nicholas, Eugene and Louis DePasquale. Visiting, J. Ronald Scott Funeral Home, Hampton Bays, Sunday February 23, 2-4 and 7-9. Mass Monday, 10AM at Sacred Heart RC Church, Southampton, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations to East End Hospice.

title: Threat of Iraq War Draws World Leaders, With Different Views, to the Pope's Door
description: Two weeks ago, it was Joschka Fischer, the German foreign minister. Last week, it was Tariq Aziz, the deputy prime minister of Iraq. On Saturday, if they keep to the schedule, it will be Tony Blair, the British prime minister.

title: Bure Shows Old Form In Rangers' Outburst
description: Rangers Coach Glen Sather said of Pavel Bure this morning, ''He's starting to become the player he was before.''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''People say in the world, it's six degrees of separation. In Rhode Island, it's probably a degree and a half.''

title: Service for Irene Diamond, the Philanthropist
description: A memorial service for Irene Diamond, the philanthropist of the arts and medical research who died on Jan. 21 at 92, will be held on Monday at the Juilliard Theater, 155 West 65th Street, at Lincoln Center.

title: Inquiry on Wellstone Crash Finds Oddities About Pilot
description: Safety officials looking into the charter-plane crash that killed Senator Paul Wellstone of Minnesota and seven other people in October have found a trail of oddities in the past of the pilot, as well as a vivid glimpse of preflight anxiety, but as yet no clear cause of the accident.

title: Fireworks Like Those Used Are a Common Part of Events
description: Indoor fireworks displays like the one that touched off Thursday's nightclub fire in Rhode Island have become so common they are almost a routine spectacle at special events.

title: THREATS AND RESPONSES: The New Capitalists; Western Investment Provides A Bonanza for East Europe
description: As Europe divides politically over war in Iraq, a different campaign is shaping in places like this, once held in thrall by the Soviet Union. Put simply, it is a battle to redraw a continent's economic frontiers, and it is cast, like the rift over Iraq, as a collision of old and new.

title: U.S. and Turkey Reach Accord to Let G.I.'s Establish a Base
description: The United States has reached agreement with Turkey on a package of $15 billion in immediate economic and military aid, in a step that is expected to pave the way for American troops to use Turkish territory as a base in case of war with Iraq, administration officials said today.

title: Rogge Tries to Light Flame Under Athens Organizers
description: The International Olympic Committee chastised the organizers of the Athens Olympics yesterday, saying their preparations were severely behind schedule.

title: Expat adviser : Planning a destination wedding
description: [Q.]My fiance and I are American expats living and working in London. We are thinking about getting married elsewhere in Europe, such as in France or Italy. Are there special considerations for expats that we should be aware of?

title: Judges Mix With Politics
description: Judges have to give up a few things in exchange for their robes, the legal system used to say. Speaking out on issues that might come before them was one such thing, and partisan political activity was another.

title: Israelis Kill 2, Raising Toll of Palestinians to 30 This Week
description: Israeli forces shot dead two Palestinians today while repelling separate attacks on an army outpost and a Jewish settlement in the Gaza Strip, the army and militant groups said.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Report Card From Mayor Says Cuts Have Not Eroded Services Yet
description: The budget has been cut four times, but essential services have not yet eroded, according to statistics released by the Bloomberg administration yesterday.

title: Where Surprise Is Commonplace
description: Last week 14 of the nation's top 25 men's college basketball teams were defeated, and already this week another five have gone down -- including two teams in the top 10 of the Associated Press poll. That number figures to grow this weekend as No. 2 Kentucky takes on No. 19 Mississippi State; No. 5 Oklahoma plays No. 6 Kansas; No. 3 Texas travels to No. 16 Oklahoma State, and No. 14 Xavier squares off with No. 25 Dayton.

title: Even Out of Net, Snow Stops Avalanche
description: Garth Snow strayed so far from the Islanders' goal to play a puck during a power play tonight that he might as well have joined his team at the other end of the ice.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Chief Justice Is Investigated
description: The Kenyan government suspended Chief Justice Bernard Chunga and appointed a tribunal to look into allegations of corruption and torture against him. The move came just days after the new president, Mwai Kibaki, announced a campaign against corruption. The tribunal will look into allegations that Mr. Chunga organized the torture of prisoners before he became chief justice and that he engaged in corrupt acts while serving in the top judicial post. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Group Persevered by Making Circuit of Smaller Clubs
description: Great White, heavy rockers from Los Angeles, started appearing in clubs on Sunset Strip in 1982, when local rock was dominated by ''hair metal'' -- bands with big, long hair and makeup and tights that celebrated whiskey, rock 'n' roll and sex. Ratt, Mtley Cre, Whitesnake, Poison and Dokken were some of the bands that were there, but Great White was never as sparkly or pop-oriented. It stuck more closely to the rock-and-blues template created by English bands in the early 70's, like Led Zeppelin and Humble Pie.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Judge From 1993 Standoff Returns To Post
description: Valery Zorkin, a judge whose ruling against President Boris N. Yeltsin in 1993 helped spark a deadly crackdown on the rebellious pro-Communist Parliament, got his old job back, becoming chairman of the Russian Constitutional Court for a second time. As chairman of the court in 1993, he ruled that Mr. Yeltsin's decree dissolving the Parliament was unconstitutional. Rebellious legislators and their allies began an armed uprising in response, and at least 140 people were killed when Mr. Yeltsin ordered tanks to fire on the Parliament. Mr. Zorkin, who was criticized as a Communist sympathizer, resigned soon after. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: U.N. Nuclear Inspection Chief Is Examining Iranian Facilities
description: The director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, Dr. Mohamed ElBaradei, arrived here today on a three-day visit to inspect Iran's nuclear sites, the state television reported.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Telecom Write-Down
description: The Australian telephone company Telstra and the Hong Kong carrier PCCW wrote down the value of their Reach undersea cable venture by $1.55 billion because a drop in prices cut revenue. Telstra will take a $546 million charge against first-half earnings to cut the value of its Reach stake to zero. PCCW will take a charge of 8.26 billion Hong Kong dollars ($1 billion) in its 2002 earnings to reduce the value of its holding.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Search At Plane Crash Site Continues
description: The search for the remains of the 302 soldiers and crew members killed when their military plane crashed in southeastern Iran on Wednesday continued amid storms and fog, the Islamic Republic News Agency reported. Nearly 50 bodies have been found, but the plane's ''black box'' data recorder still has not. The head of the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps, Yahya Safavi, visited the area and urged workers to move quickly. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: Fear on the Home Front
description: With our troops massed against Iraq, Americans are apprehensive and divided. The polls show us still torn between containment and war, between the instinct to give it time and the yearning to get it done. We worry about civilian carnage, American casualties and terrorist reprisals, about further shocks to a shaken economy, about being a nation alone. The Pentagon is ordering body bags by the thousand.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: ECONOMIC INDEX SLIPS An economic index that measures industrial activity fell 0.6 percent in December from November as retail spending slowed. The index, which is known as the all-sector activity index and is a proxy for gross domestic product, slipped 4.1 percent in the October-December quarter. The numbers were in contrast to the strong quarterly G.D.P. figures released last week and suggest that those figures may have to be revised downward.

title: Lessons Learned From Past Use of Ephedra
description: Bill Pulsipher stood 15 feet from Steve Bechler at the Baltimore Orioles' training facility in Fort Lauderdale last Sunday when Bechler collapsed while running sprints. Today, Pulsipher, who was found unconscious by his wife at the Mets' spring training camp three years ago, addressed the fact that he had again crossed paths with the weight-loss supplement ephedra in a life-threatening situation.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: MYANMAR: COURT GIVES NOBEL LAUREATE JAIL SENTENCE A court sentenced Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel Peace Prize winner and opposition leader, to a week in jail over a family dispute, but it suspended the punishment and let her go home. Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi was convicted of unlawful restraint for barring her cousin from the family compound in the capital, Yangon. The chairman of her National League for Democracy Party said the verdict was politically motivated. Earlier, the European Union voiced concern about actions that the Burmese government had taken recently against Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi, who was released in May after 19 months under house arrest.   (Reuters)

title: Rage Against the Machines
description: The ultimate boss of the New York City subway system is the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, but for most riders the face of the transit system is a train operator or, more often, a token booth agent. Unsurprisingly, a plan to replace many of the latter with automation has set off a full-throated howl.

title: Contempt for Allies
description: To the Editor:

title: A Happy Night for Old-Timers Still Singing the Blues
description: Celebrations met reparations at the 13th annual Rhythm & Blues Foundation's Pioneer Awards Ceremony, held on Thursday night at the Manhattan Center Ballroom. The night of blues, pop, soul and funk, sung by musicians whose voices had survived decades of concerts and club gigs, was a deliberate counterpoint to the Grammy Awards tomorrow.

title: Corrections
description: The Feb. 13 bridge column misstated the number of hearts the declarer, Richard Freeman, ruffed in his hand. It was three, not two, and the last ruff left the lead in the South hand.

title: Papers Indicate That Bayer Knew Of Dangers of Its Cholesterol Drug
description: Newly disclosed company documents indicate that some senior executives at Bayer were aware that their anticholesterol drug had serious problems long before the company pulled it from the market.

title: Jordan Is 40 And Fabulous Against Nets
description: The flashbulbs danced around the MCI Center tonight like fireflies on a hot night, recording every Michael Jordan moment for posterity.

title: Fit and Feisty, Mondesi Predicts Big Year Ahead
description: Raul Mondesi's idol is Mike Tyson. Really. ''A lot of people talk about him,'' said Mondesi, the Yankees' right fielder, ''but he does what he wants to do.''

title: 96 Dead in Fire Ignited by Band at Rhode Island Club
description: A raging fire ignited by a rock band's pyrotechnics display ripped through a nightclub here late Thursday night, leaving at least 96 people dead and 187 injured.

title: Judge Criticizes Letter From Bayer
description: A judge in Corpus Christi, Tex., yesterday asked the district attorney to investigate after Bayer sent thousands of letters to residents before jury selection in a lawsuit involving its anticholesterol drug Baycol.

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Child Death Leads To Wider Inquiry
description: The unexplained death of an 18-month-old child prompted state health officials to contact their counterparts in Virginia, who are investigating the mysterious deaths of five children in five days. No one could say if this latest case is connected to the sudden deaths in Virginia first reported by state health officials on Thursday. State officials have ordered an autopsy, said Dr. Jeff Engel, a North Carolina epidemiologist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAUER, LARRY M.
description: SAUER-Larry M., 50. Died on February 20, 2003. President of Cover to Cover Graphic Design. Longstanding member, District 3 School Board. Past President, West 73rd Street Block Association. Past Democratic primary candidate for NYC Council. Past member of Time Square's Square Dancing Club. Enthusiastic supporter of theater community and volunteer tolerance educator with Gay Lesbian Straight Network. Survived and beloved by domestic partner, Dale Henderson. Devoted son of Joseph and Dorothy Sauer. Loving brother of Noreen Levine and Annette Cort. Adored uncle of seven nieces and nephews. Greatuncle of three. Memorial service will be held on Sunday, February 23rd, 3:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at E. 81 St.

title: National Briefing: South
description: GEORGIA: NEW JOB FOR STATE G.O.P. LEADER Ralph Reed, the former leader of the Christian Coalition, is resigning as chairman of the Georgia Republican Party to focus on President Bush's 2004 re-election campaign. When he was elected state chairman in May 2001, Mr. Reed, left, had a right-wing reputation that threatened to hurt state Republicans, but he helped the party sweep the November elections, which gave the state its first Republican governor since Reconstruction, Sonny Perdue. Governor Perdue's choice for a new chairman is Alec Poitevint, who has previously served as party chairman and was treasurer of Mr. Perdue's campaign. (AP)

title: Reparations Formulas
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas last Saturday about Virgina Woolf purists' reaction to the novel and film ''The Hours,'' which center on Woolf's book ''Mrs. Dalloway'' and on Woolf herself, misstated the given name of a writer who was inspired by another classic novel and misstated the plots' time sequence. The author was Jean Rhys, not Jane. Her novel ''Wide Sargasso Sea'' takes place before the action in ''Jane Eyre''; it is not a sequel.

title: Partisan Pit Bull, but Not on the Bench
description: It has been said that Thomas J. Spargo never met a legal or political showdown he did not embrace.

title: Airborne Inc. to Increase Delivery Charges
description: Airborne Inc., the air freight carrier, said today that it would increase charges for plane and truck deliveries to offset the price of jet fuel, which has risen 60 percent since early December.

title: Knicks Drop the Ball On Defense Yet Again
description: Coach Don Chaney has shown the Knicks miles of videotape, highlighted their errors, begged and pleaded for them to improve their defense. But with their offense churning along better than it has in years, the players insist on playing just one end of the floor.

title: Rabbi, Ethics Overseer, Denies Child Pornography Charges
description: Rabbi Israel Kestenbaum, an ethics watchdog for a national pastors association and a chaplain of the year for his work at ground zero, assumed a different role yesterday, that of defendant in a child pornography case.

title: Corrections
description: The ''Hot and Cold'' table in Business Day yesterday, listing stocks with large percentage gains and losses on Thursday, misstated the profit forecast for the drug maker Cephalon. While the company said its first-quarter earnings per share would be 20 cents, below analysts' expectations, it did not issue a warning for the full year.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Documents Indicate Bayer Knew of a Drug's Dangers

title: The Other Baby Experiment
description: There's been a lot of talk from politicians and ethicists about needing to protect children from starting life as medical experiments. It's stunning how much attention is being paid to human cloning, given that most scientists acknowledge it may never be feasible or desirable, let alone commonplace. It's even more amazing when you consider that thousands of children are already being produced each year through potentially dangerous techniques -- with scant notice from policymakers.

title: In China, record companies find new ways to do business : Pop stars learn to live with pirates
description: SHANGHAI:  Dimpled good looks and saccharin-sweet love songs may have made him an idol to millions of teenagers in China, but dark passions emerged at an album-promotion party recently when Wang Lee Hom brandished a sword to slash an oversized compact disk marked with the Chinese character for "theft."

title: Soft-Money Melancholy
description: An unusually encouraging sound can be heard these days in Washington: the whining of professional politicians over the new strictures on runaway soft-money campaign financing.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  AARON, JONATHAN
description: AARON-Jonathan, February 22, 1952-February 24, 2002. Jonny, we love you and miss you. Your Ma, Wendy, Diane, Harold and Marianne.

title: Chirac Pledges French Support for African Prosperity
description: Seeking to renew and extend French ties with Africa, President Jacques Chirac told African leaders at a summit meeting today that France would be a ''tireless advocate'' for their interests and a catalyst for their prosperity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEMAJO, FRITZI
description: DEMAJO-Fritzi. February 20, age 88, of San Diego, CA. Beloved mother of George Reich and sister of Renee Warring. Fritzi survived the Holocaust and worked as an assistant designer in NYC. She spoke several languages fluently. She was a music lover. Donations in her memory may be made to the Alzheimers Association.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: GREEN GRASS GRACE

title: Correction
description: An article on Feb. 9 about the history and revival of the 1950's stage musical ''House of Flowers'' referred erroneously to the show's production by local theater groups after the initial Broadway run. It was not often performed by amateur or stock companies.

title: Image-Conscious
description: MODEL IN THE MIDDLE, BY STEPHANE SEDNAOUI

title: February 16-22: INTERNATIONAL; DISASTER IN KOREA
description: The South Korean subway car conjured up nightmares for mass transit riders around the world: a frame of twisted and scorched metal, burned out seats and ceilings. A morning commute in the city of Taeguturned into an underground inferno when a mentally unstable man, Kim Dae-Han, flicked his cigarette lighter at gasoline in a milk carton. His wish to die with the others came half true. The toll was 133 dead, 146 injured and scores missing. But Mr. Kim walked into a hospital, only to be arrested. James Brooke

title: Nari Matsuura, Benjamin Lewis
description: Nari Matsuura, a consultant and a pianist in New York, is to be married today to Benjamin Lewis, a manager at a New York management consulting concern. The Rev. John Moor, a minister of the United Church of Canada, will officiate at the Fairmont Chteau Laurier, a hotel in Ottawa, with Rabbi B. Susan Stone taking part.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUDLEY, JAMES LAWSON
description: DUDLEY-James Lawson of Westhampton, on February 9, 2003. Survived by his wife Anne ''Cathy'' Pavlak, mother Dorothy L. Dudley of Quiogue, NY, brothers William of Harwood, MD, and Robert of Eastport, NY. A memorial service will be held Saturday, March 1, at 2:00 PM at the Westhampton Presbyterian Church. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to East End Hospice, or the Westhampton Presbyterian Church.

title: A Movie Star Takes the Stage, Bowing to Fellini
description: FOURTEEN years!'' Antonio Banderas marveled one bright Sunday morning in late January. ''I can't believe I've been away from the theater so long. For years I've been numb to it. The movies are very persuasive, for the money you make and your projection into the world. But theater is my passion, especially musical theater. I've never been on Broadway before. And I feel like I've come home.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSMAN, WILLIAM
description: SUSMAN-William. A veteran of The Abraham Lincoln Brigade and a founder of The Abraham Lincoln Brigade Archives, Bill is deeply mourned as an activist for social justice, a film producer, and a husband, father, and grandfather, by his wife Helene of Great Neck, NY, his daughter Susan and her husband Sekhar of New York City, his son Paul and his wife Libby of Lewisburg, PA, and his grandchildren Janak, Rebecca, Shantha and Sasha.

title: February 16-22; A Crucial Nod From Turkey
description: AFTER a week of tense negotiations, Bush administration officials said they had won approval from Turkish negotiators for a $15 billion package of economic aid that they expected would ultimately allow American combat troops to use the country for an attack on Iraq.

title: State Begins Releasing Names of the People Killed in Club Inferno
description: The woman shivered in this afternoon's cold rain, running her hand through blond hair that was very much like the hair of the daughter she had just lost. An hour earlier, state officials had released seven names in what was only the first wave of the identified dead, and among them was one name that she had called out so many times over the years: Bridget.

title: New Jersey Sisters Retain Titles
description: The twins Kate and Amanda Trotter, the Red Bank Regional High School seniors who are bound for Stanford University, scored repeat triumphs at the New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association's 38th annual Meet of Champions yesterday at Princeton's Jadwin Gymnasium.

title: In Club Fire, Finger-Pointing and Task of Naming the Dead
description: WEST WARWICK, R.I., Feb. 22  The finger-pointing over the fire that roared through a nightclub here Thursday night intensified today, as the authorities deepened their investigation and struggled with the grim task of identifying the dead.

title: Pilgrim State Contractor Took Anti-Union Acts
description: A Great Neck company hired last year to remove asbestos from the Pilgrim Psychiatric Center site illegally harassed and fired workers for supporting a union, an administrative law judge ruled this month.

title: Self-Consciousness Strikes Out
description: DANIEL SUNJATA doesn't see himself as having much in common with the character he portrays in ''Take Me Out,'' the play opening on Thursday at the Walter Kerr Theater on Broadway after a successful run at the Joseph Papp Public Theater. His character, Darren Lemming, is an all-star major league baseball player who talks matter-of-factly about his ''Godlike attributes'' -- ''I'm young and rich and famous and talented and handsome'' -- and who, at the top of his game, decides one day to hold a news conference and announce that he is also gay.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARZER, ELLEN
description: SCHWARZER - Ellen. Be loved wife of Edward. Devoted mother of Karen, and Suzanne Schwarzer Lagle. Loving sister of Josiah Schneider and sister-in-law of Janet Schneider. Loving mother-inlaw, grandmother and aunt. Services private. Contributions may be made to Jacob Perlow Hospice, 317 East 17th Street, NYC 10003.

title: Say, 'Cheesecake'
description: Watching the superstar rapper Eve take an inspired turn as a 1940's pinup girl on an elaborately built set in SoHo, I am hard pressed to remember how groundbreaking these photos really are. Back when the illustrator Alberto Vargas was reshaping the American standard of beauty in the pages of Esquire magazine, sisters were hardly part of the picture. ''Separate but equal'' applied not only to water fountains and classrooms, but also to beauty contests and gas-station pinups.

title: Preparing For the Unthinkable
description: THE first wave was panic, in the days after Tom Ridge, secretary of Homeland Security, told Americans it was time to prepare for a terrorist attack.

title: Don't Put Your Wife in a Novel
description: THE SPOOKY ART

title: Sweet Tunes, Fast Beats and a Hard Edge
description: Chuck Berry is seated backstage listening to the crowd gather at Blueberry Hill, a music club and bar in the Loop area on this city's west side. Once a month, Mr. Berry, known universally as the father of rock 'n' roll, performs downstairs in the cramped Duck Room, named for the famous duck walk he has performed around the world for nearly 50 years.

title: Heightened Tensions Touch South Korea Troops
description: It was not all that long ago that Capt. Andre Toussaint assumed that for the next few months, at least, his assignment here would be just about the safest overseas posting in the United States Army.

title: Venture Capital Totaled $65.6 Million Last Year

title: Phoenix
description: Pack your baseball glove and your hiking boots if you're headed to Phoenix. Cactus League spring training, in March, provides an opportunity to catch a home run hit by such greats as Barry Bonds and Sammy Sosa. There is also an abundance of wild terrain within and on the edges of the city, and late winter and early spring are the best times to hit the trail. Six mountain parks, totaling about 26,000 acres, lie within the city limits, and another five mountain-studded recreation areas form a wider ring around it.

Donna Karan was a guest critic at the Parsons School of Design when I attended some 20 years ago, and within 10 minutes of her critique, we all knew she was a Libra with a Virgo ascendant. To this day the first thing she asks me when I run into her is whether I've been to see Maria Napoli, a psychic we both consult, a favorite of the fashion clan.

title: Analyzing Quarterbacks for Pro Qualities
description: The air at a scouting combine feels different when a quarterback walks into the room. There is electricity, even in his handshake. His words are tinged with the confidence of a college football career often spent in the warm glow of victory.

description: AS CHIEF EXECUTIVE of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, the largest arts organization in the state, Lawrence Goldman was among a handful of leaders in the arts recently invited to Governor McGreevey's office on the day before the governor went public with his proposed budget. Mr. Goldman knew that being summoned to Trenton could mean only bad news, but no one in the room knew how bad until the governor told the group that he would recommend eliminating all state funds for arts.

title: Class Clown Makes Good, Quietly
description: TO audiences at the current revival of August Wilson's ''Ma Rainey's Black Bottom,'' Anthony Mackie is the young man who, in a show lasting some three hours, basically has just one line. His character, the singer Ma Rainey's stuttering nephew, is supposed to say the line as an introduction to one of the songs being recorded, and he repeats it over and over, trying to do it without stammering, in a performance that Howard Kissel in The Daily News called ''funny and touching.''

title: Tough Times for the State Animal
description: VALERIE BORNSTEIN still sounds wistful when she talks about the 12.7-acre horse boarding farm that her family once owned here. ''My parents bought the property in 1945,'' Ms. Bornstein recalled. ''In about 1955 we had a horse and then sometime around 1970 or so we added another 16 stalls. In Bergen County, people who bought a horse got a boarding stable. We always had a huge waiting list. We bred thoroughbreds, one a year.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILENITZ, ISRAEL
description: WILENITZ-Israel. Of Greenwich Village and East Setauket, on February 20, 2003. For fifty-one years, he was the adored husband of Evelyn Berezin, the light of his life. Beloved uncle to Sara Selms and Joan Schulman and cherished brother of Solomon and Mina Bar-Sinai, of Sidney and Miriam Berezin, June Rovenger and his many nieces, nephews, cousins and friends. Born in London in 1922, he came to the U.S. in 1951. He earned a Ph.D in Chemical Engineering at Brooklyn Polytech and worked in many parts of the world. His lifelong interest in linguistics led to a Master's Degree at age 74. He will be missed by all who enjoyed his ready wit and keen mind and who marveled at the breadth of his knowledge. Services were held on Friday, February 21 at Riverside Memorial Chapel in NYC. Shiva will be observed through Sunday at his home in NYC. Contributions can be made in Israel's name to the Hematology Research Fund, c/o Dr. Bruce Raphael, 530 1st Ave, Room 9N, NY, NY 10016.

I thus became the lyricist to whom the project was, to quote Green, ''farmed out,'' and the song that resulted, with music by the show's composer, Harold Arlen, was called ''Indoor Girl.'' title: In Athens, Ouzo Sweetens Life
description: OUZO, the aniseed spirit that Greeks consider a national treasure, is a licorice-tasting aperitif that can have a potent effect -- its alcohol content can be as high as 46 percent, or 92 proof. Clear and colorless, ouzo becomes cloudy once water or ice is added -- the way Hellenes prefer ouzo, to dilute its strength. As you sip it, siga, siga (slowly, slowly), and munch on mezedes (snacks), ouzo will stimulate appetite, slacken the pace and sweeten the mind.

description: TONIGHT in Manhattan, rock stars, divas and rappers will descend en masse on Madison Square Garden, arriving at the Grammy ceremonies in a parade of glamour and attitude. title: History Isn't a Matter of Black or White
description: Is Black History Month really necessary? Or is it just a convenient time slot for teachers and television programmers to cram in material on Martin Luther King and Malcolm X so they don't have to worry about African-American issues for the rest of the year? And if Black History Month is so important, then why, asks a teenager in tonight's edition of ''Nick News,'' does it have to be relegated to February, ''the shortest month of the year''? And why, asks another, are there not months devoted to Asian-American history or Hispanic history?

title: Streetscapes/Manhattan School of Music, 122nd Street Between Claremont Avenue and Broadway; A Campus With a Century of Architectural Design
description: THE Manhattan School of Music, on 122nd Street between Claremont Avenue and Broadway, offers a kaleidoscope of urban architecture -- a richly styled Edwardian building from 1910, a sleek 1930's Art Deco addition by the architects of the Empire State Building, an ultramodern 1960's expansion and a nuanced 2001 residence hall that responds to the older structures, though not slavishly. The four-building ensemble, built over nearly a century, is one of the richest architectural compositions in the city.

title: The Gallery Owner
description: For 20 years, Dan Ferrara worked as a top-level editor at adrenaline-charged magazines like Outside and Men's Journal. Two months ago, he traded words for pictures to open Big Cat Gallery, a warm, spare white space on the Lower East Side (154 Orchard Street, 212-982-6210). "I want it to be friendly to people who are not well versed in the gallery world," said Mr. Ferrara, 43, who has collected art for 10 years. "I want people to feel comfortable and stay awhile."

title: Extending The Shelf Life Of Off Brands
description: AS shows like ''Friends'' and ''Sex and the City'' have made all too clear, the metaphysical search for truth and beauty that New Yorkers call shopping most often follows a trail of clothes and cosmetics. But farther afield -- in Ridgefield, Conn., say -- it is not Manolo Blahnik slingbacks or Prada bags that induce frissons. No, shopping there means something else: supermarket.

title: Tangled Up in Spam
description: The most obvious answer to the spam problem is charging postage for e-mail. A charge of as little as one-tenth of one cent would be unnoticeable to most users -- you would have to average 30 e-mail messages a day to approach a cost of $1 per month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, WARD L. JR.
description: JOHNSON-Ward L. Jr. Age 81, of Essex, CT, and Cold Spring Harbor, NY, died in his sleep February 20, 2003. Loving husband of Jean Taylor Johnson; devoted father of Pamela, Timothy, Taylor and Brown; proud grandfather of Sara, Katharine, William and Louisa; great-grandfather of Ian. Graduate of the Kent School and member of St. Anthony Hall at Williams College Class of '43, WWII Army Air Force, avid sailor, navigator, and a great civic leader. He worked at J.C. Penny, Help Start Purnell School, and founded Asset Management. Mentor and friend to many. Service Monday, February 24, 2003 at 11AM, St. John's Episcopal Church, Main and Cross Streets, Essex, CT.

description: When Lauren Fortmiller, the Sag Harbor mayor, announced this month that she would not seek a second term in office, she emphasized that the decision had nothing to do with any political fallout from recent publicity over the civil union ceremony she participated in with her partner, Pamela Thiele.

title: Private Sector; A Few Months in Washington And He's a Changed Man
description: It was his first public speech as President Bush's economic adviser, but for Stephen Friedman, the event was more like a nervous coming-home party. On Friday, Mr. Friedman, who spent decades on Wall Street before accepting the administration's adviser position in December, spoke to a half-full auditorium at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. He promoted the White House's economic plan and asked the audience of executives and investors to do the same.

title: Employee-Owned Place Aims to Please
description: WHEN employees own their own restaurant, is the service better? I would have said yes after my first visit to J's Seafood. The Great Neck spot had recently changed from being part of a Cincinnati-based chain to local ownership by the staff. That night, our savvy waitress could not have been better: She was familiar with all the ins and outs of the menu, knew who ordered each dish and brought appropriate replacement silver. The speed with which our meal was served was almost startling.

title: Alexander The Great
description: 'I think McQueen wants to be a bird -- and he's as wild as one, too,'' declares Isabella Blow, a woman with enough original style to stop you in your tracks, and one of the last true English eccentrics. ''He's basically a little explosive cockerel,'' she continues. ''If someone tickles his feathers in the right way, he'll do whatever they want. It's a question of tickling under the belly -- he's all about feelings, McQueen.''

title: Rain-Soaked Roofs Collapse in Washington Area
description: The roof of a Toys 'R' Us store collapsed this morning under the weight of snow and heavy rain, injuring nine people, apparently none seriously.

title: It's In The Cards
description: At the spring shows in Milan and Paris, the fashion media's pastime du jour was a tarot reading, using invitations to the day's shows in lieu of tarot cards. Of the new visionaries, Heath Brown -- the fashion director of The Times Magazine in London -- is considered the prince of the paranormal. After shuffling the deck, Brown lays out the top eight invitations face down in the shape of a Celtic cross and reads your past, present and future, according to which designer appears as he turns them over. For example, Martine Sitbon in your past means you're likely to be respected but ignored. Hussein Chalayan in your present suggests you're likely to drown in your own melancholy, while bad juju lies ahead for anyone who draws the embattled Julien Macdonald for Givenchy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAPIRA, BENNO
description: SCHAPIRA-Benno. Of Weston, CT, died Thursday, February 20. He had an extensive and varied career as a world class photographer, international commodity banker and successful investor. He was known for his discriminating taste in art and wine, as well as his love of travel and gourmet cooking. He is survived by his wife Stephanie; their children, Liesel and Jimmy; his sons, Charles and Robert and a granddaughter, Alexis. The funeral will be held on Monday, February 24, at 1 PM, at the Unitarian Church, 10 Lyons Plains Rd in Westport. Donations may be made in his memory to the Museum of Tolerance, Simon Wiesenthal Center, 1399 South Roxbury, Los Angeles, CA 90035.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: MIDNIGHT SUN -- A.A.R.P. members can save $100 a person by booking a Norwegian Coastal Voyage cruise package to Greenland or Spitsbergen by March 31. The trips, including round-trip air fare, hotel stays with breakfast, land excursions, and air and port taxes, range from 9 to 12 days and take place June 1 to Aug. 24. The discount is in addition to the regular A.A.R.P. member reduction of $100 a cabin. Ships range from the 92-passenger Brand Polaris to the 164-passenger Nordstjernen. A nine-day trip to Spitsbergen, an island between Norway and the North Pole, with a four-day cruise, ranges from $3,785 to $4,890 a person, double occupancy before the discounts. A 12-day program in Greenland and Iceland, with an eight-day cruise, is $3,375 to $7,080 a person, double. Naturalist guides give lectures and lead Zodiac excursions; (800) 323-7436 or on the Web at www.coastalvoyage.com.

Over a few months, they had bulked up considerably, and Mr. Stout suspects they are using nutritional supplements to achieve their new physiques.

title: The World; Europe's Highs and Lows Depend on Where You Stand
description: ''DE haut en bas'' -- from high to low, or from the lofty to the lowly -- is a signature phrase of French culture. The Parisians seem to know better than anyone else in the world how to look down their noses, but when President Jacques Chirac of France poured his scorn on the governments of Eastern Europe last week, he did so from a greater than usual height.

title: Potential Oil Spill Is Averted in L.I. Sound
description: THE Coast Guard is investigating why a barge carrying two million gallons of home heating oil from New York Harbor to Port Jefferson struck a charted rock reef in Long Island Sound earlier this month, rupturing six of its 12 tanks and raising fears of a major spill that could have reached the North Shore of Long Island.

title: Anxiety Rides the A Train
description: JUST as many New Yorkers were trying to memorize the smell of nerve gas -- was it Juicy Fruit or bitter almonds? -- we learned that the average terrorist doesn't need access to Saddam's stockpiles. As the attack in the South Korean subway last week proved, all you need is a milk carton, some paint thinner and a cigarette lighter. I realize the Korean arsonist was mentally deranged, not technically a terrorist. But with his primitive weapon, he killed at least 125 people. The 1995 attack with sarin nerve gas in the Tokyo subway killed only 12.

title: Spanish Harlem on His Mind
description: EL Barrio. In my childhood its mere mention conjured all kinds of feelings, from a kind of reverence for proud beginnings to my parents' wariness of its slow descent into hard times. It was a magic Spanish phrase that fell easily from my father's lips, a reference to a place that curiously seemed to belong to us, even though New York didn't belong to us. As more of us moved to various corners of the Bronx, El Barrio increasingly became the source of authenticity, like the bacalaitos (codfish fritters) on 116th Street that were the closest thing to what you could get on the island.

title: 'Property'
description: IT NEVER ENDS. I watched him through the spyglass to see what the game would be. There were five of them. He gets them all gathered at the river's edge and they are nervous. If they haven't done this before, they've heard about it. First he reads to them from the Bible. I don't have to hear it to know what passage it is. Then they have to strip, which takes no time as they are wearing only linen pantaloons. One by one they must grasp the rope, swing over the water, and drop in. It's brutally hot; the cool water is a relief, so they make the best of it. He encourages them to shout and slap at one another once they are in the water. Then they have to come out and do it again, only this time they hang on the rope two at a time, which means one has to hold on to the other. They had gotten this far when I looked.

title: 'Almost There'
description: IF I HAD BEEN ASKED TO REPORT ON middle age when I was halfway through my fifties, I would have said that it was too bleak to talk about. Much too bleak if you believed, as I passionately did, that your life has been a failure. I seemed successful, I knew-I was an opinion columnist with an Irish newspaper, and columnists are not nobodies. But when I looked at the private side of my life, all I could feel was regret, and all I could see was what was missing. I had no child, and no other creation. I didn't have a partner. I didn't have a lover, however provisional, and I didn't have any appetite for one. I occasionally saw my sisters and brothers who lived near me, but I didn't think of them as a resource for everyday living. Our father had been a big fish in a small pond because he was the first journalist in Dublin to write a daily social diary about the receptions and parties and formal events that happened around the town every night. His dapper, charming figure, usually wearing evening dress, had been welcome everywhere he went. Not so, my poor mother. She was a shy, lonely woman, the inefficient manageress of wherever we happened to be living, a bookworm who, when she added drinking to reading, could escape the reality of nine children and a husband she was in love with but could not trust. Over the years, we watched our father become more sought after and our mother become a hopeless alcoholic. Worry about her became a bond between us when she was left a widow, but once she died too, the family didn't seem to have any function. Anyway, I felt that at the age of fifty-five I shouldn't be depending on the family I came from; I should have made a circle of my own. As it was, I didn't even have the company of colleagues in a workplace because I wrote my columns from home. And the truth was that I made no effort to find company. Every night I quietly drank just a bit too much wine, and other people would have interfered with that. There were only ten years to go till retirement from the paper. But what would I retire for? I had no savings, and because I'd only just joined the staff I wasn't going to have much of a pension. I had no plans anyway. My job with The Irish Times was much the best thing I had.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOROWIK, ANGELA
description: BOROWIK-Angela. On February 20, 2003, age 100. Devoted wife of the late Lucian. Loving mother of Joan Kolobielski and Thomas Borowik. Grandmother of six. Greatgrandmother of four. Born in Poland, daughter of Abraham Gepner, a well-known elder of the Warsaw Ghetto. She escaped Nazi tyranny and shepherded her family to the New World. In New York she created a safe haven for family and fellow refugees. We will remember her tenacity, courage, intelligence, sense of humor, esthetic zeal and family loyalty. She has not really left us, for she is alive in our hearts.

Then the next movement or piece reaffirms his ability to create music of stirring simplicity and power. He is one part meticulous Old World craftsman, one part provocateur.

title: Ethnomathematics

Bloomberg has elicited something just short of vituperation. Back-to-basics advocates denounce as ''fuzzy math'' its inclusion of so-called constructivist teaching techniques. Critics complain that those approaches encourage self-discovery and collaborative problem-solving at the expense of proved practices like memorization, repetition and mastery of algorithm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLON, IRWIN T.
description: DILLON-Irwin T. Born 1906 in Toronto, Canada, passed away surrounded by his family January 13, 2003 at the age of 96. A graduate of University of Toronto and New York University. He became a leading tenor with New York City Opera in the '40's under Lazlo Halasz after years of touring Canada and U.S. with leading Oratorio societies and numerous radio performances. He sang with Columbia Concerts 1944 to 1945. At NYCO he sang Don Jose in Carmen, Turiddu in Cavalleria Rusticana and Pinkerton to Camilla Williams in Madama Butterfly. His many concert conductors included A. Dorati, E. Leinsdorf, H. Von Karajan, L. Stokowski, A. Toscanini and A. Rodzinski. In 1947 he sang three historic performances of Elektra with Marjorie Lawrence-her first performance standing after a six-year battle with polio. On April 3, 1948, he sang Beethoven's Symphony No. 9 with the NBC Symphony televised. His final performances of Wozzeck were in October 1952 at NYCO. He joined Irving Trust Co. in '52 and retired in '69. Lived in Coral Springs, FL, and last seven years in CA. Survived by daughters Patricia of Garden City, NY and Mary Jane of Dana Point, CA, three grandchildren and two great grandsons. Interment at Our Lady Queen of Heaven, Ft. Lauderdale, FL, February 1, 2003.

I was the first person who disobeyed them and built a steel interlocking retaining wall -- the same wall that was shown in your cover photograph [''Back From the Edge,'' Feb. 2] -- to protect my home, 661 Dune Road. My two neighbors were also fed up with the town and joined me in this huge effort, at huge expense, to save their homes as well. This was approximately 20 years ago. title: Thoroughly Modern, Once Upon a Time
description: GEN. WILLIAM PAULDING, the mayor of New York City, retired in 1838 to his grand new Gothic Revival mansion built in the wilds of Tarrytown, without sacrificing a jot of urban comfort. Jay Gould, the railroad baron who moved there 42 years later and named the house Lyndhurst, added more amenities, including up-to-date plumbing.

title: An Unfinished Woman
description: A slim volume falls into my hands, an artifact from a lost civilization: ''The Beautiful People's Beauty Book,'' by Princess Luciana Pignatelli, copyright 1970. Though an as-told-to book, it retains the Italian author's idiosyncratic syntax and let-them-eat-cake attitude. (On the danger of not keeping up with beauty routines: ''You take away this, take away that, and in six months you look like a cook.'') Inscrutable recipes for facial masks (''one tablespoon of lanolin and one teaspoon of Balsam of Peru, mixed until smooth'') jostle with enigmatic glimpses of la dolce vita (''Last year in Sardinia, where we all ended up nude on a deserted beach, I put my bikini on my face'').

title: Iraqi Kurds Are Wary Of a Turkish-Led Force

Nevertheless, the governor issued a public pat on the back last week to the state School Construction Corporation, an agency poised to spend $111 million next year trying to repair the New Jersey's aging schools.

title: In the Region/Westchester; A $3 Million Upgrade at Arts Center in Purchase
description: WHAT to do with a windowless, brown brick building from the 1970's that looks, at least according to some theatergoers, more like a nuclear power plant than a performing arts center? The answer decided upon recently by the board at the Performing Arts Center at Purchase College: spend $3 million to make it more welcoming to audiences.

title: Sun, Again, Bets Against the Odds
description: SCOTT G. McNEALY, the chief executive of Sun Microsystems, was pacing the stage in San Francisco two weeks ago, working hard to stir up enthusiasm in the crowd for his company's new products. The litany of offerings was long and impressive -- data serving computers of all kinds, graphics workstations, storage networks, software. The implicit message was clear: Sun, though battered by the high-technology slump, is still churning out new products and new ideas.

title: Fire Inspections Are Increased After Disasters
description: The fire department here stepped up inspections of nightclubs this weekend in response to a stampede that killed 21 people here and a fire that killed nearly 100 people in Rhode Island this week. The police, meanwhile, continued to sort out conflicting accounts of the stampede, at a South Loop club, early last Monday.

title: Setting Higher Goals for Farmingdale State

title: There's More to Trading Oil Than Handicapping a War

But the lagging prices of oil-company stocks illustrate just how tricky it can be to speculate in the energy sector.

title: In the African Sun While Dark Came Over Europe
description: ''WHEN I first read the book 'Nowhere in Africa,' I was fascinated by it,'' said the German director Caroline Link. ''I was caught up by the story it told of a woman from a protected Jewish family who suddenly has to live in the middle of the African desert. I've always loved to discover new worlds with my movies, but I remember thinking to myself: 'Wow, can I do this? Will I really be able to shoot a movie in Kenya?' ''

title: 'Little Infamies'

He could not imagine then that the poor animal was only trying to warn him. Because no sooner had he washed his dish, fed the leftovers to the chickens, and sat on the veranda to drink a glass of wine, than a roar like the beating of an enormous vat echoed across the village. Father Yerasimo watched with fascination as his glass toppled, and the red wine spilled over the table.

Young women, flushed after two merlots, push away their half-eaten plates and shake their shoulders to the music. The men manage both to eat voraciously and to dart their eyes around the room at the women. Call it the bewitching hour.

title: If the Nurse Resembles Warhol, There's a Reason
description: IN her 20-year career, Julee Cruise has played many roles entirely unconnected to theater. ''I approach everything as an acting piece, though,'' Ms. Cruise, a singer and actress, said recently. ''Supplying the singing for the song 'Mysteries of Love' in David Lynch's 'Blue Velvet'? Acting. That soft little voice isn't me; I'm actually a belter. My work with the B-52's? More acting. Their front man, Fred Schneider, saw me in this awful musical here in New York, where I had to play five instruments, speak in Shakespearean pentameter and sing rock 'n' roll. Not very many of us who can do that. Next thing I know, I'm replacing their lead singer, Cindy Wilson, while she's on maternity leave.''

title: Domains: Daniel Boulud
description: Congratulations on a fresh and creative addition to the magazine (The Way We Live Now, Feb. 9). ''Domains'' will undoubtedly become a ''turn to'' destination for many readers, a lighthearted yet insightful supplement to our Sunday routine. However, for the extensive range of questions posed, there was one vital query noticeable for its absence: What newspaper do you read?

The producer behind one of the biggest celebrities -- Emeril Lagasse -- at the Food Network is a lifetime resident of New Jersey, Rochelle Brown. And she has written a book, ''The Chef, the Story and the Dish'' (Stewart, Tabori & Chang, 2002), that gives an insider's portrayal of 20 acclaimed chefs, Emeril included.

But disclosure could mean losing patients and business. What should he do? Anonymous, Pennsylvania

title: The Anti-Anti-American
description: In the fall of 1983 I enrolled at Oxford University on a prestigious two-year fellowship meant to promote international understanding. Naturally, I expected a warm welcome. With my newly minted diploma in English literature, my German, French and Spanish pocket dictionaries and my made-in-Scotland tweed jacket with leather elbow patches, I considered myself an apprentice global citizen. Yes, I'd grown up in small-town Midwestern America, where I'd gobbled Big Macs, driven pickups and handled firearms, but I'd overcome those limitations. I'd studied Hegel. I'd signed petitions for Greenpeace. I knew what Dadaism was.

title: Heroine Chic

As surreptitious as she is soigne, she turns occasionally to see if she is being followed. She sneaks into a stranger's apartment but is soon interrupted by a man in a suit and bowler hat; a tussle ensues. But when this international woman of mystery emerges from the struggle, she is inexplicably sporting a black beehive, cat suit and leather boots, a quiver of weapons strapped to her back.

A sari-clad woman with piercing dark eyes and raven-black hair knotted in one long braid was sitting in the front of a classroom, beating out a complex rhythm with a wooden stick.

title: February 16-22: NATIONAL; NIGHTCLUB PANIC

In West Warwick, R.I., the band Great White set off fireworks without a permit in the Station, a small club with low ceilings and no sprinklers, igniting the Styrofoam soundproofing into a quick-spreading blaze. At 16, he learned that a favorite novel, ''The Wind in the Willows,'' was going to be staged by a Birmingham, Ala., children's theater. He bought a ticket.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHER, RAMSAY M.B.
description: FISCHER-Ramsay M.B. Age 86 of Mantoloking, NJ formerly of Bronxville, NY and Wynnewood, PA, died on February 14. He was a member of Squadron A (NY), serving in the 101st Calvary in a horse troop and later with the British Admiralty Technical Mission during W.W. II. He was predeceased by his older brother Charles S. Fischer II of Bronxville, NY and Bay Head, NJ. He is survived by his wife of 55 years Elisabeth, and a sister Elise Wilde formerly of Nutley, NJ and Mantoloking, now of Bedford, MA, a daughter and son-in-law Barbara and Joseph DeAmicis of Mantoloking, a son and daughter-in-law Peter Fischer and Carol Jackson of Bristol, ME, two grandchildren, T.C. and Morgan DeAmicis and four nephews and two nieces.

title: FOOTNOTES
description: 1. In Western art, monkeys often represent human foibles and desires. Painters as diverse as George Stubbs, Henri Rousseau, Teniers the Younger and Andy Warhol have all relied on monkeys at one point or another as allegories for lust, sin, folly and plain old silliness. The New York painter and primate lover Hunt Slonem has been including them in his signature flora-and-fauna canvases for 30 years. He once shared a downtown loft with Shanti, Lakshmi and Hanuman, the squirrel monkeys depicted here (a) in a recent oil painting. (Needless to say, the landlord said, it's them or you.) Meanwhile, the red-hot winner of the Turner Prize, Chris Ofili, did a twist on the Last Supper in his London show last summer with 12 lushly painted monkey ''apostles'' surrounding a monkey ''Jesus.'' And if that's not wacky enough, there is Donald Roller Wilson's old-master style monkeys (b), which are collected by such Hollywood heavyweights as Carrie Fisher, Robin Williams and Kevin Kline (www.donaldrollerwilson.com).

title: Thankfully, Ballet Is Not Quite a Universal Language
description: SEVERAL years ago, when I used to visit New York from Paris, where I lived, it would take several trips to the New York City Ballet before I began to enjoy the dancing. Having grown accustomed to the impeccable lines and disciplined elegance of the Paris Opera Ballet, I would initially perceive the American dancers as wild and disorderly, hurling themselves into the dance with what appeared to be reckless disregard for symmetry or grace. Then my eye would adjust to their way of moving, and I would appreciate anew their energy and abandon and the wonderful ballets that they could perform as no other company could.

title: A Sad Ballad for the Water-Pipe Cafes of Astoria
description: New York has no official Little Middle East, but the two blocks of Steinway Street between 28th Avenue and Astoria Boulevard in Queens come close. Yemeni, Moroccans, Egyptians and other Arab immigrants live, work and shop along this strip. Bookstores such as IPCI (International Publications of Islamic Culture) sell copies of the Koran, and the windows of delis are lined with big, green cans of ghee, the clarified butter popular in Middle Eastern cuisine. The signs for the barber, the tailor and the dentist are all in Arabic. At Laziza (Arabic for ''delicious'') Bakery, the favorite is savory, sweet kanafa, a Palestinian dessert of pomegranate juice and white cheese atop thin pastry.

The N.F.L. combine, under way in Indianapolis this weekend, is a meat market with feet, an unwieldy mass of nearly every executive and coach in the league, congealed with the top 300 or so pro prospects. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEFFNER, HOWARD M.
description: HEFFNER-Howard M., 81. Died after a brief illness at his home in Carlsbad, CA. on February 17, 2003. With him were Rosella, his beloved wife of 60 years, their sons Kenneth and Scott, and daughters-in-law Susan and Sherri. A native of New York City who during WWII was in the Army Air Force, Mr. Heffner served on the Carlsbad Traffic Safety Commission, as President of the Sea Cliff Homeowners Association, and as a member of the League of Women Voters.

title: 'Looking for Spinoza'
description: Feelings of pain or pleasure or some quality in between are the bedrock of our minds. We often fail to notice this simple reality because the mental images of the objects and events that surround us, along with the images of the words and sentences that describe them, use up so much of our overburdened attention. But there they are, feelings of myriad emotions and related states, the continuous musical line of our minds, the unstoppable humming of the most universal of melodies that only dies down when we go to sleep, a humming that turns into all-out singing when we are occupied by joy, or a mournful requiem when sorrow takes over.*

He was cheering his listeners, thumping his chest and celebrating Muhammad Ali all at once.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRIEGEL, REGINA
description: KRIEGEL-Regina. On February 15, 2003. Devoted wife of the late Samuel Goldfield and the late Jacob Kriegel. Beloved mother of Esther and Hal Pollock, Yitzchak Goldfield, Rita and Sy Rotter, and Ruth & Sheldon Kriegel. Dear sister of Clara Rongil and the late Josef Halpern. Cherished grandmother, great-grandmother and aunt. Born in Poland in 1907, she grew up in Holland and settled in Belgium. Armed with courage and foresight, she rescued herself, her husband, and her two young children from Hitler's Holocaust. A true eshet chayil, she was untiring in her lifelong support of the Zionist movement, the State of Israel and of the Jewish people. Hadassah was her passion and she gave to that organization energy, time, and her vast knowledge of Judaica during five decades. She was unique: wise, witty, insightful, charming, generous and loving; and a role model and inspiration to her family and to all who knew her.

title: Repress Yourself
description: You've been in therapy for years.You've time-traveled back to your childhood home, to your mother's makeup mirror with its ring of pearl lights. You've uncovered, or recovered, the bad baby sitter, his hands on you, and yet still, you're no better. You feel foggy and low; you flinch at intimate touch; you startle at even the slightest sounds, and you are impaired. Hundreds of sessions of talk have led you here, back to the place you started, even though you've followed all advice. You have self-soothed and dredged up; you have cried and curled up; you have aimed for integration in your fractured, broken brain.

title: Knit Picking
description: When she was in her early 20's, Anne Rubin went to Paris on holiday, and her father, who was a furrier in Beverly Hills, asked her to buy him a white beaded handbag to accessorize the coats in his shop. It was around 1950 -- Rubin, who is now in her 70's, is vague on dates -- and she disparaged the idea of purchasing anything as dull as a white beaded bag. ''I thought, Oh, how corny,'' she recalled recently in her showroom in the garment district in Manhattan. A onetime model, Rubin wore black leggings and a long black T-shirt, but her beautiful face was expertly made up, and her blond hair was carefully poufed around a black headband. ''I thought, My father can go down the street to Saks and get something ordinary like a beaded bag. Instead, I saw these bags made out of religious tapestries, and I took three back to my hotel in Paris.''

title: Children Should Be Taught In Gender-Neutral Ways

They are learning that boys perform science experiments while girls play at dress-up or cooking. Isn't it about time that we realize that boys and girls are children? Science experiments, dramatic activities, make-believe cooking and reading should be gender-neutral activities. And, as a bonus, attitude changes don't cost extra dollars.

title: Planet Ghana
description: From the mid-1980's until the mid-90's, the highways and byways of Ghana were dotted with movie posters painted on flour sacks and rough canvas. These sideshow banners were unfurled on the roadsides to advertise a new form of traveling cinema, as local entrepreneurs took the marvels of Hollywood, Bollywood and Hong Kong into the hinterlands via portable generators, VCR's and TV monitors. Western-style paper posters were neither plentiful nor tough enough to withstand the rigors of life on the road, so recycled 50-kilo canvas flour sacks -- split, joined and rolled on a dowel for transport -- became the lingua franca of this new art form.
