title: Fortress America
description: In the last several weeks, as preparations for the war against Iraq have heated up, it has begun to sink in that this will be a different conflict from what we have seen before -- that there may, in fact, be two fronts, one far away on the ground in the Middle East, the other right here at home. For the first time in history, it seems plausible that an enemy might mount a sustained attack on the United States, using weapons of terrorism. The term ''soft targets,'' which refers to everyday places like offices, shopping malls, restaurants and hotels, is now casually dropped into conversation, the way military planners talk about ''collateral damage.''

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2003 Lincoln Aviator; Now, a Scale Model Of Lincoln's Big Rig

title: Real Thoughts and Fictional Thinking

This complaint was made by the critics known as the New York intellectuals; a cynic might say that theirs was the now familiar wish of American minorities to be ''represented.'' ''The intellectual is the only character missing in the American novel,'' Philip Rahv wrote. Mary McCarthy made her case at a higher level of abstraction -- her book ''Ideas and the Novel'' attacked American squeamishness about explicit thought -- but she also maintained that ''if you are going to voice ideas in a novel, plainly you will need a spokesman.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UTZ, EDWARD C.
description: UTZ-Edward C., 76. A Westport, CT resident, since 1968, died at his home on February 11, 2003. Ed was a beloved husband and devoted father, an avid tennis player, a dedicated little league umpire, and a dear friend to all who knew and loved him. He was a private man with many public convictions. A native of the Bronx, he attended Mt. St. Michael High School and City College of New York. He was awarded his Juris Doctor from New York Law School, and was a member of the New York Bar. After working at the FBI, he joined ITT, where he rose to become president of the Wire and Cable Division in Pawtucket, RI. He was the president of Keene Corporation in New York City and later joined W. R. Grace at their headquarters. Upon retiring, he tirelessly lobbied for better compensation for victims of asbestos-related injuries. Mr. Utz is survived by his wife, Rose Ruddy; his seven daughters, Lisbeth Angeli, Jamie Utz, Claire Zielinski, Christine Romann, Barbara Argentino, Cathy Utz Greenwald, Jennifer Worsfold, and his son Edward Utz Jr. His twenty grandchildren are Philip, David, Eric, Paul and Daniel Angeli; Christopher and Chiara Bargagna; John-Dylan, William, and Lili Romann; Juliana, John and Christine Argentino; Charlie, Joseph and Jack Greenwald; James and Thomas Worsfold, and Sofia and Edward Utz III. He also leaves behind his sister Rita Peters, and nieces Christine Matthews and Bernadette Peters.

title: SANTIAGO JOB APPROVED

Mayor Palmer said that Mr. Santiago's record with gangs and urban policing in Newark made him the top candidate. In October, after only seven months as superintendent of the State Police, Mr. Santiago resigned under pressure amid an investigation into his possible abuse of office. The Star-Ledger reported on Thursday that a committee named by Governor McGreevey to find a new superintendent had interviewed 11 candidates and would soon forward the names of five or six finalists to the governor. Jeremy Pearce

title: DEER REMOVAL APPROVED

The council, whose membership is weighted toward sports hunting interests, had rejected the plan a month ago, partly because Princeton refused to allow sports hunting on its public lands and partly because of objections to the use of a pneumatic bolt to stun captured deer for slaughter. After the township agreed to consider opening some of its lands to hunting, the council voted, 7 to 2, to let the program continue for a third year, using both sharpshooters and the bolt-and-kill method. The township also agreed to stop hunters from taking deer on private land whose owners allow sports hunting. Iver Peterson

title: The Enemy Was Everyone
description: Given the current political climate in Zimbabwe, it takes guts to write a novel like THE STONE VIRGINS (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18) -- the story of two wars, two women and the horror of violence that becomes institutionalized. Yvonne Vera sets her narrative in Kezi, a small village in the Matabeleland region, during the years before and after Independence. ''To be in Kezi, to be in the bush, is to be at the mercy of misfortune,'' she writes, describing the plight of rural communities during a guerrilla war. Still, at first the enemy is easy to identify, and so are the heroes: the men ''who have returned from the war with all their senses intact, except for that faraway, traveled look that makes the girls a bit fearful'' and the ''female soldiers marked with unknowable places on their own faces.'' Independence brings no peace, however; for Zimbabwe plunges almost immediately into civil unrest, and the villagers are victimized by those who once liberated them. Now the lyricism Vera employed so movingly to delineate the suffering of the freedom fighters acts like a klieg light, exposing carnage motivated simply by brutality for its own sake. Unfortunately, the strength of Vera's style is also this novel's weakness. Her prose is so densely poetic, her opening chapters so preoccupied with ambience, that at times it is almost impossible to discern what she is talking about. This is a shame, because once she grounds her language in the lives of the sisters Thenjiwe and Nonceba, ''The Stone Virgins'' turns out to be about something very important indeed. Alix Wilber

In this autobiographical study of a tormented family, Brian Dennehy portrays the headstrong, tight-fisted patriarch, James Tyrone Sr.; Vanessa Redgrave the guilt-stricken, morphine-addicted mother, Mary Tyrone; Philip Seymour Hoffman the play's alcoholic angry young man, Jamie Tyrone; and Robert Sean Leonard its sensitive and ailing witness, Edmund Tyrone (the author's alter ego). The production is under the direction of Robert Falls, the artistic director of the Goodman Theater in Chicago, where Mr. Falls directed the play last year with Mr. Dennehy in the same role and a different cast.

title: The Future at Ground Zero

And the very process of arriving at this point has already changed the city.

title: Kim Dae Jung Gets Fond Farewell as He Steps Down in Seoul

The document was released as the United States, Britain and Spain introduced a United Nations Security Council resolution declaring that Baghdad has failed to disarm as required and must face ''serious consequences,'' diplomatic code for war.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: INDIA: POLICE THWART HINDU MARCH The police stopped about 5,000 Hindu priests from marching on Parliament to campaign for the building of a Hindu temple at the site of a ruined mosque in northern India. The priests believe the spot where the 16th-century mosque, which was demolished by Hindu militants in 1992, was the birthplace of the god Ram. Leaders of the World Hindu Council, which is part of the Hindu nationalist family of organizations that also includes the governing Bhartiya Janata Party, have vowed mass action until the site is turned over to them.    Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: Female Athletes Gaining Ground And Breaking It
description: As Annika Sorenstam, the world's top female golfer, prepares to play at a stop on the men's tour, she represents an evolution in the aspiration of female athletes. No longer are some elite women content simply with an opportunity to compete, a freedom hard won in the gender struggles of three decades ago. Increasingly, according to athletes, coaches and women's sports activists, women are seeking challenges to explore the full potential of their skills.

title: Safe Therapy Is Found for High Blood-Clot Risk

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: COURT REFUSES TO HEAR APPEAL IN A.A. CONFESSION The United States Supreme Court refused yesterday to hear the case of a man who was convicted of manslaughter in part because of his statements to fellow members of Alcoholics Anonymous. The man, Paul Cox, who has been serving a prison sentence of 16 2/3 to 50 years, sought review by the court, saying his statements should have the same confidentiality as an admission to a priest because Alcoholics Anonymous is quasi-religious. The court rejected Mr. Cox's appeal without comment. Mr. Cox's various statements to other members led to his arrest in the killing of a married couple, Dr. Shanta Chervu and Dr. Lakshman Rao Chervu, in Westchester County in 1988. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Advertiser's Profit Falls

WPP said its income fell to 25.5 million ($40.4 million) from 219.6 million a year earlier. Sales at WPP, whose units include the J. Walter Thompson, Ogilvy & Mather and Young & Rubicam agencies, declined 3 percent, to 3.9 billion. The chief executive, Sir Martin Sorrell, said he expected revenue to be flat this year and pick up next year with spending on the 2004 Summer Olympics and the presidential election in the United States.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Airgate Unit Files For Bankruptcy
description: The iPCS unit of AirGate PCS Inc. filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday. The unit, which carries wireless phone calls for the Sprint Corporation in four Midwestern states, accused Sprint in a lawsuit of contributing to its problems. The company sought protection from creditors in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Atlanta after failing to persuade Sprint to come to its aid. The Chapter 11 filing listed $253.5 million in assets and $378.4 million in debts, including $187 million of bonds. The separate suit, also filed in the bankruptcy court, accused Sprint of breaching the terms of their affiliate agreement. ''Over the past two years,'' iPCS said in the lawsuit, ''as financial conditions have become more difficult generally in the telecommunications industry, Sprint has increasingly sought to insulate itself against those worsening conditions by abusing the power it has over its affiliates.'' Sprint miscalculated what it owed iPCS and withheld payments, the suit said. The Airgate unit serves more than 235,000 Sprint PCS customers in parts of Illinois, Michigan, Iowa and Nebraska. ''We have not seen the complaint, so we can't comment specifically,'' said Dan Wilinsky, a Sprint spokesman. ''Generally speaking we have adhered to our contract with iPCS, and the Sprint network in iPCS territory will continue to operate.''

description: A former president of the United States Olympic Committee said yesterday that the $50,000 relocation payment given last year to a woman hired as the organization's chief marketing officer should have paid for all of her moving and living expenses.

title: 2 Rival Houses Said to Consider Bids to Acquire AOL Book Unit
description: Seeking to sell its book publishing division, AOL Time Warner has elicited interest from two potential bidders, Random House, a unit of Bertelsmann, and HarperCollins, part of the News Corporation, people involved in the talks said yesterday.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sun Replacing Intel Servers At Archipelago
description: Sun Microsystems Inc., which has lost server-computer sales to cheaper machines made by rivals, said yesterday that a stock exchange would use Sun servers to replace Intel-based systems. The exchange, Archipelago, will replace about 500 servers with 20 from Sun, the Chicago-based Archipelago said. The move will save the exchange ''hundreds of thousands of dollars'' a year, partly in staff costs, said Steve Rubinow, Archipelago's chief technology officer. Sun, which makes its own chips, is battling a perception that increasingly powerful computers with Intel chips can do the same things as Sun's servers for far less money. Intel-based servers made by rivals like Dell Computer, I.B.M. and Hewlett-Packard offer as much as 50 percent better price-performance than Sun machines, according to Toni Sacconaghi, a Sanford Bernstein research analyst. Shares of Sun rose 1 cent, to $3.42. They declined 75 percent last year.

title: Officials Plan New Memorial To Victims Of '93 Attack
description: State officials said yesterday that they would erect a temporary memorial to the victims of the 1993 terrorist bombing of the World Trade Center and that it would include a fragment of the original memorial, which was destroyed in the collapse of the twin towers in 2001.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: TRADE SURPLUS FALLS The merchandise trade surplus in Japan contracted for the first time in 11 months as imports surged along with the rise in crude oil prices. The country's surplus stood at 105 billion yen ($890 million) in January, 42.8 percent lower than in January 2002. Exports grew 7.9 percent, but imports grew even faster, at 10.7 percent. The trade surplus with the United States, Japan's single largest trading partner, fell 8.9 percent. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: DNA Twists to the Right. What if It Didn't?

title: Deciding When Science Has Gone Astray

title: READER'S DIGEST TO OPERATE AS 4 GROUPS INSTEAD OF 3
description: The Reader's Digest Association said yesterday that it planned to divide its operations into four groups, one of them a consolidation of its North American marketing, book and magazine businesses. The company, which is based in Pleasantville, N.Y., said the four groups would be Reader's Digest North America, Reader's Digest International, Consumer Business Services and the fund-raising unit, QSP. Previously, Reader's Digest had operated in three segments.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Industrial Growth Rises
description: India's core industries, including concrete, petroleum and steel, grew 4.1 percent in January, lifted by a healthy growth in the concrete sector, a government report said. The increase was about the same as the previous month, but was down from 7.1 percent in January 2002. The measurement of the core sector encompasses crucial industries and provides an indication of industrial growth. The concrete industry grew 9.2 percent in January aided by an increase in construction of homes resulting from cheaper home mortgage options and tax breaks. The petroleum refining sector rose 9.2 percent in January, compared with a 9.9 percent rise in January 2002. The crude oil sector grew 0.4 percent, compared with 1.4 percent last year. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: U.S. and Allies Ask U.N. to Affirm Iraq Won't Disarm

But France, Russia and Germany moved to strengthen the United Nations inspections and give Saddam Hussein months more to show that he is complying.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: SUPERMARKET BIDDER DROPS OUT Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company pulled out of a six-way takeover contest for Safeway . Kohlberg Kravis decided not to compete with William Morrison Supermarkets, Wal-Mart Stores , Tesco, J Sainsbury and a British billionaire, Philip Green, for Safeway, which owns 479 stores, Neil Richardson, a partner at Kohlberg Kravis in London, said. Shareholders in William Morrison approved the company's all-share bid for Safeway. The Asda unit of Wal-Mart, Tesco, Sainsbury and Mr. Green have said they may make rival offers, attracted to Safeway's 10 percent share of Britain's supermarket industry. (Bloomberg News)

title: Twist and Shout! The Double Helix Replicates Itself in Popular Culture

One in a series of fashion designs based on human embryonic development, it shows a woman, spinal column exposed, draped in a helical red dress of DNA sequencing gel.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Report On Information Technology Contracts
description: The federal government awarded more than 650 information technology contracts to private sector companies last year, worth more than $60 billion, according to a new report. Input, a research company in Chantilly, Va., found that five departments combined for $44 billion in contract awards. The Department of Transportation led the federal government in outside technology spending, with contracts exceeding $24 billion. The contracts do not represent single-year expenditures because some of them span several years. Still, federal departments and agencies spent more than $24 billion for information technology services like applications operations, desktop services and data center operations, the report showed. The professional services sector accounted for information technology contracts of nearly $21 billion, the report found, while contracts for network and telecommunications services amounted to about $9.5 billion.

title: Here's an X-Ray. Spot the Double Helix.

Had their rival Linus Pauling seen the image, produced by a technique called X-ray crystallography, he might have beat them to the prize.

Strange's 5-day-old baby was still hospitalized in Springfield, Mass., and he sounded both heartbroken to have left the boy behind and relieved that his health had improved.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Airline Expects Loss
description: All Nippon Airways expects to lose twice as much money in the fiscal year ending in March because of a decline in domestic passenger traffic and a price war with other carriers. All Nippon now says it will lose 35 billion yen ($296 million) this year, 95 percent more than previously forecast. The airline also trimmed its sales target by 0.5 percent. Revenue increased 13 percent, to 2.44 billion reais, helped by a price increase in October to offset last year's currency decline, the company said.

title: NATO: The Inside Story
description: WASHINGTON  NATO ambassadors gathered for a final showdown over Iraq on Feb. 16, the alliance's secretary general, Lord Robertson, held a secret trump card.

title: Sharon Close to Forming 3-Party Government in Israel
description: The new government of Prime Minister Ariel Sharon took shape today as a three-party coalition that is expected to take a tough line on the Palestinian uprising and on restarting peace negotiations.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Retailer's Profit Rises
description: Australia's largest retailer, Woolworths, said its first-half profit rose 18 percent, to 350 million Australian dollars ($211 million), as its sales rose 11 percent, to 14.1 billion Australian dollars ($8.5 billion). The result topped analysts' estimates, and Woolworths said it planned to buy back as much as 6 percent of its outstanding shares. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday about the appearance of actresses from pornographic films in a campaign for Pony footwear and apparel misspelled the surname of the chief executive of Straightline International in New York, who commented on the ads. He is Michael Watras, not Watrous.

title: Adu Leads U.S. Under-17 Roster
description: Freddy Adu, the 13-year-old wunderkind who obtained a United States passport last week, tops Coach John Ellinger's list of 18 players named yesterday to the United States roster for the Concacaf qualifying tournament, March 5-9 in Guatemala, for the under-17 world championships. Adu is originally from Ghana.

title: Zor Orgun Journal; Afghans Make New Lives Among the Old Ruins
description: Nearly 20 years after the bombing, the town remains a jumble of broken walls and gaping craters. The weather has smoothed the jagged edges, and children now play among the rubble, but the horror and scale of the carpet bombing that demolished this ancient walled town of 2,500 homes remains vivid.

title: War for Peace? It Worked in My Country
description: I often find myself counting how many of us are left in this world. One recent morning my two surviving brothers and I had coffee together. And I found myself counting again. We were seven brothers and five sisters, another large family in this tiny Catholic country.

title: Jury Rules Out Death Penalty For Failed Spy
description: A federal worker who was convicted last week of trying to sell secrets to Iraq and China will not face the death penalty, a jury decided today.

title: U.S. to Resume Food Aid to N. Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 25  The State Department announced today that it will resume shipments of food aid to North Korea after a two-month hiatus but intends to reduce its donations this year by between 35 percent to 75 percent from last year's totals.

title: Sandhogs, Blind Mules and the Birth of a Subway
description: On this date a century ago, New York City was still a metropolis without a subway. But considerable evidence suggested that one was very, very near, and that it was trying hard to devour the city it was designed to help. For example:

title: Testimony Cites Steven Seagal and Seafood, Not a Shakedown
description: When the actor Steven Seagal sat down for dinner with a group of reputed mobsters two years ago, he ''looked like he does in the movies,'' a headwaiter at the restaurant testified at a racketeering trial yesterday. What he did not look like, the headwaiter said, was a man gripped by fear.

title: AMERICAN TOWER PROJECTS A LOSS IN THE FIRST QUARTER
description: The American Tower Corporation, which rents its wireless communication towers to cellular service providers, forecast a first-quarter loss of 30 cents to 33 cents a share, excluding results from discontinued operations. The company, which is based in Boston, said it expected revenue of $176 million to $190 million. American Tower sold assets last year for about $200 million to pay down debt and acquire towers. The company's Verestar unit, to be divested this year, was also designated as discontinued operations starting in the fourth quarter. The company's stock fell 29 cents, or 6 percent, to $4.65 a share.

title: Labor, Under the Gun, Meets to Plot Strategy
description: As the nation's union leaders gather at a luxury resort here for their annual winter meeting, there is no denying they are in a funk.

title: Path to the Helix And Beyond
NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Editor of GQ To Step Down As New Rivals Add Pressure
description: Ending the magazine industry's persistent parlor game over his future, Art Cooper, editor in chief of GQ since 1983, yesterday morning walked into the office of S. I. Newhouse Jr., chairman of Cond Nast, and told him he would be retiring in June.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEBOW, RUTH
description: LEBOW-Ruth. Feb. 22, 2003. Beloved wife of 68 years to the late Sylvan Lebow. Loving mother of Mark Lebow and Joy Lebow Cohen. Adoring grandmother to Michael, Lauren, Jeffrey and Alexandra. Proud mother-in-law of Dr. William Cohen and Patricia E. Harris. Burial private.

title: MEMO PAD
description: A Fare Increase That Is Sticking

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLINGER, SYLVIA
description: BERLINGER-Sylvia. On February 22, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Jerome. Devoted mother of Lawrence and Kenneth. Loving sister of Etta, Ruthie and the late Rose. Services Wednesday 11:30am at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Supreme Court Is to Review Rehiring of Drug Abusers
description: The Supreme Court, accepting a new case today on the legal obligations of employers toward people with disabilities, agreed to decide whether companies can refuse to rehire rehabilitated drug users whose substance abuse had brought about their dismissals.

title: Jeter's Intangibles Hard to Quantify
description: The Yankees' splendid season was crashing down in Anaheim. George Steinbrenner watched from his home here and seethed. Derek Jeter watched from the top step of the visitors' dugout at Edison Field, burning in his own way.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Don't Shoot! That's Aretha's Hair!

title: Nets Seem Stuck in Finals Fog
description: The notion was posed to Nets Coach Byron Scott and it caused him to pause. Could it be that the Nets, one season after a surprising run to the N.B.A. finals, have skipped the work that was done last season to get there? Have the Nets disregarded the formality of the long season and lost the day-to-day hunger, assuming a berth that they clawed for a year ago?

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 4 Arrested At Talent Contest
description: A hip-hop talent search that drew more than 2,000 contestants to Times Square yesterday morning led to four arrests for disorderly conduct and minor injuries to two police officers, the police said. The contestants waited overnight for auditions to be conducted by MTV, with a recording contract and $25,000 offered as prizes. The police said it was a larger crowd than anticipated. Jannie Kedas, an MTV spokeswoman, which has its studios in Times Square, said the auditions would be rescheduled.

title: Ex-Inmate Denied Chair (And Clippers)
description: THANK goodness Joseph Heller wrote ''Catch-22.'' Otherwise, we would have had to scare up another phrase to describe Marc La Cloche's situation, and undoubtedly it wouldn't have been half as good.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLER, ABRAHAM
description: ELLER-Abraham. Beloved husband of Ruth (nee Flax), dear brother Jack Eller, loving grandfather of Lisa and Samantha. Services Montefiore Cemetery, Saint Albans, NY, today at 1:20 P.M. For info call: Wien & Wien, Hackensack, NJ 1-800-322-0533.

title: Synthetic Turf to Replace Grass at Giants Stadium
description: The company that makes it calls it synthetic grass, not artificial turf. Its name is FieldTurf, and it was the playing surface last season for the Seattle Seahawks and the Detroit Lions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, EUGENE
description: WEINER-Eugene. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of our longtime colleague Eugene Weiner, first managing director of our Commission on the Jewish People and role model and mentor for a generation of leaders in Jewish community service. We extend our deepest sympathies to Gene's wife, Anita; to their sons, David and Danny; and to the entire Weiner family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: Lawmaker Lashes Out at McGreevey Nominee
description: Signaling a deepening opposition to Gov. James E. McGreevey's nominee for chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, a key Republican legislator released new documents today charging ''potentially unlawful activity'' by Charles Kushner, the real estate developer and major Democratic campaign contributor in line for the job.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 10 Years For Al Qaeda Operative
description: An operative for Al Qaeda who pleaded guilty last month to conspiring to destroy national defense materials has been sentenced to 10 years in prison, the maximum term. In 2000, the operative, Mohamed Suleiman al Nalfi, was arrested in the case stemming from the 1998 bombings of two American embassies in East Africa. He faced life in prison for terrorism conspiracy, but pleaded guilty to a lesser charge, which carried the 10-year penalty. John H. Jacobs, a lawyer for Mr. al Nalfi, said yesterday that he was satisfied with the sentence imposed last Thursday. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: EVENTS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RALSTON, IAN S.
description: RALSTON-Ian S. Died on February 22 in Queens, New York after a short illness. Lived most of his life in Belgium, where he worked as a civil engineer. Beloved companion of Marion Wolff, father of Evelyn Ralston, grandfather of Aleris Rodgers, brother of Andrew Ralston and Helene Ganger. Predeceased by his wife Francine. Funeral services at Schwartz Brothers - Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills on Tuesday, February 25, at 10 A.M.

title: ELI LILLY AND 3M HALT STUDIES OF HERPES TREATMENT
description: Eli Lilly & Company and the 3M Company suspended studies of an experimental genital herpes treatment after preliminary data showed it was not effective. The companies halted late-stage studies of more than 1,000 patients with the sexually transmitted disease, a Lilly spokeswoman, Terra Fox, said. The move will delay any potential bid for approval of the compound, which the companies had planned to submit to federal regulators in 2004, Ms. Fox said. Lilly and 3M will continue to analyze the drug and may consider new trials. 3M, which is based in a suburb of St. Paul, Minn., already sells a topical cream called Aldara to treat genital warts. Lilly is based in Indianapolis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, HELEN
description: COHEN-Helen. On February 24, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Herbert. Loving mother of Pauline Sinclair, Martin and Michele Cohen, dear sister of Murray Schiffman, cherished Nana to Todd, Adam, Mollie and Barrie Cohen, Jared and Nicky Sinclair. Services private. Contributions in her memory may be made to Cabrini Hospice, 227 East 19th St., NY, NY 10003.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Summons For Executive
description: Son Kil Seung, chairman of the SK Group, a Korean conglomerate, has received a summons from prosecutors investigating charges of illegal transactions on the part of SK executives, according to YTN, a cable news channel in Korea. Mr. Son, who is chairman of the Federation of Korean Industries, made up of leaders of Korean conglomerates, known as chaebol, faces questioning about deals on behalf of Chey Tae Won, group vice chairman and a member of its founding family. Mr. Chey, who is also chairman of the SK Corporation, the group's centerpiece company, and a top aide were charged last weekend with insider trading and were jailed without bail. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: PAY FOR ADELPHIA EXECUTIVES IS DEBATED IN COURT
description: The Adelphia Communications Corporation yesterday asked Judge Robert Gerber of United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan to approve a pay package for two newly hired executives, while an investor committee asked the judge to reject or alter the contracts. Shareholders, led by a former board member, Leonard Tow, said in court papers that the $41 million in proposed pay for the two men, William Schleyer and Ronald Cooper, was ''grossly excessive.'' Adelphia's board hired Mr. Schleyer and Mr. Cooper in January, seven months after the company filed for bankruptcy, listing $20 billion in debt. The $41 million in compensation includes salary, bonuses, stock and options. Adelphia's creditors and lenders support the hiring of the two executives.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about ties between the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Dwain J. Kyles, the owner of a Chicago nightclub where 21 people were killed in a stampede, referred incorrectly to Mr. Kyles's relationship with his ex-wife, Theresa Cropper, a former assistant to Mr. Jackson. Ms. Cropper said she and Mr. Kyles do not live together.

title: Signs of Life in Argentina
description: Graffiti denouncing bankers as thieves and scoundrels still stains walls here, and small groups of angry depositors continue to pound on the front doors of many banks. But more than a year after Argentina froze most bank accounts in a failed attempt to stave off economic collapse, the financial sector is finally showing tentative signs of recovery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, CLAIRE (NEE BYRNE)
description: GREENE-Claire (nee Byrne). On February 23, 2003 of Brooklyn and Hurley, N.Y. Wife of the late Alton Warren Greene. Sister of Janet Byrne. Services are private. Stuard Funeral Home-Ardmore, PA. 610-649-0243.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Court Refuses To Hear Appeal In A.A. Confession
description: The United States Supreme Court refused yesterday to hear the case of a man who was convicted of manslaughter in part because of his statements to fellow members of Alcoholics Anonymous. The man, Paul Cox, who has been serving a prison sentence of 16 2/3 to 50 years, sought review by the court, saying his statements should have the same confidentiality as an admission to a priest because Alcoholics Anonymous is quasi-religious. The court rejected Mr. Cox's appeal without comment. Mr. Cox's various statements to other members led to his arrest in the killing of a married couple, Dr. Shanta Chervu and Dr. Lakshman Rao Chervu, in Westchester County in 1988. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: With Sheet Metal Cutouts, the Tree of Life Emerged
description: Suspended in clear liquid inside a small test tube, the tangle of glistening white fiber looks like an exceedingly delicate jellyfish or a scrap of cotton thread. The individual strands have a twist to them, the only hint that what I am looking at is a wad of helical molecules, my own DNA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELKES, GERTRUDE
description: WELKES-Gertrude. On February 24, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Loving mother of Nathaniel and Gary and mother-in-law of Toni and Sandra, cherished grandmother to Jodie, Ethan, Ayala and Avi. Services were held on Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYERS, EDNA
description: MEYERS-Edna. We mourn the passing of our beloved ''Nanny''. Her mission in life was devotion to her adoring family, who are a living testament to her boundless love and caring. The epitome of grace and beauty for 91 years, she was our source of strength in both joyous & tragic times. Devoted wife of the late Maxwell, loving & proud mother of twins Harriette Rose Katz and Renee (Jerry) Bernheim, grandmother of Trisha Bernheim, Claudia and Jonathan Warner, Doug Bernheim and Susie Flax and Melissa and Lawrence Rosenbloom, and greatgrandmother of six precious children. Loving sister to Esther Shaber, and Lillie and the late Bernard Berger. None of us, and none who knew her, will ever be the same. We will adore you always, Nan. Services Wednesday 11 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNORTZ, HERBERT C.
description: KNORTZ-Herbert C., 81. Of Ridgefield, CT. Retired financial executive and former board member at International Telephone and Telegraphy. February 21, 2003. Calling hours at the Kane Funeral Home, 41 Catoonah Street, Ridgefield, CT on Tuesday from 6PM to 8PM. Funeral services will be private. Memorials to the Ridgefield Public Library, 472 Main Street, Ridgefield, CT 06877 would be greatly appreciated.

title: Democracy Takes Office in South Korea
description: ''Koreans do not deserve democracy,'' my father used to say, on his most difficult and discouraging days as a failed politician.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSMAN, BILL
description: SUSMAN-Bill. The Abraham Lincoln Brigade Archives mourns the loss of our founding genius, Bill Susman, veteran of the Spanish Civil War and WW II, a lifetime political activist, and a dear friend. The family requests contributions be sent to ALBA-Rm 227, 799 Broadway, NY 10003.

title: Editorial Observer; Deborah Cook Is the Typical Bush Judicial Nominee -- So Watch Out
description: The case before the Ohio Supreme Court looked simple enough. Thomas Davis, a forklift operator at an Ohio Wal-Mart, was crushed to death at work. When his widow sued, Wal-Mart fought hard -- and its employees may have lied and destroyed evidence. When she learned of the possible deception, Mrs. Davis went to court to try to add an important legal claim. Too bad, Wal-Mart argued. She had missed her chance -- even if it did trick her by lying.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Flu Fears Ease
description: A 9-year-old boy infected with a rare form of avian influenza was released from the hospital a week after his father died of the disease. Both returned ill to Hong Kong two weeks ago from a vacation in Fujian Province in China. Test results announced yesterday showed that the virus had exclusively avian flu genes with no human flu genes. That may make it less contagious between people. The World Health Organization has alerted flu specialists around the world to be on the lookout for the disease. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: 'It Has Not Escaped Our Notice': Anatomy of a Paper
description: If you were not a biochemist interested in mechanisms of heredity, you would not have discerned the message in the buttoned-down language of the paper that Francis Crick and Dr. James D. Watson published in Nature on April 25, 1953. But in a fewer than 1,000 words they changed the course of biology. By suggesting that genes are encoded by the order of chemicals on two complementary strands of molecules wound around each other in a double helix, they laid the foundation for the modern science of the gene, with all its hopeful and Orwellian aspects. A look at the paper reveals some of the enduring idiosyncrasies of research reports and some of the ways they have changed over the years. DENNIS OVERBYE and LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN

title: Accounting Firms in Britain Putting Disclaimers on Audits
description: Accounting firms in Britain, including PricewaterhouseCoopers and Ernst & Young, have begun adding disclaimers to their audit letters saying that no one but the shareholders of the audited company may hold the auditors responsible for the accuracy of the figures.

title: Arby's creates a talking oven mitt to raise its sagging profile and its sales.
description: ARBY'S has spent several years carving out a position for itself as ''adult fast food.'' But now Arby's is turning to a cartoonish kitchen implement to help rescue its sagging brand recognition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONTGOMERY, ELIZABETH GRANT
description: MONTGOMERY - Elizabeth Grant. Age 93, of Canaan, CT and North Haven, ME, on February 22 in Canaan. Wife of the late Robert Montgomery; mother of Anne Harkness Mooney; grandmother of John, Anne, Elizabeth, David, Allan, and William; and greatgrandmother of eight. Services to be private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, BERNARD C.
description: LEVINE-Bernard C. College professor, mentor and administrator, died at home on February 22, 2003, after a courageous struggle with pancreatic cancer. Adored husband for 53 years of Bunny (Bernice) Utal Levine, most extraordinary and beloved father of Marty, Francie and Joe, cherished father-in-law of Judy Forrest Levine and Jay Lubin and world's greatest grandfather to Robin Emily Levine and Jeffrey Robert Lubin. Bernie was also an avid tennis player and a supporter of the arts, especially of developing actors. His gentle spirit will be with us forever. Services will be held at the Jewish Memorial Chapel in Clifton, NJ. Donations to the Lustgarten Foundation for Pancreatic Cancer Research, or the Actors' Fund would be appreciated.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Freeport: Landscaper Is Shot To Death
description: A landscaper was killed and his friend critically injured on Sunday by a man who may have mistaken them for members of a gang, the authorities said. They said the landscaper, Jaime Figueroa, 18, of Hempstead, was a passenger in a car being driven by his friend, Elvis Rivera, 25, also a landscaper. A third man, whom the police did not identify, was also a passenger. Another car pulled next to them at a traffic light at Sunrise Highway. Someone in the other car asked, in Spanish, if Mr. Rivera and his friends were members of the MS-13 gang. Mr. Rivera said no, the authorities said, and the man fired at least three shots, killing Mr. Figueroa and injuring Mr. Rivera. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: 48 Indicted in Insurance Fraud, Accused of Faking Car Accidents
description: TRENTON, Feb. 24  State officials today announced the indictment of 48 South Jersey residents who they said ran an insurance fraud ring, staging car crashes and filing more than $500,000 in false medical claims.

title: Never Mind Picasso, It's Matisse and the Curator
description: MUCH as the good husband is not supposed to covet his neighbor's wife, the good curator is not encouraged to covet a museum's art. But, hurrah, the Museum of Modern Art's terribly British curator at large, John Elderfield, briefly drops his second-skin decorum and diplomacy -- cribbed from C. P. Snow novels -- and makes a tiny confession inside this blah conference room at the museum's office near Rockefeller Center.

title: S.E.C. Approves New Credit Rater
description: Dominion Bond Rating Service won recognition today from the Securities and Exchange Commission as a credit rating company, becoming the first new competitor to Moody's Investors Service, Standard & Poor's and Fitch in more than a decade.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOLDSTEIN, MERVYN F.
description: GOLDSTEIN-Mervyn F. On the first anniversary of his death. We miss your laughter and caring discernment. Roberta, David and Harvey

title: Thomas Joseph Leonard, 47, Teacher of Business Coaching
description: Thomas Joseph Leonard, a former financial planner who founded virtual boot camps for personal and business coaches worldwide, died on Feb. 11 at his home in Phoenix. He was 47.

title: National Briefing | Washington: F.B.I. Official Faulted For 'Poor Judgment'
description: The Justice Department's inspector general has found that a senior F.B.I. official responsible for investigating charges of internal misconduct ''exercised poor judgment'' in the case of an agent who was passed over for promotion after he was interviewed on television about lapses in F.B.I. disciplinary procedures. The agent, John Roberts, repeated comments he had made at a Congressional hearing that lower-level employees were sometimes treated more harshly than their superiors. The report found that Mr. Roberts's boss, Robert Jordan, was upset by his comments but did not intend to harass or threaten him. David Johnston (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: CISCO EXPANDS 2 ALLIANCES Cisco Systems announced yesterday that it would expand two existing partnerships that are aimed at helping the company, the maker of network equipment, expand from its traditional markets. In two announcements, Cisco said it was intensifying its alliances with AT&T and with the Hewlett-Packard Company . In their partnership, Cisco and AT&T will jointly market and sell products and consulting services in the area of data transportation, security and storage. The partnership will aim at small and medium-size businesses, the partners said. In the second alliance, Hewlett-Packard said it would make its desktop and mobile computers compatible with Cisco technology that allows such computers to get access to data over wireless networks, the partners said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTMAN, DORIS
description: HARTMAN-Doris. February 18, 2003. Peacefully, age 89. Beloved wife of Leo and mother of Victoria and Laura. Dedicated teacher, nursery school director, songbird, pianist, linguist, wit, crossword puzzle solver. A remarkable lady. Much missed.

title: U.S. AND ALLIES ASK THE U.N. TO AFFIRM IRAQ WON'T DISARM
description: The United States, Britain and Spain asked the Security Council today to declare that Iraq had missed its last chance to disarm to avoid a war. But France, Russia and Germany moved to strengthen the United Nations inspections and give Saddam Hussein months more to show that he is complying.

title: Lincoln Center Rethinks 65th Street
description: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts plans to start work next year on the transformation of West 65th Street into a bright, open boulevard of marquees, even though it has yet to raise any money for that project or any other part of its planned $1.2 billion redevelopment.

title: AIDS Drug Is Priced By Roche
description: Roche said today that it was setting a European price of 52 euros a day, or more than $20,000 a year, for its new drug intended to treat AIDS patients who no longer benefit from the current regime of medicines.

title: Voting Hours for Special Elections
description: There will be four special elections today in New York City, two of them in Brooklyn and two in the Bronx. Polling places will be open from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m.

title: Ex-Zambian Leader Accused Of Theft From Government
description: Former President Frederick Chiluba of Zambia, who presided over that country's first decade of democracy, was arrested today and charged with looting the state treasury during his two terms in office.

title: Stirring A Stew Of Politics And Music
description: In his three concerts with the Czech Philharmonic Orchestra, from Thursday through Sunday at Carnegie Hall, Vladimir Ashkenazy offered what was meant to be a tightly focused historical examination. Under the title ''Music and Dictatorship: Russia Under Stalin,'' the series looked at the way music was used and abused at a specific time and place. But the programs, which included works written to glorify the state as well the personal responses of composers to their world and times, also raised the larger and more fraught question of whether symphonic music is of any use as a means of political expression.

title: Minor Leaguer Caught In Matsui Media Storm
description: Jason Anderson is 23 years old and has never thrown a pitch in the major leagues. But he threw two in an intrasquad game at Legends Field today that briefly made him an international sensation.

title: Whiffs of 'Carousel' Perfume a Love Duet
description: Christopher Wheeldon's ''Carousel (a Dance)'' was originally announced as a a piece d'occasion. It was not scheduled to be performed again after its premiere at the New York City Ballet's November gala, part of the Richard Rodgers Centennial.

title: Fears of Terror A Complication For Art Exhibits
description: Concerns over terrorism are complicating the large and luscious international loan exhibitions that have long been the lifeblood of museums, especially in places like New York that are considered a prime target for attacks.

title: Shuttle Panel Names Experts to Aid Inquiry
description: The independent board investigating the Columbia crash this evening released the names of 21 experts who are assisting its work. They are drawn from active and retired personnel from the military, the National Transportation Safety Board and the Federal Aviation Administration and from the naval nuclear propulsion program and other government agencies.

title: Remedy Raises Questions On What's Being Cured
description: It represented the best of all worlds: a rapidly growing company in a safe business. But now an accounting scandal has forced the departure of the man who led Royal Ahold as it grew, and the company says it will restate its books in ways that will reduce both reported earnings and sales.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Supermarket Bidder Drops Out
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company pulled out of a six-way takeover contest for Safeway. Kohlberg Kravis decided not to compete with William Morrison Supermarkets, Wal-Mart Stores, Tesco, J Sainsbury and a British billionaire, Philip Green, for Safeway, which owns 479 stores, Neil Richardson, a partner at Kohlberg Kravis in London, said. Shareholders in William Morrison approved the company's all-share bid for Safeway. The Asda unit of Wal-Mart, Tesco, Sainsbury and Mr. Green have said they may make rival offers, attracted to Safeway's 10 percent share of Britain's supermarket industry.

title: Official Hopes to Explain AIDS Vaccine Disparities
description: A top federal researcher expressed hope yesterday that the tests that his agency was planning would explain why the first large-scale trial of an AIDS vaccine had found it more effective among African-Americans and other non-Hispanic minorities than others.

title: KENNETH OLDEN
description: He is the director of the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences.

title: Graft Aggravates Woes Plaguing Central America
description: Long a mainstay of politics and business in Central America, corruption has taken on new life under the region's fledgling democracies and is more pervasive and corrosive than at any time in recent memory, analysts and diplomats say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRINKAUS, JOHN PHILIP
description: TRINKAUS-John Philip, 84. Eminent embryologist and author associated with Yale University and Woods Hole Marine Biology Lab, died February 8. Master of Branford College, 1966-1973. Memorial Service Saturday, March 1, 2PM, at Branford College Dining Hall, Yale Univ. Survived by wife Madeleine; children Gregor, Tanya and Eric; stepdaughter Anne-Laure; numerous grandchildren, greatgrandchildren and generations of inspired students.

title: Washington Memo; The President's Tax Cut and Its Unspoken Numbers
description: The statistics that President Bush and his allies use to promote his tax-cut plan are accurate, but many of them present only part of the picture.

title: Japan, Its Finances in Disarray, Picks Old-School Central Banker
description: Backing away from his own calls for an independent, reform-minded policy maker to lead the Japanese central bank, Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi has selected a career bureaucrat backed by the country's establishment to be the bank's next governor.

title: Eight Men Facing the Horrors of the Battlefield
description: The flesh-and-blood immediacy of theater gives it an advantage over film in the evocation of many types of emotional circumstances, particularly those of the everyday. Funerals, romantic rivalries, dinner table disputes, divorces and other situations within the experience of most theatergoers are the meat and potatoes of the stage and, not incidentally, of stagecraft.

title: North Korea Tests a Missile as South Korea Prepares for a New President
description: North Korea, in a provocative reminder of the tense security situation on the Korean Peninsula, on Monday conducted its first missile launching test in three years, South Korea's Yonyap news agency said today.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Bicyclist's Day In Court
description: Reza K. Baluchi, the Iranian bicyclist who pedaled around in the world in the name of peace only to be arrested in the United States, got a chance to explain himself in federal immigration court. The 30-year-old wanderer, left, told Judge LaMonte Freerks in Florence that he did not know he had crossed the Mexican border into the United States. He was spotted in November in the Sonora Desert. Mr. Baluchi has pedaled across six continents in six years. Judge Freerks is expected to rule on Thursday whether Mr. Baluchi will be deported . Charlie LeDuff (NYT)

title: Skipping a Night Out on the Town
description: Like many traveling executives, Peter Salmon, a senior sales manager for Sharp Electronics in Los Angeles, has taken to holing up in his hotel room at night.

title: Legislators Unmoved by Bid to Delay Nassau Smoking Ban
description: Restaurateurs and bar owners staged a last-ditch effort today to delay Nassau County's new smoking ban, which is set to take effect at midnight Friday. Supporters of the measure, however, urged county lawmakers to stand firm.

title: Top-Ranked Arizona Awaits a Final Push
description: There are defining moments in every college basketball season, some obvious immediately and some hidden, revealing themselves only over time. Arizona is the top-ranked men's team in the country and the Wildcats naturally believe they can win a national title. Funny, then, that one of Arizona's defining moments might have been the day the coach quit.

title: Governors Get Sympathy From Bush but No More Money

description: Forty-eight South Jersey residents have been indicted on charges that they were part of an insurance fraud ring, staging car crashes and filing more than $500,000 in false medical claims, state officials announced yesterday. title: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- In Zurich; A Banking Center Is Trying to Overcome Its Staid Company-Town Image
description: Banking is what Zurich is famous for, and it overshadows just about everything else in what is Switzerland's biggest city. Tight-lipped bankers still abound, even though their industry is undergoing turmoil and retrenchment. With one eye on the future, the city is courting visitors by overhauling its staid company-town image. Even though its sidewalks, on centuries-old cobbled streets, still roll up too early for some, Zurich is decidedly more hip these days with new ethnic restaurants, innovative performing arts and diverse night life.

title: Daley Walks, Not Runs, Toward Chicago Election
description: Tuesday is Election Day here in the nation's third-largest city. The ballots are printed. The polling machines are in place. Mayor Richard M. Daley has booked a ballroom at the Hilton for his victory party.

title: Facing Budget Deficit, Hong Kong Look at Deep Cuts
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 25  Faced with a widening budget deficit that is starting to hurt Hong Kong's international financial standing, the government announced plans today for deep reductions in welfare benefits and civil servants' pay.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Serb Surrenders To Tribunal
description: A Serbian politician known for his ultranationalist views, Vojislav Seselj, surrendered to the United Nations war crimes tribunal to face charges that paramilitary fighters under his command committed atrocities against civilians in the wars in Croatia and Bosnia in the early 1990's. He told a big crowd at a farewell rally that he was going to prove his innocence and that of the Serbian people. Instead of being tried himself, he said, ''I will put the Americans and NATO on trial.'' Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Consumer Confidence Falls to 9-Year Low
description: Consumer confidence plunged in February to its lowest level in more than nine years, the Conference Board reported today, as concerns about a war with Iraq, rising energy prices and jobs took a toll on attitudes.

title: North Korea Tests Missile
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Tuesday, Feb. 25  North Korea, in a provocative reminder of the tense security situation on the Korean Peninsula, on Monday conducted its first missile launching test in three years, South Korea's Yonyap news agency said today.

title: Burk Will Fight For Place To Protest
description: Martha Burk, who has spearheaded the challenge to the all-male membership of Augusta National Golf Club, said yesterday that she planned to file this week for a permit to protest outside the club during the Masters tournament in April. But Burk also said she expected her request to be rejected by city officials in Augusta, Ga.

title: A Radio Chip in Every Consumer Product
description: Here's a tip to thieves: If you are bent on stealing packages of Gillette Mach3 razor blades, go someplace other than Tesco's Newmarket Road store in Cambridge, England. There, a ''smart shelf'' continuously queries tiny radio chips embedded in the packages it holds, and senses the silence when one is removed. The system may soon be programmed to alert security when several are taken at once, Greg Sage, a Tesco spokesman, said.

title: Knicks Hoping to Ruin Yao's First Visit
description: He has snuffed the shot of Shaquille O'Neal, started in the All-Star Game and starred in several entertaining commercials. Yet the Knicks have not seen the Yao Ming who has garnered superstar accolades and worldwide attention after just four months in the N.B.A.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Creo Increases Bid For Printcafe To $3 A Share
description: Creo Inc., a maker of digital-printing gear, said yesterday that it offered $3 a share for the stock it does not already own in Printcafe Software Inc., a designer of software for the printing industry. Shares of Printcafe rose as much as 41 percent. The offer of $3 a share would be a ''substantial premium'' to an offer from another company, Creo said. Creo had said on Jan. 22 that it had an agreement to pay $1.30 a share to increase its holdings in Printcafe to 55 percent. Before the bidding began to affect the value of Printcafe shares, its stock price had been most affected by a relatively high level of debt, Tad Piper, an analyst with U.S. Bancorp Piper Jaffray, said. Creo holds about $11.8 million of Printcafe's debt, and the payment is due in the first part of 2004 in one payment, Printcafe's chief financial officer, Joseph Whang, said in an interview. The company's total debt is about $20.7 million, with about $5 million due more than a year from now, he said. Shares of Pittsburgh-based Printcafe rose 84 cents, or 35 percent, to $3.24. Creo shares fell 17 cents, to $6.45.

title: Oldest Human History Is at Risk; A Prime Center of Islamic Art and Culture May Be in Harm's Way
description: Iraq has hundreds of thousands of archaeological sites. Some 10,000 have been identified, but only a fraction have been explored. Any of them could change what we know about human history, as past excavations have done. Some have already revealed the world's earliest known villages and cities and the first examples of writing.

title: Proposed Cigna Settlement Transferred to Miami Judge
description: In a setback for Cigna, the health insurer, a federal judiciary panel has ordered that a proposed settlement of a class-action suit in Illinois be transferred to a federal judge in Miami who has sharply criticized the company's tactics.

title: War in Iraq Would Halt All Digs In Region
description: War in Iraq would halt archaeology not just in that country but across the Middle East, experts say, and could result in some of the earliest cities of Mesopotamia being bombed or looted into ruins of ruins.

description: The payments that caused problems at the U.S. Foodservice division of Royal Ahold are among the most common, and the most perilous, in an industry known for a variety of cash transactions.

title: Nationwide Raids Put Top Drug-Paraphernalia Traffickers Out of Business, U.S. Says
description: Federal officials said today that they had shut down the biggest drug-paraphernalia suppliers in the United States in a series of nationwide raids.

title: America's Cup Is Postponed Again
description: Asubtropical weather system packing winds of more than 40 knots yesterday led to the sixth straight postponement of Race 4 of the America's Cup in the waters off Auckland, New Zealand.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Bank Merges Units
description: The Bank of Ireland will merge its two British financial advisory businesses and cut almost half the combined work force as declines in the stock market deter investors from saving. The company said it would merge Chase de Vere Investments and MX Financial Solutions and reduce their combined work force by 350 jobs.

title: A New Love Inflames a Family And Ends With a Mother's Killing
description: It was a timeless situation: Rosanna Rogers had fallen in love with a mysterious man who filled her life with art and poetry. But her mother disapproved.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Cyprus: Doubts On Peace Plan
description: Prime Minister Costas Simitis of Greece and the president-elect of Cyprus, Tassos Papadopoulos, voiced doubts that a Feb. 28 deadline on a United Nations peace plan to reunite Cyprus would be met. The leaders offered the assessment as Secretary General Kofi Annan suggested he was prepared to give Cyprus's rival Greek and Turkish sides an extra week. In an effort to forge a deal, Britain offered to give both sides parts of its military bases on the island. Anthee Carassava (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Court Rejects Challenge To Times Building
description: The United States Supreme Court declined yesterday, without comment, to hear challenges by four landowners near Times Square that their properties were unconstitutionally condemned to make way for the new headquarters building planned by The New York Times Company. The Empire State Development Corporation, a state development agency, had condemned 11 properties on Eighth Avenue and on 40th and 41st Streets to make a site to be leased to the Times Company and Forest City Ratner Companies. Three owners, including West 41st Street Realty, said the state effectively prevented them from developing their property. The other owner, Three O Realty, said the state's finding of blight was merely a pretext. Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the development corporation, said yesterday that the state used its condemnation power ''to improve areas of our city where the majority of the public benefits.'' David W. Dunlap (NYT)

title: Terror's Dual Threats Of Bombs and Biology
description: Rest semiassured: guards near New York City tunnels have stopped cars with cancer patients inside; remnant radiation from their tumor-fighting therapies tripped sensors. Also, the city's existing air-quality monitors have already been retrofitted to sniff out bioterror attacks, and so far so good.

description: The IDT Corporation said yesterday that it was submitting a rival bid to buy Global Crossing out of bankruptcy, contending its proposal should be favored by government officials looking into the national security implications of a pending offer from two Asian companies.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: U.S. Official Holds Talks On Iran Reactor
description: The United States' top arms control official began three days of talks in Moscow on key strategic issues, led by American concerns that Russian aid in building an Iranian nuclear reactor complex is indirectly helping Iran develop nuclear weapons. Russia has long argued that its work at the Bushehr reactor site has no military implications but American officials fear that the Iranians are gaining knowledge useful in a bomb-making program. John R. Bolton, the under secretary of state for arms control and international security, will also discuss Russian participation in building a ballistic-missile defense system and proposals to help Russia safeguard its nuclear arsenal. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Dangers of an Herbal Supplement
description: The death of a young Baltimore Orioles pitcher who took pills containing ephedra ought to shock Major League Baseball from its cavalier attitude about the use of dietary supplements by players desperate to get in shape or gain a competitive edge. But it will be a shame if the current round of soul-searching over these largely unregulated supplements ends there. Ephedra is a danger to all Americans foolish enough to take it. The supplement ought to be banned as a threat to public health.

title: Corrections

Kyles, the owner of a Chicago nightclub where 21 people were killed in a stampede, referred incorrectly to Mr. Kyles's relationship with his ex-wife, Theresa Cropper, a former assistant to Mr. Jackson. Ms. Cropper said she and Mr. Kyles do not live together.

title: STEWART, A CEMETERY OPERATOR, CUTS 2003 FORECAST
description: Stewart Enterprises Inc., a leading operator of cemeteries and funeral homes, cut its 2003 forecast after fiscal first-quarter net income fell. The recession has made it harder for Stewart to sell prepaid funeral products and services, and yields from the company's trust funds are leaner amid slumping financial markets. First-quarter profit was also hurt by an increase in cremations, which are less profitable than traditional burials. The company, which is based in Metairie, La., lowered its 2003 earnings forecast to 30 cents to 35 cents a share, from 40 cents to 43 cents. Net income in the first quarter ended Jan. 31 fell to 9 cents a share, based on a preliminary review, the company said. Stewart's stock fell $1.19, or 25 percent, to $3.60 a share.

title: Mother of Abused Newark Boys Is Held on a Probation Violation

description: Prime Minister Jos Mara Aznar of Spain, who met with President Bush last weekend to discuss the Iraq crisis, says they also agreed on the urgent need to address the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: REPORT ON INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY CONTRACTS The federal government awarded more than 650 information technology contracts to private sector companies last year, worth more than $60 billion, according to a new report. Input, a research company in Chantilly, Va., found that five departments combined for $44 billion in contract awards. The Department of Transportation led the federal government in outside technology spending, with contracts exceeding $24 billion. The contracts do not represent single-year expenditures because some of them span several years. Still, federal departments and agencies spent more than $24 billion for information technology services like applications operations, desktop services and data center operations, the report showed. The professional services sector accounted for information technology contracts of nearly $21 billion, the report found, while contracts for network and telecommunications services amounted to about $9.5 billion.  (NYT)

title: Blair Outlines Plans to Slash Emissions Over 50 Years
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair laid out ambitious plans today to fight global warming by cutting carbon dioxide emissions in Britain by 60 percent in the next five decades and gently criticized President Bush for failing to do more to combat the damaging effects of greenhouse gases.

title: World Business Briefing: Australia
description: AUSTRALIA: PROFIT SLIPS AT BHP BILLITON The mining and energy company BHP Billiton said its profit fell 19 percent, to $931 million, in the second half of 2002 compared with the period in 2001. The chief executive, Charles W. Goodyear, left, said the profit was "a solid result in difficult economic and geopolitical conditions." Mr. Goodyear, an American, replaced Brian P. Gilbertson, a South African who resigned last month after six months on the job. Mr. Goodyear warned of tough times ahead, with weak equity markets, high oil prices and lower consumer demand. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ex-Official Sentenced In Building Corruption
description: A former official at a state construction agency was sentenced yesterday to three to nine years in prison after pleading guilty to taking thousands of dollars in kickbacks to help subcontractors receive payment for work they never performed at four colleges in Queens and Brooklyn. The official, Michael O'Connor, was project manager for the New York State Dormitory Authority and had worked for the agency for 17 years. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: France and Germany Call for Long Inspections

The document was released as the United States, Britain and Spain introduced a United Nations Security Council resolution declaring that Baghdad has failed to disarm as required and must face "serious consequences," diplomatic code for war.

title: At Least 261 Die in Earthquake in Remote Western China
description: A severe earthquake rocked a remote area along China's far western border on Monday morning, and Chinese officials said it killed at least 261 people and destroyed thousands of homes and other buildings.

title: Night Death Traps
description: The deadliest fire in American history occurred at Boston's Cocoanut Grove nightclub in 1942, when 492 patrons perished. The country seems to have learned nothing from that tragedy involving blocked and poorly marked exits. Two horrific cases of negligence last week, at nightclubs in Chicago and Rhode Island, caused the death of at least 118 more. Somehow, when it comes to establishing and enforcing safety codes for such places, we tolerate leniency that is nothing short of criminal. There is a widespread resistance to the notion that revelers crammed into dark entertainment venues late at night deserve the same safe environment as, say, office workers. This must change.

title: Regional Squabbling Scuttles an Iraqi Opposition Meeting
description: The nearly deserted Nezirhan Hotel, which bills itself as a ''unique tourism complex,'' has seen better times. And thanks to Saddam Hussein, it hopes to see them again soon.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN GAINS. The yen strengthened as the nomination of a central banker led to speculation that Japan would not adopt any policies to weaken the currency. In New York, the dollar settled at 117.92 yen, from 118.80 on Friday.

description: Mary Nathan's life was saved, but Carlos Urrutia learned he faced a premature death. Bonnie Davis received the assurance she needed to have another child, but Amy Hefner got news that might keep her from having another. Ray Krone was freed after 10 years in prison for a crime he did not commit; Mack Reaves III was convicted of a crime he committed 10 years earlier.
