Bolton, the under secretary of state for arms control and international security, will also discuss Russian participation in building a ballistic-missile defense system and proposals to help Russia safeguard its nuclear arsenal.    Michael Wines (NYT)

title: In Love With Asia, Muse and Market
description: Past the mannequins larger than Berninis near the entry of the Prada store on lower Broadway hangs a short-sleeve mandarin-collar fuchsia satin shirt, which will diminish the bank account of any future owner by a sum roughly equal to the cost of an airline ticket to Beijing: $1,365. Around the corner at Miu Miu, Prada's girlish secondary line, a similarly styled garment, with the added attraction of printed fern leaves, can be acquired for the comparative bargain of $495.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cisco Expands 2 Alliances
description: Cisco Systems announced yesterday that it would expand two existing partnerships that are aimed at helping the company, the maker of network equipment, expand from its traditional markets. In two announcements, Cisco said it was intensifying its alliances with AT&T and with the Hewlett-Packard Company. In their partnership, Cisco and AT&T will jointly market and sell products and consulting services in the area of data transportation, security and storage. The partnership will aim at small and medium-size businesses, the partners said. In the second alliance, Hewlett-Packard said it would make its desktop and mobile computers compatible with Cisco technology that allows such computers to get access to data over wireless networks, the partners said. Matt Richtel(NYT)

title: War on Iraq? Calls to Act, and Voices of Doubt; At the Front
description: To the Editor:

title: CYNTHIA KENYON
description: She studies aging in C. elegans, a flatworm, at the University of California at San Francisco.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Names Cultural Advisers
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday appointed 21 new members, including the painter Chuck Close, left, to the Cultural Affairs Advisory Commission, a body mandated by the City Charter to advise the mayor and the cultural affairs commissioner. The last commission, under Giuliani administration, was controversial. It was appointed with the goal of possibly determining which museums should receive city money based on their exhibitions, after a show at the Brooklyn Museum outraged Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. The Giuliani members' terms have expired. The new committee members will provide assistance and advocacy for cultural organizations but will not screen for indecency, Mayor Bloomberg said. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, CLAIRE
description: MURPHY-Claire. Of New York City and Kent, CT on February 24, 2003, at NY Presbyterian Hospital. Daughter of the late Lillian & Peter Murphy; sister of Daniel R. Murphy of Williamsville, NY and the late Peter J. Murphy, Mary Alice Murphy, Emmett R. Murphy and Gerald J. Murphy. Beloved by six, three nephews and many friends in NY, Kent, CT and Ireland. She was a graduate of Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart in NY. An editor for many years, she was also a partner of Murphy O'Hagan Coordinated Communica tions and a founding Vice President and prime mover for The Kent Land Trust. A memorial mass will be held Saturday, March 15 at 2PM, St. Thomas More, 65 E 89 St. Gifts in her memory may be sent to Convent of the Sacred Heart, 1 E. 91 St, NY 10128.

title: Volunteers Gather to Count the City's Homeless
description: About 1,000 volunteers gathered late last night at twelve areas in Manhattan and began fanning out after midnight in the city's first comprehensive effort to survey the homeless.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Ailing Dissident Blocked From Hospital
description: The hard-line Revolutionary Guards prevented the country's leading dissident cleric from traveling to a Tehran hospital for medical treatment, his son said. Grand Ayatollah Hossein Ali Montazeri, 80, a diabetic with heart problems, was to have had a checkup on Sunday, Ahmad Montazeri said, but his car was turned back because he refused to allow any guards to ride with him. Last month the authorities lifted a five-year house arrest of Ayatollah Montazeri, who was once in line to be Iran's supreme leader but fell out of favor because of his criticism of human rights abuses. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: Facing Down Iraq
description: Any lingering confusion about the fault line in the United Nations Security Council was erased yesterday by new American and French initiatives on Iraq. The United States wants a new resolution reaffirming the conclusion that Iraq has failed to disarm, effectively opening the way to a war sanctioned by the U.N. France, supported by Germany and Russia, prefers to give Hans Blix and his inspectors more time to see if they can disarm Iraq. The American resolution, introduced by Britain, deserves the Security Council's support.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAURICELLA, CARMINE
description: LAURICELLA - Carmine. Died on February 14th, 2003. Beloved husband of Millie. Father of John and Connie Favuzza, and grandfather to Karen, Janine and Laura. Served in World War II in the 907th Engineers. Retired from The New York Times in 1983, and has lived in Palm Coast, Florida.

title: Combat Role For the G.I.'s In Philippines Left Unclear
description: The possible combat involvement of American troops in the Philippines, opening a new front in the fight against terrorism, seemed unclear today after conflicting statements by officials of the two nations.

title: CHIEF RESIGNS AT CENDANT DIVISION THAT INCLUDES AVIS
description: The Cendant Corporation said yesterday that John Chidsey had resigned as chairman and chief executive of the company's vehicle and financial services division. The chief financial officer, Kevin Sheehan, 43, will assume responsibility for the vehicle unit, which includes the Avis rental car business. Samuel Katz, 37, chairman and chief executive of travel services, will take over financial services, which includes the Jackson Hewitt tax preparation business. Cendant is based in New York.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Austria: Far-Right Party In Coalition Talks
description: Chancellor Wolfgang Schssel's conservative Austrian People's Party began final talks to form a government with the far-right Freedom Party. The decision to renew the parties' coalition, three months after parliamentary elections, was reached after Mr. Schssel failed to form a government with either the Greens or the left-of-center Social Democratic Party. Hugh Eakin (NYT)

title: Carnival in Rio Is Dancing To More Commercial Beat
description: Picking the King of Carnival here used to be easy: find the city's fattest, jolliest man and stick a crown on his head. But after being reproached for weighing in at nearly 500 pounds, the current Rei Momo has succumbed to critics, begun exercising, changed his diet and lost 175 pounds over the last four years.

title: No Wind, Big Wind: Race 4 Off Again
description: When a yacht is stuck head-to-wind, sailors say it is ''in irons.'' No matter which way a helmsman turns the wheel, the boat sits there, bobbing as aimlessly as a piece of driftwood. It is about as frustrating a feeling as there is on a sailboat.

title: Teacher Faces Accusation She Had Sex With a Student
description: A teacher who created an independent program for gifted students in Paterson, N.J., was arrested yesterday on charges of sexually assaulting a teenage participant, the authorities said.

title: INSIDE
description: North Korea Tests Missile

title: Threats, Promises And Lies
description: So it seems that Turkey wasn't really haggling about the price, it just wouldn't accept payment by check or credit card. In return for support of an Iraq invasion, Turkey wanted -- and got -- immediate aid, cash on the barrelhead, rather than mere assurances about future help. You'd almost think President Bush had a credibility problem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, NATHAN
description: COHEN-Nathan, 83. Of Delray Beach, FL, formerly of New Hyde Park, NY, died peacefully at Hospice by the Sea in Boca Raton on Friday, February 21, 2003. Survived by his devoted wife of 61 years, Ruth (Heller) and children, Mark and Ellen Cohen and granddaughter Julie of Scarsdale, NY; Sandy and Tim Hott, and grandchildren Jaime, Molly, and Barry of Great Neck, NY; Warren and Robin Cohen, and grandchildren Daniel, Andrew, and Lisa of Great Neck, NY; and Sheila and David Feinberg and grandchildren Nina, Jed, and Ethan of Bethesda, MD. We will all remember ''Nunnie'' for his devotion to his ''Ruthie''; his love and respect for his parents, in-laws, and large extended family; his joy and pride in his children and grandchildren and their personal and professional accomplishments; his sincere warmth and engaging manner; his love of handball and golf; and his enduring belief in the positive spirit that always guided him through the course of a fulfilled life. Contributions in Nat's memory may be made to the Hospice by the Sea, 1531 West Palmetto Park Road, Boca Raton, Florida 33486.

title: Alumni Pressure Harvard To Put Reins on Spending
description: With its vast, unmatched wealth, Harvard is the envy of universities around the world. Yet it is wasting tens of millions of dollars each year because, unlike most corporations, it rarely makes the effort to look for the best deals on the $1 billion in goods and services it buys annually.

title: FRONT ROW
description: Making War and Making Nice

title: National Briefing | West: California: Guilty Plea In Transgender Case
description: One of four men charged in the hate-crime killing in October of a 17-year-old boy who lived as a girl pleaded guilty to voluntary manslaughter. The plea was made at a preliminary hearing for the man, Jaron C. Nabors, 19, of Newark, as part of a deal with prosecutors. Mr. Nabors agreed to testify against his three friends in exchange for a sentence of 11 years. The men are charged with murder in the beating and strangulation of the boy, Eddie Araujo. Prosecutors say the men killed Mr. Araujo, whom they knew as Lida, after learning that he was anatomically male. Dean E. Murphy (NYT)

title: Analyst Reduces Advertising Forecast
description: The analyst who follows Madison Avenue for Merrill Lynch & Company in New York, Lauren Rich Fine, has cut her estimates for advertising spending in 2003.

title: Strong Times at Manhattan Meet
description: Gabriel McLaren of Freeport High School on Long Island and Lance Wigfall of East Orange High in New Jersey registered outstanding victories, and Jim Morrison of Willingboro, N.J., repeated as a double winner last night in the 67th annual Eastern States championships at the Armory Track and Field Center in Manhattan.

title: Voice From a Scruffy Bar, Now Heard Everywhere
description: Morgan Taylor was standing in a hotel room on Union Square about 8:30 p.m. when he first heard the name of his friend Norah Jones announced as a winner Sunday night at the Grammy Awards.

title: U.S. Justices Reopen Door a Bit for State Inmates' Appeals
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25  The Supreme Court ordered a new hearing for a Texas death row inmate today in a surprisingly broad 8-to-1 decision that warned the federal courts of appeals against shutting the door prematurely on state prisoners who seek to present constitutional challenges to their convictions or sentences.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, ELLIOTT
description: SHAPIRO-Elliott. The New York Institute for Gestalt Therapy mourns the loss of a founder who brought Gestalt Therapy into the larger community and reformed the educational system. Dan Bloom, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELIAS, BETTY
description: ELIAS-Betty. Beloved wife of the late Ben Elias. Loving mother to Butch and Valerie, Jason and Birgit, Stanley and Terry, Estelle and Marty. Loving grandmother and great-grandmother. Loved by all who knew her. Her kindness will not be forgotten. Martin I. Elias and Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NATHANSON, GARY S. (YARON)
description: NATHANSON-Gary S. (Yaron), 76. Peacefully on February 23. He was a graduate of Music and Art High School and received a B.A. and an M.A. from the University of Wisconsin. He was a W.W. II army veteran and served in both the European and Pacific theaters. A member of Actors Equity, he enjoyed a long career in the theater. He was the son of the late Zipora and Moshe Nathanson, the Cantor of S.A.J. He is survived by his wife Ann Kate Carr; two daughters and their husbands Kim Nathanson & Steve Sager and Rachel Nathanson & Kevin Conley; one son Mark Nathanson; a stepson Adam Carr; two granddaughters Noa Sager and Sasha Conley; sisters Nomi Brettler and Deena Starr; brother-in-law Jay Starr; a niece; three nephews; loving in-laws and many devoted friends. He was predeceased by his niece Neva Starr and his beloved grandson Nathan Chapman. Gary was a rabid New York Giants fan and a lifelong, passionate Democrat. He was well known for his amazing voice, his humor and for doing the Sunday Times crossword puzzle in ink. Memorial service to be held Tuesday, February 25 at Wien & Wien Memorial Chapel in Englewood, NJ. The family will be at home on February 26 and 27. Contributions may be made to Cancer Care in Ridgewood, NJ. He will be sorely missed.

title: U.S. Crackdown Sets Off Unusual Rush to Canada
description: Once Jalil Mirza decided to leave the United States to avoid possible deportation, nothing happened quite as he expected, not even goodbye.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Profit Slips At BHP Billiton
description: The mining and energy company BHP Billiton said its profit fell 19 percent, to $931 million, in the second half of 2002 compared with the period in 2001. The chief executive, Charles W. Goodyear, left, said the profit was ''a solid result in difficult economic and geopolitical conditions.'' Mr. Goodyear, an American, replaced Brian P. Gilbertson, a South African who resigned last month after six months on the job. Mr. Goodyear warned of tough times ahead, with weak equity markets, high oil prices and lower consumer demand. John Shaw (NYT)

title: A Revolution at 50
description: In the 50 years since Francis Crick and James D. Watson discovered the double-helix structure of DNA, genetics has transformed the world. A special issue of Science Times explores the way one molecule has dominated

title: 2 Council and 2 Assembly Races Go to Voters Today
description: Candidates in four special elections in Brooklyn and the Bronx worked feverishly into the night yesterday, with their staffs making phone calls, putting together car pool operations and placing final touches on efforts to draw voters to the polls today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKYDELL, DR. RUTH
description: SKYDELL-Dr. Ruth. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Rabbi Adrian Skydell on the loss of his beloved wife. An active and longtime member of the National Women's Division Board, Ruth was a special lady, whose kindness touched so many. A Golden Founder of the Medical Center, together with her husband, her modesty and acts of tzedekah were the hallmarks of her life. May Rabbi Skydell, Laurie, Bernard ''Buddy'', Harry, grandchildren and the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Falls
description: The merchandise trade surplus in Japan contracted for the first time in 11 months as imports surged along with the rise in crude oil prices. The country's surplus stood at 105 billion yen ($890 million) in January, 42.8 percent lower than in January 2002. Exports grew 7.9 percent, but imports grew even faster, at 10.7 percent. The trade surplus with the United States, Japan's single largest trading partner, fell 8.9 percent. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOMMASI, LILLIAN
description: TOMMASI-Lillian. On February 21, 2003, of Manhattan, after a long term illness. Dear sister of Richard Tommasi, Andrienne Rympalski, Elissa Tommasi, the late Mario Tommasi Jr. (Elaine), and other family members. Visiting hours today, 2pm-4:30pm,7-9:30pm at Wantaugh Abbey Funeral Home, 3374 Park Ave, Wantaugh, NY. Mass of Christian Burial 9:45am Wednesday, St. Barnabas in Bellmore, NY. Cremation private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FULLER, BERNARD H.
description: FULLER-Bernard H. Age 95, in Boca Raton, Florida, formerly of Great Neck, NY. He is survived by his wife of 72 years, Helen, also 95, and children Deborah, Harrison, and Patricia, and June and Martin Sloane; seven grandchildren, twenty great grandchildren and 13 great-great grandchildren. He was born on the Lower East Side of Manhattan on July 19, 1907 the 10th of 11 children. He was the founder of the Fuller Tool company a leading supplier of hand tools in the USA, Canada, England, Australia and Japan. In 1947 he started Westhall Richardson in Sheffield, England, which later became Regent Sheffield of Farmingdale, NY. ''Bernie'' Fuller, remained active in the Company until his retirement in 1995. Beyond his legendary prowess in the hand tool industry, Bernard Fuller was a man of integrity, wisdom and great generosity. He was an early and lifelong supporter of the State of Israel. He and his wife Helen established the first music scholarship for the American Israeli Cultural Foundation. In retirement, he became a founder and volunteer at Mt. Sinai Hospital in Miami Beach. He was a former member of The Glen Oaks Club, Old Westbury, New York. He will be missed and fondly remembered.

title: Grocery Chain Owner Overstated Earnings
description: Royal Ahold, the giant Dutch-based grocer and food distributor, said today that it had overstated its earnings by at least $500 million over the last two years. The company's chief executive and chief financial officer are resigning.

title: City-Sold Lots Stay Vacant, Report Says
description: Hundreds of vacant lots that the city has sold at auction since 1996 remain empty trash-strewn lots that blight neighborhoods in desperate need of more housing, according to a report released yesterday by a housing advocacy group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, ELEANOR L. ''ELLY''.
description: ROBBINS-Eleanor L. ''Elly''. Died peacefully in her sleep in her New York apartment on February 16th at 85. She served for 11 years as Chairman of Public Relations for Greater New York for the American Red Cross. Elly Robbins began her Red Cross career in 1939 and put in 49 years of dedicated volunteer service to both the American and International Red Cross all over the globe. In 1989, Mrs. Robbins was a recipient of the Harriman Award for Distinguished Volunteer Service, the highest award presented by the Red Cross to a volunteer. Between 1965 and 1979 Robbins visited 17 national Red Cross societies establishing public relations programs where none had existed. On Christmas Eve in 1988, Robbins traveled to the Thai/Cambodian border to bring good wishes to an American Red Cross medical team. Mrs. Robbins worked to develop new materials and in a highly competitive market she succeeded in significantly enhancing the access of the Red Cross to electronic media. Born Eleanor Landau, she was married nearly four decades to attorney Manuel L. Robbins (d. 1976). Mrs. Robbins is survived by her children Thomas Robbins and Liz Robbins, and her granddaughter Robin Johnson, daughter of Liz Robbins and her husband, Doug Johnson. She will be greatly missed by friends, family and colleagues. Memorial donations should be sent to the Red Cross-Harlem Chapter. Condolences may be sent to Liz Robbins and Doug Johnson at 2211 Broadway #

title: Albany Puts Contraceptives Center Stage
description: Thirty-three years after New York became the first state to repeal the ban against abortion, it is emerging as the latest battleground over reproductive rights, with city and state lawmakers divided over whether emergency contraceptives should be made widely available to women.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMINASH, EMANUEL

Morris, 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, N.Y., Wednesday, February 26 at 12:15. We have lost our shining light.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25  President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair today dismissed an initiative for extended United Nations inspections in Iraq, as the United States and Britain engaged in an intense round of lobbying to find the votes they need for a resolution that could lead to war.

title: French-German Plan on Iraq Is 'Absurd,' Blair Says
description: LONDON, Feb. 25 — Prime Minister Tony Blair today dismissed a French-German plan for disarming Iraq, saying it was "absurd" to believe Saddam Hussein would relinquish his weapons while he was allowed to continue resisting United Nations demands for full cooperation.

title: SCRUTINY FOCUSES ON CLUB'S OWNERS
description: In the immediate hours after 97 people died in a fast-moving fire at a West Warwick nightclub last week, much of the focus centered on the heavy metal band whose pyrotechnics ignited the blaze. The club's owners were described as a pair of industrious brothers, local boys, who were well liked and conscientious.

title: Technology Briefing: Deals
description: EARTHLINK SAID TO BE NEAR PACT WITH VONAGE EarthLink, the nation's third-largest Internet service provider, is expected to announce soon a deal with Vonage, an Internet telephone company, to provide nationwide telephone service to its users, people involved in the transaction said yesterday. EarthLink is planning to sell Vonage's service, which allows broadband users to place an unlimited number of local and long-distance calls for $39.99 a month, under its own name, these people said. The deal is expected to extend the reach of Internet-based telephone services, which compete with traditional service from large local phone companies like Verizon Communications and SBC Communications . Financial terms of the deal were not released.   Simon Romero (NYT)

title: An Antiwar Demonstration That Does Not Take to the Streets
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  The Mall was quiet, but the switchboard on Capitol Hill was swamped today as anti-war protesters conducted what they called the first "virtual march" on Washington. The organizers, a coalition called Win Without War, said that hundreds of thousands of people were sending messages by email, fax and telephone to the Senate and the White House.

Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair on Tuesday dismissed a French-German initiative for greatly extended UN inspections in Iraq, as the United States and Britain engaged in intense worldwide lobbying to find the votes they need for a UN resolution that could lead to war.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 — The chief United Nations weapons inspector said today that full compliance by Iraq was still not evident, though there were some additional signs of Iraqi cooperation.

description: Reggie Jackson was once the most dynamic Yankee, a player whose Hall of Fame career was filled with incredible moments that solidified his spot in baseball history. Now Jackson is simply a special adviser to George Steinbrenner who spends part of the baseball season evaluating and motivating major league and minor league players.

title: Grand Jurors Interrogate Cardinal Law
description: Cardinal Bernard F. Law, who resigned as archbishop of Boston last December, was questioned today by a criminal grand jury that is trying to decide whether to indict him or other Boston church officials for their handling of clergy members accused of sexual abuse.

title: Turkish Parliament Is Asked to Approve U.S. Troops
description: Turkey's government asked Parliament today to allow as many as 62,000 American troops into the country for up to six months for an attack on Iraq, Turkish officials said.

title: Nassau Credit Rating Rises As Finances Are Repaired
description: County Executive Thomas R. Suozzi's efforts to revive Nassau's long-troubled finances won a coveted upgrade in the county's bond rating today, reversing about a decade of downgrades.

title: Split Panel Votes Against Keeping Newark Schools Chief
description: A deeply split advisory board for the state-controlled Newark school district voted tonight to recommend that a popular Newark-born superintendent not be retained, instead endorsing her rival, a former Detroit school administrator.

title: Yao's Garden Debut Brings Out Best in Knicks
description: Madison Square Garden was sold out last night, buzzing despite the Knicks' four-game losing streak out West, bustling despite their dwindling playoff chances. Yao Ming was in the building, so the home team's plight was overlooked.

title: For a Day In Jerusalem, Bitter Conflict Is Snowed Out
description: Israeli children staked out positions along Jerusalem's main arteries, and their Palestinian counterparts commandeered rooftops above alleys in the Old City. They waited for the unsuspecting, and then cut loose -- with snowballs.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Tusks Seized
description: The authorities seized 33 elephant tusks weighing 796 pounds at a roadblock in the north of the country in what they described as the largest such seizure of ivory in three years. Five men, all Kenyans, were arrested. Environment Minister Newton Kulundu said the incident showed the need to keep in place a ban on the ivory trade, which endangers elephants. Last year, southern African countries allowed a one-time sell-off of their ivory stocks, a move opposed by Kenya. Marc Lacey (NYT)

Flanagan of New York City, James Waite of Fairlawn, NJ Agnes Donaghy & Elizabeth McCabe; loving grandmother of Thomas, Devon, Nick and Anthony; and aunt of many nephews and nieces. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARROLL, JOAN
description: CARROLL-Joan. Of Rehoboth Beach, DE. Joan Carroll was born Joan Neilson on February 13, 1926 in Philadelphia, PA. Since 1980 she has been a resident of Rehoboth Beach, DE. After a long illness she passed away on February 23, 2003 surrounded by her six surviving children. Mrs. Carroll served as a guide at the Winterthur Museum and more recently as a docent at the Rehoboth Art League. She also was an active member of the Henlopen Acres Beach Club. Joan is survived by her husband Thomas J. Carroll of Middleburg, Virginia, and her children Margaret Carroll Eldridge of San Diego, CA; Cornelius X. Carroll of St. Simons Island, GA; Michael M. Carroll of Glen View, IL; Joann Carroll Linden of Reston, VA; Thomas J. Carroll, Jr. of Middleburg, VA, and Moira M. Carroll of Chicago, IL., and seven grandchildren. A son Christopher T. Parsell Funeral Homes & Crematorium, Atkins-Lodge Chapel, Lewes, DE.

title: Turning a Competition Into a Public Campaign; Finalists for Ground Zero Design Pull Out the Stops
description: Packed meetings at Town Hall, get-out-the-vote e-mails and head-to-head chats with Charlie Rose may not be as rugged and ritualized as photo-ops in the South Bronx, but in many ways the architects proposing designs for the World Trade Center site have been acting like media-age politicians.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: TIMES SQUARE RESTAURANT CLOSES World Wrestling Entertainment closed its restaurant in Times Square yesterday, the company announced. Its retail store will be open until April 27, an official said. Revenues at the restaurant declined 28 percent to $2.8 million, the company said. "We are reallocating resources to the continued growth of our global business, rather than focusing on a single, site-specific and local project," said Linda McMahon, chief executive. In its third fiscal quarter report, the company announced a loss of $26.7 million, compared with income of $8.5 million in the same period last year. Attendance for its events for the quarter was about 373,900 compared with 446,500 in the previous year's third quarter. The entertainment complex also includes a concert hall, television and audio production facilities, a nightclub and a 300-seat theater.

title: High School Tells Student To Remove Antiwar Shirt
description: Bretton Barber, a high school junior in Dearborn Heights, Mich., who is deeply interested in civil liberties, knew what to do when he was sent home from school on Feb. 17 for wearing a T-shirt with a picture of President Bush and the words ''International Terrorist.''

title: Giving Green or Turning Red
description: SEVERAL years ago, this wealthy ski town came up with a shrewd plan to hold down property taxes and at the same time maintain high-quality public schools. This was a sure thing, town leaders explained, as long as all 4,000 residents volunteered to stick to the plan. Skeptics said that getting 4,000 New Englanders to agree on anything would be like trying to commandeer a platoon of cats, but town leaders warned that there was no choice.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: G.M. To Invest In Technology Center
description: The No. 1 global carmaker General Motors will invest $60 million in a technology center in Bangalore, India's technology hub. G.M. said it would hire 260 engineers who will collaborate with the company's American and European research center through high-speed communication links. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Briefly Noted
description: PLAN FOR ARMING PILOTS Commercial airline pilots who want to be armed in the cockpit will have to carry their guns to and from planes in locked cases inside nondescript bags, under the final plan for arming pilots announced by the Transportation Security Administration. The administration said pilots would be permitted to holster the weapons only when inside the cockpit. "We don't want that weapon floating around inside the cabin," said a spokesman for the agency, Robert Johnson. Al Aitken, spokesman for the Allied Pilots Association, said that carrying a gun in a locked case would increase the chances that it could get lost or stolen. (AP)

title: Transplant Mix-Up Enters Debate on Malpractice Bills
description: The death of Jsica Santilln, the 17-year-old given a heart and lung transplant from a donor with an incompatible blood type, is influencing the Congressional debate on President Bush's proposal to limit damages in medical malpractice cases and may prevent the plan from passing intact, lawmakers say.

title: What It Will Take to Recruit Principals: A Lot
description: If New York City wants to attract award-winning principals from around the nation, here is what principals say the city must offer: income and retirement benefits that match what they get now, a comfortable place to live, successful schools for their own children and a promise that their decisions will be respected.

title: Bush Goes Global To Lobby for Votes On U.N. Measure
description: Never before has Angola felt so wanted.

title: Bush Sees Mideast Stability Once Iraqi Leader Is Disarmed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 — President Bush declared tonight that the Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein is "a direct and growing threat" but that a peaceful Iraq can help to bring peace and stability to the entire Middle East.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERTON, ROBERT K.
description: MERTON-Robert K. On February 23, 2003. Adored husband of Harriet Zuckerman Merton; loving father of Robert C. & Vanessa Merton, and Stephanie Tombrello; cherished grandfather and great-grandfather; devoted brother of the late Emma Hopkins. Contributions in his memory may be made to Columbia University or Temple University. A memorial service will be held at Columbia University at a later date. Funeral private.

title: Grim Reminder in Performance on Grammys
description: Three nights after the rock band Great White's stage pyrotechnics burned down a club in Rhode Island, killing 97 people and leaving 187 people injured, the Grammy Awards broadcast on Sunday night from Madison Square Garden included a segment with flames leaping skyward as Nelly performed his Grammy-winning hit "Hot in Herre."

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SULLIVAN, PAT
description: SULLIVAN-Pat. One year ago today as you laid your head on my shoulder to say goodbye I knew that God had taken you, I knew my heart would break in two, as I lost my lifelong best friend, my husband. Sadly missed by your wife, Catherine ''Katie''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Market Place; Royal Ahold Accounting Scandal Leaves Dutch Employees With Heavy Debts
description: The accounting scandal at Royal Ahold has left thousands of its Dutch employees in debt to the company.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Unusual Request Granted In Gun Suit
description: Lawyers suing gun manufacturers in federal court in Brooklyn were granted an unusual request yesterday that could lead to the removal of the manufacturers' lawyers in a trial that is to begin next month. Under the order, the plaintiff, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, can take sworn testimony from some lawyers who attended gun industry meetings. The request was prompted by an industry whistle-blower who said gun makers' lawyers had met to work against firearms safety proposals. The judge who granted the request, Cheryl L. Pollak of United States District Court, said, however, that it was premature to order testimony from two lawyers representing gun makers in the suit, James P. Dorr and Timothy A. Bumann, but she added that after testimony from others at the meetings, disqualification of the two trial lawyers ''may be unavoidable.'' William Glaberson (NYT)

title: Anti-Abortion Groups Prevail in Challenge to Extortion Law
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  In a decision that affects a wide spectrum of protest activities, the Supreme Court ruled today that a federal law against extortion was improperly used to punish aggressive anti-abortion demonstrators.

title: A Honeymoon, Then the In-Laws
description: When a network like CBS does not send out review tapes of its much anticipated new sitcom, ''My Big Fat Greek Life,'' that does not necessarily mean something is wrong. It is, however, a little like a doctor asking a patient to come in and discuss the test results in person -- it is impossible not to feel a pinch of dread.

title: E-mail and gray hair:Anti-war campaign has a new look
description: WASHINGTON:  CORRECTION PUBLISHED IN THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE DATED Friday, February 28, 2003:

title: You've Got Mail! A Monthly Recap From the Mayor
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, the former media mogul who has made it clear on many occasions that reporters and their ilk are the bane of his City Hall existence, has figured out a way to bypass them: send out his own version of the news in a digital newsletter.

title: Planners Say Tolls Will Ease Jams in 8 Cities
description: Traffic planners released a plan today that they say will guarantee commuters in eight large cities speedy drives or bus rides to work. Their vision of congestion-free lanes is familiar, but this time, the experts have an ambitious national plan and at least some influential allies.

title: Espada Wins Council Race in the Bronx
description: Former State Senator Pedro Espada Jr., a longtime Bronx official, was apparently returned to public office yesterday when he won a special election for a City Council seat. Mr. Espada will fill the remaining term of Ruben Diaz Sr., who defeated him in November in a Senate contest, another bruising battle.

title: Salmon Hot From the Oven, and No Slaving at the Sink
description: ''BARCELONA is like Paris, but with Latin flavor,'' Bobby Flay said as he peeled a potato in the kitchen of his Chelsea loft. Mr. Flay had just returned from a week's vacation in Barcelona, the city that inspired him in 1993 to open Bolo, the Spanish restaurant in Manhattan where he is also the executive chef.

title: Hoping for Answers Despite Lack of Clues
description: Investigators are laboriously trying out theories of flaws that could have led to the breakup of the space shuttle Columbia that are consistent with the data and images in hand, leaders of the investigation said today, because they expect to recover no more than about 20 percent of the wreckage and may not be able to tease the cause out of the debris.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKLE, EDITH J.
description: FRANKLE-Edith J., February 24. Beloved wife and sister; mother of Michael, Rosanne and Shari; grandmother and friend. We will miss you.

title: Brazilian Government's Mixed Signals
description: With Brazil's energy market in a shambles and several utilities -- including some belonging to the AES Corporation of the United States -- facing possible insolvency, Brazil's new left-leaning government is facing perhaps its most serious test yet.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: A Landmark Upgrades

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, EMANUEL
description: KAUFMAN-Emanuel, 82. On February 22, 2003. Retired CBS engineer. Beloved father, grandfather, brother, uncle and friend. Services are today, 12, Plaza Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. at 91st St.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COPPENRATH, LUCETTE VAN LOMMEL
description: COPPENRATH-Lucette Van Lommel. 1932-1996 She was our pride and joy. Bob, Margaret and Martina

title: Liquor Industry and Scientists At Odds Over Alcohol Study
description: A study of excessive drinking that appears in today's issue of the Journal of the American Medical Association has started a saloon brawl of its own between the authors and the liquor industry, with each side accusing the other of manipulating the figures.

title: Refuting 'Myth,' Study Finds Most Cerebral Palsy Predates Labor
description: Despite widespread belief among both doctors and lay people that cerebral palsy results from lack of oxygen to the baby's brain during labor and delivery, a new report says that birth asphyxia alone accounts for 10 percent of cases at most.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Record Executive's Shooting Investigated
description: Detectives investigating the shooting of the brother of Irv Gotti, the rap impresario, focused yesterday on the possibility that he accidentally shot himself in the leg, the police said. No gun has been found. Investigators also said Mr. Gotti's brother, Christopher Lorenzo, 39, also a record executive, might have been shot accidentally by an associate or by someone he did not want to name. He was leaving the Murder Inc. recording company on Eighth Avenue about 8:30 p.m. on Monday when a shot rang out. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Air Force's Top Officer Pledges Inquiry of Assaults
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  The top general in the Air Force endorsed a Congressional call today for a broader Pentagon inquiry at the Air Force Academy, where more than 20 women say they have been raped or sexually assaulted in recent years.

title: Tom Glazer, Folk Singer, Is Dead at 88
description: Tom Glazer, a folk singer and songwriter best known for his whimsical children's songs -- particularly one about a mountain of spaghetti -- died on Friday at his home in Philadelphia. He was 88.

title: New Evidence Raises Toll in South Korea Near 200
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 26  Fine-grained ash in the twisted wreckage has yielded evidence of the deaths of another 50 people in the fire that raged through two subway trains last week, bringing the death toll to nearly 200, officials said today.

title: Credit Suisse Reports Loss Of $2 Billion
description: The Credit Suisse Group reported a 2002 loss of 3.3 billion Swiss francs ($2.4 billion) today, and one of its co-chief executives called the results ''unacceptable.'' The company said it would eliminate 1,250 more jobs to try to get back to profitability.

title: Sunny, Sweet Fish Cakes
description: I'VE long used mashed potatoes to hold fish cakes together, so I didn't think it would be too much of a stretch to make a crunchier, more colorful and more flavorful fish cake using Caribbean spices and sweet potatoes in place of white ones.

title: Federated Names Chief Executive and Posts Quarterly Profit
description: Terry J. Lundgren, the chief operating officer at Federated Department Stores -- which owns 460 stores, including the Bloomingdale's and Macy's chains -- was named the company's chief executive, effective today.

title: Loiseau may have succumbed to the pressure of French success : A chef dies:How many stars are enough?
description: PARIS:  Bernard Loiseau, 52, chef-owner of La Cote d'Or restaurant in Burgundy  one of only 16 Michelin three-star restaurants in France  has died of a gunshot wound, apparently self-inflicted.

title: Maple Syrup, a Loner, Finds Partners
description: Maple syrup is an honest food that doesn't need any embellishments. But I was intrigued by Moosewood Hollow's line of maple syrups infused with herbs and spices. The company, in Plainfield, Vt., has five flavors. My favorite is Sweet Chai, intense with ginger and cardamom and good for drizzling over panna cotta or rice pudding. Sweet Autumn, with cinnamon and vanilla, will enhance French toast. Sweet Savory, with thyme and lemon, would be great as a glaze for carrots. Sweet Ginger has enough heat to punch up a sauce for poultry, and is a better bet than Sweet Heat, with chilies. The syrups cost $11 for seven ounces, including shipping, from (802) 479-7999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELIAS, BETTY
description: ELIAS-Betty. Beloved wife of the late Ben Elias. Loving mother to Butch and Valerie, Jason and Birgit, Stanley and Terry, Estelle and Marty. Loving grandmother and great-grandmother. Loved by all who knew her. Her kindness will not be forgotten. Martin I. Elias and Family

title: When France Lectures America
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: PRUDENTIAL MAY NOT RAISE DIVIDEND The large British insurance company Prudential said it might not raise its dividend in 2003, disappointing investors, who sent the stock down 18 percent. Insurance companies have felt the pinch from declining stock markets, and many of them are trying to conserve cash needed to underwrite new business. In 2002, Prudential, which has no ties to the Prudential Insurance Company of America , paid dividends totaling 26 pence (41 cents), compared with payments of 25.4 pence in 2001. The company also reported that operating profit for 2002 rose 2 percent, to 1.1 billion ($1.7 billion). Prudential said it needed to retain "financial flexibility" and that dividend payments would be determined based on the outlook for profits and a variety of other factors. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Miami and Bermuda polish their images to try to beckon Northeast residents.
description: SANDY white beaches and warm tropical breezes would seem to be enough of an attraction to lure tourists during this year's cold and snowy winter. But a stagnating economy, a jittery public and plenty of competition has prompted big tourist destinations like Miami and Bermuda to distinguish their respective brands beyond being just places for sun and fun.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about workers replacing a dome atop a building in Iowa City misidentified the building. It is the old Iowa Capitol, not the current one. The capital moved to Des Moines in 1857.

title: A Pizzeria Where You Can Skip the Pizza
description: IT takes salesmanship and flair to sell the idea of lard on a pizza. But these are precisely the qualities that define Otto, an inspired collaboration of four partners, Mario Batali, Joseph Bastianich, Mark Ladner and Jason Denton. The first two are well known to New York diners as the creators of Esca, Babbo and Lupa. At Otto, their largest restaurant to date, they took on two extra hands, Mr. Ladner, Lupa's chef, and Mr. Denton, a partner in Lupa. The new venture has its front door on Eighth Street, hence Otto, Italian for ''eight.'' That's OH-toe, please, not Ah-toe.

title: Venezuela's Lifeblood Ebbs Even as It Flows
description: Once more, tankers are setting sail loaded with crude bound for the United States, while government planners busily rebuild and reorganize the state-owned Petrleos de Venezuela, pondering how to function with 40 percent fewer workers.

title: City Asks Agencies for Cuts In Case Unions Don't Agree
description: The city sent a letter to all municipal agencies last night ordering them to find $600 million more that could be cut from the budget if the city's labor unions do not agree to the productivity savings being sought by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: Cingular's New Chief Replaces Campaign
description: The new chief executive of Cingular Wireless in Atlanta, brought in to help reverse the company's flagging fortunes, said yesterday that Cingular would make a change in its national advertising campaign by replacing ads that celebrate self-expression with ones that ''give customers a reason to buy Cingular.''

title: In Performance
description: DANCE

title: ANOTHER SENIOR EXECUTIVE LEAVES MERRILL LYNCH
description: Paul Thomas, 42, the co-head of the Merrill Lynch unit that trades government bonds, said he was retiring, becoming at least the eighth senior executive to leave the securities firm since December. Barry Wittlin, co-head of the global rates product group with Mr. Thomas since November 2001, will take over as the sole chief on March 31, Mr. Thomas said. Previously, Mr. Wittlin ran interest rate swaps, options, mortgage swaps and municipal derivatives. Mr. Thomas is also giving up his role on the group of Wall Street executives that advises the Treasury Department on managing the nation's $3.2 trillion in debt, said Woody Jay, managing director of liquid markets trading at Lehman Brothers Inc.

title: Still Youthful, Still Crooning After All These Years
description: Art Garfunkel

title: Developer of High-Rise Los Angeles Prepares for a Public Offering
description: Robert F. Maguire III, the developer widely seen here as being largely responsible for forging a high-rise downtown replete with parks and office towers in this city known for its endless suburbs, is consolidating ownership of his buildings, planning to sell them to public investors.

title: Woods-Els Final? The Best of Both Worlds
description: Tiger Woods does not know what it feels like to win the Accenture Match Play Championship. Nor do Ernie Els, Phil Mickelson or anyone ranked among the world's top 25 players.

title: Soriano Is Already in Midseason Form
description: If two intrasquad games tell anything, Alfonso Soriano is ready for opening day. Soriano, the Yankees' second baseman, homered today for the second day in a row.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: E.P.A. Approves the Use Of Monsanto's Altered Corn

title: THREATS AND RESPONSES: Briefly Noted; BRONZE STARS FOR CANADIANS
description: The Army has awarded Bronze Stars to four Canadians who were killed in April by an American bomber near Kandahar in Afghanistan, officials said. The medals for valor were sent to the United States Embassy in Ottawa on Jan. 21, the Army said. Embassy officials said they were working with their Canadian counterparts to determine ''the appropriate forum and timing for the awards'' to be presented to the families of the soldiers. The awards were first reported on Canadian television. While not unprecedented, according to Maj. Steve Stover, an Army spokesman, it is not common for American military awards to be given to foreign soldiers. The Army approved the awards for Pvt. Richard Green, Cpl. Ainsworth Dyer, Sgt. Marc Leger and Pvt. Nathan Smith of the Third Battalion of the Princess Patricia's Canadian Light Infantry.

title: Litigation Expected On Ephedra in Sports
description: Lawyers representing the Minnesota Vikings filed court papers last Friday linking the stimulant ephedra with the death of offensive lineman Korey Stringer in 2001. Their supposition, however, has not been confirmed by test results.

title: Iraqi Denies Missiles Break Rules
description: In a segment of an interview with the CBS News anchor Dan Rather, broadcast last night, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq disputed the notion that his nation possesses missiles that United Nations weapons inspectors have ordered destroyed.

title: Venice Journal; If Sea Gates Don't Work, Call Canute
description: November was actually the cruelest month. For about two-thirds of it, the water that usually edges and lattices this improbably liquid city sloshed amok, turning Piazza San Marco into a gargantuan puddle and other low-lying areas into shin-high wading pools.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKYDELL, DR. RUTH H.
description: SKYDELL-Dr. Ruth H. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a deeply cherished leader in the Jewish community and member of the Board of Governors of the Ferkauf Graduate School of Psychology, the beloved wife of Rabbi Adrian Skydell who, as YU Guardians, established the Ruth K. Skydell Scholarship for graduates of Stern College for Women at FGS. Dr. Skydell was the beloved mother of Benjamin ''Buddy'' Skydell; Laurie (and Dr. Myron) Goldberg; and Yeshiva College Board member, Harry (and Rachel) Skydell; sister of Naomi (and Stanley) Berk; and an adored grandmother. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Ronald P. Stanton, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Dr. Jayne G. Beker, Chairman FGS Board of Governors

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Profit Falls At Winemaker
description: The country's largest wine producer and exporter, Southcorp, reported a decline of 97 percent in after-tax profit for the half-year. Sales increased 2 percent, to 728 million Australian dollars ($440 million) in the period, but costs, divestments, currency hedging, discounting and lower margins cut net profits to 5.7 million Australian dollars ($3.5 million) from 210 million Australian dollars. Southcorp shares fell 16 percent. The British beverage group Allied Domecq and the Australian brewer Fosters have been named in media and market reports as possible bidders for Southcorp, whose big brands are Penfolds, Rosemount and Lindemans. But the executive chairman, Brian Finn, said the company had not received or requested any offers. John Shaw (NYT)

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: DEEP IN THE VOID, PIONEER 10 GOES SILENT Pioneer 10, the first spacecraft to venture out of the solar system, has fallen silent after traveling billions of miles from Earth over nearly 31 years, NASA said. What was apparently the spacecraft's last signal was received on Jan. 22 by the Jet Propulsion Laboratory's Deep Space Network, as Pioneer 10 was 7.6 billion miles from Earth. Nothing more was heard in a final attempt at contact on Feb. 7. Launched in 1972, Pioneer 10 became the first manmade object to leave the solar system when it passed the orbit of Pluto in 1983. (AP)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, HELEN
description: COHEN-Helen. The Board of Trustees of Temple Israel of the City of New York extends its deepest condolences to our esteemed President, Martin Cohen, on the death of his mother, Helen Cohen.

title: The Newest Big Guy Attracts New Fans
description: When Yao Ming was announced with the Houston Rockets' starting lineup last night for his first game at Madison Square Garden, Soo Koonlee leapt to her feet cheering, along with hundreds of Asian-Americans at the game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPPERT, FELICE
description: LIPPERT-Felice. The Hunter College community notes with sorrow the passing of our dear friend, a devoted alumna and member of our Hall of Fame. We extend deepest sympathy to her family. Jennifer J. Raab, President, Hunter College, CUNY

title: Governors Seek Aid From Congress and Decline to Back Medicaid Plan
description: Rebuffed by President Bush, the National Governors Association decided today to seek fiscal assistance from Congress, and some lawmakers said they would be willing to help states with the growing costs of Medicaid, education and domestic security.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, BERNARD S.
description: LEVINE-Bernard S. College professor, mentor and administrator, died at home on February 22, 2003, after a courageous struggle with pancreatic cancer. Adored husband for 53 years of Bunny (Bernice) Utal Levine, most extraordinary and beloved father of Marty, Francie and Joe, cherished father-in-law of Judy Forrest Levine and Jay Lubin and world's greatest grandfather to Robin Emily Levine and Jeffrey Robert Lubin. Bernie was also an avid tennis player and a supporter of the arts, especially of developing actors. His gentle spirit will be with us forever. Services will be held at the Jewish Memorial Chapel in Clifton, NJ. Donations to the Lustgarten Foundation for Pancreatic Cancer Research, or the Actors' Fund would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCHMAN, IDA
description: HOCHMAN-Ida. Of Boynton Beach, Florida formerly of Mt. Vernon, New York died February 25, 2003. Beloved wife of Henry, mother of Stephen, Marilyn and Bruce, grandmother of Beth Deborah, Barbara, Larry, Glenn, Susan, Lisa, Joclyn and Kendall, great-grandmother of Jordan, Spencer, Craig, Jeffery, Linsay, Samantha, Alissa, Deanna, Jae, Eli and Isaac. Services will be held on Thursday, February 27, 2003 at 12:00pm at The Westchester Riverside, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, New York. Interment to follow at Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

title: Sports of The Times; Yao Brings Old Buzz To Garden
description: YAO MING was tough on himself. When asked how he evaluated his performance last night, he could have referred to his 24 points, including 6 of 6 foul shots, in his first game at Madison Square Garden. Instead, he had only one standard for himself.

title: Did He Fiddle While Japan Burned?
description: Economic policy making here can often give the impression of a merry-go-round run amok. The arguments are circular, endless and tend to move in fits and starts. But just about everyone agrees on one point these days: Masaru Hayami failed as governor of the Bank of Japan.

title: Iraqi Star Tours U.S. And Sings Of Baghdad
description: In ''Beauty and His Love,'' the singer Kazem al-Sahir confesses to his girlfriend that there is someone he loves more than her, someone whom he sleeps with every night, someone whom he dreams of daily. His distraught girlfriend begs him to reveal the name of this lover. Her name, he finally tells her, is Baghdad.

title: The College Remembers Lehman; Its Students, Not So Much
description: The question stumped the three freshman in a cafeteria at Lehman College in the Bronx, where a certain name can be found all over. Just look at the banners that dangle from lampposts or the waist-high concrete sign near the Music Building.

title: Justices Stress Inmate's Right To Press Appeal
description: The Supreme Court ordered a new hearing for a Texas death row inmate today in a surprisingly broad 8-to-1 decision that warned the federal courts of appeals against shutting the door prematurely on state prisoners who seek to present constitutional challenges to their convictions or sentences.

title: When France Lectures America
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Bill For Improved 911 Network Advances
description: The State Assembly has passed a bill to hasten the creation of an advanced cellular telephone network to pinpoint cellphone users in emergencies. The bill, passed on Monday by a vote of 138 to 4, would let the state borrow $300 million in Dormitory Authority bonds for use by 911 dispatch centers to buy the equipment. The bonds would be repaid in part by $20 million in state wireless surcharges already collected. The bill now goes to the Senate. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Bush's Plan For Pensions Is Now Given Low Priority
description: Less than a month after President Bush proposed a radical overhaul and expansion of individual retirement and savings accounts, the White House has abandoned the idea as a legislative priority.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLMANN, ANNA
description: POLLMANN-Anna. St. Petersburg, died February 19, 2003, Born NYC. Retired first female NY Supreme Court Reporter (Gregg). Widow of Patrick J. McDonough, 42nd Rainbow Division Veteran, Fr. Duffy Chapter, NY; retired Jury Clerk, NY Supreme Court. Sister of Henry Pollmann (deceased 1983), retired NY Appellate Division Librarian. Three nieces surviving: Patricia Pollmann, AnnLou Tobin, and Christine Mermagen. L.I. National Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDGRUND, WILLIAM V.
description: SANDGRUND-William V. On February 24th. Devoted husband of Gertrude for 65 years. Beloved father of David (Alice), Patricia Walter (Richard), Joan Rudominer (Howard) and Ronald (Cheryl). Dear brother of Ruth. Cherished grandfather of Amy, Jeffrey, Emily, Rebecca, Susanna and Daniel. Service Thursday, 11:30 AM, ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave, Brooklyn NY (Opposite Kings Plaza).

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Prudential May Not Raise Dividend
description: The large British insurance company Prudential said it might not raise its dividend in 2003, disappointing investors, who sent the stock down 18 percent. Insurance companies have felt the pinch from declining stock markets, and many of them are trying to conserve cash needed to underwrite new business. In 2002, Prudential, which has no ties to the Prudential Insurance Company of America, paid dividends totaling 26 pence (41 cents), compared with payments of 25.4 pence in 2001. The company also reported that operating profit for 2002 rose 2 percent, to 1.1 billion ($1.7 billion). Prudential said it needed to retain ''financial flexibility'' and that dividend payments would be determined based on the outlook for profits and a variety of other factors. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Fiat Chairman Leaving to Make Way for Agnelli
description: Fiat's chairman, Paolo Fresco, said today that he would step down on Friday, several months earlier than planned, to make way for Umberto Agnelli to take over.

title: Gates Foundation Providing $31 Million for Small Schools
description: The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation is providing $31 million to nonprofit groups to start small, alternative high schools for 36,000 students, calling the gift a mere taste of what it would take to reach the millions of children who are ''failed and forgotten'' by the nation's public schools.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Waz Wid Salman Rushdie? My Man Iz Wack

title: Designers' Dreams, Tempered By Reality
description: The decision on who will redesign the World Trade Center site is expected to be announced later this week. Both finalists, Studio Daniel Libeskind and Think, a team led by Rafael Violy, Frederic Schwartz, Shigeru Ban and Ken Smith, have extensively revised their plans at the request of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Morristown: Guilty Plea In College Homicide
description: A Jersey City man admitted yesterday in State Superior Court here that he strangled his former girlfriend last April 14 in her room at Fairleigh Dickinson University in Florham Park. In a plea agreement, the man, Novis Parker, 19, pleaded guilty to aggravated manslaughter and faces up to 20 years in prison. Mr. Parker, then a student at Felician College in Rutherford, had been charged with murdering the woman, Tiffany Bratton, 18, of Jersey City, after she would not resume a relationship. Robert Hanley (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHMAN, GLORIA R.
description: FISCHMAN-Gloria R., 79. Passed away on February 22nd, 2003. She was a former resident of Scarsdale, NY for 35 years and a resident of Tucson since 1981. Gloria graduated from Mount Holyoke College in 1944. She was preceded in death by her husband, DeWitt. Survived by Joanne (Howard) Adams, Alan (Sherry) Fischman; sister, Barbara (Howard) Barron; five grandchildren. Memorial contributions can be made to The Lighthouse International, 111 E. 59th St., NY, NY 10022, or a charity of your choice. For information contact Evergreen Mortuary & Cemetery, Tucson, AZ.

title: Corrections
description: The $25 and Under column on Feb. 12, about a Latino restaurant at 114 Dyckman Street in the Inwood section of Manhattan, misspelled its name. It is Republi'K, not Republ-K.

title: Turks and Kurds
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. to Resume Food Aid to North Korea, at a Reduced Level
description: The State Department announced today that it would resume shipments of food aid to North Korea, ending a two-month hiatus, but that it intended to cut donations this year by 35 to 75 percent from last year's totals.

title: Sharon Ousts Netanyahu as Foreign Minister
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 26  In a surprise move, Prime Minister Ariel Sharon today replaced his foreign minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, with a relative novice in diplomatic affairs as he filled the most important cabinet posts in his new government with members of his rightist Likud Party.

title: THREATS AND RESPONSES: Briefly Noted; CLERIC CONVICTED
description: Abdullah el-Faisal, 39, a London-based Muslim cleric who circulated English and Arabic-language tapes of his speeches urging people to kill Christians, Hindus, Jews and American citizens, was convicted of three counts each of soliciting murder and inciting racial hatred. A Jamaican-born convert to Islam after study in Saudi Arabia, Mr. Faisal encouraged followers to use chemical and nuclear weapons, and on one tape played in court, was heard promising teenage Muslim boys a reward in paradise of 72 virgins if they died as religious martyrs. He moved to Britain in the early 1990's and later became imam of the Brixton mosque in South London. Sentencing was set for March 7. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Resentment Festers At Ladder's Bottom Rung
description: A grim, gray and -- after 75 minutes -- gone film by Israel Adrin Caetano, ''Bolivia'' is a tough-minded though modestly told parable of life on the streets. At certain points -- when the mire of anger, poverty and xenophobia could seemingly take place anywhere -- Mr. Caetano's work is most telling and gripping. At others, his cold hostility toward Argentina, where the film is actually set, couldn't be more specific.

title: PANEL OF EXPERTS FAULTS BUSH PLAN TO STUDY CLIMATE
description: A panel of experts has strongly criticized the Bush administration's proposed research plan on the risks of global warming, saying that it ''lacks most of the elements of a strategic plan'' and that its goals cannot be achieved without far more money than the White House has sought for climate research.

title: The One That (Routinely) Gets Away
description: When Cornelius Gallagher, the chef at Oceana, named an appetizer ''Life in the Ocean,'' he wasn't kidding. The plate, bearing unusual tidbits like sea urchin, geoduck and razor clams, comes with a small bowl in which a live Japanese fighting fish does laps, albeit solely for the diner's amusement. Mr. Gallagher said he got the idea in Japan, and when he introduced it here he used goldfish. ''But a diner tried to stab one of them, and that upset the waiters, so I decided to try the fighting fish,'' he said, adding that they are feistier than goldfish. He has 15 of them, tended by two of his chefs, Andrea Abbete and Emily Vail. ''They take good care of them, and they live a long time,'' Mr. Gallagher said.

title: Effort Is Turned Back To Oust U.S.O.C. Chief
description: Lloyd Ward, the embattled chief executive of the United States Olympic Committee, escaped an effort last night to oust him during a stormy 90-minute conference call held by the organization's executive committee.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Police Miss Hearing On War Protest
description: The subject of the City Council hearing yesterday was the Police Department's handling of the antiwar demonstration on the East Side on Feb. 15, but no department representative was present, angering council members and dozens of opponents of a possible war in Iraq who crowded a City Hall hearing room. Michael P. O'Looney, the department's chief spokesman, said the department had been invited only days before and could not provide a representative on such short notice. Robert Worth (NYT)

title: National Briefing: Science and Health
description: FEAR OF SUITS AFFECTS DOCTORS' OPENNESS Doctors are usually less willing to discuss their errors than their affected patients would like, partly because they fear being sued, a study has found. In the study, 54 patients and 46 physicians were asked to react to a hypothetical error, in which a patient was given an overdose of insulin because someone misread a doctor's handwriting, causing the patient to pass out temporarily. The report was published in this week's Journal of the American Medical Association. (Reuters)

description: The MetroStars of Major League Soccer and the Power of the Women's United Soccer Association signed players, or are close to signing them, with about eight weeks to go before the start of the regular seasons.

title: THREATS AND RESPONSES: Briefly Noted; WAR PROTESTS IN ITALY
description: War protesters near the city of Pisa briefly blocked trains carrying American military equipment across Italy, forcing hundreds of Italian military and police officers to pull them away from the tracks. The trains were carrying jeeps, earthmovers and other equipment to Camp Darby, an American military base along the coast of Tuscany. Italy's interior minister, Giuseppe Pisanu, said he would use ''the full restraining force of the state'' to make sure the trains kept running. Frank Bruni (NYT)

title: THE FINE PRINT: Finding the Money; Pataki Seeks to Tap Health Fund in Budget Crisis
description: The shorthand name sounds like something one would have with collard greens and ham hocks, or perhaps like an exotic bush of some kind. It is pronounced hick-raw, and even though it dispenses about $3 billion a year for health care, most legislators do not know precisely how the money is spent, nor can they easily find out.

title: For Reed, Ewing Rules As No. 1 Knicks Player
description: Willis Reed, the Hall of Fame center many consider the best ever to play for the Knicks, said yesterday that in his estimation Patrick Ewing was the greatest player in Knicks history.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: City Added To Nightclub Suits
description: The City of Chicago was added as a defendant to two lawsuits against the owners and operators of the E2 nightclub, where 21 people were trampled on Feb. 17. The club was ordered closed in July because of a series of code violations, but the city failed to make sure its doors remained shut, the lawsuit says. Four inspectors visited the club after it was ordered closed but only during the day, city lawyers said. City officials said they could not comment on the amended lawsuits because they had not seen them yet. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: National Briefing: South
description: VIRGINIA: SEAFOOD HELP FROM ASIA State officials approved a plan to place a million Asian oysters in the Chesapeake Bay, despite concerns that the experiment to save the beleaguered seafood industry could go awry. Harvests of the bay's native oyster have slumped, largely because of disease, and the industry wants to supplement them with Asian oysters in a two-year experiment. The Virginia Institute of Marine Science approved a plan to render the Asian oysters sterile to prevent them from spreading and causing ecological problems. (AP)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''What is at stake is the use of this city as an ordinary city.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HA-LO INDUSTRIES INC., Northbrook, Ill., a maker of promotional products, in a move to emerge from bankruptcy protection, agreed to be bought by H.I.G. Capital, Miami, Fla., an investment firm, for $22 million in cash and notes.

title: Iraq Debate in Britain's Parliament Reveals Rift in Labor
description: LONDON, Feb. 26  A daylong debate in the House of Commons today laid bare the deep divisions in Prime Minister Tony Blair's Labor Party over his hard-line stance on disarming Iraq.

title: Nursing Home Blaze That Killed 10 Is Called 'Suspicious'
description: Afire raced through one wing of a Connecticut nursing home in the middle of the night, killing 10 people and sending 23 to hospitals with injuries, officials said today. The police said that investigators were questioning a resident who has been taken into custody.

title: Nonprofits Increasingly Find Space Affordable
description: Executives at a number of nonprofit groups say that the weak Manhattan office-leasing market is allowing them to upgrade their office spaces significantly and negotiate rents that would have been almost unthinkable a year ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEENAN, PATRICIA MARIE
description: KEENAN - Patricia Marie. Died February 13, 2003. Born in New York City-May 16, 1940. Daughter of the late Gertrude & William Keenan. Sister of the late Dorothea Johnson and Julia Fray. Survived by: sister, Susan Keenan; niece, Joan Dunay; great nephews, John, Greg and Eric Dunay; great niece Kristen Tresca and great-grandniece, Emma Tresca. Graduated from Cabrini College in 1962. Received MS from Fordham University. Retired from Printronic Corporation in 1995. Funeral Mass at St. Joseph's Church in Spring Valley, N.Y. Friday, February 28, 2003 at 10 AM. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: Cabrini College Office of Institutional Advancement, 610 King of Prussia Road, Radnor, PA. 19087.

title: A Voice That Is as Prepossessing as Its Packaging
description: With her recital at Carnegie Hall on Monday night, the soprano Karita Mattila proved to a full house of enraptured fans that you can be both a serious artist and a glittering diva. Her program, deftly accompanied by the pianist Martin Katz, was no prima donna showcase of familiar songs and arias, but a substantive selection of art songs by Duparc, Sibelius, Rachmaninoff and Dvorak.

title: Rangers And Devils Settle Nothing
description: Most of the crowd of 19,040 at Continental Arena tonight, the first-place Devils' first sellout of the season, came to jeer the former Devil Bobby Holik, who was wearing a Rangers uniform here for the first time.

title: Overturned Goal Deflates Isles in Toronto
description: Jason Blake is a fast and feisty player, but he is not a magician. So Blake, an Islanders center, was surprised when he was credited with redirecting a Jason Wiemer slap shot past Toronto goaltender Ed Belfour at a critical point in tonight's 5-2 loss to the Maple Leafs at Air Canada Center.

title: Bridgeport Mayor Takes Stand And Denies He Took Bribes
description: Mayor Joseph P. Ganim of Bridgeport, Conn., took the stand today in his federal corruption trial and emphatically denied the assertions of former associates that he had accepted money, meals and gifts from them in exchange for awarding contracts to their clients.

description: It is not every foreign leader who, in 48 whirlwind hours in Washington, gets to meet with the vice president, the secretary of defense, the national security adviser, the deputy secretary of state, the United States trade representative, influential senators and the chairman of the Federal Reserve.

TV cameras pressed close to get pictures of the vital American ally alighting from the black sedan for his one-on-one with President Bush.

description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon signed up a far-right party to his proposed government early today, a move that would increase his parliamentary majority and add to the hawkish complexion of his coalition.

title: After Ephedra Hearing, County Is Closer to Ban
description: While it is still not clear what role ephedra may have played in the death of Steve Bechler, the Baltimore Orioles pitcher, Bechler's collapse from heatstroke last week was the backdrop at a hearing today on legislation to ban the sale of products containing ephedra in Suffolk County.

title: Amy Miller, 90, a Founder of Shaker Village
description: Amy Bess Williams Miller, who helped found Hancock Shaker Village, a restoration of a former Shaker community and a museum, died on Sunday at her home in Pittsfield, Mass. She was 90.

description: A CHEF'S second restaurant is like a writer's second novel or a band's second album. It could be the one that wins him a permanent place in the pantheon -- or a spot on the heap of one-hit wonders.

title: One of These Days, They'll Race Again
description: Race 4 of the America's Cup was postponed yet again today because of a low-pressure center off New Zealand that sent 30-knot winds and 5-foot seas onto the Hauraki Gulf, where Cup races are held.

title: Sony Official to Stay
description: John Calley, a top executive at Sony Pictures Entertainment since 1996 and, at 72, the subject of frequent rumors that he might soon retire, extended his contract today to remain chairman through March 2005.

title: Bomb Blasts Wound 9 at 2 Beijing Universities
description: Explosions apparently caused by homemade bombs ripped through cafeterias at two of China's most prominent universities around lunchtime today, Chinese officials and students said. At least nine people were wounded.

title: Consumer Confidence Drops to a 9-Year Low
description: Consumer confidence plunged in February to its lowest level in more than nine years, the Conference Board, a private research group, reported yesterday, as concerns about a possible war with Iraq, rising energy prices and jobs took a toll on attitudes.

title: Nets Are Saddened by MacCulloch's Condition

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Dissident Arrested At Airport
description: A human rights advocate and former member of Parliament, Qassem Sholeh-Sadi, was arrested on Monday after he arrived in Tehran from France, the Iranian Student News Agency quoted his wife as saying. title: Blair, Facing Dissent in Party, Dismisses French-German Plan
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair, trying to ward off dissent in his Labor Party on a vote on war in Iraq, dismissed a French-German proposal today and insisted that allowing Saddam Hussein to persist in defying the United Nations was ''not a road to peace.''

title: Cookies That Should Not Be So Good
description: Some of Aunt Gussie's cookies are made with spelt, an ancient wheat known for its nutty flavor and fiber. And some are made with maltitol, a starch-based sweetener, instead of sugar. But whether chocolate chip, oatmeal or pecan, these cookies still satisfy a demanding sweet tooth. All come in six- or eight-ounce packages for $4.75 and are available at Healthy Pleasures stores or from (800) 422-6654.

title: Corrections
description: A heading in the Business Digest column on Monday about the prospects for Lifetime magazine exceeded the facts of the article. The article said that the two companies behind the new magazine -- the Hearst Corporation and the Walt Disney Company -- faced ''formidable'' odds in making it a success. The chances were not described as ''dire.''

title: Bush Sees Mideast Stability Once Iraqi Leader Is Disarmed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  President Bush is expected to tell the American people tonight that the Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein is "a direct and growing threat" but that a peaceful Iraq can help to bring peace and stability to the entire Middle East.

title: Beating the Drum for a Forgotten Grape
description: FAINT signs are pointing to a renewed interest in chenin blanc. Actually, renewed may not be the right word; there never was much interest in the grape in the first place, at least not lately. But some good reviews of chenin blanc wines have appeared recently, and a few stubborn cranks -- nonconformists, if you will -- have always supported any possible substitute for chardonnay.

title: Pirates Run Away From Knights
description: The differences between Seton Hall and Rutgers were apparent for only the final few minutes tonight, but for that vital stretch they were glaring. Seton Hall was focused, intense, determined not to lose and got some exceptional minutes from a star player and leader. Rutgers was caught up in a malaise, nonfunctional on offense and no one was willing to take charge.

title: U.N. Official Says Iraqis Still Build Barred Missile
description: Iraq continues to build its Al Samoud 2 missiles even while facing a United Nations order demanding the start of their destruction by the end of the week, a United Nations spokesman said today.

title: Dishes to Go, and the Tables, Too
description: Like the lasagna at the new Noi Italian Bistro, 271 Bleecker Street (Jones Street), in Greenwich Village? You can order it to go ($12.50). Like the colorful pottery plate it was served on? You can buy that, too. The napkin holders, candlesticks, plates decorating the walls and even the tabletops at this tiny place are for sale. Marco Carmelo Barrila, above, the chef and owner, has a shop, Il Coccio, 182 Hester Street (Mulberry Street) in Little Italy, where he sells ceramics from Deruta, a town known for them in Umbria, and by artisans in Sicily. Prices start at about $15 and can climb to $30,000 for a large table. The Italian cafe menu, including appetizers, salads, panini, pastas and a few main courses, is cheaper, from about $6.50 to $17.50.

title: No Door-to-Door in This Census; Volunteers Outnumber Subjects in Homeless Count
description: Three men and three women gathered around a table Monday night and tied yellow identification cards around their necks with twine. With this, they became members of Group 5, crusading against homelessness in New York City.

description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. promised today to do its utmost to unseat President Bush in the election next year, saying he is vulnerable because of growing dismay with his economic policies.

title: Even a Superpower Needs Help
description: Twelve years ago, this city shook under Scud missile bombardments and the roar of American and Saudi bombers on their way to pound Iraqi forces. It was the command center of two great coalitions: one was Western, led by the United States; another was Arab and Islamic, led by Saudi Arabia. Soldiers from 33 other countries fought alongside America's, risking their lives to reverse Iraqi aggression. Japan and Germany, unable then to send troops, joined Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf states in reimbursing America's military expenses.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: S.& P. Will Not Cut Lucent Credit Rating
description: Lucent Technologies, the largest United States maker of telephone equipment, will not have its junk credit rating lowered soon by Standard & Poor's, which cited improved management. Yesterday, S.& P. removed Lucent from watch status for a near-term cut in its rating, an S.& P. analyst, Bruce Hyman, said. The rating on Lucent's $7.2 billion of debt remains B-, six levels below investment grade, and S.& P. maintained a negative outlook. Lucent's loss in its first quarter ended Dec. 31 narrowed, sales declines are slowing, and the company will have enough cash to meet its needs, Mr. Hyman said. Lucent said in October that it would shed another 10,000 jobs to pare costs. Standard & Poor's placed Lucent on credit watch in October. A Lucent spokesman, Bill Price, said that the S.& P. move ''reflects the progress we've been making on our turnaround, and we're going to remain focused on the work we have to do on our path to profitability.''
