title: World Briefing | Asia: East Timor: Indonesian General Is Charged
description: United Nations prosecutors have charged the former Indonesian military chief, Gen. Wiranto, with crimes against humanity for his role in the violence surrounding the 1999 referendum on independence for East Timor. The crime unit of the United Nations Mission in Dili, the East Timorese capital, said the evidence against General Wiranto was supported by the statements of more than 1,500 witnesses. It also cited six other military officers and a civilian official in the indictment, which lists 280 killings and 10 major attacks before and after the referendum on August 30, 1999. The Indonesian government has refused to extradite the eight who were accused. Jane Perlez (NYT)

title: EL PASO RECEIVES $1 BILLION LOAN TO REPAY DEBT
description: The El Paso Corporation, the biggest United States owner of natural gas pipelines, received a $1 billion loan to repay debt coming due next month and will sell $700 million in notes to raise cash after losses on energy trades. A spokeswoman, Norma Dunn, said Salomon Smith Barney and the Credit Suisse First Boston unit of Credit Suisse had arranged a secured line of credit for El Paso with an interest rate in the ''low teens.'' El Paso will retire $825 million in debt and use the proceeds from note sales by two units to repay other obligations. Shares of El Paso were up 45 cents, to $5.

title: Our Towns; At Indian Pt., Watchdogs Sit on Fence
description: TALK about uncontrolled chain reactions. Nuclear fission has nothing on the serial finger-pointing under way in the debate over the Indian Point power plant.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Business Confidence Improves
description: The German business climate continues to brighten, with surprisingly strong growth in the Ifo index in February after a slight increase in January. The Ifo Institute's survey of executives said business confidence rose to a seven-month high of 88.9 from 87.4 in January. Most forecasts expected no growth. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: New System Will Extend Surveillance of Harbor
description: When it comes to watching what travels through the busy waters surrounding New York City, the surveillance cameras that captured a deadly explosion off Staten Island last week are just the tip of the iceberg.

title: BIG GROCERY DISTRIBUTOR WILL CUT 1,800 JOBS
description: The Fleming Companies, the grocery distributor, will cut 1,800 jobs and said the Securities and Exchange Commission had formalized an accounting investigation. Fleming will have pretax costs of about $290 million to cut about 15 percent of its work force, close distribution centers and write down inventory after ending a contract to supply Kmart. A spokesman, Shane Boyd, said jobs would be cut in Lewisville, Tex., and Oklahoma City. The S.E.C. is reviewing the accounting for payments to suppliers. Shares of Fleming, based in Lewisville, fell $1.12, to $1.85; they are off 90 percent in the last year.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Earnings Climb At Bank Of Montreal
description: The Bank of Montreal said that it had net earnings of 399 million Canadian dollars ($268 million), up 7 percent from a year earlier. The bank raised its dividend for the 11th consecutive year. The bank, based in Toronto, said, however, that the contribution from operations in the United States, primarily Harris Bank of Chicago, dropped to 17 percent, from 30 percent a year ago. It cited lower volumes in investment banking and wealth management, and a stronger Canadian dollar. At the bank's annual meeting, Anthony Comper, the bank's chairman, urged the government to allow a ''carefully constructed'' merger among Canada's big banks. In the last five years, the government has blocked two proposed deals involving the Bank of Montreal. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: THREATS AND RESPONSES: Briefly Noted; ALERT IN NEW ZEALAND
description: The police in New Zealand issued a terror alert to foreign diplomats and crowds attending the America's Cup yacht races after intercepting three threatening letters, one containing cyanide, that were addressed to the United States Embassy and the British and Australian High Commissions in Wellington, the capital. Jon White, the assistant police commissioner for counterterrorism, said the letters threatened further action if the United States attacked Iraq. The letters also mentioned the America's Cup, the international regatta now under way in Auckland. The letters were seized at an Auckland mail sorting facility by a postal worker who noticed a white substance coming from one of the envelopes. While the powder in one of the letters was identified as cyanide, the police said the substance in the other letters was harmless. Warren St. John (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about Daniel Aaron, a founder of Comcast, the largest cable company in the United States, misspelled the surname of the founder of an earlier cable company, Jerrold Electronics, where Mr. Aaron once worked. He was Milton Shapp, not Schapp. The article also misstated the year Mr. Shapp first ran successfully for governor of Pennsylvania. It was 1970, not 1961.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Daley Landslide
description: Mayor Richard M. Daley of Chicago won a resounding victory over three little-known challengers, capturing 79 percent of the vote. Mayor Daley, a 14-year incumbent, won another four-year term after a barely visible campaign that led to record low voter turnout of 34 percent. The Rev. Paul Jakes came in second, with 14 percent, giving the mayor his largest victory margin in his five elections. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Panel Supports 2 Tall Towers At Disaster Site
description: A key committee recommended yesterday that Lower Manhattan be rebuilt along the lines of a plan that had seemed out of favor, a proposal by the Think architectural team for two soaring latticework towers as the centerpiece of a memorial area. The unexpected decision appeared to set the stage for a showdown today among city and state officials.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Turkey's deliberations over whether to allow American troops to use its bases for a possible assault on Iraq misstated the troops' means of transportation. Ships currently in the eastern Mediterranean or heading toward it from ports in Texas and Alabama carry only military equipment. Troops, if allowed, would be flown in.

title: Hong Kong Reducing Benefits And Wages
description: The leaders of this autonomous Chinese territory announced reductions in pay and welfare today that are expected to inflict the pain of deflation on hundreds of thousands of families.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIEDERMAN, SONDRA
description: BIEDERMAN - Sondra. Be loved wife of the late Gerald. Loving mother of Eric and Lynn and the late Larry Biederman. Most wonderful and special sister to Renee Novak. Cherished and adored grandmother of Bradley and Gabrielle. Service today, 12 noon, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: Winter Has a Dark Side: What Luck
description: IF ever there was a season for hot chocolate, it has been this one. At its best, a cup of hot chocolate is the ultimate deep-winter pick-me-up, an almost mystical blend of bittersweet chocolate intensity and creaminess. And at its worst . . . well, it's still a cup of hot chocolate.

title: U.S. Lists Iraqis to Punish, or to Work With
description: United States intelligence officials have specifically identified more than 2,000 members of the Iraqi elite, including some to be captured as possible war criminals and many more the American military will try to turn against Saddam Hussein during any invasion, senior government officials said today.

title: In the First Mile of a Marathon, Kerry Emerges as a Front-Runner
description: Senator John Kerry was not on hand today as his rivals for the Democratic presidential nomination pitched for support from A.F.L.-C.I.O. leaders assembled here. And he was not in Washington this past weekend as Democratic contenders tried out their speeches at the winter meeting of the party's leaders.

title: SCHERING-PLOUGH LOWERS EARNINGS FOR SETTLEMENTS
description: The Schering-Plough Corporation, the drug maker whose sales and marketing practices are being investigated, lowered its fourth-quarter and 2002 earnings yesterday, saying it had set aside an additional $150 million for legal settlements. The revision trimmed fourth-quarter net income by 27 percent, to $313 million, or 21 cents a share, from $428 million, or 29 cents a share, which the company reported on Jan. 23. Net income was $143 million, or 10 cents a share in the period of 2001. Schering-Plough's shares fell 27 cents, to $17.58.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Earthlink Said To Be Near Pact With Vonage
description: EarthLink, the nation's third-largest Internet service provider, is expected to announce soon a deal with Vonage, an Internet telephone company, to provide nationwide telephone service to its users, people involved in the transaction said yesterday. EarthLink is planning to sell Vonage's service, which allows broadband users to place an unlimited number of local and long-distance calls for $39.99 a month, under its own name, these people said. The deal is expected to extend the reach of Internet-based telephone services, which compete with traditional service from large local phone companies like Verizon Communications and SBC Communications. Financial terms of the deal were not released. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Worst Team Has Its Moments in Upset of the Nets
description: Forget the state of funk. The Nets are in a state of emergency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASS, LOUIS
description: GLASS-Louis. On February 24, 2003. Beloved husband of the late Rose Glass, loving father of his late son and daughter, Richard and Judy, adoring grandfather of Jeff, Johnathon and Sherrie. Loving brother of Bernice and the late Henney, and the late Fay. Dear uncle. Devoted friend of Frank, Evelyne, Anik, Sal, Ginny, Joann, Tony and Courtney and family. Service 9:30AM, Thursday, at ''Schwartz Brothers - Jeffer Memorial Chapels'', Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills, New York.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican: Marking The Highs And The Low
description: A black and white stamp commemorating the assassination attempt on Pope John Paul II in 1981 will be one of 25 stamps issued by the Vatican to mark the quarter-century since he became pope in 1978, the Vatican said. The other stamps will be in color and include depictions of the pope's meeting with the Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev in 1989 and his visit to Rome's main synagogue in 1986. About 250,000 sheets of the stamps, which have a face value of about 44 cents each, will go on sale on March 20. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Architectural Politics At Trade Center Site
description: On the eve of a decision about the future of Lower Manhattan, an influential committee unexpectedly endorsed a plan by the Think architectural team, which features two soaring latticework towers. The committee's preference is not binding on a group of officials that is to choose between the Think proposal and a rival plan, by Studio Daniel Libeskind. But the endorsement is a challenge to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Gov. George E. Pataki.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: ILLINOIS: DALEY LANDSLIDE Mayor Richard M. Daley of Chicago won a resounding victory over three little-known challengers, capturing 79 percent of the vote. Mayor Daley, a 14-year incumbent, won another four-year term after a barely visible campaign that led to record low voter turnout of 34 percent. The Rev. Paul Jakes came in second, with 14 percent, giving the mayor his largest victory margin in his five elections.

title: Yes, the Name Is Gotti. O.K., Now Forget It, Jury Is Told.
description: In her summation at the Peter Gotti racketeering trial yesterday, a prosecutor said she had a surprise for the defense.

title: America's Cup Race Is Postponed Again
description: A subtropical weather system packing winds of more than 40 knots yesterday led to the sixth straight postponement of Race 4 of the America's Cup in the waters off Auckland, New Zealand.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Times Square Restaurant Closes
description: World Wrestling Entertainment closed its restaurant in Times Square yesterday, the company announced. Its retail store will be open until April 27, an official said. Revenues at the restaurant declined 28 percent to $2.8 million, the company said. ''We are reallocating resources to the continued growth of our global business, rather than focusing on a single, site-specific and local project,'' said Linda McMahon, chief executive. In its third fiscal quarter report, the company announced a loss of $26.7 million, compared with income of $8.5 million in the same period last year. Attendance for its events for the quarter was about 373,900 compared with 446,500 in the previous year's third quarter. The entertainment complex also includes a concert hall, television and audio production facilities, a nightclub and a 300-seat theater.

title: Statehouse Pain and the President
description: President Bush did not just stiff the nation's governors this week when they came seeking help in handling their ever-growing state deficits. He added insult to injury by lobbying the governors to support his latest wave of upper-bracket tax-cut proposals. These would cost the states an estimated $64 billion over the next decade beyond what they are suffering right now: total deficits of up to $50 billion this year and $80 billion next. As they plead for help, the president could only prescribe more of the same economic ''cure'' that helped to create the problem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, JAMES E.
description: ADAMS-James E. Born August 10, 1928, last known to have resided in the Brooklyn area, died Friday, February 21, 2003, in Camden, NY. Would any kin or anyone knowing any next of kin please contact the Central New York DDSO, collect, at 315-336-2300, regarding any special funeral arrangements.

title: Timber Company Accused of Fraud in Deal to Save Redwoods
description: A deal struck four years ago to save about 10,000 acres of giant redwoods in Humboldt County in Northern California was supposed to end the bitter feuding over logging there.

title: Chancellor's Chief of Staff Resigns
description: Marcelite J. Harris, a retired Air Force major general who signed on in October as chief of staff to Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein, has resigned, the Department of Education said yesterday.

title: Provincial Upstarts Who Changed the World
description: TO BEGIN THE WORLD ANEW

title: New Urgency for Bolstering Oversight
description: The disclosure by Royal Ahold of the Netherlands that it had overstated its earnings by at least $500 million over the last two years may spur efforts to overhaul financial oversight in Europe, experts in corporate governance said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKOWITZ, JUDITH
description: MARKOWITZ - Judith. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Judith Markowitz, beloved mother of Amy Stavis, a cherished friend of UJA-Federation. A board member of the JCC of Mid-Westchester, Amy and her husband, Rob, a member of our Board of Directors, are dedicated leaders and deeply committed to Jewish and humanitarian causes. We extend our deepest sympathies to Mrs. Markowitz's husband, Raymond, and to the entire Markowitz and Stavis families. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: Explosions Rip Diplomatic Offices in Caracas
description: Powerful explosions outside two diplomatic offices shattered windows and nerves early today, leaving four people wounded and many others uncertain about the prospects for a peaceful solution to the political crisis here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, SIMEON, PE.
description: ROSS-Simeon, PE. Age 89, graduate of Cooper Union. Longtime resident of Amagansett, formerly of Rego Park, Queens. On February 22, 2003. Survived by loving daughters, Nancy and Louise, grandchildren Michael and Susana, sister Lillian and nephew Erik. Memorial contributions to The Group for the South Fork, P.O. Box 569, Bridgehampton, NY, 11932, would be appreciated.

title: The Poor Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Takes Dual Actions In Qwest Case
description: The Justice Department brought criminal fraud charges yesterday against four former midlevel executives at Qwest Communications International, accusing them of inflating revenues from a project to link Arizona schools to the Internet.

title: Christopher Hill, 91, Dies; Marxist Historian of English Civil War
description: Christopher Hill, a leading Marxist historian of 17th-century England who helped illuminate the radical tradition of that revolutionary period, died on Monday. He was 91.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: High School Gets Renovated Track
description: It was too cold for a ribbon-cutting ceremony at the renovated athletic field, so officials at Murry Bergtraum High School in Lower Manhattan tied a red bow around a photograph of the field in the school auditorium yesterday. Caroline Kennedy, the head of strategic partnerships for the Education Department, wore sneakers to the event. ''I thought we were going to get to run around,'' she said. The field, with artificial turf and a rubberized running track, was renovated for $4 million by Take the Field, a nonprofit group. The Verizon Foundation gave $1 million and the city matched private donations three to one. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)

title: The Alpine Touch, Weathered in Vermont
description: AN ivory French Alpine cow's milk cheese called Beaufort has become a model for American artisanal cheesemakers, who are making their own versions of this almost fruity-tasting cheese. First there was Pleasant Ridge Reserve from Wisconsin. Now there is Thistle Hill Farm's Tarentaise, made in North Pomfret, Vt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, ALICE SABRIN
description: GORDON-Alice Sabrin. Of Great Neck, NY on February 24, 2003. Beloved wife of Jacob Gordon, DDS. Cherished mother of Jane Kassoff, Robert Gordon and Richard Gordon. Devoted grandmother of Michael and Lara Kassoff, and Rebecca and David Gordon. Services at 9AM, February 26, 2003, Riverside Nassau North, 55 North Station Road, Great Neck, NY.

title: Real Reality TV
description: Will Saddam Hussein prove to be a match for Joe Millionaire or Michael Jackson? CBS is rightly pleased to have landed an exclusive Dan Rather interview with the Iraqi dictator. Tonight, when much of Mr. Rather's scoop airs on ''60 Minutes II,'' we'll find out whether the nation's viewers find Mr. Hussein as compelling as reality TV or eccentric celebrities.

title: MIRANT POSTPONES CALL WITH ANALYSTS PENDING AN AUDIT
description: The Mirant Corporation, a power producer that overstated profit by $41 million in a period of three and a half years, postponed a conference call with financial analysts planned for this week to complete an audit of its accounting. A spokesman, James Peters, said Mirant would wait until its audited annual financial report is filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission; it has not set a date for the filing. Mirant, which is based in Atlanta, had said it intended to complete its 2002 audit before reporting full-year and fourth-quarter results. The deadline to file a 2002 annual report is March 31.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: HARTFORD: NEW TRIAL ORDERED IN HOMICIDE The State Supreme Court has ordered a new trial for a man convicted of murdering a mentally retarded Bridgeport woman. The court ruled on Monday that the jury should have had the option of convicting the man, Scott Smith, of manslaughter. Prosecutors accused Mr. Smith and an accomplice of raping and strangling the woman, Melissa Mills, 29, in her apartment in May 1995. Mr. Smith was convicted of murder and sexual assault and sentenced to 60 years in prison. Mr. Smith said the killing was unintentional. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Judge Sets $50,000 Bail for Mother of Boys in Newark Abuse Case
description: The mother of Faheem Williams, the 7-year-old boy whose remains were found in the basement of a relative's home here last month, will probably remain in jail until March 21, when she faces a hearing on charges that she violated the terms of her probation in an earlier child-endangerment case, her lawyers said today.

title: 2 SODA GIANTS TO OFFER NEW FLAVORS OF EXISTING BRANDS
description: Pepsi-Cola North America and the Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that they would introduce extensions of their soft drink brands. Pepsi said it had revamped Mountain Dew for a 12-week promotion running from Memorial Day to Labor Day to add an orange flavor to Mountain Dew, to be called Mountain Dew LiveWire. Coke's new entry will be called Sprite Remix. The drink, expected to be in stores by late spring, will have a tropical taste, the company said. Sherri Day (NYT)

title: Libeskind Plan Chosen for World Trade Center Site
description: An open pit, the crucible where the fires burned for weeks after Sept. 11, 2001, and the hallowed ground that held most of the bodies of the dead, will stand as the centerpiece of the city's effort to memorialize and rebuild following the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center, city and state officials said last night.

title: Kmart, Saying Ex-Chief Misled Board, Wants Payments Returned
description: Kmart accused its former chief executive, Charles C. Conaway, of misleading directors as the company ran short of money in late 2001, according to documents filed yesterday in Federal Bankruptcy Court.

title: Politicus: Why one French voice says 'Saddam must go'
description: PARIS:  The man who could call himself the most popular politician in France is alive and well, living in Boston, and blaming the lousy local bus system for getting him to work late. He also says Saddam must go.

title: The Gridlock Gang
description: William Rees-Mogg, the former editor of The Times of London, raised a very important question in an essay he wrote after watching the recent, massive antiwar demonstrations in Europe. Referring to the various banners carried by protesters, he noted: ''There was, I thought, one slogan which was missing. There were quite a number which called for 'Freedom for Palestine' [but] I looked in vain for one which called for 'Freedom for Iraq.' . . . None of the speakers expressed any wish to free Iraq. . . .''

title: In Queens, a Chip Off the Old Hungarian Empire
description: OF all the cuisines available in this smorgasbord of a city, few are as under-represented as Hungarian. That's hard to fathom, given Hungary's reputation as a country of great eating.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAIRBERG, MARALYN BETH
description: FAIRBERG-Maralyn Beth. Beloved daughter of the late Fred and Harriet Fairberg died February 25. A very special person, whose intelligence, sense of style, skill as a lawyer, love of cooking and entertaining, and support of the Avon Breast Cancer Walk will always be remembered. A wonderful person, loved by cousins and friends, her fellow ''walkers'', and her colleagues in the legal community, Maralyn will be sorely missed. Her great courage will be an inspiration going forward to all who knew her. A private graveside service will be held, and a Memorial will be held at a later date. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Avon Walk for Breast Cancer-NY, Avon Plaza, Rye, NY, 10580.

title: THREATS AND RESPONSES: Briefly Noted; ARAB SUMMIT TO PROCEED
description: The Arab League said it would proceed with a meeting of Arab leaders on Saturday in Sharm el-Sheik, Egypt, despite Iraq's request that the conference be postponed for two weeks. Iraq's foreign minister, Naji Sabri, said on Al Jazeera television that a delay, until March 14, was necessary to allow the government to focus on United Nations weapons inspections. Syria, Lebanon, Yemen and Algeria had supported Iraq's appeal, underscoring deep divisions among Arab leaders over the crisis. But the league's assistant secretary general, Hisham Badr, said this week on Egypt's official MENA news agency that a quorum of the league's 22 members had already agreed to hold the meeting as planned. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERRY, LOUISA LIVINGSTON
description: GERRY-Louisa Livingston, 39. Died in New York Presbyterian Hospital after a long illness on February 24, 2003. Beloved daughter of Elbridge T. and Caroline A. Gerry of Locust Valley, N.Y. Sister of Elbridge T. Gerry III of New Canaan, CT., Ellen G. Breed of Greenwich, CT., Alison G. Rodney of Edwards, CO., and Carolyn A. Gerry of New York City and aunt to eight nieces & nephews. A Memorial Service will be held at St. John's of Lattingtown, Locust Valley, N.Y. on Monday, March 3rd at 10:30 AM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made in her memory to the New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, 161 William Street, N.Y., N.Y. 10003, or St. John's Episcopal Church, 705 Hale Street, Beverly, MA. 01915.

title: Le Monde, Pride of French Press, Is Pilloried in Book
description: It is France's journalistic icon, long considered a national symbol of sobriety and propriety, of moralism and slightly left-of-center centrism.

title: U.S. Approves Type of Corn That May Cut Pesticide Use
description: The government announced yesterday that it had approved a type of genetically modified corn that it says could lead to a significant reduction in the use of toxic insecticides.

title: A Day of Urgent Talk Yields No Fix for Deficit in Albany
description: Gov. George E. Pataki sought today to shift some of the burden of New York's budget crisis onto the new state comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, urging him to act quickly to delay sharply rising pension costs.

title: Stumbles on the AIDS Front
description: Nobody thinks the struggle against AIDS will be easy, but the great difficulties still lying ahead were underscored this week by two unrelated developments. The makers of the first vaccine to be subjected to a large clinical trial had to admit that it didn't seem to work for most people, although they found glimmers of hope that it might protect black and Asian recipients. And the manufacturer of a breakthrough AIDS drug that might control the disease when standard drugs have failed delivered the bad news that a year's supply will cost $20,000 in Europe, and presumably even more in the United States. That makes it questionable how many people infected with the AIDS virus will have the insurance or personal wealth to afford it.

title: Sound Manager at Nightclub Says He Warned About Fires
description: The sound manager at the nightclub where 97 people died Thursday after a band's pyrotechnic display set it ablaze said today that three months ago he had advised one club owner that such displays presented a potentially deadly fire hazard.

title: Graduates' Eye-Opener
description: To the Editor:

title: FEMA Given Deadline on Indian Pt. Report
description: A House panel today gave the Federal Emergency Management Agency 30 days to disclose how it intends to respond to a state report concluding that emergency plans are inadequate to protect the public in the event of a disastrous radiation leak at the Indian Point nuclear power plant in Westchester County.

title: No Clear-Cut Favorite So Far to Be the Mets' No. 5 Starter
description: Mike Bacsik watched the changeup leave his hand and float to home plate, ready for its descent. Unfortunately for Bacsik, one of four Mets pitchers vying for the fifth spot in the starting rotation, Mike Piazza was waiting with a bat. Instead of swinging early, Piazza waited, uncoiled his compact stroke and launched a fly ball that easily cleared the left-field wall.

title: Dishes to Go, and the Tables, Too
description: Like the lasagna at the new Noi Italian Bistro, 271 Bleecker Street (Jones Street), in Greenwich Village? You can order it to go ($12.50). Like the colorful pottery plate it was served on? You can buy that, too. The napkin holders, candlesticks, plates decorating the walls and even the tabletops at this tiny place are for sale. Marco Carmelo Barrila, pictured at right, the chef and owner, has a shop, Il Coccio, 182 Hester Street (Mulberry Street) in Little Italy, where he sells ceramics from Deruta, a town known for them in Umbria, and by artisans in Sicily. Prices start at about $15 and can climb to $30,000 for a large table. The Italian cafe menu, including appetizers, salads, panini, pastas and a few main courses, is cheaper, from about $6.50 to $17.50.

title: Dial-a-Challah: From Bakery to Doorstep
description: A shiny, braided challah is a necessity on Friday evenings for those celebrating the Jewish sabbath. It also makes delicious French toast. Now there is a way to get this sweet bread delivered to your door. The Challah Connection of Westport, Conn., delivers from Maine to Washington, D.C. The excellent challahs, weighing more than a pound, are from a kosher bakery in Monsey, N.Y. They come in plain, cinnamon, raisin, chocolate chip and honeyed whole wheat versions, and are delivered fresh by 5 p.m. every Friday by a newspaper service or express mail. Among the goods the company also sells are rugelah, babka, cookies and Russian coffee cake. Challah delivery is $32.99 for four weeks, $59.99 for eight weeks and $109.99 for 16 weeks in parts of Fairfield County, Conn. Elsewhere, it's $38.99, $73.99 and $139.99. For information: www.challahconnection.com. Orders can be placed with (866) 242-5524.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Broadwing To Sell Unit For $129 Million
description: Broadwing Inc., which owns the local-telephone company Cincinnati Bell, agreed yesterday to sell its long-distance unit to C III Communications for $129 million, a fraction of what the business cost in 1999. A Broadwing spokesman, Tom Osha, said the company would receive a stake of less than 5 percent in C III, which will assume $375 million of operating liabilities of the unit. C III is owned by the Corvis Corporation, a maker of fiber optic equipment based in Columbia, Md., and the investment company Cequel III. The unit being sold, Broadwing Communication Services, sells phone and data services to more than 1,000 businesses, including other carriers. It was called IXC Communications when Broadwing bought it for $3 billion in 1999. The operation's third-quarter sales fell 3 percent, to $296 million, because of surplus fiber optic capacity. Shares of Broadwing rose 65 cents, or 16 percent, to $4.69. They had fallen 33 percent in the last year. The transaction will close in about six months, Mr. Osha, the Broadwing spokesman, said. Proceeds will be used to reduce the company's debt, which stood at $2.56 billion at the end of September.

title: Impressive Victories At Eastern States
description: Gabriel McLaren of Freeport High School on Long Island and Lance Wigfall of East Orange High in New Jersey registered outstanding victories, and Jim Morrison of Willingboro, N.J., repeated as a double winner last night in the 67th annual Eastern States championships at the Armory Track and Field Center in Manhattan.

title: 13-Year-Old Leads Under-17 Roster
description: Freddy Adu, the 13-year-old wunderkind who obtained a United States passport last week, tops Coach John Ellinger's list of 18 players named yesterday to the United States roster for the Concacaf qualifying tournament, March 5-9 in Guatemala, for the under-17 world championships. Adu is originally from Ghana.

title: When France Lectures America
description: To the Editor:

title: Little Men From Big 12 Grab Nation's Attention
description: He had just scored 19 points in a victory over Kansas, helping Oklahoma into a tie for first place in the Big 12 Conference, but Hollis Price was not satisfied. He grimaced about his sloppy passing, which had helped the Jayhawks get back in the game, and he could not forgive himself for missing two free throws that could have secured the victory earlier.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Airline To Cut Jobs
description: The successor to Swissair, Swiss International Air Lines, announced that it would cut 700 jobs and retire 20 planes as it struggles for existence. Andr Dos, left, the chief executive, said the cuts were necessary because of a drop in overall travel. In addition, the airline has been hurt by cut-rate competitors in short-haul flights. Most of the planes being retired are regional carriers. The company, which grew out of Swissair's former regional subsidiary, Crossair, also said it no longer expected to reach its goal of breaking even this year. Swiss International began operations last June with the help of the government and some companies. The government said the cuts, ''though hard and deep,'' were necessary, given the grave condition of the economy and the tenuous global security situation. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: Politicians in Judges' Robes
description: Judges have long been barred from engaging in partisan political activity. Since many of them are required to run for office, there is a thin and sometimes problematic line between what types of behavior are and are not acceptable. But last week a federal court went far beyond rationality in striking down parts of New York State's code of judicial conduct preventing judges from attending campaign events and endorsing candidates. The ruling is wrong on the law, and it threatens the integrity of the courts.

title: The Tragedies In the Nightclubs
description: To the Editor:

title: Rushing the Border
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Weinfeld's Work, Inside and Out
description: Isay Weinfeld is a Brazilian architect whose boldly scaled spaces have attracted a high-powered following.

title: An Auction House With a Flair for the Dramatic
description: Auctions by the Bay wants to rival Christie's and Sotheby's by turning sales into theatrical events.

title: At Request of N.C.A.A., Site Will Sever Its Gambling Ties
description: SportsLine.com Inc. announced an agreement yesterday to run a new N.C.A.A. championship Web site, with the men's Division I-A basketball tournament as its cornerstone, but had to promise to sell its two Las Vegas gambling concerns.

title: Europeans Propose to End 'Open Skies' Deals
description: The European Union moved today to strip its members of power to negotiate their own bilateral aviation agreements with outside nations and to replace those agreements with unionwide deals negotiated in Brussels.

title: A Memorial, Yes, but Battle Lines Form for Everything Else
description: The easy part of the rebuilding on the World Trade Center site may be over, even if it took nearly 18 months of often fractious public hearings and disputes between rival public and private interests to select a design team for the endeavor.

title: Democracy, War And the Arabs
description: To the Editor:

title: Admiral Sees Even Chance Of Finding Cause of Crash
description: The leader of the board investigating the Columbia space shuttle disaster told lawmakers today that there was a 50-50 chance the board would be able to use specific evidence to isolate the exact cause of the crash.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: NEPAL: TALKS WITH REBELS SET FOR MARCH The Nepal government and Maoist rebels will begin formal peace talks by the second week of March, a government official said. The government and the rebels agreed to an indefinite cease-fire on Jan. 29 in a seven-year revolt that has claimed more than 7,000 lives. A day before the announcement of talks, the rebel leader, Prachanda, told Reuters that the government had "not taken any positive and concrete step in favor of talks in the nearly one month since cease-fire." Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  INGALLS, ROSCOE C. JR.
description: INGALLS-Roscoe C. Jr. (Rocky), 1920 - 2003, died peacefully in Antigua, WI, on February 14, 2003. He was a resident of Bronxville, NY. As a graduate of Bowdoin College ('43, BS), Brunswick, ME, he subsequently attended the Naval Academy at Annapolis, MD, and was on active duty in the U.S. Navy Reserve from 1943 to 1946. As a lieutenant (gunnery officer) on the USS Lough DE586 he did duty in the Mediterranean and Pacific theatres during World War II. He was honorably discharged in 1955. He married Marjorie G. Davis in 1947. Children, Levana (Lynn Knight), Roscoe Cunningham III, Andrew Riegel. In 1946, he joined the firm of Ingalls & Snyder (I&S), New York City, and became a partner in 1949. Later as senior partner he led I&S through the difficulties of the 1970's, until his retirement at age 79 on the 75th anniversary of I&S. He was elected overseer at Bowdoin College in 1968 and became a trustee in 1973 and remained on the board till 1989. He was a member of the Securities Industries Association and the Chamber of Commerce; chairman of the NYSE Specialty Firms Advisory Committee (1986-1989). From 1966-1986 he was a board member of The Eastern Savings Bank which merged into The Apple Bank For Savings, where he continued to serve as a director until 1990. He held other board memberships at Apple Bancorp Inc. (1988-1990); Rexham Corporation (1971-1987) prior to which he was a director of Riegel Paper (1969) of which certain parts were converted into Rexham Corporation; Barclays Bank of New York (1974-1984); National Recreation and Park Association (1950-1977); Vice President of the National Recreation Foundation (1950-?). In 1983 he married Paula M.S. Verbeek. In Bronxville, he served on various committees at the Reformed Church. He was on the board of governors of Lawrence Hospital (19591966). He was the leading fund raiser to expand Lawrence Hospital with what is now known as the East Wing. Member of the Zoning Board of Appeals (1970-1974). Mr. Ingalls was a people's man and loved children. He was attracted to and by people spanning four generations: from his father's friends to his grandchildren and their friends. He is survived by his wife, Paula M.S. Ingalls, Bronxville, NY; sister, Shirley Ingalls Thackara, Carmel, CA; two sons, Andrew R. Ingalls, Dummerston, VT; Roscoe C. Ingalls III, Malvern, PA; daughter, Levana Fraval, Seattle, WA, and four grandchildren.

title: The House of Speer: Still Rising on the Skyline
description: His name is Albert Speer, and his profession is architect and urban planner, and this Albert Speer shrugs with a certain resignation over the inescapable fact that his father had the same name and the same profession.

title: Be Your Own Wireless Network
description: THE allure of an Internet connection anytime, anywhere is powerful. To satisfy the craving, wireless networks have proliferated in airports, bookstores and coffee shops. But what if you have online affairs to tend to on the road, but no access to such a network?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOLINS, DR. STEPHEN H.
description: TOLINS-Dr. Stephen H. On February 24th, of North Andover, MA, formerly of Larchmont, NY, Greenwich and Fairfield, CT. Adored husband of Peggy J. (Jiler) Tolins; loving father of Amelia R. ''Leigh'' Coughlin and Joseph J. Tolins; cherished grandfather of Shaun J. and Kelsey A. Coughlin. For more information: 978-372-1534.

title: Big Changes Likely At Interpublic Today
description: Significant changes in the top leadership of the Interpublic Group of Companies in New York, the agency company that has been struggling for months with financial and operational problems, are likely to be announced today after a board meeting, executives who spoke on the condition of anonymity said late yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINN, EDWARD J.
description: FINN-Edward J., 89, formerly of Horse Shoe, North Carolina and Oradell, New Jersey, died February 21, 2003 at his home at Arbor Terrace in Asheville, North Carolina. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to The Class of 1934, Columbia University, attn: Gift Systems, MC 7724, 475 Riverside Drive, Suite 964, New York, New York 10115.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCHMAN, IDA
description: HOCHMAN-Ida. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family joins with the leadership of its parent company, Continuum Health Partners, in acknowledging with sadness the passing of our friend and benefactress, Ida Hochman, beloved mother of our devoted friend and colleague, Stephen Hochman, Esq., a member of the Continuum and Beth Israel Boards of Trustees. Together with her husband Henry, she provided the valuable philanthropic support to several key clinical programs at Beth Israel, and their generosity was recognized with the naming of the Henry and Ida Hochman Division of Cardiovascular Interventions and the Henry and Ida Hochman Department of Emergency Medical Services at Beth Israel's Singer Division. To Stephen, his father Henry, his family and all of his mother's loved ones, we extend heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman, Boards of Trustees Continuum and Beth Israel Gail F. Donovan, Interim President and CEO, Continuum Thomas Killip, M.D., Interim President and CEO, Beth Israel Gregg Husk, M.D., Chairman of Emergency Medicine David L. Brown, M.D., Director of Interventional Cardiology

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLMANN, ANNA
description: POLLMANN-Anna. St. Petersburg, died February 19, 2003, Born NYC. Retired first female NY Supreme Court Reporter (Gregg). Widow of Patrick J. McDonough, 42nd Rainbow Division Veteran, Fr. Duffy Chapter, NY; retired Jury Clerk, NY Supreme Court. Sister of Henry Pollmann (deceased 1983), retired NY Appellate Division Librarian. Three nieces surviving: Patricia Pollmann, AnnLou Tobin, and Christine Mermagen. L.I. National Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: Economic Scene; Looking inside the brains of the stingy and the openhanded.
description: HERE's a game economists play: Player 1 has $10 and can give any dollar amount to Player 2. Player 2 can either accept or reject it. If Player 2 accepts, they both keep the money. If Player 2 rejects it, neither player gets anything.

title: U.S. aids fragile peace in southern Philippines
description: BASILAN ISLAND, Philippines:  The uneasy peace established since U.S. soldiers turned up in the abduction capital of the southern Philippines has Dr. Nilo Barandino thankful: He no longer finds himself sewing heads back on patients and friends.

title: U.S. Envoy Reassures Kurds on Concerns About Turkey
description: At the first meeting of top Iraqi dissidents on Iraqi soil in nearly a decade, an American envoy pledged today that the United States did not want to rule Iraq and would rely on a broad-based opposition to govern the country if American forces invade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, SAMUEL
description: ROTH-Samuel, 77. Died peacefully on February 24 after a long illness while away from his home in Cliffside Park, N.J. Loving husband of Phyllis (Shapiro) for more than 54 years. Devoted father of Stephanie Bove of Howell, N.J. and Roni Rosenberg of Cliffside Park, father-in-law of Tony Bove and Lester Rosenberg. Proud grandfather of Darrell, Alexis and Michael. Beloved brother of Lois R. Jaffe of Mesa, Arizona and the late Dr. Edward Roth, brother-in-law of Morton Jaffe, Eileen Roth and Jean Shapiro. Loving uncle to his nieces. Sam will be missed by the many people who knew him as an honorable man and trusted confidante. Memorial service on Friday, February 28 at 11:30AM at Wien & Wien Memorial Chapel in Hackensack, N.J.

title: Sophomore Puts Up Impressive Numbers
description: It may just be the pads and the skates, but DAVE LeNEVEU, Cornell's peerless goaltender, looks bigger on the ice than someone who is actually an unimposing 6-foot-1 and 180 pounds.

title: Balancing Liberty and Security
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: New American Embassy To Open
description: A new and heavily fortified American Embassy will be inaugurated next week in Kenya, nearly five years after terrorists leveled the previous one with a bomb. President Bush had been set to preside over the flag-raising in January, but his trip to Africa was postponed indefinitely. Instead, State Department officials will open the Nairobi complex, as well as an embassy under construction in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania. Both sites were destroyed in attacks on Aug. 7, 1998. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, FRED J.
description: SCHWARTZ-Fred J., 91, died February 15. Loving husband to Corrine for 53 years. Father to Teri and Abby.

title: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Glycosciences Rejects Celltech Bid
description: Oxford GlycoSciences, a British biotechnology company at the center of a takeover tussle, said it had rejected a hostile bid from a rival, Celltech. Celltech offered 182 pence a share in cash to outbid Cambridge Antibody Technology's all-stock bid, initially worth 110 million ($174 million). The Cambridge bid has since fallen in value because of a decline in its share price. Shares of Oxford GlycoSciences fell 5 pence, to 190 pence, yesterday, while Cambridge Antibody and Celltech stock rose slightly. David Ebsworth, Oxford GlycoSciences' chief executive, said the Celltech offer would not give value to the company's investors. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: National Briefing: South
description: FLORIDA: EXECUTION FOR KILLER Amos King, a convicted killer who had sought exoneration through DNA evidence that proved inconclusive, was executed by lethal injection for the murder of a 68-year-old woman in her home 26 years ago. Mr. King, 48, was pronounced dead at 6:43 p.m. at Florida State Prison in Starke, the governor's office said. His insistence that DNA testing could clear him of raping and killing Natalie Brady led Gov. Jeb Bush to issue a stay 90 minutes before Mr. King was to be executed on Dec. 2. Governor Bush lifted the stay this month after the tests yielded no new evidence. (AP)

title: Top-Ranked Nicol Advances to Final
description: Peter Nicol of England, the top-ranked player in the world and the top-seeded men's player in the Harrisdirect Tournament of Champions, advanced to the final yesterday, outlasting David Palmer of Australia, 15-8, 9-15, 15-12, 15-10, in a semifinal match at Grand Central Terminal.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Serbia And Montenegro: Parliament Formed
description: Europe's newest country set up a Parliament to replace the old federal assembly that was dissolved when Yugoslavia was renamed and reconstituted this month. The Parliament has limited authority because most powers have passed to the governments of the country's two republics, Serbia and Montenegro. But its 126 members will elect a president of the new union and have a say in foreign policy. Daniel Simpson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JAFFE, DANIEL.
description: JAFFE-Daniel. One year! You left us all broken hearted. In our hearts forever, Your Famil

title: U.S. Cuts Threat-Level Alert a Notch, From Orange to Yellow
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27  The Bush administration lowered the country's threat-alert level by one notch today, from orange to yellow, but emphasized that the risk of terrorist attacks is by no means over.

title: Bush Looks Past War To Peace in Middle East
description: Responding to calls from allies and friends , President Bush tonight embraced the goals that his father pursued when he attacked Saddam Hussein's forces more than a decade ago.

title: From a Bellicose Belly to Dramatized Emotions, All on Video
description: This is a tale of two Bills, two video Bills. One is Bill Wegman and the other is Bill Viola. They have nothing in common, except video. And Bill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIFF, VINCENT G.
description: LIFF-Vincent G. A wonderful friend. Inspiring in life and in death. He will be greatly missed by the many whose lives he touched and who loved him so. Scott Rudin

title: A Slimmer And Nimbler (And Costlier) Tablet PC
description: It is still unclear whether consumers really want tablet PC's, the pen-based computers that were released with great fanfare (and Microsoft marketing dollars) last November. But the new models certainly have evolved.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Firefighter Accused Of Child Abuse
description: A firefighter was arrested yesterday on charges of molesting three young girls, law enforcement officials said. The police said that a 10-year-old girl had told them that the firefighter, Kenneth Dorsey, 41, had taken her into an alley and touched her buttock on several occasions during visits to the firehouse of Ladder 12, Engine 3, on West 19th street. The girl's sister and a friend said he had performed a sexual act in front of them, the police said. Last year, Mr. Dorsey was arrested on charges of sodomizing a child, which he denied, and the Queens district attorney dropped the charges, citing lack of evidence. Mr. Dorsey was expected to be arraigned today on multiple counts of sexual abuse and endangering the welfare of a child, a spokeswoman for the Manhattan district attorney said.

title: Vincent Liff, 52, Casting Director for Many Broadway Hits
description: Vincent G. Liff, a prolific casting director who assembled the talent for some of Broadway's biggest hits, died on Tuesday at his home at Manhattan. He was 52.

title: Where the Hall Monitor Is a Webcam
description: THEY look like small snow globes. The dozen inconspicuous cameras on walls and ceilings at the school campus at the center of this central California city capture video images of students as they enter and leave the two buildings, work in the computer lab, climb and descend the main staircase or relax outside.

title: U.N. Team Calls Iran Helpful in Inquiry Showing Rights Abuses
description: A United Nations team examining human rights abuses in Iran said today that it had found violations but noted that Iranian authorities had shown extensive cooperation in the inquiry.

title: Reactor Started In North Korea, U.S. Concludes
description: North Korea has restarted a reactor at its primary nuclear complex, American intelligence officials said today. Over time, the reactor could provide a continuing source of plutonium for nuclear weapons.

title: Mixed Reviews Around the World for Bush's Mideast Speech
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27  President Bush's latest assertion that the overthrow of President Saddam Hussein would help democratize the region and bring peace between Israel and a new "truly democratic" Palestinian state met with decidedly mixed reactions today.

title: Sharon Drops Netanyahu, A Rival, From New Cabinet
description: In a surprise move, Prime Minister Ariel Sharon replaced his foreign minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, on Wednesday with a relative novice in diplomatic affairs as he filled the most important cabinet posts in his new government with members of his rightist Likud Party.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YABLOK, MIRIAM (NEE HANDELSMAN)
description: YABLOK-Miriam (nee Handelsman). Age 91, of New York and Fire Island. Beloved by daughter Nina and nieces and nephews. Colorful to the end.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DISARLE, BOBBIE.
description: DISARLE-Bobbie. Remembering Mom on her birthday. Remembering love

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Fashion page on Tuesday about a renewed interest in Asian style misspelled the surname of a French couturier who appropriated styles from the East in an earlier era. He was Paul Poiret, not Poirret.

title: Unheralded Player Sends Els Out of Match-Play Event
description: All that stood between Ernie Els and victory today was a 26-foot putt by Phil Tataurangi on the 18th hole. Few people expected the putt to go in, just as few people expected Els to lose his opening-round match.

title: CBS News and White House Differ on Rebutting Hussein
description: The exclusive interview by CBS News with Saddam Hussein, broadcast last night, led to a disagreement between the network and the White House yesterday after CBS News declined a request to have a White House representative appear during the interview to rebut claims made by the Iraqi president.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Forceful Forsythia

title: Libeskind Design Chosen for Rebuilding at Ground Zero
description: In the end, it was not so much about architecture, about solemn memorial pits or soaring gardens in the sky. Instead, the decision announced yesterday to choose Daniel Libeskind's design for the World Trade Center site revolved mainly around politics, economics and engineering, people close to the selection process said.

title: Riding a Bear Market in Oriental Carpets
description: FOR anyone who has ever wanted an old Persian rug to warm up a favorite room, now may be the time to snag one. Thousands of old Oriental carpets will be on sale at reduced prices this month, many in the softer palette favored by designers this year.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Steps Up Club Inspections
description: The Fire Department plans to step up inspections of nightclubs after deadly nightclub disasters in Chicago and Rhode Island, Francis X. Gribbon, the department's chief spokesman, said yesterday. Last weekend, inspectors began revisiting clubs that had been shut down over the past 10 years to ensure they remained closed. Fire Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta is preparing a letter reminding club owners of their safety responsibilities. City officials stressed that all of the city's 350 licensed nightclubs are inspected regularly. But Ed Burke, a member of the executive board of the Uniformed Firefighters Association, said that the number of fire marshals had decreased to 110, from 250 in 1994.

title: Long Island Utility Takes Heat For Polls With Political Angle
description: The Long Island Power Authority, a public utility created by Gov. George E. Pataki, has come under criticism for paying at least $35,000 for a series of polls asking residents, among other things, their opinions of the governor and of other politicians.

title: Decade-Old Portraits of Grief
description: John DiGiovanni, Robert Kirkpatrick, Steven Knapp, William Macko, Wilfredo Mercado and Monica Rodriguez Smith were the first fatalities claimed by a terrorist attack on the World Trade Center complex. Their families gathered yesterday for a memorial service on the 10th anniversary of the 1993 bombing, their private grief overshadowed by the nation's collective mourning for thousands of later World Trade Center victims.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: A Write-Down Of Hynix Shares
description: The creditor institutions that own a majority of shares in Hynix Semiconductor pushed through a program for writing down the value of the shares by 21 to 1 so total equity would fall from 26.22 trillion won ($22.1 billion) to 1.27 trillion won and the number of shares from 5.24 billion to 249.5 million. The leading creditor, Kookmin Exchange Bank, said the write-down was needed to conform with terms of the latest rescue package, $4.9 billion in new loans and extensions of previous loans. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Swiss Drug Giant Takes Charges Resulting in a Big Loss
description: Roche Holding, the Swiss drug maker, decided to swallow a lot of bitter financial medicine at once, taking huge charges for bad stock market investments and an array of other write-offs in the second half of 2002. As a result, the company reported a loss of 4 billion Swiss francs ($3 billion) for the year today, only the second annual loss in its 106-year history.

title: FEDERAL-MOGUL TO SELL DIVISION FOR $28 MILLION
description: The Federal-Mogul Corporation, a leading maker of engine bearings and seals, has won a judge's approval for the sale of its North American camshaft business to Asimco International for $28 million. Asimco, a closely held Chinese auto-parts maker, submitted the best bid, lawyers told Judge Randall Newsome of United State Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del. The sale includes plants in Michigan and Indiana. The approval moves Federal-Mogul a step closer to emerging from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The operations being sold have about 500 employees and had combined sales of about $80 million in 2001, Federal-Mogul officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, SIMEON
description: ROSS-Simeon. The Jewish Center of the Hamptons mourns the passing of Simeon Ross, beloved father of Nancy Ross-Ascuitto. We send our deepest condolences to Nancy and family. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Rabbi Alon Levkovitz Cantor Debra Stein Donald Zucker, President

description: Classroom Quotes

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALL, MARIANNE
description: HALL-Marianne. Our beloved colleague, so instrumental to our endeavors, brought us joy, humor and music. We will miss her dearly. Jennifer J. Raab, President Sanford Wurmfeld, Chair Members, Department of Art Hunter College

title: Reality TV, and the Real World Beyond
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRIEFF, RUTH M.
description: GRIEFF-Ruth M. On February 25, 2003 at the age of 90. Beloved aunt of Sandra Cohen of Suffern, NY and Annette Kaufman of Boca Raton, FL. Loving great aunt and greatgreat aunt. She was born on August 8, 1912 in Little Falls, NY to Sam and Selina Grieff. She was the sister of the late Celia Land. Donations may be made to the Little Falls Library, 10 Waverly Place, Little Falls, NY 13365. For further information contact Hellman Memorial Chapels, 845-356-8600.

title: Mets Hope a Set Outfield Will Also Be Productive
description: Each year, the Mets form an outfield that they think will finally produce some runs and catch enough balls to let their pitchers relax. It's a nice idea, but their hopes are usually scrapped by midseason.

title: The Tropics Come To Philadelphia
description: SNOW-WEARY and plant-hungry? Plunge into spring on Sunday at the Philadelphia Flower Show's ''Festival de las Flores.'' The theme this year is definitely tropical, with orchids, hibiscus, gardenias, banana plants, elephant ears and bougainvilleas spilling into a town square modeled after Loiza, Puerto Rico.

title: Open to the Stars, Indoors and Out
description: IN Brazil, Fernando Altrio is known as Mr. Showbiz. He produces concerts by musical stalwarts like Gilberto Gil, Chico Buarque and Caetano Veloso, a singer and a songwriter who has a musical cameo in Pedro Almodvar's movie ''Talk to Her.''

title: Felice Lippert, 73, a Founder Of Weight Watchers Business
description: Felice Marks Lippert, in whose kitchen Weight Watchers was hatched 40 years ago, died on Saturday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, N.Y.

title: Three Ducks From the Tropics
description: ISAY WEINFELD'S first commercial line of furniture is a three-piece series playfully named after Donald Duck's nephews, Huey, Dewey and Louie -- or, as they are known in Portuguese, Huguinho, Zezinho and Luizinho. Made of tropical woods, the pieces look like three brothers who dress differently. Zezinho, above, a sideboard 106 inches long, 22 inches deep and 26 inches high, is made with veneers of timbaba (on the left front panel) and cedro (the top) and is $9,500. Luizinho, a four-drawer dresser with a mirror, is made with guariba and cedro veneer; it is 32 inches high, 47 inches long and 22 inches deep ($8,500). And Huguinho is a bar counter made with yellow muirapiranga and cedro ($9,000). Zezinho is at the new Espasso showroom, with his brethren expected to arrive shortly; 34-01 38th Avenue (fourth floor), Long Island City, Queens; by appointment, (718) 472-0022. RAUL A. BARRENECHE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRETZFELDER, GEORGE
description: PRETZFELDER - George. Congregation Emanu-El of The City of New York expresses to the family of our devoted member, George Pretzfelder, our deepest sympathies on the occasion of his passing. It is our hope and prayer that beautiful memories will linger as a legacy to his life. May all who loved him be comforted. Robert A. Bernhard, Pres Herbert C. Bernard, Secty

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Poland: Delay On Jet Purchase
description: Polish officials said that they would delay final approval of a $3.5 billion purchase of F-16 fighter jets for about two months until a dispute over reciprocal investments with the plane's manufacturer is settled. Poland signed an agreement in December to purchase 48 Lockheed Martin F-16's, choosing the American plane over competitors from BAE Systems of Britain and Dassault Aviation of France. Lockheed had pledged to invest $9.8 billion to offset the cost to Poland of buying the supersonic fighters, but Polish officials said the offsets were worth only $6 billion, a news agency reported. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: More Jeers As Storm Hits .500 With Thud
description: If it were not for the catcalls directed at St. John's, there would have been no hum at all in Madison Square Garden last night.

title: Turkish Lawmakers Tugged By Their Public and the U.S.
description: As Turkey's leaders agonize over a momentous decision on Iraq, the regulars here at Workingman's Tea House say they made up their minds a long time ago.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Major concerns were raised. It's chilling. Several people talk about worst-case scenarios and hope they don't come to pass.''

title: Turning the Desktop Into a Meeting Place
description: ROBB BEAL, a software engineer, had a mission: to unite a broad range of Internet information and services behind a single interface. For years that interface has been based on the metaphor of a desktop, a throwback to the personal computer's beginnings as an office automation tool rather than a gateway to the world.

title: Shuttle Engineers Debated Chances of Grave Damage
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 26  In the days before the Columbia disaster, NASA and contractor engineers explored the possibility that the shuttle had been fatally damaged on liftoff and precisely predicted some of the symptoms that the orbiter showed on re-entry.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Punched, Bruised, Terrified; Gee, It Was a Swell Role

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLUM, KENNETH N.
description: ROSENBLUM-Kenneth N. Died on February 25, 2003 of cancer. Beloved husband of Patricia. Devoted father of Eryn and Seth. Loving son of Sylvia. Cherished brother of Harriet and Marc. Senior Vice-President at J.P. Morgan Chase. He received his Bachelor's degree from the University of Rochester and his Master of industrial administration (MSIA) from Carnegie Mellon University. Contributions in his memory may be made to Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center or the Brooklyn Public Library.

title: President Bush's Nation-Building
description: President Bush sketched an expansive vision last night of what he expects to accomplish by a war in Iraq. Instead of focusing on eliminating weapons of mass destruction, or reducing the threat of terror to the United States, Mr. Bush talked about establishing a ''free and peaceful Iraq'' that would serve as a ''dramatic and inspiring example'' to the entire Arab and Muslim world, provide a stabilizing influence in the Middle East and even help end the Arab-Israeli conflict.

title: A Grand Jury Is Investigating Bridgestone Tires
description: A federal grand jury is conducting a criminal investigation related to Bridgestone tires that were linked to deaths and injuries involving Ford Explorers, according to a subpoena issued to lawyers suing the companies.

title: Quietest Man on Television Is Celebrated in a Special
description: Fred Rogers, the host of ''Mr. Rogers' Neighborhood,'' took the pictures of children from his wallet and displayed them, as any proud parent would do. But the photos were not of his children; they were of children who had visited his ''Neighborhood.'' Mr. Rogers simply loves children.

title: Bush and Pentagon Wrangle Over War Budget Request
description: The Pentagon and the White House budget office are wrestling over how much money to seek from Congress to pay for a war against Iraq and reconstruction costs between now and the end of September.

title: Pataki Faces A Separation Of Kosher And State
description: Two days after the United States Supreme Court effectively struck down New York State's kosher food laws, Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that he would propose new legislation that would replace the law's explicit religious criteria with more neutral language tying inspections to ''consumer expectations and trade standards.''

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Talks With Rebels Set For March
description: The Nepal government and Maoist rebels will begin formal peace talks by the second week of March, a government official said. The government and the rebels agreed to an indefinite cease-fire on Jan. 29 in a seven-year revolt that has claimed more than 7,000 lives. A day before the announcement of talks, the rebel leader, Prachanda, told Reuters that the government had ''not taken any positive and concrete step in favor of talks in the nearly one month since cease-fire.'' Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: In Reversal, White House Concedes That Counterterrorism Budget Is Too Meager
description: Responding to criticism from Democrats and to the mounting concern of state and local governments, the White House is now saying that the long delayed government spending plan for the year does not provide enough money to protect against terrorist attacks on American soil.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Current Account Deficit Rises
description: Rising oil prices resulted in a national current account deficit of $646 million in December, according to the Bank of Korea. Economists predicted still more monthly deficits and a possible weakening of South Korea's currency. The deficit, the highest in five and a half years, was four times the deficit for December 2002. For the year, the central bank posted a current account surplus of $6.09 billion, $2.15 billion below the surplus for 2001. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Effectiveness of AIDS Vaccine May Be Overstated, Expert Says
description: VaxGen may have overstated the effectiveness of its AIDS vaccine because it did not make the proper statistical adjustments to its data, an expert consulted by the company said yesterday.

title: A Phone That Makes Callers Stars of the Small Screen
description: For people who have become so accustomed to videoconferences at work that they can't live without them at home, or for those who want to let distant grandparents feel closer to growing children, D-Link has an answer: the new i2eye DVC-1000.

title: Dutch Carrier Will Be Shut for a Month After Ryanair Buys It
description: Ryanair, the low-budget Irish airline, said today that it would ground all flights at Buzz, the ailing discount carrier it recently agreed to acquire from KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, for one month once the acquisition is completed in April.

title: Guatemalans Try to Mend Ties Snapped by War
description: Jos Marcos Bernal stood among his neighbors and calmly recounted a tale that was as horrifying as it was common during this country's civil war. More than 20 years ago, he said, the army forced him to ambush and kill friends and strangers alike as part of its merciless campaign to eliminate rebel sympathizers.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column on Feb. 12, about the Rheingold Brewing Company's renewed marketing push in New York City, misstated annual beer sales in the city. (The error was repeated in the Public Lives profile last Thursday, about Thomas L. Bendheim, the company's chief executive.) According to Beer Marketer's Insights, an industry newsletter, sales total at least $1.4 billion a year, not $40 million.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 19 about a surge in volunteerism by lawyers misstated the title of Richard Gruenberger, who described the trend at the New York Legal Assistance Group, which represents poor people. He is director of its volunteer unit, not of the organization over all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERTON, ROBERT K.
description: MERTON-Robert K. It is with great sorrow that the American Academy of Arts and Sciences mourns the death of Robert K. Merton, distinguished sociologist, recipient of the Academy's Talcott Parsons Prize in the Social Sciences, and a Fellow of this society for over a half-century. Professor Merton devoted a lifetime to expanding our understanding of human actions and motives in works that combined historical penetration, analytic rigor, deep psychological insight, and an uncommon interest in all fields of knowledge. On his shoulders, much of the innovative thinking of twentiethcentury sociology has been built. The Academy extends its condolences to his wife, Harriet Zuckerman, and his son, Robert C. Merton-both Fellows of the Academyand to his entire family. Patricia Meyer Spacks, President Louis Cabot, Vice President Emilio Bizzi, Secretary Peter Lynch, Treasurer Leslie Berlowitz, Executive Officer

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nextel Partners Posts Narrower Loss
description: Nextel Partners, which sells combined cellphone and walkie-talkie service under the Nextel brand, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter loss had narrowed to $52.9 million as sales rose 62 percent. The loss shrank to 22 cents a share from $78.2 million, or 33 cents, a year earlier, Nextel Partners said. Sales increased to $195.8 million from $120.8 million. The figures per share reflect the payment of preferred dividends. The company had the lowest disconnection rate among American wireless carriers because it sells a product that rivals lack: a device that lets a user speak to members of a group with a single call. Nextel Communications owns 32 percent of the company. Nextel Partners sells service in cities like Omaha and Boise, Idaho, and added 93,100 customers in the quarter. Its shares fell 32 cents, or 7.1 percent, to $5.40.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Oil Prices Hit Highest Levels Since the Persian Gulf War
description: Oil prices surged yesterday to their highest levels since Iraq invaded Kuwait 12 years ago, buoyed by a combination of cold weather and a weekly government report that showed low inventories of oil and petroleum products.

title: Born Early, but Under a Good Sign: E-ZPass
description: It is among the least forgiving settings in New York City: morning rush at the approach to the toll booths at the Midtown Tunnel, daily passageway for tens of thousands of cars carrying tens of thousands of people.

title: Pieces That Go Well With T-Shirts and Shorts And Tracked-In Beach Sand Forever Underfoot
description: The new furniture line from Celerie Kemble, Mimi Maddock McMakin and Brooke Huttig of Kemble Interiors, of Palm Beach, Fla., and New York, is meant for casual living. ''You want to plop down in it,'' Ms. Kemble said. The company's 61-piece Palm Beach collection includes the overscale rattan Everglades Cuddle chair, $1,365, and Everglades Chaise ottoman, below, about $715. The Tortoise Shell Chest, right, $1,800, stands on tiny turtle feet and is decorated with seashell hardware and hand-painted tortoiseshell; it seems destined for many a Hamptons home. The line also includes sofas and armoires. The collection will be available in stores in May; for dealers, www.laneventure.com or (800) 235-3558. N. C. MAISAK

title: As Knicks Melt Down, Only Sprewell Is Calm
description: Latrell Sprewell was the last of the Knicks starters out of his warm-ups tonight. As he moved along the sideline toward the Nets' bench, the weeks of back-and-forth between him and Nets Coach Byron Scott seemed about to come to a head.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKER, RUTH HOCHSTEIN
description: BECKER - Ruth Hochstein. February 25, 2003, age 95. Wife of the late Hon. George O. Becker. Beloved mother of Bob (Jeanne), Marty (Rabbi Shelley Kovar Becker), dear grandmother of Jeffrey (Karen). Private graveside service. Contributions to Daughters of Miriam, Clifton, NJ. Shiva information: Direct Family Funerals, 631-424-6535.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERRY, LOUISA LIVINGSTON
description: GERRY-Louisa Livingston, 39. Died in New York Presbyterian Hospital after a long illness on February 24, 2003. Beloved daughter of Elbridge T. and Caroline A. Gerry of Locust Valley, N.Y. Sister of Elbridge T. Gerry III of New Canaan, CT., Ellen G. Breed of Greenwich, CT., Alison G. Rodney of Edwards, CO., and Carolyn A. Gerry of New York City and aunt to eight nieces & nephews. A Memorial Service will be held at St. John's of Lattingtown, Locust Valley, N.Y. on Monday, March 3rd at 10:30 AM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made in her memory to the New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, 161 William Street, N.Y., N.Y. 10003, or St. John's Episcopal Church, 705 Hale Street, Beverly, MA. 01915.

title: Colored Stones Light a Fire in Jewelry Sales
description: At Ralph Lauren's show two weeks ago, an impossibly slim model, wearing a white satin evening gown that would have made Jean Harlow proud, strode down the runway wearing something just as stunning: a bold, chunky, showy necklace made of dozens of crystal quartz beads, wrapped around and around and around her narrow neck.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about electronic voting referred incompletely to a decision by the Santa Clara County Board of Supervisors in California to invest $20 million in 5,000 electronic voting machines. While the machines have the ability to produce paper receipts, the county's plan for a pilot receipt program is contingent on state approval and negotiations with the manufacturer.

title: INSIDE
description: Nursing Home Fire Kills 10

title: 42 Are Indicted In Investigation Of Mob Control In Construction
description: Federal and state authorities in New York announced broad indictments yesterday charging that members of the Genovese and Colombo organized crime families had gained control of two union locals that represent operators of cranes, loaders and other heavy equipment at major construction sites throughout the city.

title: Democracy, War And the Arabs
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Lawyers Accused In Hospital Scheme
description: A ring of lawyers are accused of paying bribes for medical information useful in personal-injury civil cases, the Manhattan district attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, left, said yesterday. Six lawyers, a Bronx hospital employee and a husband-and-wife team were indicted yesterday on charges that they ran a multimillion-dollar scheme for seven years. Prosecutors said the lawyers -- Anthony Ferrandino, Lawrence Dicker, Scott Sessler, Daniel Chilewich, Fredric Zarkin and Olga Sorkin -- illegally paid the husband-and-wife team, Mary and Jean Phillipe Landi, to bribe hospital workers for information about accident victims. Efraim Vega, an employee of Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center in the Bronx, was also charged. The defendants, who face up to 25 years in prison if convicted, pleaded not guilty last night.

title: Battle Lines Form for Everything Else
description: The easy part of the rebuilding on the World Trade Center site may be over, even if it took nearly 18 months of often fractious public hearings and disputes between rival public and private interests to select a design team for the endeavor.

title: Bayer Stock Falls As Drug Lawsuits Frighten Investors
description: Shareholders of Bayer, the German pharmaceutical and chemical giant, are abandoning the company in droves out of fear that it may be forced to pay vast amounts to settle lawsuits filed by people who used an anticholesterol drug linked to more than 100 deaths worldwide.

title: The Athlete and the Flag
description: To the Editor:

title: World's Top-Ranked Squash Player Wins Again
description: Peter Nicol of England, the world's top-ranked squash player, defeated Thierry Lincou of France, 3 games to 1, to capture his second Harrisdirect Tournament of Champions title last night at Grand Central Station.

title: Israel Says War on Iraq Would Benefit The Region
description: Israelis once believed that the Oslo agreement with the Palestinians would usher in a new Middle East of comfortable Israeli-Arab coexistence.

title: Parliament Backs Blair on Iraq, but Vote Bares Rift in Labor Party
description: A daylong debate in the House of Commons today laid bare the deep divisions in Prime Minister Tony Blair's Labor Party over his hard-line stance on disarming Iraq.

title: S.E.C. LOOKING INTO COMMUNICATIONS BY SPIEGEL
description: Spiegel, the owner of Eddie Bauer stores and the Spiegel catalog, says the Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating whether the company failed to disclose auditor doubts about its financial health. The informal inquiry stems from Spiegel's failure to file S.E.C. reports on time and its notices that it would miss those deadlines, the company said yesterday in regulatory filings for the first three quarters of 2002. The delays began with Spiegel's annual filing for 2001, which was submitted on Feb. 4. Spiegel told the agency that the delays were caused by talks with lenders over defaulted debt and the auction of a credit card business. The notices of delay did not say that Spiegel's auditor, KPMG, had doubts about Spiegel's viability, the company said in the filings. Spiegel's continued defaults on debt agreements ''raise substantial doubt about the company's ability to continue as a going concern for a reasonable period of time,'' the filings said.

title: SHUTTLE ENGINEERS DEBATED CHANCES OF GRAVE DAMAGE
description: In the days before the Columbia disaster, NASA and contractor engineers explored the possibility that the shuttle had been fatally damaged on liftoff and precisely predicted some of the symptoms that the orbiter showed on re-entry.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: E-Mail Suggests Analyst Coached WorldCom Chief

title: Balancing Liberty and Security
description: To the Editor:

title: High, Wide And Transomed
description: AVERAGE American house size: down four square feet. Average American front door size: up seven square feet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, ALAN G.
description: JONES-Alan G. Beloved husband of Marie, loving father of Laurie and Christine, adoring grandfather of Bob and Stephie. Visiting Friday, 25pm & 7-9PM. Chapel service 7:30PM. Thomas M. Quinn and Sons Inc, 35-20 Broadway at 36th Street, LIC, NY.

title: Saving the Wall That Saved New York
description: From September 2001 through May 2002, I had the privilege of being inside the forbidden city of ground zero. I walked and photographed nearly every inch of it as it was transformed from an awesome pile to a vast and empty pit. Over that time, I was constantly amazed by the shifts in scale: human scale, city scale and, not least, nature's scale in its fractured and fitful relationship to architecture. Like an accordion, the 16-acre site was capable of appearing compressed and encircled one moment and then vast and beyond measure a second later. It breathed, as cities and nature do, when they draw us toward wonder and contemplation.

title: McGreevey's Nominee to Lead Port Authority Withdraws
description: Gov. James E.
