McGreevey's nominee for chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey today asked to withdraw his name from consideration and resigned from the board, amid complaints that his generous contributions to New Jersey Democrats may have violated campaign-finance and conflict-of-interest laws.

title: An Auction House With a Flair for the Dramatic
description: Auctions by the Bay wants to rival Bonhams & Butterfields, Christie's and Sotheby's by turning sales into theatrical events. Renaissance Rialto, which has restored 20 theaters in California, found a landmarked shell of a movie theater (top) at a former naval air station on San Francisco Bay and turned it into an Art Deco movie palace, right, where auctions are held two or three times a month. The 450-seat theater, newly decorated with 20-foot golden papyrus columns, hieroglyphs and enough ornamental plasterwork to keep King Tut on his toes, will also be used for private parties and film screenings.

title: Bitterly Divided Security Council Meets on Iraq Resolution
description: Abitterly divided Security Council met today to begin considering a resolution drafted by the United States that would find Baghdad in breach of weapons restrictions.

title: Keeping an Eye on Things, by Cellphone
description: IT IS a fundamental law of electronics: the audio breakthrough always precedes the video. Think about it: radio came before television, CD's came before DVD's, and Ella Fitzgerald came before Britney Spears.

title: Jackson Tries to Unruffle Some Feathers
description: Reggie Jackson looked around at the reporters he had summoned today and pleaded in vain for a lifeline. ''Where's Jeter when I need him?'' Jackson said.

title: U.S. Diplomat's Letter of Resignation
description: The following is the text of John Brady Kiesling's letter of resignation to Secretary of State Colin L. Powell. Mr. Kiesling is a career diplomat who has served in United States embassies from Tel Aviv to Casablanca to Yerevan.

title: Dialogue Box, Hollywood Version
description: ROGER S.H. SCHULMAN recalls being in the control room of a Hollywood sound studio as John Goodman, the actor, recorded the voice of Baloo the bear in ''The Jungle Book 2.'' As Mr. Goodman's voice resonated over a telephone line from a studio in New Orleans, a Disney executive turned to Mr. Schulman, one of the film's writers, to request additional dialogue for a roughhousing scene. But with the executive, Mr. Goodman, a dialogue director, engineers and others waiting in two studios, Mr. Schulman drew a blank. ''My brain just froze,'' he said.

title: Hijacking The Future
description: After pretending for more than a year that the State of New York was not experiencing a fiscal meltdown, Gov. George Pataki is now waging an unconscionable budget war against the public schools, which in many parts of the state were already in desperate trouble.

title: ALLEGHENY ENERGY TO SELL ITS STAKE IN POWER PLANT
description: Allegheny Energy, a utility owner that is selling assets to pay off debt, has agreed to sell its stake in a Pennsylvania power plant to the UGI Corporation for $51.3 million. Allegheny's share of the plant, the Conemaugh Generating Station near Johnstown, is 4.86 percent, the company said. Allegheny, based in Hagerstown, Md., received $2.4 billion in new loans yesterday to repay at least $1.64 billion in debt that had gone into default after losses in the company's energy-trading business last year. UGI is based in King of Prussia, Pa.

title: 4 Accused of Illegally Sending Money to Iraq
description: Federal authorities charged four men yesterday with illegally funneling at least $4 million to Iraq through a charity in Syracuse.

title: Lauder's Mix Of Restitution And Collecting
description: Ronald S. Lauder, heir to the cosmetics fortune, former American ambassador to Austria, once a mayoral candidate, prodigious art collector and major benefactor of Jewish causes, knows a lot about art stolen by the Nazis, much of it from Jews.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the resignation of Art Cooper as editor in chief of GQ misstated the magazine's circulation. It is about 800,000, not 950,000.

title: No Need for Arguments Over Whose Music to Play
description: As entertainment options multiply in cars and vans, delivering the appropriate soundtrack to every passenger is becoming complicated. Unwired Technology, a company that supplies audio components to several automakers, will offer wireless headphones that allow listeners and viewers to choose from among four sound sources.

title: Risks Await Jones in Heavier Class
description: The news conference for the coming heavyweight title fight between Roy Jones Jr. and John Ruiz began 1 hour 16 minutes late, which for boxing is quite prompt. There was the usual bluster, along with the standard threats and the required braggadocio.

title: A Baroque Group Plays Lively Bach
description: Through Saturday, the musicians of the Freiburg Baroque Orchestra, a period-instrument ensemble from Germany, will join the members of the Ballett Freiburg Pretty Ugly dance company for a choreographic presentation of Bach's ''Art of the Fugue,'' part of Lincoln Center's Bach Variations festival.

title: Acting President Won't Be Resigning
description: William C. Martin said yesterday that he was not resigning as acting president of the United States Olympic Committee. During an emergency conference call Tuesday of the organization's executive committee, Martin said that if their discussion reached the news media, he might resign.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BAUMAN, LIONEL R.
description: BAUMAN-Lionel R. Beloved partner, friend and colleague. Died on February 27, 1987. Sorely missed by all. Eugene M. Grant & Co. LLC

title: BUSH SAYS OUSTING HUSSEIN COULD AID PEACE IN MIDEAST
description: President Bush declared tonight that removing Saddam Hussein from power in Iraq would bring stability to the region and could set the stage for peace between Israel and a ''truly democratic'' Palestinian state.

title: Thousands Protest in Cairo Against a U.S.-Led War on Iraq
description: CAIRO, Feb. 27  Tens of thousands of Egyptians gathered today in this city's main stadium for the largest protest so far here against an American-led war in Iraq. It was also the largest antiwar demonstration in the Arab world, outside of Iraq itself.

title: Rams Pay Warner $6 Million Bonus
description: The St. Louis Rams paid quarterback Kurt Warner a $6 million roster bonus yesterday after attempts to restructure his contract fell through.

title: In Chicago, Ex-Athletes Know Politics Is a Sport
description: As the song says, and as the campaign posters tied to trees and placed in windows and staked on front lawns read, ''All You Need Is Love.''

title: Keep Tabs on Software That Can Share Secrets
description: Q. With heightened privacy awareness, I am concerned that in downloading tax form updates, my tax-preparation software (or another self-updating program like Windows) will try to send personal information from my computer to the company. My firewall program is currently blocking such attempts, but is there a way for consumers to find out what information is contained in these transmissions before they allow them out?

title: Capture a Single Moment As Well as the Entire Hour
description: While many digital video cameras can do double duty producing still pictures, the photographer usually has to make a choice of one format or the other. Two new digicams from Canon, however, are able to take snapshots while they are performing their main job.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column on Feb. 12, about the Rheingold Brewing Company's renewed marketing push in New York City, misstated annual beer sales in the city. (The error was repeated in the Public Lives profile last Thursday, about Thomas L. Bendheim, the company's chief executive.) According to Beer Marketer's Insights, an industry newsletter, sales total at least $1.4 billion a year, not $40 million.

title: A Slick Carry-On for the Modern Pilgrim
description: I HAVE been getting ready to take a trip to the past, to my grandmother's eastern Kentucky hometown, circa 1935.

title: Thomson Profits Rise 10%
description: The Thomson Corporation, the electronic publishing group controlled by the Thomson family of Canada, reported yesterday a 10 percent rise in fourth-quarter earnings, to $288 million, or 44 cents a share.

title: G.M. SAYS ONSTAR SERVICE IS MAKING MONEY AFTER 7 YEARS
description: The General Motors Corporation is making money on its OnStar in-vehicle communications service for the first time since the company began offering it seven years ago, said John Devine, the chief financial officer. OnStar, introduced in Cadillac cars, uses cellular and satellite technology to communicate when a driver calls or when an accident sets off airbags. The service is now available on most G.M. vehicles and on vehicles sold by Honda, Toyota and Volkswagen. Mr. Devine said OnStar had more than 2 million customers. G.M. has said it wants to increase revenue from OnStar to $4 billion by 2005 from $750 million in 2001. General Motors does not disclose how much it has invested in OnStar.

title: Voices raised in Chirac's party against veto
description: PARIS:  Significant elements  perhaps more than half  of Jacques Chirac's presidential majority in the National Assembly are making clear they oppose France's eventual use of its veto in the Security Council to block a new American-led resolution that would justify a strike against Iraq.

title: People
description: * Nick Bell was named executive creative director at the London office of J. Walter Thompson, part of the WPP Group, effective in May. He succeeds Jaspar Shelbourne, who will become one of 10 worldwide creative directors for the agency, based in London. Mr. Bell had been executive creative director at the London office of Leo Burnett Worldwide, part of the Publicis Groupe, where two creative directors, Greg Martin and Michael McKenna, will oversee the day-to-day operations of the department until a successor is named.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: New Products Needed, Executive Says
description: Thomas J. Engibous, the chief executive of Texas Instruments, said yesterday that electronics makers needed to create new products to spur consumer interest and revive sales. ''We're in a lull in that regard right now,'' Mr. Engibous said at an investment conference in La Quinta, Calif. Analog modems and personal computers that can run audio and video applications have increased orders for electronics components in the past, he said. Slack consumer demand has been heightened by concern about a possible war in Iraq, which he said had put corporate spending into a holding pattern. Texas Instruments, the world's biggest maker of chips for cellphones, will have sales this quarter about equal to the fourth quarter's $2.15 billion, he said, confirming a previous forecast.

title: Ruling Allows Bid by Motorola to Proceed
description: Motorola Inc., the maker of mobile phones, can proceed with its $30 million bid for the 26 percent of Next Level Communications it does not own, a judge ruled here today.

title: Lucent Sets Deal With S.E.C. to End Accounting Inquiry
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. , the largest American maker of telecommunications equipment, said today that it had reached a preliminary agreement with the Securities and Exchange Commission to conclude an investigation of its accounting practices.

title: U.N. Says Iraq Agrees in Principle to Destroy Missiles
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27  The United Nations said this evening that Iraq had agreed in principle to destroy its ballistic missiles.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Convicted In Bloomberg Extortion
description: A man from Kazakhstan was convicted yesterday of trying to extort money from Michael R. Bloomberg before Mr. Bloomberg became mayor. Trial testimony showed that the man, Oleg Zezev, had hacked into the computers of Mr. Bloomberg's media company, Bloomberg L.P., which is dependent on computer security between it and its clients. Mr. Zezev sent threatening e-mail messages, demanding $200,000, prosecutors said.

title: From Political Calculation, a Sweeping Vision of Ground Zero
description: Just weeks after the World Trade Center attack, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki began to imagine the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan, and they immediately saw two problems.

title: One of These Days, Racing Will Resume
description: Race 4 of the America's Cup was postponed again today because of high winds in the Hauraki Gulf, where Cup races are held.

title: Title IX Reformers Keep Men in Mind
description: A federal commission formed to examine Title IX, the 1972 law that forced schools to offer women equal opportunity in sports, delivered its final report today, recommending that the law be retooled to ensure that new sports opportunities for girls and women do not come at the expense of boys' and men's teams.

title: Old Mississippi Crime Scene Revisited in Murder Trial
description: Eddie Walters has gray in his hair now and works at the Wal-Mart, but in the summer of 1966 he was 11 years old, barefoot and buck-wild.

title: 2 Ex-Officials At Kmart Face Fraud Charges
description: Two former Kmart executives were indicted yesterday by a Detroit grand jury on federal charges of fraud, conspiracy and making false statements over their recording of a $42 million payment that resulted in an overstatement of Kmart's results.

title: Sony Is Venturing Into Online Games for Multitudes
description: Grid computing, a concept that originated in supercomputing centers, is taking a step toward the mainstream: Sony will announce today that it will use the technology to accelerate its push into the emerging market for online games with thousands of players at a time.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Support For Bible Study
description: The American Civil Liberties Union has raised questions about weekly Bible study for state officials and Capitol employees, but Gov. Bob Riley said the voluntary sessions are not a big deal. ''It meant a lot to me, and I think it meant a lot for members of my cabinet,'' Governor Riley said. The A.C.L.U. questioned whether the Tuesday and Wednesday sessions in nonworking hours mix religion and politics. ''The biggest concern that I have with this kind of thing is how it may exclude those who do not participate from the decision making process in government,'' said Rob Weinberg, staff lawyer for the American Civil Liberties Union of Alabama. Dana Beyerle (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Activist Jailed In Attack On Modified Crops
description: Jos Bov, the French sheep farmer and much-publicized enemy of junk food and globalization, was ordered to serve 10 months in prison for damaging fields of genetically modified rice in 1998. Mr. Bove, 49, became a popular figure after spending six weeks in prison last year for organizing the bulldozing of a McDonald's restaurant. He said he would ask President Jacques Chirac for a pardon. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Christopher Hill, Historian, Is Dead at 91
description: Christopher Hill, a leading Marxist historian of 17th-century England who helped illuminate the radical tradition of that revolutionary period, died on Monday. He was 91.

title: The Day the Music Died
description: Highlights from this week's forum discussions, including critiques of the Grammys and "The Pill" documentary.

title: Swiss Re to Post Loss and Cut Dividend
description: Swiss Reinsurance, a big reinsurer, said today that it would post a loss for 2002 of 100 million Swiss francs ($74 million). The company, known as Swiss Re, also said it would sharply reduce its dividend for the first time in nearly a century.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: No Winner Yet In Council Races
description: It will take a week or more to determine the winner in last Tuesday's special election for a City Council seat in Bay Ridge and Bensonhurst, the New York City Board of Elections said yesterday. Officials said that unofficial results from the five-candidate race showed a virtual dead heat between former State Senator Vincent Gentile and Rosemarie O'Keefe, who was commissioner of the Community Assistance Unit under Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Each campaign suggested that its candidate led, but by a margin of fewer than 75 votes. A spokeswoman for the board said about 560 absentee ballots remained to be counted. Jonathan P. Hicks (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CROWN CORK AND SEAL CO., Philadelphia, said it had completed a $3.2 billion refinancing and formed a new public holding company, Crown Holdings, which now owns it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, JAMES J.
description: WALSH-James J. The members of the Philosophy Department at Columbia University mourn the death of their colleague and former chairman, James Walsh, who served the department and its students with distinction, loyalty and devotion.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Computer Sciences Wins Basell Contract
description: The Computer Sciences Corporation, the third-largest United States seller of technology services, won an eight-year, $320 million contract yesterday to manage Basell's computer networks. BASF and the Royal Dutch/Shell Group own Basell, which is based in the Netherlands and is the world's largest maker of polypropylene, an industrial chemical. A Computer Sciences spokesman, Mike Dickerson, said the company would manage data centers, help desks, networks and other parts of Basell's computer systems, starting April 1. Computer Sciences, based in El Segundo, Calif., has contracts with other chemical companies, including a 1997 multibillion-dollar pact to manage DuPont's computer networks. Shares in Computer Sciences fell 69 cents, to $30.52.

title: Top Air Force General Backs Independent Inquiry in Rapes
description: The top general in the Air Force endorsed a Congressional call today for an independent inquiry at the Air Force Academy, where at least 20 women say they have been raped or sexually assaulted in recent years.

title: New, Improved Hall Panel Elects No One
description: A revolutionary change in the Baseball Hall of Fame's veterans committee produced no new members of the Hall yesterday. The new, expanded committee elected no former players and no former managers, umpires or executives, including Marvin Miller, who had headed the players union.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Paterson: Woman Who Killed Son Is Sentenced
description: A woman who killed her toddler by dropping him into a river has been sentenced to 18 years in prison, the Passaic County prosecutor's office said. The woman, Martita Gonzalez, now 20, was sentenced on Tuesday after pleading guilty in January to aggravated manslaughter for throwing her 16-month-old son, Anthony Valentin, over a footbridge into the Passaic River in 2000. Ms. Gonzalez, 17 at the time, confessed to the crime a day after it happened, saying she had a date and could not find a baby sitter. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about potential investments by oil companies in Iraq referred incompletely to negotiations between the country and TotalFinaElf of France. While the company held discussions on a production-sharing contract, it never signed one.

title: A Japanese Theme Park Company Fails
description: The Huis Ten Bosch Company, one of Japan's largest theme park operators, has declared bankruptcy, highlighting the mounting troubles in the country's vast government-financed recreation industry.

title: F.D.A. APPROVES EARLIER USE OF BRAIN TUMOR TREATMENT
description: Guilford Pharmaceuticals has won Food and Drug Administration approval to expand use of a brain cancer treatment by permitting doctors to implant it the first time a patient has surgery. Guilford's Gliadel wafer was already cleared for use in patients whose brain tumors reappear after surgery. The new approval permits the use of Gliadel during initial surgery for malignant glioma; patients with that cancer seldom survive longer than 10 months after diagnosis. The widened approval may increase the number of potential American patients to 11,000 from 3,000 a year, Guilford said.

title: A Memorial, Yes, but Battle Lines Form for Everything Else at Ground Zero
description: The easy part of the rebuilding on the World Trade Center site may be over, even if it took nearly 18 months of often fractious public hearings and disputes between rival public and private interests to select a design team for the endeavor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORMENT, MARGUERITE (O'CALLAGHAN)
description: DORMENT - Marguerite (O'Callaghan). Of Monmouth Beach, formerly of Montclair, NJ on February 23, 2003. Mrs. Dorment, Peggy as she was known, was a graduate of Georgian Court College. She was a past member and Women's Golf Champion at the Montclair Golf Club, Upper Montclair Golf Club, the Deal Golf and Country Club, and the Everglades Club, Palm Beach, Florida. She was a former president of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association in New York. She was a patron of the Metropolitan Opera, Lincoln Center Theatre, and the American Ballet Theatre. She will be remembered as a graceful and gracious mother and friend, as well as for her intellectual curiosity and keen sense of humor which she has lovingly passed on to all her survivors. Wife of the late James Francis Dorment and the late Richard V. Stein; mother of James (Maureen) Dorment, Thomas Dorment, John (Jacqueline) Dorment, Diane (George) Dorment Finn, Christopher (Rosemary) Dorment, Richard (Hattie) Dorment and Marguerite (Harvey) Dorment Glover; sister of Patricia Abell and the late Thomas O'Callaghan; stepmother of Tony (Kathy) Stein and Maureen (Alan) Pearce; also survived by twenty-four grandchildren and one greatgrandchild. Mass of Christian Burial will be offered at Immaculate Conception Church, Montclair on Friday at 10:30 AM. Interment at Immaculate Conception Cemetery, Upper Montclair. Visitation at the Hugh M. Moriarty Funeral Home, 76 Park St on Thursday 2-4 and 7-9PM. In lieu of flowers donations to the Christian Brothers Academy, 850 Newman Springs Road, Lincroft, New Jersey 07738.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-18

title: For Family Members, an Early-Morning Frenzy and a Cold Reality
description: Hermengildo Pereira, 71, had been in the Greenwood Health Center for just over a year, placed there reluctantly by his large, doting family after he developed diabetes, suffered a stroke and began to lose his vision.

title: Both Parties Begin Effort To Restore Organic Standard
description: Republican and Democratic lawmakers today answered a rising call from a broad range of citizens, corporate food producers, farmers and environmentalists to overturn a tiny provision, tucked into the huge omnibus spending bill that had loosened an organic food standard to benefit a single chicken company in Georgia.

title: British Judge Rules Sperm Donor Is Legal Father in Mix-Up Case
description: Britain's top family court judge declared today that a black man whose sperm had mistakenly been used to fertilize the eggs of a white woman at a fertility clinic was the legal father of the twins born nine months later.

title: European Leaders Dig In to Defend Their Positions on Iraq
description: As the Bush administration stepped up lobbying efforts for its new resolution on Iraq, Europe's leaders worked determinedly today to ensure against defections from their well-defined ranks on the issue.

title: Inspiration Begins (but Doesn't End) With Degas
description: ''Le Travail,'' a one-act ballet choreographed by Matthew Neenan, a 28-year-old member of the Pennsylvania Ballet, is the company's felicitous tribute to ''Degas and the Dance,'' the current exhibition at the Philadelphia Museum of Art.

title: Umpires Ready To Become One
description: Three and a half years after an intramural fight shattered their unity, Major League Baseball umpires are reuniting with the union that emerged from their 1999 dispute.

title: Office Chairs to Ease Repetitive Wallet Strain
description: Finding an adjustable, ergonomically correct desk chair is essential, but often expensive. Three chairs styles from Steelcase can be had at deep discounts at Corporate Furniture Resource. The Leap chair, below, usually about $740, is $475 here. The Rapport chair is $300 instead of $580. The Criterion is $200, not $580. Most of the chairs are upholstered in black; quantities are limited. Corporate Furniture Resource is at 125 Maiden Lane (Water Street); www.cfrfurniture.com or (212) 607-5549. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Fire Sweeps Through Nursing Home in Hartford, Killing 10
description: A fire tore through a nursing home here early today, killing 10 residents, injuring 23 and sending dozens of frail, terrified people into the frigid night. Investigators were hoping to interview one resident in connection with the blaze.

title: With 6 Degrees of Separation, Computers Stay in Sync
description: FOR most people, the theory that a link between any two people on earth can be found through no more than six other people is little more than an amusing subject for party chat. But the ''small world'' or ''six degrees of separation'' concept, which makes political leaders or Hollywood stars seem practically like our neighbors, may also play a role in helping huge networks of computers work together in harmony. A study by five United States-based researchers has found that random links much like those between people may be more effective than centralized control in coordinating massive parallel computing systems.

title: OIL AND GAS PRODUCER TO ABANDON UNSUCCESSFUL WELL
description: The McMoRan Exploration Company, an American oil and natural gas producer, said it would abandon an unsuccessful well drilled in shallow waters of the Gulf of Mexico. The Lighthouse Point-Deep prospect was drilled to almost 18,000 feet in about 10 feet of water off Louisiana, the company said. Results of the effort were being reviewed to determine whether further drilling in the area was warranted, the company said. McMoRan Exploration is participating in four exploration wells being drilled in shallow gulf waters, the company said. Production from one of the wells is expected to begin in the second quarter, and plans for another well in the area are being developed.

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: S.E.C. Expands Investigation of HealthSouth Transactions
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 26 (AP)  Federal regulators have expanded their inquiry into the HealthSouth Corporation , with investigators gaining subpoena power as they review possible wrongdoing at the company.

title: Pope Reportedly Acts to Speed Removal of Abusive Priests
description: Pope John Paul II quietly approved changes in church law this month that will speed the removal of sexual abusers from the priesthood, according to a spokesman for the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Quake Aftershocks Kill More In Remote West
description: Hundreds of aftershocks added to the death toll in a severe earthquake in China's western region of Xinjiang, and authorities sent thousands of tents and relief supplies to the hardest-hit region near China's border with Kyrgyzstan. Official said the number of dead reached 266, with another 2,000 reported injured. Joseph Kahn (NYT)

title: First-Half Profit Drops 44% at Telstra
description: Telstra, Australia's national telephone company, reported a 44 percent drop in net income today for the first six months of its fiscal year.

title: Theater for Students
description: To the Editor:

title: A War of Succession With 70's Soul
description: SOUL CIRCUS

title: Garden Gives In To Ewing's Guest List
description: Two days before his No. 33 was to be hung in Madison Square Garden in perpetuity, Patrick Ewing and the Knicks were involved in a tug of war over the guest list that threatened to jeopardize the ceremony.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: CURRENT ACCOUNT DEFICIT RISES Rising oil prices resulted in a national current account deficit of $646 million in December, according to the Bank of Korea. Economists predicted still more monthly deficits and a possible weakening of South Korea's currency. The deficit, the highest in five and a half years, was four times the deficit for December 2002. For the year, the central bank posted a current account surplus of $6.09 billion, $2.15 billion below the surplus for 2001.

title: In Hell's Kitchen, Slivers of Coolness
description: CLINTON, the formerly forlorn patch of low-rise buildings also known as Hell's Kitchen, has begun to attract developers, and with them new boutiques. In the afternoon sun, the area, just west of Times Square, still looks like a Hopper painting. Amid the ethnic grocery stores and tenement row houses, however, are quirky new storefronts, including a floral design studio and an antiques shop, a refreshing alternative to the chain stores popping up in virtually every other Manhattan neighborhood. Begin your walking tour on West 43rd Street, working your way up Ninth and 10th Avenues to 50th Street, and enjoy the village atmosphere while it lasts.

title: Strategists See Victory in Stalemate
description: President Bush and his fellow Republicans complain about Miguel Estrada's treatment at the hands of Senate Democrats, but some also see a political advantage for their party in the continuing fight over his nomination to an important appeals court.

title: Tough Questions on Safety For Automakers at Hearing
description: A bipartisan group of senators challenged the auto industry's commitment today to voluntarily improve the safety of sport utility vehicles and questioned the Bush administration's preference for self-regulation.

title: Labor Secretary's Talk Angers Union Leaders
description: Labor Secretary Elaine L. Chao ignited a furor today among labor leaders, including the administration's strongest friend in labor, the teamster president James P. Hoffa, when she cited repeated examples of union corruption while addressing the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s winter meeting.

title: Turkey Delays Vote on Allowing In U.S. Troops for Iraq War
description: ANKARA, Feb. 27  Turkey's leaders postponed a scheduled parliamentary vote today on whether to allow American combat troops to use the country as a base against Iraq. The move came amid indications that the ruling party was having difficulty mustering the necessary support.

title: Stewart Gets His Wish and Is Released
description: Kordell Stewart already knew that the Pittsburgh Steelers would grant his wish to become a free agent, so when the Steelers' owner, Dan Rooney, and Coach Bill Cowher phoned him separately Tuesday to formalize the separation, Stewart chatted mostly about memories -- the good days and the bad days.

title: Shuttle Debris Forms Giant Puzzle in a Hangar
description: In a hangar designed for a possible successor to the space shuttle, engineers and technicians are painstakingly trying to reassemble what remains of America's first reusable spaceship.

title: Six Reprieves for Bad CD's: Use These Under Drinks Instead
description: Maira Kalman and Rick Meyerowitz, designers with M & Company, have turned CD's into coasters, inspired by colleagues who stuck old CD's under their coffee cups. Six coasters ($18) in bright colors come with instructions not to put them in your CD player ''unless you are mad in which case you may not need any coasters at all.'' At the MoMa Design Store, 44 West 53rd Street, or 81 Spring Street (Crosby); (800) 793-3167. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Europe's Trade Retaliatory List
description: The European Commission yesterday unveiled a list of American products that would be hit by sanctions if the United States does not scrap a tax break it grants to many of its biggest exporters. The World Trade Organization supported the union's complaint about the tax breaks last year. It permitted the union to impose trade sanctions on up to $4 billion of United States products, making this by far the biggest trans-Atlantic trade dispute to date. Last September the commission, the executive body of the union, drew up a long list worth $12 billion. After consulting European industry, it has reduced the target list. Items excluded from the short list include some textiles, agriculture and paper products. A commission spokeswoman said that Europe was still hoping that the United States would repeal the law on the tax breaks before any sanctions became necessary. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Residents, Increasingly, Are Younger And Troubled
description: The Hartford nursing home where 10 residents died in a fire yesterday morning caters to more than just the elderly, having filled its wards in recent years in part by admitting relatively younger people who have schizophrenia, AIDS and other illnesses.

title: Just Like Old Times, A Jug Band Stompin'
description: Jim Kweskin is in the construction business. To be more precise, he's a partner in Fort Hill Construction, supervising projects in New York and Boston, where he lives. When he can, Mr. Kweskin likes to get together with friends to play music, often informally but sometimes in front of an audience. Tonight he will be appearing at Makor, a club on the Upper West Side. And he has a new CD out.

title: Fans of Classic Amps Find Nirvana in a Chip
description: THERE are days when Jeff Slingluff, a sound engineer, feels like a musical archivist, a bit like a latter-day Alan Lomax. The difference is that Mr. Lomax made recordings of vanishing American songs and music styles, whereas Mr. Slingluff seeks to preserve the sounds of vintage guitar amplifiers and fine guitars.

title: A Top White House Economic Adviser Steps Down
description: R. Glenn Hubbard, a leading architect of President Bush's ambitious tax-cutting agenda, resigned today as chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers.

title: Voters Say Why Mayor Is Slipping In Popularity
description: At the mention of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's name, Barbara Carr's arm moved furiously up and down, as if she were trying to wave away the odor of three-day-old cod.

title: Serb in Court in The Hague, Playing to a TV Audience at Home
description: Vojislav Seselj, one of Serbia's most hard-line and most articulate nationalists, appeared at the United Nations tribunal in The Hague yesterday to answer charges that he ran a band of volunteer fighters that killed and robbed non-Serbs during the Balkan wars of the 1990's.

title: Miscellany
description: * Dentsu, Tokyo, is opening an office in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, called Dentsu Vietnam, with 24 employees.

title: Legislature And Rowland Close Deal On Budget Gap
description: At a midnight legislative session, the Connecticut General Assembly and Gov. John G. Rowland sealed a deal this morning to close the state's $650 million budget gap, settling on a package of tax increases and spending cuts that includes a broad-based increase in the state income tax.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: SHARES OF SONIC SOLUTIONS SOAR ON AOL PACT Shares of Sonic Solutions rose as much as 24 percent yesterday after America Online agreed to license Sonic's technology for creating compact discs and DVD's. AOL is the world's biggest Internet service, with 27 million customers in the United States. MusicNet on AOL, a music-subscription service that AOL introduced yesterday, will include Sonic's AuthorScript program, which burns CD's. MusicNet subscribers will be asked to pay as much as $17.95 a month for access to 250,000 songs by performers from all five of the world's biggest music companies. People who buy tracks will be able to burn them directly to a CD. Shares of Sonic rose 53 cents, or 13 percent, to $4.63. The stock had dropped 31 percent in the last year. (Bloomberg News)

title: Hong Kong Moves to Raise Birth Rate and Draw Richer Immigrants
description: Local leaders announced today that they would begin accepting immigrants based partly on their wealth and talents and would adjust tax policies to encourage families to have more babies.

title: Design Chosen For Rebuilding At Ground Zero
description: An open pit, the crucible where the fires burned for weeks after Sept. 11, 2001, and the ground that held most of the bodies of the dead, will stand as the centerpiece of the city's effort to memorialize and rebuild after the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center, under a decision made by city and state officials last night.

title: New Efforts To Recover Nazi Plunder; But Pessimism Grows For Recoveries
description: Much of the art world is on the lookout as never before for lost Nazi plunder, but experts have become increasingly pessimistic that much more of it will ever be recovered and restored to its rightful owners.

title: A New Phase For Gay Books
description: Here are the conventional wisdoms about why gay and lesbian book publishing is nearly inaudible: assimilation has generally succeeded; so many television shows and movies appeal to gay consumers with gay characters that they have robbed reading time; gay fiction has gotten far beyond ''coming out'' and is sold on the regular fiction racks in bookstores and not as a niche; the number of gay and lesbian bookstores has declined.

title: F.C.C. Members Defend Proposals on Bell Companies
description: The five members of the Federal Communications Commission defended their new telephone and broadband policy in front of a Congressional hearing today, but they conceded that their compromise proposal, which requires the regional Bell companies to continue to share their phone lines with competitors, left no one happy and was not certain to pump up the flailing telecommunications sector in the near term.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Shares Of Sonic Solutions Soar On AOL Pact
description: Shares of Sonic Solutions rose as much as 24 percent yesterday after America Online agreed to license Sonic's technology for creating compact discs and DVD's. AOL is the world's biggest Internet service, with 27 million customers in the United States. MusicNet on AOL, a music-subscription service that AOL introduced yesterday, will include Sonic's AuthorScript program, which burns CD's. MusicNet subscribers will be asked to pay as much as $17.95 a month for access to 250,000 songs by performers from all five of the world's biggest music companies. People who buy tracks will be able to burn them directly to a CD. Shares of Sonic rose 53 cents, or 13 percent, to $4.63. The stock had dropped 31 percent in the last year.

title: Troubles Build for Ahold Over Audit Irregularities
description: The troubles of Royal Ahold deepened today, as investigations and investor lawsuits mounted against the Dutch-based supermarket giant.

title: NORTHWEST ASKS PILOTS FOR 20% PAY CUTS
description: The Northwest Airlines Corporation has asked pilots for a 20 percent pay cut and permanent changes in benefits and work rules, the pilots' union said yesterday. The union, the Air Line Pilots Association, told its 5,700 active and 633 laid-off members that it would not respond to the company proposal until after it analyzes the airline's finances. Northwest asked pilots earlier this year to begin talks on labor-cost reductions because revenue had not recovered from a decline that began in 2001. The airline has said it is trying to cut annual expenses as much as $1.5 billion to avoid filing for bankruptcy protection.

title: House Is Set To Back Ban On Cloning Of Humans
description: Dolly the sheep is dead, but the political controversy she engendered lives in the House of Representatives, where lawmakers are expected on Thursday to pass a bill making human cloning a crime.

title: Reality TV, and the Real World Beyond
description: To the Editor:

title: Pentagon Seeking to Deploy Missiles Before Full Testing
description: The Pentagon wants to begin deploying its missile defense system on the West Coast next year, before it is fully tested, an idea that has drawn fire from several Democratic lawmakers.

title: Mister Rogers Goes to Russia
description: The negotiations were dragging during the marathon bargaining session last week. The Soviet side had reacted stiffly to the American proposals. Then the chief American delegate turned to a furry, eight-inch-long puppet for help.

title: Downloading Data by Cellphone
description: Wireless carriers offer a broad variety of data transmission plans. A selection of plans, based on information provided by the companies (prices are per month):

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, RABBI EUGENE
description: WEINER-Rabbi Eugene. The Jewish Center of the Hamptons mourns the passing of Rabbi Eugene Weiner, beloved husband of Anita Weiner, a visionary and gifted teacher, and former interim Rabbi of the Jewish Center. We extend deepest condolences to Anita and her family. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Rabbi Alon Levkovitz Cantor Debra Stein Donald Zucker, President

title: Sniper Case Defense Lawyers Seek Voiding of a Confession
description: Defense lawyers for Lee Malvo, the teenager charged in the Washington-area sniper attacks, said today that police investigators were aware of a federal judge's order that should have precluded them from questioning Mr. Malvo without a lawyer.

title: For Stay-at-Home Film Buffs With a Taste for the Opulent
description: With DVD players, surround-sound speakers and screens bigger than those of some Manhattan art-film houses, home theater systems can make bunkering in the house seem appealing. For consumers willing to spare no expense, a high-end new package from Bang & Olufsen combines size, style and control in one customized system that may even make snow days in close confinement fly by.

title: Funny Accident Gets Into the Record Book
description: The book of the 2002 World Championships in Montreal, played last August, is perhaps the best in the 50-year series. It not only has 320 tightly packed pages with a wealth of photographs, but also set a production record in the modern era. The book rolled off the presses four weeks ago, less than five months after play ended. It is available for $29.95 plus $5 for mailing from Baron Barclay Bridge Supplies at (800) 274-2221.

title: Group Gives City Poor Mark on Child Welfare
description: After reviewing the deaths of nearly 200 children in New York City over five years, a national child advocacy organization said yesterday that despite many improvements in the city's child welfare agency, caseworkers were still doing a poor job of weighing risks and responding to evidence of abuse or neglect.

title: Company Gets Record Fine For Its Giving To Lawmakers
description: The state's Lobbying Commission fined a private prison company a record $300,000 today for failing to report free transportation, meals and other gifts it had given to legislators in an effort to keep millions of dollars in state contracts.

title: Sports of The Times; Two Ladders To Induction Or Inertia
description: THEY didn't elect anybody, but the Baseball Hall of Fame's new veterans committee did create two ladders to guide its voters in the future. If the committee doesn't disappear from lack of interest.

title: On Stand, Bridgeport Mayor Concedes Little in Bribery Case
description: Pressed by prosecutors to admit to dozens of crimes, including accepting cases of French wine and custom-tailored shirts in exchange for awarding lucrative contracts to associates, Mayor Joseph P. Ganim of Bridgeport conceded today on one charge: cheating on his federal income taxes.

title: Finding Uniformity in the Lexicon of Snow
description: It seemed like a perfect fit, a job melding the skills of a former Congressional investigator with those of a person whose responsibility it is to report mountain snow conditions. After all, what is more important to a skier or snowboarder than the truth?

title: Excerpts From NASA E-Mail About Space Shuttle Before It Disintegrated
description: Following are excerpts from e-mail messages exchanged among engineers during the shuttle Columbia's flight. They were released by the space agency yesterday in response to requests under the Freedom of Information Act.

title: New York Teams Are Making Deals
description: The MetroStars of Major League Soccer and the Power of the Women's United Soccer Association signed players, or are close to signing them, with about six weeks to go before the start of the regular seasons.

title: In China, a New Signature for a Soft Drink
description: Coca-Cola has unveiled a curvy logo in Shanghai, its first Chinese script logo since 1979, when Coca-Cola re-entered the Chinese market after a 30-year absence. ''With the new logo, we wanted to inject some new energy, so it looks more consistent with the English Spencerian script -- with the curves on the bottom and the top,'' said John Cheung, director of division marketing of Coca-Cola in China. The 1979 logo, he said, ''wasn't a very specific design.''

title: A Solar Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Families Pay Respects To Victims of '93 Attack
description: As they have done every year for the last decade, the families and friends of the six people who died in 1993 in the first terrorist attack on the World Trade Center gathered yesterday to remember their loved ones.

title: No Contest: So-Called Rivalry Is a Rout
description: The anticipated meeting of the so-called rivals was an understated affair, over almost as soon as it began.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Abbey Has First Annual Loss
description: After a disastrous foray into corporate banking, the mortgage lender Abbey National reported the first annual loss in its history, writing down losses equivalent to $3.6 billion on acquisitions and investments. The net loss for 2002 was 1.2 billion ($1.91 billion) in contrast to a net profit in 2001 of 947 million. The company also halved its dividend to 25 percent. Analysts had expected the dividend cut and the loss, but were divided on the extent of the damage. Abbey's shares seesawed, rising by as much as 8 percent before falling to 378 pence. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Met Gets Gift of 100 Works Collected by Son of Matisse
description: More than 100 works of art by the most prominent masters of the 20th century, including nearly 50 paintings, sculptures, drawings and prints by Henri Matisse, have been given to the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Time to Ban Ephedra
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINERT, MARY A.
description: REINERT-Mary A. On February 25, 2003. Beloved daughter of the late Frederick and Catherine. Beloved sister of the late Margaret Diehl and John. Also survived by many nieces & nephews. Longtime friend of Regina Fischer. The family will receive friends at the Williams Funeral Home Inc., 5628 Broadway at 232nd St, Bronx on Thursday and Friday from 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial in St. Nicholas of Tolentine Church on Saturday at 9:30 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Police Shoot 2 In Separate Incidents
description: The police have shot and wounded two men, one a relative of the detective who shot him, in separate incidents in Brooklyn and Manhattan, the authorities said yesterday. A preliminary review indicated that both shootings were within police guidelines, police officials said. Yesterday, an off-duty detective wounded a cousin, Samuel Bland, 20, after he menaced her with a knife in a backyard in Coney Island about 1 a.m., the police said. The detective, whose name was not released, had intervened in a family argument, the police said. Mr. Bland was struck in the right arm and taken to Coney Island Hospital in stable condition. He faces assault charges. On Tuesday night in Washington Heights, a plainclothes officer, who was not identified, shot and wounded a man who was getting out of a car with a pistol about 7 p.m., the police said. The man, Jose Medina, 27, was hit in the wrist and buttocks and taken to Harlem Hospital Center in stable condition, the police said. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Democracy, War And the Arabs
description: To the Editor:

title: The Accountable Mayor Bloomberg
description: Michael Bloomberg, the mayor who is reinventing education in New York City, graded himself a while back. In his first 13 months in office, he said, 80 percent of his 380 campaign promises had been met, were on their way to fulfillment or had at least made it to the drawing board. That, he said good-naturedly, deserved A+. Even allowing for grade inflation, his effort to hold himself accountable is commendable. It also sets a useful precedent.

title: In the President's Words: 'Free People Will Keep the Peace of the World'
description: Following is a transcript of the speech given yesterday by President Bush to the American Enterprise Institute in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: More U.S. Money For Police Force
description: The American ambassador to Indonesia, Ralph L. Boyce, said the Bush administration planned to give another $4 million to the Indonesian police force for training and to purchase more than two dozen vehicles. At a signing ceremony with the national police chief, Da'i Bachtiar, Mr. Boyce said Washington had already provided $12 million to help the Indonesian police become more professional. Jane Perlez (NYT)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Debating People-Rating
description: Last week in this newsletter, I mused that dating would be a lot more efficient if some Web site could warn us about potential dates before we spent an evening, or a month, with people who turn out to be sociopaths.

title: Vanquishing A Troubled Legacy
description: ON the wall of the den in Dr. Sherwin Nuland's sun-filled home outside New Haven is a New Yorker cartoon, showing a couple on Christmas morning, opening presents in front of their tree. The man holds up a book, elated, and the caption reads, '' 'How We Die' -- Fabulous!''

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BROOKLYN: NO WINNER YET IN COUNCIL RACES It will take a week or more to determine the winner in last Tuesday's special election for a City Council seat in Bay Ridge and Bensonhurst, the New York City Board of Elections said yesterday. Officials said that unofficial results from the five-candidate race showed a virtual dead heat between former State Senator Vincent Gentile and Rosemarie O'Keefe, who was commissioner of the Community Assistance Unit under Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Each campaign suggested that its candidate led, but by a margin of fewer than 75 votes. A spokeswoman for the board said about 560 absentee ballots remained to be counted. Jonathan P. Hicks (NYT)

title: CALENDAR
description: Writers on New York

title: Council Backs Greater Access to 'Morning-After Pill' Despite Possible Veto
description: With many state legislators already calling for wider access to emergency contraceptives, the City Council joined the fight yesterday, passing a package of bills requiring pharmacies to advertise sale of the drugs and demanding the pills be made available in all city-financed hospitals and health clinics.

title: Staples is changing its slogan to stress the ease of shopping for office supplies in its stores.
description: STAPLES, the office-supply retailer, has no longer got ''Yeah, we've got that.''

title: Supreme Court Voids Racketeering Conviction of Anti-Abortion Groups in 80's Case
description: The Supreme Court today overturned a federal racketeering judgment against a coalition of anti-abortion groups that conducted a widespread campaign of disrupting and blockading abortion clinics during the 1980's. The protesters' actions, although in some instances criminal, did not fit the federal definition of extortion that was the basis for the lawsuit against them, the court said.

title: UConn Extends Streak
description: Connecticut locked up a share of the Big East Conference title last night and stretched its winning streak to 66 games with a 97-57 trouncing of Georgetown at McDonough Gymnasium in Washington.

title: 4 Killed in Suicide Bombing at Checkpoint in Northern Iraq
description: A man detonated a bomb he was wearing near a Kurdish military headquarters in northern Iraq today, killing himself and three others in what the authorities described as the first Kurdish suicide bombing.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about electronic voting referred incompletely to a decision by the Santa Clara County Board of Supervisors in California to invest $20 million in 5,000 electronic voting machines. While the machines have the ability to produce paper receipts, the county's plan for a pilot receipt program is contingent on state approval and negotiations with the manufacturer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINER, SOL
description: KLEINER-Sol. Of Englewood, NJ on February 25. Former President of Garden State Container Corp. Beloved husband of Helen. Devoted father of Joel and Rhonda Kleiner. Cherished father-in-law of Susan Kleiner. Loving grandfather of Aviva, Reuben, Alizah and Elana. Services Congregation Ahavath Torah, 240 Broad Ave, Englewood, Thursday 10AM. Should friends desire, contributions to the synagogue would be appreciated. For information ''Wien & Wien'', 800-322-0533.

title: Reality TV, and the Real World Beyond
description: To the Editor:

title: Manhunt for bin Laden And Top Aide, Zawahiri, Continues to Be Fruitless
description: For months American troops and covert operatives have combed the rugged outlands of eastern Afghanistan and western Pakistan in search of Osama bin Laden and his principal deputy, Ayman al-Zawahiri.

title: South Korean President Names Cabinet and Faces New Challenge
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 27  President Roh Moo Hyun today named his first cabinet, a mix of inexperienced and veteran officials, and faced his first major challenge in the form of claims by Washington that North Korea had restarted the nuclear reactor at its complex north of Pyongyang.

title: THE FORMER PHILIP MORRIS TO BUY ITS OWN STOCK BACK
description: The Altria Group, the world's biggest cigarette maker, will buy back as much as $3 billion in stock over the next 12 months after losing more than a quarter of its market value over the last year. The company, which makes Marlboro and Virginia Slims, will be able to buy back 78.8 million shares based on yesterday's closing price of $38.05 a share. Altria, which changed its name last month from the Philip Morris Companies, also said it would pay a quarterly dividend of 64 cents a share on April 9 to shareholders of record on March 14. Altria owns Philip Morris International and 84 percent of Kraft Foods.

title: Amtrak's Future
description: After flirting last year with the idea of derailing the nation's passenger railroad, Washington seems to have come to its senses. Thanks largely to the perseverance of senators from both parties, Amtrak fared well in the recent budgetary battles that belatedly allocated federal spending for the current fiscal year. Congress appropriated $1.05 billion for the railroad, 10 percent less than it had asked for, but far more than either the White House or conservative House leaders had sought.

title: Of Rats and Squirrels
description: When the newly elected President Richard Nixon picked a 29-year-old adman to be his press secretary, the press looked on the choice of Ron Ziegler, with no background in journalism or politics, as Nixon's expression of disdain for the media.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Growth Stagnates
description: German economic growth stagnated by the end of last year, leaving full-year growth at only 0.2 percent, the slowest since the 1993 recession. Real gross domestic product in the fourth quarter fell a marginal 0.03 percent from the previous quarter, the German Federal Statistics Office said yesterday. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Archbishop of Canterbury Is Enthroned
description: CANTERBURY, England, Feb. 27  With its narrow lanes, Roman ruins, timbered pubs named for friars and pilgrims and its namesake tales, Canterbury is a place of lasting antiquity. Today it turned its sturdy ancient face to a lively, if less certain, future.

title: Balancing Liberty and Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Balancing Liberty and Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Fred Rogers, Host of 'Mister Rogers' Neighborhood,' Dies at 74
description: Fred Rogers, the thoughtful television neighbor whose songs, stories and heart-to-heart talks taught generations of children how to get along in the world, died yesterday at his home in Pittsburgh. He was 74.

title: U.S. Diplomat Resigns, Protesting 'Our Fervent Pursuit of War'
description: A career diplomat who has served in United States embassies from Tel Aviv to Casablanca to Yerevan resigned this week in protest against the country's policies on Iraq.

title: Club Workers Say Insulation Was Donated
description: Employees of the nightclub where 97 people were killed in a fast-moving fire last week said that the soundproofing foam insulation around the club's stage had been donated in 2000 by a neighbor who worked at a company that sold acoustic insulation and that once lighted the foam rapidly spread the fire throughout the club.

title: Romney's Campus Plan Would Cut Deficit, and a Political Foe
description: Gov. Mitt Romney today proposed to reorganize the University of Massachusetts as part of his plan to cut the state's huge budget deficit. In the process, he would eliminate the $309,000-a-year job of the school's president, William M. Bulger.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Replacement For Ailing Presidential Plane
description: The Irish government approved plans to buy a new airplane for official business, including one larger than its ailing Gulfstream jet, that could cost nearly $90 million. Opposition parties said that the plane should be leased instead, and attacked the decision as frivolous because Ireland's health and educational system have suffered deep budget cuts recently. Prime Minister Bertie Ahern was stranded during two international engagements in January when the 12-year-old Gulfstream broke down just before takeoff. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: National Briefing: Science and Health
description: RISKS IN LIVER TRANSPLANTS Adult liver transplants that use partial organs taken from live people carry a higher-than-expected 1-in-7 chance of serious complications for the donor but a lower risk of death than doctors thought, a study says. The live-donor procedure involves giving the donor's right liver lobe, the larger one, to the transplant recipient. Each lobe grows to the size of a full liver in about six weeks. The first detailed study of the increasingly common operation reported today in the New England Journal of Medicine, found just one donor death in 449 such transplants done in the United States from 1997 through late 2000, but 14 percent of donors had serious complications. (AP)

title: 'Atonement' Wins Book Critics Award
description: ''Atonement,'' Ian McEwan's novel about the destructive powers of the imagination and the lifelong repercussions of a single childhood lie, has won the National Book Critics Circle Award for fiction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTNER, SAURA
description: BARTNER-Saura. February 25, 2003. Teacher of the Alexander Technique. As peaceful dying as she was graceful in life. Loving family and community member. Wife of Dr. Paul Aaron; mother of Shem and Nataw Bartner-Aaron; daughter of Elliot and Thelma Bartner; sister of Jay and Dr. Robert Bartner. Updated funeral, shiva, memorial service and memorial contribution information at www.saurabartner.us Crabiel Parkwest Funeral Chapel, New Brunswick, NJ 08901.

title: Perky, Blond and as Inescapable as Paying the Fare
description: TRUST someone to find a way to intrude on one of the few places left in New York where you can have an intellectual discussion with a stranger behind the wheel, and you get the idea behind putting televisions in taxis.

title: G.E. TO BUY BRITISH INSTRUMENT UNIT FOR $4.74 MILLION
description: The General Electric Company, which began selling electronic sensors last year, plans to buy the pressure-measurement and calibration unit of Hill & Smith Holdings of England for 3 million ($4.74 million). Hill & Smith's SI Pressure Instruments unit makes sensors for companies like automakers and utilities, G.E. said. The acquisition will be folded into Druck Holdings, a sensor maker bought last year by GE Industrial Systems. The purchase is expected to close by the end of June.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: MANHATTAN

title: From a White House Roof, Solar Power Proclaims Gains
description: THE White House may be occupied by an administration steeped in the oil industry, but solar power has quietly become part of the landscape at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue.

title: Libeskind Design Chosen for Rebuilding at Ground Zero
description: An open pit, the crucible where the fires burned for weeks after Sept. 11, 2001, and the ground that held most of the bodies of the dead, will stand as the centerpiece of the city's effort to memorialize and rebuild after the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center, under a decision made by city and state officials last night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOSK, JEANNETTE S.
description: VOSK-Jeannette S. Age 94, died February 26, 2003 at her home in Williamsport, PA. For many years, she was the school psychologist for the Board of Education in New York City. She is survived by her son, Dr. Arno D. Vosk, and two grandchildren.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Conviction Upheld In Jurez Killing
description: A state court upheld the conviction of an Egyptian citizen for the 1995 murder of a woman in the border city of Ciudad Jurez. The ruling against the defendant, Abdel Latif Sharif, who has been jailed since 1995, came on the tenth anniversary of the first of a series of killings of women in Jurez. Both the prosecution and the defense said they were planning to appeal. Nearly 300 women have been killed -- three more bodies were discovered last week -- and human-rights groups and some police officials say at least 87 of those killings are linked by evidence to the same killer or killers. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: Senator Named to Delaware River Authority
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey today named a Republican state senator, John J. Matheussen, to lead the Delaware River Port Authority, removing a popular Republican from the evenly divided Senate.

title: South Korea's New President Gets His Choice for Prime Minister
description: Roh Moo Hyun, South Korea's new president, spent his first full day in office today using his persuasive skills, winning support for his choice of prime minister from the opposition lawmakers who dominate the National Assembly.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Videotape Of Trampling Is Barred
description: A judge has ruled that a 60-minute security videotape of the E2 nightclub where 21 people were trampled this month was too graphic to release. Judge Daniel J. Lynch issued an emergency order barring the tape's release after city attorneys said it would be too disturbing for family members to see. The court restricted the dissemination of the tape to those people involved in litigation. Court records say that the tape shows pictures of the deceased and injured. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Acevedo's Good Stuff Might Not Be Enough
description: Call it collusion. Call it a market correction. Juan Acevedo has his private suspicions. Whatever it was that chilled the free-agent market this winter, he got caught in the middle of it.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: MORE CASH FOR CAR VENTURE Louis Schweitzer, chairman of Renault, told reporters in Moscow that the company would invest $250 million to expand Avtoframos, its car-assembly joint venture with the Moscow city government, and finance development of a new model, the X90. Avtoframos's output is now just 10 cars a day, all Symbol economy sedans. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Borobudur Journal; Buddhist Monument and Mall: Will Twain Meet?
description: The ancient carved stone terraces of the Borobudur monument rise out of the plain of central Java like a grand wedding cake trimmed with hundreds of Buddha statues.

title: Eve Stillman, 97; Owned Lingerie Company
description: Eve Stillman, a retired lingerie designer who also owned and led the lingerie company that bore her name, died on Friday at her home in Palm Beach, Fla. She was 97.

title: Balancing Liberty and Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONTGOMERY, ELIZABETH GRANT
description: MONTGOMERY - Elizabeth Grant. Age 93, of Canaan, CT and North Haven, ME, on February 22 in Canaan. Wife of the late Robert Montgomery; mother of Anne Harkness Mooney; grandmother of John, Anne, Elizabeth, David, Allan, and William; and greatgrandmother of eight. Services to be private.

title: KANSAS ENERGY COMPANY TO SELL ALL UNITS EXCEPT UTILITY
description: Westar Energy, owner of the biggest utility in Kansas, will sell all its other businesses by the end of 2004, undoing an expansion engineered by the previous chief executive, David Wittig, that increased debt and sent share prices into decline. The company, which owns security businesses and 27 percent of Oneok, a distributor of natural gas, would become a holding company with a utility subsidiary, said James Haines, who became chief executive after Mr. Wittig was indicted in November on bank fraud charges. He resigned after leading the company, based in Topeka, into energy-trading and securities businesses, and two unsuccessful mergers over four years.

title: Forget Borneo; Head for the Bronx
description: IF you can't afford to fly to Hawaii, Costa Rica or Moorea this weekend, you could take a train to the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx and plunge into a cloud forest -- full of thousands of orchids blooming among the tree ferns and palms.

title: Excerpts From NASA E-Mail Messages About Space Shuttle Before Crash
description: Following are excerpts from e-mail messages exchanged among engineers during the shuttle Columbia's flight. They were released by the space agency yesterday in response to requests under the Freedom of Information Act.

title: Analyst Coached WorldCom Chief on His Script
description: As shares of WorldCom were falling on rumbles of a pending financial crisis a year ago, the company's founder, Bernard J. Ebbers, took to the microphone in a conference call with Wall Street analysts and swatted down rumors about the company's problems.

title: A Call to Guitars As War Looms
description: The first time Barbara Dane recalls performing was at a demonstration outside a segregated restaurant in Detroit, her hometown, in the 1940's. In the 50's she sang for civil rights and workers' rights. In the 60's she sang in North and South Vietnam during the war, was one of the first American musicians to tour post-revolutionary Cuba and performed at clandestine meetings of soldiers resisting the war.

title: Instead of ID, They Show Badges; Infusion of Young Officers Helps to Tame Tough Areas
description: On a Friday night in Manhattan, with the temperature dropping and the lights of Times Square blurred by drizzle, 52 young people fanned out on the streets of Midtown, looking for trouble.

title: National Briefing | Washington: House Approves Redesign Of Nickel
description: The House passed legislation approving a temporary three-year commemorative redesign of the nickel. The bill would allow the United States Mint to change the image on the back of the coin to celebrate the bicentennial of the Louisiana Purchase and the Lewis and Clark expedition. But Thomas Jefferson's home, Monticello, will return to its place on the coin in 2006. Last year, the mint suggested that it alter the design of the nickel, among changes to other coins. The Jefferson nickel has been around since 1938. Representative Eric Cantor, Republican of Virginia, sponsored the measure, which will now go to the Senate.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: More Cash For Car Venture
description: Louis Schweitzer, chairman of Renault, told reporters in Moscow that the company would invest $250 million to expand Avtoframos, its car-assembly joint venture with the Moscow city government, and finance development of a new model, the X90. Avtoframos's output is now just 10 cars a day, all Symbol economy sedans. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Leniency Urged For Convicted Politician
description: Lawyers for a convicted former City Council member from Brooklyn argued yesterday for a reduced sentence, saying that his conduct was a ''brief meander'' in illegality and that he was suffering nearly disabling remorse. The former councilman, Angel Rodriguez, pleaded guilty in August to voting in favor of a supermarket project in exchange for $50,000 and a lucrative real estate deal. In court papers, a psychiatrist who has treated Mr. Rodriguez said he was depressed and sleepless and was engaging in ''almost daily drinking'' of alcohol. Under sentencing guidelines, Mr. Rodriguez faces 46 to 57 months in prison. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: Manager Says Club Outsold Its Capacity Several Times
description: The nightclub that burned to the ground here last week, killing 97 people, often sold tickets for concerts far in excess of its legal capacity of about 300 people, a manager for several bands that played at the club said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPPERT, FELICE
description: LIPPERT-Felice. She was the epitome of a cosmopolitan woman. Her love, laughter, kindess and warmth will always be remembered. Our deepest sympathy to her children and grandchildren. Priscilla, Sol, Jordan and Jill

title: Court Appeal Puts Off Raise For Poor Clients' Lawyers
description: Higher fees for lawyers who represent the poor were put off yesterday after the city appealed a court ruling that declared its system for compensating the lawyers unconstitutional.

title: Trousdale Is Back
description: Welcome to swingin' Trousdale, home of ring-a-ding-ding.

title: A Choice of Voice
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Albert R. Hibbs, 78, Scientist And Voice of NASA Missions
description: Albert R. Hibbs, a veteran space scientist who helped build the United States' first Earth orbiter then was the popular voice of NASA missions to the planets, died on Monday in Pasadena, Calif. He was 78.

title: California Ending Use of Minor Traffic Stops as Search Pretext
description: The California Highway Patrol agreed to stop using minor traffic violations as a pretext for searching cars for drugs under a settlement of a racial-profiling lawsuit announced today.

title: U.S. to Impose New Restrictions on Dietary Supplement
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  The federal government announced steps today to crack down on ephedra, the dietary supplement linked to many injuries and deaths.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAF, JOYCE
description: GRAF-Joyce. Devoted wife of Herman. Loving mother of the late Suzanne. Dearest sister of Ruth Spielsinger. Cherished grandmother of Jeremy Seth Haruvi. Services Sunday 12 noon ''Parkside Chapel'', Queens Boulevard at 66th Ave. Forest Hills, NY.

title: The Trend To 'Naked' Lures Back Ex-Bikers
description: MORE than 20 years after he had owned his last motorcycle, a 1973 Kawasaki Z-1, Don Green figured that the bike-riding itch of his younger days had been thoroughly scratched.

title: Judith Schaechter -- 'Extra Virgin'
description: Claire Oliver Fine Art

title: Reinsurer Offering Raises $221 Million
description: Endurance Specialty Holdings, a Bermuda-based reinsurer, raised $220.8 million, as much as 15 percent less than planned, in only the third initial public offering in the United States this year.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Japanese Computer Shipments Decline
description: Domestic shipments of personal computers fell for the second consecutive year in 2002, the first back-to-back declines since 1984, Gartner Japan Dataquest said yesterday. Computer makers shipped 11.5 million units, a 10.4 percent slide after a 2.8 percent decrease in 2001. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Trying to Regain A Sense of Normalcy
description: The tingling began in Todd MacCulloch's feet during training camp. Foot problems were nothing new for him or for many players in the National Basketball Association. He tried orthotic supports in his sneakers, but the tingling became a bothersome throb, forcing him to remove his shoes hastily after each practice.

description: THE KING IN THE TREE

title: Smith Era Ends in Dallas; Giants Re-Sign Petitgout
description: Emmitt Smith still believes he can play football and he wants to reach 20,000 yards, but he won't achieve that goal with the Dallas Cowboys.

title: Diocese Resists Releasing Names of Accused Priests
description: When a grand jury looking into sexual abuse by members of the Catholic clergy finished its work in December, it reported that it had uncovered accusations against 145 priests.

title: Appeals Court Reinstates Ban on 'Under God' in Pledge
description: Over the vehement objections of 9 of its 24 active judges, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, essentially let stand today a decision that the phrase "under God" in the Pledge of Allegiance is unconstitutional.
