description: Daredevil

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about a plan by the IDT Corporation to try to buy the Global Crossing telecommunications company out of bankruptcy misstated the outcome of an IDT attempt to acquire the assets of another company, Teligent, in 2001. That deal was rejected by Teligent's creditors; the company remains independent.

title: Air Force Chief Urges Cadets To Weed Out the Predatory
description: After a fervent speech on character in which he challenged Air Force Academy cadets to weed out those who would sexually prey upon women in their ranks, Air Force Secretary James G. Roche said tonight that the protocols put in place a decade ago to prevent such attacks had failed and needed to be replaced.

title: Family Resorts: Part Idyll, Part Survival Test
description: AT 5 p.m. the day after Christmas, my family arrived at the Grand Wailea Hotel on Maui, bleary-eyed from flying to Hawaii, halfway around the world from our home in Connecticut. Outside, white-uniformed porters scurried around with overloaded trolleys of luggage; inside, the gleaming marble lobby was teeming with people. While waiting to check in, we noticed a curious phenomenon: everyone, staff members and guests alike, seemed to be carrying walkie-talkies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELBART, JUNE
description: GELBART-June. I will miss you, friend of half a century; your warmth, your quirky humor, your culinary advice, your presence. Alan and I send condolences to Brad, Robin, Philicia and all the family. Simone Hartman

title: Kathleen Edwards
description: Village Underground

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Convictions In Christian-Muslim Violence
description: A court in southern Egypt convicted two Muslims on murder charges stemming from two days of clashes between Coptic Christians and Muslims that left 20 Christians and a Muslim dead in January 2000. The court acquitted 96 others, 38 of them Copts. The violence, which erupted in Kusheh after an argument between a Coptic shopkeeper and a Muslim customer, was the worst inter-religious conflict in years. Coptic Christians make up an estimated 6 to 10 percent of Egypt's 69 million people.

title: Keeping Business in the Family
description: When the board of Rogers Communications met here earlier this month to choose a new head for its flagship cable television unit, the company's founder and chief executive, Edward S. Rogers, left the room. So did two other directors -- Loretta Rogers, his wife, and Edward S. Rogers Jr., his son.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESSEGUIER, OLGA W.
description: RESSEGUIER-Olga W. Born in Vienna, Austria, November 16, 1915. Wife of Clemens Resseguier. Mother of John H. Wyman and Virginia W. Meyer. Loving grandmother of Christina, Charles, Edward and Katharine. Predeceased by her first husband, Charles A. Wyman and son Thomas. Contributions may be made to World Wildlife Foundation, 1250 24th Street, N.W. Washington, D.C. 20037, or Panwy Foundation, 9 Greenwich Office Park, Greenwich, CT 06831. A memorial gathering will be held for family and friends at a future date.

title: Swiss Machinery Maker Posts Wider Loss
description: ABB, the troubled Swiss maker of machinery, reported a loss of $787 million today for 2002. The loss widened from $691 million in 2001 and was much steeper than forecasts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, DR. MARTIN W.
description: ABRAMS-Dr. Martin W. Age 76, passed away on February 26, 2003. He was the beloved husband of Marie and the cherished father of Danal and his wife Wendy, Seth, David Frankel and his wife Ann, Barbara Frankel, Steven Frankel and his wife Kathy, and Richard Frankel and his wife Mary Jo. He was also the adored grandfather of Madeline, Graham, Max, Alan, David, Adam, Sarah and Brian and the loving brother of Beverly Castor and the late Evelyn Cutler. His long and distinguished career as a pediatric surgeon was highlighted by: Co-Founder of Schneider Children's Hospital at Long Island Jewish Medical Center; staff at Long Island Jewish Medical Center and North Shore Hospital for over 40 years; Chief of Pediatric Surgery at Brooklyn Hospital; staff appointments at numerous other hospitals, including Booth Memorial, Catholic Medical Centers (Mary Immaculate, St. John's Queens and St. Mary's), Mercy and the Nassau County Medical Center; Assistant Professor of Medicine at S.U.N.Y.-Stony Brook; Clinical Instructor of Surgery at Albert Einstein College of Medicine and S.U.N.Y College of Medicine; Fellow of American College of Surgeons, American Academy of Pediatrics and Pediatric Surgical Association. He also served in the Army Medical Corps from 1944-1945 and was Second Lieutenant, Military Intelligence (USAR) from 1946-1951. For all of this and more, Dr. Martin W. Abrams will be terribly missed by his loving family and those he touched during his full and meaningful life. Funeral Service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. today at 1:30 PM. Donations in memory of Dr. Martin W. Abrams should be made to the Child Life Program of the Schneider Children's Hospital of Long Island Jewish Medical Center.

title: East and West Embrace
description: To the Editor:

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums, children under 12 and museum members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Troops Called Out For Carnival
description: The violence that swept Rio de Janeiro just days before Carnival has prompted the government to send 3,000 troops to join nearly 30,000 police officers in protecting the hordes of tourists arriving for the four-day bacchanalia, which starts tomorrow. In another security measure, officials transferred from a Rio prison to one in So Paulo the drug lord believed to be behind the violence, Luiz Fernando da Costa. Mery Galanternick (NYT)

title: Sharon's New Government Increases Pressure on Arafat
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's new right-wing government won parliamentary approval early today, and he declared that peace negotiations with the Palestinians would not resume until the violence stops and the current Palestinian leadership is replaced.

title: Hopes Ebbing for Scottish Parliament
description: If there is one uncomplicated symbol of the public stumbles taken by the Scottish Parliament in its first four years, it is ''Follywood,'' the derisive name given to the grandiose, unfinished building that will one day house Parliament on a stretch of mile called Holyrood.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Peace Effort Slogs On
description: Prime Minister Bertie Ahern of Ireland met with Prime Minister Tony Blair at 10 Downing Street in London to prepare for talks in Belfast on Monday on the stagnated Northern Ireland peace effort. The province's five-year-old home-rule government was suspended in October because of disagreement between Roman Catholic and Protestant political parties on issues like the disarmament of paramilitaries and the reform of the police force. ''We can't sit around forever,'' Mr. Ahern said, calling Monday an important day. ''I really think it is time to come to an agreement.'' He announced a $3.2 million compensation fund for people in the Irish Republic affected by violence during the 30-year conflict.

title: MESA AIR AGREES TO OPERATE SOME ROUTES FOR UAL
description: UAL, the parent company of United Airlines, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the Mesa Air Group for Mesa Air to operate as a United Express carrier. A definitive contract should be reached in the next several weeks, the companies said. Mesa Air will operate regional service in medium-size cities that will primarily feed passengers into United's Denver hub. The operation is expected to start in July, but United declined to say what cities will be served or how frequently the flights will run. Mesa is taking over some routes from Air Wisconsin, another United Express carrier, but Air Wisconsin will continue to operate elsewhere in the United Express system. Edward Wong (NYT)

title: The Homeless Census
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A report in the World Business Briefing column on Wednesday about job reductions at Swiss International Air Lines misstated the month the company began operation. It was last April, not June.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, RANDOLPH
description: GOODMAN - Randolph, 94. Retired professor Brooklyn College, author, graduate of NYU, Yale, Columbia. Devoted to teaching, community, friends and family. Service Sunday, March 2, 2003, 11:15AM ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Reduced Space Station Crew Is Likely, NASA Chief Says
description: A shortage of water and other necessities created by the grounding of the space shuttle fleet will force NASA to replace the three crew members on the International Space Station with rotating two-member crews by early May, officials said today.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Insurer Posts Gain
description: France's largest insurer, AXA, posted an 82 percent rise in profit for 2002 after write-downs, but said that it would cut its dividend to increase capital. Earnings were 949 million euros ($1.02 billion), compared with 520 million euros in 2001, when the company took charges related to Sept. 11. AXA said it would reduce its dividend, to 0.34 euro from 0.56 euro a share. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEDERMAN, ABRAHAM
description: LEDERMAN-Abraham. Of Silver Springs, MD. Beloved husband of Helen (nee Spiegel). Devoted father of Gloria Santiago, Susan Cohen and Marilyn Goldman. Dear father-in-law of Joe Santiago, Peter Cohen and Martin Goldman. Loving grandfather of seven grandchildren and one great granddaughter. Services were held. Shiva at the home of Susan and Peter Cohen in Rockville, MD, Sunday through Tuesday. Contributions to the U.S. Holocaust Museum, Washington, DC. For information: ''Wien & Wien'' 800-322-0533.

title: House Votes to Ban All Human Cloning
description: Warning that human cloning amounted to a dark and dangerous step into an unethical realm of science, the House of Representatives voted today to ban all human-cloning experiments, whether for baby-making or to create cells that might be used to treat disease.

title: Mayor Denies That He Knew Of Corruption In Bridgeport
description: The way the mayor of Bridgeport told it today, just about every witness but him has lied at his corruption trial.

title: Wandering, All Right, but on Harleys; Jewish Bikers Band Together to Enjoy the Company and Their Cycles
description: Their T-shirt motto? ''My hog is kosher.'' Their slogan? ''We're loud, we're proud, we're Hebrew.'' But relax already. The members of the Star of Davidson Motorcycle Club will not be rattling windows here as March roars in like a lion.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Vetoes School-Report Bill
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg vetoed a bill yesterday that would give the City Council frequent progress reports on all school construction projects. In his veto message, Mr. Bloomberg said the bill would have created an unnecessary administrative burden. Eva S. Moskowitz, chairwoman of the Council's education committee, said the Council would hold an override vote. The legislation would have required the Department of Education to submit quarterly reports to the Council, updating the status and anticipated cost of all its capital projects. Council members have called for stricter oversight of capital planning and spending since August 2001, when education officials disclosed a shortfall of nearly $3 billion in the $7 billion, five-year school construction budget. Abby Goodnough (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLAPINGER, ALICE EINSTEIN
description: PLAPINGER-Alice Einstein of Washington, D.C., on February 22, 2003. She is survived by her husband of almost 53 years Jerome S. Plapinger; her son William A. Plapinger and his wife Kathleen J. Murray and their children Alexander, Elizabeth and Thomas; her daughter Elizabeth Schaap Plapinger and her husband John L. Berger and their children William and Chloe; and her sister Barbara Asch. Memorial services were held in private. Contributions in her memory may be made to Sibley Memorial Hospital Cancer Support Groups, 5255 Loughboro Road, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20016-2695.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: And the Award Goes to . . .

title: PFIZER'S BID FOR PHARMACIA ADVANCES IN EUROPE
description: The European Commission gave conditional approval yesterday to Pfizer's takeover of Pharmacia, a rival drug company. The companies agreed to sell some of their Viagra-type drugs in development and a urinary incontinence product called darifenacin. They also agreed to sell or license Ketensin, a hypertension drug, in the Netherlands and divest themselves of an animal penicillin drug in Germany to obtain regulatory approval in Europe, the commission said. The companies still need regulatory approval in the United States. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: African Stowaway Falls From Plane
description: An African man was killed this week when he fell from the landing gear cavity of a plane that was about to land at Charles de Gaulle airport near Paris. The man, who the police said was about 20 to 25 years old and had no identification papers, was discovered by the owner of a suburban home in Groslay, north of Paris, and probably fell from a flight arriving from Mali or Gabon in Central Africa. The police said that each year there are two to three similar deaths of people seeking to enter France illegally. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Revising Mandatory Minimums
description: The state will release at least 280 drug offenders under a new law eliminating mandatory minimum sentences, the Department of Corrections said. Gone under the new sentencing guidelines are a 10-year minimum for offenses involving 50 to 224 grams of a controlled substance and a 20-year minimum for amounts over 225 grams. The statute applies retroactively, and 700 inmates are eligible to have their sentences halved by the parole board. Anand Giridharadas (NYT)

title: One Budget Gap Solved, Then On to the Next
description: Barely 12 hours after Gov. John G. Rowland and Connecticut lawmakers made peace on a deal to fill a $650 million hole in this year's budget, the furor over the state's fiscal woes resumed today as state officials began looking ahead to wrestling with an even bigger deficit next year.

title: Coming Soon to Meadowlands: Condos, Hotel and Golfing
description: The New Jersey Meadowlands Commission has approved a plan to transform 1,350 acres of smelly former landfill into a huge development featuring four golf courses surrounded by a resort hotel, commercial space and a residential village.

title: NASA Is Asked to Drop Officials From Inquiry
description: The independent board overseeing the investigation of the Columbia disaster has asked the NASA administrator to reassign some NASA personnel involved in the inquiry because their participation raises questions of conflict of interest, Congressional aides and others involved in the investigation said today.

title: REGULATOR SEEKS DETAILS OF EL PASO'S BORROWING PLAN
description: The El Paso Corporation has been asked by federal regulators to provide details of a plan to sell assets and borrow against two units as the company raises cash for debt reduction. In a request for information, the regulator, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, said it was concerned that the company's Southern Natural Gas and ANR Pipeline units might become saddled with the debt of their parent. El Paso said on Tuesday that it had received a $1 billion loan to retire debt coming due next month and would sell $700 million in notes to raise cash. The company, which has $25 billion in debt, also agreed to sell natural gas reserves to Chesapeake Energy.

title: Omnicom Debt Is Downgraded
description: Moody's Investors Service has downgraded its rating on the senior unsecured debt of the Omnicom Group in New York by one notch, to three notches above junk status.

title: To Be the Fastest Car on the Road
description: REEVES CALLAWAY builds one of the fastest and most exclusive cars in the world, the 188-mile-per-hour Callaway C12. Never seen one? It's not surprising; only 26 of them exist.

title: Graham Files, Becoming 9th Democrat In '04 Race
description: Senator Bob Graham of Florida, popular former governor of a crucial electoral state and a prominent critic of President Bush's priorities in the war on terrorism, filed papers today that will allow him to raise money to seek the Democratic presidential nomination.

title: Judge Approves Laidlaw's Plan to Emerge From Bankruptcy
description: Laidlaw Inc., the owner of Greyhound Lines Inc., won a federal judge's approval of its bankruptcy recovery plan today, clearing the way for it to come out of Chapter 11.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 18 about attempts to ride a sled on the Brooklyn Bridge walkway during the recent blizzard misstated some of the bridge's measurements. The vertical drop from the bases of the towers to the low points on shore is about 84 feet on the Manhattan side and 61 feet on the Brooklyn side, not 130 feet on each side. The average grade of the walkway is slightly less than 4 percent, not 6 percent.

title: 'IN PRINCIPLE,' IRAQ AGREES TO DESTROY FORBIDDEN MISSILES
description: As the Security Council argued bitterly over whether to go to war with Iraq, the government of Saddam Hussein said today that it had agreed ''in principle'' to begin destroying ballistic missiles judged illegal because their range exceeds limits imposed after the Persian Gulf war.

title: Burlington Industries Bid Stalls
description: A bid by Berkshire Hathaway, the investment company led by Warren E. Buffett, to pay $579 million for the textile maker Burlington Industries stalled today when a federal judge rejected sales procedures that favored Berkshire.

title: 'Chicago' and the Future Of the Movie Musical
description: I am one of that deprived band who wished and hoped for the return of the movie musical, knowing that the mass marketeers of Hollywood had no interest in us.

title: Men Navigating Subplots While Shooting Pool
description: ''I'm going outside to get some smog.'' This line is delivered off screen, but there is no mistaking the speaker. It is Christopher Walken, who ambles into the frantically overplotted ''Poolhall Junkies,'' as he has in so many other mediocre movies lately, with his game face on and his reedy voice in perfect tune. Wandering out onto a balcony during a fancy soire, Mr. Walken encounters Mars Callahan, the movie's writer and director as well as its star, and, noticing the younger man's skillet-shaped face and gravity-defying hair, asks, ''Are we related?''

title: `Stacked'; John Tremblay; `African-American Art: 20th-Century Masterworks X'
description: `Stacked'

title: Terrorism Alert Level Is Lowered a Notch
description: The Bush administration lowered the nation's terrorism alert level to yellow, or ''elevated risk,'' but warned of a continuing threat.

title: Sam Gordon, Mamie Hoist, Jason Fox
description: Feature Inc.

title: NORTHLAND MAKES BID FOR PARTS OF OCEAN SPRAY
description: Northland Cranberries, the maker of Seneca juices, said yesterday that it had offered to buy the juice business and the brand name of Ocean Spray Cranberries for $800 million. Northland's chief executive, John Swendrowski, said that the company had not heard back from Ocean Spray, a marketing cooperative owned by about 900 growers that is the world's largest cranberry producer. The offer was made on Friday, he said. Northland would license back the Ocean Spray name to Ocean Spray for its use on products like cranberry sauce and Craisins, a sweetened dried cranberry, he said.

title: Pentagon Contradicts General On Iraq Occupation Force's Size
description: In a contentious exchange over the costs of war with Iraq, the Pentagon's second-ranking official today disparaged a top Army general's assessment of the number of troops needed to secure postwar Iraq. House Democrats then accused the Pentagon official, Paul D. Wolfowitz, of concealing internal administration estimates on the cost of fighting and rebuilding the country.

title: Gays Criticize Mayor's Decision to March in St. Patrick's Parade
description: A group of gay elected officials and community organizers yesterday criticized Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's decision to march in the St. Patrick's Day Parade this year. They said that because gays are forbidden to march under their own banner, the mayor should shun the parade, much as he did the Columbus Day Parade when its organizers refused to let him bring television stars from ''The Sopranos.''

title: Transit Agency Is Criticized on Van Service for the Disabled
description: The chairman of a committee that oversees the city's subways and buses angrily accused New York City Transit yesterday of failing to address the poor service and longstanding cost overruns of a van system used to transport thousands of disabled passengers around the city.

title: Miscellany
description: * Avenue A Inc., Seattle, was renamed aQuantive Inc., to differentiate the agency company from an agency it operates, Avenue A.

title: White House Reports a Decline in Colombia's Coca Cultivation
description: With aggressive aerial spraying in the past year, antidrug forces in Colombia for the first time have reduced the amount of coca being cultivated in the Andean country, Bush administration officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, BARRY M.
description: DAVIS-Barry M., 56. Of Manhattan, Southampton and Aventura, FL. Amazing husband of Janet, adoring father of Joanna. You are a part of our hearts and souls; what a gift you have been to us!

title: New York Remains at Level Orange
description: The rest of the country may be downshifting from orange to yellow, but New York City's level of vigilance against terrorist attacks will not change, police officials said yesterday.

title: Residential Real Estate; Few Sellers Take the Chance of Filing Disclosure
description: To disclose or not to disclose; that is the question: whether 'tis nobler to complete the form, suffer possible litigation and expose one's fortune, or keepeth quiet and forfeit the $500.

title: Filipinos Awaiting U.S. Troops With Skepticism
description: Sometimes, when they are reciting their times tables, the children at the little rural school here are interrupted by the bang of the howitzers planted in a row outside their windows.

title: Immigrants on the Run
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, VERA
description: LEVINE-Vera, 79. Of No. Palm Beach, Florida, late of Hewlett, Long Island, died on February 24, 2003. Beloved wife of Henry I. Levine, loving mother of Joel and Roger Levine and Louise Webber, devoted grandmother of Annie Levine and dear sister of Harriet Schnur. Memorial to be held at Riverside-Gordon Memorial Chapel, 4714 Okeechobee Blvd. WPB on Sunday, March 2 at 2PM. Shiva will be observed after the ceremony at the apartment of Harriet Schnur, and at her New York home from Tuesday through Thursday, with services at 7:30 PM. The Levine children will sit Shiva March 5th from 5-10 P.M. at the Webber residence. A New York area memorial will be scheduled at a later date. In lieu of flowers, the family is requesting that donations be made in memory of Vera F. Levine to Brandeis University National Women's Committee, C/O Barbara Silberman, 140 Isle Dr., Palm Beach Gardens, FL. 33418.

title: 'African-American Art: 20th-Century Masterworks X'
description: Michael Rosenfeld Gallery

title: The Seats Of Power
description: At Snug Harbor on Staten Island, 16th- and 17th-century Dutch and English decorative art from George Way's collection is on view, including this oak side chair from the show's Charles II room.

title: Bush Would Offer Drug Plan To Elderly Within Medicare
description: The Bush administration told Congressional Republicans today that it had come up with a new plan to provide prescription drug benefits to the elderly through Medicare, administration officials and lawmakers said.

title: Sprewell Drives And Is Stopped
description: The Knicks' Latrell Sprewell was arrested yesterday morning at a Midtown security checkpoint and charged with driving with a suspended license, the police said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Garden City: Nassau Lawmakers Approve New Districts
description: The Nassau County Legislature, voting along party lines late last night, adopted new legislative district lines. The 10 Democrats, who hope to expand their slim one-vote majority, voted yes and the 9 Republicans voted no. The legislative map, which is subject to court approval, applies to the election in November. Although there are more Republican voters than Democratic voters in Nassau, the Democrats won control in 1999 in a rebellion against what critics called fiscal mismanagement. Democrats say that the old legislative lines concentrated their voters into a few districts and gave Republicans a wide margin in the rest, while the new lines would give Democrats a better chance to win one or two more seats. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: Weekender | Westport, Conn.
description: AT a recent meeting of the Westport Representative Town Meeting, the local governing body, two members put forth a resolution on Iraq: ''Let the United Nations work it out and exhaust diplomatic and economic means to avoid war.'' Meanwhile, another member and some townspeople asked for a review of the regulations about the gamboling rights of dogs without leashes on Compo Beach.

title: Gypsies in Slovakia Complain of Sterilizations
description: The morning after Zita, a young Gypsy mother, gave birth to her second child at age 17, a nurse shoved a piece of paper in front of her. Zita, who is illiterate, says she marked three crosses on the paper, and thus unwittingly agreed to be sterilized.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: AUTO EXPORTS GAIN Exports of Japanese vehicles increased 16.8 percent in January from a year earlier as carmakers supplemented onshore production in North America and Europe. Auto exports, which hit a nine-year high in 2002, have risen for 13 consecutive months. Shipments by Toyota Motor , Honda Motor and Mitsubishi all rose more than 25 percent in January.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, NATHAN
description: ROSENBERG - Nathan, 93. Beloved uncle of Mark and Beryl Slater and Eileen Slater. Great-uncle of Audrey Slater Spiegel and Bill Spiegel, Cynthia and Brian Fink, Amanda Slater, Nanci and Gary Farrell, Mathew and Stephanie Slater. He will be greatly missed. For information call Boulevard Riverside Chapels, 516-295-3100.

title: Seeded 60th, the Only Thing Sutherland Does Is Win
description: When Kevin Sutherland won the Accenture Match Play Championship last year, it was a shocking development, the first career victory for the player seeded 62nd in the 64-player field.

title: Sharing a Dirty Little Secret
description: WHAT religion is to some, fine washables are to me: a source of guilt (that pile -- when will I get to it?), redemption (clean clothes are the fashion equivalent of confession), and faith (lipstick, chocolate and pinot have no sway over me).

title: Telling All, Wells Book May Upset Teammates
description: David Wells will start for the Yankees in an exhibition game Friday, but the focus might not be on his pitching. Wells is a budding author, and he will need to explain some spicy comments about his teammates.

title: Labor, Breaking Tradition, Criticizes War Preparations
description: After backing administrations in the Korean, Vietnam and Persian Gulf wars, the labor movement departed today from tradition and criticized President Bush's approach to a conflict with Iraq.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Telecom Loss
description: The Spanish telecommunications company Telefnica reported a record loss of 5.6 billion euros ($6 billion) for 2002 after heavy write-downs by its cellphone and Internet divisions, but the clearing of accounts and debt-cutting should help future growth. Operating profit fell 8 percent, to 11.72 billion euros, compared with 2001, when net profit was 2.11 billion euros, while sales fell 8.5 percent to 28.41 billion euros. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: Hussein Grabs a Top Sweeps-Month Rating in His Network Prime-Time Debut
description: Saddam Hussein drew 18 million viewers to CBS on Wednesday night, far outdoing other heatedly promoted interviews with Robert Chambers, ''the Preppy murderer,'' and Robert Blake, the actor and accused wife killer. That alone suggested that Americans are finally focusing on the imminent prospect of war.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Growth Despite Turmoil
description: Shrugging off rising interest rates and market turmoil, Brazil's economy grew more than 3.4 percent in the last quarter of 2002, bringing annual growth to 1.52 percent. The country's currency, the real, fell by 35 percent against the dollar, helping the agribusiness sector surge by 5.8 percent over 2002, while industry grew 1.52 percent. The year was one of political uncertainty ahead of elections in October in which Luiz Incio Lula da Silva was elected president. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO WEAKENS. The dollar pared losses against the euro as unexpectedly strong durable goods data for America outweighed concerns over Iraq. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0763, from $1.0791 on Wednesday

title: Record Number Sought Asylum in Britain in 2002
description: LONDON, Feb. 28  A record 110,700 people sought asylum in Britain last year, a number that is expected to inflame concerns over the country's immigration policy and increase pressure on the government to act swiftly to stem the flow.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: New President Names Cabinet
description: President Roh Moo Hyun, who took office this week, named a professor at Seoul National University, Yoon Young Kwan, foreign minister as he appointed his cabinet. Mr. Yoon is expected to try to translate Mr. Roh's desire for a ''more reciprocal and equitable relationship'' with the United States into an independent stance on North Korea. Cho Young Kil was named defense minister with the mission of mapping out new strategies for South Korean forces if the United States pulls some of its troops from the invasion route to Seoul.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bank Official Selected
description: The British government appointed Rachel Lomax, a top civil servant, economist and former World Bank official, to succeed Mervyn A. King as deputy governor of the Bank of England when Mr. King takes over from Sir Edward George as governor later this year. Ms. Lomax is the most senior official at the transportation department. Her appointment will make her the highest-ranking woman in the bank's history, a spokesman for the Bank of England said. The government also announced that Richard Lambert, former editor of The Financial Times, would join the Monetary Policy Committee, which sets interest rates, in June. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: A Salesman for Bush's Tax Plan Who Has Belittled Similar Ideas
description: In nominating a respected Harvard economist as one of his top advisers, President Bush has now replaced nearly everyone from his original economic team with people who at one time spoke out against the kinds of policies Mr. Bush is prescribing.

title: World Briefing: Middle East
description: QATAR: JORDANIAN JOURNALIST FACES EXECUTION An appeals court has upheld a death sentence against a Jordanian journalist convicted of spying for Jordan, Al Jazeera television reported. Firas Majali was arrested in January 2002 on charges including military espionage. Qatar said he had provided Jordan with information on the status of American troops in Qatar, along with economic and social data. His death sentence, imposed by a lower court in October, provoked street protests in Jordan. (Reuters)

title: Microsoft Settles an Antitrust Complaint Filed by Taiwan
description: Microsoft has settled an antitrust complaint filed by the Taiwan Fair Trade Commission, but the sides differ on how much the company has actually conceded.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: The Seats of Power (The Beds, Too)
description: It was probably the very day furniture was invented that seating order became a measure of social status. Today it's about being to the left or right of the host, at the head table, in the front row. In Tudor England it wasn't about where but on what. Only the man of the house or important guests got the chairs. And beautiful chairs they were, symbols of authority, carved of oak and fitted with cushions. Women and children were relegated to sorry little stools bereft of ornament and low enough that a lady's hems ended up in a damp heap on the floor.

title: A Sideshow Breaks Out As Fighters Weigh In
description: Only in boxing could the following occur: an altercation breaks out at a weigh-in between a manager and a trainer that leads to a melee. Bizarre accusations are tossed around like dough at a pizza shop. At the brawl's conclusion, one boxer complains that he could not help break up the scrap because he was wearing high heels.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Sentencing For Teenage Killer
description: A woman who was 13 when she killed a livery-cab driver in Harlem in 1997 has been sentenced to nine years to life in prison after being found guilty of murder. Prosecutors in the Manhattan district attorney's office said that the woman, Marta Nelson Cassiano, now 19, was trying to rob Elhadji Gaye, 33, a Senegalese immigrant, and shot him as he tried to flee. Ms. Nelson told the police at the time that she was 17, but because she was actually 13, she was tried and sentenced as a juvenile. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: City to Open Centers for Disruptive Students
description: The head of school safety for the city's Department of Education said yesterday that officials would soon open 17 New Beginnings centers for students with the most serious behavior problems, as part of an intensifying effort to reduce violence in the city's toughest high schools.

title: 3-Bedroom Converted Barn; Ephrata, Penn.; $279,900
description: WHERE Ephrata, Penn.

title: When Kung-Fu Overcomes Chest-Beating Hip-Hop
description: One of the only graceful moments in ''Cradle 2 the Grave,'' a movie that has the flailing momentum of a defective action toy run amok, comes when the camera pulls back to observe Jet Li leaping from a building and dropping from ledge to ledge in a superhuman exhibition of acrobatic nerve. The scene doesn't last long, but it brings to mind the movie its director Andrzej Bartkowiak might have made had he relaxed his camera and reprogrammed his editorial shredding machine to allow a few more touches of balletic poise.

title: Canadian and Dutch Officials Warn of Security's Side Effects
description: Privacy officials from Canada and the Netherlands complained today that the American campaign to crack down on terrorism was needlessly infringing on the privacy of their citizens.

title: Into Sinister Webs Of a Jumbled Mind
description: David Cronenberg's grim little psychodrama ''Spider'' is a cinematic maze whose dark, cramped passages spiral toward a terrifying cul de sac. Brilliantly realized but bone-chillingly bleak, the film, adapted from the 1990 novel by Patrick McGrath, tunnels into the warped imagination of Dennis Cleg (Ralph Fiennes), a k a Spider, a mumbling paranoid-schizophrenic man in his 30's discharged from a mental hospital after two decades of confinement.

title: Corrections
description: An essay in Science Times on Tuesday about the discovery of DNA's structure misidentified an enzyme in meat tenderizer that can be used to extract DNA. It is papain. (Monosodium glutamate is a salt of an amino acid.)

title: GEORGIA-PACIFIC UNIT WITHDRAWS PLAN TO ISSUE STOCK
description: Georgia-Pacific's CP&P unit, the maker of Brawny paper towels and Dixie cups, withdrew its filing for a $1 billion stock offering and a bond swap that were part of a plan to split Georgia-Pacific in two. CP&P filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to withdraw its registration for the initial public offering and bond exchange, because of ''changed circumstances'' since submitting the statements in June. Georgia-Pacific, burdened by asbestos lawsuits and mounting debt, said on Sept. 12 that it would delay the separation of its consumer products and building materials units indefinitely.

title: Ralph Steadman -- 'Who? Me!! No!!! Why Not?'
description: Gallery at 49

title: Thousands of Egyptians Fill Cairo Stadium for a Protest Against a U.S. War in Iraq
description: Tens of thousands of Egyptians gathered today in this city's main stadium for the largest protest so far in the Arab world, outside Iraq, against an American-led war to topple Saddam Hussein.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BAUMAN, LIONEL R.
description: BAUMAN-Lionel R. Beloved partner, friend and colleague. Died on February 27, 1987. Sorely missed by all. Eugene M. Grant & Co. LLC

title: Bush Urges New Security Agency to Adopt New Thinking
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  A day before their new agency begins its work in earnest, President Bush called upon employees of the Department of Homeland Security to protect America's borders against a new kind of enemy.

title: Report by Comcast Is Upbeat, Buoying Cable TV Industry
description: In its first financial report since it acquired AT&T's cable business, the Comcast Corporation said yesterday that it posted strong growth in fourth-quarter revenue and cash flow. It also announced a solid 2003 forecast based on good subscriber numbers and lower-than-expected capital spending.

title: 'Perdition,' With Its Ghosts
description: Among the early front-runners for major Oscar nominations, Sam Mendes's "Road to Perdition" was passed in the home stretch by the likes of "The Pianist" and "Gangs of New York." In 1999 Mr. Mendes's first feature film, "American Beauty," won in the best film, director and actor categories, but this time the only "Perdition" contender for the so-called big six Oscars is Paul Newman as best supporting actor for his portayal of the mob boss John Rooney.

description: 92nd Street Y

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASS, MICHAEL
description: KASS-Michael. The members, Board of Governors, and staff of Pine Hollow Country Club mourn the passing of our long time member and good friend. We extend our sympathies to his wife, Alaine, and the entire family. The Board of Governors Pine Hollow Country Club

title: Iranian Cyclist Detained at Border Wins Political Asylum
description: An Iranian man who cycled 46,000 miles around the world for six years on a personal peace mission only to be arrested in the Arizona desert for entering the United States illegally was granted political asylum yesterday by an immigration judge.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Big Fat Market For Gamblers

title: Shopping List | Hot Dogs
description: DOGS are more than our best friends. They're the ultimate travel companions (they won't fight you for the arm rest on the plane), and in today's age of handbag waiting lists, when trend-seeking label lovers are out to get the next big thing, there are certain breeds that convey the kind of status that the Birkin bag represents. (You have that dog! Where did you get it? And how?) Finding the hottest four-legged creatures in town may require a bit of travel. KAREN ROBINOVITZ

title: Not Solely Blueprints, But Cultural Insight, Too
description: Daniel Libeskind's study in urban fragmentation is not, perhaps, the vision that the public was looking for at ground zero when it rejected the six plans originally presented by the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation in July. The development corporation's land-use committee favored the other finalist's design chosen from a study project conducted last year. But our elected officials have spoken. The losing plan, for towers of steel lattice, prepared by the Think team, will enter the golden archive of the city that never was.

title: The Lullaby of Broadway
description: A fight is brewing on Broadway, and it should be a lulu. On Sunday, the contract between Broadway theatrical producers and musicians will expire. The musicians union is threatening to strike; producers are threatening to use synthesized music. The stated impasse is the number of live musicians producers are required to hire. But the real issue is the advance and threat of new technology.

title: Leadership Calls
description: The House majority leader, Tom DeLay, is so gifted at the political art of fund-raising that he has been dubbed DeLay Inc. for the many political action committees he fattens, the better to protect his party majority. Lately his recorded voice has been brandished intrusively by fund-raising telemarketers who identify themselves as his aides and announce to businessmen, physicians, dentists -- any solvent American on a promising telephone list, it seems -- that they have been selected for a special award as a businessman of the year, physician of the year, a standout amid life's routine.

title: People
description: * C. Clift Jones was named to the new post of president at Modernista, Boston, assuming some duties that had been handled by Lance Jensen, who was named chief executive. Mr. Jensen succeeds Gary Koepke, who continues as chairman. Mr. Jones had been a consultant and before that worked at agencies including Bozell and Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, units of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Cheap Chic: The Joys of Low Stock Prices
description: IN this bear market, low share prices have become more than a reality. Now some people think they are stylish.

title: Out of Office, McCall Joins Investment Firm
description: Almost four months after his failed bid for governor, H. Carl McCall, the former state comptroller, announced today that he had joined a recently formed Park Avenue equity firm that invests in the development and manufacturing of orthopedic devices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROZMAN, SOL
description: ROZMAN-Sol. Age 93. Philanthropist, philatelist, Judaica collector, member Collectors Club, member Manhattan Beach Jewish Center, founder of the Great Synagogue in Jerusalem, founder Sunrise Jewish Center, Sunrise, FL, member Lubavitch, supporter Yeshiva Ohel Moshe. Loving father of Rita Birnbaum (Stanley) and Beverly S. Goldfarb (Dr. Herbert). Grandfather of Jill Perlstein, Barry Birnbaum, Judy Pearlman, Laurence J. Goldfarb, Dr. Lisa M. Goldfarb, Scott N. Goldfarb, and 11 loving great grandchildren. We love and miss our Pop-pop. Funeral service Kehila Chapel, 60 Brighton 11 St., Brooklyn, NY, 10 AM Friday. 718-332-3311.

title: Mister Rogers, TV's Friend For Children, Is Dead at 74
description: Fred Rogers, the thoughtful television neighbor whose songs, stories and heart-to-heart talks taught generations of children how to get along in the world, died yesterday at his home in Pittsburgh. He was 74.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: 50 Executives Resign From Hynix
description: About 50 executives of Hynix Semiconductor handed in their resignations yesterday. The mass resignation followed a meeting of shareholders earlier this week in which the creditors who hold a majority of the stock approved a 21-to-1 write-down in the value of the company's shares. Park Sang Ho resigned earlier as co-president while the fate of the other co-president, Woo Eui Jei, was not clear. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Goldman Makes More Cuts In Its Research Department
description: Goldman Sachs announced yesterday that it was paring its research staff, a sign that investment banks are taking further aim at stock research departments they regard as bloated.

title: New York Seeks Federal Help In Paying State Jobless Claims
description: New York State wants to borrow an additional $860 million from the federal government to finance unemployment benefits for jobless workers, bringing its total loan to more than $1.6 billion, the New York State Department of Labor announced yesterday.

title: Ending Its Mega-Run, 'Les Miz' Comes Full Circle
description: TERRENCE MANN was the first Inspector Javert in the Broadway production of ''Les Misrables.'' Now, 16 years later, he has come back to be the last.

title: Ad Agency Chairman Is Pleased to Avoid Labels
description: THIS is the misunderstood world of Claude Grunitzky, the chairman of an advertising agency who often throws people off balance when they find out that he is Claude Grunitzky. We'll get to the name later. (O.K. All right. He's from Togo, where his family name, dating from a 19th-century German-Polish settler, is prominent. His father was an ambassador to the United States, his granduncle the second president of Togo, in West Africa.)

title: Chief Demoted In Shake-Up At Interpublic, The Ad Giant
description: In three startling boardroom shifts, the directors of the Interpublic Group of Companies in New York voted yesterday to demote the chairman and chief executive of the troubled agency company, replace him with another top manager and dismiss the leader of its largest and most problem-plagued division.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGERS, FRED MCFEELY
description: ROGERS-Fred McFeely. On behalf of the Board of Trustees, Staff and Volunteers of Thirteen/WNET New York, we express our deepest sympathies to the family, friends and co-workers of Fred McFeely Rogers. In a world that is so often loud, violent and sensational, Mr. Rogers was a comforting friend, committed to sharing his peace, love and simple wisdom with America's children. Mr. Rogers was the embodiment of public television's mission, and a hero to all who care about the welfare of our young ones. Parents and children alike will dearly miss his gentle prescence. Steven Rattner, Chairman Dr. William F. Baker, Pres.

title: Lucent Reaches Accord With S.E.C. to End Inquiry
description: Lucent Technologies, the nation's largest maker of telecommunications equipment, said yesterday that it had reached a preliminary agreement with the Securities and Exchange Commission to end an investigation of its accounting practices.

title: No Relief in Sight
description: So Glenn Hubbard has resigned as chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers -- to spend more time with his family, of course. (Pay no attention to the knife handles protruding from his back.) Gregory Mankiw, his successor, is a very good economist, but never mind: When the political apparatchiks who make all decisions in this administration want Mr. Mankiw's opinion, they'll tell Mr. Mankiw what it is.

title: 5 Are Hurt and 75 Left Homeless After Gas Explosion in Perth Amboy
description: A car crashed into an exposed natural gas pipe here early today, rupturing the pipe and prompting a frantic evacuation of nearby houses and apartments that was completed only moments before a thunderous explosion. Five people were injured, a three-story brick apartment building was demolished and about 75 people were left homeless.

title: New Zealand Mast Shatters As Alinghi Takes 4-0 Lead
description: The meltdown of Team New Zealand, the America's Cup defender, continued today when, on the third leg of Race 4 against the Swiss boat Alinghi, the Kiwis' mast exploded into a heap of carbon fiber shards.

title: The Classicists of Contemporary Design
description: THE search for intelligent life in architecture is artfully rewarded at the Whitney Museum's retrospective of the work of Elizabeth Diller and Ricardo Scofidio, New York's brainiest architectural team. But intelligent visitors will have to pick their way through a few unwelcome booby traps: curatorial winks and nods designed to dumb things down for the chimerical unsophisticates to whom far too many museum shows today are needlessly pitched.

title: Invoking Peace to Justify War
description: To the Editor:

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Archdiocese Raises Record Amount
description: The Archdiocese of Chicago has raised $220 million in three years in the largest campaign by the church in the United States, with $10 million to $15 million more expected by June. The 374 parishes in the archdiocese will keep 80 percent of the money they raised, using it for maintenance and art projects, and the rest will be controlled by the central administration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIBBONS, WILLIAM J. (BILL)
description: GIBBONS-William J. (Bill). Originally from Cold Spring Harbor, NY and Beverly Hills, CA. Passed away at his Palm Springs, CA residence on February 23, 2003. He is survived by his children Laura Burns, Sally Livingston, and Philip Gibbons, and his four grandchildren. He is also survived by his sisters Mary Hemberger, Kay Raleigh, Nancy Moser, Christine Burchik, and his brother Jack, along with many nieces and nephews who loved him for his charm and sense of humor. Bill graduated from CCNY and St. John's Law School. He served his country in the Korean War as an officer in the 7th Cavalry Infantry of the U.S. Army. He was a prominent labor lawyer who held executive positions with numerous major corporations which included Colt Industries, Max Factor, Pan American World Airways and W.R. Grace. He also served as the chief labor attorney for the state of Alaska and practiced labor law in Oregon and Washington. He was an ardent supporter of the struggle for human rights in the North of Ireland and made many trips there to show his support for the Good Friday Peace Accord and for the suffering people. Mr. Gibbons will be buried on March 3rd at the Riverside Military Cemetery, Riverside, CA. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Irish Northern Aid Committee, 363 Seventh Avenue, NY, NY 10001.

title: Love Affair With Baseball And a Lot of Big Ideas
description: Looking for a natural high in the down, down days of late winter? Well, it is said that eating chocolate can simulate the heady sensations aroused by the first phases of being in love. But if you're allergic to the stuff or on a diet, you may want to consider an unlikely but potent alternative that goes by the name of Denis O'Hare.

title: Fight Is Likely in Senate as Bush Sends Tax Cut Plan to Congress
description: President Bush's tax cut plan moved from speechmaking to legislation today when it was introduced in both houses of Congress, setting off what may be the most tumultuous debate of the Congressional session.

title: Independent Panel Named To Review U.S.O.C.'s Crisis
description: An independent review of the chaos within the United States Olympic Committee will be led by Donald M. Fehr and Roberta Cooper Ramo, members of a commission that determined in 1999 that the Salt Lake City bribery scandal epitomized the Olympic movement's ''culture of improper gift-giving.''

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: With a glut of bistros and brasseries in the city, the temptation to fiddle with the formula is almost overpowering. Moutarde resists it. This attractive by-the-book bistro, with yellow walls and a shiny zinc bar, serves a crme caramel labeled ''traditional,'' a splendid, totally authentic tarte Tatin ''faon grandmre'' (grandmother's style) and a molten chocolate cake ''ancienne.'' The ceramic doodads on display could be a hundred years old. The typeface on the menu would have been familar to Zola.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about a plan by the IDT Corporation to try to buy the Global Crossing telecommunications company out of bankruptcy misstated the outcome of an IDT attempt to acquire the assets of another company, Teligent, in 2001. That deal was rejected by Teligent's creditors; the company remains independent.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Next Time, We'd Like A Room With a Chair

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: BELLEVILLE: EMINEM LOOK-ALIKE ACCUSED OF ROBBERY A man whose resemblance to the rap performer Eminem helped identify him was arrested yesterday and accused of robbing 12 banks since October. A police lieutenant saw the suspect, Michael R. Hasuga, 44, leave a Belleville bank shortly after a robbery was reported, said Special Agent William Evanina of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The officer saw Mr. Hasuga replace a dark wool hat, which witnesses cited in other robberies, with a baseball cap, he said. Federal charges of bank robbery are expected to be filed against Mr. Hasuga, he said. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Denial Of Class Action Status
description: A federal judge in Miami denied class action status to plaintiffs who say they were injured by chromated copper arsenate, a wood preservative. The substance, which prevents decay and repels termites, contains arsenic, and it is being phased out. Judge Donald M. Middlebrooks did not decide if the chemical poses a health risk or has caused property damage. He ruled that the case could not be a class action because the plaintiffs had too little in common. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANCHBERY, JOHN
description: LANCHBERY-John. American Ballet Theatre mourns the passing of its former music director and colleague, John Lanchbery. A world-renowned conductor and arranger of music for ballets and film, Jack most notably arranged the Minkus score for ABT's La Bayadere in 1980. His career highlights included the musical arrangement for the film The Turning Point and the ballets The Merry Widow and La Fille mal gardee. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family and friends.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: MAYOR VETOES SCHOOL-REPORT BILL Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg vetoed a bill yesterday that would give the City Council frequent progress reports on all school construction projects. In his veto message, Mr. Bloomberg said the bill would have created an unnecessary administrative burden. Eva S. Moskowitz, chairwoman of the Council's education committee, said the Council would hold an override vote. The legislation would have required the Department of Education to submit quarterly reports to the Council, updating the status and anticipated cost of all its capital projects. Council members have called for stricter oversight of capital planning and spending since August 2001, when education officials disclosed a shortfall of nearly $3 billion in the $7 billion, five-year school construction budget.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: NORTHERN IRELAND: PEACE EFFORT SLOGS ON Prime Minister Bertie Ahern of Ireland met with Prime Minister Tony Blair at 10 Downing Street in London to prepare for talks in Belfast on Monday on the stagnated Northern Ireland peace effort. The province's five-year-old home-rule government was suspended in October because of disagreement between Roman Catholic and Protestant political parties on issues like the disarmament of paramilitaries and the reform of the police force. "We can't sit around forever," Mr. Ahern said, calling Monday an important day. "I really think it is time to come to an agreement." He announced a $3.2 million compensation fund for people in the Irish Republic affected by violence during the 30-year conflict. Brian Lavery (NYT)

Then she would grab a cab and head to the airport for the shuttle, where said packages were duly X-rayed, prompting, in those laxer times, some pretty rich gazes from airport security.

title: 36 Hours | Key West, Fla.
description: HOSPITALITY is the way of life in Key West. The generous reception of guests dates back to the 1820's when ship salvagers and Cuban cigarmakers settled on the island. In more recent times, Key West has been both a sanctuary for aging hippies in Margaritaville and a popular destination on the gay circuit. The island, which has a full-time population of 28,000, offers a combination of the highbrow (the Old Town historic district with its Victorian architecture) and the low (a lot of shops selling T-shirts with rude sayings). An artistic tradition reaching from Ernest Hemingway to Jimmy Buffett has been packaged for tourists. Yet somehow the mix works. Key West is fun, with activities, bars and inns that cater to nearly every taste and orientation. After all, everyone still travels here for the same things: to bask in the sun, feast on fresh fish and guzzle their cocktails of choice. GEORGE GENE GUSTINES

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Names Campaign Finance Chief

The board distributes public matching funds to candidates who qualify, publishes voter guides to each election, and oversees a candidate debate program. Mr. Schwarz is a lawyer who was the city's corporation counsel during the Koch administration and chairman of the 1989 charter commission that reshaped city government. A great-grandson of the founder of the Fifth Avenue toy store F. A. O. Schwarz, he will succeed the Rev. Joseph A. O'Hare, who was the first chairman of the finance board. Michael Cooper (NYT)

The Board of Directors and membership of The American Ireland Fund mourn the death of our dear friend, Felice Lippert, who, with her late husband Al, was a central member of the AIF Family. Her wit, charm and potent persuasiveness, matched only by her total commitment to her special charities, saw fulfillment in the establishment of the ''Al and Felice Lippert Chair of Jewish Studies'' at Trinity College, Dublin. Felice will be greatly missed and lovingly remembered by her many friends in the AIF who join with us in extending their sincere condolences to her sons and their families.

title: For Nedved, Scoring in the N.H.L. Could Use a Boost
description: Petr Nedved's late goal at Continental Arena on Tuesday night not only enabled the Rangers to tie the Devils, 3-3, but it also gave him 22 goals for the season, one more than he scored all of last season.

title: Art Listings
description: Aselective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums, children under 12 and museum members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: Indian Point Nuclear Plant
description: The City Council has scheduled a public hearing on the possible consequences of ''a radiological release from the Indian Point Nuclear Facility on New York City and its water supply.'' Council Chambers, City Hall, Manhattan, 10 a.m. Information: (718) 217-4969.

title: MRS. FIELDS AND HERSHEY SETTLE CONSUMER PRIVACY CASES
description: Mrs. Fields' Original Cookies agreed to pay $100,000 and Hershey Foods will pay $85,000 to settle Federal Trade Commission claims that the companies failed to seek parental permission before gathering personal information from children online. The F.T.C. said the penalties were the largest since the agency began enforcing the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act in 2000. The law requires companies to seek verifiable parental permission before they get names, ages and e-mail addresses of children younger than 13. Mrs. Fields' Original Cookies is owned by Mrs. Fields' Holding.
